Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Pasadena, Texas" and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as the "Pasadena Code." 
(Code 1964, § 1-1) 
Charter reference— Codification of ordinances, Art. II, § 16. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt Code of Ordinances, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1176a.  
Sec. 1-2. - Catchlines of sections. 
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1964, § 1-2)  
Sec. 1-3. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council, the following rules and definitions shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council: 
Generally. Words shall be construed in their common and usual significance unless the contrary is clearly indicated. 
City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Pasadena, in the County of Harris and State of Texas. 
City secretary, chief of police or other city officers. The words "city secretary," "chief of police" or other references to an officer or department shall be construed to mean the city secretary, chief of police or such other municipal officer or department, respectively, of the City of Pasadena, Texas. References to any city officer shall include his duly authorized assistants, deputies, agents and representatives, unless the context indicates to the contrary. 
Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted. 
Council. The term "council," or "city council" shall mean the City Council of the City of Pasadena. 
Councilman. The term "councilman" shall mean a member of the city council. 
County. The term "county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Harris, Texas. 
Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, associations and corporations, as well as to males. 
Highway. The term "highway" shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or part of such building or land. 
Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
Roadway. The word "roadway" shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
Signature or subscription. The words "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Texas. 
Street. The term "street" shall include any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
Written or in writing. The words "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1964, § 1-3) 
State Law reference— Similar definitions of state law, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. arts. 10, 23.  
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances, as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number, subsection number, or part thereof, of this Code to be amended. In the event two (2) or more sections, or parts of either, within one chapter of the Code are amended, reference to the chapter number shall be sufficient. The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, it may be expressly stated that such section is an addition to this Code and may specify the chapter to which the same shall belong; provided, however, additions to the Code may be made by an ordinance purporting to amend the Code, where repealing or altering thereof is otherwise made, and the intent that such addition shall be to the Code is clear therefrom. The new matter shall be set out in full as desired. 
(Code 1964, § 1-4; Ord. No. 1774, § 1, 2-15-66)  
Sec. 1-5. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(2)  Any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of taxes or for an annual budget; 
(3)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city or discontinuing territory as a part of the city; 
(4)  Any ordinance approving, prescribing or otherwise relating to rates to be charged by utility companies; 
(5)  Any ordinance granting any right or franchise; 
(6)  Any ordinance relating to local improvements and assessments therefor; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.  
Sec. 1-6. - Code does not affect prior offenses, contracts, etc. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code.  
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. 
Whenever any city ordinance which governs fire safety, zoning, or public health and sanitation, including dumping of refuse, is violated, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, such violation, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine or penalty not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00); all other violations of this Code or of any ordinance of the city in which an act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, other than fire safety, zoning, or public health and sanitation, including dumping of refuse, such violation, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00); provided, however, that no penalty shall be greater or less that the penalty provided for the same offense under the laws of the state. Each and every day any violation of this Code or any ordinance shall continue constitutes a separate offense. 
(Code 1964, § 1-5; Ord, No. 83-352, § 1, 11-22-83; Ord. No. 86-100, § 1, 5-27-86; Ord. No. 90-62, § 1, 4-3-90) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to prescribe penalties for violation of Code of Ordinances, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1176a, § 1.  
Sec. 1-8. - Cumulative remedies. 
Any remedy prescribed by this Code shall be merely cumulative and shall not preclude resort to any other remedy provided by law.  
Sec. 1-9. - Severability of parts of Code. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1964, § 1-6)  
Sec. 1-10. - Emergency action. 
Every officer, agent or employee of the city, while responding to emergency situations, is hereby authorized to act in such a manner as to most effectively deal with the emergency. This provision shall prevail over every other ordinance of the city and, to the extent to which the city has the authority to so authorize, over any other law establishing a standard of care in conflict with this section. Neither the city nor the employee shall be liable for any failure to use ordinary care in such emergency. 
(Ord. No. 85-235, § 1, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 1-11. - Fee for negotiable instrument. 
A charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be assessed and collected by the city for the processing of a negotiable instrument given to the City of Pasadena in full or in part payment of any debt for which payment is refused upon presentation by the drawee for any reason, per refusal. Thereafter, the city may, at its option, require that such payment be made by cash, money order, or cashier's check. 
(Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 04-156, § 1, 7-27-04)  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Disposition of money and property seized under "Controlled Substances Act," § 20-9.2; traffic and transportation commission, § 36-206 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Corporate seal—Adopted; use generally. 
(a)  A corporate seal for the city is hereby adopted, the design of which shall be as follows: 
 
(b)  The corporate seal adopted by this section shall be affixed to all papers, documents and instruments officially executed as the act of the city, and as otherwise required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1691, § 1, 8-24-65; Ord. No. 98-165, § 1, 10-20-98) 
Charter reference— Authority of city to use corporate seal, Art. I, § 2.  
Sec. 2-2. - Same—Custodian. 
The city secretary is hereby exclusively entrusted with the duty and responsibility of custody, use and maintenance of the corporate seal of the city; provided, however, subject to his direct supervision and control, duly constituted agents for, assistants to, and deputies of the city secretary may have custody and use and effect maintenance of true copies or facsimiles of such corporate seal, all of which, duly and lawfully used, shall have the same legal effect. 
(Ord. No. 1691, § 2, 8-24-65)  
Sec. 2-3. - Same—Reproduction on documents, letterheads, etc. 
The design of the corporate seal of the city may, by written order of the mayor or by motion of the city council duly recorded in the minutes thereof, be imprinted or otherwise reproduced on such papers, documents, stones, woods, metals or other materials as so designated. The design of such corporate seal shall appear on all department, division and agency letterheads of the city. The designs referred to in this section may be of varying diameters, depths and other dimensions. 
(Ord. No. 1691, § 3, 8-24-65)  
Sec. 2-4. - Use of facsimile signature of mayor, city controller and building official. 
(a)  The mayor and the city controller are hereby authorized to sign all checks, vouchers, and warrants for the withdrawal of money from the city depository, which are required to be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city controller, by stamping or imprinting their respective names thereon, or causing the same to be done, by use of machine imprinted facsimile signatures. 
(b)  The building official and his duly authorized representative are hereby authorized to sign any and all occupational or trade licenses issuable by the building official by stamping or imprinting his or their names thereon or causing the same to be done, by use of machine imprinted facsimile signatures. 
(Code 1964, § 2-1; Ord. No. 1692, § 1, 7-27-65; Ord. No. 1769, § 1, 2-22-66) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to enact ordinance similar to subsection (a) above, Art. IX, § 6(o).  
Sec. 2-5. - Bonds for city officers and employees. 
(a)  The director of purchasing, the director of public works, the building official, all clerks employed in the water division of the department of public works, all clerks of the municipal court, the director of parks and recreation, pool managers and assistant pool managers of the parks department and all other city employees who handle city funds shall be covered by a blanket bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for each of such employees, payable to the city, conditioned upon the faithful performance of their duties and upon any other condition as may be required by the city council. 
(b)  The city controller shall give bond in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) payable to the city as provided for in subsection (a) above. 
(c)  The tax assessor and collector shall be covered by a bond in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) payable to the city as provided in subsection (a) above. 
(d)  The bonds required by the provisions of this section shall be executed by a solvent commercial surety company authorized to do business in Texas and acceptable to the city council, and the premiums thereon shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-2; Ord. No. 68-75, § 1, 5-21-68; Ord. No. 68-185, § 1, 11-5-68) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to require official bonds, Art. VI, § 4; bond for city controller, Art. IX, § 1.  
Sec. 2-6. - Authority of mayor to pay certain damage claims. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to pay claims against the city, notice of which has been filed pursuant to Article XII, section 7, of the Charter, in amounts not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), upon the written recommendation of the city attorney, based upon a complete investigation of the claim. 
(Ord. No. 70-172, § 1, 8-25-70; Ord. No. 75-92, § 1, 6-3-75)  
Sec. 2-7. - Fixed or capital assets inventory procedure. 
(a)  The mayor shall be responsible for the fixed or capital assets of the city. The mayor may assign such assets or any of them to the various departments of the city as acquired or needed and may authorize the transfer of such property from time to time and from department to department as deemed necessary for the continuance and proper operation of the city's business. 
(b)  To the extent possible, such assets shall be assigned to a particular department of the city, which shall safeguard such assets. 
(c)  The compilation shall be kept current by the addition to the inventory of any item of property purchased of a permanent nature or property purchased with an expectation of its existence for an indefinite period. 
(d)  Assets in inventory shall be numbered and tagged, where practical. 
(e)  Items appearing on the fixed or capital assets inventory that have outlived their usefulness to the city shall be disposed of or sold as provided by ordinance and deleted from the inventory. 
(f)  All compilations of fixed or capital assets inventory shall be transmitted to the city controller and updated by personnel in the finance department. 
(Ord. No. 83-250, § 1, 9-20-83)  
Sec. 2-8. - Data processing or programming. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance relating to data processing or programming or creating any office or agency for the city for the purpose of data processing or programming and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Sec. 2-9. - Development board. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect Ordinance No. 1749, adopted January 11, 1966, relating to the City of Pasadena Development Board, and such ordinance is hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Sec. 2-10. - Sale of city land generally. 
(a)  Any land owned by the city, other than land provided for in sections 2-11, 2-12, and 2-13 determined not to be needed for city purposes, shall be advertised and may be sold to the highest bidder upon authorization of the city council, based upon the appraised fair market value of such land. The selling price for such land shall never be for less than the market value fixed by city council, which determination as to such market value will be final. 
(b)  When such land is advertised for sale upon authorization of the city council, any bidder may bid on the basis of all or part of the consideration for such land being the bidder's conveyance to the city of good, clear and merchantable title to land which the city council, prior to the advertisement for bids, has determined is needed by the city for public purposes. 
(Ord. No. 80-266, § 2, 11-18-80)  
Sec. 2-11. - Abandonment of streets and alleys. 
Streets or alleys, whether owned in fee or used by easement, may be sold to the abutting owner or owners, in proportion to the underlying fee ownership as exists, or would exist if by easement. When ownership is of the underlying fee, the apportionment shall be determined by city council, which determination will be final. Upon the payment of: 
(1)  A fee according to chapter 28, article IV, section 28-46, and 
(2)  The appraised market value of the street or alley, based on not less than one appraisal, or 
(3)  The actual costs to the city based upon a "per square foot" proration of the city's cost plus the cost of any city improvements subsequently made that pertain to the property covered by the street or alley; 
whichever is greater; and, after abandonment of the street or alley, the city will deliver a quitclaim deed to the owners of the fee simple title thereto or abutting owners. The market value of any street or alley shall be fixed by city council, which determination as to such market value will be final. 
(Ord. No. 80-266, § 2, 11-18-80; Ord. No. 18-102, § 1, 8-21-18)  
Sec. 2-12. - Abandonment of easement. 
Upon the payment of: 
(1)  A fee according to chapter 28, article IV, section 28-46, and 
(2)  The appraised market value of the easement, based on not less than one appraisal, or 
(3)  The actual costs to the city based upon a "per square foot" proration of the city's costs plus the cost of any city improvements subsequently made that pertain to the property covered by the easement; 
whichever is greater; and, after abandonment of the easement, the city will deliver a quitclaim deed to the owners of the fee simple title thereto. The market value of any easement shall be fixed by city council, which determination as to such market value will be final. 
(Ord. No. 80-266, § 2, 11-18-80; Ord. No. 18-102, § 1, 8-21-18)  
Sec. 2-13. - Narrow strips of land. 
Fee-owned narrow strips of land, or land so shaped as to be incapable of being used independently, may be sold to the abutting owner or owners, in proportion to the abutting ownership. Apportionment will generally be based on: 
(1)  The projection of existing abutting property lines over such narrow strip, or 
(2)  Street frontage, if any, or 
(3)  Access to the property. 
Said apportionment to be determined by city council which determination will be final. Payment for such land will be based on the appraised market value of the land, such market value to be fixed by city council, which determination as to such market value will be final. 
(Ord. No. 80-266, § 2, 11-18-80)  
Sec. 2-14. - Conditions to all sales. 
(a)  Nothing in this section, nor in sections 2-10, 2-11, or 2-12 shall require the city council to accept any bid or offer, or be required to consummate any sale of any land or property interest under such sections. 
(b)  Any applicant under sections 2-11 or 2-12 will be required to make a three hundred dollar ($300.00) deposit to be applied toward the purchase price under section 2-11, or 2-12. The deposit of three hundred dollars ($300.00) will be forfeited to the city in the event the abandonment and sale is not completed. 
(c)  The land and those interests described by subsections 2-11 and 2-12 of this article I may not be conveyed, sold, or exchanged for less than the fair market value of the land or interest unless the conveyance, sale, or exchange is with one or more abutting property owners who own the underlying fee simple. 
(Ord. No. 80-266, § 2, 11-18-80; Ord. No. 11-075, § 1, 4-19-11)  
Sec. 2-15. - Sections 2-10 through 2-14 not to be construed as grant of right. 
Sections 2-10 through 2-14 shall never be construed to give any person a vested right to compel the city either to abandon, vacate or dispose of any land or any easement or right therein, or to compel or require that the same be upon any particular or exact term or consideration. 
(Ord. No. 80-266, § 2, 11-18-80)  
Secs. 2-16—2-23. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RULES OF PROCEDURE FOR COUNCIL MEETINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Council meetings, Art. II, § 7 et seq.; council to determine, by ordinance, its own rules and order of business, Art. II, § 8. 
 
Sec. 2-24. - Order of business. 
(1)  Call to order. 
(2)  Roll call of members. 
(3)  Invocation. 
(4)  Pledge of allegiance. 
(5)  Community interest comments in accordance with Chapter 551.0415 of the Government Code; ie. 
• Expression of thanks, congratulations, or condolences; 
• Information regarding holiday schedules; 
• An honorary or salutary recognition of a public official, public employee, or other citizen; 
• A reminder about an upcoming event organized or sponsored by the governing body; 
• Information regarding a social, ceremonial, or community event; and 
• Announcements involving an imminent threat to the public health and safety of people in the political subdivision that has arisen after the posting of the agenda. 
(6)  Citizens wishing to address council. 
(7)  Docketed city council hearings. 
(8)  Presentation of proclamations and awards and community events. 
(9)  Proposals for city business. 
(10)  Presentation of minutes. 
(11)  Presentation of minutes of special meetings. 
(12)  Contract change orders. 
(13)  Progress payments. 
(14)  Finance resolutions/miscellaneous claims and invoices. 
(15)  Personnel changes. 
a.  Regular employees. 
b.  Finance department employees. 
c.  Administration changes in personnel. 
d.  Introduction of new city employees. 
(16)  Mayoral appointments. 
(17)  City boards and commissions. Reports. 
(18)  Reports of committees. 
(19)  Mayor's report. 
a.  Ordinances. 
1.  Final readings. 
2.  First readings. 
3.  Emergency readings. 
4.  Issuance of obligations. 
b.  Resolutions. 
(20)  Other business. 
(21)  Executive session. 
(22)  Adjournment by the presiding officer. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 12-6-66; Ord. No. 67-1922, § 1, 3-21-67; Ord. No. 2016, § 1, 9-12-67; Ord. No. 96-93, § 1, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 97-207, § 1, 11-12-97; Ord. No. 99-7, § 1, 1-19-99; Ord. No. 01-111, § 1, 7-17-01; Ord. No. 02-179, § 1, 8-6-02; Ord. No. 14-020, § 1(Exh. A), 2-18-14)  
Sec. 2-25. - Agenda. 
For every regular meeting of the city council, an agenda, pursuant to the order of business prescribed in section 2-24, shall be prepared by the city secretary under the direction and control of the mayor; provided, however, the nonavailability to council members of an agenda prior to any regular meeting shall in no way invalidate or impair the force and effect of any mayor or council action at such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 12-6-66)  
Sec. 2-26. - Qualified adoption of Robert's Rules of Order. 
(a)  Robert's Rules of Order Revised, a current edition, except where otherwise provided by the City Charter, the laws of the State of Texas, this article, or other ordinance of the city, shall be the rules of order of the city council; provided, however, that failure of the council to observe or act in accord with any applicable rule of order prescribed therein shall in no way operate or work to invalidate, modify or diminish any otherwise lawful action or vote of the council. 
(b)  The following rules will specifically apply to city councilmembers: 
• A member must obtain the floor and be recognized by the presiding officer before beginning to speak. 
• Each member may speak for no more than two (2) minutes on an issue under consideration except that time extensions may be granted by the presiding officer when important to clarify the matter. 
• Debate must be germane (relevant) to the motion. 
• Speakers must address all remarks to the chair; cross talk between members is not allowed. 
• Speakers must be courteous and never attack other members or question the motives of the members. In controversial issues, the discussion must focus on ideas, not personalities. Members must not use inflammatory statements directed at other members of council or any other person. 
(Ord. No. 1884, § 1, 12-6-66; Ord. No. 96-93, § 2, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 14-020, § 2, 2-18-14)  
Sec. 2-27. - Rules of conduct for any person attending meetings of city council or other public meetings held under the auspices of the city government. 
(1)  Any person may address the council regarding any city related matter or agenda item that is relevant to any subject matter of city affairs or business which is within the scope of the authority and legislative functions of the city council. The mayor or any council member shall have the privilege of raising a point of order as to whether the subject matter to be heard and considered as presented by a citizen is germane and relevant to city affairs or business to be considered by council. A speaker may be ruled out of order and denied the opportunity to address council if he or she violates the rule of relevance. 
(2)  Any person wishing to address the council shall first sign the register provided by the city secretary and note the item about which they wish to speak. When the person's name is called they shall have three (3) minutes to address council. 
(3)  In the event a group of people desire to speak on a common issue it is suggested that a spokesperson be chosen for each group. In the event more than one person does speak on each side of an issue a maximum time limit of two (2) minutes per person is allowed. 
(4)  All remarks shall be addressed to council as a whole and no question shall be asked of council or the city staff except through the mayor. 
(5)  No person shall applaud, boo, clap, or otherwise audibly express approval or disapproval of an action being taken that would disturb the meeting. This shall not be interpreted so as to prevent positive public recognition initiated by the mayor or city council. Any person in violation will be removed by security personnel. 
(6)  No person making an appearance before the council shall have in his or her possession at the podium any paper bag, plastic bag, handbag, briefcase, purse, satchel, box, envelope, tape recorder or other container of any sort. 
(7)  Loud, profane, abusive and/or disruptive language is inappropriate and will not be permitted. 
(8)  No person shall brandish, wave or display or cause to be brandished, waved or displayed any sign, placard, poster or banner during a meeting in such a manner as to impede the use of the aisles; interfere with the use of the seating area; or obstruct the view of another or in any other manner disturb or interfere with the orderly conduct of the meeting at any time during which the city council is conducting a meeting. 
(9)  No person shall brandish, wave or display or cause to be brandished any sign, placard, poster or banner or to make statements concerning political campaigns either for or against a political candidate. 
(10)  In order to speak, one must be recognized by the presiding officer and must step to the podium stating his or her name and address. 
(11)  Speakers may not defame or disparage any other persons. 
(12)  No person shall make personal, impertinent, or derogatory remarks or become boisterous during a council meeting. 
(13)  No person in the meeting will be allowed to delay, interrupt, or disrupt the proceedings or refuse to obey the orders of the presiding officer. 
(14)  Any person in violation of these rules who, after having been advised by the presiding officer of his or her noncompliance, continues to violate the rules shall, at the direction of the presiding officer, be ejected from the meeting. The operation of this provision shall not be construed to preclude any person from prosecution for violation of any applicable criminal law. 
(15)  Any speaker who is found in repeated violation (more than once) of the rules may be denied the opportunity for a twelve-month period to appear and address a meeting of the body before which the repeated violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 00-56, § 1, 4-18-00; Ord. No. 08-63, § 1, 3-11-08; Ord. No. 14-019, § 1(Exh. A), 2-18-14)  
Secs. 2-28—2-38. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PERSONNEL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Classification plan for classified service, § 30-27 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-39. - Department established. 
There is hereby created and established the department of personnel of the city, an executive department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1781, § 1, 3-22-66)  
Sec. 2-40. - Office of director established; appointment and term of director. 
There is hereby created and established the office of director of personnel. The director shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed and approved by the city council. The director may serve for a term of one (1) year or until his successor is appointed, confirmed, approved and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 1781, § 1, 3-22-66)  
Sec. 2-41. - General powers and duties of director. 
(a)  The director of personnel shall be the head of the department of personnel and of all officers and employees assigned thereto and their duties shall be performed subject to the supervision of the director. In addition to the specific duties prescribed in this chapter and other ordinances of the city, the director of personnel shall perform such other duties as he may be from time to time assigned by the mayor. 
(b)  The director of personnel shall coordinate with the city's wage and job classification consultant in developing a comprehensive wage and job classification proposal for the city and recommend substantive provisions for standard personnel policies, procedures, rules and regulations and a complete revision of the civil service ordinances and applicable rules and regulations. It shall be the director's responsibility to continuously administer and study the operation of this chapter and recommend, at least annually to the mayor and the city council, such changes therein as he deems proper. 
(Ord. No. 1781, § 1, 3-22-66)  
Sec. 2-42. - Director designated as director of civil service. 
The director of personnel is hereby declared to be the available officer of the city for designation by the civil service commission as director of the firemen's and policemen's civil service commission. 
(Ord. No. 1781, § 1, 3-22-66) 
Cross reference— Civil service for policemen, § 30-27 et seq.  
Sec. 2-43. - Processing of requests and recommendations as to compensation, leaves and other personnel matters. 
All requests or recommendations relating to rates or amounts of compensation, method of compensation, sick leaves, vacations, leaves of absence, recruitment, hiring or employment, transfers, promotions, demotions, reductions in force, suspensions, resignations and terminations, as the foregoing terms are commonly understood, unless otherwise hereinafter expressly defined, of nonclassified, compensated, appointive personnel, except heads of departments and independent offices of the city and members of the firemen's and policemen's civil service of the city, shall be submitted to the director of personnel for initial action and processing. After processing and investigation, the director shall forward the same to the mayor, along with any written requests, recommendations or comments of any department or office head involved, with the director's written recommendation as to action, if any, to be taken thereon. The director shall particularly note in his recommendations the effect, if any of the proposed personnel action relative to the city wage and job classification and all other applicable city personnel rules, regulations, policies, procedures or practices. He shall also obtain, for transmittal to the mayor, a certification of funds from the city controller for any recommended increase in the compensation rate of a presently employed person or for the supplement of additional personnel. The mayor acquires no authority hereunder as to department of finance personnel. 
(Ord. No. 1781, § 1, 3-22-66)  
Sec. 2-44. - Investigation of personnel inquiries and complaints. 
The director of personnel may receive and investigate such inquiries or complaints of nonclassified, compensated, appointive personnel, outside the city civil service, regarding the matters enumerated in section 2-43, as may be submitted to him. 
(Ord. No. 1781, § 1, 3-22-66)  
Sec. 2-45. - General policies. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect Ordinance No. 67-2047 Adopted October 24, 1967, which ordinance prescribes certain personnel policies and procedures, and such ordinance is hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Secs. 2-46, 2-47. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, adopted April 18, 2006, repealed §§ 2-46, 2-47, which pertained to travel policies—generally, reimbursable expenditures and derived from Ord. No. 68-25, Arts. I, II, 2-20-68; Ord. No. 77-208, § 1, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 84-36, § 1, 3-6-84; Ord. No. 86, 170, § 1, 8-5-86.  
Sec. 2-48. - Wages, salaries and other compensation. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance establishing any wage, salary or compensation plan or otherwise relating to wages, salaries or other compensation of city officers and employees, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Sec. 2-49. - Texas Municipal Retirement System—Election to participate. 
The city council hereby exercises its option and elects to have the city and all of the employees of all of the departments of the city participate in the Texas Municipal Retirement System, as provided in Chapter 75, Acts of the 50th Legislature, as amended, (Article 6243h of Vernon's Civil Statutes of Texas), and all of the benefits and obligations of such system are hereby accepted as to such employees. 
(Code 1964, § 2-5)  
Sec. 2-50. - Same—Employees included; part-time employees excepted. 
(a)  Each person who becomes an employee of any participating department of this city, except part-time employees, and who is not already a member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System shall become a member of the system as a condition of employment, provided such person is then under sixty (60) years of age. 
(b)  Any member, after one year from the effective date of membership, shall be eligible for service retirement who has attained the age of fifty (50) years and has completed twenty-five (25) years of creditable service with this city, or who has attained the age of sixty (60) years and has completed at least ten (10) years of creditable service with participating municipalities which have adopted the plan provisions of this section, or who has become eligible for service retirement under any other applicable provision of Article 6243h, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes. 
(c)  The membership of any member who has completed at least ten (10) years of creditable service with this city and other participating municipalities which have adopted the plan provisions of Section XX of Article 6243h, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes shall not terminate because of absence from service. 
(d)  Any person who is an employee of a participating department of this municipality at the effective date of this section but who at the date of his employment was under sixty (60) years of age but did not become a member of Texas Municipal Retirement System because he was then above the maximum age then prescribed by law for initial membership in the system, shall become a member of the system at the effective date of this section, unless he has already become a member under other provisions of the governing act, and shall be allowed prior service credit for each month of creditable service performed for this municipality subsequent to the date such person was precluded from membership and prior to the effective date of his membership. Such prior service credit shall be calculated using the same percentage of the base prior service credit as was most recently used in calculating prior service credits or updated service credits in said system for current member employees of this city. 
(e)  The rights, credits and benefits hereinabove authorized shall be in addition to the plan provisions heretofore adopted and in force at the effective date of this section pursuant to the act governing said system. 
(Ord. No. 73-48, § 1, 2-27-73; Ord. No. 73-273, § 1, 11-6-73; Ord. No. 79-110, § 2, 9-4-79)  
Sec. 2-51. - Same—Rate of employees contributions. 
Effective January 1, 1991, all employees of the city, except part-time employees, who are members of the Texas Municipal Retirement System shall make deposits to the system at the rate of seven (7) per cent of their compensation, as such term is defined in Section 851.001 of the Government Code of the State of Texas, as the same may be hereafter amended. However, this rate shall not be applied to compensation in excess of the maximum compensation subject to retirement deductions as fixed by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 73-48, § 2, 2-27-73; Ord. No. 73-273, § 2, 11-6-73; Ord. No. 81-222, § 1, 11-17-81; Ord. No. 90-242, § 1, 12-11-90)  
Sec. 2-52. - Same—City contributions. 
For each month of current service thereafter rendered by each of its employees as members of the Texas Municipal Retirement System, the City of Pasadena will contribute to the current service annuity reserve of each such member at the time of his retirement, a sum that is two hundred (200) per cent of such member's accumulated deposits for such month of employment; and said sum shall be contributed from the city's account in the municipality current service accumulation fund. 
(Ord. No. 73-48, § 3, 2-27-73; Ord. No. 73-273, § 3, 11-6-73)  
Sec. 2-52.1. - Same—Eligibility for service retirement. 
From and after the 1st day of January, 1973, any employee of the City of Pasadena, Texas, who has attained the age of fifty (50) years, and who as an employee of this city has completed twenty-five (25) or more years of creditable service for which he is entitled to credit in the Texas Municipal Retirement System, and who has been a member of the system for one year or more, shall be eligible for service retirement as provided in subsection 1(b), Section VII of Article 6243h, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, as amended. Any such employee who shall have completed twenty (20) years or more of creditable service as an employee of said city shall continue as a member of Texas Municipal Retirement System despite subsequent absence from service for a period in excess of sixty (60) months, provided he does not withdraw his deposits during such absence, and shall be eligible to retirement upon and after attainment of the minimum age prescribed by the Act above mentioned. 
(Ord. No. 73-48, § 4, 2-27-73; Ord. No. 73-273, § 4, 11-6-73)  
Secs. 2-52.2, 2-52.3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— At the discretion of the editor, § 2-52.2, relative to antecedent service credits and § 2-52.3, relative to special prior service credits, have been deleted as being superseded by provisions deriving from Ord. No. 81-222, § 5, adopted Nov. 17, 1981 and codified as § 2-52.9. The deleted provisions derived from Ord. No. 73-48, §§ 5, 6, adopted Feb. 27, 1973 and Ord. No. 73-273, §§ 5, 6, adopted Nov. 6, 1973.  
Sec. 2-52.4. - Texas Municipal Retirement System—Remittance and certifications to board of trustees. 
The city controller is hereby directed to remit to the board of trustees of the Texas Municipal Retirement System, at its office in Austin, Texas, the city's contributions to the system and the amounts which shall be deducted from the compensation or payroll of employees, all as required by said board under the provisions of Chapter 75, Acts of the 50th Legislature of the State of Texas, as amended, and the said city controller is hereby authorized and directed to ascertain and certify officially on behalf of the City of Pasadena, Texas, the prior service rendered to the said municipality by each of the employees of the city, and the average prior service rendered to the said municipality by each of the employees of the city, and the average prior service compensation received by each, and to make and execute all prior service certifications and all other reports and certifications which may be required of the City of Pasadena, Texas, under the provisions of Chapter 75, Acts Regular Session, 50th Legislature, as amended, or in compliance with the rules and regulations of the board of trustees of the Texas Municipal Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 73-48, § 7, 2-27-73; Ord. No. 73-273, § 7, 11-6-73)  
Sec. 2-52.5. - Same—Supplemental death benefits fund. 
(a)  The City of Pasadena hereby elects to participate in the supplemental death benefits fund of the Texas Municipal Retirement System beginning on the first day of the calendar month following written notification to the system of the adoption of this section, for the purpose of providing in-service death benefits in the amounts and on the terms provided for in Section XIX of the TMRS Act (Article 6243h, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, as amended) for each of the city's employees who is a member of said system, and for the purpose of providing post-retirement death benefits as provided in said Section XIX for any annuitant whose last covered employment was as an employee of this city. 
(b)  The City of Pasadena is hereby authorized and directed to notify the director of the system of adoption of this section, and of the participation of the city in said fund. 
(Ord. No. 79-108, § 1, 9-4-79) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-108, § 1, adopted Sept. 4, 1979, enacted provisions designated § 2-55.4; in order to keep material relating to the state retirement system together, the editor has redesignated said section as § 2-52.5.  
Sec. 2-52.6. - Same—Buy-back allowance. 
(a)  Pursuant to subsection 8 of Section VI of Article 6243h, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, as amended, the city hereby elects to allow any member of Texas Municipal Retirement System who is an employee of this city on the seventeenth day of November, 1981, who has terminated a previous membership in said system by withdrawal of deposits while absent from service, to deposit with the system in a lump sum the amount withdrawn, plus a withdrawal charge of five (5) per cent of such amount for each year from date of such withdrawal to date of redeposit, and thereupon such member shall be allowed credit for all service to which the member had been entitled at date of termination of the earlier membership, with like effect as if all such service had been rendered as an employee of this city, whether so rendered or not. The city agrees to underwrite and hereby assumes the obligations arising out of the granting of all such credits, and agrees that all such obligations and reserves required to provide such credits shall be charged to the city's account in the municipality prior service accumulation fund. The five (5) per cent per annum withdrawal charge paid by the member shall be deposited to the credit of the city's account in said municipality prior service accumulation fund; and the deposits of the amount previously withdrawn by the member shall be credited to his individual account in the employees saving fund of the system. 
(b)  Paragraph (a) above shall become effective on the seventeenth day of November, 1981, which is a date on or after the date set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 81-222, § 2, 11-17-81) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 81-222, §§ 2—5, adopted Nov. 17, 1981, enacted provisions designated §§ 2-55.3—2-55.7; in order to keep material relating to the state retirement system together, the editor has redesignated said sections as §§ 2-52.6—2-52.10.  
Sec. 2-52.7. - Same—Military service credit. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 1982 the city, pursuant to Subchapter F of Chapter 63, Title 110B, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, as amended, hereby elects to allow eligible members in its employment to establish credit in the Texas Municipal Retirement System for active military service performed as a member of the armed forces or armed forces reserves of the United States or an auxiliary of the armed forces or armed forces reserves, during a period in which the United States is or was involved in a state of conflict with foreign forces. Eligible members as used herein shall be those employees meeting the criteria set forth in subsection (b) of Section 63.501 of said Subchapter F, and the amount and use of creditable military service shall be as further set forth in that subchapter. 
(b)  In order to establish credit for military service hereunder, a member must deposit with the Texas Municipal Retirement System (in that member's individual account in the employees saving fund), before the first anniversary of the effective date of this section, to wit, January 1, 1982, or before the first anniversary of the date the member becomes eligible to establish the credit (whichever is later) an amount equal to the number of months for which credit is sought, multiplied by fifteen dollars ($15.00), and the city must contribute an amount equal to the amount required of the member, multiplied by the city's current service matching percentage in effect on the date the member applies for credit hereunder. The city agrees to pay into its account in the municipality accumulation fund all sums which become due hereunder as a result of the granting of such credit. 
(Ord. No. 81-222, § 3, 11-17-81) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 2-52.6.  
Sec. 2-52.8. - Same—Elected officials membership. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 1982, the city, pursuant to Section 62.107 of Chapter 62, Title 110B, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, 1925, as amended, hereby elects to provide that persons who hold and are regularly engaged in the performance of duties of an elective office that normally requires actual performance of services of not less than one thousand (1,000) hours a year in a department of this city that participates in the Texas Municipal Retirement System shall be and are hereby required to become members of that retirement system, provided that such persons are not ineligible for membership in the system under the applicable age restrictions of Subtitle G of Title 110B, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, 1925, as amended. 
(b)  Any person required to become a member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System under this section becomes a member of that system on the effective date, to wit, January 1, 1982, the date the person takes office, whichever is later. 
(c)  Any elected official who becomes a member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System on the effective date of this section shall be entitled to prior service credit with the system, computed under Section 63.302 of Chapter 63, Title 110B, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, 1925, as amended. 
(d)  Subject to the requirements of Section 63.003(c) of Chapter 63, Title 110B, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, 1925, as amended, this provision shall be and become effective the first day of January, 1982, which is a date on or after the first day of January, 1982. 
(Ord. No. 81-222, § 4, 11-17-81) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 2-52.6.  
Sec. 2-52.9. - Same—Authorization of updated service credits. 
(a)  On the terms and conditions set out in Sections 63.401 through 63.403 of Title 110B, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, as amended, each member of the Texas Municipal Retirement System who has current service credit or prior service credit in said system in force and effect on the first day of January, 1982, by reason of service in the employment of the city, and on such date has at least thirty-six (36) months of credit service with said system, shall be and is hereby allowed "updated service credit" (as that term is defined in subsection d of Section 63.402 of said title) in an amount that is one hundred (100) per cent of the "base updated service credit" of the member (calculated as provided in subsection c of Section 63.402 of said title). The updated service credit hereby allowed shall replace any updated service credit, prior service credit, special prior service credit or antecedent service credit previously authorized for part of the same service. 
(b)  In accordance with the provisions of subsection d of Section 63.401 of said Title 110B, the deposits required to be made to the Texas Municipal Retirement System by employees of the several participating departments on account of current service shall be calculated from and after the date aforesaid on the full amount of such person's earnings as an employee of the city. 
(c)  Subject to approval by the board of trustees of Texas Municipal Retirement System, the updated service credits hereby granted shall be and become effective on the first day of January, 1982. 
(Ord. No. 81-222, § 5, 11-17-81) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 2-52.6.  
Sec. 2-52.10. - Same—Increase in retirement annuities. 
(a)  On the terms and conditions set out in Section 64.203 of Title 110B, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, as amended, the city hereby elects to allow and to provide for payment of the increases below stated in monthly benefits payable by the Texas Municipal Retirement System to retired employees and to beneficiaries of deceased employees of this city under current service annuities and prior service annuities arising from service by such employees to this city. An annuity increased under this section replaces any annuity or increased annuity previously granted to the same person. 
(b)  The amount of annuity increase under this section is computed as the sum of the prior and current service annuities on the effective date of retirement of the person on whose service the annuities are based, multiplied by seventy (70) per cent of the percentage change in Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers, from December of the year immediately preceding the effective date of the person's retirement to the December that is thirteen (13) months before the effective date of this section, to wit, January 1, 1982. 
(c)  An increase in an annuity that was reduced because of an option selection is reducible in the same proportion and in the same manner that the original annuity was reduced. 
(d)  If a computation hereunder does not result in an increase in the amount of an annuity, the amount of the annuity will not be changed hereby. 
(e)  The amount by which an increase under this section exceeds all previously granted increases to an annuitant is an obligation of this city and of its account in the municipality accumulation fund of the Texas Municipal Retirement System. 
(f)  Subject to approval by the board of trustees of Texas Municipal Retirement System, the increases in retirement annuities granted hereby shall be and become effective on the first day of January, 1982. 
(Ord. No. 81-222, § 5, 11-17-81) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 2-52.6.  
Sec. 2-53. - Social security for employees—Execution of agreements. 
The city council, acting for and on behalf of the city, shall enter into all necessary agreements with the state department of public welfare for the purpose of securing federal old age and survivor's insurance benefits for city employees, as authorized in federal and state laws. The mayor is hereby appointed as agent of the city council and of the city to execute all necessary agreements and instruments for and in behalf of the city council for such purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 2-9) 
State Law reference— Social security coverage for municipal employees, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 695g.  
Sec. 2-54. - Same—Duties of city controller. 
The city controller is hereby directed to be the person responsible for assessments, collections, payments and reports, as required by the state department of public welfare, or its successor department or other agency, if any, as to these functions of the city regarding social security and federal and state old age and survivor's insurance benefits, under applicable state and federal laws in connection with social security and federal and state old age and survivor's insurance programs. 
(Code 1964, § 2-10; Ord. No. 1777, § 1, 3-8-66)  
Sec. 2-55. - Same—Fund established. 
A sufficient sum of money shall be allocated and set aside from available funds for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of the federal old age and survivor's insurance law, under applicable state and federal statutes, such money so allocated and set aside to be known as the City of Pasadena Social Security Fund, which fund shall be set aside and maintained in the regular city depository. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11)  
Sec. 2-56. - Holidays. 
(a)  The following holidays shall be declared official holidays for city employees. If the holiday falls on Saturday, it will be observed on Friday unless that day is already a holiday, in which case the holiday will be observed the following Monday. If the holiday falls on Sunday, it will be observed on Monday unless that day is already a holiday, in which case the holiday will be observed the preceding Friday. 
New Year's Day 	January 1 
Martin Luther King, Jr. Day 	Third Monday in January 
Good Friday 	Friday, before Easter Sunday 
San Jacinto Day 	April 21 
Memorial Day 	Last Monday in May 
Independence Day 	July 4 
Labor Day 	1st Monday in September 
Veterans' Day 	November 11 
Thanksgiving Day 	Fourth Thursday and following 
 Friday in November 
Christmas Eve 	December 24 
Christmas Day 	December 25 
 
All employees shall be given one-half day off on New Year's Eve if it falls on a work day. 
(b)  As many employees as possible shall be given each holiday off without loss of pay. All regular employees, except employees of the police department, fire department dispatchers, and utility plants, required to work on a holiday, which is a work day, shall, in addition to their regular pay for that day, be paid their regular rates for the actual time worked. Holiday time shall be considered actual time worked for pay purposes. 
(c)  When the holiday and regular day off occur on the same day, those employees scheduled off-duty on that day shall be entitled to additional pay or another day off. 
(d)  Part-time employees shall be paid their regular rates on a holiday only if required to work. No payment shall be allowed any employee for holiday work not specifically authorized by a department head. 
(e)  An employee who is absent without authorized leave on the day immediately preceding or following a holiday shall lose pay for the holiday as well as pay for that day. 
(f)  When the city council declares a special holiday, it shall be observed as provided above. 
(g)  Employees wishing to observe national or religious holidays not listed herein shall at their option be given time off without pay or have the time charged to their vacation. 
(Ord. No. 72-243, § 1, 9-5-72; Ord. No. 74-112, § 1, 6-4-74; Ord. No. 76-176, § 6.4, 9-21-76; Ord. No. 77-79, § 1, 4-26-77; Ord. No. 78-91, § 1, 6-20-78; Ord. No. 79-51, § 1, 5-1-79; Ord. No. 84-294, § 1, 11-27-84; Ord. No. 02-123, § 1, 5-28-02)  
DIVISION 2. - TRAVEL AND AUTHORIZATION AND EXPENSE POLICY GUIDE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 06-84, § 1, adopted April 18, 2006, added new provision which have been designated by the editor as §§ 2-57—2-66.1. 
 
Sec. 2-57. - Purpose of the guide. 
To protect the interest of the city and insure like treatment for all, uniform policies are established to govern expense allowances to be granted to city employees and city officials who travel out of the city on city business for public purposes. The representative of the city traveling is responsible for justifying their expenses adequately and fully to the satisfaction of the city controller within the limits set out in this Travel and Authorization and Expense Policy Guide and City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-58. - Travel authorization. 
All out-of-the-city travel at the expense of the city shall be made only on authorization of the department head or direct supervisor. Before making a trip, the city official or employee must submit a "Travel Advance and Expense Report" form on which the purpose of the trip, destination, times and dates of the departure and return, and estimates of the cost must be stated. (See section 2-66.1) 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-59. - Advance payments. 
City officials and employees will be allowed to request advance payments on estimated expenses to finance travel on city business for public purposes. Advance should be requested two (2) weeks before departure date however the advance will not be released before seven days prior to date of function. The expenditure will be charged to the accounting period that the seminar or business event takes place unless it benefits the city or if question of seating availability. Upon review, the city department head or direct supervisor may authorize advance payment of the estimated amount to the official or employee. Some type of supporting documentation, brochure, seminar form, must be attached to advance request. When advance payments for travel expenses, etc. are made, the reimbursement procedure, as stated in section 2-62, must still be followed. Advancing money for travel expense does not constitute approval for the expenses of the entire amount of advanced, as all expenses must be for public purposes and must have itemized documentation except as provided in this document. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-60. - Expenses approved for reimbursement. 
The following list of expense classifications is for information and guidance in determining which expenses are appropriate and reasonable when traveling on city business. The list is intended as a guide and is not necessarily all-inclusive. 
Items specifically prohibited include the purchase of personal items and alcoholic beverages. Prohibited also are the expenses of the official's or employee's family who accompany him/her on a trip. 
Officials and employees are expected to show good judgment about travel expenses and have proper regard for economy in conducting business away from the City of Pasadena. 
(a)  Transportation: The least expensive air fare (advance purchase, non-refundable tickets) will be considered standard air travel. For travel beyond a two hundred fifty-mile radius of the city, only transportation by air will be approved, except as provided below. It is the city's policy that air travel be used whenever possible to eliminate the lost time which is otherwise involved. Lodging will not be approved for traveling time in excess of one (1) day if the employee chooses to use personal vehicle. The use of a personal vehicle for a trip exceeding the two hundred fifty-mile radius by two (2) or more personnel traveling together, where the combined air fares would greatly exceed the cost of travel time (salaries) and mileage expense, will be an exception to this subsection, when the use of such private vehicle is approved by the department head or direct supervisor. 
When two (2) or more officials or employees are traveling by personal automobile to the same destination on city business, they are encouraged to car pool. 
The use of personal automobiles for travel may be approved when the convenience of the city is served and when the convenience of the official or employee is served. When personal automobiles are approved for the convenience of the city, reimbursement will be at the rate allowed by the Internal Revenue Service using the most current "Texas Mileage Guide" on the internet at http://www.window.state.tx.us/comptrol/texastra.html to determine mileage between cities. The same mileage reimbursement rate will be allowed between Pasadena and a Houston airport for officials and employees (excluding employees who receive a monthly automobile allowance or the use of a city vehicle) using personal automobiles to reach the airport for air travel. Parking fees will also be allowed if the employee must park his/her car during the duration of his/her official leave of absence (a receipt is necessary). 
Travel in city vehicles may be approved when circumstances warrant it. When such travel is approved, purchase of gasoline, oil, other routine supplies, and emergency repairs for the vehicle will be allowed excluding car washes. The notation "city vehicle used" must be written on the travel advance and expense report. All itemized receipts for such payments must be furnished to obtain reimbursements. 
When air is used, expenses for local transportation, such as taxicab fare, will be allowed whenever such transportation is necessary for conducting city business. Itemized receipts are necessary to receive reimbursement. 
Car rentals will not be approved unless it can be demonstrated that rental is essential to the purpose of the trip and/or is more cost effective than other ground transportation alternatives. Approval must be received prior to departure and nothing larger than an intermediate car will be reimbursed, compact recommended depending on number of travelers. 
(b)  Lodging: Expenses will be allowed for adequate lodging. Hotel accommodations should be suitable to the purpose of the trip. The benchmark to review reasonableness of reimbursement will be the amount allowed by the Internal Revenue Service under the high-low substantiation method. (See section 2-66) Itemized receipts for lodging must be provided to obtain reimbursement. Refer to incidental expenses (Item h) for other charges incurred in addition to lodging costs. 
(c)  Meals and tips: Meals and incidental expenses will be reimbursed based upon itemized receipts or per diem rate may be used. Reimbursement will not exceed the per diem rate. It should be noted, no receipts are needed if the per diem rate is used for meals and tip reimbursement. The benchmark to review reasonableness of reimbursement will be the amount allowed by the Internal Revenue Service. (See section 2-66) 
(d)  Telephone: Reimbursement will be allowed for long distance telephone calls needed for city business only. 
(e)  Registration fees: Fees charged for registration at any convention or meeting are allowed for reimbursement or if possible pay for in advance with the procurement cards or city check. A receipt or some proof of the fee, such as a copy of the conference program setting forth the fee rate, must be provided with the expense report. Payment for the registration fees should normally be in the same fiscal year as the convention or meeting except under extreme circumstances, handled on case by case bases. 
(f)  Lodging, meals, and travel time when traveling by personal automobile: In instances where use of personal automobile for travel is allowed for the convenience of the official and employee, lodging, meals, and other expenses will be allowed on the same basis as if the official or employee traveled by air. The employee will charge to the city only the time that they would normally be at work. All time used in excess will be charged to vacation or accumulated compensatory time. 
(g)  Other methods of reimbursement: If the city is to be reimbursed for the official's or employee's travel expenses by another government or agency, the official or employee may use the travel policy from that government or agency for reimbursement of his/her travel expenses. A copy of the travel policy for that government or agency must be attached to the official's or employee's expense report. Also, officials or employees from other governments or agencies working with the city through joint task force agreements may use the travel policy of their government or agency. A copy of the travel policy for that government or agency must be attached to the expense report. 
(h)  Incidental expenses: Incidental expenses include, but are not limited to fees and tips for services, such as baggage handlers excludes waiter which is included in the meal per diem. It does not include expenses for laundry, cleaning and pressing of clothing, movie rental, maid services, and snacks. Note: Laundry and cleaning and pressing of clothing will be reimbursed if stay is in excess of five (5) working days. 
(i)  Non-allowable expenses: The city will not reimburse officials or employees for in-hotel pay television and videos, health clubs and spas, and alcoholic beverages. 
(j)  Spouse/family travel: When accompanied by a family member, an official or employee shall pay all incremental costs related to having the member along on the trip. Examples of incremental costs include the difference in lodging cost between single and double occupancy and all meals and incidental costs of the family. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-61. - Travel advance and expense report. 
Any official or employee traveling on city business shall complete the "travel advance and expense report" in which a detail record of his/her expenses must be stated. All items must be supported by itemized receipts attached to the report unless specifically exempted by this policy. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-62. - Reimbursement. 
To be reimbursed for travel expenses, the official or employee must sign, have his/her department head or direct supervisor approve his/her "travel advance and expense report", and submit it to the controller's office as soon as possible; but in no event later than fifteen (15) days after returning from the trip. No reimbursement will be made until the "travel advance and expense report" has been approved by the department head, city controller, and mayor. The department head shall check for reasonableness and the city controller shall review the expenses and check the accuracy of transportation costs and time covered. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-63. - Settlement of advance payments. 
If an official or employee has drawn expense money in advance, a settlement must be made on the basis of actual expenses and/or approved Internal Revenue Service per diem rates and the unused balance promptly deposited with the city controller. All expenditure reports must be filed with the controller's office within fifteen (15) days after the travel's return. Noncompliance will subject the traveler to a payroll deduction for funds advanced. If actual expenses exceed the estimate, upon approval of the mayor, the employee will be reimbursed by the city. Again, it is emphasized that when advance payments are made, they do not constitute approval to spend this amount. All expenses must be justified and documented. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-64. - Same day travel clarifications. 
The travel policy does not apply to same day travel to and return from any location. In these cases, officials and employees do not use the travel advance and expense report form. 
(1)  Mileage reimbursement. Reimbursement for mileage can be received by completing a mileage report form (see attached) and obtaining reimbursement from petty cash or by completing a cash payment requisition and attaching the mileage report form. The date, beginning and ending mileage, total mileage, and purpose of trip must be shown on the document used for reimbursement. If the official or employee uses a personal automobile, reimbursement for mileage will be at the "standard mileage rate" allowed by the Internal Revenue Service. Mileage should be based from City Hall to destination unless route from home is closer. The mileage reimbursement rate will be updated to remain consistent with the Internal Revenue Service reimbursement rate. 
(2)  Other expense reimbursement. For any other expenses (parking, etc. including meals) that the official/employee needs reimbursement for they should complete a cash payment requisition form and he/she must have a receipt and a written explanation of the city purpose of the expense. It should be noted that meals will be reimbursed for same day travel to and return from any location only if prior approval is obtained from the employee's direct supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-65. - Mileage reimbursement and official mileage guide. 
The mileage reimbursement rate for January thru August 2005 is 40.5 cents per mile and for September thru December 2005 is 48.5 cents per mile. Effective January 1, 2006 the mileage reimbursement rate will be 44.5 cents per mile. The mileage reimbursement rate will be updated to remain consistent with the Internal Revenue Service reimbursement rate. 
When personal automobiles are approved for the convenience of the city, reimbursement will be at the rate allowed by the Internal Revenue Service using the most current "Texas Mileage Guide" on the internet at http://www.window.state.tx.us/comptrol/texastra.html to determine mileage between cities. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-66. - Internal Revenue Service per diem rates. 
The standard ("low") reimbursement for 2006 (effective October 1, 2005) is forty-five dollars ($45.00) for meals which includes tips per day. See below for maximum ("high") per diem rates. The high/low reimbursement rates will be updated to remain consistent with the Internal Revenue Service reimbursement rate. 
The attached Publication 1542 Table 2 per diem rates is to be used for the benchmark for reimbursement for city travel away from home for lodging and meals for maximum ("high") per diem rates. The reimbursement rate will be updated to remain consistent with the Internal Revenue Service reimbursement rates. 
(Ord. No. 06-84, § 1, 4-18-06)

Mileage Reimbursement Policy: 
If you use your personal vehicle while on city business it is reimbursable at the IRS approved rate: Mileage should be calculated from City Hall to your destination and back to City Hall. Travel from your home to your work site may be reimbursed only for travel other than your regular schedule work hours or work days (i.e. call out or call back). Travel to and from your home during regular work hours is commuting and is a personal expenditure not subject to reimbursement.

ARTICLE IV. - CITY SECRETARY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 79-1, adopted Jan. 16, 1979, repealed §§ 2-67—2-70, pertaining to the city secretary, and § 2 of said ordinance enacted similar provisions codified as new §§ 2-67—2-70. Former Art. IV derived from Ord. No. 1760, § 1, adopted Feb. 1, 1966; Ord. No. 1797, § 1, adopted April 5, 1966. 
 
Sec. 2-67. - Office created. 
The department of the city secretary is hereby created and re-created in furtherance of Article II, Section 6 of the City Charter. The city secretary shall be the head of the department and shall be appointed by the city council, upon recommendation of the mayor, and shall serve at the pleasure of the council. 
(Ord. No. 79-1, § 2, 1-16-79)  
Sec. 2-68. - Compilation, printing, etc., of council agenda, and agendas and minutes of meeting of boards, commissions, etc. 
It shall be the duty of the city secretary to compile, prepare, print or reproduce and distribute copies of the agendas of all regular and special meetings of the city council, and the agendas and minutes of meetings of such commissions, boards, agencies, offices and departments of the city as the city council may, from time to time, direct. The city secretary shall furnish two (2) copies of the minutes of all council meetings to the city library within thirty (30) days after their approval; and the copies of the minutes of the council shall become and be maintained as permanent public records. 
(Ord. No. 79-1, § 2, 1-16-79)  
Sec. 2-69. - Duties with respect to ordinances and other official documents of council. 
The city secretary shall see that the original or master, as the case may be, of all ordinances, orders, resolutions, notices and other official documents of the city council are properly subscribed, recorded, filed, and, as required by law or the instruction of city council, posted or published. 
(Ord. No. 79-1, § 2, 1-16-79)  
Sec. 2-70. - Charges for copies of public records. 
(a)  For reproductions of a noncertified public record supplied to a requesting party the city secretary shall collect the most current fee(s) established or recommended by the state purchasing and general services commission, its successor department or other applicable state agency for the particular type of public record requested. 
(b)  For reproductions of certified public records supplied to a requesting party the city secretary shall collect the sum of fifty cents ($0.50) per reproduced sheet of such copy from the person ordering the same. 
(c)  The city council may by resolution adopted pursuant hereto, prescribe different charges for the sale of official documents and public records reproduced in pamphlet, book or other bound form. Such charges shall be based on the actual cost of providing the particular public record to the requesting party. 
(d)  All moneys collected under this section shall be nonrefundable, promptly deposited in a city depository, and shall be the sole property of the city. 
(e)  The governments of the United States of America, the State of Texas, Harris County, the Pasadena Independent School District, and their departments and agencies and the departments, offices and agencies of the city shall not be charged for copies of public records issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 79-1, § 2, 1-16-79; Ord. No. 89-129, § 1, 8-8-89) 
Cross reference— Fee for tax certificates and copies of tax records, § 34-4; charges for copies of official accident reports and accident photographs, § 36-24.  
Secs. 2-71—2-83. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-109. - Sale of city equipment; collection of fees. 
The department of maintenance services of the City of Pasadena is hereby authorized to sell, from time to time, as the director may deem advisable: 
(a)  Any scrap metal which may accumulate upon city property either: 
(1)  By public auction as authorized by city council, or 
(2)  If the value of such scrap is under twenty-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) by private sale at fair market value, such values and sale to be verified by a representative of the finance department. 
(b)  Garbage bags in quantities of not less than ten (10) bundles at the cost per bundle to the City of Pasadena to local businesses for resale to the customers of such business. Such local business shall be restricted to fifteen (15) per cent markup on the bids for resale. 
(c)  Quantities of not less than one bundle at the same price as the cost per bundle to the City of Pasadena to any individual representing a family resident of the City of Pasadena. 
(d)  Any surplus vehicles and/or equipment, etc., by public auction as authorized by city council. All monies collected under this section shall be nonrefundable, promptly deposited in a city depository and shall be the sole property of the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 74-68, § 2, 4-2-74; Ord. No. 83-113, § 1, 5-3-83)

(Ord. No. 74-68, § 2, 4-2-74)
