ARTICLE VI. - PURCHASES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference— Purchasing procedures, Art. IX, § 18. 
 
Sec. 2-121. - Department created. 
There is hereby created the department of purchases of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 2, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-122. - Department subject to control and direction of mayor. 
All operations of the department of purchases under this article shall be subject to the control and direction of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 13, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-123. - Office of director created; appointment and term of director. 
There is hereby created the office of director of purchases. The director shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed and approved by the city council. The director shall serve for a term of one year or until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 3, 6-1-65) 
Cross reference— Bond of director of purchasing, § 2-5.  
Sec. 2-124. - General duties of director. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specifically provided by the Charter, or elsewhere in this article, or by other ordinances of the city, or as specifically otherwise required by law, the director of purchases shall make all purchases of materials, equipment, and supplies for the city. He shall be responsible for buying at the most favorable price for the city and shall see to it that the materials, equipment or supplies delivered are correct in number or amount and comply with the standards and specifications fixed for such purchases by the city council, through motion, resolution or ordinance, and under the supervision of the mayor. 
(b)  The director of purchases shall perform such other duties as may be assigned to him by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1679, §§ 5, 14, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-125. - Requisitions, purchase orders, etc.; coordination with mayor and controller. 
(a)  The requisitions prescribed by Article IX, section 18 of the Charter, may be for quantities of materials, equipment and supplies based on commitments or on estimates sufficient for one fiscal year. The director of purchases shall coordinate with the city controller for certification of purchases and with the city controller and the mayor for assurance of compliance with the purchase procedure of Article IX, Section 18, of the Charter. 
(b)  All requisitions, purchase orders and purchase contracts for materials, equipment and supplies of the city shall be initially submitted to the director of purchases for his handling and processing with the city controller and the mayor and with the city council, if required. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 6, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-126. - Standards and specifications. 
The director of purchases shall, where possible, establish sets of standards and specifications to control all purchases by the city, and he shall prepare and recommend to the city council such standards as to quality, size and variety of articles, equipment and supplies used by the offices and departments of municipal government as will make possible uniform purchasing for all city offices and departments, when consistent with efficiency. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 8, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-127. - Procedure when bids required. 
Where calling for bids is required by the Charter or ordinance, or by the laws of the state, or by motion of the city council or order of the mayor, the director of purchases shall prepare the specifications and notice to bidders and deliver the same to the city secretary, who shall see that the required notices are published. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 9, 6-1-65) 
Cross reference— When bids required, Art. IX, § 18.  
Sec. 2-128. - Advance and bulk purchases. 
(a)  The director of purchases shall advise the city council, through the mayor, as to the anticipated needs for purchases whenever possible, and shall ask authority to make purchases in advance of needs, or in bulk amounts, where such practices would result in economy or improved efficiency. 
(b)  Any commodity, equipment or supplies purchased in advance of actual need shall remain in the custody of the director of purchases for delivery to the officer, department or employee needing it at the time its use is required. 
(Ord. No. 1679, §§ 9, 10, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-129. - Records to be kept. 
The director of purchases shall keep records of all purchases made by him and of the destination or ultimate use of materials, equipment or supplies so purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 10, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-130. - Inventory of municipal property. 
(a)  The director of purchases shall cause to be kept an inventory of all municipal property in his custody. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each officer or employee having municipal property in his custody to keep an inventory of such property and to furnish a copy thereof to the director of purchases on request. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 11, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-131. - Director's authority to transfer property from the department, officer or employee to another. 
The director of purchases shall have authority to transfer, from time to time, stocks of materials, equipment and supplies from one department, officer or employee to another in order to maintain balanced departmental inventories of appropriate items and to eliminate unnecessary stockpiling and relieve materials, equipment and supplies shortages. All such transfers shall be effected, only after approval by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1679, § 12, 6-1-65)  
Sec. 2-132. - Contracts and purchases by mayor. 
(a)  The mayor shall have general authority to contract for expenditures for all budgeted items, without notice or application to, or by advice or consent or approval of, the council so long as an expenditure shall not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) per budgeted item. 
(b)  Whenever the mayor, under the contract authority granted to him in this section, elects to invite bids for a budgeted item, he shall have the right to reject any and all bids made therefor. The mayor, in affording the opportunity for competition required by Article IX, Section 18, of the Charter, shall provide the opportunity for competition by methods and procedures he deems reasonable, fair, and appropriate for the sale and purchase of the various budgeted items, giving due consideration to the quality, quantity and probable value of such items and the number and character of business suppliers he anticipates to be interested in and competent for the sale and purchase. 
(c)  The provisions of the other sections of this article shall not apply to purchases of budgeted items of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), unless the mayor expressly authorizes the director of purchases to purchase, or standardize and specify, or test, or otherwise exercise control over such budgeted items. The mayor may fully or partially lend his purchasing authority to the director of purchases and he may specify the conditions of such authorization; provided, such authorization shall not constitute a delegation of the responsibility of the mayor and he shall remain answerable to the city council for the purchase of such budgeted items. Purchases made by the mayor are hereby assigned to his custody and he shall cause an inventory of such purchases to be regularly maintained. 
(Ord. No. 1678, §§ 1, 2, 5-18-65; Ord. No. 1679, § 7, 6-1-65; Ord. No. 75-50, § 1, 4-1-75) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to authorize mayor to contract for expenditures for budgeted items, Art. IX, § 18.  
ARTICLE VI½. - DEPARTMENT OF TRAFFIC AND TRANSPORTATION 
 
Sec. 2-133. - Department created. 
There is hereby created and recreated within the municipal government of the City of Pasadena a department to be known as the department of traffic and transportation. 
(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 2-134. - Office created; appointment and term. 
There is hereby created and recreated in the department of traffic and transportation the office of traffic and transportation director. The traffic and transportation director shall be appointed by the mayor, confirmed and approved by the city council; and he shall serve subject to removal as provided by City Charter. He shall exercise the powers and duties as provided in this article and in other traffic ordinances of the city, and the laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 2-135. - Director to be head of department. 
The director shall be head of the traffic and transportation department and all officers and employees assigned thereto whose duties shall be performed subject to the supervision of the director. In addition to the specific powers and duties provided by this article, the director shall engage in such other executive functions and perform such other duties as are assigned by the mayor and the city council by ordinance to the department or one of its divisions. 
(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 2-136. - General duties of traffic and transportation director. 
It shall be the general duty of the director to determine the installation, removal, and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control devices, to conduct analyses of traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures, to conduct investigation of traffic conditions, to plan the operation of traffic on the streets and highways of this city, and to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of this city, and the laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 2-137. - Emergency and experimental regulations of traffic and transportation director. 
The director is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this article and the traffic ordinances of this city and to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulations shall remain in effect for more than ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 2-138. - City traffic and transportation director orders, rules, etc., public record and public notice. 
Every order, rule, regulation, designation, delineation or determination promulgated by the director pursuant to the authority granted in this article shall, unless otherwise provided herein, be described in writing and filed with the city secretary. Such writing shall constitute a public record, and all persons shall be charged with notice of the contents of the same. Unless otherwise designated therein by the director, such order, rule, regulation, designation, delineation or determination promulgated shall be deemed permanent. 
(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 2-139. - City traffic and transportation director further authority and presumptions. 
Whenever in this article the authority is given to the director to do acts as he deems or, [such acts], in his opinion, are advisable, necessary or desirable, such acts shall be based on his observations and studies, according to generally used, accepted traffic-control principles or techniques. 
(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 2-140. - Positions and classifications. 
There shall exist in the department of traffic and transportation the following positions and classifications: 
Department 	Classification

(Ord. No. 80-79, § 2, 4-22-80)  
Secs. 2-141—2-144. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - CODE ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 2-145. - Code enforcement citations. 
(a)  Construction, administration and relation to related laws. The authority, responsibility and duties of peace officers to issue citations, pursuant to Article 14.06(d) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and/or Section 543.003 of the Transportation Code, is not obviated or in any way eliminated by the provisions of this section. 
A citation issued pursuant to this section does not relate to the issuance of a citation by a peace officer pursuant to Article 14.06(d) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, or Section 543.003 of the Transportation Code. 
(b)  Authority to issue citations. Whenever there is a reference in this Code to violation of a Code provision being a misdemeanor, and/or whenever any provision of this Code provides that the city, certain city officials, or their designees, have the authority to enforce the provisions of this Code, or any applicable ordinance or other statutes, regulations or codes adopted by the city, that authority includes, but is not limited to, the ability to issue citations to be prosecuted in the municipal court or other appropriate court, depending on the type of offense and the location of the offense. The city reserves the right to exercise all of the appropriate enforcement remedies. 
Pursuant to this section, and the scope of their assigned duties and respective authority, the following departments/individuals listed herein may issue citations: 
(1)  Code compliance officer/code enforcement. 
(2)  Building official/inspector. 
(3)  Animal control/humane officer. 
(4)  Health official/inspector. 
(5)  Public works inspector. 
(6)  Fire marshal/deputies. 
(7)  Fire chief. 
(c)  Offenses. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with any individuals authorized under subsection (b) to issue citations in the performance of his/her duties. 
(d)  Warrants. Under Article 18.05 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, if any individual authorized under subsection (b) is refused access to a premises, building, facility or residence, or any part thereof, and said individual can demonstrate probable cause to believe that a fire or health hazard, code violation or unsafe building condition is present in the specified location sought to be inspected, the municipal court judge shall issue a search warrant for the purpose of allowing the inspection of the specified premises/location to determine the presence of the hazard, code violation, or unsafe building condition. 
(Ord. No. 15-136, § 2, 10-20-15)  
Secs. 2-146—2-167. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - CITIZEN'S ADVISORY BOARD[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 76-100, §§ 1—5, adopted June 8, 1976, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion of Art. VIII, §§ 2-168—2-172, is at the discretion of the editors. 
 
Sec. 2-168. - Created. 
There is hereby created a citizen's advisory committee hereinafter known as the city board of development. 
(Ord. No. 76-100, § 1, 6-8-76)  
Sec. 2-169. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the city board of development shall be for the purpose of investigating the desirability of various methods of advertising and promoting the city, and to make appropriate recommendations to the city council as to the best method of spending funds already available, and as to the amount which should be appropriated for such purposes in the next budget. Such recommendation of the city board of development shall in no wise be binding on the city council of the City of Pasadena, but merely advisory only, and all such recommendations shall be acted upon by the city council in regular council session, as these recommendations are presented to the city council on the agenda. 
(Ord. No. 76-100, § 2, 6-8-76)  
Sec. 2-170. - Composition; appointment of members; length of term. 
The city board of development shall be composed of five (5) members who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. Members so appointed and approved will serve terms of two (2) years, at which time said members will be replaced and/or reappointed and approved as previously provided for. 
(Ord. No. 76-100, § 3, 6-8-76)  
Sec. 2-171. - Compensation; powers of board to be advisory. 
The members of the city board of development shall serve without compensation, have advisory powers only, and shall not be deemed to be public officers or agents of the city, for any purposes, and their service thereon shall not invalidate any contracts in which the city and any such members or all of them may have a mutual interest. 
(Ord. No. 76-100, § 4, 6-8-76)  
Sec. 2-172. - Appointment of ex officio secretary; duties. 
The mayor may appoint and the city council may approve the appointment of a person, who may or may not be an official of the City of Pasadena, to manage the promotion, development, tourism and convention activities of the City of Pasadena, and such persons so appointed or designated shall be in addition to the five (5) member board and shall serve ex officio as the secretary of the board of development. 
(Ord. No. 76-100, § 5, 6-8-76)  
Secs. 2-173—2-179. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, Ch. 24; trees and shrubs, Ch. 36½. 
 
Sec. 2-180. - Commission created; appointment and term. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established the Pasadena Beautification Commission, which shall consist of nine (9) members to be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. The members of the commission shall not, by virtue of their membership, be employees of or officers or agents of the city, and shall receive no compensation from the city for their services on such commission. Such commission shall not, except to the limited extent hereinafter expressly stated, be an agent or instrumentality of the city or authorized to in any way obligate or bind the city. 
(b)  The nine (9) members shall be appointed for a term to expire on December thirty-first of the second year after appointment. Before the expiration of one month after such expiration of the terms of office of members of such commission, successors shall be so appointed, subject to such confirmation, to serve terms expiring two (2) years after the expiration of such previous term. Vacancies occurring from death, resignation or removal shall be similarly filled by appointment and confirmation for the remaining unexpired term of the member deceased, resigned or removed. The mayor shall appoint the chairman and such other officers as he desires, and the commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure and organization except that one-half of its members at any time shall constitute a quorum. 
Two (2) additional ex officio members shall be appointed by the mayor, to wit: A representative of the beautification committee of the Pasadena Chamber of Commerce and a representative of Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA). Their terms of appointment shall coincide with the terms of regular commission members. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the commission to examine ways and means to enhance the quality of the physical environment of the city. To this end, the commission shall conduct public hearings, hear reports from city officials and employees and sponsor or co-sponsor plans and programs approved by the city council for the purpose of fulfilling its responsibility. The commission shall make recommendations of policy to the city council and shall prepare an annual report of its activities. 
(d)  An official of the city designated by the mayor shall serve as coordinator for the commission and shall prepare materials for distribution and conduct such other business of the commission as may be assigned. 
(e)  The city council declares its purpose and intention (but does not in any way obligate itself or attempt to obligate any future city council) to from time to time appropriate and cause to be paid over to the commission (or upon the commission's recommendation) such sums as the council may deem proper and appropriate to aid in defraying the expenses of operation, maintenance and development. 
(f)  By virtue of this section there shall not be vested in the commission or in the members of the commission any right except it be subject to termination by the city by repeal or amendment of this section or other appropriate action of its governing body. 
(Ord. No. 77-153, §§ 1—4, 8-17-77; Ord. No. 79-103, § 1, 8-28-79; Ord. No. 83-97, § 1, 4-5-83)  
Secs. 2-181—2-190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - SENIOR CITIZENS' COMMISSION[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-153, §§ 1—12, adopted Nov. 6, 1979, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been codified as Art. X, §§ 2-191—2-202, at the editor's discretion. 
 
Sec. 2-191. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created and established, within and for the city, the City of Pasadena Senior Citizens' Commission, composed of nine (9) members, appointed by the mayor, whose offices are hereby created and established as an advisory commission to assist and advise the city council on proper operation of all functions relating to the health, education and welfare of all senior citizens of Pasadena, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 1, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-192. - Qualifications of members. 
Each member of the commission shall be a resident citizen and a qualified voter of the city. Any member who ceases to hold all such qualifications shall, ipso facto upon each cessation, terminate his membership, subject only to written approval by the mayor filed with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 2, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-193. - Appointment and terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  All members of the senior citizens' commission shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. 
(b)  The chairman and vice-chairman of the senior citizens' commissioner who are first so appointed shall be designated to serve for terms of two (2) years; the remaining commissioners shall be designated to serve for terms of one year, respectively, from the date of their appointment, but thereafter, commissioners shall be appointed for a term of office of two (2) years, unless sooner terminated. 
(c)  All vacancies in membership of the commission for any reason shall be filed by the mayor for the unexpired terms as soon as practicable after the position becomes vacant (subject to confirmation by city council). 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 3, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-194. - Members to serve without compensation. 
The members of the senior citizens' commission, in the performance of their official duties, shall serve without compensation for office. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 4, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-195. - Officers designated. 
The officers of the commission shall consist of a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary. The mayor is directed to appoint appropriate ex officio members of the commission. The directors of parks and recreation shall serve as the executive officers of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 5, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-196. - Election and terms of officers. 
The chairman and vice-chairman shall be appointed by the mayor; and the secretary of the commission shall be nominated by the members of the commission in such manner as the commission shall prescribe at its first meeting as a committee of the whole, and each officer shall be elected by a majority vote of the qualified and serving members of the commission. The terms of all elected offices shall be concurrent and limited within the terms of the officer's commission membership appointment. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 6, 11-6-79) 
Editor's note— The city has advised that the chairman and vice-chairman are to be construed as appointed officers; that the secretary is to be nominated by the commission and that "each other" offices shall be elected.  
Sec. 2-197. - Attendance at meetings. 
The commission may establish its own rules as to attendance of its members at meetings; and, in furtherance of such, the commission may, by a majority vote, expel any member who, in the opinion of the commission, misses an unreasonable number of meetings. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 7, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-198. - Procedure. 
The commission is hereby empowered to establish its own parliamentary procedure; provided that such shall not be in conflict with the City Charter or other provisions of law, or the following: A quorum shall consist of a majority of the entire membership of the commission, and any issue to be voted on shall be resolved by those members present. The chairman shall be entitled to vote upon any issue, but shall have no veto power. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 8, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-199. - Authority to advise the mayor. 
Said senior citizens' commission is hereby authorized to work with the mayor and make recommendations to the mayor about any matter that it deems beneficial to the administration; provided, that such functions shall not contravene the City Charter or any other law and such shall be considered advisory only. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 9, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-200. - General powers and duties. 
In the discharge of its duties and responsibilities, the senior citizens' commission shall be authorized to advise and make recommendations for final approval to the mayor and city council in areas including but not limited to the following: 
(a)  Housing for senior citizens. 
(b)  Tax relief for senior citizens. 
(c)  The availability and application of federal grants or funds designed to provide benefit to senior citizens generally. 
(d)  Social and recreational needs of senior citizens and how existing or proposed city development can be designed to accommodate these needs. 
(e)  Transportation needs of the city as they affect senior citizens generally and particularly how future or proposed transit systems will affect the senior citizen users. 
(f)  The publication and dissemination to the public of information on various senior citizen programs and activities. 
(g)  Methods by which the wealth of learning and experience possessed by Pasadena's senior citizenry can be made available to the betterment of the populace. 
(h)  The continued development of a historical appreciation and civic pride among the populace. 
(i)  The making, amending, and repeal of bylaws of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 10, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-201. - Coordinator. 
An official of the city designated by the mayor shall serve as coordinator for the commission and shall prepare materials for distribution and conduct such other business of the commission as may be assigned. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 11, 11-6-79)  
Sec. 2-202. - Finances; construction of rights of commission. 
The city council declares its purpose and intention (but does not in any way obligate itself or attempt to obligate any future city council) to from time to time, appropriate and cause to be paid over to the commission (or upon the commission's recommendation) such sums as the council may deem proper and appropriate to aid in defraying the expenses of operation, maintenance and development. 
By virtue of this article, there shall not be vested in the commission or in the members of the commission any right except it be subject to termination by the city by repeal or amendment of this article or other appropriate action of its governing body. 
(Ord. No. 79-153, § 12, 11-6-79)  
Secs. 2-203—2-210. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - RECORDS MANAGEMENT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 90-250, adopted Dec. 26, 1990, added a new Art. XI, §§ 1—22, pertaining to records management. Said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 2-211—2-232 at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 2-211. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
City means the City of Pasadena, Harris County, Texas. 
City record or record means all documents, papers, letters, books, maps, photographs, sound or video recordings, microfilm, magnetic tape, electronic media, or other information recording media, regardless of physical form or characteristic and regardless of whether public access to it is open or restricted under the laws of the state, created or received by the city or any of its officers or employees pursuant to law or in the transaction of public business are hereby declared to be the records of the city. The term does not include: 
(1)  Extra identical copies of documents created only for convenience of reference or research by officers or employees of the city. 
(2)  Notes, journals, diaries, and similar documents created by an officer or employee of the city for the officer's or employee's personal convenience. 
(3)  Blank forms. 
(4)  Stocks of publications. 
(5)  Library and museum materials acquired solely for the purpose of reference or display. 
(6)  Copies of documents in any media furnished to members of the public to which they are entitled under Chapter 424, Acts of the 63rd Legislature, Regular Session 1973 (Article 6252-17a), Vernon's Civil Statutes, or other state law. 
Commission means the Texas State Library and Archives Commission. 
Department head means the officer who is authorized to be in charge of an office of the city that creates or receives records. 
Director and librarian means the executive and administrative officer of the Texas State Library and Archives Commission. 
Essential record means any city record necessary to the resumption or continuation of the city's operations in an emergency or disaster, to the re-creation of the legal and financial status of the city, or to the protection and fulfillment of obligations to the city. 
Permanent record means any record of the city for which the retention period on a records control schedule issued by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission is given as permanent. 
Records assistant means any person designated under section 2-217 of this article. 
Records control schedule means a document prepared by or under the authority of the records management officer listing the records maintained by the city, their retention periods, and other records disposition information that the records management program may require. 
Records management means the application of management techniques to the creation, use, maintenance, retention, preservation, and disposal of records for the purposes of reducing the costs and improving the efficiency of recordkeeping. The term includes the development of records control schedules, the management of filing and information retrieval systems, the protection of essential and permanent records, the economical and space-effective storage of inactive records, control over the creation and distribution of forms, reports, and correspondence, and the management of micrographics and electronic and other records storage systems. 
Records management committee means the committee established in section 2-215 of this article. 
Records management officer means the person designated under section 2-213 of this article. 
Records management plan means the plan developed under section 2-220 of this article. 
Retention period means the minimum time that must pass after the creation, recording, or receipt of a record, or the fulfillment of certain actions associated with a record, before it is eligible for destruction. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 1), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-212. - City or municipal records declared public property. 
All city records as defined in section 2-111 of this article are hereby declared to be the property of the city. No city official or employee has, by virtue of his or her position, any personal or property right to such records even though he or she may have developed or compiled them. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 2), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-213. - Designation of records management officer. 
The city secretary, and the successive holders of said office, shall serve as records management officer for the city. As provided by state law, each successive holder of the office shall file his or her name with the director and librarian within thirty (30) days of the initial designation or of taking up the office, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 3), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-214. - Duties of records management officer. 
(a)  In addition to other duties assigned in this article, the records management officer shall: 
(1)  Administer the records management program and provide assistance to department heads in its implementation. 
(2)  Plan, formulate, and prescribe records disposition policies, systems, standards, and procedures. 
(3)  Identify, in cooperation with department heads, essential records and establish a disaster plan for each city office and department to ensure maximum availability of the records in order to reestablish operations quickly and with minimum disruption and expense. 
(4)  Develop procedures to ensure the permanent preservation of the historically valuable records of the city. 
(5)  Establish standards for filing and storage equipment and for recordkeeping supplies. 
(6)  Study the feasibility of and, if appropriate, establish a uniform filing system and a forms design and control system for the city. 
(7)  Provide records management advice and assistance to all city departments by preparation of a manual or manuals of procedure and policy and by onsite consultation; 
(8)  Monitor records retention schedules and administrative rules issued by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission to determine if the records management program and the city's records control schedules are in compliance with state regulations. 
(9)  Disseminate to the city council and department heads information concerning state laws and administrative rules relating to local government records. 
(10)  Instruct records assistants and other personnel in policies and procedures of the records management plan and their duties in the records management program. 
(11)  Direct records assistants or other personnel in the conduct of records inventories in preparation for the development of records control schedules as required by state law and this article. 
(12)  Ensure that the maintenance, preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition of city records is carried out in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program and the requirement of state law. 
(13)  Maintain records on the volume of records destroyed under approved records control schedules, the volume of records microfilmed or stored electronically, and the estimated cost and space savings as the result of such disposal or disposition. 
(14)  Review schedules annually and update or amend as needed. 
(15)  Report annually to the city council on the implementation of the records management plan in each department of the city. 
(16)  Bring to the attention of the city council noncompliance by department heads or other city personnel with the policies and procedures of the records management program or the Local Government Records Act. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 4), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-215. - Establishment of records management committee; duties. 
A records management committee consisting of the mayor, city attorney, city controller, chief of police, presiding municipal court judge, librarian, and director of personnel or their respective records assistants is hereby established. The committee shall: 
(1)  Assist the records management officer in the development of policies and procedures governing the records management program. 
(2)  Review the performance of the program on a regular basis and propose changes and improvements if needed. 
(3)  Review and approve records control schedules submitted by the records management officer. 
(4)  Give final approval to the destruction of records in accordance with approved records control schedules. 
(5)  Actively support and promote the records management program throughout the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 5), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-216. - Duties and responsibilities of department heads. 
In addition to other duties assigned in this article, department heads shall: 
(1)  Cooperate with the records management officer in carrying out the policies and procedures established in the city for the efficient and economical management of records and in carrying out the requirements of this article. 
(2)  Adequately document the transaction of government business and the services, programs, and duties for which the department head and his or her staff are responsible. 
(3)  Maintain the records in his or her care and carry out their preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition only in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program of the city and the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 6), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-217. - Designation of records assistants. 
Each department head may designate a member of his or her staff to serve as records assistant for the implementation of the records management program in that department. If the records management officer determines that in the best interests of the records management program more than one (1) records assistant should be designated for a department, the department head may designate the number of records assistants specified by the records management officer. Persons designated as records assistants should be thoroughly familiar with all the records created and maintained by the department. In the event of the resignation, retirement, dismissal, or removal by action of the department head of a person designated as a records assistant, the department head shall promptly designate another person to fill the vacancy. A department head may serve as records assistant for his or her department. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 7), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-218. - Duties and responsibilities of records assistants. 
In addition to other duties assigned in this article, records assistants shall: 
(1)  Conduct or supervise the conduct of inventories of the records of the department in preparation for the development of records control schedules. 
(2)  In cooperation with the records management officer coordinate and implement the policies and procedures of the records management program in their department. 
(3)  Disseminate information to department staff concerning the records management program. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 8), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-219. - Records control schedules to be developed; approval; filing with state. 
(a)  The records management officer, in cooperation with department heads and records assistants, shall prepare records control schedules on a department by department basis listing all records created or received by the department and the retention period for each record on or before January 2, 1995. Records control schedules shall also contain such other information regarding the disposition of city records as the records management plan may require. 
(b)  Each records control schedule shall be monitored and amended as needed by the records management officer on a regular basis to ensure that it is in compliance with records retention schedules issued by the state and that it continues to reflect the recordkeeping procedures and needs of the department and the records management program of the city. 
(c)  Before its adoption a records control schedule or amended schedule for a department must be approved by the department head and a majority vote of the members of the records management committee. 
(d)  Before its adoption the records management officer shall submit the records control schedules to the director and librarian as provided by state law. If a schedule is not accepted for filing by the director and librarian the schedule shall be amended to make it acceptable for filing. 
(e)  When a records control schedule is adopted and accepted by the director and librarian, it shall thenceforth constitute full authority to destroy, transfer, microphotograph, or take other action, and the city council hereby directs that such action be taken by the records management officer or under his or her supervision. The records management officer shall comply with state law, no further notice to the city council or other city offices shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 9), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-220. - Records management plan to be developed; approval of plan; authority of plan. 
(a)  The records management officer and the records management committee shall develop a records management plan for the city for submission to the city council. The plan should contain policies and procedures designed to reduce the costs and improve the efficiency of recordkeeping, to adequately protect the essential records of the city, and to properly preserve those records of the city that are of historical value. The plan shall be designed to enable the records management officer to effectively carry out his or her duties prescribed by state law and this article. 
(b)  Once approved by majority vote of the city council the records management plan shall be binding on all offices, departments, divisions, programs, commissions, bureaus, boards, committees, or similar entities of the city and records shall be created, maintained, stored, microfilmed, or disposed of in accordance with the plan. 
(c)  State law relating to the duties, other responsibilities, or recordkeeping requirements of a department head do not exempt the department head or the records in the department head's care from the application of this article and the records management plan adopted under it and may not be used by the department head as a basis for refusal to participate in the records management program of the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 10), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-221. - Implementation of records control schedules; destruction of records under schedule. 
(a)  A records control schedule for a department that has been approved and adopted under section 2-219 must be implemented by department heads and records assistants according to the policies and procedures of the records management plan. 
(b)  A record whose retention period has expired on a records control schedule shall be destroyed unless: 
(1)  An open records request is pending on the record; 
(2)  The subject matter of the record is pertinent to a pending law suit; or 
(3)  The department head requests in writing to the records management committee that the record be retained for an additional period. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 11), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-222. - Destruction of records. 
(a)  City records may be destroyed if: 
(1)  The records are listed on a records control schedule accepted for filing by the director and librarian as provided by Subtitle C Title 6, Local Government Code, Section 203.041 (preparation and filing of records control schedules) and section 2-119 of this article and either its retention period has expired or it has been microfilmed or stored electronically in accordance with the requirements of Subtitle C, Title 6, Local Government Code, Sections 204 and 205 (microfilming of records and electronic storage of records, respectively) and this article; 
(2)  The record appears on a list of obsolete records approved by the director and librarian as provided by Subtitle C, Title 6, Local Government Code, Section 203.044 (initial destruction of obsolete records); or 
(3)  A destruction request is filed with and approved by the director and librarian as provided by Section 203.045 (destruction of unscheduled records) of Subtitle C, Title 6, Local Government Code and section 2-223 of this article for a record not listed on an approved control schedule. 
(b)  The following records may be destroyed without meeting the conditions of this section: 
(1)  Records the destruction or obliteration of which is directed by an expunction order issued by a district court pursuant to state law. 
(2)  Records defined as exempt from schedule or filing requirements by rules adopted by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 12), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-223. - Destruction of unscheduled records. 
(a)  Before the filing of a records control schedule with the director and librarian, the city shall destroy records only with the prior approval of the director and librarian. 
(b)  After the filing of a records control schedule as provided by this article, a record that does not appear on a records control schedule or amended schedule accepted for filing may be destroyed only with the prior approval of the director and librarian. 
(c)  Requests for authorization to destroy unscheduled records shall be submitted to the director and librarian by the records management officer or under the officer's direction. If the director and librarian approves the request, the records listed on it may be destroyed. Should the request not be approved, the director and librarian's instruction on the records' further retention shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 13), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-224. - Litigation and open records requests. 
(a)  Regardless of any other provision of this article or rules adopted under it, a city record, the subject matter of which is known by the custodian to be in litigation, may not be destroyed until the litigation is settled. 
(b)  Regardless of any other provisions of this article or rules adopted under it, a city record subject to an open records request under Chapter 424, Acts of the 63rd Legislature, Regular Session, 1973 (Article 6252-17a, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes), may not be destroyed until the request is resolved. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 14), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-225. - Method of destruction. 
(a)  A city record may be destroyed by burning, shredding, pulping, or burial in a landfill or by sale or donation for recycling purposes; however, those records to which public access is restricted under Chapter 414, Acts of the 63rd Legislature, Regular Session, 1973 (Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes), or other state law may be destroyed only by burning, pulping, or shredding. 
(b)  Should the city sell or donate records for recycling purposes, a procedure shall be established ensuring that the records are rendered unrecognizable as city records by the recycler. 
(c)  The director and librarian may approve other methods of destruction that render the records unrecognizable as city records. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 15), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-226. - Alienation of records prohibited. 
(a)  A city record may not be sold or donated (except for the purposes of recycling), loaned, transferred, or otherwise passed out of the custody of the city to any private college or university, private museum or library, private organization of any type, or any individual, except with the consent of the director and librarian and at the expiration of its retention period under the city's records control schedule. 
(b)  The above paragraph does not apply to the city temporarily transferring to a person for the purposes of microfilming, duplicating, converting to electronic media, restoring or similar records management and preservation procedures if the transfer is authorized by the records management officer. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 16), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-227. - Right of recovery. 
The city may demand and receive from any person any city records in private possession created or received by the city the removal of which was not authorized by law. Recovery under this section shall be pursuant to Subtitle C, Title 6, Local Government Code, Chapter 201, Section 202.005. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 17), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-228. - Destruction of nonrecord material. 
(a)  Material that is not included in the definition of a city record and is described by Subtitle C, Title 6, Local Government Code, Chapter 201, Section 201.003(8)(A), (B) or (c) and Subsection (1), (2) or (3) of Section 2-211 of this article may be disposed of at the discretion of the custodian or the creator of the document, as applicable, subject to any policies developed by the city regarding the destruction. 
(b)  Extra identical copies of a city record to which public access is restricted under Chapter 424, Acts of the 63rd Legislature, Regular Session, 1973 (Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes), or other state law may be destroyed only by burning, pulping or shredding. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 18), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-229. - Recordkeeping requirements. 
The records management officer shall keep accurate lists of records destroyed, their volume, and other information of records management activities. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 19), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-230. - Records center. 
A records center, developed pursuant to the plan required by section 2-220 shall be under the direct control and supervision of the records management officer. Policies and procedures regulating the operations and use of the records center shall be contained in the records management plan developed under section 2-220. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 20), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-231. - Micrographs. 
(a)  Unless a micrographics program in a department is specifically exempted by order of the city council, all microfilming of records will be centralized and under the direct supervision of the records management officer. The records management plan will establish policies and procedures for the microfilming of city records, including policies to ensure that all microfilming is done in accordance with standards and procedures for the microfilming of local government records established in rules of the commission. The plan will also establish criteria for determining the eligibility of records for microfilming, and protocols for ensuring that a microfilming program that is exempted from the centralized operation is, nevertheless, subject to periodic review by the records management officer as to cost-effectiveness, administrative efficiency, and compliance with commission rules. 
(b)  Microfilm shall mean roll microfilm, microfiche and all other formats produced by any method of microphotography or other means of miniaturization on film. Microfilming shall mean the method, procedures and processes used to produce roll microfilm, microfiche or other microphotographic formats. 
(c)  Destruction of original records that have been microfilmed shall be in compliance with state laws. A list of originals of microfilmed records destroyed shall be filed with the records management officer and the microfilmed record shall be retained until the expiration of the retention period of the original record. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 21), 12-26-90)  
Sec. 2-232. - Personal liability. 
The custodian of city records, records management officer, records assistant, or other officer or employee of the city may not be held personally liable for the destruction of a city record if the destruction is in compliance with this article and state law. 
(Ord. No. 90-250, § 1(Exh. A, § 22), 12-26-90)  
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Purchase, possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages by minors at drive-in restaurants, § 20-56; taxes required to be paid prior to issuance of license or permit, § 26-1 et seq.; disposition of alcoholic beverages in possession of police department, § 30-67. 
 
Sec. 3-1. - License to manufacture, sell, distribute, etc. 
(a)  No person shall manufacture, sell, distribute, or store any intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or other alcoholic beverage, or engage in any other activity with relation to same for which a permit or license is required by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, within the city, without first obtaining a license so to do from the city. The fee for such license shall be the maximum fee which the city is authorized, by state law, to collect. 
(b)  Terms of license. 
(1)  A license issued under the terms of this section shall terminate one year from the date issued, and no license shall be issued for a longer term than one year. 
(2)  The applicant shall present a valid and current State of Texas permit or license, as required by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code as a necessary prerequisite to obtaining a city license. 
(3)  A city license or permit issued under this section shall be dated so as to coincide with those dates on the state permit or license and must be renewed on or before ten (10) days following the expiration date. 
(c)  Any violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor, and any person, upon conviction of any such violation, shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and each and every day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1964, § 3-1; Ord. No. 67-1911, 2-14-67; Ord. No. 67-2075, 12-12-67; Ord. No. 68-65, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 74-270, § 1, 12-17-79; Ord. No. 83-236, § 1, 9-6-83)  
Sec. 3-2. - License fees for liquor, distilled spirits, malt, and vinous liquors. 
The city building official is hereby authorized and directed to collect a fee from each person holding any license or permit issued by the State of Texas under the authority of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code. 
The amount of such fee to be collected by the building official shall be the maximum fee permitted by the most current versions of §§ 11.38 and 61.36 of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code or their statutory successors for the particular license or permit issued by the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 71-356, § 1, 11-30-71; Ord. No. 83-236, § 1, 9-6-83; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03; Ord. No. 06-013, § 1, 1-31-06)  
Sec. 3-3. - License fees for beer. 
The city building official is hereby authorized and directed to collect a fee from each person holding any license or permit issued by the State of Texas under the authority of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code. 
The amount of such fee to be collected by the building official shall be the maximum fee permitted by the most current versions of §§ 11.38 and 61.36 of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code or their statutory successors for the particular license or permit issued by the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 71-356, § 1, 11-30-71; Ord. No. 83-236, § 1, 9-6-83; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03; Ord. No. 06-013, § 2, 1-31-06)  
Sec. 3-4. - License issuance prohibited in certain areas. 
(a)  The sale of alcoholic beverages by a dealer whose place of business is within three hundred (300) feet of a church, public school, or public hospital is prohibited. 
(b)  The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the church or public hospital shall be along the property lines of the street fronts and from front door to front door, and in direct line across intersections. The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the public school shall be from the nearest property line of the public school to the nearest doorway by which the public may enter the place of business, along street lines and in direct line across intersections. For any permit or license covering a premises where minors are prohibited from entering the premises under Section 109.53 of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code, the measurement of the distance between the premises and a public school shall be along the property lines of the street fronts and from front door to front door, and in direct line across intersections. 
(c)  Every applicant for an original alcoholic beverage license or permit for a location with a door by which the public may enter the place of business of the applicant that is within one thousand (1,000) feet of the nearest property line of a public school, measuring along street lines and directly across intersections, must give written notice of the application to officials of the public school before filing the application with the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission. A copy of the notice must be submitted to the Commission with the application; provided however this subsection (c) does not apply to a permit or license covering a premise where minors are prohibited from entering the premises under Section 109.53 of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code. 
(d)  As to any dealer who held a license or permit on September 1, 1983, in a location where a regulation under this section was in effect on that date, for the purposes of subsection (a), but not subsection (c), of this section, the measurement of the distance between the place of business of the dealer and a public school shall be along the property lines of the street fronts and from front door to front door, and in direct line across intersections. This subsection applies only as long as the place of business is continuously in operation from that date, whether or not under the same license or permit. 
(e)  The city council may also allow variances to the regulation provided in subsection (a) if the city council determines that enforcement of the regulation in a particular instance is not in the best interest of the public, constitutes waste or inefficient use of land or other resources, creates an undo hardship on an applicant for a license or permit, does not serve its intended purpose, is not effective or necessary, or for any other reason the city council, after consideration of the health, safety, and welfare of the public and the equities of the situation, determines is in the best interest of the community. 
(f)  Any variances requested under subsection (e) of this section shall be filed with the city secretary and copies of the requested variance sent to city council. The petition for variance filed with the city secretary shall state the following: 
(1)  That a variance of subsection (a) of section 3-4 of the Code of Ordinances is requested. 
(2)  A general statement of the facts the petitioner will show that the enforcement of the regulation in a particular instance is not in the best interest of the public, constitutes waste or inefficient use of land or other resources, creates an undo hardship on an applicant for a license or permit, does not serve its intended purpose, is not effective or necessary, or any other reason the city council after consideration of the health, safety, and welfare of the public and equities of the situation should determine that the variance is in the best interest of the community. 
(g)  The city council shall set a hearing at a city council meeting, not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days after the petition has been filed with the city secretary for the purpose of hearing the petitioner and determining whether a variance should be permitted. After hearing the evidence of the petitioner and any witnesses from the community at large, city council shall, by motion, determine whether or not to grant the variance. Approval of a variance requires a majority vote of the council as in other cases. 
(Ord. No. 77-237, § 1, 12-20-77; Ord. No. 83-198, § 1, 7-26-83)  
Chapter 4 - AMBULANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 83-54, § 1, adopted Feb. 15, 1983, repealed Ch. 4, Art. I, § 4-1 and Art. II, §§ 4-16—4-22, relative to ambulances, and § 2 enacted, in lieu thereof, new §§ 4-1—4-20 to read as herein set out. The former provisions derived from Ord. No. 67-1943, §§ 1—5, adopted April 25, 1967; Ord. No. 67-1982, §§ 2, 3, adopted Aug. 1, 1967 and Ord. No. 80-61, § 1, adopted April 8, 1980. 
Cross reference— Auto wreckers, Ch. 7; traffic, Ch. 36; certain ambulances defined as "authorized emergency vehicles" for traffic purposes, §§ 36-1, 36-13. 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise specified, the term: 
Ambulance means any privately or publicly owned motor vehicle that is specially designed or constructed and equipped and is intended to be used for and is maintained or operated for the transportation of patients. 
Applicant means any person, partnership, corporation or other operator that makes application to obtain a certificate to operate within the city limits. If the applicant is a corporation or partnership, this definition will include all officers or partners. 
Attendant means any person who has the duty of performing or assisting in the performance of an ambulance call and is certified at the minimal level as an emergency medical technician—ambulance by the Texas Department of Health. The same registration shall be current and valid. 
Board of health means the board of health, City of Pasadena, Texas. 
Certification means that which meets the requirements of the Texas Department of Health. 
Chief EMS officer means the chief of emergency medical services, department of public health of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
City means the City of Pasadena, Texas. 
City council means the Pasadena City Council. 
Director means the director of public health of the City of Pasadena or his duly authorized representative. 
Driver's license means the license issued by the department of public safety, State of Texas. 
Emergency means any circumstance that calls for immediate action and in which the element of time in transporting the sick, wounded or injured for medical treatment is essential to the health or life of the person. Said circumstances include, but are not limited to, accidents generally, traffic accidents, acts of violence resulting in personal injury and sudden illness. 
Emergency call means any request for ambulance service that is made by telephone or other means of communication in circumstances which are, or have been represented to be, an emergency requiring immediate ambulance service. 
Emergency medical technician means any person currently registered by the Texas Department of Health as an EMT—Ambulance, EMT—Special Skills, and/or EMT—Paramedic. 
Emergency run means the emergency ambulance trip to the place where the emergency exists or from the place of such emergency to the emergency room of a receiving hospital. 
License means a license or permit issued by the City of Pasadena Health Department pursuant to this chapter. 
Mayor means the mayor of Pasadena, Texas. 
Medical director means any licensed physician who serves in an advisory capacity to any ambulance for the purpose of providing medical direction under the terms of the Medical Practice Act (Article 4495b, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes) and rules promulgated by the Texas State Board of Medical Examiners pursuant to terms of the Medical Practice Act. 
Patient means any person desiring transportation to an appropriate medical facility either on an emergency or transfer basis. 
Person means an individual, corporation, organization, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business, trust, partnership, association or any other legal entity. 
Police means any officer of the City of Pasadena, Texas, Police Department. 
Protocol means written medical orders signed by a licensed physician serving as medical director for an ambulance giving 
medical direction to provide treatment for certain emergencies or other pre-hospital situations requiring physician's orders. These orders must conform to all applicable laws. 
Street means any street, alley, avenue, boulevard, drive or highway commonly used for the purpose of travel within the corporate limits of the city. 
Subcommittee on ambulance services means all members who serve on the subcommittee on ambulance services, board of health, City of Pasadena. 
Transfer ambulance means any motor vehicle constructed, equipped and used for transferring the sick or injured under circumstances which do not constitute an emergency and which have not been represented as an emergency. 
Transfer call means any request for ambulance service that is made by telephone, or other means of communication in circumstances which are or have been represented to be, a nonemergency requiring nonemergency service. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87; Ord. No. 00-110, § 1, 7-25-00)  
Sec. 4-2. - Licenses required. 
(a)  No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise shall operate, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in or profess to be engaged in the business of ambulance service upon the streets, alleys or any public way or place of Pasadena, Texas, unless he holds a currently valid license for an ambulance vehicle and an ambulance company issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  Ambulance vehicle licenses, ambulance company licenses, and attendants' licenses shall be issued one (1) year or any part thereof during which an ambulance service is maintained, and the license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per company shall be due and payable at the time of application; provided, however, that a company shall not be charged a vehicle license fee for more than fifteen (15) vehicles. The licensure period shall be from October first of each year to the 30th day of September of the subsequent year. Any license issued for the period of March first, 2000 to the last day of February, 2001 shall be extended to the last day of September, 2001. 
(c)  No person shall act as an attendant on any ambulance operated under this chapter unless he or she holds a valid attendant's license issued pursuant to this chapter. A twenty-one-day temporary permit may be issued at the time application for permit is submitted to the health department. 
(d)  All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter are not assignable or transferrable and remain the property of the city. 
(e)  No official entry made upon a license may be defaced, removed or obliterated. 
(f)  All licenses shall be available for inspection by any officer of the city at all times. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87; Ord. No. 94-1, § 2, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 00-110, § 1, 7-25-00)  
Sec. 4-3. - Application for ambulance license. 
(a)  Application for an ambulance vehicle license and ambulance company license shall be made upon a form furnished by the chief EMS officer who shall issue such a license to an applicant only upon proof by the applicant that the applicant has satisfied all provisions and conditions provided for and has given complete and truthful information to all requirements stated herein. 
(b)  The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant and of the owner of the ambulance; 
(2)  The trade or other fictitious name, if any, under which the applicant does business or proposes to do business; 
(3)  A complete report on whether or not the applicant has any claims or judgments against him for damages resulting from the negligent operation of the applicant's ambulance(s); 
(4)  A report that the applicant business has paid all city taxes; 
(5)  Business address and medical license number of medical director; 
(6)  A description of each ambulance, including the make, model, year of manufacture, motor and chassis number, current state license number, the length of time the ambulance has been in use, and the color scheme, insignia, name, monogram, or other distinguishing characteristics to be used to designate applicant's ambulance; 
(7)  Any such other information as may be applicable. 
(c)  No application will be considered before it is complete. 
(d)  Falsification of information on applications will be grounds for revocation of license. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 94-1, § 2, 1-11-94)  
Sec. 4-4. - Standards for ambulance license. 
(a)  Each ambulance shall, at all times when in use as such, be suitable for the transportation of patient from the standpoint of health, sanitation and safety. 
(b)  Minimum equipment requirements for each ambulance shall be those established by the Texas Department of Health. 
(c)  When an ambulance permit is issued or renewed under provisions of this chapter, the chief EMS officer will affix to each vehicle two (2) decals which indicate the vehicle meets all requirements established by this chapter. The color of such decals shall be changed annually. 
(d)  The chief EMS officer or his duly authorized representative shall cause all ambulances to be inspected before being placed in service and shall thereafter inspect such ambulances no less than once each year and at least two (2) times per year on a spot inspection basis. In the event an ambulance fails to pass inspection, the chief EMS officer shall notify the ambulance operator to correct the defects noted in the inspection and, after such notification, the chief shall cause such ambulance to be reinspected within forty-eight (48) hours. If upon such reinspection the defects noted in the original inspection have not been corrected, the vehicle decals shall be removed from the ambulance and shall only be replaced upon such ambulance after the defects have been corrected. The license fee shall be paid in full for the balance of current year of the original vehicle decal provided. 
(e)  No ambulance that has been substantially damaged or altered, or has received damage the repair cost of which exceeds five hundred dollars ($500.00), shall be again placed in service until it has been repaired and reinspected by the chief EMS officer. No charge for reinspection. 
(f)  Every ambulance must be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(g)  On any emergency call authorized by the city dispatcher, the operator shall not delay in dispatching personnel and equipment to the location authorized. 
(h)  Effective September 1, 2010, ambulance providers licensed to operate in the City of Pasadena shall provide to the city department of health, the licensing entity, a monthly activity report containing the number of calls of ambulance transports originating within the City of Pasadena 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87; Ord. No. 10-172, § 1, 8-10-10)  
Sec. 4-5. - Requirements for business location. 
If the business location of the ambulance service, firm or organization is located within the city limits, the building must be in compliance with all city ordinances, state and federal laws. Pursuant to this specific chapter, no such ambulance service, firm or organization can operate as its main place of business or a storage facility in a private residence. The chief EMS officer has the right to inspect such locations as often as he deems necessary to make sure all provisions of this chapter are in effect. Refusal of any ambulance provided with a business office located within the city limits to allow the chief EMS officer to inspect such premises shall be considered a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-6. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  No ambulance license shall be issued under this chapter, nor shall such license be valid after issuance, nor shall any ambulance be operated for any reason in the city, unless there is at all times in force and effect insurance coverage, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Texas, for each and every ambulance owned and/or operated by or for the applicant for license providing for the payment of damages: 
(1)  For injury to or death of individuals in accident resulting from any cause for which the owner of said vehicle would be liable on account of liability imposed on him by law, regardless of whether the ambulance was being driven by the owner or his agent. 
(2)  For the loss of or damages to the property of another, including personal property, under like circumstances, in the following sums: Not less that one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each accident and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for property damage. A written statement from an authorized agent of the ambulance operator(s) insurance carrier verifying the issuance of such insurance shall be filed with the chief EMS officer before any permit may be issued. All such verifications of insurance shall provide for a thirty-day cancellation notice to the chief EMS officer. 
(3)  Every insurance policy required hereunder shall contain a provision for a continuing liability thereunder to the full amount thereof not withstanding any recovery thereon, that the liability of the insurer shall not be affected by the insolvency or the bankruptcy of the assured, in that until the policy is revoked the insurance company will not be relieved from liability on account of nonpayment of premium, failure to renew license at the end of the year, or any act or admission of the named assured. Such policy of insurance shall be further conditioned for the payment of any judgments up to the limits of said policy, recovered against any person other than the owner, by his agent or employee, who may operate the same with the consent or acquiescence of the owner. 
(b)  Each attendant involved in the operation of an ambulance within the city limits shall be required to carry at all times professional liability insurance. 
(1)  This coverage must be from an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Texas for each and every person operating within the city limits of Pasadena. 
(2)  The limits of liability required are no less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per claim and a one million dollar ($1,000,000.00) aggregate umbrella policy. 
(3)  It shall be the responsibility of each person to provide to the chief EMS officer proof of such insurance. 
(4)  Failure to provide proof of insurance will be justification to suspend and/or not issue any attendant, driver and/or ambulance permit. 
(5)  The City of Pasadena Health Department must be notified within twenty-four (24) hours of any cancellation of insurance coverage. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 4-7. - Application for attendant and driver's license. 
(a)  Applications for attendant and driver's licenses hereunder shall be made upon such form as may be prepared by the EMS division and shall contain the following information which is a requirement for the issuance of a license. 
(1)  The applicant's full name, current address, how long he has lived at current address, previous address, how long he lived at previous address, home telephone number, and social security number. 
(2)  The applicant's age, date of birth, height, weight, place of birth, hair and eye color. 
(3)  The applicant's Texas chauffeur's license number, and expiration date. 
(4)  The applicant's present EMS certification level, appropriate Texas Department of Health registration number and expiration date. 
(5)  Two (2) recent photographs of a size designated by the chief EMS officer which shall be attached to the license application. 
(6)  A report from a duly licensed physician of the State of Texas of a recent physical examination which attests that the person has vision in both eyes correctable to 20/20 and has no physical defects which would impair his or her ability to perform the duties of an ambulance attendant. 
(7)  Such other information as the chief EMS officer shall deem reasonably necessary to a fair determination of compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  The chief EMS officer shall within twenty-one (21) days of receipt of a completed application for an attendant's license investigate the application and issue the license or notify the applicant that the application is denied. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-8. - Standards for attendant and driver's license. 
(a)  All attendants and drivers must be able to read, write and speak the English language. 
(b)  All drivers must have a valid Texas driver's license. (Class A, B, or C). 
(c)  All attendants and drivers must hold current certification from the Texas Department of Health as an emergency medical technician. 
(d)  No attendant or driver shall have a final conviction for theft, robbery, state or federal controlled substances acts, rape, sexual abuse, indecency with a child, or abuse of a corpse. 
(e)  No attendant or driver shall have been convicted of three (3) or more moving violations within the preceding two-year period. 
(f)  All attendants and drivers shall have vision correctable to 20/20 in both eyes and shall have no physical limitations which would impair their ability to perform the duties of an ambulance attendant. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 4-9. - Renewal of license. 
Renewal of any license hereunder, upon expiration or after revocation, shall require conformance with all requirements of this chapter as upon original licensing. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-10. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The chief EMS officer may, and is hereby authorized to, suspend or revoke a license issued hereunder for failure of a licensee to comply and to maintain compliance with, or for his violation of, any applicable provisions, standards or requirements of this chapter, or of regulations promulgated hereunder, or of any other applicable laws or ordinances, but only after warning and such reasonable time for compliance as may be set by the chief EMS officer. Any applicant denied a license or any licensee whose license is suspended or revoked shall have the right of appeal to the director, department of public health. Such appeal shall be submitted to the director in writing within ten (10) days of the action being appealed. The director shall, within ten (10) days after appeal is filed, consider all the evidence in support of or against the ruling appealed from and render a decision either sustaining, reversing, or modifying the determination of the chief EMS officer. 
(b)  If the director's, department of public health, decision is not acceptable to the applicant or licensee, he may, within ten (10) days of that decision, file an appeal in writing with the city secretary to the city council. Such a written appeal shall set forth the specific grounds therefor. The city secretary shall notify the appellant within ten (10) days after receipt of appeal as to the time and place of the hearing by the city council, which shall be within thirty (30) days of receipt of such appeal. The determination of the city council on any appeal pursuant to this chapter shall be final. 
(c)  Upon suspension, revocation or termination of an ambulance license hereunder, such ambulance shall cease operation as such and no person shall permit such ambulance to continue operations as such. Upon suspension, revocation or termination of attendant's or driver's license hereunder, such attendant or driver shall cease to drive or attend an ambulance and no person shall employ or permit such individual to drive or attend an ambulance. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-11. - Medical director to serve in an advisory capacity. 
(a)  Any ambulance whose attendant receives physicians' orders either by telemetry or written standing orders must have, in an advisory capacity, a physician, licensed in the State of Texas and registered in Harris County, to serve as medical director. 
(b)  Any ambulance licensed under this chapter must maintain with the chief EMS officer a statement of their current medical director including his or her name, business address, business telephone number, and Texas medical license number; and the federal narcotics license number if any drugs or supplies are prescribed by this physician. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-12. - Inspection of ambulances.
