(a)  Subsequent to issuance of any ambulance license hereunder, the chief EMS officer shall cause to be inspected each such licensed vehicle, its equipment, premises and personnel, whenever he deems such inspection to be necessary but in any event no less frequently than twice each year and shall promptly report his findings in a written report to the health director. The periodic inspection required hereunder shall be in addition to any other safety or motor vehicle inspection required to be made for ambulance or other motor vehicles in the State of Texas, or other inspections required to be made, under general laws and ordinances, and shall not excuse compliance with any requirements of law and ordinance to display any official certificate of motor vehicle inspection at all times. 
(b)  A copy of each initial, semiannual, spot or other ambulance, equipment, premises and personnel inspection report submitted by the chief EMS officer to the health director under the provisions of this section shall be promptly transmitted to the applicant or licensee to whom it refers. 
(c)  The chief EMS officer may immediately suspend any of the licenses issued under this chapter if an inspection reveals violations or deficiencies that might endanger a patient or the public. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-13. - Central emergency dispatching system. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any ambulance to respond to an emergency call without receiving permission from the city's central dispatching system. 
(b)  If any person receives any request for ambulance service on an emergency basis other than through the city's central dispatching system; it is the obligation of that person to immediately report the same to the city central dispatching system and not proceed until cleared by the same dispatcher. 
(c)  It shall not be unlawful for a person operating a licensed transfer ambulance in the city, upon responding to a direct call for nonemergency transfer ambulance service, to operate such ambulance under emergency conditions, using emergency equipment, after notifying the city central dispatching dispatcher and requesting permission to make an emergency run, when a determination is made by the senior ambulance attendant that a true emergency exists, as defined in this chapter, requiring the sick or injured person to be transported with all practical speed to a hospital. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-14. - Triage: Multiple casualty emergency call. 
(a)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of the senior certified medical person to conduct medical triage at a scene involving the transport and pre-hospital care of patients requiring transport to an appropriate medical facility by more than one ambulance. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of all ambulances to follow all triage directives given by the senior certified medical person. 
(c)  The senior certified medical person shall not delegate this duty unless he is ordered to do so by a licensed physician who is willing to take responsibility for all patients at the scene of the triage. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 4-15. - Uniform emergency run records. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of each emergency ambulance operating within the city to use at all times run records that are approved by the subcommittee on ambulance services, board of health. 
(b)  A copy of the run record on any 911 calls made within the city must be submitted to the chief EMS officer. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 4-16. - Variances to chapter requirements. 
(a)  An affected person or organization may request a variance from the licensure requirements of this chapter if the person satisfies one (1) or more of the specific criteria listed in subsection (d). 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the subcommittee on ambulance services, board of health to grant such a variance. 
(c)  The variance must specify the specific licensure requirements and/or fees being waived. 
(d)  The criteria for variance are as follows: 
(1)  The person has transported a sick or injured person to medical care as an individual citizen not ordinarily engaged in that activity; 
(2)  The person transports a sick or injured person in a multiple casualty situation that exceeds the capacity of the emergency medical services available; 
(3)  The person is a member of an organization and the person's function is to transport members of that same organization to an appropriate medical facility at no charge to the individual being transferred; and that same organization does not solicit business outside itself or provide service to any other organization except in a multiple casualty situation; 
(4)  The vehicle or person is moving through the city on a call that neither originates nor ends within the city; 
(5)  The organization is principally an air transport system; 
(6)  The organization or vehicle is licensed by the state as a "specialized emergency medical services vehicle" and is designed to provide service patients with special needs not easily met by other transport services; 
(7)  The organization is an agency or designated provider of a municipal government. 
(e)  A variance shall not be granted unless it is necessary to assure the availability of quality care to the citizens of the city. 
(f)  A variance shall not be granted unless all ambulance units and personnel meet the minimum standards set by the state health department. 
(g)  The city council reserves the right to reserve the decision of the subcommittee on ambulance services in granting or refusing a variance. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 83-264, § 1, 9-27-83; Ord. No. 84-54, § 1, 3-20-84)  
Sec. 4-17. - Standards for emergency ambulance transfer rates. 
(a)  The city council shall set standards for the determination of all charges relating to the transport of patients on an emergency basis. Such standards shall include the following: 
(1)  A breakdown of the actual cost of providing emergency ambulance service by each transfer ambulance company licensed to operate in the city. 
(2)  Such financial evidence as needed by the subcommittee for ambulance services to determine an adequate percentage of profit to be included in the emergency ambulance transfer rate. 
(3)  Any other financial information as deemed necessary by the subcommittee for ambulance services. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the subcommittee for ambulance services to review all fees annually. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-18. - Standards for reimbursement for indigent emergency ambulance transfer service. 
(a)  The city agrees to reimburse private provider for the emergency transport of those persons who are unable to pay for emergency ambulance transportation. 
(b)  The city will only reimburse for those calls that are dispatched by the city's central dispatching system, and will reimburse at the rates provided in section 4-20 of this chapter. 
(c)  The provider shall make diligent effort to collect charges from customers for emergency back-up ambulance calls dispatched by the city to the provider. The procedure for collecting such accounts shall include the initial billing to the customer shortly after such service is rendered. A second billing no later than thirty (30) days following the rendition of such service shall be sent to the customer and a third billing no later than sixty (60) days after initial service is rendered. If unpaid balance still remains outstanding, at the end of ninety (90) days of the rendition of service, the provider will turn unpaid balance over to the division of emergency medical services, department of public health of the city for reimbursement. 
(d)  It is specifically understood and agreed by the parties hereto that the city will not make reimbursement to the provider for any delinquent accounts involving nonemergency transfer service. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-19. - Contractual agreement required. 
(a)  Each licensed transfer ambulance company who desires to provide back-up emergency service must have a written contractual agreement between the city and itself. 
(b)  If the licensed transfer ambulance company does not secure a contractual agreement; the name of said company will not be placed on the city's back-up emergency ambulance dispatching list. 
(c)  Ambulance companies currently in the city's central dispatching rotation list will be given first consideration to apply for a contractual agreement, as stated herein. Any additional companies who desire to secure a contractual agreement must show a public need and necessity. Each company must present their application for a contractual agreement to the subcommittee for ambulance services, board of health, and their recommendation will be made to city council for any additional companies to operate within the city limits. The subcommittee for ambulance services will develop criteria in order to determine an equable need and necessity for the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83)  
Sec. 4-20. - Fees for emergency transport. 
Each patient, attended or transported by a 911 call shall not be charged in excess of fees approved by city council. 
(Ord. No. 83-54, § 2, 2-15-83; Ord. No. 87-220, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Chapter 5 - AMUSEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, Ch. 24; swimming pools, Ch. 33; authority of chief of police to close places of amusement, § 30-3. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 5-1—5-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - THEATERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Authority of chief of police to close theaters, § 30-3. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 5-16. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein: 
Drive-in theater. The term "drive-in theater" means any premises in which motion pictures are projected upon a screen or theatrical performances are given for viewing by patrons seated in automobiles or other vehicles, and which is open to the public. 
Shall. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
Theater. A "theater" is any premise in which motion pictures are projected upon a screen or a theatrical performance is given for viewing by patrons and which is open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 1, 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 1, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-17. - Compliance with article. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner/operator to operate a theater in the city without complying with the requirements and standards prescribed in this article. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9, 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-18. - Report of violations of article. 
The chief of police or the building official shall report all violations of this article, or the failure or refusal of any owner/operator to comply with any of the provisions of this article, to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 10, 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-19. - Penalty for violations of article. 
Any person who shall violate, or allow or cause any person to violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for such offense. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 11, 6-12-70; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Sec. 5-20. - Police officers' right of entry. 
Officers of the police department are hereby authorized and empowered to enter the premises of any theater within the city, at any time, for the purpose of inspection and for the preservation of law and order, and to determine whether or not the provisions of this article are being complied with. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B10), 6-12-70)  
Sec. 5-21. - Access to public streets. 
The owner/operator shall provide access available from a theater to public streets or other public ways from at least two (2) points at all times. Such means of access shall be kept clear by the owner/operator at all times to facilitate departure of persons from the premises upon which the theater is operated and to permit entrance of fire apparatus or other emergency equipment in case of emergency. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B1), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-22. - Driveways at drive-in. 
Driveways on the premises of a drive-in theater shall be channelized by the owner/operator and limited to not more than four (4) lanes to control traffic. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B1), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-23. - Lighting of exits. 
Theater exits, and aisles and passageways leading to them, shall be kept adequately lighted by the owner/operator at all times when open to the public. The owner/operator shall provide artificial light whenever natural light is inadequate. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B2), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-24. - Electrical installations. 
Except as otherwise provided by law or city ordinance, the owner/operator shall provide, for the theater, electrical installations conforming to the requirements of the electrical code of the city. The electrical system shall be installed, maintained and operated in a safe and workmanlike manner. The electrical system and equipment shall be isolated from the public by proper elevation or guarding, and all electrical fuses and switches shall be enclosed in approved enclosures. Cables on the ground in areas traversed by the public shall be placed in trenches or protected by approved covers. The electrical installations shall be inspected and approved by the electrical inspector before the theater is opened to the public and shall thereafter be open to inspection by the electrical inspector at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B3), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75) 
Cross reference— Electrical code, Ch. 12.  
Sec. 5-25. - Fire extinguishing equipment. 
Fire extinguishing equipment shall be furnished by the owner/operator for each theater, in such amount and in such locations as may be directed by the fire marshal. Fire extinguishing equipment shall be inspected and approved by the fire marshal before the theater is opened to the public and shall thereafter be open to inspection by the fire marshal at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B4), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection generally, Ch. 13.  
Sec. 5-26. - Sanitary facilities. 
Adequate and proper sanitary facilities, approved by the department of health, shall be provided by the owner/operator for each theater. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B5), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-27. - Attendants. 
At all times when a theater is open to the public, the owner/operator shall provide an adequate number of qualified attendants on duty at all times, who shall patrol the aisles, exits, entrances and parking spaces to see that order is maintained, that disorderly or immoral conduct is prevented, that the entrances and exits are kept free from congestion, and that this article and all other governing ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to theaters are observed. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B6), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-28. - Wall or fence for drive-ins. 
Should the owner/operator of any drive-in theater desire to provide a wall or fence of adequate height to screen the patrons and cars in attendance at the drive-in theater from the view of surrounding property, such wall or fence shall be of a design and structure complying with the building code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B7), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75) 
Cross reference— Permit to build or enlarge fence or wall, § 9-3; building code, § 9-62 et seq.  
Sec. 5-29. - Individual loudspeakers required at drive-ins. 
In drive-in theaters, individual loudspeakers for each car shall be provided and no central loudspeaker shall be permitted by the owner/operator. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B8), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-30. - Concessions. 
Any sale of soft drinks, confections or other articles of merchandise on the premises where any theater is operated shall be governed by the laws and ordinances governing such business and shall require the same license as if such sales were conducted elsewhere. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(B9), 6-12-70)  
Sec. 5-31. - Maintenance of quiet and good order; loitering prohibited. 
The owner/operator shall maintain quiet and good order upon the premises where any theater is operated and shall not permit loitering of persons in or about the entrances to or exits from such theater. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(A1), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Sec. 5-32. - Nude scenes visible from street or highway. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner/operator, ticket seller, ticket taker, usher, motion picture operator and any other person connected with or employed by any owner/operator to show or exhibit, at a theater in the city, or to aid or assist in such exhibition, any motion picture, slide, or other exhibit which is visible from any public street or highway in which the bare buttocks or the bare female breasts of the human body are shown or in which striptease, burlesque or nudist-type scenes constitute the main or primary material of such movie, slide or exhibit. 
(Ord. No. 70-123, § 9(A2), 6-12-70; Ord. No. 75-116, § 2, 7-1-75)  
Secs. 5-33—5-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED 
 
Secs. 5-41—5-61. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 75-116, § 3, adopted July 1, 1975, repealed Div. 2, §§ 5-41—5-50, which pertained to licenses. Said division had been derived from Ord. No. 70-123, §§ 2—8, 10, 11, adopted June 12, 1970.  
ARTICLE III. - BILLIARD HALLS AND DOMINO HALLS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate billiard halls, V.A.T.S. Tax.-Gen. art. 19.01 (10). 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 5-62. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Billiard hall. A "billiard hall," is any room, hall, building, or part of a building, tent or other enclosure, or any enclosed or partially enclosed space, in which is exhibited for hire, revenue, fee or gain of any kind any pool table or billiard table, stand or structure of any kind, on which may be played pool or billiards, or any game similar to pool or billiards, played with balls or cues, or both, or a similar device. 
Billiard hall and domino hall operator. A "billiard hall operator" or "domino hall operator" is any person owning, leasing, managing or in any manner controlling the operation of a billiard hall or domino hall, as the case may be. 
Billiard or pool table. The term "billiard table" or "pool table" shall mean and include any table surrounded by a ledge or cushion, with or without pockets, upon which balls are impelled by a stick or cue, or where the player thereon does not or is not required to make a coin deposit causing an electrical device of any kind or nature to be activated before such game may be actually commenced. 
Domino hall. A "domino hall" is any room, hall, building, or part of a building, tent, or enclosure of any kind, or any enclosed or partially enclosed space, in which the playing of dominoes is permitted, for a fee or gain of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. I, § 1, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-63. - Operators not to permit violations of article. 
The operator or person in charge of any billiard hall or domino table shall not permit a violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. I, § 5, 11-14-69)  
Sec. 5-64. - Penalty for violations of article. 
Any person who shall violate, or allow or cause any person under his control to violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. IV, § 2, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Sec. 5-65. - Police officers' right of entry. 
Officers of the police department are hereby authorized and empowered to enter, at any time, for the purposes of inspection and for the preservation of law and order, any billiard hall or domino hall within the city. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. I, § 4, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-66. - Hours of operation. 
Billiard halls and/or domino halls shall not be open except during the following hours: 
(1)  Mondays through Fridays, 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. 
(2)  Saturdays, 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. 
(3)  Sundays, 1:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m. No person shall play billiards therein except during such hours. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. III, § 1, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 71-212, § 1, 7-27-71; Ord. No. 74-76, § 1, 4-16-74)  
Sec. 5-67. - Unobstructed view to interior. 
Every billiard hall and domino hall shall have unobstructed windows or open space on at least one side, so that the area is open to view by members of the public passing by on a public street, or using a corridor, lobby or other room to which the public resorts and is admitted without charge. The operator of such hall shall not permit any obstruction of such public view by the use of drawn shades, blinds, screens, partitions or other structures. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. III, § 2, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-68. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 90-127, § 1, adopted July 24, 1990, repealed § 5-68 which pertained to vagrants, prostitutes and known police characters and derived from Ord. No. 69-195, Art. III, § 3, adopted Nov. 4, 1969.  
Sec. 5-69. - Gambling prohibited. 
No person shall gamble, wager or bet or cause any person to gamble, wager or bet, on the outcome of billiard or domino games in a billiard or domino hall, nor shall any operator, employee, licensee or owner of such a hall allow any person to gamble, wager or bet on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. III, § 4, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-70. - Minors prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall be allowed on the premises to play pool, billiards or dominoes in a billiard or domino hall, unless such minor is accompanied by his parent or his legal guardian. It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be either the parent or the legal guardian of a minor, for the purpose of evading the provisions of this section. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a billiard hall or domino hall for which a Class C license has been issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. I, § 3, 11-4-69)  
Secs. 5-71—5-76. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 5-77. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a billiard hall or domino hall having more than one (1) billiard table or domino table therein, unless the billiard hall or domino hall shall first have been licensed by the building official for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 1a, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to license billiard halls, V.A.T.S. Tax-Gen. art. 19.01 (10).  
Sec. 5-78. - Classification. 
Billiard hall and domino hall licenses shall be of four (4) classes as follows: 
(1)  A Class A license is intended for places having four (4) or more billiard tables or domino tables. 
(2)  A Class B license is intended for places in which only coin-operated pool tables or billiard tables are supplied and their use resembles that of other coin-operated amusement devices. A Class B license shall be issued for coin-operated billiard tables only and the licensee may operate no more than ten (10) billiard tables on the premises. 
(3)  A Class C license is intended for those places certified as suitable for minors in accord with section 5-83. 
(4)  A Class D license is intended for those places having three (3) or less pool or billiard tables. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, §§ 1b, 1c, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-79. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring a license to operate a billiard hall or domino hall shall file with the building official a written sworn application, upon forms furnished by the building official, for such license, which application shall state the following: 
(1)  The location, by street and number, of the place or building. 
(2)  The name, age, residence address and citizenship of the applicant. 
(3)  If the applicant is a firm, association or partnership, all the information required of an individual applicant shall be required of each individual member of the firm, association or partnership. 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, that it is organized and chartered under the corporate laws of this state applicable to such corporation, or, if a foreign corporation, that it has complied with the laws of this state applicable to such corporation, and the same information with reference to the operator or person in charge of the operation of the billiard hall or domino hall to be licensed as is prescribed for an individual applicant. Such information shall also be given as to each person owning twenty per cent (20%) or more of the capital stock. The application shall give the state of incorporation and the address of the principal office and the corporation's agent for service of citation. 
(5)  Each individual named on the application shall swear that he is a law-abiding citizen and shall state whether he has ever been convicted of a felony or an offense involving moral turpitude, and if he has, shall list the same on the application. 
(6)  Previous occupation or employment of the applicant for a period of five (5) years preceding the filing of his application. 
(7)  Such other and additional information as the chief of police may, from time to time, deem proper and necessary. 
(b)  A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the building official and shall accompany each application for a license under this division. Such fee is nonreturnable if the application for a license is refused. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 1d, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-80. - List of employees to accompany application; fingerprinting and investigation of applicant and employees. 
The applicant for a billiard or domino hall license shall file, along with his application for a license, a sworn list of the persons to be employed by him, giving the name, age, citizenship, residence, and information as to convictions required by an applicant. Each proposed employee and the applicant shall be fingerprinted by the police department, and the chief of police shall determine whether each of the proposed employees and the applicant meet the qualifications required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2a, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-81. - Not to issue in violation of deed restrictions; duty of applicant with respect to deed restrictions. 
(a)  No license shall be granted under the terms of this division for the location of any billiard hall or domino hall where it is prohibited by any deed restrictions recorded in the office of the County Clerk of Harris County. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the applicant for a billiard hall or domino hall license to search the records of the county clerk's office to insure that this type of business is not prohibited by any deed restrictions, and the applicant must file a verified affidavit that the location of the premises for which he is applying for a license is not prohibited by deed restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2e, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-82. - Fees. 
(a)  Class A. The fee for a Class A license under this division shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year per billiard table or domino table. Each such license shall state the number of tables licensed. The licensee may operate more tables by paying an additional fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each additional table per year. 
(b)  Class B. The fee for a Class B license under this division shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per year per coin-operated billiard table. Each such license shall state the number of tables licensed. The licensee may operate more tables by paying an additional fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each additional table per year. 
(c)  Class C. The annual fee for a Class C license under this division shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), except that, where a licensee previously holds a Class A or Class B license, the annual fee for a Class C license shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(d)  Class D. The annual fee for a Class D license under this division shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(e)  Not prorated. No license fee provided for herein shall be prorated. 
(f)  Not refundable. No refund of any license fee paid in accordance with this section shall be made by the city for any cause whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, §§ 1c, 2c, 2g, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-83. - Special provisions relative to Class C licenses. 
(a)  The building official shall not issue a Class C license under this division, unless the chief of police has certified that the billiard or domino hall for which it is to be issued is suitable for minors. The chief of police shall, after a reasonable time for investigation, certify that the establishment is suitable for minors, if the following standards are met: 
(1)  That the applicant has never been guilty of a violation of any provision of this article. 
(2)  That no alcoholic beverages of any kind shall ever be permitted, sold or consumed on the premises. 
(3)  That three (3) signs, at least one (1) foot by three (3) feet in size, stating "No alcoholic beverages allowed on premises," are prominently displayed on the premises. 
(4)  That such billiard hall or domino hall is at least three hundred (300) feet away from any bar or business selling alcoholic beverages of any kind, the measurement to be along the property line of the street front and from front door to front door, and in a direct line across intersections where they occur. 
(5)  That the applicant will operate an orderly place of business, where no unruly behavior is permitted, and that no person under the influence of alcoholic beverages will be allowed on the premises. 
(b)  A Class C license, when issued, shall be for a specified licensee at a specified location. 
(c)  After reasonable notice and opportunity to be heard, the chief of police may revoke or suspend a certificate issued under this section for failure to maintain the standards herein required or any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. I, § 3, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-84. - Appeal from refusal. 
In the event the building official shall refuse to grant a license to any applicant under this division, such action shall be final, unless the applicant shall, within ten (10) days after the refusal to grant such license, file a written appeal with the city secretary addressed to the city council, requesting a hearing upon the question as to whether or not his application shall be granted. In the event such appeal is filed, the building official and the chief of police shall provide the city council with a record of all proceedings theretofore had with reference to the application, including the written application, together with the action of the building official and the chief of police and the reasons for such action. The city council shall, within thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the building official and the chief of police, at which hearing, the council may make such investigation as it may see fit, whether all the pertinent facts appear in the application or not. Within seven (7) days after final adjournment of the hearing, the city council shall cause a written deduction of its judgment thereon to be filed with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2f, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-85. - Posting. 
A license issued under this division shall be posted in a prominent place in the billiard hall or domino hall for which it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. I, § 3, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-86. - Transfer. 
A license issued under this division may be transferred to a different lawful location, upon sworn application and payment of a transfer fee of ten dollars ($10.00). Such a license shall not be transferred to a different licensee. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2b, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-87. - Term; renewal. 
All licenses issued under this division shall be valid from January first through December thirty-first of each calendar year, unless sooner suspended or revoked, and the same must be renewed by January first of each year. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2c, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-88. - Change of employees after issuance. 
After a license is issued under this division, the licensee shall obtain authorization for the employment of any person whom he intends to employ and who has not been previously so authorized for employment. The licensee shall notify the chief of police of the termination of an employee. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2a, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-89. - Changes in members of partnership or corporate officers or stockholders after issuance. 
(a)  A license issued under this division to a partnership is not voided by withdrawal of one or more partners, so long as one of the original partners remains. If a new partner becomes a member of such partnership, a new license is required, unless he already holds a license, and a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) will be charged for the issuance of such new license. 
(b)  A license issued under this division to a corporation is voided if an unqualified person becomes the principal officer or acquires twenty per cent (20%) or more of the capital stock. 
(c)  All changes in the membership of a partnership holding a license under this division, and all changes in the identity of the principal officer of a corporation so licensed or the ownership of twenty per cent (20%) or more of its stock, shall be reported to the chief of police within ten (10) days after they occur, accompanied with a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for the issuance of a new license. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2b, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-90. - Does not grant vested rights. 
No license granted under the terms of this division shall be deemed the granting of a vested right, but such license shall remain subject to the terms and provisions of this article and subject to such future regulations as shall be promulgated by the city council by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. II, § 2h, 11-4-69)  
Sec. 5-91. - Revocation. 
If a person holding a license issued under this division violates any provision of this article, this Code or the laws of the state, or if a billiard hall or domino hall licensed under this division is not being conducted in accordance with this article, this Code and the laws of the state, or is being conducted in violation thereof, the building official may at any time give notice in writing to the operator, licensee, manager, or other person in control of the operation and maintenance of such billiard hall or domino hall that the license issued for the operation and maintenance of such hall has been revoked, stating therein the reason or reasons for such revocation. Such notice of revocation shall become a final revocation after the expiration of ten (10) days from the date of the service of same upon the operator, licensee, manager or other person in charge of the billiard hall or domino hall, unless, on or before the expiration of such ten (10) days, the licensee, operator, manager or other person in charge of the hall shall file with the city secretary a written appeal addressed to the city council, in which it is requested that the city council grant him a hearing upon the question of whether or not the license shall be revoked. Such appeal, if made and filed as prescribed herein, shall operate as a stay or postponement of the revocation, until such time as the city council shall grant a hearing and make final adjudication upon the question of whether or not the license should be revoked. Such hearing shall be held within thirty (30) days after the date of the filing of the appeal. Within seven (7) days after final adjournment of the hearing, the city council shall cause a written deduction of its judgment thereon to be filed with the city secretary. Such action and judgment of the city council, after hearing all the evidence and facts, shall be final and conclusive as to all parties, and shall be, in all cases, by a majority vote. 
(Ord. No. 69-195, Art. I, § 5; Art. II, § 2d; Art. IV, § 2, 11-4-69; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Secs. 5-92—5-102. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DANCE HALLS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Authority of chief of police to close ballrooms, § 30-3; prostitutes, vagrants, drunks, etc., not to attend public dance or dance hall, § 20-40. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 5-103. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Cabaret or nightclub. The term "cabaret" or "nightclub" shall mean any space, structure, building or resort open to the public, enclosed or unenclosed, where food, beer or wine or other alcoholic beverage is served on the premises, including restaurants and cafes, and where patrons are provided with a space for dancing, or are permitted to dance. 
Club. The term "club" shall mean any bona fide nonprofit society, association of persons or corporation, organized for civic, fraternal, social or charitable purposes, or for any purpose not a business or commercial purpose, which owns, rents or operates a place or building for the accommodation of its members, when such place or premises or any part thereof is used for dancing by members of the club, or is rented to others for such purpose. 
Dancing school. The term "dancing school" shall mean any room, place, space or academy in which classes in dancing are held and instruction in dancing is given for hire. 
Incidental to the main business; principal business. The terms "incidental to the main business" and "principal business" shall be construed as being used in the common and ordinary understanding of such terms; provided, however, that any operator or licensee, to be considered as coming within the exceptions provided for in this article, shall show, by a written, sworn statement, that the revenues or money received from the patrons of the dance hall involved, for admission charges, sales of food, beer or wine, or any other charges made within the licensed premises, amounts in dollars and cents to less than fifty-one per cent (51%) of the revenue of money received from all other sources in connection with the operation of the business as a whole, and from any bona fide cabaret or nightclub having an actual seating capacity, including tables and chairs, for three hundred (300) patrons, or more, where vaudeville acts are offered and where food, beer and wine are served. 
Operator or dance hall operator. The term "operator" or "dance hall operator" shall mean the person who conducts, manages, maintains or controls, either directly or indirectly, any dance hall as defined and designated in this article. 
Premises. The term "premises" shall be construed to include all the rooms, spaces, places or buildings which are joined by connecting doors or other openings, or which are so constructed that either or all of such rooms or spaces serve each of the other such rooms or spaces. 
Private dance. The term "private dance" shall mean and include any dance given at any home or any dance given or held and officially sponsored by a bona fide club, admission to which is granted to members and their respective relatives of consanguinity or affinity, or both, or to such members and relatives and one (1) invited guest per member, accompanied by such host-member, and from which the general public is excluded. 
Public dance or public ball. The term "public dance" or "public ball" shall mean any dance or ball to which admission can be had by payment of a fee, or by the purchase, possession or presentation of a ticket or token, or in which a charge is made for caring for clothing, or any other dance to which the public generally may gain admission with the payment of a fee, directly or indirectly, or without payment of a fee. 
Public dance hall. The term "public dance hall" shall mean any one or more rooms, places, spaces or buildings where a public dance is held or conducted. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-1), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 78-98, § 4, 7-5-78)  
Sec. 5-104. - Classification. 
For the purposes of this article, dance halls are hereby designated and rated according to the following classes: 
(1)  Class A. Cabarets and nightclubs are designated and rated as Class A dance halls. 
(2)  Class B. All dance halls not otherwise specifically classified are designated and rated as Class B dance halls. 
(3)  Class C. Dancing schools are designated and rated as Class C dance halls. 
(4)  Class D. Places or buildings owned, rented or operated by a club and used for dancing by members of the club or rented to others for such purpose are designated and rated as Class D dance halls. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-1), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-105. - Designation of inspectors. 
City employees shall be designated as dance hall inspectors, from time to time by directive of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-7), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-106. - Permit for single dances. 
(a)  When any person or club shall hold a single dance in a dance hall licensed under this article, a single dance permit shall be secured from the building official for the holding of such dance, and a fee of three dollars ($3.00) shall be paid therefor. A verified application for such permit shall be made not less than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the time such dance is to be held. Such application shall be signed by the person applying for such permit. The applicant shall present a letter of authority for securing the permit from the organization applying for the permit. The verified application for such permit shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the person or club under whose auspices the dance is to be conducted. 
(2)  A statement in detail as to whether the dance is to be conducted for any special benefit or in behalf of any particular organization or group of individuals. 
(3)  A statement as to whether the sale of admissions to members or the general public is contemplated by telephone solicitation. 
(4)  A statement as to whether the sale of admissions to members or to the general public is contemplated by personal solicitation. 
(5)  A statement as to whether commissions are to be paid individual solicitors for the sale of admissions and the amount of any such commissions. 
(6)  A statement that the applicant agrees that the issuance of the permit is based on the declarations and statements contained in the application, and that the representations made therein are true and that misrepresentations of any fact or statement and any misrepresentation for the purposes of avoiding the provisions of this article shall, in addition to the other penalties prescribed by law, be cause for the revocation and cancellation of the license issued under this article for the dance hall. 
(b)  In the event it appears to the building official that any dance is to be conducted on behalf of or for the benefit of any organization or group of individuals, then, before issuing a permit under this section, he shall refer the application for the permit to the city council. 
(c)  In lieu of the single-dance permit required by subsection (a), an annual continuous permit for single dances may be secured upon the payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). Such continuous permit shall authorize not to exceed twenty-four (24) dances during any twelve (12) consecutive calendar months. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-19, 20, 27), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-107. - General construction requirements. 
(a)  The construction of dance halls shall meet all applicable requirements of the building code and other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(b)  No dance hall shall be permitted above the ground floor level in any wood frame building. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to dance halls in operation on April 12, 1966, so long as they are in continuous operation. 
(c)  Class A, Class B or Class D dance halls which were in operation on April 12, 1966 and which are operating in wood frame constructed buildings shall not be added to, enlarged, extended, remodeled or rebuilt, and there shall be a clearance of at least ten (10) feet from any building or structure adjacent to any such wood frame constructed dance hall. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-22), 4-12-66) 
Cross reference— Buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 9.  
Sec. 5-108. - Minimum dancing space. 
Every Class A or Class B dance hall shall have at least three hundred (300) square feet of floor space for dancing, if the seating capacity of such hall is under two hundred (200) patrons seated at tables. Every such dance hall shall have at least four hundred (400) square feet of floor space for dancing, if the seating capacity of such hall is over two hundred (200) patrons seated at tables. This section shall not apply to any public dance hall where the operation and maintenance of the dance hall is merely incidental to the main business, and is not the principal business of such establishment. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-21), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-109. - Partitions separating kitchens and other occupancies. 
Partitions separating kitchens from the public portions of a Class A, Class B or Class D dance hall shall be of not less than one (1) hour fire resistive construction in all types of construction. Partitions, walls and floors separating dance halls from all other occupancies in the same building shall be as otherwise required by the building code. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-22), 4-12-66) 
Cross reference— Building code, § 9-62 et seq.  
Sec. 5-110. - Sleeping rooms prohibited; exception. 
No dance hall shall have connected with it in any way, any room equipped or fitted in any way as a sleeping room which is open to or let to the patrons of such dance hall or to the public, with or without a charge being made therefor, except bona fide hotels, motels, or motor hotels having more than twenty-five (25) rooms. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(1a-5), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-111. - Toilet facilities. 
Each dance hall shall be supplied with separate and convenient toilet facilities for the male and female sex. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-6), 4-12-66) 
Cross reference— Plumbing, Ch. 29.  
Sec. 5-112. - Exits generally. 
Every Class A, Class B or Class D dance hall shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Exit passageways shall be not less than six (6) feet, eight (8) inches in height. 
(2)  Stages shall have not less than one (1) exit on each side and such exits shall be not less than two (2) feet, six (6) inches in width. 
(3)  Doors shall swing in the direction of exit travel, and if provided with latches, such latches shall be of a self-releasing type, such as panic bolts or similar devices which will permit the door to open when pressed against. No revolving door shall be permitted in any dance hall. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-11), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-113. - Exits, aisles, etc., not to be obstructed. 
No persons or obstructions of any kind, either permanent or movable, shall be placed in any exit, aisle, passageway or corridor of any dance hall. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-22), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-114. - Decorations, draperies, etc., to be fire resistant. 
All decorations, draperies and acoustical materials used in a dance hall shall be fire resistant. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-22), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-115. - Fire extinguishers. 
Fire extinguishers shall be provided in the following locations at every Class A, Class B or Class D dance hall: 
(1)  One (1) eight (8) pound CO 2 extinguisher in the kitchen. 
(2)  One (1) two and three-quarter (2¾) gallon soda and acid extinguisher, or other water-type extinguisher approved by the American Insurance Association, for each two thousand (2,000) square feet or fraction thereof of gross floor space. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-22), 4-12-66)  
Secs. 5-116, 5-117. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 78-98, §§ 1, 2, enacted July 5, 1978, repealed §§ 5-116, 5-117, derived from Ord. No. 1796, § 1 (10A-9—10A-11), enacted April 12, 1966, pertaining to guards and their access to telephones in dance halls.  
Sec. 5-118. - Minors under seventeen years of age prohibited after midnight; exception. 
No person under the age of seventeen (17) years shall be permitted to attend any public dance at a dance hall after 12:00 midnight, unless such person is accompanied by his parent or guardian. It shall be unlawful for any person to misrepresent himself to be either the parent or guardian of any such minor for the purpose of gaining his admittance into a dance hall. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-4), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-119. - Dancing prohibited between certain hours in Class A and B halls. 
Dancing shall not be permitted and it shall be unlawful for any person to dance between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. in any Class A or Class B dance hall; provided, however, that the chief of police may grant special permits for dancing until a later hour, upon special occasions. Application for such special permits shall be made not less than forty-eight (48) hours prior thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-3), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-120. - Smoking on dance floor prohibited. 
Smoking by a dancer, or other person, while on the dance floor of a dance hall is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-8A), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-121. - Free access for city officers on duty. 
Free access and entrance into all dance halls shall at all times be accorded and granted to city dance hall inspectors and police and fire officers when on official duty. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-7), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-122. - Operators not to permit violation of article. 
The operator of any dance hall shall not permit the violation of any of the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-8), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-123. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 78-98, § 3, passed July 5, 1978, repealed § 5-123, pertaining to compliance with dance hall regulations and derived from Ord. No. 1796, § 1 (10A-8), enacted April 12, 1966.  
Secs. 5-124—5-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 5-131. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to hold or conduct any public dance, public ball or any dancing school within the city, unless and until the dance hall in which the same is held has been licensed for such purposes; provided, that this section shall not apply where instruction is given to members of a family in their own home, or where community facilities of the city are used for community dances sponsored and supervised by the city, or are rented or engaged by private individuals or organizations for the purpose of private parties from which are excluded members of the general public, or where property of the Pasadena Independent School District or of the Deer Park Independent School District is used for public school dances supervised by public school officials. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dance at any place except at a place licensed as required by this section. The owner, proprietor, manager or person in charge of any establishment not licensed as required by this section, who permits any person to dance therein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-12, 15), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-132. - Special license required where public dancing not permitted but facilities are leased for private dances. 
When any person operates, conducts or maintains a restaurant, cafe or other similar business on or at premises where no public dancing is permitted or conducted, but where the physical facilities and premises are capable of being used for private dances, and where such premises are leased, rented or engaged periodically on particular occasions by private individuals or organizations for the purpose of dining and private dancing by such individuals or organizations and their invited guests and members, a special license shall be secured by the person operating, conducting and maintaining such premises. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-20), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-133. - Filing and contents of application. 
Any person desiring a license to operate a dance hall shall file, with the building official, a written, sworn application, for such license, on a form provided for that purpose. Such application shall state: 
(1)  The location, by street and number, of the place, space or building and room or floor, and the size of such room or space which is proposed to be used for such purpose, and the name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  If the applicant is an individual, that he is a law-abiding tax-paying citizen of the state; that he has not been convicted of a felony, or if he has, the nature of the offense; and the length of his residence in the city. 
(3)  If the applicant is a firm, association or partnership, all of the information prescribed in paragraph (2) of this section as to each individual composing the firm, association or partnership. 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, that the applicant is organized and chartered under the corporation laws of this state applicable to such corporation, or, if a foreign corporation, that such corporation has complied with the laws of this state applicable to such corporation, and the same information with reference to the operator or person in charge of the operation of the dance hall desired to be licensed as is prescribed in paragraph (2) of this section; and in addition thereto, a statement as to the names of the incorporators or shareholders, and the amount of interest owned by each. 
(5)  Previous occupation or employment of the applicant for a period of five (5) years preceding the filing of his application. 
(6)  If the application is for a license to operate a dancing school, or Class C dance hall, such application shall give the name and address of each person who is to instruct in such school. 
(7)  Whether a hotel, rooming house or lodging house is conducted in any part of the premises for which a license is sought, and if so, the number of rooms contained in such hotel, rooming house or lodging house; provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall prevent the issuance of a license to any public dance hall having connected with it any sleeping rooms which are not open to nor let to the patrons of such dance hall or to the public. 
(8)  The hours and days of operation when the dance hall is open to the public or guests; a description of beverages or food to be served, if any; the number and size of doors and distances from outside edges of any other doors opening into a given room or space to be used for a dance floor; type of music source; and frequency of availability and general description of entertainment, if any. 
(9)  Such other and additional information as the city council may deem proper and necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-17), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-134. - Purpose of information required in application; misrepresentations. 
The information required to be given in an application for a license under this division is for the purpose of determining whether or not the applicant is a fit and proper person to operate a dance hall, and whether or not the premises are a proper and safe place for licensed dancing. It shall be unlawful for any person to misrepresent the kind and character of dance hall to be operated, or any other fact or statement made in such application. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-18), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-135. - Payment of taxes, liens, etc., prerequisite to issuance. 
No dance hall license shall be issued unless all ad valorem taxes and other taxes, fees, liens, assessments, or charges on property, real, personal or mixed, situated at the proposed license address or location, including interest and penalty, which are due and owing the city are fully and proved to be so paid by valid, lawful receipt. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-14), 4-12-66) 
Cross reference— Taxation, Ch. 34.  
Sec. 5-136. - Applicant's insurance. 
(a)  No dance hall license shall be issued under this division, unless the applicant has in force and effect a public liability insurance policy covering all premises employed in the conduct of dancing and issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Texas, or by a surplus line insurance company which is not legally prohibited from doing business in the State of Texas. Such insurance policy shall provide liability insurance in the amount of not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per person injured in an accident and not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) total per accident. 
(b)  Certificates or certified copies of such policies shall be filed with the building official prior to issue of a dance hall license. All such insurance policies, certificates, or certified copies thereof shall provide for a written 30-day cancellation notice to the building official. 
(c)  In lieu of the insurance required by subsections (a) and (b), surety bonds issued by solvent and responsible corporate sureties authorized to do business in the State of Texas may be accepted by the building official for all or any part of such insurance; provided, that each bond shall be conditioned for the payment and satisfaction of any financial judgment in conformity with the provisions of any insurance policy required herein. Such surety bonds shall be filed with the building official before a license can be issued under this division. All such bonds, certificates thereof, or certified copies thereof shall provide for a 30-day cancellation notice to the building official. 
(d)  The cancellation or other termination of any such policy or bond shall automatically revoke the license issued for the dance hall covered by such policy or bond, unless another insurance policy or bond complying with this section is provided and in effect at the time of such cancellation or termination. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-28), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-137. - Inspection of premises and approval or disapproval of application. 
No license shall be granted pursuant to this division unless it shall appear, upon investigation by or under the direction of the chief of police, the director of public health, the fire marshal, and the building official, that the premises desired to be used for the purpose of conducting a dance hall complies with the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city regulating health and sanitation, the fire regulations, and the building code. Such officers shall, in their respective capacities, note their approval or disapproval upon the application. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-15), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-138. - Fees. 
(a)  The following fees shall be charged for each license issued under the terms of this division and shall be collected for the city by the building official: 
(1)  For a Class A dance hall, the license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00); provided, however, that where such dance hall is not operated more than three (3) nights per week, the license fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(2)  For a Class B dance hall, the license fee shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00); provided, however, that where such dance hall is not operated more than three (3) nights per week, the license fee shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
(3)  For a Class C dance hall, the license fee shall be five dollars ($5.00); provided, however, that where such dance hall is used for the holding of public or private dances in addition to the classes and instruction in dancing, the fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(4)  For a Class D dance hall, the license fee shall be five dollars ($5.00); provided, however, that where such dance hall is rented to other operators for the holding of a public or private dance, the license fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(5)  For a special license required by section 5-132, the fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(b)  No refund of any license fee paid in accord with this section shall be made by the city for any cause whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-20, 26), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-139. - Issuance. 
A license applied for under this division shall be issued by the building official when the conditions of this article have been complied with and the application has been approved in accord with this division. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-14), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-140. - Contents; signing and sealing. 
A license issued under this division shall state on its face to whom it is issued, the date it will expire, the address and location of the dance hall for which issued, and whether the licensee is authorized to operate and conduct a Class A, B, C or D dance hall. It shall be signed and sealed by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-16), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-141. - Posting. 
A license issued under this division shall be posted by the licensee in a conspicuous place, at or near the entrance to the dance hall, and in such a place and position that it may be easily read at any time of the day or night. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-16), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-142. - Does not grant vested rights. 
The granting of any license under the terms of this division shall in no event be construed as the granting or conferring of any vested right to the licensee or operator, and such license shall be subject to suspension, revocation and cancellation as provided for in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-23), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-143. - Not assignable; transfer from one location to another. 
Licenses issued pursuant to this division shall be deemed personal to the licensee and shall not be assignable. A license issued hereunder may be transferred from one location or place of business to another location, after the chief of police shall have been given five (5) days notice of such proposed transfer for investigation, and the chief of police has given consent thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-26), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-144. - Continuation after reorganization or change in management of corporate licensee. 
If any corporation having a license under this division is reorganized or has a change in management, such license shall not continue in force until the chief of police shall have been given five (5) days notice of such reorganization or change in management, and until he shall have made an investigation of such reorganization and change in management and given his consent for the continuation of the license after determining that the personnel of the new management is fit and proper to operate a dance hall under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-26), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-145. - Expiration. 
All licenses issued under the provisions of this division shall terminate one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-27), 4-12-66)  
Sec. 5-146. - Appeal from denial. 
In the event the building official shall refuse to grant a license to any applicant under this division, his action shall be final, unless the applicant shall, within ten (10) days after the refusal to grant such license, file a written appeal with the city secretary, addressed to the city council, requesting a hearing by the city council upon the question as to whether or not his application shall be granted. In the event such appeal is filed, the building official shall provide the city council with a record of all proceedings theretofore had with reference to the application in question, including the written application, together with the action of the building official and the reasons for such action. The city council shall, within thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the building official, at which hearing, the city council may make such investigation as it may see fit, whether or not all the pertinent facts appear in the application. It shall be discretionary with the city council as to whether or not a license shall be granted, and such action as the city council determines shall be administratively final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-24), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 5-147. - Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  The building official may revoke or suspend the license of any dance hall at any time for failure to keep the licensed premises in compliance with this article and all applicable state laws and ordinances, rules and regulations of the city. 
(b)  Any misrepresentation by the applicant for the purpose of avoiding the provisions of this article shall, in addition to the other penalties prescribed by law, be cause for revocation of the license. 
(c)  Every revocation or suspension under this section, and every appeal therefrom, shall be made in compliance with the procedures for revocation and suspension and appeal provided in Article II of Chapter 33 of this Code. The word "procedures," as used herein, refers to the order of and time limits for notices and hearings, as well as the method and effect of notice. 
(Ord. No. 1796, § 1(10A-18, 25), 4-12-66; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Secs. 5-148—5-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - COMMERCIALLY OPERATED TRANSIENT AMUSEMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 71-171, adopted June 15, 1971, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion of §§ 1—11 and 14 herein as Art. V, §§ 5-151—5-162 was at the discretion of the editors. The substantive provisions of said ordinance are included herein as enacted, however "ordinance" was changed to "article" where necessary and §§ 12, 13 and 15, severability, repealer, publication and effective date provisions, were omitted. 
 
Sec. 5-151. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(a)  City is the City of Pasadena. 
(b)  Building official is the license officer or permit officer of the City of Pasadena. 
(c)  Transient amusement is any circus, carnival, concession, game, ride, exhibit or any other type of public amusement device which is of a type generally considered to be of a transient nature, but shall not include such amusements where they are operated by a school or a church and all of the persons engaged in the operation are members of the school or church organization which is operating such amusement. 
(d)  Licensee is any person having a city license in full force and effect issued hereunder for a transient amusement. 
(e)  Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 1, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-152. - License required. 
No person shall install, construct, operate or maintain a transient amusement within the city without having a valid license therefor in force and effect under the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 2, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-153. - Application procedure. 
Applications for licenses issued hereunder for a transient amusement shall be made upon blank forms to be prepared and made available by the building official and shall state: 
(a)  The name, home address and proposed business address of the applicant; 
(b)  The hours of operation for said transient amusement; 
(c)  The names, addresses and number of employees, exhibitors and other persons to be engaged in the operation of the transient amusement; and 
(d)  If the applicant is a firm, association, partnership or corporation, then all of the information required of an individual shall be required of each individual of the said firm, association, partnership or corporation; and 
(e)  If a corporation, the application shall state: 
(1)  That the applicant is either a domestic corporation duly organized and existing under the laws of the State of Texas, or, if a foreign corporation, the state of its incorporation and that it is duly authorized to transact business in the State of Texas; 
(2)  The name of its registered agent and the address of its registered office in the State of Texas; 
(3)  The name, home address and proposed business address of the operator or person in charge of the operation of the transient amusement to be licensed hereunder; and 
(4)  The name, home address and business address of the president and of each member of the board of directors of such corporation. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 3, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-154. - Application fee. 
An application hereunder shall be accompanied by an application fee of twenty-five and no/100 dollars ($25.00) to defray the expense of investigation of the application and said fee is nonreturnable if the application for a license is refused or not issued after an investigation has been made. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 4, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-155. - License fee. 
After investigation of an application is completed and a license is to be issued, the building official shall notify applicant and, upon payment of a license fee in the amount of one hundred and no/100 dollars ($100.00), for each day or part thereof that the transient amusement is to be operated, the building official shall issue the license for the operation of the transient amusement for the period set forth in the application and covered by the license fee paid. Any license issued by the building official shall be to the applicant named at the location designated in the application. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 5, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-156. - Transfer of licenses; changes in partnerships or corporations. 
A license may be transferred to a different location upon application and payment of a transfer fee of twenty-five and no/100 dollars ($25.00). 
(a)  A license issued to a partnership is not voided by withdrawal of one or more partners so long as one of the original partners remain. 
(b)  All changes in the membership of the partnership and all changes in the identity of the principal officers of the corporation shall be reported to the building official within ten (10) days after they occur. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 6, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-157. - Investigation of application. 
The building official shall forward a copy of each application filed under section 5-153 hereof to the chief of police for investigation. The building official and chief of police shall complete their investigation within two (2) days from date of filing of the application. The report of the chief of police shall include the number of special police that applicant shall, at its own expense, have on duty at the location during the operation of the transient amusement and the building official, when an application is approved, shall give written notice, with the license issued, of such requirements. Every special policeman to be employed by a licensee must be approved of the chief of police prior to his employment. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 7, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-158. - Standards for issuance. 
The building official shall issue a license hereunder when he finds that the requirements of this article and of all other governing laws and ordinances have been met. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 8, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-159. - Duties of licensee. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to operate a transient amusement in the city without complying with the following requirements and standards of operation: 
(a)  Conduct and operation. The licensee shall maintain good order upon the premises where any transient amusement is operated. 
(b)  Standards for maintenance of premises. 
(1)  Access. The licensee shall provide access available to public streets or other public ways at all times to facilitate departure of persons from the premises where the transient amusement is operated and to permit entrance of fire apparatus or other emergency equipment in case of emergency. 
(2)  Lighting. Licensee shall provide artificial light whenever natural light is inadequate. 
(3)  Electrical installations. The electrical system shall be installed, maintained and operated in a safe and workmanlike manner. All electrical equipment must meet the requirements of the electrical code of the city. Cables on the ground in areas traversed by the public shall be protected by approved covers. The electrical installations shall be inspected and approved by the city electrical inspector before the transient amusement is opened to the public and shall thereafter be open to inspection by the electrical inspector at all reasonable hours. 
(4)  Fire extinguishing equipment. Fire extinguishing equipment shall be furnished by the licensee in such amount and in such locations as may be directed by the city fire marshal. Fire extinguishing equipment shall be inspected and approved by the city fire marshal before the transient amusement is open to the public and shall thereafter be open to inspection by the city fire marshal at all reasonable hours. 
(5)  Sanitary facilities. When sanitary facilities are to be made available to the public they shall be inspected and approved by the department of health. 
(6)  Attendants. At all times when a transient amusement is open to the public, the licensee shall provide an adequate number of attendants and special police who shall be responsible for seeing that order is maintained, that disorderly or immoral conduct is prevented, that the entrances and exits are kept free from congestion and that this ordinance and all other governing ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to transient amusements are observed. 
(7)  Noise. The transient amusement shall be operated in such manner as to comply with section 20-1 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pasadena. 
(8)  Concessions. Any sales of items covered by Chapter 15, Article II of the Code of Ordinances shall be strictly in compliance with such article and licensee shall see that the required permits and health certificates are obtained prior to the making of such sales to the public. 
(9)  Inspection. Officers of the police department are hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon the premises where any transient amusement is being operated within the city, at any time, for the purpose of inspection, for preservation of law and order and to determine whether or not the provisions of this article are being complied with. 
(c)  Standard for vacated premises. 
(1)  Licensee shall, upon removal of a transient amusement licensed hereunder, clean the premises of any trash, rubbish and other unsightly or unsanitary matter which has accumulated thereon within twenty-four (24) hours after removal of the transient amusement. 
(2)  Licensee shall, to guarantee compliance with the foregoing subsection (1), prior to the time a license is issued for the operation of a transient amusement, post with the building official a bond in the minimum amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which shall be issued by a company doing business in the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 9, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-160. - Suspension of license; appeal. 
The building official, chief of police, fire marshal or fire chief shall, upon discovery of a transient amusement being operated in violation of the terms of this article, immediately suspend the license to operate such transient amusement until such violations are removed. Suspension shall be by notice to the licensee or to the person in charge of the operation of such transient amusement. The one who acts to suspend a license under the terms of this section shall, within twenty-four (24) hours following such action file a written report with the building official setting forth the exact violation, the date and hour of suspension and whether the violation has been removed by the licensee. Where a license has been suspended hereunder and not thereafter reinstated, the licensee may appeal such action by appropriate action in the proper court at law; provided, however, that such proceedings shall be commenced within fifteen (15) days and not thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 10, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-161. - Penalty. 
Any person, persons, operator, owner, owners, partners, licensee, or the agents of a corporation, or whoever is in charge or control of a transient amusement, or any part thereof, who shall violate or allow or cause any person or persons to violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty and no/100 dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred and no/100 dollars ($200.00) for such offense; and the license or licenses shall be subject to revocation or suspension for a violation of any provision of this article or of any other provision of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pasadena or any violation of the laws of the State of Texas. Any remedy prescribed by this article shall be merely cumulative and shall not preclude resort to any other remedy provided by law. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 11, 6-15-71)  
Sec. 5-162. - Accrued rights and remedies preserved for benefit of city. 
All rights and remedies which have accrued in favor of the city under this article and amendments thereto shall be and are preserved for the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 71-171, § 14, 6-15-71)  
Secs. 5-163—5-174. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - COIN-OPERATED MACHINES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 83-84, adopted March 22, 1983, repealed Art. VI, Div. 1, §§ 5-175—5-181, and Div. 2, §§ 5-193—5-203, relative to game rooms and § 2 enacted, in place thereof, new §§ 5-175—5-215 to read as herein set out in Arts. VI and VII, with minor, nonsubstantive changes made by the editor in order to facilitate reference and maintain Code format. The repealed sections derived from Ord. No. 77-203, §§ 1—18, adopted Oct. 14, 1977. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 5-175. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following definitions shall apply: 
Coin-operated machines shall mean every machine or device of any kind or character which is operated by or with coins, metal slugs, tokens, checks or similar objects. Music coin-operated machines and skill and pleasure coin-operated machines, as those terms are hereafter defined, shall be included in such term. 
Music coin-operated machine shall mean and include every coin-operated machine of any kind or character which dispenses or vends, or which is used or operated for dispensing or vending music and which is operated by or with coins, metal slugs, tokens, checks or similar objects.
