(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-8. - Parking areas for apartment buildings. 
All parking areas to be used by occupants of apartment buildings shall be off of the public streets and alleys. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-9. - Plat filing fees. 
Prior to the preparation of the preliminary plat, the developer may seek the advice of the planning department or the planning commission, in order to determine the feasibility of the proposal before substantial expense is incurred, to acquaint him with any plans and requirements for the area and the availability of utilities and sewer that the proposed development meets the primary objectives of this chapter. A filing fee according to chapter 28, article IV, section 28-46 shall be paid by the developer for review of the project and shall not be refundable, in whole or in part. All fees shall be made payable to the City of Pasadena. Upon submittal of a preliminary and a final plat, a filing fee according to chapter 28, article IV, section 28-46 shall be paid by the developer for review of the project and shall not be refundable, in whole or in part, whether approval is granted or not. All fees shall be made payable to the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17; Ord. No. 18-102, § 2, 8-21-18)  
Sec. 9-10. - Notice of deed restrictions upon conveyance. 
(a)  In this section the following words and terms shall have the meaning herein ascribed: 
(1)  Deed restrictions shall have the meaning ascribed to the word "restriction" in section 230.002 of the Local Government Code, as amended, and section 9-1(b), Code of Ordinances, provided that it shall not be deemed to include any restrictions that by their express provisions have terminated or any provisions contained within any restrictions to the extent and only to the extent that the provisions restrict the sale, rental, or use of property on the basis of race, color, religion, sex or national origin. 
(2)  Sale or conveyance means any transfer of any lot, tract or parcel of real property subject to deed restrictions that is situated in whole or in part within the corporate limits of the city, except: 
a.  A conveyance by trustee's or substitute trustee's deed to the lienholder pursuant to a foreclosure sale; 
b.  A conveyance by deed to the lienholder in full or partial satisfaction of a debt secured by the property conveyed; 
c.  A deed of trust conveyed to secure a lien; 
d.  An auction sale conducted by a public official pursuant to an order of a court of competent jurisdiction; or 
e.  A conveyance in which the purchaser is a governmental entity. 
Without limitation, the term shall include an executory contract of purchase and sale having a performance period of more than six (6) months. 
(3)  Purchaser shall mean each person who constitutes a grantee, purchaser, buyer, or transferee in a sale or conveyance, regardless of the amount or nature of the consideration received. 
(4)  Seller shall mean each person who constitutes a seller, grantor or transferor in a sale or conveyance, regardless of the amount or nature of the consideration received. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each seller to ensure that each buyer receives in connection with each sale or conveyance notice issued in accordance with the terms of this section in the form of Exhibit "A" [6], Notice to Purchaser(s), to this ordinance [Ordinance No. 90-6], which exhibit is incorporated herein by reference. The following procedure shall be followed in the giving and recording of the notice: 
(1)  The notice shall be given to each purchaser at the final closing of the sale and purchase; provided, however, seller may provide the notice prior to closing; 
(2)  Each seller and each purchaser shall sign and acknowledge the notice; and 
(3)  Following the execution, acknowledgment and closing of the sale and purchase, the notice shall be recorded in the real property records of Harris County. 
(c)  The failure of any seller to comply with this section shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable upon conviction by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each person who constitutes a seller shall be criminally responsible and each sale or conveyance in which the seller has failed to comply with this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  This section does not limit the seller's right to recover a penalty, or any part of a penalty, imposed pursuant to subsection (c) from a third party for the negligent failure to obtain the execution or proper recordation of the notice. 
(e)  The failure of the seller to comply with this section shall not affect the validity or enforceability of the sale or conveyance of the restricted property or the validity of enforceability of restrictions covering the property. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17) 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Exhibit "A" is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
 
Sec. 9-11. - Bond and insurance for multifamily residential development. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued for the construction of any multifamily residential housing complex over one hundred (100) dwelling units unless a bond or irrevocable letter of credit in favor of the City of Pasadena in the amount of one million dollars is furnished to the City of Pasadena as a guaranty of compliance with this chapter to ensure accountability for upkeep and maintenance, and other applicable law, including but not limited to, demolition of buildings, and such other remedial measures as may be necessary to guaranty full and constant compliance with all applicable laws. Such bond shall be kept in full force and effect by all subsequent owners of the complex. Failure of the owner or any subsequent owners to maintain such bond shall cause the revocation of the certificate of occupancy for such complex or structure therein. 
(b)  No permit shall issue for the construction of any multifamily residential housing complex over one hundred (100) dwelling units unless there is in force and effect a comprehensive general liability insurance policy, with the City of Pasadena named as additional insured, in the amount of two (2) million dollars for such complex. Such insurance policy shall remain in effect during the life of the structure, including all times that it is inhabited. Failure of the owner or any subsequent owner to maintain such insurance shall cause the revocation of the certificate of occupancy for such structure. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 9-12—9-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING AND STANDARDS COMMISSION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 9-21. - Building and standards commission created. 
There is hereby created and established a building and standards commission hereinafter referred to as the commission which shall be appointed, organized and function according to the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-22. - Organization of the commission. 
The commission shall be composed of five (5) members and eight (8) alternates who shall serve in the event of the absence or resignation of any of the five (5) members of the commission when requested to do so by the mayor. Each of the members and alternates shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council for a term of two (2) years. All such members shall hold office for the two-year period. Any vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term. Upon a majority vote the members of the commission shall elect a chairman, an acting chairman and secretary. The chairman shall serve as the presiding officer of the commission. The acting chairman of the commission shall serve as the presiding officer in the event of the absence of the chairman. Members of the commission and alternates shall not be employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-23. - Membership of commission. 
The members of the commission and alternates shall consist of persons who are qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to property maintenance and who are not employees of the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-24. - Members to serve without compensation. 
Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-25. - Removal of member. 
The mayor, with confirmation of city council, may remove a commission member for cause on a written charge. Cause for removal shall exist when a commission member has three (3) consecutive absences from regular meetings without an excuse approved by a majority of the commission members qualified and serving, and the member has been given due notice of such meetings personally by phone or mail or by notice in the minutes of a prior regular meeting. In such event the secretary of the commission shall draft a written charge accordingly and file such with the city secretary. The foregoing shall not be construed to constitute the only cause for removal. Before a decision regarding removal is made, the city council shall hold a public hearing on the matter if requested by the commission member subject to the removal action. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-26. - Alternate members. 
Alternate members of the commission shall serve for the same period and are subject to removal in the same manner as the regular members. A vacancy among the alternates shall be filled in the same manner as a vacancy among the regular members. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-27. - Proceedings of the commission. 
(a)  All cases to be heard by the commission must be heard by at least four (4) members. 
(b)  The commission shall adopt rules to establish procedures for use in hearings which must provide ample opportunity for presentation of evidence and testimony by respondents or persons opposing charges brought by the city or its building official relating to alleged violations of ordinances. 
(c)  Meetings of the commission may be held at the call of the chairman and at times determined necessary by the commission. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. The chairman, or in the chairman's absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. 
(d)  The commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member on each question or the fact that a member is absent or fails to vote. The commission shall keep records of its examinations and other official acts. The minutes and records shall be filed immediately in the office of the city secretary as public records. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-28. - Vote. 
The concurring vote of four (4) members of the commission is necessary to take any action with respect to those ordinances designated in Chapter 54, Subchapter C of the Local Government Code, as hereafter amended by the State Legislature. The vote of a simple majority of the members of the commission is sufficient to take action with respect to all other ordinances over which the commission has jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-29. - Notice of proceedings. 
(a)  Notice of all proceedings before the commission shall be given by the building official: 
(1)  By certified mail, return receipt requested, to the record owners of the affected property, and each holder of a recorded lien against the affected property, as shown by the records in the office of the county clerk of the county in which the affected property is located if the address of the lienholder can be ascertained from the deed of trust establishing the lien or other applicable instruments on file in the office of the county clerk; and 
(2)  To all unknown owners by posting a copy of the notice on the front door of the building or structure situated on the affected property or as close to the front door as practicable. 
(b)  The notice shall be mailed and posted before the tenth day before the date of the hearing before the commission and must state the date, time, and place of the hearing. In addition, the notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city on one (1) occasion before the tenth day before the date fixed for the hearing. 
(c)  If the address of a person having an interest in the property as shown in the deed records is unknown or if the notice is returned undelivered, a copy of such notice posted on the building or structure shall constitute notice to any person having an interest in the property who does not receive personal service. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-30. - Powers of commission. 
The commission shall have the power to: 
(1)  Order the repair, within a fixed period, of buildings or structures found to be in violation of an ordinance; 
(2)  Declare a building substandard in accordance with the provisions of Article VII hereof, as the same be hereafter amended; 
(3)  Order, in an appropriate case, the immediate removal of persons or property found on private property if it is determined that conditions exist on the property that constitute a violation of an ordinance; 
(4)  Order action to be taken as necessary to remedy, alleviate, or remove any substandard building or structure found to exist in violation of Article VII hereof, as the same may be hereafter amended; 
(5)  Issue orders or directives to any peace officer of the state, including a sheriff or constable or the chief of police of the city to enforce and carry out the lawful orders or directives of the commission; 
(6)  Assess and determine the amount and duration of the civil penalty the city may recover as provided by Section 54.017 of the Local Government Code, as hereafter amended; 
(7)  Order, in an appropriate case, that a building or structure be secured from unauthorized entry and establish the specifications that must be complied with to secure the building or structure and order that the building be repaired or demolished if the building or structure is not secured in compliance with the order; 
(8)  Order the building official to post an appropriate notice in a conspicuous place on a building or structure when the building or structure has been declared substandard by the commission and dangerous to the health, safety, or welfare of its occupants or to the citizens of the city. Such notice may contain, among other provisions, language to the effect that (i) the building/structure has been declared substandard or unsafe by the commission; (ii) occupancy of the building or structure is prohibited; (iii) the building or structure must be vacated within a specified period of time; and/or (iv) entrance into the building or structure is prohibited by any persons other than inspectors of the city and persons authorized by the owner who enter solely for the purpose of correcting the hazardous condition; 
(9)  Review and study the building code, as the same now exists or may be hereafter amended, and all rules and regulations issued thereunder for the purpose of remedying any deficiencies, errors, or discrepancies therein, assessing the use of the latest safe and sound building materials, standards, specifications, and practices conducive to the constant improvement of human habitation within the city, and recommending to the building official modifications of existing rules and regulations or the promulgation of additional rules and regulations; 
(10)  Review written requests for advisory opinions from the building official regarding the technical sufficiency of any substitute material or practice not expressly authorized by the building code and issue opinions in connection therewith; 
(11)  Adjudicate appeals from acts, orders or rulings of the building official or his assistants or deputies as provided in Division 2 of this article; 
(12)  Order action to be taken to remedy, alleviate, or remove any condition relating to the accumulation of refuse, vegetation or other matter that creates breeding and living places for insects and rodents; and 
(13)  Issue appropriate orders in connection with all matters brought before it over which it exercises jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-31. - Liaison with electrical, plumbing code and heating, air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration boards. 
The commission shall establish and maintain liaison with the city electrical board, city plumbing code review board, and the city heating, air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration board to promote harmonious administration of all the construction codes of the city and the accommodation of innovations permitted or recommended within their respective jurisdictions by such boards. For the accomplishment of this function, the commission may, from time to time, petition the mayor to order a joint meeting or meetings of the commission and one (1) or more of such boards. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-32. - Additional authority of the commission. 
In addition to its statutory authority provided for under Chapter 54, Subchapter C of the Local Government Code, as hereafter amended, the commission shall have such additional authority as shall be from time to time delegated to it by the city council of the City of Pasadena and shall determine such issues and render decisions in accordance therewith that may be from time to time required of an appellate body, regardless of the name or designation provided in the various codes adopted by the city council of the City of Pasadena and shall render decisions in accordance with the limitations, restrictions and provisions as provided for in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-33. - Failure to comply with order of commission. 
Failure to comply with an order issued by the commission shall entitle the city to avail itself of any and all remedies provided by law, including but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  To vacate, secure, remove, repair or demolish a building or relocate the occupants at its expense and assess the expenses as a lien upon the real property on which the building or structure is located; 
(2)  To remedy at its expense conditions caused by accumulations of refuse, vegetation or other matter creating breeding and living places for insects and rodents and assess the expenses as a lien upon the real property on which the condition existed; 
(3)  To proceed under the jurisdiction of the municipal court of the city; provided, however, that this remedy shall not be construed to require an order from the commission before the city may proceed under the jurisdiction of the municipal court; 
(4)  To enforce a civil penalty by filing a certified copy of the order with the district clerk of Harris County; and 
(5)  To proceed, in appropriate cases, in district or county court to enforce the city ordinances and orders of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-34. - Procedures to follow when order issued. 
After the decision becomes final a copy of the order issued by the commission shall be promptly mailed first class, certified, return receipt requested to all persons to whom notice is required to be sent under section 9-29 hereof. In addition, a copy of the order shall be published one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the city within ten (10) calendar days after the date of mailing the copy as provided in this section. Also, a copy of the order shall be filed in the office of the city secretary and in the deed records of the county in which the land is located. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-35. - Appeals from commission orders. 
Appeals from commission orders may be taken to the court of appropriate jurisdiction. However, with respect to orders issued hereunder pursuant to authority granted in Chapter 54, Subchapter C of the Local Government Code, as hereafter amended, if appeals are not taken within the required period, the decision of the commission shall be, in all things, final and binding. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-36. - Repair or demolition after contract execution. 
If an order has been issued pursuant to this article for the repair or demolition of a building or structure and the city has let a contract for demolition or repair, and the building or structure is subsequently repaired or demolished by the owner(s) prior to completion of the contract let by the city, the administrative expenses and all costs for cancellation of the contract shall be certified as a charge which shall be assessed against the owner(s) thereof, and which shall constitute a lien on the land on which the building or structure is or was situated. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-37. - Execution of written release upon payment of charges or where lien placed on property through error; execution of written notice of compliance. 
(a)  Upon full payment of the charges assessed against any property, or in the event the lien is placed on the property through error, the mayor is hereby authorized to execute, for and in behalf of the city, a written release approved in each case by the legal department. 
(b)  Upon compliance with an order of the commission to repair or demolish a building or structure, the building official shall be and is hereby authorized to execute a written "Notice of Compliance" setting forth the date the notice of compliance is issued, the date the building inspector found the building or structure to be repaired or demolished in compliance with the order; and if the building or structure has not been demolished, whether or not the building or structure is in such condition that it may be occupied. 
(c)  A fee shall be imposed for such release of lien provided hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 9-38—9-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - APPEALS TO COMMISSION UNDER BUILDING CODE 
 
Sec. 9-41. - Generally. 
This Division 2 shall apply only to those cases which are not subject to authority granted in Chapter 54, Subchapter C of the Local Government Code, as hereafter amended. In such cases the Commission shall act as an appellate body to receive, hear, process and adjudicate appeals from the acts, orders or rulings of the building official or his/her assistants or deputies under the building code and other ordinances under which the building official, or his/her assistants or deputies exercise authority, as the same now exist or may be hereafter amended. The procedure for such appeals is prescribed in this division. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-42. - Appellant's statement to be filed with building official. 
(a)  Any person desiring to effect an appeal under this division shall file with the building official a written statement in English, typewritten or printed in ink, containing the following information: 
(1)  A description of the place where the subject construction or installation is located, including postal address and legal description; 
(2)  The name of the assistant or inspector, if any, whose act, order or ruling is complained of; 
(3)  A description, including scale diagram, of the subject construction or installation, or so much thereof as is involved in the act, order or ruling complained of; 
(4)  The date of the disputed act, order or ruling; 
(5)  A statement of the act, order or ruling complained of; 
(6)  A statement of reasons why such act, order or ruling is incorrect and a declaration of the act the appellant desires by the building official; and 
(7)  The mailing address of the appellant. 
(b)  The statement referred to herein shall be signed by the owner of the subject property or by a representative of a contractor working or applying to work on the subject property, as the case may be, and duly acknowledged under oath. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-43. - Notice to appellant as to change in action complained of. 
Within ten (10) consecutive, regular business days after receipt of a statement under the provisions of section 9-42, the building official shall deposit in the mail a written notice stating whether or not the act, order, or ruling complained of has been or is to be changed, and if so, in what manner and when the change was or will be made. Such notice shall be addressed to the appellant at the mailing address shown in such statement. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-44. - Request for hearing. 
Within ten (10) days after the mailing of a notice pursuant to section 9-43, and not thereafter, the appellant may file with the city secretary a written request in the English language for a hearing upon such notice, together with a true copy of the appellant's written statement filed pursuant to section 9-42 and a true copy of the notice received by the appellant under section 9-43. The appellant must clearly state in his written request his objections to the notice, the grounds of the objections, and the particular commission action requested thereon. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-45. - Fixing time for hearing. 
The city secretary shall fix a hearing day for such appeal at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-46. - Notice of time and place of hearing. 
The city secretary shall mail or cause to be mailed written notice of the hour and day set for a hearing under this division to the appellant, at the address shown in his statement filed under section 9-42 within not less than five (5) days prior to the day fixed for the hearing. Such notice shall name a chamber or office within the city hall where such appeal shall be heard. The deposit, in the mail, of such written notice of hearing shall be deemed conclusive proof of notice given. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-47. - Right of building official and other appropriate parties to be heard and to introduce evidence. 
The building official and other appropriate city employees shall have the right to be heard at a hearing held under this division and to introduce evidence therein. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-48. - Commission action and notice thereof. 
The commission shall have the right to affirm, notify or reverse the act, order or ruling appealed from under this division. Written notice of the commission's decision shall be mailed to the appellant in the manner prescribed in section 9-46. In no case shall such notice of decision be mailed later than thirty (30) days after the first day of such hearing. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-49. - Interested member disqualified from voting. 
No commission member shall vote upon any appeal before the commission in which he/she is an appealing party. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-50. - Appealed action not suspended or abated during appeal. 
Nothing in this division shall be construed to operate, during an appeal, as a suspension or abatement to any act, order or ruling of the building official unless and until such suspension or abatement is effected by the written decision or modification or reversal, if any, of the appealed act, order or ruling. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 9-51—9-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Electrical code, Ch. 12; fire prevention code, § 13-151; heating, air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration code, Ch. 16; plumbing code, Ch. 29; signs, Ch. 31. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 9-60. - 2015 International Building Code—Adopted. 
This section hereby adopts 2015 International Building Code for all commercial projects in this jurisdiction; this shall include multifamily residential projects. Exception: One- and two-family dwellings must comply with the 2015 edition of the International Residential Code, per the requirements of sections 9-62 and 9-63. 
(1)  Any previously adopted specific reference to the BOCA Building Code, the BOCA National Building Code, the BOCA Basic Building Code or the 2003 edition of the NFPA 5000 Building Construction and Safety Code in the Code of Ordinances for the City of Pasadena is hereby changed to read as per the relative section of the 2015 International Building Code. This includes but is not limited to the following specific references in the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances: 
a.  Section 9-2. General requirements for multifamily dwellings. 
b.  Section 9-2.1. Living requirements for multifamily dwellings. 
c.  Section 9-4. Fence or wall for multifamily dwelling. 
d.  Section 31-9. Sign applications, permits and fees. 
e.  Section 31-14. Structural requirements; generally and for specific signs. 
f.  Section 33-1.006. Conflicts in construction. (pools) 
(2)  If for any reason whatsoever there exist any conflicts, contradictions, discrepancies or omissions from the previous building codes and/or ordinances and the 2015 International Building Code, as adopted, the more stringent requirements shall apply unless otherwise allowed or directed by the "Authority Having Jurisdiction". 
(3)  Building permit department fees. General requirements and conditions apply to all permits, registrations or other specific conditions are as follows: 
Any fee for permit, registration and other fees identified in this section is required to be permitted as identified by the fee schedule(s). 
No permit in any case or project discipline will be less than a minimum standard $50.00 including the application fee, for processing and allows for one site inspection except as specifically identified elsewhere in this Code. Fees not specifically modified or adjusted will be charged a fee as previously established in Code. 
a.  Building fee schedule. 
1.  Commercial. New commercial construction, additions, alterations and repairs. The fee for all types of commercial constructions, additions, alterations, and repairs shall be computed at the rate of twenty cents ($0.20) per square foot of area covered by roof or similar structure to include stand alone foundations with required review approvals. This is the accumulative aggregate of all floor(s) square footages. Provided that the fee computed shall never be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Foundation only permits will have specific conditions required with allowance based on the project conditions. 
2.  Residential. The fee for all types of new one- and two-family residential dwelling construction, additions, alterations and repairs shall be computed at the rate of twenty cents ($0.20) per square foot covered by roof or similar structure. This is the accumulative aggregate of all floor(s) square footages. Provided that the fee computed shall never be less than fifty dollars ($50.00). Residential storage buildings one hundred (100) square feet and under are exempt from permit requirements, but must comply with setback requirements. Foundation-only permits for all types of new one- and two-family residential dwelling construction and additions shall not be allowed unless specifically authorized and fees paid as per normal construction of one-story under roof. 
The construction of residential garages, shops, barns, storage and other utility type structures at 1,200 square feet or less are allowed to be constructed to residential standards, those structures over 1,200 square feet must be constructed to all commercial building for fire separations/distances, design loads and structural conditions, mechanical, electrical and plumbing codes and standards. Yet the structure can be used for private residential use only without required plumbing fixture ratios without any type of business, operation or advertisement use allowed with minimum improved residential off-street parking access. In no case can a structure over 1,200 square feet be allowed to be constructed closer than five (5) feet from any property line and must satisfy all property specific setback requirements. 
3.  Roof system repair or replacement. Roof system replacement and/or repairs in excess of 25 per cent of each roof requires permits. 
i.  The permit fee for any residential roofing repair or replacement shall be forty dollars ($40.00) for each structure inclusive of the application. This is for overlay only or replacement of like materials and any minor decking and structural work, with the approval of the building inspector or a plan reviewer. 
ii.  The permit for any commercial roofing, repair or replacements shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each structure plus the standard ten dollars ($10.00) application. This is for overlay only or replacement of like materials and any minor decking and structural work, with the approval of the building inspector or a plan reviewer. 
Commercial roof projects where the roof is to be altered or structurally modified in any form must provide engineered drawings and the plan review fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), the building permit fee will be no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). The identified fees apply per each building. 
Wood shingle, shake and other combustible roofing materials are specifically prohibited in any type of roofing project with the exception of minor repairs to existing residential single-family homes. 
4.  Plan checking and review. 
i.  Commercial building permit. An applicant for commercial building permit for construction, alteration, additions or repairs shall submit with the application two (2) sets of plans and specifications complete with topography, landscape, boundary survey, drainage, electrical, plumbing, ADA compliance, IECC compliance and heating-air conditioning. The applicant shall also submit a plan review fee in the amount equal to one-half (½) of the building permit fee of twenty cents ($0.20) per square foot of area covered under roof. This plan review fee shall be ten cents ($0.10) per square foot under roof. That said plan review fee shall never be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). The plan review fee shall be submitted in advance when submitting the application package for construction, no routing or plan review will take place prior to the fees being satisfied. Plan checking fee shall not be refundable. 
ii.  Residential building permit. An applicant for a residential building permit for construction, alteration, additions, or repairs shall submit with the application two (2) sets of drawings of plans and specifications complete with a boundary survey, and any plans for plumbing, electrical, IECC compliance and heating-air conditions. The minimum plan review fee shall be computed at ten cents ($0.10) per square foot for any construction, alteration, additions or repairs for five hundred (500) square feet or more under roof. No plan review fee will be charged for any plan review of residential construction project covering less than five hundred (500) square feet under roof. All detached structures will be viewed as independent construction with plan review fees incurred for construction over five hundred (500) square feet under roof. 
5.  Application fee. Where not otherwise specified in this section, there shall be a ten dollar ($10.00) application fee charged for all permits issued, regardless of the discipline. 
6.  Fences. Permits for new residential fences shall be forty dollars ($40.00) including the application fee. Permits for new commercial fences shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per one thousand (1,000) linear feet or additional portion thereof plus an application fee. Permits for new commercial storage lot fences shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per five hundred (500) linear feet or additional portion thereof plus an application fee. The permit fee for a multi-family fence shall be calculated at the rate of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each five hundred (500) lineal feet or part thereof in the length of each side of the fence or wall, gates and doors inclusive plus an application fee. Repair and replacement of alike materials in the exact same location and elevations are exempt unless the fence and attachments thereof are found in violation of other City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances or specific business requirements. 
7.  Reinspection. Where all or any part of an operation authorized by a permit issued hereunder fails to pass inspection, a reinspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) may be charged for each required subsequent inspection. 
8.  Failure to obtain permit. The identification of a fee shall determine the requirement for a permit in any discipline in this Code. No construction, alteration, removal, demolition or other building operation shall be commenced until the required fees, as set forth in this Code, have been paid and a permit issued and where such operations have begun prior to issuance of the permit, all such operations shall cease and the property be placed on "HOLD" until a fee equal to twice the fee that would normally be required and a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) administrative fee have been paid and a proper permit approved and issued. Mechanical, electrical and plumbing permits shall be required for any category and/or work for which a fee is established. This includes any installation, modification, alteration, addition to, relocations or other work determined to require a permit per the building official or his duly appointed agent(s). 
9.  Driveways, approaches, sidewalk. The fee for construction or alteration of any portion of a driveway, approach or sidewalk shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each portion when included in a building permit. The stand alone fee(s) will be the same plus the application but in no case less than forty dollars ($40.00) residential and sixty dollars ($60.00) commercial for each permit issued, inclusive of the application. 
10.  Carport, canopy, awning and similar overhead structure(s). The fee for each carport, canopy, awning and similar overhead structure(s) or installations will be calculated at ten cents ($0.10) per square foot under roof but in no case shall the permit be less than fifty dollars ($50.00) including application. The residential construction and/or erection must satisfy setbacks and construction requirements as identified in section 9-76 of this Code. Those structures in excess of five hundred (500) per square foot shall satisfy the plan review fee requirements and satisfy minimum commercial design requirements. Carports cannot be enclosed nor any portion of the structure capable of occupancy or habitation, this specifically prohibits storage areas above a residential carport unless the minimum required setbacks can be satisfied. 
Any type of carport, canopy, awning and similar overhead structure(s) or installations at a commercial site or for commercial/business use, must satisfy all relative commercial building/plan review fee(s) and design requirements. 
11.  Culverts. The fee for a permit to install residential stormwater culverts shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
12.  Incinerators. The fee for a permit for the construction or installation of an incinerator shall be one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) for each unit. 
13.  Storage tanks and product lines. The permit fee for a permit for the installation or removal of any type above or below grade storage tank or product lines shall be one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for each tank. 
14.  Demolition. The fee for a permit for the demolition of a building, a structure or any portion thereof shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for residential and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for commercial and the permit shall be good for thirty (30) days only or the duration of the remodel project. This fee is in addition to the normal building permit fee but can be added to at half the rate of the normal rate when inclusive in a building remodel permit. If a demolition fee is included with a commercial or residential building permit, the demolition is allowed to run concurrent with the respective building permit. 
15.  House moving within, into or out of the City of Pasadena. No structure can be relocated within or outside the city limits without the satisfying of an inspection prior to the move at a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). This fee is in addition to the permit fees and procedures for the building and placement and the other specifics identified elsewhere in the code(s). The licensed mover must provide approved routes and copies of TXDOT required permits prior to the start of the moving into, outside or within the jurisdiction of the City of Pasadena. 
16.  Paving. Paving installations, including landscape islands shall be priced at twenty dollars ($20.00) per every five thousand (5,000) square feet or portion thereof, with a minimum fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Any consideration or type of surface areas for storage lot of shall be priced at seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per every three thousand (3,000) square feet or portion thereof, with a minimum fee of one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00), this permit will only be available with all required improvements. 
Fee for a commercial, equipment/storage yard or multifamily residential parking lot area shall be based upon twenty dollars ($20.00) per first ten thousand (10,000) square feet and ten dollars ($10.00) per any additional five thousand (5,000) square feet or portion thereof. Fee for a one- or two-family residential off-street parking area shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). 
17.  Paving and/or parking repairs. Paving and/or parking repairs shall require a permit for any type repair or rework to include asphalt patching, potholes, curb and concrete repairs with a minimum fee of sixty dollars ($60.00). Repairs or improvements at/or over fifty (50) percent of existing area shall be brought into minimum off-street paving and parking requirements with the exceptions of landscaping, parking count and current stormwater drainage at existing business locations. 
This does not supersede the change of use or ownership compliance requirements with regards to the certificate of occupancy program. This is to include storage lot surface areas. Storage lots require permit for any site repairs or improvements and must be completed to minimum codes and standards. 
18.  Swimming pools. 
1.  Swimming pool contractors must register the legal company name, officers, responsible party/parties and insurance information as required per minimum requirements for plumbing contractors to include insurance responsibilities and responsible party or parties are identified, with the permit department on a form provided by the permit department for an annual fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). This registration will be good for one calendar year from the date of initial registration or subsequent follow up annual registrations unless the required insurance is not maintained. 
2.  All swimming pools/spa(s) shall be permitted and fee(s) applied in the same manner as building permits with the improved water surface area, measured in square feet to be used in the building fee calculation of the pool(s)/spa(s). No pool/spa shall be used or in any way occupied for recreation without satisfying all inspections. All local, state and federal requirements shall be the responsibility of the permit holder. Any violation of these requirements will be the sole responsibility of the permit holder/contractor. Plan review fees will apply to all swimming pool projects. 
19.  Address modifications. The administrative fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for each such condition shall be charged for changing or correcting permit addresses, application information or other modifications requested or necessary to any permit process, after the clerical setup of permits are completed by the permit office. This will only be completed after a written request is provided by the original applicant or owner stating specific requested revisions and reason(s) for the request. 
20.  Certificate of occupancy for an existing building or space. It shall be unlawful to make any change in the use or occupancy of any existing structure and/or space to be used for a commercial purpose which would make it subject to any special provision of this and any other applicable code, without obtaining a certificate of occupancy from the City of Pasadena Permit Department, prior to any release of utilities (electrical, gas or water) being approved by the City of Pasadena Building Official or the Permit Department. If there is no change within the use group classification by the new occupant of any existing structure to be used for a commercial purpose, the existing off-street parking requirements shall be deemed to be adequate. Variance procedures for any landscaping site plan requirements shall be submitted to the City of Pasadena Planning and Zoning Commission in accordance with chapter 9, building and general regulations, section 9-199(C) of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pasadena. A certificate of occupancy shall be approved only after application is made and all codes deemed in compliance after inspection by the building official, the fire marshal, health department and the planning department or designated representatives. Such certifications shall be indicative that the structure or space meets the intent of the provisions of law governing building regulations for the purposed new occupant/occupancy and that such change does not result in any greater hazard to the public safety or welfare. A fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the inspections shall be submitted with the application for the certificate of occupancy. 
21.  Certificates of occupancy. Certificates of occupancy issued with a one- or two-family project will be a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) added to the permit and plan review fees. Commercial project certificate of occupancy's in conjunction with a permit will be a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) added to the permit and plan review fees. 
22.  Temporary certificate of occupancy or a letter of completion. The fee for a temporary certificate of occupancy or a letter of completion (no occupancy) shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) and will only be provided at written request of the owner, applicant or the general contractor. 
23.  Temporary utility release(s). The fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) will be required with a written request for any and all utility release(s) to an owner or agent for the cleaning, showing or other requests for commercial spaces without occupancy. This type of release(s) will only be available after inspector site inspection and approval for a maximum of ninety (90) days but can be renewed for the same price for each additional ninety (90) days or portion thereof with an additional written request and department approval. 
24.  Annual building contractor registration fee. All building and remodel contractors must register with the City of Pasadena Permit Department for an initial fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) and annual renewal fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Residential contractors must provide verifiable Builder Registration proof of compliance with the Texas Residential Construction Commission program. Commercial building contractors for any new construction or the remodel of an existing structure must provide a minimum proof of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) liability insurance with the City of Pasadena as a certificate holder. The annual City of Pasadena registration will be valid concurrent with the same date as the state for residential contractors, the commercial builders/contractors' registration will be valid for one year from the annual anniversary of the registration date, or the valid insurance period whichever is most stringent. Loss of registration with the state or failure to maintain proper insurance will void any City of Pasadena registration and require renewal to reinstate the required registration. 
Exemption: Homeowners with homestead exemptions per the current tax records or an individual that is building or remodeling a personal single-family dwelling for the purpose of habitation by this same individual are exempt from this registration.

3.  Annual occupancy license fee(s). The fee(s) from section 16½-7 of the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances will be as follows: 
i.  The annual occupancy licensing fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per dwelling unit including the annual inspection fee for a duplex or triplex. The annual occupancy fee for multiunit complex with four (4) or more units shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) base fee per multifamily complex. There will be an annual inspection fee of three dollars and twenty-five cents ($3.25) per unit, with a minimum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per multifamily complex. 
ii.  The annual occupancy license fee and unit inspection fees shall be due and payable to the City of Pasadena Permit Division on or before the expiration date of the license. 
iii.  A replacement license may be issued for lost, destroyed, or mutilated licensed upon application of the form provided by the administrator for a fee of five dollars ($5.00). A replacement license shall have the word "replacement" stamped across the face and shall bear the same number as the [license] replaced. 
4.  Itinerant vendors and solicitors license fees. The fees for section 25-15 of the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances will be as follows: 
The fee for an itinerant vendor's license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). When any person engages in any activity mentioned in section 25-11 through one or more agents or employees, such person shall, in addition to such $50.00 fee, pay a license fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each agent or employee so engaged. The fees provided for herein shall be used for the purpose of defraying expenses incident to the issuing of such licenses. No such fee shall be prorated. 
f.  Holds, revocation, fines and penalties. 
1.  Contractors or homeowners with two (2) or more outstanding re-inspect fees on any current project permit will be placed on administrative "HOLD" and will not be extended any further inspections until re-inspect fees are paid, arrangements are satisfied with the required inspector or supervisor to satisfy release of the permit "HOLD" status. 
2.  Double fees plus a twenty-five dollars ($25.00) administrative fee shall be paid prior to issuance of permits for any work started prior to permit issuance unless verifiable through the request received time on the escrow system that is available for contractors. 
3.  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor to violate any provision or requirement hereof and any person convicted of violating any provision, restriction, requirement, or prohibition of this chapter for which no specific penalty is provided shall be fined in a sum of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. Each offense is independent and can be prosecuted separately. 
4.  Contractors and/or projects may be put on administrative "HOLD" by the permit department for violations of any provisions of local code, State of Texas or other Federal Program(s). 
g.  Permit suspension or revocation. A permit may be suspended or revoked for any one of the following reasons: 
1.  Fraud or misrepresentation in obtaining a permit. 
2.  Violating either willfully or maliciously or by reason of incompetence, any provision of this section or adopted codes with amendments thereto. 
3.  Conviction of defrauding any person for whom he/she has rendered or contracted to render service. 
4.  Contractors with three (3) or more outstanding re-fees on all permits in this jurisdiction shall be placed on administrative "HOLD" until recovery efforts are satisfied with the city permit department. Additionally, if the contractor fails to satisfy this requirement, the contractor will have all permits cancelled and the contractor registration revoked. If this transpires, it will require that all new applications, permit and contractor registration fees must be satisfied. 
5.  Failure on the contractor to satisfy all inspection requirements and properly close out permits with requested and approved final inspections will result in the contractor being placed on administrative "HOLD" until all necessary inspections are satisfied with the city permit department. 
h.  Specific policies and procedures. 
1.  Scheduled overtime inspections. Shall be scheduled and paid for by 4:00 p.m. on the business day prior to the requested scheduled inspection. The fee shall be two hundred forty dollars ($240.00) for a three-hour maximum inspection, including driving time. Time will commence when the inspector leaves the office or his home (portal to portal). Inspections exceeding three (3) hours, including travel time, will require the charge of a new overtime inspection at the above rate for every additional three (3) hours or portion thereof, as described above. 
2.  Emergency inspections. Emergency inspections may be conducted as per subsection 1. above with the exception that the requestor contractor or property owner shall satisfy the permit process within two (2) full business days (forty-eight (48) hours elapsed) after the permit department is open for normal business. Failure to satisfy this requirement may subject the property or project to removal of utilities and/or revocation/denial of the certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-61. - Same—Amendments. 
This section hereby sets forth and adopts amendments to the 2015 International Building Code. Specific items to be changed, amended, replaced and or deleted are as follows: 
(1)  101.1 Insert [City of Pasadena, Texas] and add after "this code" at end of sentence: to include all applicable requirements in the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  101.4.1 - .7 Deleted in its entirety and insert: All installations must comply with Chapters 12, 16, 16½ and 29 with approved amendments from the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances. 
(3)  103 Change the reference to the "Department of Public Safety" in all locations in the International Building Code(s) to read the "Permit Department for the City of Pasadena". 
(4)  103.1 Delete this and infill/modify the language to read: This must comply with the established requirements per [Chapter 9] Section 9 of the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances. 
(5)  105.2 Deleted in its entirety and insert: 
All construction, modifications or installations must comply with Chapters 12, 16, 16½ and 29 with approved amendments from the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances. 
(6)  Delete Sections 106, 107, 108, 110, 112, 113 and 115 and replace all to read as follows: 
This must comply with the existing established requirements per relative elements of [Chapter 9] Section 9 of the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances. 
(7)  Section 202; amend definition of Ambulatory Care Facility as follows: 
AMBULATORY CARE FACILITY. DIVISION 2. - BUILDING CODE REGULATING ELEVATORS, ESCALATORS AND MOVING WALKS 
 
Sec. 9-64. - Scope. 
The provisions of this Code shall apply to the design, construction, installation, maintenance, operation, alteration and repair of all new and existing elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, manlifts, moving walks, inclined chairlifts, wheelchair lifts, and personnel hoists. 
All of the above type installations must comply with the requirements of the Texas Health and Safety Code, Chapter 754 (Vernon Supp. 2002) in its current form. The license and permit programs will be administered by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation in Austin, Texas. The cite for that department's rules regulating elevators is 16 Administrative Code Chapter 74, in its current form. 
The Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation will honor the current license of equipment and installations that are currently approved and duly licensed or permitted for operation within this jurisdiction until such time as renewal of license or operating permits are required for the same. The Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation shall begin overseeing the design, construction, installation, maintenance, operation, alteration and repair of all new and existing elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, manlifts, moving walks, inclined chairlifts, wheelchair lifts, and personnel hoists on January 1, 2004. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-65. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms, for the purposes of this Code and as used elsewhere, shall have the meanings shown herein: 
Automotive lift: A fixed mechanical device for raising an entire motor vehicle above the floor level, but not through successive floors of the building or structure. 
Conveyors: A system of machinery and manual or mechanized devices other than elevator and dumbwaiter equipment, consisting of belts, chains, rollers, buckets, aprons, slides and chutes and other miscellaneous equipment for hoisting, lowering and transporting materials and merchandise in packages or in bulk in any direction in a building or structure. 
Dumbwaiter: A hoisting and lowering mechanism with a car of limited capacity and size which moves in guides in a substantially vertical direction and is used exclusively for carrying material. 
Elevator: A hoisting and lowering mechanism equipped with a car or platform which moves in guides for the transportation of individuals or freight in a substantially vertical direction through successive floors or levels of a building or structure. 
Elevator repairs: All work necessary to maintain present elevator equipment in a safe and serviceable condition and to adjust or replace defective, broken or worn parts with parts made of equivalent material, strength and design, and only where the replacing part performs the same function as the replaced part. 
Escalator: A power-driven, inclined, continuous stairway used for raising and lowering passengers. 
Freight elevator: An elevator primarily used for carrying freight and on which only the operator and the persons necessary for loading or unloading and employees having special permission of the building official are permitted to ride. 
Freight lift: A power-operated raising and lowering device for transporting freight vertically, operating entirely within one (1) story of the building or structure. 
Hand elevator: A freight elevator that is driven by manual power. 
Hoist, material platform: A manually or power-operated suspended platform conveyance operating in guide rails for the exclusive raising or lowering of materials, which is operated and controlled from a point outside the conveyance. 
Hoisting and conveying equipment, special: Manually or power-operated hoisting, lowering or conveying mechanisms - other than elevators, escalators, or dumbwaiters - for the transport of persons or freight in vertical, inclined or horizontal direction on one (1) floor or in successive floors. 
Hoisting and elevating equipment, miscellaneous: All power-operated hoisting and elevating equipment for raising, lowering and moving persons or merchandise from one (1) level to another, such as: inclined elevators; slings and hooks; tiering and piling machines not permanently located in a fixed position; mine elevators; skip hoists for blast furnaces; stage and orchestra lifts; lift bridges; temporary builders' hoists; and similar equipment. 
Hydraulic elevator: A power elevator in which the motion of the car is obtained through the application of force from liquid under pressure. 
Moving walk: A type of passenger-carrying device on which passengers stand or walk, and in which the passenger-carrying surface remains parallel to its direction of motion and is uninterrupted. 
Passenger elevator: An elevator for the transportation of individuals. 
Power elevator: An elevator in which the motion of the car is obtained through the application of force other than by hand or gravity. 
Sidewalk elevator: A freight elevator which operates between a sidewalk or other area exterior to the building and floor levels inside the building below such area, which does not have a landing opening into the building at its upper limit of travel and which is not used to carry automobiles. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 9-66—9-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SETBACK REQUIREMENTS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to establish building lines on streets, Art. I, § 5. 
Cross reference— Fences and walls for junkyards and automobile wrecking yards to conform to setback requirements, § 17-47; fence or wall for outside storage of used goods, wares and merchandise to conform to setback requirements, § 17-68; setback requirements for mobile homes located outside mobile home park, § 21-44; setback requirements for units and mobile homes in mobile home parks, § 21-64; ground signs to comply with setback requirements, § 31-64(d); setback requirements for townhouse subdivisions, App. B, § 2B. 
 
Sec. 9-76. - Generally. 
(a)  No permit for the construction, erection or installation of a building or structure, or parts of a building or structure, shall be issued for the construction, erection or installation of a building or structure within twenty-five (25) feet of: 
(1)  The property line on the front side of the property; or 
(2)  The existing or ultimate proposed future right-of-way lines of any street, road, avenue, highway or drive or any extensions thereof as set forth in the major street plan for Pasadena, Texas. 
Provided, however, that a carport may be erected in conjunction with single or duplex residential dwellings unless prohibited by a subdivision deed restriction. It is the duty of the applicant for the permit to determine if there exists any subdivision deed restrictions which prohibit the erection of the carport and by applying for the permit certifies to the city that such a prohibition does not exist. 
Carports which are permitted under this section may be constructed of wood or metal and shall be attached to the main structure at the innermost end with either a flat roof or a roof with a pitch not to exceed four-foot vertical on twelve-foot horizontal. The carport shall not have any ceiling openings accessible for any storage area, shall be supported at its outermost end by not more than two (2) stanchions (poles) with braces anchored in a manner approved by the building official, and such poles shall not be placed nearer than five (5) feet from any property line. The horizontal portion of the carport framework shall not be less than eight (8) feet nor more than twelve (12) feet above grade (natural ground) elevation. The stanchions supporting the carport shall be separated by not more than twenty (20) feet and the roof overhang shall not exceed two (2) feet from the supporting stanchions on any side. No wall shall be erected or attached to any carport permitted under this section. 
(b)  No permit for the construction, erection or installation of a single or duplex residential building or structure, or parts of such building or structure, shall be issued for the construction, erection or installation of such building or structure, within five (5) feet of any property line, subject to subsection (a) hereof. For purposes of this subsection (b) "single residential building or structure" means a building occupied exclusively for residential purposes or as a boarding or rooming house serving not more than fifteen (15) persons with meals or sleeping accommodations or both. 
"Duplex residential building or structure" means a building occupied exclusively for residence purposes and having two (2) apartments, or as a boarding or rooming house serving not more than fifteen (15) persons with meals or sleeping accommodations or both. 
(c)  No permit for the construction, erection, or installation of a service station gasoline island metal canopy having a clearance of at least twelve (12) feet above the finished grade elevation shall be issued nearer than ten (10) feet from any property line. Any stanchion(s) supporting the metal canopy for a service station gasoline island shall not encroach onto the property setback lines as set forth elsewhere in this article. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-77. - Conformity with recorded subdivision plats. 
No permit shall be issued for the construction or erection of a building or structure between the right-of-way line of any street, avenue or drive, and the building setback lines as dedicated and shown by the plats of subdivisions within the city which have been properly filed of record in the deed or map records of Harris County, except that permits may be issued for the construction or erection of a building or a structure up to a distance of twenty (20) feet from the right-of-way line in the 700 and 800 blocks of Center Street. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17) 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, App. A, App. B.  
Sec. 9-78. - Private garages, sheds, shops, etc. 
(a)  Unattached. No permit shall be issued for the construction, erection or installation of a building or structure, or part of a building or structure, to be occupied exclusively as a private garage, shed, shop or other nonresidential use, or any combination thereof, located on the same lot with a dwelling, and not attached to such dwelling, within three (3) feet of the lot line of the adjoining property nearest either side of such private garage, shed, shop, building or structure or within five (5) feet of the rear lot line of the lot on which the same is situated. 
(b)  Attached. No permit shall be issued for the construction, erection or installation of a building or structure, or part of a building or structure, to be occupied exclusively as a private garage, shed, shop or other nonresidential use, or any combination thereof, located on the same lot with a dwelling, and attached to the dwelling, within five (5) feet of the lot line of the adjoining property nearest either side of such private garage, shed, shop, building or structure or within five (5) feet of the rear lot line of the lot on which the same is situated. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-79. - Variances. 
The building official, with city council approval, may authorize a variance from these regulations when, in his opinion, undue hardship will result from requiring strict compliance. In granting a variance, the building official shall prescribe only conditions that he deems necessary to or desirable in the public interest. In making the findings hereinbelow required, the building official shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land involved, existing uses of land in the vicinity, the number of persons who will reside or work at the proposed location, and the probable effect of such variance upon traffic conditions and upon the public health, safety, convenience and welfare in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the building official, with city council approval, finds: 
(a)  That there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the land involved such that the strict application of the provisions of this article would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land; and 
(b)  That the variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the applicant; and 
(c)  That the granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, or injurious to other property in the area; and 
(d)  That the granting of the variance will not have the effect of preventing the orderly development of other land in the area in accordance with the provisions of this article. Such findings of the building official, together with the specific facts upon which such findings are based, shall be kept on file in the office of the building official. Variances may be granted only when in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this article so that the public health, safety and welfare may be secured and substantial justice done. Pecuniary hardship to those seeking the variance, standing alone, shall not be deemed to constitute undue hardship. 
(e)  That the city traffic director has made a favorable recommendation relative to the effect on traffic safety of the proposed variance. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 9-80—9-92. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - HOUSE LEVELING 
 
Sec. 9-93. - Definition. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, a "house leveler" is a person who levels a house or any other type of building that is either on blocks or on a slab, by adjusting or repairing same, or by reenforcing the foundation of a house or building, by any method or means used. 
(b)  Any person who is contracted, hired or obtained by any method, or by any system, to obtain the services of a "house leveler" shall be deemed to be a "house leveler" and shall be regulated by this article. 
(c)  A "house leveler" or any person so defined in this section shall be referred to as a "leveler" in this article. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-94. - Violations of article. 
Any violation of any provision of this article shall be deemed a misdemeanor and each and every day that such violation continues shall be a separate violation. Upon conviction, any person guilty of such violation shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-95. - Permit required; permit fee. 
Any leveler shall be required to obtain a permit from the department of building inspection before any work is done on the proposed site. A twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee shall be required for such permit. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-96. - Leveler's bond or insurance. 
(a)  When a leveler applies for a permit to level a house or building, or repair the foundation of a house or building, he shall submit to the department of building inspection a good and sufficient surety bond or insurance policy (in the event of a bond, to be executed by some good solvent bonding company authorized to do business in this state, and in the event of an insurance policy, to be executed by some good solvent insurance company authorized to do business in this state). Such surety bond or insurance policy shall be in the sum of at least ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and shall be conditioned that the obligor therein will pay, to the extent of the face amount of such surety bond or insurance policy, all judgments which may be recovered against the leveler by reason of the wrongful or illegal acts of the leveler, or his servants, officers, agents or employees, that are committed in the performance of his or their duties. Such surety bond or insurance policy shall be further conditioned that such person so injured shall have the right to sue directly upon the bond or policy in his own name, and the same shall be subject to successive suits for recovery until a complete exhaustion for the face amount thereof. 
(b)  Such bond or insurance policy shall be further conditioned that if the leveler abandons or wholly fails to carry out the provisions of any contract with a subscriber for his services, the same shall be prima facie evidence of the right of the subscriber to demand and recover up to the full face amount of such bond or insurance policy as liquidated damages for such failure to provide the service as contracted. 
(c)  Such bond or insurance policy shall be further conditioned that it shall not expire for at least six (6) months after the job for which a permit is sought is completed. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-97. - Plans and specifications. 
When a leveler requests a permit to level a house or building, or repair a foundation, he shall submit to the department of building inspection two (2) copies of plot plans or specifications, which shall reveal the dimensions of the house or building and that portion of the house or building that needs leveling. If the slab foundation is cracked, the location of the area in which the foundation is cracked shall be marked on the plans or specifications. One (1) copy of such plans or specifications will be returned to the leveler when his permit is issued, and the department of building inspection will retain the other copy. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-98. - Inspection of work; plank requirements. 
When the leveler to whom a permit is issued under this article has excavated and has placed the jack or plank (which plank shall not be less than a good 4? by 4? wooden plank) in position, the leveler shall call the building official to the site for inspection of same. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-99. - Correction of rejected work; new permit required. 
If the building official rejects a job inspected under this article due to the leveler's failure, in the judgment of the building official to comply with the minimum standards, for such work, the leveler must make the necessary corrections and it shall be necessary for him to obtain another permit, with the same fees, before the building official will return to the site and make another inspection. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 9-100—9-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - HOUSE MOVING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 9-111. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
House. By the term "house," is meant any building or structure used or designed to be used for human habitation or occupancy in any manner or for any purpose. 
House moving. By the term "house moving" is meant the transportation of a house from place to place along or across any public street or alley within the corporate limits of the city. 
Licensee. The term "licensee" shall mean any person to whom a license required by section 9-131 has been issued. 
Street. The term "street" shall mean any part of the street, including the sidewalk area. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-112. - Permit. 
(a)  Any licensee desiring to move any house shall, prior to beginning work, apply for and obtain a permit from the building official. Such application shall show the present location of the house, the new location, the proposed route of moving, the size and type of construction of the house, and such other information as the building official may require. The licensee shall pay a permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each structure to be moved, where the ground space of the structure does not exceed four hundred (400) square feet. For each structure to be moved that has a ground space of more than four hundred (400) square feet, the permit fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00), plus one-half (½) cent for each square foot in excess of four hundred (400). In case of buildings of two (2) stories or more, the fee shall be fifty (50) per cent more than that above stated herein. The permit fees herein provided for are in addition to the yearly license fee provided for in section 9-134. 
(b)  The permit fees prescribed in subsection (a) shall apply to the moving of a house from one (1) location to another within the city or from within the city to a point outside the city. The fee for a permit to move a house which has been previously permanently located outside the city into the city shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such house. 
(c)  Written notice of the filing of an application for a permit under this section, together with a copy of such application, shall be served by the applicant or his agent upon the owner of any wires, poles or other structure located upon the streets, alleys or public places which may be affected by the moving of the house. Such notice, together with the copy of the application, shall be served on such owner at least three (3) days before the application for the permit shall be considered by the building official. If the owner of any such wires, poles or other structures located upon the streets, alleys or public places desires to file any objection to the application, he shall do so within three (3) days after the service of such notice and the building official may, after the expiration of such three-day period, grant or refuse such application, filing written reasons for refusal if such be the case, and in the event any objections have been filed thereto, he may extend the time for consideration of the application and notify all interested parties to appear before him for hearing thereon upon some specific date to be set by him, subject to confirmation of the city council. 
(d)  If a permit is granted under this section, the building official shall enter an order upon the application stating the conditions under which it is granted, designating the route along or over which the house, building or structure may be moved and the time within which the work of moving shall be completed. Each such permit shall show: 
(1)  The name of the licensee. 
(2)  The present location of the house. 
(3)  The proposed new location. 
(4)  The route of moving, as approved by the chief of police. 
(5)  The exact date and time during which the house will occupy the street and sidewalk. 
(6)  The time that the house is allowed to remain in the streets. 
(7)  The size and type of construction of the house. 
(8)  The receipt of the permit fee. 
(e)  Each permit provided for in this section shall be issued in duplicate and one (1) copy shall be posted on the house to be moved. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-113. - Bond. 
A licensee, when applying for a permit to move a building, shall be required to post a bond or valid insurance policy in the minimum amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which shall be issued by a company doing business in the State of Texas, for the purpose of guaranteeing payment by the licensee for any damages to city property incurred in the process of moving; and to guarantee that the licensee shall clear the property from which the building was moved of all debris within ten (10) days after moving such building. The insurance policy or bond shall be valid for at least six (6) months after the building has been moved. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-114. - Permanent location and installation to comply with codes and ordinances. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to begin or complete the moving of any house onto any property in the city unless the permanent location and installation of such house on such property in all respects complies with all applicable codes and ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-115. - Notice to chief of police and fire chief. 
Immediately upon issuance of a permit under this article, the building official shall notify the chief of police and the fire chief of the issuance of the permit, stating the route of moving, when the moving will begin and the number of days allowed. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-116. - Maximum time for occupancy of street. 
The maximum time during which a house may legally remain in a street under a permit granted pursuant to this article shall be twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 9-117. - House to be kept in motion.
