Death of One Person 
7 or less 	$5,000.00 	$300,000.00 
8 to 12 	5,000.00 	400,000.00 
13 to 20 	5,000.00 	500,000.00 
21 to 30 	5,000.00 	600,000.00 
31 or more 	5,000.00 	700,000.00 
 
For the injury or destruction of property in any one accident, limit of liability shall be not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). 
(c)  Such insurance shall be for the protection of the passengers of such bus or buses as well as for the general public but shall not cover personal injuries sustained by the servants, agents or employees of the person filing same. Policies issued under this section shall contain a provision for a continuing liability thereon up to the full amount thereon, notwithstanding a recovery thereon. 
(d)  If the director shall determine, after a hearing duly had, and after ten (10) days' notice is given to the operator, that any standard policy of insurance filed with the director has become so impaired so as to afford less protection to the public than when originally filed, he shall require a new and additional policy so as to bring the protection of such insurance to its original amount, the operator shall have five (5) days' notice after receiving notice of such requirement to provide the new or additional policy. In the event such operator fails to provide the additional policy required, his license shall automatically terminate and expire. 
(e)  Neither the city nor any of its officers shall be liable for the pecuniary responsibility or solvency of any such insurance or in any manner become liable for any sum on account of such claim or act of omission nor for any failure on the part of any of its officers or employees to have required either strict or substantial compliance by any operator with any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-15. - Certificate of self-insurance in lieu of insurance. 
(a)  A bus operator may, in lieu of the insurance requirements provided for in section 9½-14, file with the director a certificate of self-insurance issued by the state department of public safety in accordance with the provisions of the Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Law. In the event of the cancellation at any time of the certificate of self-insurance, the right of the holder of the bus license to operate buses thereunder on the streets of the city shall automatically be suspended and shall remain suspended until the restoration of the certificate of self-insurance or until the holder of the license complies with all the provisions of section 9½-14 concerning liability insurance. 
(b)  This section does not and shall not be construed to reduce the minimum insurance requirements of section 9½-14 based on seating capacity. The certificate of self-insurance shall only be accepted in lieu of an insurance policy in an amount which would be required to establish "proof of financial responsibility," as defined in subsection 10 of Section 1 of Article 1 of the Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Law, and any excess over that amount must be supplied by a policy of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-16. - Maintenance. 
All buses shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition and every bus shall be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected at least once in each twenty-four-hour period. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-17. - Equipment. 
All buses shall be equipped with rear vision mirrors, a double windshield wiper, a partition or other guard to keep passengers from standing to the left of the driver, proper headlights and taillights which shall always be in good working condition and which shall be lit from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise while and if the bus is being driven and four-wheel brakes which may be either hydraulic or air brakes and which shall always be kept in first-class working order. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-18. - Rates to be fixed by council. 
Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter, and notwithstanding the granting of any license pursuant to this chapter, the rates to be charged by the operator of any bus or line of buses shall and may be fixed and determined from time to time by the city council and such rates may be changed from time to time by the city council where passengers are transported for hire wholly within the city limits. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be deemed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any ordinance fixing such rates. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-19. - Posting of rates and routes. 
Every bus shall have posted in a conspicuous place in the bus the route to be travelled thereby and a schedule of the rates of fares and shall have painted on the front and on the rear thereof, or on both sides, a serial bus number indicating the bus route in accordance with such classification and enumeration of routes as the director may devise and order. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-20. - Inspection; correction of defects. 
The director, or his duly appointed representative, may at any time make tests and inspections of all buses, and if, as a result of such inspection, any bus is found to be in an unsatisfactory condition, the owner or operator thereof shall be notified of the defects observed and shall immediately correct same to the satisfaction of the director. If the director finds any bus to be unfit or unsafe for the carriage of passengers, he shall forthwith notify the operator of such bus or line of buses and such operator shall not thereafter cause or permit such bus to be operated on any street of the city until it has been made safe for the carriage of passengers. The director and any employee whom he may designate to the duty of inspection of buses shall be given free and ready access to all buses. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-21. - Drivers not to smoke or use tobacco. 
Drivers of buses shall not smoke or use tobacco during the time they are driving such buses. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-22. - Drivers not to work more than twelve hours in twenty-four-hour period. 
No driver of a bus shall drive the bus for more than twelve (12) hours in any twenty-four-hour period and no owner of any bus shall permit any person to drive such bus more than twelve (12) hours in any twenty-four-hour period. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-23. - Doors to be closed while in motion. 
The doors of a bus shall be securely closed at all times while the bus is in motion. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-24. - Receipt or discharge of passengers generally. 
Bus passengers shall not be received or discharged in the travelled portion of any street, but if passengers are to be received or discharged, the driver shall pull the bus to the curb and discharge the passengers on the side of the bus immediately against the curb. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-25. - Designation of loading points. 
Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter or any license granted under this chapter, the city reserves the right, by ordinance or by rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to any ordinance in effect at this time or hereafter passed, to designate certain areas within the city and certain portions of certain streets within the city and upon which passengers may not be loaded or discharged by any bus except at loading points to be so designated and to provide by penal ordinance for the prevention of loading or unloading within such areas or upon such streets except at such designated loading points. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-26. - Intoxicated passengers; indecent language by passengers. 
No person who is intoxicated shall be permitted to enter or ride in a bus, and no person shall curse or swear or use any indecent language in any bus. It shall be the duty of the driver of any bus to eject from such bus any person violating this section or to report such violation to a peace officer at the first opportunity. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-27. - Passengers not to ride on outside or block driver's vision. 
No driver of a bus shall permit or allow passengers or employees to stand or ride on the running board, dash board, fender or any outside portion of the bus, nor shall he permit any passenger to stand in such a position that the driver's vision forward or to the right front or left is blocked. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-28. - Conversation between driver and passengers. 
No driver of any bus shall converse with any passenger while the bus is in motion except to give necessary information, but he shall give his entire attention to the operation of the bus while the same is in motion. A sign or poster shall be carried in plain view of all passengers on a bus stating: "No passenger shall converse with the driver while the bus is in motion." 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-29. - Accident reports. 
Bus operators shall make immediate report to the director of each and every accident in which any bus is involved. Such report shall give the time and place of the accident, the number and names of all persons injured or killed, both passengers and nonpassengers. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-30. - Chapter does not affect city's right to regulate operation of vehicles. 
Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter or any license granted under this chapter, the city reserves the right, by ordinance or any other lawful rule or regulation, to regulate the operation of all motor vehicles on the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Sec. 9½-31. - Appeals from and stay of orders, rules or regulations of director under chapter. 
(a)  Any person dissatisfied with any order, rule or regulation of the director made by him pursuant to any provision of this chapter shall have the same right of appeal to the city council which is provided by section 9½-10 for appeals from his refusal to grant a certificate of public necessity and convenience, all of which appeals shall be perfected in the manner therein provided and shall be acted upon by the city council in the manner therein provided. Any appeal from any order, rule or decision of the director shall be perfected within ten (10) days from the date of the order, rule or regulation appealed from, and not thereafter. 
(b)  Upon the application of any person aggrieved by or dissatisfied by a rule, order or regulation made by the director pursuant to any provision of this chapter, the mayor may, if in his opinion the public safety or welfare will not be endangered by a temporary stay thereof, stay the effect and force of such rule, regulation or order pending appeal therefrom as hereinabove provided or pending the lapse of time within which to perfect an appeal. 
(Ord. No. 81-247, § 1, 12-22-81)  
Chapter 10 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-157, § 1, adopted August 4, 2009, amended chapter in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former chapter 10, §§ 10-1—10-10, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 03-22, §§ 1, 2, 2-4-03. 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Office of emergency management created. 
The Office of Emergency Management for the City of Pasadena is hereby created and constituted in accordance with state law as follows: 
(a)  The chief executive officer of the city, the mayor, is designated as the director of the office of emergency management. 
(b)  The director shall be responsible for a program of comprehensive emergency management within the city and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this chapter. The director may delegate authority for execution of these duties to the emergency management coordinator, but ultimate responsibility for such execution shall remain with the director. 
(c)  The director hereby appoints the emergency management coordinator. The emergency management coordinator shall serve at the pleasure of the director and shall be charged with the preparation of an emergency management plan for the City of Pasadena, operational supervision of the office, and such other duties as may be authorized and prescribed by the director. 
(d)  The emergency management coordinator shall serve as the department head for the office of emergency management. 
(e)  The emergency management coordinator shall be assisted by deputy coordinators, who shall serve as employees of the city within the office of emergency management. 
(f)  The operational emergency management organization of the City of Pasadena may consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the director in the emergency management plans, as well as organized volunteer groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency management plan. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-2. - Emergency management director; powers and duties. 
The powers and duties of the office of emergency management shall be exercised by the director either directly or by delegation, and shall include the following: 
(a)  Conduct an on-going survey of actual or potential hazards which threaten life and property within the city and an on-going program of identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster was to occur. 
(b)  Supervision of the development and approval of an emergency management plan for the City of Pasadena. 
(c)  The drafting, execution and recommendation for adoption by the city council of any and all mutual aid plans and agreements deemed essential or desirable for the implementation of the city's emergency plan and coordination of combined disaster services efforts. 
(d)  Authority to declare a local state of disaster. "Disaster" in this chapter shall mean the occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or manmade cause, including fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill or other water contamination, volcanic activity, epidemic air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot, hostile military or paramilitary action, other public calamity requiring emergency action, or energy emergency. "Energy emergency" shall mean a temporary statewide, regional, or local shortage of petroleum, natural gas, or liquid fuel energy supplies that make emergency measures necessary to reduce demand or allocate supply. The declaration of a local state of disaster may not be continued, nor may it be extended, for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the city council. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local state of disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city secretary. After the declaration of a local state of disaster, the director may in the interest of public safety and welfare, make orders for the following items, including but not limited to: 
(1)  A general curfew prohibiting any person or persons not officially authorized in connection with the civil emergency from walking, running, loitering, standing, motoring, or otherwise moving upon any alley, street, highway, public property, or vacant premises in the corporate limits of the City of Pasadena, applicable to such geographical areas and during such hours of the day or night as deemed necessary and advisable. 
(2)  The discontinuance of the sale of all alcoholic beverages and/or the closing of all establishments of portions thereof wherein the consumption or sale of alcoholic beverages is permitted. 
(3)  The discontinuance of the selling, distributing, or giving away of gasoline or other flammable or combustible products. 
(4)  The closing of gasoline stations and other establishments or portions thereof, the chief or a major activity of which is the sale, distribution or dispensing of liquid flammable of combustible products. 
(5)  The discontinuance of the selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
(6)  The closing of any or all establishments or portions thereof, a chief or major activity of which is the sale, distribution, dispensing or giving away of firearms and/or ammunition. 
(7)  The protection of life and property by such means as are imminently necessary and authorized under state law. 
(8)  The suspension or modification of the formal bidding requirements for purchase of goods and services as authorized by state law. 
(9)  The suspension or modification of the requirements for itinerant vendors' permits, electrician licenses, and similar regulations so as to give due consideration to the license, certificate, or other permit issued to a person by a state or any political subdivision of any state evidencing qualifications for professional, mechanical, or other skills, so that the person may render aid involving the skill to meet the emergency or disaster. 
(e)  Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations, or directives necessary for carrying out the purposes of this chapter. Proclamations, regulations, and directives shall be disseminated promptly by means calculated to bring their content to the attention of the general public and, unless circumstances attendant on the disaster prevent or impede such action, promptly filed with the city secretary. 
(f)  The control and direction of all operations of the City of Pasadena emergency management organization. 
(g)  Determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city. 
(h)  Maintenance of liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional, or federal emergency management organizations. 
(i)  Marshalling of necessary personnel, equipment, or supplies from any department of the city to aid in implementation of the provisions of the emergency management plan. 
(j)  Supervision over drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with representatives of the state and of other political subdivisions of the state, and drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county and other municipalities within the county, for the county-wide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(k)  Supervision and final authorization for the procurement of necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the city. 
(l)  Authorizing agreements, after approval by the city attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(m)  Survey the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies, and services which could be used during a disaster provided for herein. 
(n)  Other requirements and powers as specified in the Texas Disaster Act of 1975 (Chapter 418 Government Code, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes). 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-3. - Emergency management plan. 
A comprehensive emergency management plan shall be developed and maintained in a current state. 
(a)  The plan shall set forth the form of the organization, tasks, duties, and powers, and designation of officers and employees to carry out the provisions of the plan. 
(b)  As provided by state law, the plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the Governor's Division of Emergency Management for the State of Texas, and must include the following: 
(1)  Wage, price, and rent control and other economic stabilization methods in the event of disaster; and 
(2)  Curfews, blockades and limitations on utility usage in an area affected by disaster, rules governing ingress and egress to the affected area and other security measures. 
(c)  Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles, and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the governor's division of emergency management. 
(d)  City of Pasadena departments and agencies will perform the functions assigned by the plan and maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. 
(e)  City departments, officers, and employees will be trained in emergency management topics and procedures to carry-out the objectives of the plan, and to comply with all federal and state requirements for emergency management. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec 10-4. - Pasadena Security Council. 
(a)  The mayor hereby establishes the Pasadena Security Council to advise and assist the mayor and the office of emergency management in matters relating to disaster mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery. The council will also serve as an advisory entity for matters relating to Homeland Security, as they pertain to the City of Pasadena and its citizens. 
(b)  The Pasadena Security Council is composed of the heads of city departments, agencies, and private-sector partners, including organized volunteer groups. 
(c)  The council is comprised of the mayor, the emergency management coordinator, and the following positions within the City of Pasadena: 
(1)  City of Pasadena Mayor Pro Tem. 
(2)  City of Pasadena Chief of Police. 
(3)  City of Pasadena Fire Chief. 
(4)  City of Pasadena City Attorney. 
(5)  City of Pasadena Health Director. 
(6)  City of Pasadena Public Works Director. 
(7)  City of Pasadena Public Information Officer. 
(8)  Other City of Pasadena Department Heads or Managers as designated by the mayor. 
(d)  In addition, the council may include the following representatives and others as may be designated: 
(1)  Director of the entity providing EMS service for the City of Pasadena. 
(2)  Superintendent of Schools, Pasadena Independent School District. 
(3)  One (1) local hospital CEO, chosen and appointed by the mayor. 
(4)  Pasadena Chamber of Commerce President. 
(5)  East Harris County Manufacturer's Association Pasadena Outreach Group Chair. 
(6)  Southeast Regional LEPC President. 
(7)  San Jacinto College President. 
(8)  Representation from local VOAD (Volunteer Organizations Active in Disasters), such as Salvation Army, American Red Cross, etc. 
(9)  Representation from local utility companies, to include telephone, gas, and electric. 
(10)  Other local business and industry representatives, as appointed by the mayor. 
(e)  Administration. 
(1)  The Pasadena Security Council is an advisory entity administered by the office of emergency management. 
(2)  The mayor may adopt rules as necessary for the operation of the security council. 
(3)  The mayor hereby designates the emergency management coordinator as the presiding officer of the security council. 
(4)  The security council shall meet at the call of the mayor, and shall meet at least once per semi-annum in each calendar year. 
(f)  The Pasadena Security Council shall advise the mayor on: 
(1)  The improvement of the city's comprehensive emergency management plan through coordination of the plans of public and private entities throughout the city. 
(2)  The development and coordination of a city-wide critical infrastructure protection strategy. 
(3)  The implementation of the mayor's homeland security strategy. 
(4)  Other matters related to the planning, coordination, and implementation of initiatives to promote the city's emergency management plan or homeland security strategy. 
(g)  Special advisory committees. 
(1)  The mayor may appoint one or more special advisory committees composed of representatives from city departments or nongovernmental entities, whether or not those entities are represented on the council. 
(2)  The mayor shall determine the number of members and qualifications for membership on a special advisory committee under this section. 
(3)  A special advisory committee under this section shall assist the council in performing its duties. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-5. - Interjurisdictional program. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to join with the County Judge of Harris County and the mayors of the other cities in said county in the formation of an Emergency Management Council for the County of Harris, or a portion thereof, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a county-wide program of emergency management insofar as said program may affect the City of Pasadena. This would include the cooperation of the Pasadena Security Council in a joint Security Council for the County of Harris, or a portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-6. - Override of existing regulations. 
To the extent allowed by law, at all times when orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-7. - Liability. 
This chapter is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and neither the City of Pasadena, the agents and representatives of said city or any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, or any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule, or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be liable for any damage sustained by any persons as a result of said activity. Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the City of Pasadena a license or privilege, or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate, and use the whole or part of parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending, practice emergency, may together with his successors in interest, if any, to the extent allowed by law, not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege, or other permission or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-8. - Commitment of funds. 
No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this chapter without prior approval by the city council, nor shall any person have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement, or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the city council unless during a declared disaster. During a declared disaster, the director may expend and/or commit public funds of the city and execute mutual aid agreements when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection of health, life, or property. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-9. - Offenses; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter, or to knowingly do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly wear, carry, or display any emblem, insignia, or any other means of identification as a member of the Emergency Management Organization of the City of Pasadena unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to knowingly operate or cause to be operated a siren or other device so as to simulate a warning signal or the termination of a warning signal. 
(d)  With the exception of members of the emergency management organization who are working to carry out the objectives of their duties, each violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Sec. 10-10. - Conflict; severability. 
This chapter shall not be construed so as to conflict with any state or federal statute, or with any military or naval order, rule, or regulation. If any portion of this chapter shall, for any reason, be declared invalid, such validity shall not affect the remaining provisions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 09-157, § 1, 8-4-09)  
Chapter 11 - ELECTIONS 
 
Sec. 11-1. - State law and Charter to govern. 
All elections pertaining to municipal affairs shall be governed by the election laws of the state and the Charter of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 11-1) 
Charter reference— Elections, Art. IV. 
State Law reference— Elections generally, V.A.T.S. Election Code.  
Secs. 11-2—11-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 00-148, § 1, adopted October 3, 2000, deleted former §§ 11-2—11-6 in their entirety. These sections pertained to the following: city divided into councilmanic districts; means of qualification to accompany application to become candidate for mayor or councilman; residence requirements for candidates for council; general duties of mayor, city secretary and council; withdrawal of candidate; Code does not affect ordinances designating voting. Former §§ 11-2—11-6 were derived from the following: Ord. No 68-80, §§ 1, 2, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 76-95, §§ 1—4, 6-8-76; Ord. No. 80-124, § 1, 6-24-80; Ord. No. 73-44, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 68-80, § 3, 6-11-68; Code of 1964, § 11-2; Code of 1964, § 11-5.  
Chapter 12 - ELECTRICAL CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), adopted January 17, 2017, amended chapter 12 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former chapter 12, pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Cross reference— Electrical installations in theaters, § 5-24; buildings containing defective wiring declared as fire hazards, § 13-118(1); buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 9; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 13; heating, air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration code, Ch. 16; signs, Ch. 31. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Purpose. 
This Code is an ordinance providing minimum requirements and standards for the practical safeguarding of persons and property from the hazards arising from the installation of electrical systems and the use of electricity. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-2. - Scope. 
The provisions of this Code shall apply to the erection, installation, alteration to, use, or maintenance of electrical systems within this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-3. - Adoption of codes and state laws. 
The City of Pasadena Mayor and City Council, with the recommendation of the City of Pasadena Electrical Board, does hereby adopt the most current edition of the National Electrical Code, as adopted by the Texas State Legislature in its most current form (excluding Article 80) and all relative elements of Chapter 12 of the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-4. - Administration and enforcement. 
Definitions. No terms in this electrical code are deemed as gender specific: 
Administrative "HOLD" prevents a contractor or location from acquisition of electrical or other permits pending a requested appeals review by the electrical board or other appropriate body, made to the permit department. 
Apprentice electrician* is a person undertaking "electrical work," as defined in this Code, under the direct, personal supervision and control of either a licensed master electrician, sign master electrician, journeyman electrician, journeyman lineman, sign journeyman electrician, residential journeyman electrician or maintenance electrician. 
Approved, as to materials, equipment and method of construction, refers to approval by the chief electrical inspector as the result of investigation and tests conducted by the chief electrical inspector or by reason of accepted principles or tests by recognized authorities or technical or scientific organizations. 
Building code is the City of Pasadena Building Code as currently adopted. 
Building official is the officer of the City of Pasadena charged with the administration and enforcement of the Building Department Codes of the City of Pasadena or his duly authorized representative. 
Chief and/or electrical inspector(s) is the person(s) designated by the building official to be the supervisor of the electrical inspections group and/or perform such inspections. These individuals will not be allowed to have any financial or advisory interests in any electrical company or project endeavor which could be determined a conflict of interests by the building official. Appeal available through electrical board. 
City is the City of Pasadena being the jurisdiction that has adopted this Code. 
City Code is the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pasadena, Texas. 
Contractor* is a person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of performing electrical maintenance work, electrical work, outside electrical work, residential electrical work or sign electrical work. 
Decorative structure. These installations shall not strobe, chase, flash, spin or in any way cause a problem with general traffic or be considered a public nuisance as determined by the permit department. Prior to installation; location and installation approvals from the permit department will be required. Additionally, certain types of these installations may be determined to be regulated under the city sign code. 
Electrical code is the most current edition of the National Electrical Code promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, as adopted by the city. 
Electrical maintenance work is the keeping in safe repair of existing electrical installations, apparatus and equipment. The term "electrical maintenance work" shall include the repair or replacement of fixed motors, transformers or fixed appliances of the same type and rating in the same location. The term does not include the installation of additional electrical work, electrical equipment or electrical apparatus. 
Electrical work is the installing, maintaining, altering, repairing or erecting of any wiring apparatus, devices, appliances, fixtures or equipment for which a permit is required under the terms and provisions of this Code, except poles and guy anchors installed by a telephone, telegraph, signal and/or electric utility company as a part of its distribution system. 
Firewall is the same as that of a firewall or fire separation assembly as defined in the building code. 
Journeyman electrician* is a person undertaking "electrical work" as defined in this Code, under the supervision, direction and control of a licensed master electrician. 
Listed and listing are terms referring to equipment and materials that are shown in a list published by an approved agency, which states that the equipment complies with recognized safety standards. 
Maintenance electrician is a person regularly employed on a permanent basis at one or more facilities under common ownership or control when there is a current annual maintenance permit for the facilities where the person works, provided the person performs "electrical maintenance work," as defined in this Code, only on the premises under the ownership or control of the person's employer. Specifically, this type of license holder cannot work on any installations of any type over 600 VAC. 
Master electrician* is a person who is the holder of a master electrician license issued by the State of Texas Licensing and Regulations Department. 
Multiple occupancy building is a building that has more than one tenant regardless of whether the tenants' uses are of the same or different occupancy classifications or use groups as classified by the building code. 
Occupancy is the purpose for which a building, or part thereof, is used or intended to be used, as defined by the building code. 
Outside electrical work is the assembly, maintenance, installation and erection of all electrical equipment and appurtenances that are part of an outside distribution system generally located outside of any building. Work performed under this term shall include, but not be limited to, the installation, repair or maintenance of substations, street lighting, pole lines, underground duct banks, electrical decorations, traffic signals and parking lot lighting. 
Person is an individual, partnership, corporation or other legal entity. 
Residential electrical work is the installation, maintenance, alteration, repair or erection of any wiring apparatus, devices, appliances, fixtures or equipment that by ordinance can be wired with nonmetallic sheathed cable. This work will be limited to single or multi-family dwellings (and their accessory structures) of wood frame construction not exceeding four (4) stories. 
Residential wireman* is a person undertaking "residential electrical work," as defined in this Code, under the supervision, direction and control of a licensed master electrician. 
Sign electrical work is the manufacture or installation, or both, of electric signs, conductors and equipment for signs, outline lighting, and inside lighting with high-voltage gas tubes as defined in the electrical code. 
Sign journeyman electrician* is a person undertaking "sign electrical work," as defined in this Code, under the supervision, direction and control of a licensed master or sign master electrician. 
Sign master electrician* is a person who is the holder of a sign master electrician license issued by the State of Texas Licensing and Regulations Department. 
*Indicates all State of Texas electrician license requirements, this shall include any City of Pasadena parallel requirements of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 12-5—12-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICAL BOARD 
 
Sec. 12-26. - Electrical board created. 
There is hereby created an electrical board consisting of seven (7) members, appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-27. - Members of electrical board. 
(a)  Positions one (1) and two (2) shall be filled by duly licensed master electricians of the State of Texas or Electrical Contractors registered with the City of Pasadena. 
(b)  Position three (3) shall be filled by an electrical engineer in the employ of an electric public utility company or retail electrical provider operating under a City of Pasadena franchise. 
(c)  Position four (4) and five (5) shall be filled by registered professional engineers of the State of Texas, who are proficient in the field of electricity or a master electrician licensed by the State of Texas. 
(d)  Position six (6) shall be filled by a representative from the city at large. 
(e)  Position seven (7) shall be filled by the chief electrical inspector or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-28. - Appointments, terms, removal. 
Board member appointments shall be made on or before January 2 of each year and take effect on that date. All appointments shall be from the effective date of appointment until January 2 of the next year, but each member of the board shall serve until his successor has been appointed and qualified. Any appointed member of the board may be removed from office in accordance with Article III, Section 7 of the City of Pasadena Home Rule Charter. The existing board members are retained in service until such time as the established process would modify those appointments. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-29. - Quorum. 
Four (4) members of the electrical board present at any meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business of the board, and a majority vote of the members present shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-30. - Officers, procedure, order of business. 
The officers of the board shall consist of a chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary. The chairman, vice-chairman, and the secretary shall be nominated by the members of the board each year in its first meeting after January 2. Each officer shall be elected by a majority vote of the then qualified and serving members of the board. Employees of the city shall not serve as officers of the board. The terms of all elective officers shall be concurrent and limited within the terms of the officer's board membership. The meeting procedure and order of business shall be as prescribed by the board. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-31. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  The electrical board shall be responsible for making interpretations of this electrical code including the approval of equipment, material installation techniques, and granting special permission for the condition, material and installations not covered herein. 
(b)  The electrical board shall submit to the mayor, city council and the building official, written suggestions and recommendations for the improvement of the city electrical code. 
(c)  The electrical board will review appeals requested on behalf of contractors, homeowners and citizens of the City of Pasadena and advise the permit department or mayor and council, as to specific rulings and/or opinions. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-32. - Reports. 
The electrical board shall prepare a written report to the mayor and building official indicating herein the official actions of the board. Said report is to be submitted during January of each year or as may be requested with regard to specific appeals before the board. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-33. - Investigations. 
The inspector shall make such investigations regarding electrical work as deemed necessary or as requested by the mayor, chief electrical inspector, building official, or fire marshal of the city, and prepare a written report to requestor and correction requirements to owner or occupant. Inspectors shall have "right of entry" during reasonable hours for investigating the previous mentioned items in this Code and complaints as may be properly reported to the city. By adoption, this allows the city to recover an hourly amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) an hour for staff fees associated to any individual or company found at fault or responsible by determination of the board. This is separate and independent of fines that may result from the investigation. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-34. - Right to appeal. 
(a)  Any person, firm, corporation or organization dissatisfied with a decision of an electrical inspector shall have the right to appeal such decision. The appeal shall be in writing for review to the electrical board within two (2) working days after such decision. Thereupon, the electrical board within fifteen (15) working days, shall hear and determine said appeal. The board shall have the right to affirm, modify or reverse the action of the electrical inspector, provided, that until such time as the inspector's action is reversed or modified, such action shall in all things be effective. The decision of the electrical board shall be subject to review by the city council as provided for in item (b) below. 
(b)  Any person, firm, corporation or organization that questions a decision of the electrical board shall have the right to appeal. Such appeal shall be made in writing to the city secretary within ten (10) days after the decision of the board. After receipt of such appeal, the city council shall set the date for a hearing, and the city secretary shall notify the appellant and the chairman of the electrical board. The electrical board, as well as the appellant, shall have the right to be heard. The city council shall affirm, modify or reverse the action and/or decision of the electrical board. The action of the city council shall be final. If no appeal is not requested within the time and manner herein provided, the ruling of the electrical board shall be final. The action of the electrical board shall in all things be effective until reversed or modified by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 12-35—12-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PERMIT FEES 
 
Sec. 12-41. - Electrical permit fees. 
All permit fees must comply with the provisions of the City of Pasadena Ordinance Number 2006-322 or if the fee was unmodified, it defaults to any previous established fee(s). 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-42. - Reserved.  
Sec. 12-43. - Holds, fines, penalties, and disallowance of permits. 
(a)  Contractors or homeowners with two (2) or more outstanding re-inspect fees on any current project permit will not be extended any further inspections until re-inspect fees are paid, corrections are made and inspections are approved. 
(b)  Double fees plus twenty-five dollars ($25.00); all electrical fixture and appliance inspections permit fees shall apply except when application is made for a permit after the work has been started, or after the work has been partially completed or concealed, then all required fee or fees will be double plus an additional twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid by the electrical contractor. This provision shall be cumulative of all other penalties provided by this chapter. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor to violate any provision or requirement hereof and any person convicted of violating any provision, restriction, requirement, or prohibition of this chapter for which no specific penalty is provided shall be fined in a sum of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(d)  In item (c) above, each offense is independent and can be prosecuted separately. 
(e)  Contractors may be put on administrative "HOLD" by the permit department for violations of any provisions of local code or of the State of Texas License Program. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-44. - Permit suspension or revocation. 
A permit may be suspended or revoked for the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud or misrepresentation in obtaining a permit. 
(2)  Violating either willfully or maliciously or by reason of incompetence, any provision of this electrical code or amendments thereto. 
(3)  Conviction of defrauding any person for whom he has rendered or contracted to render service. 
(4)  Acquisition of a permit for electrical work not actually controlled by the master electrician or performed by licensed employees under his control, supervision, and direction. 
(5)  Securing a permit under any pretext for which applicant has no valid contract. 
(6)  Contractors with three (3) or more outstanding re-fees on all permits in this jurisdiction shall be placed on administrative "HOLD" until recovery efforts are satisfied with the city permit department. Additionally, if the contractor fails to satisfy this requirement — the contractor will have all permits cancelled and the contractor registration revoked. If this transpires, all new applications and permit fees must be satisfied. 
(7)  Failure on the contractor to satisfy inspection requirements will result in the contractor being placed on administrative "HOLD" until all necessary inspections are satisfied with the city permit department. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 12-45—12-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SPECIFIC POLICIES AND PROCEDURES 
 
Sec. 12-51. - Scheduled overtime or emergency inspections. 
All shall comply with the specific provisions in the City of Pasadena Ordinance Number 2006-322. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-52. - Reserved.  
Sec. 12-53. - Electrical connection approval. 
This jurisdiction requires permits and inspection programs to be satisfied prior to utility service provider releases from the permit department. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-54. - Energy connections. 
Any electrical system or equipment regulated by this Code shall not be connected to a source of energy or power until approved by the chief electrical inspector or his representative. Failure to comply will result in additional burdens for inspections and/or the removal of service from structure or location by the permit department. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-55. - Generators. 
The owner or management of any building and/or place of assembly where an emergency, standby or supplemental generator is installed with a new or existing electrical system on a temporary or permanent basis shall obtain a permit and approval from the chief electrical inspector or his representative prior to operation of any such system. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-56. - Temporary connections. 
The chief electrical inspector or his representative may authorize the temporary connection, of electrical service to building(s) or system(s) for the purpose of construction activity, testing equipment and the cleaning or maintenance of that building or space. This requires proper contractor permits and inspections to be satisfied. Extensions allowed in excess of the ninety-day allowance will require additional permits for every ninety (90) days or portion thereof. 
No permit for temporary use shall be valid for a period more than ninety (90) calendar days. Except as otherwise provided below, at expiration of the authorized period, the chief electrical inspector or his representative shall issue written instructions to the electric utility company or other person having control of the supply of energy to the installation to disconnect service to the temporary installation, unless he or she has granted a permanent approval or an additional temporary approval. At least ten (10) calendar days prior to the proposed date of disconnection, the chief electrical inspector or his representative shall give written notice to the electric utility company or other person having control of the supply of power to the temporary installation and to the owner of the building, setting forth the date that the electricity will be disconnected unless permanent approval of the connection has been obtained or an additional permit for temporary use has been issued. The notice shall be posted on or in view of each principal entrance to building for the information of all persons who enter the building. Any person affected by the proposed disconnection of the electricity may request a hearing on the matter. The request shall be in writing and delivered to the office of the chief electrical inspector at least three (3) city work days prior to the proposed date of disconnection. If a hearing is requested, a hearing date shall be set by the chief electrical inspector and the hearing shall be held prior to the disconnection of electricity, unless person asking for hearing requests a delay in the hearing. 
Building or space occupancy or business operation of any type is specifically prohibited without written authorization of the permit department. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-57. - Electrical work by homeowner. 
A homeowner may perform electrical work (for which a permit is required) in and or on his legal homestead provided a permit is obtained, and the electrical work is installed in accordance with all applicable provisions of this chapter with inspections. The homeowner shall not employ, pay, or compensate in any manner an electrician or any other person to perform any part of the electrical work, and all electrical work shall be performed by the homeowner. Work allowance is not to be inclusive of any new or existing meter loop, service equipment and building additions. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-58. - Enforcement. 
It shall be unlawful for a license holder to permit his license to be used in any manner contrary to any of the provisions adopted by this Code or to obtain a permit required under the provisions of this Code in his name or to allow the use of his name or company name directly or indirectly by another person for the purpose of obtaining a permit. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 12-59—12-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ADDITIONAL PASADENA AMENDMENTS 
 
Sec. 12-66. - General. 
In general, any type of wiring systems may be used in the city limits of Pasadena as approved in the National Electrical Code, except where specifically prohibited herein, provided that all components are listed and properly installed. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-67. - Aluminum conductors. 
Aluminum conductors may be used for the meter loop and the distribution feeders. Branch wiring or connection(s) are not allowed in aluminum conductors. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-68. - Small appliances. 
For the appliance loads in the kitchen, breakfast and dining area, two (2) or more twenty (20) ampere branch circuit with not more than five (5) duplex receptacles per circuit shall be provided and shall have no other outlets connected to these branch circuits (clock outlets excepted). 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-69. - Non-metallic sheathed cable. 
Non-metallic sheathed cable shall be used only for temporary work or within apartment houses and residential dwellings not exceeding four (4) stories in height. Conductors in or on all tile and masonry walls shall be installed in an approved method. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-70. - Code one for manufactured home. 
Existing manufactured homes on residential lots or in mobile home parks will require a minimum electrical safety inspection, known as a code one, under the permit application fee schedule. As vacancy occurs the new owner or occupant will be required to obtain a permit for this safety inspection prior to release of electrical service reconnect to the electrical service provider. 
If Code one inspection fails, a new electrical permit will be required for repairs or corrections to be performed by a licensed electrical contractor registered with the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-71. - Minimum grounding systems. 
As a minimum, two (2) vertically driven ground rods shall be provided for each electrical service to a building. If these ground rods project above grade, they shall be installed so as not to create personnel hazards from tripping or impalement and also to minimize likelihood of damage from lawn care equipment to the rods, grounding electrode conductors and connectors. 
Additional, supplemental grounding systems may be allowed. Specialized general grounding systems such as grid type and for specialized purposes such as lightning protection must be inspected and approved by a Texas Registered Professional Engineer. A project specific letter certifying acceptable design and installation of additional, supplemental grounding systems shall be submitted to the City of Pasadena Inspection Department. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-72. - Wiring of electrical devices. 
Wiring to all electrical devices equipped with screw terminals, including but not limited to outlets and switches, shall be installed using the screw terminals method. Quick-stab or back-stab type wiring installation is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-73. - Minimum wiring methods in residential occupancies. 
General purpose and lighting branch circuits shall be rated a minimum of twenty (20) amperes (twenty (20) amp breakers; no. 12 AWG conductors). Each such circuit shall not serve over twelve (12) outlets. For this purpose an outlet is a duplex or single receptacle or a luminaire. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-74. - Utility standards. 
Pasadena accepts with enforcement authority the most current installation standards of the electrical utility service provider. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-75. - Jobsite journeyman to apprentice ratio requirement. 
On each jobsite apprentice electricians shall work under the direct supervision of journeyman electrician(s). On each jobsite there shall be a ratio of at least one journeyman electrician to five (5) apprentice electricians. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 12-76. - Direct burial cable. 
For service entrance conductors, direct burial cable shall be prohibited unless it is run in a conduit. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 12-77—12-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - APPLICATION FOR ELECTRICAL PERMIT 
 
Sec. 12-81. - File an application in writing. 
To obtain an electrical permit, the licensed electrical contractor, or his duly authorized agent, shall first file an application in writing on a form furnished for that purpose. Each application shall: 
(1)  Identify and describe the scope of work to be covered by the permit. 
(2)  Describe the location where the proposed work will take place by street address or similar description that will readily identify and locate the jobsite. 
(3)  Show the use, function or occupant of the building and/or project. 
(4)  Be accompanied by plans and specifications. 
(5)  Be signed by the licensed electrician, who may be required to submit evidence to indicate such authority. 
(6)  State that the applicant requesting the issuance of a permit has read this chapter in its entirety and will supervise, direct and control all electrical work performed under it. 
NOTE: To establish an escrow account, the electrical contractor must contact the City of Pasadena Permit Department and make the necessary arrangements prior to request(s) for permit(s) to be billed in this method. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-82. - Plans and specifications. 
(a)  With each application for an electrical permit, when required by the chief electrical inspector, the applicant must submit two (2) sets of plans and specifications. The chief electrical inspector may require that such plans and specifications bear the seal of a registered professional electrical engineer licensed by the State of Texas. 
(b)  Plan submittal will require an equipment layout, one-line diagram, panel schedules, electrical floor plan, and load analysis. 
(c)  All public buildings shall be required to submit plans and specifications before securing any permit, except minor additions or alterations to existing facilities when specifically exempted by the chief electrical inspector or his representative. Plans and specifications shall be submitted for all commercial buildings, places of assembly and where emergency electric systems are required, except minor building alterations to the existing facilities when specifically exempted by the chief electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-83. - Approval of plans and specifications. 
(a)  The applications, plans and specifications submitted shall be reviewed by the chief electrical inspector or his representative, such plans may be reviewed by other departments of the city for compliance with laws and ordinances under their jurisdiction. If the chief electrical inspector concurs that the work described in the specifications and plans conform to the requirements of the city, he shall authorize a permit to be issued. 
(b)  When the chief electrical inspector authorizes a permit, he shall stamp on both sets of plans and specifications, "approved", and affix his signature thereto. 
(c)  All stamps, approval notes or other requirement comments on the approved plans shall be required in the electrical project. 
(d)  The chief electrical inspector may authorize a permit for part of a building or structure before the entire plans and specifications have been submitted or approved, provided adequate and detailed information has been made which comply with all pertinent requirement of this chapter. The holder of such permit may proceed, but without assurance that the permit for the work in the entire building or structure will be granted. 
(e)  No work permit shall be transferred or assigned to any person by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-84. - Validity. 
(a)  To issue or grant a permit with approval of plans and specifications shall not be construed to be a permit for, or an approval of, any violation of the provisions of this chapter. No permit shall give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this chapter, except to authorize the work or use as lawful. 
(b)  To issue a permit based on plans and specifications shall not prevent the chief electrical inspector from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in the plans and specifications or from preventing building operations from being carried out when in violation of any provision of this chapter or other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-85. - Display of permit at jobsite. 
(a)  The permit on all new construction for electrical work shall be displayed on the jobsite in a readily accessible location throughout the period of such installation. 
(b)  A permit for an existing installation which has been approved or where additional electrical work is required on a job in progress, the permit for such installation or alteration shall be delivered to the person or firm for whom the installation is to be made and posted at the jobsite as directed by the chief electrical inspector before the addition or alteration is started. 
(c)  The permit document shall be protected from the elements. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-86. - Expiration of permit. 
Each permit issued by the chief electrical inspector shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the project authorized has not started within sixty (60) days from the date of issue of such permit, or if the project is suspended or abandoned at any time after the work has started for a period of ninety (90) days. Before such work can be started again, a new permit shall be obtained. The fee shall be one-half (½) the amount of the original fee, if obtained within one hundred eighty (180) days, provided no changes have been made in the original plans and specifications. The permit shall be allowed to run concurrent with building permits, otherwise, a new full fee permit shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-87. - Correction of unsafe conditions. 
(a)  The chief electrical inspector or any electrical inspector shall investigate upon information or belief that faulty and/or unsafe conditions exist, a thorough inspection of any electrical workmanship, material or equipment now installed or that may hereafter be installed within the city. 
(b)  When the electrical work is found to be of a substandard installation or improperly connected, or to be in a dangerous or unsafe condition, or that the electrical measuring device has been tampered with to create an unsafe condition, the owner, using or operating the same, shall be notified in writing. After notification, the owner shall have the necessary repairs or changes made to such equipment in safe condition and shall have such work completed per direction of the city chief electrical inspector or his representative. This will require contractor permits, fee collection and a subsequent satisfactory inspection process. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-88. - Re-inspection—Correction of unsafe conditions. 
(a)  If during the normal inspection process, violation(s) are identified, these violation(s) shall be subject to a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a re-inspection. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection from a source of electrical energy to any electrical wiring, apparatus, devices, appliances, fixtures, or equipment for the installation of which a permit is required until a certificate of approval has been issued by the chief electrical inspector. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection from a source of electrical energy to any electrical wiring, apparatus, devices, appliances, fixtures or equipment which have been disconnected by an electrical inspector or to be discontinued until a certificate of approval has been granted by the city chief electrical inspector or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-89. - Interference with or change of installation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with any electrical wiring installed or being installed in, or within or without, any structure or building. If, in the course of erection of a building or structure, the wiring is in such position as to interfere with the erection or completion of the building or structure as called for by plans, notice shall immediately be given the person installing the wiring and the needed change shall be made by such person. 
(1)  Installation of commercial and or residential exterior lighting shall not be projected onto another property or directed as to cause traffic problems or concerns, as determined by the city. 
(2)  Exterior flashing lights, strobe lights, pulsating lights, etc. shall not be allowed under this Code. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-90. - Insurance requirements for electrical contractors doing work. 
(a)  Every electrical contractor required to be registered as a business or entity under this Code shall keep in full force and effect, at all times, a policy or policies of insurance for the minimum limits of coverage as required by the State of Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation, and naming such contractor as an insured under the provisions of such policy or policies. 
(b)  The insurance required by this Code shall be written by an accredited company under the supervision of the state board of insurance commissioners. Evidence of compliance with such insurance requirements shall be considered as having been met when the policy or a certified copy thereof, or a properly executed certificate of insurance (Accord form), has been filed with and approved by the building official, and lists the City of Pasadena as the certificate holder. 
(c)  Each policy of insurance required by this Code shall include an endorsement thereon that the City of Pasadena Permit Department will be notified at least thirty (30) days in advance in the event the policy is cancelled or expires before the expiration date of the license issued under this Code to the insured. 
(d)  No electrical contractor's license shall be valid in the City of Pasadena, unless the applicant has complied with this section. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 12-91—12-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - CONTRACTORS AND ELECTRICIANS REGISTRATION PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 12-101. - General. 
There is hereby established a city contractor registration requirement for contractors and for persons or other causing the performance of electrical work, electrical maintenance work, residential electrical work, and sign electrical work. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-102. - License requirements. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to employ or utilize any person who does not hold a current and valid electrical license issued by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation to perform electrical work, electrical maintenance work, residential electrical work or sign electrical work. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-103. - Registration fee schedule. 
Electrical contractor, annually ..... $100.00 
Electrical maintenance, annually ..... $100.00 
Electrical sign contractor, annually ..... $100.00 
Registration shall expire on anniversary of state license issue date. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-104. - Permit for maintenance electrician's employer. 
(a)  An annual permit is allowed for any person or firm employing a maintenance electrician licensed by the State of Texas to perform electrical maintenance work within the confines of a building in or on the premises where he is employed. (Exception: Work that may be contracted by licensed and registered contractors with the standard permit process) - No allowance for equipment or installation over 600 VAC. The application for the annual permit shall be made on the form provided by the city permit department and shall contain a description of the address location(s), number of structures, major equipment and the insurance information as required by all contractors. 
(b)  The fee of the annual permit shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall expire on December 31 each year. This allows for general electrical maintenance to existing equipment only. 
(c)  The maintenance electrician shall be required to obtain a permit to move and relocate electrical equipment authorized to be completed as specifically allowed by the city chief electrical inspector or his representative. 
(d)  Each location will be required to post the permit to include the named state licensed maintenance electrician per the direction of the city chief electrical inspector or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-105. - Project specific requirements. 
(a)  At the discretion of the chief electrical inspector or designated representative a maximum ratio of four (4) apprentice electricians per journeyman or master electrician can be required. 
(b)  The project master, contractor or permit signature party must be available at the request of the electrical inspections group within seventy-two (72) hours of notification to any electrical project personnel. Failure to comply may result in revocation of the project electrical permit. Thus new permits and fees would be required. Possible denials of the contractor from future permit availability in this jurisdiction. 
(c)  New or existing distribution, branch or feeder systems or equipment installations over 600 VAC shall be completed under the direction and supervision of a State of Texas Licensed Electrical Engineer. Emergency repairs must be permitted within two (2) business days with stamped and embossed letter of compliance by the electrical engineer on file with the permit department. Scheduled work must have specific design criteria by the project electrical engineer with a letter of installation certification upon project completion by the same electrical engineer. 
(d)  All work in item (c) above must be in compliance with all relative elements of the most current editions and versions of the NESC, NEC and all distribution and or service provider requirements. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-106. - Permit(s) not required. 
(a)  No permit shall be required for replacing fuses or lamps or the connection of portable equipment to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed or for repairs to portable appliances. This shall be inclusive of listed seasonal decorative lighting for residential use only. 
(b)  No permit shall be required for any electrical work performed in this jurisdiction by employees of the U.S. Government, State of Texas, Harris County or city electrical department on building or property owned by such entities. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 12-107. - City issued electrician license program. 
The city electrician licensing program will run concurrent with the state program through December 31, 2004. The city electrician licensing program for new or renewal issuance will be dissolved September 1, 2004 and not issue any further licenses after that date. In the interim period, the State of Texas Electricians Licensing Program will be the primary for this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Chapter 13 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes:
