Cross reference— Fire extinguishing equipment in theaters, § 5-25; fire prevention and protection requirements at dance halls, § 5-112 et seq.; Strawberry Park fire ring, § 24-18 et seq.; signs not to interfere with exits or to be attached to fire escapes, §§ 31-11, 31-12; buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 9; electrical code, Ch. 12; heating, air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration code, Ch. 16. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Burning of trash and refuse. 
(a)  Except as otherwise expressly provided in subsection (b) or some other ordinance of the city, it shall be unlawful for any person to kindle, maintain as a fire, ignite, or burn any paper, wood, organic matter, grass, weeds, brush, or other trash, refuse or rubbish within the corporate limits of the city outside any building, unless such fire is contained in a waste burner or incinerator, including a wire mesh cover of not more than one-quarter (¼) inch mesh, as a spark arrestor, on the incinerator stack or exhaust vent, approved by the fire marshal after inspection and the issuance by him of a certificate of incinerator approval, in such form as the fire marshal may from time to time prescribe. No incinerator shall be located within fifteen (15) feet of any other building or structure. Such certificate may be cancelled by the fire marshal at any time he finds a hitherto-approved incinerator to be in a condition substandard to the original approved condition as of the time of issuance of the certificate therefor. The fee for issuance of such certificate shall be two dollars ($2.00). 
(b)  Upon the payment of a fee of seventy-five cents ($0.75) and obtaining the approval of the fire marshal and his permit for open burning, to be in such form as the fire marshal may from time to time prescribe, a single bonfire or rubbish fire may be ignited and burned on a permitted date, on private land or a city easement, within not less than fifty (50) feet of any building or structure, provided the fire is precluded from spreading within fifty (50) feet of any building or structure. A competent person shall attend such fire at all times from ignition until extinguishment and shall maintain a garden hose connected to a water supply under pressure, or equivalent approved fire extinguishing equipment, during all such times. The fire marshal may prohibit any or all bonfires and outdoor rubbish fires when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances render such fire or fires hazardous. 
(c)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon final conviction therefor, shall be fined in a sum of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(Code 1964, § 13-2; Ord. No. 1840, §§ 1, 2, 8-2-66; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90) 
Cross reference— Trash and rubbish generally, Ch. 14; regulations for use of Strawberry Park fire ring, § 24-22.  
Sec. 13-2. - Adoption of state law and rules and regulations relating to storage, handling and use of flammable liquids at retail service stations. 
The city council hereby adopts Article 9201, Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, and the rules and regulations adopted by the State of Texas Board of Insurance, to insure uniform force and effect throughout the State of Texas in enforcing the rules and regulations for the safe storage, handling and use of flammable liquids at retail service stations. 
(Ord. No. 70-143, § 1, 7-21-70; Ord. No. 80-62, § 3, 4-8-80)  
Sec. 13-3. - Stopping or parking vehicles used for transportation of flammable liquids, gas or chemicals. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any commercial truck or vehicle equipped with tanks for the transportation of any type of flammable liquids, gas or gases, or chemicals, whether loaded or empty, is hereby prohibited from stopping or parking such truck or vehicle on any street, driveway, alley, vacant lot or public parking area near or by any home, residence, building or premises in the corporate limits of the city, at any time. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not be applicable to trucks or vehicles stopped or parked in the observance of controlled traffic regulations, or to those trucks or vehicles stopped in and during the time of delivery of flammable liquids, gas or gases, or chemicals to a home, residence, building or premises. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the above provisions of this section, trucks or vehicles used exclusively for the transport of gasoline or automotive fuels or lubricants, or gases or chemicals of equal or higher flash points, shall be allowed to stop or park not less than ten (10) feet from the nearest point of any building, if such trucks or vehicles are on premises wholly owned or controlled by the owner or lessee of such trucks or vehicles; provided that such trucks or vehicles are, at all times while thus stopped or parked, equipped with regularly and properly operating Interstate Commerce Commission approved safety valves and necessary related appliances, if any, for the control of fire and explosion in the tank or tanks of such trucks or vehicles; and further provided, that at all times while the trucks or vehicles are thus stopped or parked, the same shall be completely surrounded by a chain link type fence, fitted with a lockable gate, that is at least six (6) feet in height with a minimum six (6) gauge wire, with three (3) barbed wire strands at the top angled out and away from the fenced enclosure. Additionally, such enclosure shall be well-illuminated by artificial light continuously between sunset and sunrise and during which interval such trucks or vehicles are stopped or parked therein. The fence gate or gates must be securely locked at all times except when a driver, owner, helper, loader or any authorized person or employee is on duty in the fenced enclosure. 
(d)  In case of a truck or vehicle governed by this section being stopped or parked due to mechanical or other breakdown thereof, the driver, owner or lessee of such truck or vehicle shall, after one (1) hour from the commencement of the breakdown, if the truck or vehicle remains disabled, notify the fire marshal of the breakdown, the description of the truck cargo, and its location in the city, unless such truck or vehicle is then stopped or parked in compliance with this section. In event of such stopping or parking not in compliance herewith, the fire marshal may order and arrange for the removal of such truck or vehicle to a safe place, at the expense of the owner thereof and without any liability on the part of the city, in the interest of public safety. 
(e)  Any truck or vehicle described in subsection (a) that has been left on any street, driveway, alley, vacant lot or public parking area in this city for a period in excess of one (1) hour shall be deemed abandoned, and the fire marshal or the chief of police or their designated representatives may have such truck or vehicle removed and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 67-2006, §§ 1, 2, 4, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 69-40, § 1, 2-18-69; Ord. No. 80-62, § 4, 4-8-80; Ord. No. 90-85, § 4, 5-15-90) 
Cross reference— Stopping and parking of vehicles generally, § 36-163 et seq.  
Sec. 13-4. - False fire alarms. 
(a)  If any person shall falsely or maliciously, by any means whatsoever, give an alarm of fire when there is no fire, he shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  The city hereby offers a reward of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to be paid to any person furnishing information leading to the arrest and conviction of any other person for a violation of this section. Any person claiming the right to be paid such a reward must file a notice of such claim in writing with the city council not later than ninety (90) days from and after the date of the conviction of any person for violating this section in any court of competent jurisdiction, which notice shall fully state the circumstances under which such person laid the information before the authorities, leading to the arrest and conviction of the criminal, the full name of the claimant, and the names and addresses of any witnesses upon whom the claimant relies to verify his claim. 
(c)  The city council shall be the sole judge of whether or not any claimant is entitled to receive the reward provided for by this section, and the decision of the city council upon any claim for such reward shall be final and binding upon all parties. 
(d)  It is further a condition of this offer of reward that all persons taking notice of this offer shall also take notice that this offer may be revoked by the mere passage of an ordinance by the city council repealing this section and the passage of such repealing ordinance shall be held to give notice to all parties that the offer has been withdrawn. 
(Code 1964, § 13-6)  
Sec. 13-5. - Interfering with or injuring fire alarm system; maintenance of fire suppression equipment; sale of defective fire extinguishers. 
(a)  Any person who shall interfere with, cut or injure any of the boxes, wires or poles, or any of the appurtenances thereto, of the electric fire alarm system shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  No person shall obstruct, remove, tamper with or otherwise disturb any fire hydrant or fire appliance required to be installed or maintained under the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code except for the purpose of extinguishing fire, training or testing purposes, recharging or making necessary repairs, or when permitted by the fire official. Whenever a fire appliance is removed as herein permitted, it shall be replaced or re-installed as soon as the purpose for which it was removed has been accomplished. Defective and nonapproved fire appliances or equipment shall be replaced or repaired as directed by the fire official. 
(c)  No person shall sell, trade, loan or give away any form, type or kind of fire extinguisher which is not approved by the fire official, or which is not in proper working order, or the contents of which do not meet the requirements of the fire official. The requirements of this section shall not apply to the sale, trade or exchange of obsolete or damaged equipment for junk and said units are permanently disfigured or marked with permanent sign identifying the unit as junk. 
(Code 1964, § 13-7; Ord. No. 80-62, § 5, 4-8-80)  
Sec. 13-6. - Arson reward. 
(a)  A standing reward in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) is hereby established to be paid to any person furnishing evidence as a result of which any person is arrested and finally convicted of the crime of arson, as such crime is now or shall hereafter be defined in the penal code of the state, provided such crime is committed within the limits of the city. In the event more than one person furnishes evidence leading to the arrest and final conviction of such person for such crime as herein provided, the reward hereby offered shall be divided among such persons. 
(b)  A special fund is hereby created to be known as the "Arson Fund" and there shall be deposited to the credit of such fund, at all times, not less than the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Code 1964, § 13-8)  
Sec. 13-7. - Storage, handling and dispensing flammable liquids. 
The owner, operator, or person in charge of a service station is hereby held responsible for the compliance of the following requirements: 
(a)  All Class I flammable liquids shall be stored, handled, and/or dispensed from approved underground tanks, through approved pumping equipment. 
(b)  This section is intended to prohibit the use of so-called "portable service stations" ("mobile service units") or similar units construed to dispense flammable liquids and designed so that the unit can be easily picked up and moved, provided, however, tank trucks or tank wagons or other mobile tanks may deliver gasoline direct to approved aboveground and underground installations, provided further, that tank trucks or tank wagons, or other mobile tanks may deliver gasoline to persons engaged in street building excavations or in the construction of large buildings, provided such delivery is made into approved installations such as underground storage tanks or approved skid tanks of not over two hundred and fifty (250) gallon capacity, and provided further, that tank trucks or tank wagons or other mobile tanks may deliver gasoline directly into the supply tanks of heavy construction equipment which cannot feasibly be taken to an approved installation only after the point of delivery has been inspected and approved by the fire marshal or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 71-227, § 1, 8-10-71) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 71-227, § 1, amended the 1964 Code by adding the provisions included herein as § 13-7.  
Sec. 13-8. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  A "fire lane" is defined for the purpose of this section to mean an area appurtenant to entrances or exits of any assembly building, shopping center, hospital, apartment house or school which is deemed necessary by the fire official to remain free and clear of parked vehicles and other obstructions in order to provide access to such building in case of fire or other emergency and designated by the fire official. 
Such lane shall be a width of not less than twenty (20) feet perpendicular to such exits and entrances and shall extend for the minimum length necessary to provide access for fire vehicles. 
Such lane may, at the discretion of the fire official, include sidewalks, driveways, portions of parking lots, or any other area adjacent to or near the entrances or exits to such building; provided, however, that fifteen (15) feet on either side of a "fire protection device" is designated a "fire lane" without the necessity of a designation by the fire official. 
It is further provided that the fire official shall not designate a lane of more than fifteen (15) feet perpendicular to exits or entrances of buildings if the designation of a lane of more than fifteen (15) feet would necessitate structural changes to existing buildings. 
(2)  A "shopping center" is defined for the purposes of this section to mean a group of commercial business establishments planned, developed, owned or managed as a unit, with off-street parking provided on the property, and related in location, size and types of shops to the trade area that the unit serves. 
(3)  A "hospital" is defined for the purposes of this section to mean any public or private hospital, convalescent home or nursing home. 
(4)  An "apartment house" is any building, or portion thereof, which is designed, built, rented, leased, let or hired out to be occupied, or which is occupied as the home or residence of three (3) or more families living independently of each other and doing their own cooking in the said building, and shall include flats and apartments. 
(5)  "Assembly building" is a building or portion of a building used for the gathering together of fifty (50) or more persons for such purposes as deliberation, education, instruction, worship, entertainment, amusement or awaiting transportation, or of one hundred (100) or more persons in drinking or dining establishments. 
(6)  A "school" is a building, public or private, used for educational purposes, and having an attendance of fifty (50) or more persons. 
(7)  "Proper officer," for the purposes of this section, shall include the fire marshal, fire chief, chief of police, inspectors of the fire prevention department, and officers of the police department. 
(8)  A "fire protection device" shall mean a device such as sprinkler connections, standpipe connections and private fire hydrants. 
(b)  Fire official to designate. The fire official of the City of Pasadena is hereby authorized to designate fire lanes on the property of shopping centers, hospitals, apartment houses, assembly buildings, and schools, as defined herein, appurtenant to buildings or the entrances or exits to stores, groups of stores or buildings, where, in his opinion, such areas must be kept free of parked vehicles and other obstructions to provide ready access in case of fire or other emergency. 
(c)  Erection of signs or painting fire lanes; maintenance. Every owner of a premise subject to this section shall, within thirty (30) days after designation of "fire lanes," erect signs and/or paint the "fire lane" in compliance with this section. Failure to erect signs and/or paint the "fire lanes" is a misdemeanor and is punishable as provided herein. The means by which fire lanes are designated shall be maintained in a clean and legible condition at all times and replaced or repaired when necessary to provide adequate visibility. The designation by the fire marshal or his designee of such fire lanes shall never be held to make the City of Pasadena responsible for the maintenance of such fire lanes on private property, but the owner of such property shall continue to be responsible for the maintenance of such area. 
(d)  Record of designated lanes; changes, cancellations, etc. Every designation, determination or location of a fire lane by the fire marshal or his designee pursuant to the authority granted in this section 13-8 shall be submitted to the office of the fire marshal for approval. Unless otherwise designated therein by the fire marshal or his designee, such designation, determination or location of a fire lane shall be deemed permanent. 
(e)  Marking of fire lanes. Upon the designation of a fire lane pursuant to this section, the fire marshal or his designee shall give notice of such designation to the owner of such commercial building, to include shopping centers, hospitals, apartment houses, assembly buildings, or schools, directing the owner to identify the designated fire lane by erecting signage and/or surface painting at the expense of the owner. 
Posting of a designated fire lane shall be by the erection of signage and/or painted surface and shall be lettered, "FIRE LANE—NO PARKING." Such fire lane markings shall be of a standard size, color, lettering, and mounting as approved by the fire marshal or his designee. Samples and instructions for signage and surface markings may be obtained from the office of the fire marshal. 
(f)  Obstruction of fire lanes prohibited. Fire lanes shall not be obstructed in any manner, including but not limited to the standing and parking of vehicles. Such vehicles or obstructions shall be subject to a citation and/or being removed from said fire lanes at the owner's expense. 
(1)  Proper officers are hereby authorized to provide for the removal of vehicles in violation of this section when, in the opinion of such officers, the vehicles could constitute a hazard in regard to fire prevention and protection. 
Vehicles so removed shall be delivered to the nearest authorized garage or other place of impoundment designated by the city council. No vehicle impounded as herein provided shall be released until the charges for towing such vehicle and any accumulated storage charges have been paid. 
(2)  Citations for violation of this section may be issued by a proper officer. Such citation shall specify the location of the fire lane in which such violation occurred and the date and time of such violation. Any citation for violation shall be issued on the official form theretofore prescribed by the City of Pasadena. Such citation shall require the appearance of the violator before the municipal court and all fines paid by the violator shall be paid to the municipal court clerk. 
(g)  Presumption of violation. In any prosecution charging a vehicle violation of this section, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle in the proscribed area. 
(h)  Defense to violation. It is hereby declared unlawful to park any vehicle other than an authorized emergency vehicle of the City of Pasadena in any fire lane where the signs provided for herein have been erected; provided, however, if the signs are not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person, it shall be a defense to any alleged violation thereof. 
(i)  Injuring, etc., of signs prohibited. It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person, without lawful authority, to attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down, or remove any sign designated a fire lane which has been erected under the terms of this section. 
(j)  Permission required to close lanes. No owner, manager, or person in charge of any premises served by a required fire lane shall abandon or close any such fire lane without the permission of the fire official; and such person shall keep the fire lanes clear of parked vehicles and/or objects that would impede escape from or access to said premises. 
(k)  Penalty for violation of article. Any violation of any provision of this article shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person convicted of any such violation shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day and every day that such violation shall continue shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 80-62, § 6, 4-8-80; Ord. No. 90-85, § 5, 5-15-90; Ord. No. 18-105, § 1(Exh. A), 8-7-18)  
Sec. 13-9. - Smoking regulations. 
(a)  Posting of "no smoking" signs. Where conditions are such as to make smoking a hazard in any areas of piers, wharves, warehouses, stores, industrial plants, institutions, schools, places of assembly, and in open spaces where combustible materials are stored or handled, the fire official is empowered and authorized to order the owner or occupant in writing to post "no smoking" signs in each building, structure, room or place in which smoking shall be prohibited. Such signs shall be conspicuously and suitably located. The fire official shall designate specific safe locations, if necessary, in any building, structure or place in which smoking may be permitted. 
(b)  General regulations. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person during that period of the year declared by the fire official as the hazardous season to light, ignite or otherwise set fire to or to smoke any tobacco, cigarette, pipe or cigar in or upon any road or trail traversing any such brush- or forest-covered land or land covered with flammable material; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall apply to the area within the boundaries of any established smoking areas as designated by the fire official. 
(2)  No person shall throw or drop or cause to be thrown or dropped an ignited match, cigar, cigarette, tobacco or other ignited material from any window or roof or balcony or any building or structure. Nor shall any person dispose of such materials in such a manner that they possibly would fall on combustible material of any nature. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke, or to carry or possess a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or match, or any open flame, under, in or upon any bulkhead, dock, pier, wharfs, landing or buildings or structures, appurtenances or approaches within fifty (50) feet of such bulkheads, docks, piers, wharfs, landings or buildings or structures (including grain elevators, workhouses, storage annexes, or unloading shed), within the boundaries of the city limits of the City of Pasadena, or to smoke or carry or possess a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or match, or any openflame, on any open deck or in the hold of any ship, lighter, barge or other floating vessels, craft or equipment, whether the same is berthed or moored at a dock, wharf or landing, or tied to another vessel made fast thereto, or to cast off or throw from any such ship, lighter, barge or other floating vessel, craft or equipment any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or match, or any open flame, except that the above prohibitions shall not apply in those areas specially designated and posted by proper authorities as "smoking areas." 
(c)  Lettering, size, color and location of "no smoking" signs. The lettering, size, color and location of legally required "no smoking" signs shall be subject to the approval of the fire official. The following sizes will be considered standard for the type of occupancy indicated; and where required in this code: 
(1)  Public assembly, stores, schools, institutions (inside). "No smoking," letters two (2) inches high, minimum, on contrasting background, Example: Red on white and the words, "by order of the fire marshal" in letters one-half inch high. 
(2)  Industrial plants (inside). 
(a)  "Danger—No smoking, matches or open flame," letters to be three (3) inches high minimum on contrasting background. 
(b)  Add: "Keep twenty-five (25) feet away," where flammable materials are stored, such as required in spray application process areas and flammable liquid storage areas and rooms. 
(3)  Industrial plants and outside storage areas. "Danger—No smoking, keep open flame or spark-producing devices twenty-five (25) feet away." Letters to be four (4) inches high, red on white background or approved contrasting color combination. 
(4)  Where signs are required by federal or state occupational safety laws, such signs may be used in lieu of the above when approved by the fire official or his representative. 
(d)  Removing, mutilating, destroying "no smoking" signs. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or mutilate or destroy any legally required "no smoking" sign. 
(e)  Smoking prohibited in "no smoking" areas. It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or throw or deposit any lighted or smoldering substance in any place where "no smoking" signs are posted or in any other place where smoking would occasion or constitute a fire or life hazard. 
(f)  Receptacles and ashtrays to be provided where smoking permitted in specific areas; disposal of contents of ashtrays. Where specific areas are designated in certain occupancies, approved receptacles or ashtrays shall be readily available and in sufficient number for the number of persons intended. Disposal of the contents of ashtrays is to be done in closed metal containers with due regard for the hazard created by smoldering "butts." 
(Ord. No. 80-62, § 7, 4-8-80)  
Sec. 13-10. - Emergency access gates. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or maintain, or cause to be constructed, installed or maintained, any blocking device, such as a gate, chains or other barrier, used for the purpose of blocking access from a public street to a private street or driveway of any multifamily residential property without first obtaining a permit approved by the fire marshal. 
(b)  Such gates or barriers on private street drives at entrances to multifamily residential property projects shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  One fourteen-foot gate that opens to provide at least fourteen (14) feet of access width where the drive is less than twenty-eight (28) feet wide. 
(2)  Two (2) gates of minimum thirteen-foot width each where drive is twenty-eight (28) feet wide. 
(3)  One twenty-eight-foot gate that gives full access where drive is twenty-eight (28) feet wide. 
(c)  Existing gates 
(1)  "Approved" gates shall mean those gates approved, in writing, by the fire marshal. An applicant seeking such approval shall submit four (4) sets of plans to the building official with his application for a building permit. Gates approved prior to February 1, 1994 are not affected by this ordinance, unless gates prove inadequate during an actual emergency situation. Such unsatisfactory performance will require full compliance with all requirements of this section. Any remodeling or rebuilding of approved gates that changes the gate opening or opening device must be resubmitted to the fire marshal for approval. 
(2)  "Unapproved" gates shall mean those gates that do not have written fire marshal approval. Unapproved gates shall be submitted for the fire marshal's approval as specified in section 13-10 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pasadena. 
(d)  All construction codes and permitting requirements of the City of Pasadena shall be applicable to the blocking devices described in section 13-10(a). Any such blocking device, shall be designed, constructed, installed or maintained to meet the following standards: 
(1)  An emergency vehicle of the fire department moving at a speed of one to seven (7) miles per hour can force open the blocking device without causing any damage to the emergency equipment, or fifty (50) pounds or less pressure exerted against such blocking device. 
(2)  All blocking devices (except break-away type chains) shall be so designed that once the blocking device is released, it will automatically open and remain so until it is closed manually. 
(3)  All locking, holding, or latching devices permitted shall be of the shear pin or shear-section type meeting the requirements set forth in paragraph one of this document. 
(4)  All blocking devices shall be so designed so that no damage will occur to an emergency vehicle when pressure is exerted to force such devices open. 
(5)  A blocking device may incorporate the above numbers one through four (4) or the equivalent as determined by the fire marshal or his representative using recognized industry standards. 
(6)  All blocking devices shall be equipped with a radio receiver compatible with police department and fire department radio equipment which allows emergency vehicles and other necessary on-duty city employees to open the blocking device by use of such equipment. 
(e)  Prior to any changes, alterations or blocking of private streets, plans detailing such change, accompanied by drawings, shall be submitted to the fire marshal for approval. The fire marshal or his representative shall inspect all such installations and shall be given the opportunity to be present when such blocking devices are tested for final approval. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 1, 1-25-94; Ord. No. 03-189, § 1, 9-2-03)  
Sec. 13-11. - Fire alarms. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
Alarm site means a single premises or location (one street address) served by a fire alarm system or systems that are under the control of one owner. 
Automatic dialing device means a fire alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a pre-recorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
False alarm means any fire alarm, which was discharged falsely, accidentally, through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, lack of maintenance, or by negligence of the owner or lessee of the alarm system or of his and/or her employees or agents. False alarms shall not include: 
(1)  Alarms that occur during electrical storms, tornadoes, hurricanes, ice storms, earthquakes, or other natural disaster or Acts of God. 
(2)  Disruption of the telephone circuits beyond the control of the alarm company and/or the alarm user. 
(3)  Electrical power or disruption or failure not caused by the user. 
(4)  Alarms which occur as a result of an actual fire or emergency condition. 
Fire alarm system(s) means any equipment, device or devices arranged to signal the presence of fire, smoke, heat or other hazards requiring urgent attention and to which the fire department is expected to respond. 
Fire alarm system user means the owner, agent or person in control of the property on which a fire alarm system or systems is maintained within the corporate limits of the city. 
Fire department response means the dispatching of a fire unit to investigate a fire alarm. 
Health care occupancies are those occupancies used for the purposes of treatment or care of persons suffering from physical or mental illness, disease or infirmity; the care of infants, convalescents or aged persons. Health care occupancies provide sleeping facilities for the occupants and are occupied by persons who are mostly incapable of self-preservation because of age, physical or mental disability, or because of security measures not under the occupant's control. 
Non-residential occupancies are those occupancies used for or engaged in commerce, business, or manufacturing. 
Permit means a certificate of authorization issued by the City of Pasadena to the owner, agent, or person in control of the property, which authorizes the operation of a fire alarm system or systems at an alarm site. 
Permit holder means any individual, corporation, partnership or other legal entity to which an alarm system permit is issued. 
Person means any individual, corporation, partnership or other legal entity. 
Residential occupancies are those private occupancies that provide living accommodations for persons not under medical care. 
(b)  Applicability. 
(1)  The provisions of this section applies to all fire alarm systems installed within the corporate limits of the City of Pasadena, except for those fire alarm systems installed upon the premises occupied by the United States Government, the State of Texas, the City of Pasadena, or any county government or school districts. 
(c)  Permit application: issuance. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to be operated, or permit the operation of a fire alarm system or systems at an alarm site unless a valid permit has been issued by the City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office for such system. Alarm sites in existence before the effective date of this section must be permitted within one hundred eighty (180) days of the effective date of this section. A fire alarm system user shall be in violation of this section if he permits the operation of such system without a proper permit. 
(2)  A fire alarm system user or his agent shall obtain a permit for each alarm site. 
(3)  Application for a permit for the operation of a fire alarm system or systems at an alarm site shall be made with the City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office by the owner, agent, or person having control over the property on which the fire alarm system is to be installed and operated. Application shall be made in writing on a form designated by the city. On such application form, the applicant shall set forth: 
a.  The name, address, and telephone number of the owner, agent, or person in control of the property to be protected; 
b.  The street address of the property on which the alarm system is to be installed and operated; 
c.  A brief description of the type of property to be protected (i.e. commercial, residential, or industrial, etc.); 
d.  Any business name or title used for the premises on which the alarm system is to be installed and operated; 
e.  Name, address, and telephone number of the alarm company or person who will install and service the alarm system; 
f.  Names and telephone numbers of two or more persons who are able to and have agreed to receive notification at any time from the fire department in order to deactivate the alarm system if it becomes necessary; 
g.  Any other pertinent information required by the fire department or the fire marshal's office, which is necessary for the enforcement of this section. 
(4)  The City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office shall issue a permit to the individual, corporation or other legal entity in control of the property to be protected upon submission in person or by mail of a completed application and payment of the appropriate fee, unless any statement made in the application is incomplete or false. 
(5)  The City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office shall treat all information on the application as confidential. 
(6)  Any permit issued pursuant of this ordinance shall be applicable only to the permit holder and is not transferable. 
(7)  Each permit issued to a fire alarm system user shall be valid for the duration of the permit unless one of the following occurs earlier: 
a.  Control of protected property is transferred from the permit holder; 
b.  Permit holder voluntarily discontinues services provided by a particular alarm protective service, and/or disconnections and alarm system; 
c.  Revocation of the permit by the City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office pursuant to this section. 
(d)  Permit fee. 
(1)  The fee for a permit issued pursuant to this section shall be: 
a.  The fee for an initial permit issued to non-residential fire alarm system users shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). This permit shall be renewed bi-annually. The renewal fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
b.  The fee for an initial permit issued to residential fire alarm system users shall be ten dollars ($10.00). This permit shall be renewed bi-annually. The renewal fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
c.  The fee for an initial permit issued to health care occupancies pursuant to this section shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). The permit shall be renewed annually for a fee of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). 
(e)  Service fee for fire department responses to excessive false alarms. 
(1)  The user of any fire alarm system, which upon activation elicits a fire department response from the City of Pasadena, shall be subject to the following answering fee schedule for each false alarm in the calendar year. 
(2)  The City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office shall impose a service fee for each fire department response to any false alarm. The owner of the property shall be subject to the fee schedule below. The fee schedule for each premises shall be as follows in a twelve month period: 
a.  First and second false alarms ..... No Charge 
b.  Third and fourth false alarms ..... $100.00 
c.  Fifth through tenth false alarms ..... $200.00 
d.  Eleventh and subsequent false alarms ..... $500.00 
(3)  This service fee shall be imposed whether the fire department received the alarm by direct connection or through an intermediary, such as an answering service or modified central station. If the fire marshal is notified in writing prior to the day of installation of a new alarm system, the fee imposed by this section shall be waived for a thirty-day period beginning with the date of the installation. 
(4)  Those subject to service fees for false alarms shall be notified, in writing, of such fees by the City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office. Failure to pay the fee within thirty (30) days of invoice shall be grounds for revocation of the fire alarm permit. 
(f)  Duty to respond. 
(1)  It shall be a violation of this section if a fire alarm system user cannot be contacted, or refuse to respond to the alarm site within one-half hour after receiving a request by fire department or a fire marshal's office officials. Fire alarm system user may be subject to a fine under the penalty section of this ordinance in addition to any applicable service fee. 
(g)  Revocation of permits. 
(1)  The fire marshal may revoke a fire alarm system permit if he determines that: 
a.  There is a false statement of a material matter on the application for a permit; 
b.  The permit holder has violated this ordinance or any of its provisions; or 
c.  The permit holder has failed to make timely payment of a service fee. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an alarm system during the period in which his alarm permit is revoked. 
(h)  Appeal of service fee; denial or revocation of a permit. 
(1)  Any permit holder aggrieved by the decision to assess a service fee by the fire marshal or his designated representative as provided for in subsection (c), may appeal the decision to a five-member board appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal within ten (10) days after the fire marshal or his designated representative renders the decision. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the city secretary stays an action of the fire marshal in assessing a service fee until the five-member board makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the fire marshal or his designated representative is final. 
(2)  If the fire marshal refuses to issue or revokes a permit, he shall send to the applicant or permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action and a statement of the right to an appeal. The applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the fire marshal to the five-member board by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal, within ten (10) days after receipt or the notice from the fire marshal. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the board stays an action of the fire marshal in revoking a permit until the board makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the fire marshal is final. 
(i)  Defense of prosecution. 
(1)  It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section that: 
a.  The activation of the fire alarm system was a result of an actual fire or emergency. 
b.  The alarm system was sounded solely for the purpose of testing the alarm and the person who tested the alarm took reasonable precautions to avoid any request being made to the Pasadena Fire Department to respond to such alarm. This section shall not apply to conduct which is in violation of Section 42.06 of the Penal Code of the State of Texas. 
(j)  Penalty for violation of section. Any violation of any provision of this section shall be deemed a class C misdemeanor and any person convicted of any such violation shall be fined not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day and every day that such violation shall continue shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 05-253, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 13-12. - Fire and life safety operating permit, special use permits, and inspections fees. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
Assembly use occupancies are buildings or structures, or a portion thereof, used for the gathering of persons for purposes of recreation, food or drink consumption including, but not limited to: banquet halls, night clubs, restaurants, taverns and bars. 
Day care use occupancies are buildings and structures occupied by persons of any age who receive custodial care for less than twenty-four (24) hours by individuals other than parents or guardians, relatives by blood marriage, or adoption and in a place other than the home of the person cared for including but not limited to: Day care centers, after school programs and family/group day care homes. 
Emergency generators means an engine generator in commercial, not residential, occupancies supplying emergency or standby power to fire and life safety systems, fire alarms or fire pumps. 
Fire and life safety operating permit means a certificate of authorization issued by the City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office to the owner, agent, or person in control of the property, which authorizes the operation of certain occupancies which by virtue of their operation or clientele has an increased fire and life safety hazard. 
Foster homes or group foster home occupancies means a private residential dwelling and its surrounding grounds which is licensed or approved by the state to provide twenty-four (24) hour substitute foster care for children. 
High-hazard use occupancies are buildings or structures, or a portion thereof, which involves the manufacturing, processing, generation or storage of materials that constitute a physical or health hazard including, but not limited to: auto wrecking yards, automotive repair shops, fuel dispensing, hazardous materials storage, high pile storage, industrials ovens, lumberyards, service stations and tire storage facilities. 
Institutional use occupancies are buildings or structures, or a portion thereof, in which people are cared for or living in a supervised environment and having physical limitations because of health or age, are harbored for medical treatment or other care or treatment including but not limited to: alcohol and drug centers, assisted living facilities, congregate care facilities, convalescent facilities, group homes, half-way houses, residential board and care facilities, social rehabilitation facilities, hospitals, nursing homes (both intermediate care facilities and skilled nursing facilities), mental hospitals, detoxification facilities. 
Multi-family residential use occupancies are buildings or structures, or a portion thereof containing three (3) or more dwelling units including but not limited to: apartment houses, boarding houses, congregate living facilities, dormitories, fraternities and sororities, hotels, and motels. 
Special use permit means a certificate of authorization issued by the City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office to the owner, agent, or person in control of the property, which authorizes the operation of certain businesses which by the very nature of the operations constitute a special fire hazard. 
Tent means a structure, enclosure or shelter constructed of fabric or pliable material supported by any manner used for the gathering of persons for commercial purposes of recreation and entertainment including tents that are used for assemblies, carnivals or circuses. For the purpose of this section, "tent" does not include pop tents or tents used for personal use. 
(b)  Applicability. The provision of this section applies to all fire and life safety operating permits, special use permits and certain inspections conducted by the fire prevention department (fire marshal's office) within the corporate limits of the City of Pasadena. 
(c)  Permit application: issuance. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to be operated, or permit the operation of an assembly use occupancy, a day care use occupancy, foster or group foster home occupancy, a high-hazard use occupancy, an institutional use occupancy, or a multi-family residential use occupancy unless a valid fire and life safety operating permit or a special use operating permit has been issued by the City of Pasadena Fire Marshal's Office for such business or operation. 
(d)  Existing occupancies. Occupancies in existence before the effective date of this section shall be required to obtain a fire and life safety permit or the special use operating permit upon their next scheduled yearly inspection unless a new certificate of occupancy is issued or a significant change in the occupancy use occurs. 
(e)  Separate permit for each place of business. Every person who desires to maintain and operate more than one (1) place of business or branch office or substitute place of business for which a permit is required by this section must designate in his application each and every such place of business, branch office or substitute place of business, giving each address, and pay a separate permit fee and secure a separate permit for each address. 
(f)  Display. A permit issued under this article shall at all times be displayed in a conspicuous place in the office of each place of business maintained by the permit holder. 
(g)  Term; renewal. Permits issued under this section shall expire one (1) calendar year from the date of issuance. Such permits shall be renewed by filling an application for renewal at least ten (10) days prior to the expiration of the current permit with the fire marshal's office. 
(h)  Fee required. A fee shall be assessed for all annual fire and life safety operating permits, special use operating permit, certain types of inspections and plan reviews conducted by the fire marshal's office. Such fee shall be paid prior to issuance of the initial permit to an applicant and upon renewal of such permit annually thereafter. The fees shall be as listed: 
Assembly Use Occupancy 
1—99 person occupant load ..... $250.00

300 or more person occupant load ..... $500.00 
Licensed Facilities Providing Less Than 24 Hour Care 
Licensed for 1—25 children ..... $100.00
