(i)  Reinspections. If, after the 2nd inspection, it is necessary for the fire inspector to reinspect any work whether from a defect or the work not being ready a reinspection fee of ($25.00) shall be collected for each reinspection. 
(j)  Permit revocation. The fire marshal shall have, and is hereby granted, the power and the authority to revoke any and all permits authorized by this section for violation of the terms and provisions of city ordinances, fire codes adopted by the City of Pasadena and applicable state laws. 
(k)  Penalty. Any violation of any provision of this section shall be deemed a class C misdemeanor and any person, firm, corporation, or other entity convicted of any such violation shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10-012, § 1(Exh. A), 1-19-10; Ord. No. 18-043, § 1(Exh. A), 4-17-18; Ord. No. 18-106, § 1(Exh. A), 8-7-18)  
Secs. 13-13—13-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 79-67, adopted June 12, 1979, changed the title of Art. II from "Fire Marshal" to "Fire Prevention Department." Sec. 2 of said ordinance repealed § 13-19, which created the independent office of the fire marshal, derived from Code 1964, § 13-16. Sec. 3 enacted a new § 13-19 as herein set out. 
 
Sec. 13-19. - Fire prevention department created; composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created and re-created within the municipal government of the City of Pasadena a department to be known as the fire prevention department, consisting of the following positions, classifications, career codes and salary grades: 
Position 
No. 	Classification Title 	Career Code 	Salary Grade 
1 	Fire marshal 	CS 	E 	18 
2 	Assistant fire marshal 	CS 	E 	12 
3 	Fire inspector 	CS 	E 	8 
4 	Fire inspector 	CS 	E 	8 
5 	Fire inspector 	CS 	E 	8 
6 	Secretary I 	CS 		6 
 
(b)  The holder of a position herein created shall have such duties and responsibilities as are assigned to him by the mayor of the City of Pasadena, Texas, the Charter and ordinances of the City of Pasadena, Texas, and the laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 79-67, § 3, 6-19-79) 
Cross reference— Duty of fire marshal to assist building commission, § 9-33.  
Sec. 13-20. - Appointment of fire marshal; qualifications. 
The fire marshal shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the city council, and he shall be properly qualified for the duties of his office. 
(Code 1964, § 13-17)  
Sec. 13-21. - Right of entry. 
The fire marshal shall have the authority at all times of day or night, when necessary in the performance of the duties imposed upon him by the provisions of this article, to enter upon and examine any building or premises where any fire has occurred and other buildings and premises adjoining or near the same, which authority shall be exercised only with reason and good discretion. The fire marshal shall have the right to enter any other building or premises, with or without complaint of adjacent property owners, for the purpose of examining the same for fire hazards. 
(Code 1964, § 13-27)  
Sec. 13-22. - Duty of fire marshal to investigate fires. 
The fire marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring within the city by which property has been destroyed or damaged, and shall especially make investigation as to whether such fire was the result of carelessness or design. Such investigation shall be commenced within twenty-four (24) hours, not including Sundays, after the occurrence of such fire. 
(Code 1964, § 13-18)  
Sec. 13-23. - Taking of testimony, summoning witnesses, administration of oaths, etc. 
(a)  The fire marshal, when in his opinion further investigation of a fire is necessary, shall take or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the same to be reduced to writing. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him to testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this article, a subject to inquiry and investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper or document deemed pertinent thereto. The fire marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations to any persons appearing as witnesses before him. 
(Code 1964, § 13-19)  
Sec. 13-24. - Investigations may be private; separation of witnesses. 
All investigations held by or under the direction of the fire marshal may, in his discretion, be private, and persons other than those required to be present may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held, and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been examined. 
(Code 1964, § 13-20)  
Sec. 13-25. - Duty when evidence indicates crime in connection with fire. 
If the fire marshal is of the opinion that there is evidence sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson, or with an attempt to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud, or criminal conduct in connection with a fire investigated by him, he shall cause such person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offense or either of them, and shall furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with the names of witnesses and all of the information obtained by him, including a copy of all the pertinent and material testimony taken in the case. 
(Code 1964, § 13-21)  
Sec. 13-26. - Periodic inspections of mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings. 
It shall be the duty of the fire marshal, monthly or more often, to enter upon and make or cause to be entered and made a thorough examination of all mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings, together with the premises belonging thereto. 
(Code 1964, § 13-22)  
Sec. 13-27. - Misconduct of witnesses summoned by fire marshal. 
Any witness who refuses to be sworn or who refuses to appear or testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the fire marshal, or who fails or refuses to produce any book or document touching any matter under examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the proceedings of the fire marshal in the matter of such investigation or inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter under investigation as provided in this article, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and it shall be the duty of the fire marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted. 
(Code 1964, § 13-24)  
Sec. 13-28. - Record of fires to be kept. 
The fire marshal shall keep in his office a record of all fires, together with all facts, statistics and circumstances, including the origin of the fires and the amount of the loss, which may be determined by the investigation required by this article. 
(Code 1964, § 13-25)  
Sec. 13-29. - Monthly reports to state fire marshal. 
At the end of each month, the fire marshal shall report to the state fire marshal all existing hazardous conditions, together with a separate report on each fire in the city during the month. 
(Code 1964, § 13-26)  
Secs. 13-30—13-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Fire department vehicles and private vehicles operated by volunteer firemen while answering fire alarms are designated as "authorized emergency vehicles" and exempt from certain traffic regulations, §§ 36-1, 36-13; authority of fire department officers to direct traffic at scene of fire, § 36-9. 
 
Sec. 13-41. - Created. 
There is hereby created an organization to be known as the Pasadena Volunteer Fire Department. 
(Code 1964, § 13-35)  
Sec. 13-42. - Purposes. 
The purposes of the volunteer fire department shall be: 
(1)  The systematic suppression and fighting of fires within the city limits. 
(2)  The training of members of such department in the methods of suppression and fighting of fires. 
(3)  The education of the citizens of the city in means and methods of the prevention of fires. 
(4)  The removal of fire hazards. 
(Code 1964, § 13-36)  
Sec. 13-43. - Composition. 
The membership of the volunteer fire department shall be divided into active and nonactive members. The membership in each category shall be limited to such number as is determined by the executive board of the department and this article. 
(1)  Active means those persons qualified and acceptable for active duty in the department. 
(2)  Nonactive means those persons, who, by reason of disability incurred after membership in the department has been established, are permitted to remain as members of the department in accordance with age and retirement benefit provisions, but are not permitted to participate actively in any fire scene service activities. This classification is intended to permit current volunteers who may be up to the age of sixty-five (65) retaining their membership in the department for pension purposes and other benefits. It will also permit new entry-level applicants to remain in the department as provided in Section 13-83. 
(Code 1964, § 13-37; Ord. No. 83-95, § 1, 3-29-83; Ord. No. 84-146, § 1, 7-10-84)  
Sec. 13-44. - Election of members. 
All members of the volunteer fire department, except the position of fire chief, may be elected by a majority vote of the membership of the department, but no member shall be eligible to election until his name has been submitted by the department officials to the city council and has been approved by the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 13-38; Ord. No. 02-120, § 3, 5-14-02)  
Sec. 13-45. - Qualifications of members. 
(a)  Applicants for active membership in the volunteer fire department shall be twenty-one (21) years of age and under forty-five (45) years of age, shall be citizens of the city or reside in the vicinity of a city fire station, shall be sound in mind and members of good moral standing and good physical condition, and shall have such other qualifications as may be set by the executive board of the department. 
(b)  In the event normal recruitment activity fails to provide sufficient volunteers to man and operate a city fire station, the executive committee may waive the upper age limits required for active membership. Notification to the mayor shall be given of this event ten (10) days prior to the commencement of fire training for new recruits. Any fireman who is over the age of forty-five (45) and who has been recruited and trained in substantial compliance to the intent of this waiver prior to the adoption of this section shall be deemed to be so covered. 
(Code 1964, § 13-39; Ord. No. 83-95, § 1, 3-29-83; Ord. No. 84-146, § 1, 7-10-84; Ord. No. 91-101, § 1, 6-11-91; Ord. No. 94-29, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 13-46. - Agreement required of members. 
Any candidate for membership in the volunteer fire department, either active or honorary, must, before being admitted to such membership, sign an obligation agreeing to abide by and comply with any and all ordinances, rules, and regulations prescribed by the city council or by the volunteer fire department. Active members shall, in addition thereto, agree to attend any and all fire drills and regular or special meetings of the department, obey all rules and instructions of the officers thereof and attend and assist in the fighting of all fires within the city limits or adjacent thereto, when, as and if ordered so to do, illness or absence from the city not preventing. 
(Code 1964, § 13-40)  
Sec. 13-47. - Rules, regulations and bylaws. 
The volunteer fire department shall pass such rules and regulations and adopt such bylaws as the membership thereof shall deem wise, expedient and necessary for the government, control and benefit of such department, and such rules, regulations and bylaws, when and if approved by the city council, shall govern the procedure of such department, until the same are repealed or amended. 
(Code 1964, § 13-41)  
Sec. 13-48. - Authority of fire chief. 
(a)  The fire chief or his duly authorized representatives, as may be in charge at the scene of a fire or other emergency, and for a reasonable time subsequent thereto, involving the protection of life and/or property, are empowered to direct such operations as may be necessary to extinguish or control any suspected or reported fires, gas leaks, or other hazardous conditions or situations or of taking any other action necessary in the reasonable performance of their duty. The fire chief may prohibit any person, vehicle or object from approaching the scene any may remove or cause to be removed from the scene any person, vehicle or object which may impede or interfere with the operations of the fire department. The fire chief may remove or cause to be removed any person, vehicle or object from hazardous areas. All persons ordered to leave a hazardous area shall do so immediately and shall not reenter the areas until authorized to do so by the fire chief. 
(b)  The authority of the fire chief as described in subsection (a) of this section is subject to the authority of the safety coordinator of the City of Pasadena in regard to incidents involving hazardous or highly toxic materials. 
(Code 1964, § 13-42; Ord. No. 80-62, § 8, 4-8-80; Ord. No. 94-167, § 1, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 13-49. - Disposition of funds. 
No individual member or members of the volunteer fire department shall ever have any right, title, claim or interest in or to any of the funds of such department from whatsoever source derived, but such funds shall be for the sole and exclusive use and benefit of the individual members and the membership of such department as long as the department continues to exist. In the event of the department's abolition or disbarment from any cause whatsoever, any funds on hand to the credit of the department shall immediately revert to and become a part of the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 13-43)  
Sec. 13-50. - Death benefits. 
Members of the volunteer fire department are referred to Article 6228(f), Vernon's Annotated Texas Statutes for Texas death benefits and 42 U. S. Code 3796 et seq. for federal death benefits, and such other ordinances of the city which have been or may be adopted. 
(Ord. No. 83-95, § 1, 3-29-83)  
Sec. 13-51. - Income protection. 
The city shall, for a period not to exceed twelve (12) months, pay to a volunteer fireman injured on duty and unable to return to employment by reason of such injury the amount of two-thirds of that person's average weekly base wage at the time of the injury. Provided, however, that such income protection shall be subject to the conditions and exceptions as follows: 
(1)  Any volunteer fireman not employed at the time of such injury shall receive only worker's compensation benefits. 
(2)  In computing the amount of two-thirds of a person's average weekly base wage, the city shall deduct from the amount paid the amount of the worker's compensation payment and any other income protection provided by the city. 
(3)  The fireman must qualify for membership in compliance with this article. 
(4)  The benefit shall in no event exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 83-95, § 1, 3-29-83)  
Sec. 13-52. - Training and education. 
All applicants shall successfully complete the cadet program established by the department and all members shall successfully complete such continuing education as is required by the rules, regulations and bylaws of the department. 
(Ord. No. 83-95, § 1, 3-29-83)  
Sec. 13-53. - Worker's compensation. 
The city, pursuant to Article 8309h, Vernon's Annotated Texas Statutes, elects to provide worker's compensation for volunteer firefighters who shall be added to the city's current self-insured insurance program upon compliance with the following conditions: 
(1)  New applicants. Due to the demanding physical and mental exertion involved in fire suppression, effective moral, medical, physical and mental screening is necessary. Physical, medical, moral and psychological standards shall be established by city council or the department in its bylaws. Applicants shall fulfill all qualifications upon completion of cadet classes. To determine eligibility, applicants shall provide the following: 
a.  Application. All volunteers shall complete an application which will be used as the basis for developing the personnel file. Applicants must complete a background investigation. 
(b)  Age requirements. All volunteers must be at least eighteen (18) years of age and must not have reached their forty-fifth (45th) birthday to be accepted for cadet training. Required retirement for all new entry-level applicants shall be age sixty (60), except new entrants to the department who are between their fortieth (40th) and forty-fifth (45th) birthday. Retirement for new entrants who join the department between their fortieth (40th) and forty-fifth (45th) birthday shall be on their twentieth (20th) anniversary of service in the department or their sixty-fifth (65th) birthday, whichever event occurs first. An annual physical will be required after the age of sixty (60) to determine whether the applicant shall have an active or inactive state. 
c.  Medical history. All applicants must furnish a complete medical history, listing all past injuries, physical disabilities and medication which may affect their performance and physical limitations. 
d.  Physical examination. Applicants must produce evidence that they have submitted to and passed a thorough physical examination required by the City of Pasadena prior to completion of cadet classes. 
e.  Physical agility. Applicants must successfully complete and pass a physical agility test as established by the volunteer department training standards. 
f.  Texas driver's license. Applicants must have a valid driver's license. 
g.  Psychological evaluation. All volunteer firemen will have a psychological evaluation paid for by the city upon completion of cadet classes. 
(2)  Current volunteers. Current volunteers must be physically and mentally capable of suppressing fires. Any volunteer unable to suppress fires shall be immediately placed on nonactive status by the department. The chief of the fire department shall notify the personnel department of all volunteer firemen on nonactive status. The executive board of the department shall order a physical examination of any fireman it determines may be physically unable to suppress fires; such examinations shall be paid for by the city. Additionally, current volunteers shall provide and be subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Medical history. A complete medical history record will be completed by each volunteer fireman on forms furnished by the city. 
b.  Age requirements. Current volunteers may not be over the age of sixty (60). However, those current volunteers who require continuance in the department to receive twenty-year certification may do so up to the age of sixty-five (65), but an annual physical will be required after the age of sixty (60) to determine whether the volunteer shall have an active or nonactive status. 
c.  Psychological evaluation. Current volunteers will be required to pass a physical evaluation as a condition precedent to their retention in the department. Refusal to submit to the examination or failure to pass such examination will result in dismissal from the department. 
(3)  All volunteers. All volunteers shall be subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Report of injury or illness. Report to the department any injury received on regular employment or any illness. Present to the fire department copies of doctor's statement allowing them to return to work. If not able to return to normal employment, employee would not be able to return to fireman status. 
b.  Annual physical examination. An annual physical may be required for all volunteer fireman at city's expense. The city will select requirements and physicians. The city will provide details of such physical if such physical is required. 
c.  Accident reporting. Accident reporting shall be the responsibility of each fireman. He shall report to his supervisor immediately any accident occurring while in the process of training or covered department activities. All accidents must be reported within a twenty-four-hour period. Failure to do so may mean loss of benefits. All reports shall be submitted to the administrative head of the fire department with responsibility for transmission to the personnel department of the city immediately. 
(Ord. No. 83-95, § 1, 3-29-83; Ord. No. 84-38, §§ 1, 2, 2-28-84; Ord. No. 84-146, § 1, 7-10-84; Ord. No. 94-29, § 2, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 02-70, § 2, 3-5-02)  
Sec. 13-54. - Activities covered. 
(a)  The following activities are covered by the Income Protection Plan and Worker's Compensation: 
(1)  Travel to and from the scene of a fire, and all activities at the scene of a fire. 
(2)  On-duty status at the station houses. 
(3)  Training activities conducted by or for the benefit of the department. 
(4)  All scheduled physical training and conditioning programs or events. 
(5)  Events in which members participate which are conducted directly for the maintenance and promotion of the department and its assets. 
(b)  The following activities are not covered by the Income Protection Plan or Worker's Compensation: 
(1)  Social events conducted by the department. 
(2)  Events in which members participate which are conducted directly for the benefit of third-party organizations and promotions. 
(c)  Where inclusions in the Income Protection Plan or Worker's Compensation law, as interpreted by the courts, conflict with subsections (a) and/or (b) the law or plan, as the case may be, shall control. 
(Ord. No. 84-146, § 1, 7-10-84)  
Sec. 13-55. - Fire chief. 
(a)  There is hereby created and recreated the position of fire chief of the City of Pasadena, Texas. Such position shall be designated as salary grade PE-05. The fire chief shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(b)  The fire chief shall be head of the Pasadena Fire Department and shall have such duties and responsibilities as are assigned to him by the mayor of the City of Pasadena, Texas, the charter, ordinances of the City of Pasadena, and the laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 02-120, § 2, 5-14-02)  
Secs. 13-56—13-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - EXPLOSIVES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 13-61. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Explosive; explosives. The terms "explosive" and "explosives" shall mean gunpowders, powders used for blasting, all forms of high explosives, blasting material, fuses (other than electric circuit breakers), detonators and other detonating agents, smokeless powders and any chemical compounds or mechanical mixture that contains any oxidizing any combustible units, or other ingredients, in such proportions, quantities or packing that ignition by fire, by friction, by concussion, by percussion or by detonation of the compound or mixture of any part thereof may cause an explosion. The term "explosive" or "explosives" shall not include cartridges for small arms or shotguns, signaling devices or emergency equipment designated by the fire marshal. The terms "explosive" and "explosives" mean and include, among others, any of the following chemical compounds or mechanical mixtures: 
(1)  Amatol (mixture of ammonium nitrate and trinitrotoluene). 
(2)  Ammonal (mixture of ammonium nitrate, trinitrotoluene and powdered aluminum, with or without other ingredients). 
(3)  Azides. 
(4)  Black powder, all forms, except in completely assembled cartridges for small arms or shotguns. 
(5)  Caps, blasting (fuse and electric), detonating, all classes except percussion caps and small arms primers. 
(6)  Detonators. 
(7)  Dynamites. 
(8)  Fertilizers (ammonium sulfate with nitrogen). 
(9)  Fireworks, all kinds. 
(10)  Fulminates. 
(11)  Fuses of all varieties, used in connection with setting off explosives. 
(12)  Guncotton (see Nitrocellulose). 
(13)  Gunpowder and gunpowder mixtures (Except in completely assembled cartridges for small arms or shotguns). 
(14)  Hexanitrodiphonylamine (dipicrylamine, hexamine). 
(15)  Nitrocellulose exceeding 12.2 per cent nitrogen. 
(16)  Nitroglucose. 
(17)  Nitroglycerine (except in pharmacopoeia solution, or in form of pills, or granules, containing not more than one-fiftieth of a grain each, for pharmaceutical purposes). 
(18)  Nitrostarch. 
(19)  Nitrosugar. 
(20)  Pentaerythritetetranitrate (penthrite or pentrite, PETN). 
(21)  Permissible explosives. 
(22)  Picrates. 
(23)  Picric acid (except in solutions not exceeding 1.24 per cent at normal or room temperature, for medicinal use, in quantities not exceeding eight fluid ounces of such solution). 
(24)  Potassium nitrate powders (black saltpeter powder and nitro). 
(25)  Schnoiderite (mixture of ammonium nitrate and dinitronalphthene, with or without other ingredients). 
(26)  Smokeless powder (except in completely assembled cartridges for small arms or shotguns). 
(27)  Sodium nitrate powders (black soda powder). 
(28)  Squibs. 
(29)  Styphanates. 
(30)  Tetranitreaniline (TNA). 
(31)  Tetranitronaphthalene. 
(32)  Totryl (trinitrophonylmothylnitramine, totranitromethylaniline, tetralite, phronite). 
(33)  Trimethylene trinitramine (hexogon T4, cyclonite). 
(34)  Trinitroanisol (methyl picrate, trinitrophenylmethyl ether). 
(35)  Trinitrocresol (crysylite). 
(36)  Trinitrotoluene (triten, TNY). 
(37)  Trinitroxylene (TNX). 
Explosive permit. The term "explosive permit" shall be held to mean the written authority issued by the fire marshal for the keeping, storing or using of explosives, under such conditions as specified in this article. 
Fireworks. The term "fireworks" shall mean any device that can be used to produce or is intended to produce a striking display, such as light or noise or smoke, or a combination of those, by the combustion of explosive or flammable composition. 
Ingredients. The term "ingredients" shall mean phosphorus and active oxidizing and other chemicals, except those that are nonflammable gases at normal temperatures and under normal atmospheric conditions, that can be combined with one or more reducing materials to produce an explosive. The terms "ingredient" and "ingredients" mean any of the following chemicals (except in tablet, capsule or liquid form for medicinal purposes): 
(1)  Chlorates: 
Ammonium 
Barium 
Potassium 
Sodium 
(2)  Nitrates: 
Ammonium 
Potassium 
Sodium 
(3)  Perchlorates: 
Perchlorate acid and salts 
Phosphorus 
Relation in the ascending line. The term "relation in the ascending line" means the mother or father, either the natural parent or parent by marriage, of a minor. 
Special permit. The term "special permit" shall be held to mean the written authority issued by the fire marshal for the keeping, storing or using of explosives, under such unusual conditions as specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 1, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-62. - Compliance with article. 
Explosives not expressly prohibited by this article may be kept, stored, sold or offered for sale, given away, used, transported or manufactured in the city only as provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 2, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-63. - Prohibited explosives. 
No person shall have in his possession, keep, store, sell, offer for sale, give away, use, transport or manufacture any of the following explosives in any amount within the city: 
(1)  Liquid nitroglycerine. 
(2)  High explosives containing over sixty (60) per cent nitroglycerine, except gelatin dynamite. 
(3)  High explosives having an unsatisfactory absorbent or one that permits leakage of nitroglycerine under any conditions liable to exist during transportation or storage. 
(4)  Nitrocellulose in a dry condition in quantity greater than ten (10) pounds in one exterior package. 
(5)  Fulminate of mercury in bulk in a dry condition, and fulminate of all other metals in any condition, except as a component of manufactured articles not forbidden by this article. 
(6)  Fireworks of all kinds. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 2, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-64. - Exceptions from article—Small quantities of certain ingredients. 
There shall be excepted from the provisions of this article ingredients in small quantities and not used or intended to be used in the manufacture of explosives. The meaning of the term "small quantities," as used herein, is dependent upon the type of the ingredient and the classification of the person acquiring same, according to the following table: 
Type of 
ingredient 
(of each) 	Classification of person 
acquiring ingredient 	Meaning of 
small quantity 
Chlorate 	Industrial users ..... 	225 lb. 
	Colleges, universities ..... 	50 lb. 
	Wholesalers ..... 	25 lb. 
	High schools, hospitals, industrial research laboratories ..... 	10 lb. 
	Druggists ..... 	2 lb. 
	Others ..... 	¼ lb. 
Nitrate 	Industrial ..... 	200 lb. 
	Colleges, universities, wholesalers ..... 	50 lb. 
	High schools, druggists ..... 	10 lb. 
	Others ..... 	5 lb. 
Perchlorate 	Industrial users, industrial research laboratories ..... 	140 lb. 
	Colleges, Universities ..... 	70 lb. 
	Wholesalers ..... 	10 lb. 
	Druggists, high schools, hospitals ..... 	2 lb. 
	Others ..... 	¼ lb. 
Phosphorus 	Industrial users ..... 	50 lb. 
	Wholesalers, colleges, universities ..... 	10 lb. 
	Industrial research laboratories, high schools, hospitals ..... 	2 lb. 
	Others ..... 	¼ lb. 
 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 4, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-65. - Same—Explosives or ingredients in transit. 
There shall be excepted from the provisions of this article explosives or ingredients which are in transit upon railroad cars, when such transportation is regulated by acts of Congress, or rules and regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission or any other federal or state governing agency. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 4, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-66. - Storage requirements. 
All explosives or ingredients of explosives, whether or not the possessor has a permit under this article, shall be stored in accordance with conditions not less stringent than those recommended by the American Insurance Association, the Interstate Commerce Commission or other recognized authorities. The fire marshal may place such additional restrictions upon the storage of ingredients as he may deem necessary for fire or explosion prevention purposes, without any modification of this article. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 8, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-67. - Packaging and marking requirements for delivery or transportation. 
No person shall deliver or transport explosives into the corporate limits of the city, unless they are packed and marked in compliance with the Interstate Commerce Commission regulations governing the transportation of explosives, as formulated and published from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 9, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-68. - Requirements for vehicles transporting explosives. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle transporting explosives within the city, unless the same complies with all regulations which have been established by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Civil Aeronautics Board, the state or the city, as such regulations may apply governing the construction or operation of such motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 10, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-69. - Aiding minors to purchase, use, etc., fireworks. 
No relation in the ascending line of a minor, or guardian of a minor, shall furnish money or a thing of value to a minor for the purchase of fireworks, or encourage, act in conjunction with or in any manner instigate or aid a minor in the commission of having, keeping, storing, selling, offering for sale, giving away, using, transporting, or manufacturing fireworks within the corporate limits of the city. This shall be an offense regardless of whether the minor has been found guilty of the offense. The commission of the offense by the minor on the property under the control or owned by the relation or guardian shall be prima facie evidence that the relation or guardian was instigating or aiding the minor. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 3, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-70. - Confiscation of explosives found in violation of article. 
All explosives or ingredients thereof which shall be kept, possessed or stored or in anywise handled in violation of this article may be confiscated and impounded by the fire marshal and disposed of by the fire marshal as provided for by the applicable laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 13, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-71. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any violation of any provision of this article shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person convicted of any such violation shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day and every day that such violation shall continue shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 14, 5-30-67; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Secs. 13-72—13-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT TO MANUFACTURE, STORE, USE, ETC. 
 
Sec. 13-81. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  Every person, company, partnership, corporation or branch of any government agency, except those excepted herein, manufacturing, storing, handling, using or transporting or otherwise possessing explosives or ingredients within the city must obtain a permit under the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Every person having individuals in his employ who manufacture, handle, store, use, transport or possess explosives for him must have an explosive permit issued under this division. 
(c)  Every person who possesses or has access to the keys or combination of the storage place or magazine, or who has custody of the explosives or ingredients, or who charges the explosives into a hole, or who detonates explosives, shall possess an individual explosive permit, except as hereinafter provided. 
(d)  No permit shall be required for the manufacture, distribution, storage, sale, purchase, possession, handling or use of explosives or ingredients by the Military or Naval Services of the United States or by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the city police department or the county sheriff, provided such explosives or ingredients are to be used for the purpose of law enforcement. Nor shall any permit be required by arsenals, depots, or other establishments owned wholly by the United States Department of Defense; provided, however, that a permit shall be required for private operators of such establishments who possess explosives or ingredients for shipment or who ship on other than government bills of lading. A permit shall also be required for persons who manufacture explosives under the authority of the United States for, or sell explosives to, the Military or Naval Services of the United States, or the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 5, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-82. - Qualifications of applicant. 
Only those persons who have proven to the fire marshal or some person designated by him, by examination or actual test or by checked references of three (3) persons not related to the applicant, or by all these means, that they are qualified to manufacture, store, handle, use, transport or possess explosives and ingredients and who have proved to the satisfaction of the fire marshal that they have read, or have had read to them, and know the provisions of this article, shall be given an explosive permit. Every new applicant for a permit shall be checked through the records and identification bureau of the police department and any person convicted of a felony shall not be entitled to a permit. No permit shall be issued in time of war or riot to any person who is not a citizen of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(a, c), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-83. - Application; applicant to appear in person. 
The fire marshal shall require a written application for an explosive permit. Every person, including an authorized agent, applying for an explosive permit must appear in person before the fire marshal or his authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(j), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-84. - Fee. 
The fee for an explosive permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), which fee shall be paid to the building official prior to issuance of the permit. Such fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall likewise apply to all renewals or extensions of all permits granted or issued under the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 12, 5-30-67; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 13-85. - Investigation upon receipt of application; issuance or refusal generally. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for an explosive permit, the fire marshal shall make or cause to be made an investigation to determine if all conditions of this article and applying to the permit specified are fulfilled, and if the fire marshal shall find that such conditions are fulfilled and that the information set forth in the permit application is true, the permit shall be issued, subject, however, to all other provisions of this division. 
(b)  The fire marshal may refuse to issue an explosive permit to any person, without disclosing his reason, except as otherwise provided in this division. He may also defer the issuance of an explosive permit to make such investigation as he deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(b, h), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-86. - Record of issuance. 
The fire marshal's office shall keep an accurate and complete record of all explosive permits issued under this division. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(i), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-87. - Government departments, firms, etc., may obtain permit through authorized agent. 
Government departments, firms, corporations, partnerships, contractors and the like may obtain explosive permits through a person authorized to act for or to assume legal responsibility for them. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(j), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-88. - Employer's permit prerequisite to issuance or continuance of employee's permit. 
No employee of a government department, firm, partnership, corporation or individual shall be issued an explosive permit unless his employer first obtains an explosive permit. An employee's explosive permit becomes void if his employer's explosive permit expires or is revoked. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(k, l), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-89. - Council approval required for issuance in certain cases. 
The fire marshal shall not issue a permit for quantities to exceed one hundred (100) pounds of high or low explosives, five hundred (500) electric blasting caps, or twenty-five (25) pounds of black powder of any kind, without the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(f), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-90. - Not to issue over objection of fire or police chief. 
The fire marshal shall not issue an explosive permit if he receives a written objection from the chief of the fire department or the chief of the police department, or from persons authorized to act for them. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(e), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-91. - Police and fire chiefs to be notified of issuance in certain cases. 
The fire marshal may issue permits for any quantity of explosive ingredients, provided the chief of the fire department and the chief of the police department are advised by him in writing of permits issued for quantities in excess of five hundred (500) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(g), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-92. - Numbering; contents. 
Explosive permits shall be numbered consecutively and shall specify the purpose for which the explosives or their ingredients are to be manufactured, stored, handled, transported or possessed, and the maximum amount that will be allowed. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(c), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-93. - Term. 
An explosive permit shall not be issued for a period of longer than one (1) year from date of issuance. It shall be issued for a less period if deemed advisable by the fire marshal or if the purpose for which the permit is issued will not require a period of a year. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(d), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-94. - Notice of loss or destruction. 
The fire marshal shall be notified of the loss or destruction of any valid permit issued under this division. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(s), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-95. - To be presented to person delivering explosives. 
No person shall allow any substance which is labeled "Explosives" or which is known by the invoice or bill of lading to be explosives, and labeled in accordance with interstate regulations, to pass from his possession for delivery, or to be delivered by any person representing him, to any person required to have a permit under this division, unless such person presents to him, for examination, a valid permit issued under this division. A photostatic copy of the same size as the permit shall be considered the same as the permit for the purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 11, 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-96. - Permittee's statement as to disposition of unused ingredients or explosives. 
The fire marshal shall require a statement from any explosive permit holder regarding the disposition of unused ingredients or explosives from any job. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(m), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-97. - Procedure when permittee's ingredients become dangerous or hazardous. 
In case ingredients in the hands of the holder of an explosive permit shall, in the opinion and judgment of the fire marshal, become dangerous or hazardous, the fire marshal shall notify the permittee and shall allow forty-eight (48) hours to remove the ingredients to a safe location, except in the case of a serious hazard, shorter time for removal may be designated by the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(t), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-98. - Assignment or transfer prohibited. 
Explosive permits cannot be assigned or in any way transferred, nor can any person operate under, or have the benefit of, another person's permit. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(o), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-99. - Procedure upon death or discharge from employment of permittee. 
In the event of the death of the holder of an explosive permit, the permit becomes immediately void, and the personal representative or heirs of the decedent must apply for a permit to cover remaining explosives or ingredients or uncompleted operations requiring a permit. If the permit holder is discharged from his employment, his permit becomes immediately void and shall be delivered to his employer, who must deface it by writing across the face thereof the word "Void", together with a notation of the date and reason for the voidance, and thereafter mail or deliver it to the fire marshal, and the employer must at once take possession and charge of any explosives or ingredients for which the permittee was accountable. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(p), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-100. - Procedure upon dissolution or transfer of permittee's business. 
In the event of the dissolution or transfer of the business of the holder of an explosive permit, the successor in interest of the permittee shall immediately apply for a permit to cover any explosives, ingredients or operations relating to same. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(p), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-101. - Procedure in event of permittee's bankruptcy. 
In the event of bankruptcy of the holder of an explosive permit, the trustee or receiver of his bankrupt estate shall immediately apply for a permit to cover any remaining explosives, ingredients or operations relating thereto. The permit shall not pass with any forced sale or other forced transfer of explosives, ingredients or operations covered by it, and the transferee must immediately apply for a permit to cover same. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(q), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-102. - Return of void permits. 
Any explosive permit that becomes void during the period for which it was issued shall be returned immediately to the office of the fire marshal and it shall be accompanied with all photostatic copies thereof and a list showing all photostatic copies that have been made. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(r), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-103. - Revocation generally. 
The fire marshal shall revoke an explosive permit for violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 6(n), 5-30-67)  
Sec. 13-104. - Appeal from refusal or revocation. 
Any person who has been refused issuance of an explosive permit by the fire marshal or who has had his explosive permit revoked by the fire marshal may appeal such action to the city council by notifying the city secretary in writing, within ten (10) days of such action of the fire marshal. Upon receipt of such notice of appeal, the mayor shall call a meeting of the council, within not less than ten (10) days of the receipt of the notice. Complete minutes shall be taken of all such proceedings of the council, and the findings and decision of the council shall be made in writing within ten (10) days after the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 67-1958, § 7, 5-30-67)  
Secs. 13-105—13-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - BUILDINGS CONSTITUTING FIRE HAZARDS GENERALLY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Dangerous buildings generally, § 9-151 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to provide for the condemnation and removal of structures constituting fire hazards, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(25). 
 
Sec. 13-116. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
Building. The term "building" is used in its customary and ordinary meaning, but where a shed or attachment has been built onto an original structure, or where two (2) or more buildings have been joined together or where a second building has been built adjacent to the first and utilizes a wall of the first building as a party wall, all parts shall be considered one building. 
Combustible fiber. The term "combustible fiber" shall mean and include cotton, sisal, henequen, ixtle, jute, hemp, tow, cocoa fiber, oakum, baled waste, baled wastepaper, kapok, hay, straw, Spanish moss and excelsior. 
Lodging house. The term "lodging house" is used in its ordinary and customary meaning and shall also mean and include hotels, boardinghouses, rooming houses, tenement houses, or any other houses, by whatever name known, used and occupied, or designed and constructed so that the same may be used and occupied, for the permanent or temporary occupancy for living quarters for ten (10) or more persons. 
Owner. The term "owner" is used in its customary and ordinary meaning and in addition thereto: 
(1)  If the building is owned by two (2) or more persons, each shall be responsible hereunder as an owner. 
(2)  If the building is owned or leased by a corporation, the president, the general agent (if there is one), the general manager (if there is one), and each member of the board of directors shall be responsible hereunder as an owner. 
(3)  If the building is owned by one and leased to another, the responsibility hereunder shall be the responsibility of both the lessor and lessee and each or both may be held accountable for a violation hereof, and the term "owner" shall include "lessee." 
(4)  If the building is the property of an estate under administration, in custodia legis, or held in trust, the executor, administrator, guardian, receiver or trustee shall be responsible hereunder as an owner. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 1, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-117. - Powers of fire marshal and deputies in enforcing article. 
(a)  For the purpose of the enforcement of this article, the fire marshal and any assistant fire marshal, arson investigator or inspector of the fire prevention division of the fire department of the city shall be vested with all of the authority, duties and powers of a duly constituted police officer of this city. 
(b)  For the purpose of the enforcement of this article, any assistant fire marshal, city arson investigator or inspector of the fire prevention division of the fire department of the city shall be deemed to be a deputy of the fire marshal and any of the powers and duties herein given the fire marshal may be exercised by any such deputy on behalf of the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 10, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-118. - Fire hazards enumerated. 
The following shall be considered fire hazards: 
(1)  Any building containing electrical wiring or appliances in a dangerous and defective condition likely to cause fire. Electrical wiring and appliances installed or in use which are not in compliance with the provisions of any ordinance of this city regulating such wiring and appliances and the installation thereof shall be deemed dangerous and defective. [5] 
(2)  Any building containing gas plumbing or appliances in a dangerous and defective condition likely to cause fire. Gas plumbing or appliances installed or in use which are not in compliance with the provisions of any ordinance of this city regulating such plumbing and appliances and the installation thereof shall be deemed dangerous and defective. [6] 
(3)  Any building of wooden frame construction wherein flammable liquids are used or stored in violation of any ordinance passed by the city council regulating the storage, handling, keeping and use of flammable liquids. 
(4)  Any building of wooden frame construction wherein any cafe or restaurant business is operated unless the walls and ceiling of that portion of the building in which the cafe or restaurant is operated are separated from the remainder of the building by one (1) hour fire resistive materials, as defined in the building code. [7] 
(5)  Any building of wooden frame construction wherein any automobile repair or service business is carried on, unless fire-resistive separation is installed as provided in paragraph (4) above. 
(6)  Any building of wooden frame construction wherein any combustible fibers are stored in excess of one hundred (100) cubic feet or wherein combustible fibers of less quantity than one hundred (100) cubic feet are stored other than in a metal-lined wooden bin, equipped with a self-closing metal cover. 
(7)  Any lodging house being operated in a two (2) story building of wooden frame construction; provided, however, that no such lodging house shall constitute a fire hazard if: 
(a)  The ceiling of the first floor is separated from the floor of the second floor by one (1) hour fire-resistive materials; and 
(b)  The walls between the rooms are insulated by one (1) hour fire-resistive materials and extend from ceiling to floor; and 
(c)  The floors, stairways, walls and frame of the house are in safe and sound structural condition; and 
(d)  The building does not otherwise constitute a fire hazard as provided herein. 
(8)  Any wooden frame building, a substantial portion of which is in a state of dilapidation and in an advanced stage of rot and deterioration, where the rotten, dilapidated and deteriorated condition of the building renders its occupancy extremely hazardous to human life due to the increased likelihood of the occurrence of fire and the increased danger of its rapid and violent spread. 
(9)  Though not otherwise defined herein, any building wherein exists a dangerous, defective and hazardous condition the nature of which renders the occupancy of such building an extreme risk to human life and the continued existence of which will, under all probabilities, result in a loss of human life. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 2, 5-2-67) 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Electrical code, Ch. 12. 

--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Plumbing, Ch. 29. 

--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Building code, § 9-62 et seq. 
 
Sec. 13-119. - Initial placarding. 
(a)  Whenever the fire marshal shall find that any building within the city constitutes a fire hazard, he shall forthwith cause to be posted on or near the front door of such building, in as conspicuous a manner as possible, a substantial placard upon which shall be printed in red in letters at least two and one-half (2½) inches high in words "WARNING—FIRE HAZARD," and on which placard there shall also appear the following words: 
"THE BUILDING IS A FIRE HAZARD. ITS OCCUPANCY IS DANGEROUS TO HUMAN LIFE. THE OWNER AND ALL OCCUPANTS ARE DIRECTED BY LAW TO COMMUNICATE IN PERSON OR BY TELEPHONE, IMMEDIATELY, WITH THE OFFICE OF THE FIRE MARSHAL OF THE CITY OF PASADENA." 
Such placard may contain other information deemed advisable by the fire marshal. Like placards shall be placed in or on other portions of the building as may be deemed necessary by the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 3, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-120. - Notice to owner. 
(a)  The fire marshal shall give notice to the owner of the building placarded in accord with section 13-119 that the same constitutes a fire hazard, stating substantially what conditions exist giving rise to same and substantially what measures should be taken to abolish the hazard. Such notice shall normally be given in writing by mail or delivery, but may be given orally if the circumstances are urgent and delay would endanger life. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall find and determine from the existing facts what maximum amount of time may be safely permitted the owner to abolish the fire hazard, without materially increasing the danger to life and shall specify in his notice to the owner the extent of such time limit. 
(c)  Where the fire marshal cannot, by the exercise of reasonable diligence, ascertain the identity or the residence of the owner, or is wholly unable to communicate with him for any reason, it shall be sufficient for the fire marshal to post a written notice near his placard on the building. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 4, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-121. - Duty of owner to abolish hazard. 
(a)  Whenever any owner shall be given notice as provided in section 13-120, he shall forthwith take such action as may be necessary to abolish the fire hazard. He shall do so by either correcting the physical condition or conditions which cause fire, or by causing the building to be vacated of human occupancy. Purported or alleged inability to abolish the hazard in one way will not excuse failure to abolish it in the other. He shall take all necessary action and abolish the fire hazard within the time which the fire marshal has found from the facts may safely be allowed. 
(b)  Any owner of any building who shall receive notice from the fire marshal that it is a fire hazard, as provided in section 13-120, and shall fail or refuse to abolish the fire hazard within the maximum time limit found by the fire marshal, as provided in section 13-120, shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day such fire hazard continues to exist after the expiration of the time limit shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, §§ 5, 11(a), 5-2-67; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Sec. 13-122. - Acceptance of rent prohibited until hazard abolished. 
(a)  Any owner of any building who shall receive notice from the fire marshal that it is a fire hazard, as provided in section 13-120, and shall fail or refuse to abolish the fire hazard within the maximum time limit found by the fire marshal, as provided in section 13-120, and shall, after the expiration of such time limit, accept payment of rent from any person as consideration for occupying such building or any portion thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). This offense shall be separate and distinct from the offense denounced in section 13-121. Each acceptance of payment of rent shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any owner of any building who has received a notice from the fire marshal that it is a fire hazard, as provided in section 13-120, and, without abolishing the fire hazard, thereafter rents any portion of the building to some person not theretofore renting or occupying same, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 11(b), (e), 5-2-67; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Sec. 13-123. - Discontinuing electrical service. 
When any fire hazard is permitted to continue in existence by the owner after receiving the notice provided for in section 13-120, and after the expiration of the time limit as determined under section 13-120, if the fire marshal shall find and determine from the facts that the danger to human life is materially increased by the electrical wiring and appliances present in the building, he shall give notice to the public utility company supplying electrical current to such building, to disconnect its service and forthwith cease supplying electrical current thereto. It shall thereupon be the duty of the chief officer of the company in active charge of its operations to cause such service to be disconnected and the supply of electrical current discontinued, immediately. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 8, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-124. - Discontinuing gas service. 
When any fire hazard is permitted to continue to exist by the owner after receiving the notice provided for in section 13-120, and after the expiration of the time limit as determined under section 13-120, if the fire marshal shall find and determine from the facts that the danger to human life is materially increased by the gas plumbing and appliances present in the building, he shall give notice to the public utility company supplying gas to such building, to disconnect its service and forthwith cease supplying gas thereto. It shall thereupon be the duty of the chief officer of the company in active charge of its operations to cause such service to be disconnected and the supply of gas discontinued, immediately. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 9, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-125. - Second placarding. 
(a)  Whenever the fire marshal shall find that a fire hazard continues to exist after the giving of notice and the expiration of the time limits provided in sections 13-120 and 13-121, he shall cause to be posted on or near the front door of such building, in as conspicuous a manner as possible, a second substantial placard upon which shall be printed in red in letters at least two and one-half (2½) inches high the words, "SECOND WARNING—FIRE HAZARD," and on which placard there shall also appear the following words: 
"THE TIME LIMIT HAS EXPIRED FOR THE CORRECTION OF THE CONDITIONS WHICH MAKE THIS BUILDING A FIRE HAZARD, AND THEY HAVE NOT BEEN CORRECTED. 
THE FURTHER OCCUPANCY OF THIS BUILDING BY ANY PERSON IS PROHIBITED BY LAW AS IT IS DANGEROUS TO LIFE. 
THIS NOTICE IS POSTED (Here the notice shall show the date and hour). ALL PERSONS ARE REQUIRED BY LAW TO VACATE SAME NOT LATER THAN FORTY-EIGHT HOURS AFTER SUCH TIME, AND ARE PROHIBITED FROM RE-ENTERING SAME UNTIL THE FIRE MARSHAL FINDS THAT THE FIRE HAZARD HAS BEEN ABOLISHED. 
FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, CALL THE FIRE MARSHAL OF THE CITY OF PASADENA." 
Such placard may contain other information deemed advisable by the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 6, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-126. - Unlawful occupancy or entry. 
After forty-eight (48) hours from the stated hour of the posting of the second placard in accord with section 13-125, as shown therein, it shall be unlawful for any person to occupy the building as living quarters or to enter or remain in same, except for short visits not exceeding thirty (30) minutes in any one day, during daylight hours, after first giving notice to the fire marshal's office of intention to enter; provided that, after first giving notice to the fire marshal and subject to his regulation, the owner may cause persons to enter the premises for the purpose of correcting the physical conditions which give rise to the hazard. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 7, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-127. - Allowing reoccupancy without correcting conditions. 
Any owner of any building who receives a notice from the fire marshal that it is a fire hazard as provided in section 13-120, and abolishes the fire hazard by causing the building to be vacated of human occupancy and thereafter reconstitutes the fire hazard by allowing or causing human occupancy to be resumed without correcting the hazardous physical condition of the building, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and each day that such reconstituted fire hazard continues to exist shall be a separate offense. No additional notice from the fire marshal shall be required in such case. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 11(c), 5-2-67; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Sec. 13-128. - Unlawful removal or defacing of placards. 
(a)  Any owner of any building who shall tear down or deface any placard posted by the fire marshal under the provisions of this article or cause the same to be done shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  Any other person who shall tear down or deface any such placard shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 11(d), 5-2-67; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Sec. 13-129. - Removal of placards after conditions remedied. 
Whenever the fire marshal finds that the physical conditions causing the fire hazard no longer exist, he shall forthwith notify the owner and remove his placard or placards. After such finding, it shall be lawful to occupy the building. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 7, 5-2-67)  
Secs. 13-130—13-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - FIRE HAZARD INSPECTION 
 
Sec. 13-141. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article, the word "owner" shall mean the owner, occupant, lessee or other person interested in any building, whether one or more, and regardless of actual interest in the building. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 14, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-142. - Committee created; general functions and composition of committee. 
There is hereby created a fire hazard inspection committee to be an agency and instrumentality of the city to aid and assist the city in the protection of the lives and property of its citizens under its Charter powers. The committee shall consist of the director of public works, the fire marshal and the director of public health. In the absence of the director of public works or at any time when he is unable to act, the assistant director of public works may act in his place. In like manner, the assistant fire marshal or any deputy fire marshal may act in the place of the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 12, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-143. - Investigation and hearing by committee—Motion of council; notice to owner. 
(a)  Whenever the city council shall receive information that any building situated within the city constitutes a serious fire hazard to life and property due to the construction of the building, the use or occupancy of it, or due to any other condition whatsoever, the city council shall, by motion, direct the fire hazard inspection committee to investigate the building, report the facts found by it, and make recommendations thereon. 
(b)  Upon the passage of such motion, the fire hazard inspection committee shall forthwith set a time, date and place for the holding of a hearing and inspection of the building. It shall give the owner a notice in writing, by United States mail, of the time, date and place of the hearing and the purpose of same. Such notice shall inform the owner that he has a right to be present at such hearing and to examine or cross-examine witnesses. Such notice shall be given to the owner at least twenty (20) days prior to the time set for the hearing. If the owner of the building is unknown, or cannot be found in the city, the fire hazard inspection committee shall cause such notice to be given by advertising same in a daily newspaper published within the city at least two (2) times prior to the date of the hearing. Such notice may be signed by any member of the fire hazard inspection committee or by the city secretary or the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 14, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-144. - Same—Conduct of hearing; inspection of building; report to council. 
The fire hazard inspection committee shall hold a hearing at the time, date and place set by it. The city attorney or one of his assistants, if requested, shall be present to advise the committee on legal matters and assist it in the examination of witnesses. During the course of the hearing, or subsequent thereto and prior to the filing of its report, the fire hazard inspection committee shall inspect the building in question. The committee shall fully determine the facts relative to such building and shall file a full report of same with the city council. Each report shall embrace, among others, the following fact findings: 
(1)  The fire district or zone in which the building is located. 
(2)  The names of any parties interested in the building as an owner, occupant, lessee, lien holder, or by virtue of any other claim, if the names of such parties can be ascertained. 
(3)  A description of the general type of the building, the construction of same, and the occupancy and use being made of it. 
(4)  The existence in such building of conditions rendering such building or the use being made thereof a serious fire hazard to life and property, setting forth the conditions in detail. 
(5)  In such report, if the fire hazard inspection committee has found facts showing that the building constitutes a serious fire hazard to life and property, the committee shall recommend to the council such measures, if any, as can be taken to remove such fire hazard and render the building safe. If the fire hazard inspection committee finds that the building constitutes a serious fire hazard to life and property and that the condition cannot be corrected, the committee shall so state in its report to the city council. A copy of the report shall be given or mailed to the owner, together with the probable time and date that the city council will consider the report. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 15, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-145. - Action of council on committee's report. 
(a)  The city council shall receive the report provided for in section 13-144 and consider the same at its first regular or special meeting thereafter or as soon as practicable. The owner shall be entitled at such meeting to be heard on the matters contained in the report and to present witnesses to the council, and shall be entitled to obtain the necessary process to summon such witnesses. The council shall also hear such other witnesses and consider such other facts as may be deemed necessary by it to arrive at proper conclusions concerning the building. 
(b)  Should the city council conclude that the facts show that the building constitutes a serious fire hazard to life and property, but that measures can be taken to remove the dangerous conditions and render the building safe, it shall specify the measures necessary to correct the dangerous conditions and shall order the owner, by ordinance, to take such measures and correct such conditions, setting forth the time in which the work is to be accomplished by him. The owner may, at his discretion, instead of complying with such order, demolish the building completely and remove same. 
(c)  If the city council should conclude that the facts show that the conditions rendering the building a serious fire hazard to life and property cannot be corrected by any measures, it shall find and declare the building to be a nuisance and shall order the owner, by ordinance, to proceed forthwith and within a specified time to demolish the building and remove same. 
(d)  A copy of the ordinance embodying the final decision and orders of the city council shall be mailed or delivered to the owner by the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 16, 5-2-67)  
Sec. 13-146. - Failure to comply with council's order. 
If the owner fails to comply with the order of the city council given pursuant to section 13-145, within the time specified in such order, and such time is not extended by the city council, the city attorney is authorized and directed to file suit in the proper court against such owner and obtain the necessary court orders and process to enforce the orders of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 67-1937, § 17, 5-2-67)  
Secs. 13-147—13-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 
 
Sec. 13-151. - Adoption. 
The city council of the City of Pasadena, Texas does hereby adopt the International Fire Code, 2015 Edition inclusive of all Appendices, as published by the International Code Council and all National Fire Protection Association current Standards, as the fire prevention code of the City of Pasadena, Texas for the control of buildings and structures as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said 2015 International Fire Code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, subject, however, to the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, set forth in section 13-152 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-62, § 1, 4-8-80; Ord. No. 90-85, § 2, 5-15-90; Ord. No. 99-175, § 1, 9-28-99; Ord. No. 2007-169, § 2, 5-15-07; Ord. No. 17-010, § 2, 1-17-17)  
Sec. 13-152. - Additions, insertions and changes. 
The articles and sections of the International Fire Code 2006 edition, as adopted and specified in section 13-151 of the Pasadena Code of Ordinances shall be amended as read as follows: 
CHAPTER 1 ADMINISTRATION 
Section 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of the City of Pasadena, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
Sections 108 Board of Appeals through Section 108.3 shall be deleted in their entirety. 
Section 109.4 Violation penalties. Any person, firm, corporation, or other entity who violates a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000). Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall constitute a separate offense. 
Section 111.4 Failure to comply. Any person, firm, corporation, or other entity who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person, firm, corporation, or other entity is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000). 
CHAPTER 5 FIRE SERVICE FEATURES 
Section 507.5.1 Where required. Where a portion of the facility or building hereafter constructed or moved into or within the jurisdiction is more than 300 feet from a hydrant on a fire apparatus access road, as measured by an approved route around the exterior of the facility or building, on-site fire hydrants and mains shall be provided where required by the fire code official and shall not exceed 100 feet from any Fire Department Connection (FDC). 
CHAPTER 9 FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS 
901.5 Where required. Fire Detection and Alarm Systems, Fire Extinguishing Systems, Fire Hydrant Systems, Fire Pump Systems, Private Fire Service Mains and all other fire protection systems and appurtenances thereto, shall be subject to acceptance test as contained in the installation standards, with all Post Indicator Valves (PIV/WPIV) to be installed above ground and have exterior access as approved by the Fire Code Official. The Fire Code Official shall be notified before any required acceptance testing. 
903.2 Where required. Approved automatic sprinkler systems in new buildings and structures shall be provided in the locations described in this section or when the gross square footage of the building or structure exceeds 10,000 square feet. 
903.2.3 An Approved automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for all Group E Day Care occupancies where the occupant load exceeds 100 persons. 
905.3 Where Required and in addition to the requirements set forth in Chapter 9 of the Fire Code, the Fire Code Official may require the installation of a Class III standpipe system in any new premises where the gross square footage of the premises exceeds 200,000 square feet and its location shall be approved by the Fire Code Official. 
912.2 Where required. Fire Department Connections (FDC) shall be installed in accordance with NFPA Standards at a remote location with all standards applicable to system design and shall comply with 912.2 through 912.7 and upon approval and acceptance by the Fire Code Official. 
APPENDICES 
Appendix A. Board of Appeals shall be deleted in its entirety. 
Appendix B. Fire-Flow Requirements for Buildings shall be adopted in its entirety. 
Appendix C. Fire Hydrant Locations and Distribution shall be adopted in its entirety. 
Appendix D. Fire Apparatus Access Roads shall be adopted in its entirety. 
Appendix E. Hazard Categories shall be adopted in its entirety. 
Section 102.3 Change of Use or Occupancy, shall be deleted in its entirety. 
Section 102.4 Application of New Building Code, shall be deleted in its entirety. 
Section 103 Department of Fire Prevention, shall be deleted in its entirety. 
(Ord. No. 80-62, § 2, 4-8-80; Ord. No. 90-85, § 3, 5-15-90; Ord. No. 99-175, § 2, 9-28-99; Ord. No. 03-210, § 2, 10-14-03; Ord. No. 2007-169, § 1, 5-15-07; Ord. No. 17-010, § 3, 1-17-17)

ARTICLE IX. - FEES 
 
Sec. 13-173. - Emergency services fees. 
The following fees shall apply to the recovery of costs associated with emergency services response to releases of hazardous substances conducted inside and outside the city limits of the City of Pasadena, Texas. 
The fire department, or its authorized agent, shall send an invoice to the "responsible party." The "responsible party" shall remit full payment of such fees immediately upon receipt for the following emergency services: 
(1)  Incident stabilization and remediation of spilled hazardous substances including but not limited to fuel products. 
a.  Response. The National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan (NCP) is required by section 105 of CERCLA of 1980, as amended by SARA of 1986, and by the Clean Water Act (CWA), as amended by the Oil Pollution Act (OPA) of 1990. The NCP is applicable to response actions taken pursuant to the authorities of CERCLA and section 311 of the CWA, as amended. Specifically, the NCP makes clear in 40 CFR Part 300.700 (Activities by Other Persons) "(b)(1) … The Mechanisms available to recover the costs of response actions under CERCLA are, in summary: (1) Section 107(a) wherein any person may receive a court award of his or her response costs, plus interest, from the party or parties found liable;" (b)(4) "Section 123, wherein a general purpose unit of local government may apply to the Fund" (Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund - OSLTF) "under 40 CFR part 310 for reimbursement of the costs of temporary emergency measures that are necessary to prevent or mitigate injury to human health or the environment associated with a release," (c)(1) "Responsible parties shall be liable for all response costs incurred by the United States government or a state or an Indian tribe not inconsistent with the NCP," and (c)(2)" Responsible parties shall be liable for necessary costs of response actions to releases of hazardous substances incurred by any other person consistent with the NCP." 
b.  Response to spilled or released hazardous substances by Emergency Services of the City of Pasadena shall be invoiced at one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00) for up to sixty (60) minutes and twenty dollars ($20.00) per minute thereafter until the incident has been stabilized and remediated. Emergency services include but are not limited to fire department, law enforcement and/or public works personnel and/or equipment utilized for site stabilization, public protective actions, traffic control, etc. 
(2)  Site control and standby for leaking or spilled hazardous substances including, but not limited to, fuel products. 
a.  Activation of public emergency notification systems. The Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA), also known as SARA Title III, was enacted in November 1986. This law provided an infrastructure at the state and local levels to plan for chemical emergencies. Facilities that have spilled hazardous substances, or that store, use, or release certain chemicals are subject to various reporting requirements. All of this information is made publicly available so that interested parties may become informed about potentially dangerous chemicals in their community. Common EPCRA topics include: Emergency planning; hazardous chemical inventory reporting; public access to chemical information; toxic chemical release reporting and the Form R; and the toxics release inventory (TRI) database. 
Under the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) of 1986, the federal government has designated several hundred chemicals as "extremely hazardous substances" based on their acute lethal toxicity. Under the law, releases of these extremely hazardous substances trigger reporting requirements to state and local authorities. Specifically, EPA requires that the owner or operator of a facility that releases an extremely hazardous substance in an amount greater than its established RQ notify the state emergency response commission and the local emergency planning committee established for the location where the incident occurs. 
There are over one hundred (100) chemicals that are designated as both a Superfund hazardous substance and an EPCRA extremely hazardous substance. In the event of a release of any of these substances, the person responsible (responsible party) for the release is required to contact all of the appropriate federal, state, and local authorities. 
b.  The "responsible party" shall also be invoiced at cost for the associated activation of the public emergency notification system and Reverse 911 for shelter in place and public information dissemination if applicable to the incident under EPCRA. 
(Ord. No. 10-148, § 1(Exh. A), 7-13-10)  
Chapter 13½ - FLOOD CONTROL AND DRAINAGE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---
