ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 13½-1—13½-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COMMISSION ON FLOOD CONTROL AND DRAINAGE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-80, §§ 1—12, adopted July 17, 1979, did not expressly amend the Code; therefore, codification as Art. II of Ch. 13½, §§ 13½-21—13½-32, has been at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference— Public works department, § 2-84 et seq. 
 
Sec. 13½-21. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created and established, within and for the city, the City of Pasadena Commission on Flood Control and Drainage, composed of ten (10) members, appointed by the mayor whose offices are hereby created and established as an advisory commission to assist and advise the mayor and city council on all matters relative to drainage and flood control as they would affect the citizens and/or property of Pasadena, Texas. The commission will be composed of the following members: The directors of public works, planning, and civil defense, three (3) citizens of the City of Pasadena, and four (4) additional individuals from Pasadena who have engineering background or experience. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 1, 7-19-79)  
Sec. 13½-22. - Appointment and terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  Seven (7) members of the commission on flood control and drainage will be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. 
(b)  The directors of planning, public works, and civil defense are hereby appointed to the commission by office and will serve until they either no longer hold their offices or until the office is deleted from the commission by act of the governing body of the city. Each new director or acting director of planning, public works, and civil defense shall automatically assume the place of his or her predecessor on the commission but will not, ipso facto, assume any office the predecessor may have held on the commission. 
(c)  Four (4) of the commissioners who are first so appointed shall be designated to serve for terms of three (3) years and the remaining commissioners shall be designated to serve for two (2) years respectively from the date of their appointment, but thereafter, commissioners shall be appointed as aforesaid for a term of office of two (2) years, unless sooner terminated. 
(d)  All vacancies in membership of the commission other than those designated members by office shall be filled by the mayor (subject to confirmation by city council) for the unexpired terms as soon as practicable after the position becomes vacant. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 2, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-23. - Members to serve without compensation. 
The members of the commission on flood control and drainage, in the performance of their official duties, shall serve without compensation for office. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 3, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-24. - Officers designated. 
The officers of the commission shall consist of a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary. The mayor is empowered to appoint appropriate ex officio members of the commission. The director of public works shall serve as the executive officer of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 4, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-25. - Election and terms of officers. 
The chairman shall be appointed by the mayor, and the vice-chairman and the secretary of the commission shall be nominated by the members of the commission in such a manner as the commission shall prescribe at its first meeting as a committee of the whole, and each officer shall be elected by a majority vote of the qualified and serving members of the commission. The terms of all elected offices shall be concurrent and limited within the terms of the officer's commission membership appointment, except that the directors of planning, public works, and civil defense shall hold no elected office for a period in excess of two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 5, 7-19-79) 
Editor's note— The city has advised that the offices of chairman and vice-chairman are appointive; that the secretary is to be nominated by the commission and that "each other" officer is elective.  
Sec. 13½-26. - Attendance at meetings. 
The commission may establish its own rules as to attendance of its members at meetings and, in furtherance of such, the commission may by a majority vote, expel any member who, in the opinion of the commission, misses an unreasonable number of meetings. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 6, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-27. - Procedure. 
The commission is hereby empowered to establish its own parliamentary procedure; provided, that such procedures shall not be in conflict with the City Charter or other provisions of law, or the following: A quorum shall consist of a majority of the entire membership of the commission; and any issue to be voted on shall be resolved by those members present. The chairman shall be entitled to vote upon any issue, but shall have no veto power. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 7, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-28. - General powers and duties. 
The commission on flood control and drainage is hereby generally authorized to work with the mayor and council to provide a long-range flood control and drainage plan for Pasadena and to make recommendations as it deems beneficial within the scope of its function and purpose aforesaid, provided that it shall undertake no task in contravention of the City of Pasadena Charter or any other law or ordinance, and its function is to be considered advisory only. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 8, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-29. - Scope of function. 
Within the general powers and duties aforesaid, the commission is specifically authorized: 
(a)  To coordinate and interact with the Harris County Flood Control District, the Corps of Engineers and with the similar commissions of sister cities, as such may be, to harmonize its efforts with the overall plan for southeast Harris County. 
(b)  To inspect various drainage and flood control facilities throughout the City of Pasadena and report its findings to mayor and council. 
(c)  To advise and recommend to mayor and council new programs, methodology and/or facilities which the commission may deem beneficial to the city's program of drainage and flood control. 
(d)  To publicize and provide information, subject to approval of the mayor and council, which is beneficial to the public in connection with drainage and flood control. 
(e)  Coordinate with the Civil Defense and other disaster relief agencies in an exchange of information for the general benefit of the populace. 
(f)  To make, and from time to time, amend and repeal bylaws subject to the approval of mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 9, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-30. - Obligation of city. 
The commission shall have no power to obligate the city in any manner whatsoever; its finances shall be administered in the same manner as any department of the city government. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 10, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-31. - Coordinator. 
An official of the city designated by the mayor shall serve as coordinator for the commission and shall prepare materials for distribution and conduct such other business of the commission as may be assigned. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 11, 7-17-79)  
Sec. 13½-32. - Finances; construction of commission's authority. 
The city council declares its purpose and intention (but does not in any way obligate itself or attempt to obligate any future city council) to, from time to time, appropriate and cause to be paid over to the commission (or upon the commission's recommendation) such sums as the council may deem proper and appropriate to aid in defraying the expenses of operation, maintenance and development. 
By virtue of this article, there shall not be vested in the commission or in the members of the commission any right, except it be subject to termination by the city by repeal or amendment of this article or other appropriate action of its governing body. 
(Ord. No. 79-80, § 12, 7-17-79)  
Chapter 14 - GARBAGE, TRASH AND RUBBISH[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, adopted February 27, 2001, deleted former §§ 14-1—14-25 in their entirety, and added new §§ 14-1—14-25 as set out herein. Former §§ 14-1—14-25 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the following: Ord. No. 67-1974, §§ 1(14-1)—1(14-18), 7-25-67; Ord. No. 67-2068, § 1, 11-21-67; Ord. No. 68-26, 2-13-68; Ord. No. 68-112, 8-6-68; Ord. No. 68-146, §§ 1, 2, 10-8-68; Ord. No. 69-146, § 1, 7-1-69; Ord. No. 69-215, §§ 1—4, 9-30-69; Ord. No. 71-159, § 1, 6-1-71; Ord. No. 71-274, § 1, 9-7-71; Ord. No. 71-370, §§ 1, 2, 12-7-71; Ord. No. 77-206, § 1, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 77-224, § 2, 11-29-77; Ord. No. 77-274, § 1, 11-29-77; Ord. o. 79-87, § 1, 7-24-79; Ord. No. 83-269, § 1, 9-27-83; Ord. No. 83-366, §§ 1—3, 12-6-83; Ord. No. 90-124, § 1, 7-24-90; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90; Ord. No. 97-138, § 1, 8-5-97; Ord. No. 99-217, § 1, 11-30-99. 
State Law reference— Accumulation and removal of garbage and trash, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4477-1, § 4. 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
Generally. All words not expressly defined shall be understood and construed in their ordinary signification. 
Commercial. Whether used as a noun, adjective or adverb, the word "commercial" refers to a business enterprise or activity, wherein gross revenue is derived from services other than the furnishing of residential accommodations. Whenever the superintendent of sanitation or the water division of the department of public works has designated a business enterprise or activity as "commercial," such designation shall be presumed correct hereunder, and if disputed, the burden shall be upon the owner or duly authorized agent to disprove it, by sworn, audited records of such business enterprise or activity. An activity or enterprise shall also be deemed "commercial," whenever the garbage, trash and rubbish collection policies under this chapter require use of sanitation container units. 
Dry kitchen refuse. The solids remaining from the preparation of food for immediate consumption, with all liquids or slop drained off, shall constitute "dry kitchen refuse." 
Freon free. Items which contained freon such as refrigerators, freezers or air conditioners must be certified by the appropriate authority as free of freon before that item can be collected. 
Kitchen garbage. "Kitchen garbage" includes dry kitchen refuse and all meat, vegetable and fruit refuse, small dead fowl, and edible domesticated animal carcasses, collectible subject to health department rules and regulations. 
Premises. The term "premises" includes business houses, boardinghouses, offices, theaters, hotels, restaurants, cafes, cafeterias, tourist camps, mobile home parks, trailer courts, apartments, apartment houses, town houses, condominiums, hospitals, medical clinics, rooming houses, schools, nursing homes, day-care nurseries, charitable and religious institutions, private residences, manufacturing plants, processing plants and the grounds upon which the same are located, vacant lots, and all other places where garbage, trash, rubbish or waste accumulates. 
Residential. Whether used as a noun, adjective or adverb, the term "residential" refers to a building, room or rooms fitted or used, in whole or in part, for human sleeping accommodations, including, but not limited to, except as otherwise expressly provided for herein, residential subdivision houses, garage apartments, and duplex, triplex and quadplex residential apartments. It comprehends household and household activity. 
Rubbish or household rubbish. "Rubbish" or "household rubbish" means tin cans, paper, empty bottles or glass containers of not more than five-gallon capacity, fragmented glass, scraps of iron or other metal, wire, used plastic articles, vacuum cleaning lint, empty dry-food, drug and notion boxes and like waste products of normal household activity able to be deposited in containers in accordance with this chapter. 
Sanitation container unit. The term "sanitation container unit" means a wood or metal, or combination thereof, box or container, fixed with a lid and equipped for handling by city sanitation vehicles, owned by the city and furnished to a commercial customer for sanitary use at fees prescribed in this chapter. 
Trash. The word "trash" means containered or non-containered used rubber articles, except automotive tires, pieces of wood, rope, feathers, fiberboard containers, empty used boxes, barrels and crates, weeds, grass and trimmings from shrubs. 
White goods. Freon-free appliances and other metals that are recyclable including, but not limited to, refrigerators, freezers, stoves, and dishwashers. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-2. - Office of superintendent of sanitation created; general duties of superintendent. 
There is hereby created the office of the superintendent of sanitation. It shall be the duty of the superintendent to direct the operations of city sanitation, including the collection, removal and disposal of garbage, rubbish and trash within the city, and oversee the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-3. - Disposal generally. 
It shall be the duty of every person in charge of inhabited premises within the city to prepare the garbage, trash and rubbish from such premises and timely place the same for collection by the city in accordance with the terms and conditions of the chapter; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to persons removing from premises garbage, trash and rubbish under a contract issued by the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-4. - Disposable containers required. 
(a)  The City of Pasadena shall provide each residential premises with sufficient garbage bags for biweekly collection for the disposal of accumulated dry kitchen refuse, kitchen garbage and rubbish. Cardboard boxes and other disposal containers may be used in addition to the bags, provided that they are tightly sealed and disposable. No containers of any shape, size or form will be emptied and returned to the curb. Containers having a total loaded weight in excess of fifty (50) pounds will not be handled by city crews. 
(b)  All loose trash and rubbish accumulations shall be deposited in receptacles as specified in subsection (a) above, and set out for collection. No item or trash subject to being blown by winds from its place of deposit for collection on the premises shall be deposited loose on the premises, but shall be placed in the required receptacle. 
(c)  White goods may be collected separately in a manner to be prescribed by the superintendent of sanitation. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the above, or section 14-9 regarding the number of collections per week, the city may, at its discretion, purchase and furnish containers other than bags for garbage service customers and, further, may adjust the numbers and times of weekly collections. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01; Ord. No. 05-233, § 2, 9-20-05; Ord. No. 10-215, § 1, 10-12-10)  
Sec. 14-5. - Maintenance of containers; defective cans and containers not to be handled by city personnel. 
(a)  Garbage sacks and other disposable containers used for dry kitchen refuse, kitchen garbage and rubbish shall be maintained in sanitary condition and closed tightly when containing any dry kitchen refuse, kitchen garbage and/or rubbish. 
(b)  Garbage cans or other nondisposable containers and containers which are broken, split or open, or which are capable of causing injury to city handling personnel, shall not be touched by city personnel or the contents of such cans or receptacles collected. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-6. - Placement of containers for city collectors. 
Garbage sacks and other disposable containers to be collected by city personnel shall be placed inside the curb line or drain ditch line of the street near the front property line of the premises unless otherwise instructed by the superintendent of sanitation, no later than 7:30 a.m. on those days designated from time to time by the superintendent of sanitation for residential collections. Garbage sacks and other disposable containers to be collected by city personnel shall not be placed at such location prior to 9:00 p.m. the evening before such pickup day. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-7. - Sacks, other containers and city sanitation container units; pilfering and tampering. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with garbage sacks, other containers, trash receptacles or city sanitation container units or to pilfer or scatter the contents thereof in any city street, alley or easement. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-8. - Preparation of tree limbs and shrubbery for collection. 
(a)  Accumulations of tree limbs or shrubbery shall be stacked neatly in a location easily accessible to city crews for removal. 
(b)  Excluding tree limbs, no single item of trash shall exceed four (4) feet in length and two (2) feet in diameter. 
(c)  Tree limbs and trunks may not exceed one (1) foot in diameter and ten (10) feet long. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-9. - City's collection schedule; integration of commercial and residential routes. 
(a)  Every residential user of the city's garbage and rubbish collection service shall normally receive two (2) collections each week according to a standard schedule determined by the superintendent of sanitation. Garbage and household rubbish will be collected at the same time. Separate trash and white goods collections will be made according to a schedule determined by the superintendent of sanitation. Special annual or semiannual collections of junk, trash or rubbish may be made as determined by the city council. No extra fee will be charged for the regularly scheduled trash collection. 
(b)  Garbage, rubbish and trash collection service to commercial users shall be limited to the terms and provisions of the "City of Pasadena Commercial Refuse Disposal Contract" approved by the city council. 
(c)  Residential and commercial services may be operated on integrated routes, if the superintendent of sanitation certifies such integration to be economical and not in violation of this chapter, but no person is entitled as a matter of right to commercial service on a residential route or to residential service on a commercial route. 
(d)  Hereafter the city will not use its collection trucks on private streets to collect garbage, trash and rubbish as set out herein, except for those private streets upon which it now collects from single-family privately-owned residences and such residence and its lot is individually and privately owned. 
(e)  The superintendent will as soon as possible identify and notify those areas where the service will be discontinued. He will then notify the authorized commercial collectors of garbage, trash and rubbish of the intended change in service and discontinue the city service as soon as the authorized commercial collectors assume this service. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-10. - Charges for collection by city—Rates prescribed. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Commercial shall mean all premises from which garbage, refuse and trash are collected except those defined as "residential" in (2) below, and shall specifically, but not limited to, include mobile home parks, apartments, townhouses and condominiums. 
(2)  Residential shall mean a single-family dwelling and/or household. 
(b)  Charges. 
(1)  There shall be charged, assessed and collected, a monthly service charge for collection and disposal by the city of residential garbage, refuse and trash in the amount of twenty-four dollars and fifty cents ($24.50) per single residence. 
(2)  For those residential customers sixty-five (65) years of age or over the rate shall be fifteen dollars and thirty cents ($15.30) per single residence. 
(3)  There shall be charged, assessed and collected a monthly service charge for collection and disposal of commercial garbage, refuse and trash, by private haulers licensed under the provisions of the "City of Pasadena Commercial Refuse Disposal Contract" approved by the city council. 
(c)  Annual adjustment of water and sewer rates. The rates to which this section applies shall be adjusted according to this provision and automatically increased each year on October 1 using the U.S. Consumer Price Index (CPI) for all Urban Consumers for the Houston-Galveston-Brazoria Texas Metropolitan Area published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The year over year percent change in the April index will be issued as the basis for this charge. If there is a decrease in the CPI, or if there is no increase in the period measured, the rates then existing shall remain unchanged. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01; Ord. No. 05-233, § 2, 9-20-05; Ord. No. 10-215, § 2, 10-12-10; Ord. No. 18-045, § 2, 4-3-18)  
Sec. 14-11. - Billing and collection. 
(a)  The water division of the department of public works shall be responsible for the billing and collection of the charges prescribed by section 14-10(b)(1). Such charges shall be paid to the water division each month, with the water and sewer charges, if either or both such city services are had. Unless otherwise expressly provided by written agreement between the person to be billed and the city, which agreement shall be approved by the superintendent of sanitation and filed with the water division, such charges shall be assessed against the person to whom the city is furnishing water and in whose name a water meter is registered. The amount of the monthly sanitation charge shall be mailed to such person by the water division on the same card with the statement of charges for the monthly water or sewer services. 
(b)  In the event any person accepts city sanitation service and is not being served by either the water or sewer systems of the city, and no specially approved written agreement for billing has been filed with the water division, then the sanitation charges shall be assessed and billed in the name of the person who requests or accepts such service. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-12. - Assessment against multiple-family dwellings and motels and hotels. 
(a)  Multiple-family dwellings of more than four (4) units, including but not limited to apartment house and town house projects and condominiums, shall be assessed, for sanitation service purposes, as individual residences on a basis of one hundred (100) per cent occupancy. If the owner desires containerized service, he shall pay the service charge prescribed in section 14-10 (b)(2), without regard to the number of units occupied. 
(b)  All motels and hotels shall be assessed for city commercial sanitation services in accordance with section 14-10(b)(2). 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-13. - Failure to pay. 
(a)  If the charges billed under section 14-11 are not paid by the twelfth day of the month following that in which the service was rendered, the sanitation service for that customer shall be discontinued and shall not be resumed until all such charges have been paid in full. 
(b)  No garbage, rubbish or trash shall be collected by the city from any vacant lot or from premises occupied by any vacant house or building, unless all city water, garbage, rubbish and trash charges accrued therefor are fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-14. - Duty of water division and superintendent of sanitation with regard to new commercial accounts. 
If a question should arise whether an account is to be classified as commercial or residential, it shall be the duty of the superintendent of sanitation to determine the classification of service requested and notify the water billing division of the classification. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-15. - City not to collect if chapter violated. 
The city shall not collect kitchen garbage, rubbish, trash or tree limbs where the same are not prepared for collection and placed in accordance with this chapter. The city's failure to collect shall not excuse the violation of any provision of this chapter or of any other city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-16. - Disposal of heavy or dangerous accumulations. 
The city sanitation service shall not collect dangerous accumulations of explosives, fireworks, ammunition, bottled acids, corrosive chemicals, insecticides, paint, oil or other hydrocarbon accumulations, heavy or dangerous accumulations of concrete, dirt, sand, tree stumps, creosote-treated timber, roofing material, automotive bodies or other accumulations deemed dangerous by the sanitation department, but same such shall be disposed of by the resident/owner. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-17. - Unlawful collection or transportation generally. 
No person, except a duly authorized agent and employee of the City of Pasadena or a person hauling and transporting his own garbage, rubbish or trash, or a private hauler holding a contract with the City of Pasadena, shall collect, haul, transport or empty garbage or trash receptacles or convey or transport garbage, rubbish or trash on the streets, alleys or easements of the city.  
Sec. 14-18. - Reserved.  
Sec. 14-19. - Unlawful deposits generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, unload, discharge, or in any manner place or cause to be placed any garbage, trash or other waste materials of any kind or description whatsoever on any lot, tract or parcel of land located within the city limits, except at such places as permitted by the State of Texas for garbage disposal. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-20. - Spilling from vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, or for any person to permit any employee, agent, servant, or other person under his general supervision or control, to drive any vehicle carrying, hauling or transporting trash, dirt or debris, wastepaper, rags, rubbish, refuse, garbage, manure, slop, ashes or other loose materials of a similar nature, on the public streets and alleys of the city, unless such vehicle is loaded, equipped and operated in such a manner as to prevent such materials from falling out of, spilling from or blowing out of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-21. - Reserved.  
Sec. 14-22. - Reserved.  
Sec. 14-23. - Reserved.  
Sec. 14-24. - Restrictions on placement, use or operation of solid waste facilities near private residences. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, unless the context requires a different definition: 
(1)  City means City of Pasadena, Texas. 
(2)  Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic solid waste under aerobic conditions. 
(3)  Disposal means the discharge, deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking, or placing of any solid waste or hazardous waste (whether containered or non-containered) into or on any land or water so that such solid waste or hazardous waste or any constituent thereof may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including groundwaters. 
(4)  Garbage means solid waste consisting of putrescible animal and vegetable waste materials resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and consumption of food, including waste materials from markets, storage facilities, handling, and sale of produce and other food products. 
(5)  Hazardous waste means any solid waste identified or listed as a hazardous waste by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) pursuant to the federal Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901 et seq., as amended. 
(6)  Industrial solid waste means solid waste resulting from or incidental to any process of industry or manufacturing, or mining or agricultural operations. 
(7)  Municipal solid waste means solid waste resulting from or incidental to municipal, community, commercial, institutional, and recreational activities, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and all other solid waste other than industrial solid waste. 
(8)  Person means individual, corporation, organization, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, partnership, association, or any other legal entity. 
(9)  Private residence means any structure designed or intended for human occupancy and which has actually been occupied for a continuous period of ninety (90) days within two (2) years of commencement of operation of the solid waste facility. 
(10)  Processing means the extraction of materials, transfer, volume reduction, conversion to energy, or other separation and preparation of solid waste for reuse or disposal, including the treatment or neutralization of hazardous waste, designed to change the physical, chemical, or biological character or composition of any hazardous waste so as to neutralize such waste, or so as to recover energy or material from the waste, or so as to render such waste nonhazardous, or less hazardous, safer to transport, store, or dispose of, or amenable for recovery, amenable for storage, or reduced in volume. Unless the state agency determines that regulation of such activity under the Solid Waste Disposal Act is necessary to protect human health or the environment, the definition of "processing" does not include activities relating to those materials exempted by the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the Federal Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901, et seq., as amended. 
(11)  Radioactive waste means that waste which requires specific licensing under Chapter 72, Acts of the 57th Legislature, Regular Session, 1961, as amended (Article 4590f, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes), and the rules adopted by the Texas Board of Health under that law. 
(12)  Rubbish means nonputrescible solid waste (excluding ashes), consisting of both combustible and noncombustible waste materials; combustible rubbish includes paper, rags, cartons, wood, excelsior, furniture, rubber, plastics, yard trimmings, leaves, and similar materials; noncombustible rubbish includes glass, crockery, tin cans, aluminum cans, metal furniture, and like materials which will not burn at ordinary incinerator temperatures (sixteen hundred (1600) degrees Fahrenheit to eighteen hundred (1800) degrees Fahrenheit). 
(13)  Sanitary landfill means a controlled area of land upon which solid waste is disposed of in accordance with standards, rules, or orders established by the TNRCC. 
(14)  Sludge means any solid, semisolid, or liquid waste generated from a municipal, commercial, or industrial wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility exclusive of the treated effluent from a wastewater treatment plant. 
(15)  Solid waste means any garbage, refuse, sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant or air pollution control facility, and other discarded material, including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, municipal, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations, and from community and institutional activities, but does not include: (i) solid or dissolved material in domestic sewage, or solid or dissolved material in irrigation return flows, or industrial discharges subject to regulation by permit issued pursuant to Chapter 26, Water Code; (ii) soil, dirt, rock, sand and other natural or man-made inert solid materials used to fill land if the object of the fill is to make the land suitable for the construction of surface improvements; or (iii) waste materials which result from activities associated with the exploration, development, or production of oil or gas and are subject to control by the Texas Railroad Commission. 
(16)  Solid waste facility means all contiguous land, structures, other appurtenances, and improvements on the land, used for processing, storing, or disposing of solid waste. A facility may be publicly or privately owned and consist of several processing, storage, or disposal operational units; e.g., one (1) or more landfills, surface impoundments, or combinations of them. 
(17)  Solid waste technician means an individual who is trained in the practical aspects of the design, operation, and maintenance of a solid waste facility in accordance with standards, rules, or orders established by TNRCC. 
(18)  Storage means the holding of solid waste for a temporary period, at the end of which the solid waste is processed, disposed of, or stored elsewhere. 
(b)  Location. 
(1)  No person shall establish, use, or operate a solid waste facility within the city which is within one thousand (1,000) feet of a private residence. 
(2)  The measurement of the one thousand (1,000) feet distance prescribed by subsection (b)(1) hereof shall be straight line distance from the point of the solid waste facility nearest the private residence to the point on the private residence nearest the solid waste facility. 
(c)  Defense to prosecution. It shall be a defense to prosecution under this section that the solid waste facility: 
(1)  Was in existence at the time the city was incorporated or at the time the city annexed the area where it is located. 
(2)  Is operated in substantial compliance with all applicable state and county regulations. 
(d)  Applicability. The provisions of this section shall be applicable to all waste facilities permitted by the state after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derived. 
(e)  Penalty. It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor to violate any provision or requirement hereof and any person convicted of such violation shall be fined in a sum not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day that a violation continues or occurs shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Sec. 14-25. - Penalty for violations of chapter. 
Any person convicted for a violation of any provision, restriction, requirement or prohibition of this chapter, for which no specific penalty is provided, shall be fined in a sum of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) and not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 01-37, § 1, 2-27-01)  
Chapter 15 - HEALTH[1]

Cross reference— Ambulances, Ch. 4; maintenance of premises where livestock and fowl are kept, §§ 6-1, 6-9, 6-11; rabies inoculation for dogs and cats, § 6-38; buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 9; buildings with conditions detrimental to health declared to be dangerous buildings, § 9-151; heating, air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration code, Ch. 16; protection of used bedding, clothing, etc., § 17-69; health provisions relative to massage establishments, Ch. 19; plumbing, Ch. 29; swimming pools, Ch. 33; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 37.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 15-1. - Board of health—Created; composition; appointment of members. 
There is hereby created a board of health for the city, which board shall be appointed annually by the mayor with the consent of the city council and shall consist of the following five (5) members whose terms of office shall consist of one (1) year: A licensed physician, a licensed veterinarian, a representative of the Pasadena Independent School District, a representative of the hospitals in the city and a representative of the food establishment owners in the city. The physician member shall be the chairman of the board of health. The director of public health shall be an ex officio member, without vote, of the board of health. 
(Code 1964, § 15-1; Ord. No. 82-161, § 1, 7-20-82; Ord. No. 86-32, § 1, 3-4-86)  
Sec. 15-2. - Same—Subcommittees created. 
There shall be two (2) subcommittees to the board of health appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. 
(1)  The subcommittee for the humane department shall consist of the following three (3) members: The veterinarian who sits on the board of health, the chief humane officer for the city and a representative of an animal welfare organization. The veterinarian member of the subcommittee shall act as chairman. 
(2)  [Emergency ambulance consultant subcommittee:] 
(a)  The emergency ambulance consultant subcommittee shall consist of the following members: 
1.  The chairperson of the board of health who will serve as the chairperson of this subcommittee and shall receive the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each monthly meeting actually attended by said chairperson. 
2.  Four (4) licensed physicians appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council for one year terms. Of the four (4), one physician shall be appointed from each of the following hospitals and based on the recommendations given by the hospital administrators: Pasadena Bayshore Hospital, Pasadena General Hospital, Beltway Community Hospital, and Humana Hospital Southmore. As compensation for service thereon these four (4) physicians shall receive the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each monthly meeting actually attended by said appointed physician. If such physician is unavailable for a given meeting, the respective hospital may send a representative that will not be compensated. Three (3) consecutive absences from monthly meetings constitutes a resignation from the subcommittee. 
3.  The following will serve as ex-officio members: 
The Director of the City of Pasadena Health Department; 
The paramedic supervisor; and 
The medical director of the ambulance company performing emergency service. 
(b)  The functions of this subcommittee shall include the following: 
1.  A general review of the activities and quality of health care provided by the ambulance company performing emergency medical services. This shall include approval of the ambulance company's protocols; and 
2.  Recommendations to the city council regarding areas of general concern in connection with the quality of care provided. 
(Code 1964, § 15-2; Ord. No. 82-161, § 1, 7-20-82; Ord. No. 86-261, § 1, 12-16-86)  
Sec. 15-3. - Same—Meetings; quorum. 
The board of health shall meet in regular attendance at least one time per quarter, three (3) members constituting a quorum. Subcommittees shall meet as often as necessary as determined by the chairman or the board of health, three (3) members constituting a quorum. 
(Code 1964, § 15-3; Ord. No. 82-161, § 1, 7-20-82)  
Sec. 15-4. - Same—General powers and duties. 
The duties of the board of health will be to set policy and effect general regulations of the health department. The board of health shall have supervision of the enforcement of this chapter and all other health and sanitary ordinances of the city. The board of health shall have general powers over all matters pertaining to sanitary conditions in the city and to the health of its inhabitants. 
(Code 1964, § 15-4) 
Cross reference— Authority of board of health to promulgate rules and regulations governing public swimming pools, § 33-20.  
Sec. 15-5. - Same—Powers and duties of chairman. 
The duties of the chairman of the board of health shall be to preside at the meetings of the board, select committees, and work with the other members of the board toward the betterment of the department of health for the benefit of the people of the city. The chairman shall have the same voting rights as other members of the board. 
(Code 1964, § 15-5)  
Sec. 15-6. - Health department and health officer. 
There is hereby created a health department, the officers and employees of which are charged with the duty of enforcing all the laws and ordinances relating to health and such other duties as are now or may hereafter be placed upon them by the city council or the board of health. The mayor shall appoint, with the consent of city council, a physician who will be the city health officer. The health officer of the city shall have the duties and powers granted by state laws and city ordinances. 
(Code 1964, § 15-6; Ord. No. 82-161, § 1, 7-20-82)  
Sec. 15-7. - Director of public health. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of the director of public health, and such officer is charged with the responsibility of supervising the activities of the health department and its employees. The director of public health shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council, and shall carry out the general duties of the health department in accordance with the policies and regulations promulgated by the board of health and the city council, and he shall have the powers conferred upon him in this chapter and other ordinances. He shall have the power to supervise all inspections provided for in this chapter. 
(b)  The director of public health shall act in an advisory capacity to any city department, office or employee concerned with the care, treatment or welfare of animals and shall, when he deems it necessary, render aid and assistance in all matters which may improve the condition of animals in the city. [2] He shall cooperate with all county, state and federal agencies in improving the health and sanitary conditions of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 15-7; Ord. No. 67-2051, 10-24-67) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Animals generally, Ch. 6. 
 
Sec. 15-8. - Interference with enforcement of chapter. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the chief of police, or any of his subordinates, the health officer, the director of public health, or any health inspector or health employee from entering into any building or enclosure or upon any premises, for the purpose of performing and executing any of the powers and duties conferred upon such officers, or either of them, by this chapter, or to resist any of such officers or employees in the execution of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 15-8)  
Sec. 15-9. - Penalty for violations of chapter. 
Any person convicted for a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be fined in a sum not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 1635, § 3, 6-9-64; Ord. No. 90-128, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-90)  
Secs. 15-10—15-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS 
 
Sec. 15-21. - Definitions. 
The following terms shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section when used in this article: 
Commissary means a catering establishment, restaurant, or any other place in which food, containers, or supplies are kept, handled, prepared, packaged or stored. 
Farm produce shall mean and include vegetables, fruits, nuts, berries, and melons in their natural state, but shall not include food or food stuffs processed or manufactured from such named items. 
Food establishments shall include any premises, restaurant, soda fountain, cafe, diner, grocery store, fruit stand, vegetable stand, bakery, abattoir, meat processing or packing plant, dairy, ice cream parlor, and any other place where food or drink is sold or offered for sale, processed, stored, prepared or otherwise handled for sale or distribution within the city. Such term shall include any vehicle or mobile unit, shed, stand, building or structure used for the purposes of selling, distribution, processing, preparing or otherwise handling food or drink. This term shall also include frozen desserts retail preparation establishments, mobile food service units, mobile frozen dessert units, prepackaged food establishments, supermarkets, and temporary food establishments. 
Frozen desserts means any of the following: ice cream, ice milk, fruit sherbet, water ice, non-fruit sherbet, non-fruit water ice, frozen dietary dairy desserts, frozen yogurt, quiescently frozen confection, quiescently frozen dairy confection, mellorine, lorine, parevine, freezer-made milk shake, freezer-made shake, or non-dairy frozen dessert. The term includes the mix used in the freezing of one of those frozen desserts. 
Frozen desserts retail preparation establishment shall mean any food establishment where frozen dessert mixes are frozen or partially frozen and dispensed from freezing cylinder for retail sale or distribution. Permits for such establishments will be required for each freezing cylinder. 
Mobile food service unit means a vehicle-mounted food service establishment designed to be readily movable which does not serve frozen dessert products. 
Mobile frozen dessert unit means a vehicle-mounted food service establishment designed for the purpose of selling or dispensing refrigerated frozen dessert products that are prepackaged, fully wrapped, enclosed and contained in individual wrappers or containers. 
Person in charge means the individual present in a food service establishment who is the apparent supervisor of the food service establishment at the time of inspection. If no individual is the apparent supervisor, then any employee present is the person in charge. 
Prepackaged food establishment means any establishment where food and food products that are fully wrapped and contained in individual wrappers or containers are offered for sale to the ultimate consumer and intended for off-premise consumption. 
Prepackaged food shall mean food or beverage products that are packaged by an approved manufacturer for retail sale to the public without any further processing. 
Supermarket shall mean a self-service retail market where food and food products are offered to the consumer and intended for off-premise consumption and contains two (2) or more of the following departments: bakery, delicatessen, meat, produce, seafood, snack bar (on-premise consumption). 
Temporary food establishment shall mean any food establishment that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of not more than fourteen (14) consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration. 
(Code 1964, § 15-16; Ord. No. 90-9, § 1, 1-30-90)  
Sec. 15-22. - Permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, operate, or maintain any food establishment as defined by this article within the city unless a permit for that establishment has been issued by the health department. 
(b)  All food establishments shall be inspected and approved by all city departments necessary to obtaining a certificate of occupancy including, but not limited to, fire, health, fire marshal, permit, and sign administration. A certificate of occupancy must be obtained for the placement and operation of such establishments. Provided, however, mobile frozen dessert units shall not be required to obtain a certificate of occupancy. 
(c)  Food establishments fixed at a particular location for more than twenty-four (24) hours shall conform to all building, plumbing, electrical codes and city ordinances including, but not limited to, requirement of paved parking, grease traps, sanitary sewer connections, restroom facilities, and connection to city water supply. Such establishments shall be required to obtain a certificate of occupancy. As used herein, the word "fixed" shall apply to all classes of food establishments without regard to their mobile capability and shall include all types of vehicles and structures whether moved by wheels or otherwise. Such establishments shall further be limited to operating for no more than fourteen (14) consecutive days at said location. 
(d)  There shall be seven (7) classes of food establishment permits issued by the director of public health or his designee(s) according to the type of establishment permitted: a farm produce permit, a food establishment permit, a frozen dessert retail preparation permit, a mobile food unit permit, a mobile frozen dessert unit permit, a prepackaged food establishment permit and a temporary food establishment permit. 
(e)  No more than two (2) temporary food establishment permits or two (2) farm produce permits, each valid for fourteen (14) consecutive days only, will be issued to any temporary food establishment per calendar year. This limitation shall not apply to temporary food establishments operating at city or community sponsored events. 
(Code 1964, § 15-17; Ord. No. 81-228, § 1, 12-1-81; Ord. No. 85-210, § 1, 10-29-85; Ord. No. 90-9, § 1, 1-30-90; Ord. No. 01-64, § 1, 4-4-01)  
Sec. 15-22.1. - Applications. 
Application for all original or renewal permit or permits shall be made on a city health department form provided for that purpose and shall be filed with the director of public health or his designee(s). No such permit shall be issued unless the director of public health or his authorized designee(s) determines that the food establishment is constructed, operated and maintained in compliance with all applicable city ordinances and state and federal laws and regulations. All permits issued shall remain the property of the city and shall be displayed in public view when the food establishment is open for business. 
Renewal applications received by the city health department after the expiration date of the permit to be renewed shall be charged an additional twenty-five dollar ($25.00) late fee. 
Renewal applications received by the department not in completed form or with insufficient fonds to cover the required permit tees shall be returned to the applicant. The applicant shall resubmit the application in completed form with all applicable fees. There shall be an additional late fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) imposed for all incomplete or insufficient fund applications. 
Such late fees are imposed to help defray the additional administrative costs related to late or incomplete applications and shall not be considered to be a civil or criminal penalty. 
(Ord. No. 90-9, § 2, 1-30-90)  
Sec. 15-22.2. - Lost permits. 
A food establishment permittee who has lost a valid permit may obtain a replacement permit from the city health department for a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. 90-9, § 2, 1-30-90; Ord. No. 94-1, § 5, 1-11-94)  
Sec. 15-22.3. - Permit fees. 
(a)  All food establishments in the city are required to obtain the proper permit or permits for such establishments. Such fees are set forth as follows: 
(1)  Farm produce permit, per year ..... $75.00 
(2)  Food establishment permit (other than supermarket), per year ..... 150.00 
(3)  Supermarket food establishment permit, per year: 
1—9 employees ..... 200.00 
10—25 employees ..... 250.00 
26—50 employees ..... 375.00 
51—99 employees ..... 500.00 
100 or more employees ..... 700.00 
(4)  Frozen dessert retail preparation permit, per freezing cylinder, per year ..... 100.00 
(5)  Mobile food service unit permit, per year ..... 100.00 
(6)  Mobile frozen dessert unit permit, per year ..... 100.00 
(7)  Prepackaged food establishment permit, per year ..... 100.00 
(8)  Temporary food establishment permit, per event for ten (10) days or $20.00 per day, whichever is less, plus a fifteen-dollar registration fee. ..... 75.00 
(b)  A frozen dessert retail preparation permit is required, in addition to a food establishment permit, when frozen dessert mixes are frozen or partially frozen and dispensed from a freezing cylinder for retail sale or distribution. 
(c)  A mobile food service unit permit or a mobile frozen dessert unit permit is required for each mobile unit operating within the city in addition to the food establishment permit required by the jurisdiction in which the commissary or manufacturing plant providing the merchandise for these units lies. Proof of such permit will be required upon application for either of these permits. 
(d)  Those food establishments operating as nonprofit organizations or as part of a nonprofit organization shall be required to obtain the proper food establishment permit(s); however, no permit fee will be required of such organization. 
(e)  All permits shall expire on the fifteenth day of February next after their issuance. 
(f)  In the event that a food establishment permit, a supermarket food establishment permit, a frozen dessert retail preparation permit, or a prepackaged food establishment permit is issued after February 15, the permit fee shall be prorated. For a food establishment permit, a frozen dessert retail preparation permit, or a prepackaged food establishment permit, the prorated fee shall be twelve dollars ($12.00) per month for every month or portion of a month left. For a supermarket food establishment permit, the prorated fee shall be the permit fee divided by twelve (12) months rounded to the nearest dollar for every month or portion of a month left. However, the minimum prorated fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). Establishments found operating without a permit shall pay the full permitting fee. 
(Ord. No. 90-9, § 2, 1-30-90; Ord. No. 92-4, § 1, 1-14-92; Ord. No. 94-1, § 5, 1-11-94)  
Sec. 15-22.4. - Penalty clause. 
Any person who as an owner or a person in charge intentionally or knowingly violates any of the provisions contained in the article shall be guilty of a Class "C" misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not exceeding two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each offense. Each day in which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 90-9, § 2, 1-30-90; Ord. No. 02-80, § 1, 3-12-02)  
Sec. 15-23. - Employees to be free from disease. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any food establishment to work, employ or keep in his employ, or permit to work in or about any such place, whether employed or not, any person who is infected with or affected by any infectious or contagious disease. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to work in or about any food establishment when he is so infected or affected. 
(Code 1964, § 15-19)  
Sec. 15-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-82, § 1, adopted July 17, 1979, repealed § 15-24, which required health cards for employees of food establishments, derived from Code 1964, § 15-20.  
Sec. 15-25. - U.S. Public Health Service's "Food Code" adopted and incorporated by reference. 
(a)  The standards for, inspection of, and enforcement of the provisions of this article for all food handling establishments located in the City of Pasadena shall be in compliance with the provisions of the latest edition of the "Food Code" of the U. S. Public Health Service. A copy of the "Food Code" will be in the office of the Department of Health of the City of Pasadena for public inspection. 
(b)  The "Food Code" is adopted as the regulations for food handling establishments by the City of Pasadena just as if it were copied herein verbatim. 
(c)  The State of Texas also publishes regulations for food handling services and such standards are also adopted by the City; however, the standard of the "Food Code" shall be followed unless and except the director of public health for the City of Pasadena shall in writing designate some specific provision of the state code as controlling. 
(d)  The state regulations as they now exist or as they may from time to time be altered, amended, supplemented or changed in the future are adopted by the City of Pasadena and a copy of such regulations if designated as provided shall be on file with the department of health of the City of Pasadena. 
(e)  The regulatory authority referred to in the "Food Code" shall be interpreted to mean the Health Department of the City of Pasadena. 
(Code 1964, § 15-21; Ord. No. 1635, § 1, 6-9-64; Ord. No. 86-34, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 94-188, § 1, 9-27-94; Ord. No. 98-78, § 1, 5-19-98)  
Sec. 15-26. - Retail and wholesale food store sanitation, examination and condemnation of food or drink. 
(a)  Food or drink may be examined or sampled by the regulatory authority as often as he deems necessary for enforcement of this section. The regulatory authority may, upon written notice to the owner, the permit holder or person in charge specifying with particularity the reasons therefor, place a hold order on any food or drink which it believes is in violation of this section or any state or federal law. The regulatory authority shall tag, label, or otherwise identify any food or drink subject to the hold order. No food or drink subject to a hold order shall be used, served, or moved from the establishment. The regulatory authority shall permit storage of the food or drink under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in which case immediate destruction shall be ordered and accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request for hearing may be filed with the regulatory authority within ten (10) days and that if no hearing is requested the food or drink shall be destroyed. A hearing shall be held if so requested, and on the basis of evidence produced at that hearing, the hold order may be vacated, or the owner or permit holder or person in charge of the food or drink may be directed by written order to destroy such food or drink or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this section to display, give sell or offer for sale any food or drink which is in part or whole mislabeled, adulterated, contaminated, spoiled or whose package or container has been dented, punctured, or otherwise damaged to an extent where its contents may have been exposed to possible contamination. 
(c)  Dates placed on containers or packages by the manufacturer, packer, repacker, wholesaler or retailer shall not be removed, covered or concealed. 
(d)  Food determined to be in violation of this section shall not be returned to inventory for sale without prior written approval of the regulatory authority. Destruction of food determined to be unfit for human consumption will be accomplished under the supervision of the regulatory authority. 
(e)  Food determined to be in violation of this section shall not be returned to inventory for sale without prior written approval of the regulatory authority. Destruction of food determined to be unfit for human consumption will be accomplished under the supervisions of the regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 86-36, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 14-190, § 2, 11-4-14)  
Secs. 15-27—15-36. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MEAT 
 
Sec. 15-37. - State rules and regulations adopted. 
The rules and regulations and standards for the inspection of meat, meat products, and meat food products, promulgated by the Commissioner of Health of the State of Texas, under authority of article 4418d, Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, as approved by the State Board of Health, as authorized by article 4476-3, Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, dated April, 1959, as amended by amendments dated December 14, 1959, and all future amendments made thereto, are hereby in all things adopted and made a part of this article as if set forth in full herein, and the provisions, standards, rules and regulations contained therein are made mandatory requirements for the inspection and labeling of meat and meat food products produced, sold or offered for sale within the limits of the city with the "Texas State Approved Meat for Human Food" label thereon. Any establishment desiring to sell or offer for sale meat, meat products and meat food products in the city containing thereon the "Texas State Approved Meat for Human Food" label on such meat, meat products and meat food products shall be governed by the specifications and regulations promulgated by the state commissioner of health as approved by the state board of health adopted herein, and all requirements specified therein shall be complied with. 
(Ord. No. 1635, § 2, 6-9-64)  
Sec. 15-38. - Permit for abattoirs. 
No person shall construct or establish any abattoir or other place for the slaughter of animals within the city without first obtaining a permit from the city council. No such permit shall be issued unless plans and specifications are submitted showing that such abattoir or other slaughtering place will be constructed, operated and maintained in accord with all applicable city ordinances and state and federal laws, rules and regulations. The permit required by this section shall be in addition to the permit required by section 15-22. 
(Code 1964, § 15-18)  
Sec. 15-39. - Meat to be from animals slaughtered at approved abattoir. 
No meat from any animal shall be sold or offered for sale for human consumption in the city, unless such animal shall have been slaughtered in an abattoir approved by the State Department of Health or the United States government. 
(Code 1964, § 15-33; Ord. No. 1874, § 1, 10-25-66)  
Sec. 15-40. - Approval of wholesale processing or storage establishments. 
No person shall operate a wholesale establishment for the processing or storage of meat or meat food products, unless the establishment has been approved by the state department of health or the United States government. 
(Ord. No. 67-1965, § 1, 6-20-67)  
Sec. 15-41. - Meat must be stamped. 
All meat or meat food products used for food or sold for food in the city must carry the stamp of approval of the State Department of Health, or of an establishment that is Texas State approved, or of the United States government. 
(Code 1964, § 15-34; Ord. No. 1874, § 2, 10-25-66)  
Sec. 15-42. - Diseased animals and meat therefrom not to be brought into or sold in city. 
No person shall bring within the city or offer or expose for sale or sell within the city any sick or diseased animal commonly used for food purposes, or any part of the flesh thereof, or the flesh or any part of any animal which, when killed, was sick or diseased, or which died a natural or accidental death. 
(Ord. No. 67-1965, § 1, 6-20-67)  
Sec. 15-43. - Protection of meat being transported. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to transport or cause to be transported in any vehicle through the streets or public ways of the city any meat or meat products unless the same are securely wrapped in paper or tightly woven cloth covering, or unless the same are carried in a refrigeration compartment in such vehicle, so as not to expose the meat to dust, dirt, filth or any other deleterious substance. 
(Code 1964, § 15-36)  
Secs. 15-44—15-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - INSANITARY, UNSIGHTLY, ETC., CONDITIONS ON PRIVATE PREMISES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to prohibit conditions described in this article, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4436. 
 
Sec. 15-56. - Prohibited conditions designated—Stagnant water. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow the accumulation of stagnant water on any lot owned or occupied by him within the city or to permit stagnant water to remain thereon. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to permit or allow holes or places on such lots where water may accumulate and become stagnant or to permit the same to remain thereon. 
(Code 1964, § 15-44)  
Sec. 15-57. - Same—Accumulations of carrion, filth, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy any house, building, establishment, lot or yard in the city to permit or allow any carrion, filth or other impure or unwholesome matter to accumulate or remain thereon. 
(Code 1964, § 15-45)  
Sec. 15-58. - Same—Growth or accumulation of weeds, rubbish, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy any lot in the city to allow weeds, rubbish, brush or any other unsightly, objectionable or unsanitary matter to accumulate or grow on such lot. 
(Code 1964, § 15-46)  
Sec. 15-59. - Insect vectors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy any house, building, establishment, lot or yard, whether public or private, in the city to permit or allow insects which can vector disease to accumulate or remain thereon. 
(Ord. No. 83-238, § 3, 9-6-83)  
Sec. 15-60. - Rodent control. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy any house, building, establishment, lot or yard, whether public or private, to permit or allow rats, mice or other feral rodents to remain thereon or to permit or allow conditions to exist which attract or shelter such rodents. 
All public buildings and residences shall be secured against the entry of such rodents. 
(Ord. No. 83-238, § 3, 9-6-83)  
Sec. 15-61. - Notice to owner to remove or remedy conditions. 
(a)  (1)  Upon the failure of the owner, occupant, or person in control of private premises to comply with section 15-58 of this article, the director shall have the weeds or grass cut, mulched or raked, and removed from the premises. 
(2)  Before having the weeds or grass cut, mulched, raked, or removed, the director must notify the owner of the premises to bring the premises into compliance with section 15-58 within ten (10) days. The notice must be in writing and may be served by handing it to the owner in person or by United States regular mail, five-day return receipt requested, addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address as shown on the tax rolls of the city or of the county in which the premises are located. If the owner cannot be found and the letter is returned by the United States Postal Service, then the owner may be notified by: 
a.  Publication two (2) times within ten (10) consecutive days in the official newspaper adopted by the city council; 
b.  Posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the premises to which the violation relates; or 
c.  Posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the premises to which the violation relates, if the premises contain no buildings. 
(3)  The director may send a notice of violation of this article by certified mail, return receipt requested, informing the owner of the property on which the violation exists that, if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, the city may, without further notice, correct the violation at the owner's expense and then assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this subsection occurs within the one-year period, and the city has not been informed in writing by the owner of a change in ownership of the property, then the city may, without notice, take any action permitted by subsection (a) and assess its expenses as provided in section 15-58. 
(b)  Whenever any condition described in this article, except for accumulation of weeds, is found to exist upon any lot or premises in the city, the director of public health shall notify the owner of such lot or premises to remove or remedy the condition within ten (10) days after the date of such notice. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be served on the owner in person or mailed to him at his latest known address. In the event personal service cannot be had and the owner's address is not known, such notice shall be given by publication in a newspaper published in the city, at least twice within ten (10) consecutive days. 
(Code 1964, § 15-47; Ord. No. 83-238, § 1, 9-6-83; Ord. No. 03-040, § 1, 3-4-03)  
Sec. 15-62. - Removal or correction of condition by city—Generally. 
In the event the owner of any lot or premises fails to remove or remedy any condition described in this article within ten (10) days after notice has been given as provided in section 15-61, the city may do whatever is necessary to remove or remedy the condition, or cause the same to be done, and charge the expense incurred thereby to the owner of such lot or premises and such expense shall be assessed against the real estate upon which the work was done. The amount of said expense shall be determined by adding to the charge incurred by the city for performing, or causing to be performed, the work necessary to cause such lot or premises to come into conformance with chapter 15 of the Pasadena Code of Ordinances, plus an administrative fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00), all of which shall be due and payable by the owner of the lot or premises upon which said work was done within thirty (30) days of said billing by the city. If such expense is not paid within thirty (30) days of said billing, there shall be added thereto an amount equal to one-third ( 1/3 ) of said expense. The doing of such work and the charging and assessing of the expenses thereof against the owner shall not relieve the owner or occupant of any prosecution for violation of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 15-48; Ord. No. 75-101, § 1, 6-17-75; Ord. No. 83-238, § 1, 9-6-83; Ord. No. 94-1, § 5, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 04-55, § 1, 3-23-04)  
Sec. 15-63. - Same—Statement of expenses; lien for and interest on expenses; suit to collect expenses. 
The director of public health of the city shall file a statement of expenses incurred under section 15-62, giving the amount of such expenses and the date on which the work was done or improvements made, with the county clerk and the city shall have a privileged lien on such lot or real estate upon which the work was done or improvements made to secure the expenditures so made, in accordance with the provisions of Article 4436, Revised Civil Statutes of Texas, which lien shall be second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. The amount of such expenses shall bear ten (10) per cent interest from the date such statement is filed. For any such expenditures and interest, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure of such lien may be had in the name of the city and the statement of expenses so made, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended for such work or improvements. The director of public health is authorized to accept payments for such liens in installments and give releases or partial releases as necessary. 
(Code 1964, § 15-49; Ord. No. 83-238, § 1, 9-6-83; Ord. No. 84-232, § 1, 9-25-84)  
Sec. 15-64. - Insurance requirements for contractors doing weed mowing and cleanup work. 
(a)  Each contractor performing weed mowing or cleanup work for the city under this article shall comply with the following insurance requirements: 
(1)  He shall carry public liability insurance to the extent of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one person. 
(2)  He shall carry property damage insurance to the extent of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one piece of property. 
(b)  The insurance required by this section shall be written by an accredited company under the supervision of the State Board of Insurance Commissioners. Evidence of compliance with these requirements shall be met when the policy or a copy thereof or a certificate of insurance has been filed with and approved by the city. The policy shall include an endorsement thereon that the city will be notified at least ten (10) days in advance in the event of cancellation or expiration of the policy. 
(Ord. No. 86-115, § 1, 6-17-86)  
Secs. 15-65—15-69. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - FOOD AND BEVERAGE VENDING MACHINE SANITATION 
 
Sec. 15-70. - Purpose. 
This article shall be liberally construed and applied to promote its underlying purpose of protecting the public health. 
(Ord. No. 83-68, § 1, 3-1-83)  
Sec. 15-71. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases are, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, defined as follows: 
Bulk food means a food which when dispensed to the customer is not packaged, wrapped or otherwise enclosed. 
Commissary means a catering establishment, restaurant or any other place in which food, containers or supplies are kept, handled, prepared, packaged or stored for use in vending machines. The term shall not apply to an area or conveyance at a vending machine location used for the temporary storage of packaged food or beverages. 
Condiment means any food such as salt, pepper, mustard and ketchup that is used to enhance the flavor of other food. 
Controlled location vending machine (limited service vending machine) means a vending machine which: 
(1)  Dispenses only nonpotentially hazardous food; 
(2)  Is of such design that it can be filled and maintained in a sanitary manner by untrained persons at the location; and 
(3)  Is intended for and used at locations in which protection is assured against environmental contamination. 
Corrosion-resistant materials means those materials that maintain their original surface characteristics under prolonged influence of the food to be contacted, the normal use of cleaning compounds and bactericidal solutions, and other conditions of the use environment. 
Easily cleanable means that surfaces are readily accessible and made of such material and finish and so fabricated that residues may be effectively removed by normal cleaning methods. 
Employee means the permit holder, individual having supervisory or management duties and any other person who handles any food to be dispensed through vending machines, or who comes into contact with food-contact surfaces of containers, equipment, utensils or packaging materials, used in connection with vending machine operations, or who otherwise services or maintains one or more such machines. 
Equipment means vending machines, ovens, tables, counters, sinks and similar items, other than utensils used in vending operations. 
Food means any raw, cooked, or processed edible substance, ice, beverage or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in whole or in part for human consumption. 
Food-contact surfaces means those surfaces with which food normally comes into contact, and those surfaces from which food may drain, drip or splash back onto surfaces normally in contact with food. 
Hermetically sealed container means a container which is designed and intended to be secure against the entry of microorganisms and to maintain the commercial sterility of its contents after processing. 
Law includes federal, state and local statutes, ordinances and regulations. 
Machine location means the room, enclosure, space or area where one or more vending machines are installed and operated. 
Operator means any person who, by contract, agreement, or ownership, takes responsibility for furnishing, installing, servicing, operating or maintaining one or more vending machines. 
Packaged means bottled, canned, cartoned or securely wrapped. 
Person includes an individual, partnership, corporation, association or other legal entity. 
Potentially hazardous food means any food that consists in whole or in part of fluid milk, milk products, eggs, meat, poultry, fish, shell fish, edible crustacea or other ingredients including synthetic ingredients, which is in a form capable of supporting rapid and progressive growth of infectious or toxigenic microorganisms. The term does not include clean, whole, uncracked, odor-free shell eggs or foods which have a pH level of 4.6 or below or a water activity (Aw) value of 0.85 or less under standard conditions. 
Readily accessible means exposed or capable of being exposed for cleaning and inspection without the use of tools. 
Regulatory authority means the director of health of the city or the director's duly authorized representative. 
Safe materials means articles manufactured from or composed of materials that may not reasonably be expected to result, directly or indirectly, in their becoming a component or otherwise affecting the characteristics of any food. If materials are food additives or color additives as defined in Section 201(s) or (t) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act as used, they are "safe" only if they are used in conformity with regulations established pursuant to Section 409 or Section 706 of the Act. Other materials are "safe" only if they are not food additives or color additives as defined in Section 201(s) or (t) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, and are used in conformity with regulations issued under the Act. 
Safe temperatures for potentially hazardous food means temperatures of forty-five (45) degrees Fahrenheit (7.2 degrees centigrade) or below or one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit (60 degrees centigrade) or above. 
Sanitization means effective bactericidal treatment by a process that provides enough accumulative heat or concentration of chemicals for enough time to reduce the bacterial count, including pathogens, to a safe level on utensils and equipment. 
Sealed means free of cracks or other openings that permit the entry or passage of moisture. 
Single-service articles means cups, containers, lids, closures, plates, knives, forks, spoons, stirrers, paddles, straws, napkins, wrapping materials, toothpicks and similar articles designed for one time, one person use, and then discarded. 
Utensil means any implement used in the storage, preparation, transportation or service of food. 
Vending machine means any self-service device which, upon insertion of a coin, paper currency, token, card or key, dispenses unit servings of food or water, either in bulk or in packages, without the necessity of replenishing the device between each vending operation. It shall also include self-service dispensers equipped for coin, paper currency, token, card or key operation and optional manual operation. Unless otherwise stated, vending machine includes controlled location vending machines. 
(Ord. No. 83-68, § 1, 3-1-83)  
Sec. 15-72. - Captions. 
Section and other captions are part of this article. 
(Ord. No. 83-68, § 1, 3-1-83)  
Sec. 15-73. - Repealer; effective date. 
This article shall be in full force and effect three (3) months after its adoption and publication in accordance with law. At that time, all ordinances and parts of ordinances that conflict with this article are repealed. 
(Ord. No. 83-68, § 1, 3-1-83)  
Sec. 15-74. - Separability. 
If any provision or application of any provision of this article is held invalid, that invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this article. 
(Ord. No. 83-68, § 1, 3-1-83)  
Sec. 15-75. - Food supplies. 
Food exposed for sale, offered for sale, sold through vending machines and offered to patrons of vending machines shall be sound and free from spillage, filth, or other contamination and shall be safe for human consumption. The food shall be obtained from sources that comply with all laws relating to food and food labeling. The use of food in hermetically sealed containers that was not prepared in a food processing establishment is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 83-68, § 1, 3-1-83)  
Sec. 15-76. - Food protection. 
At all times, including while being prepared, stored, loaded, displayed, or transported, food intended for sale through vending machines shall be protected from contamination by all agents, including dust, insects, rodents, unclean equipment and utensils, unnecessary handling, coughs, sneezes, flooding, draining, and overhead leakage or condensation. All potentially hazardous foods must have pull dates that can be seen by the purchaser. 
The temperature of potentially hazardous foods shall be forty-five (45) degrees Fahrenheit (7.2 degrees centigrade) or below one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit (60 degrees centigrade) or above at all times, except as otherwise provided in subsection 15-77(g). 
(Ord. No. 83-68, § 1, 3-1-83; Ord. No. 83-140, § 1, 5-31-83)
