Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 9; electrical code, Ch. 12; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 13; housing, Ch. 16½; plumbing, Ch. 29. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Purpose. 
This Code is an ordinance providing minimum requirements and standards for the practical safeguarding of persons and property from the hazards arising from the installation of heating, air conditioning, refrigeration, air treatment, and boiler systems. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-2. - Scope. 
The provisions of this Code shall apply to the installation, replacement, relocation, or maintenance of heating, air conditioning, refrigeration, air treatment, or boiler equipment within this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-3. - Adoption of codes and state laws. 
The City of Pasadena Mayor and City Council, with the recommendation of the City of Pasadena Heating, Air Conditioning, Refrigeration, and Boiler Board (hereafter referred to as Mechanical Board), does hereby adopt the most current edition of the 2015 Uniform Mechanical Code, the most current edition (as adopted and mandated by the State of Texas) of the International Energy Conservation Code, and the current Laws and Regulations adopted by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation for air conditioning, heating, refrigeration, and boilers. Also adopted is Chapter 16 of the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances, hereafter known as the Mechanical Codes. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 16-4—16-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MECHANICAL BOARD 
 
Sec. 16-26. - Mechanical board created. 
There is hereby created a mechanical board consisting of seven (7) members of who shall be resident's or own a business in the City of Pasadena, and appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-27. - Members of mechanical board. 
(a)  Position one (1) shall be filled by the chief air conditioning and boiler inspector of the City of Pasadena or his duly authorized representative. 
(b)  Position two (2) shall be filled by a representative of the building trades in Pasadena. 
(c)  Positions three (3), four (4), five (5), and six (6) shall be filled by duly licensed heating, air conditioning, or refrigeration contractors. Such contractors shall have been registered and actively engaged in heating, air conditioning, or refrigeration contracting in the City of Pasadena for at least one (1) year immediately prior to confirmation for membership on the mechanical board. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-28. - Appointments, terms, and removal. 
Board members for the mechanical board shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council, and serve a term of two (2) calendar years, or until his or her successor has been appointed, and confirmed to take office. Any appointed member of the board may be removed from office in accordance with article III, section 7 of the City of Pasadena Home Rule Charter. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-29. - Quorum. 
Four (4) members of the mechanical board present at any meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business of the board, and a majority vote of the members present shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-30. - Officers, procedures, order of business. 
The officers of the board shall consist of a chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary, the chairman, vice-chairman, and the secretary shall be nominated by the members of the mechanical board each year in its first meeting after January 2nd. Each officer shall be elected by a majority vote of the then qualified and serving members of the mechanical board. Employees of the City of Pasadena shall not serve as officers of the mechanical board. The terms of all elective officers shall be concurrent and limited within the terms of the officer's board membership. The meeting procedure and order of business shall be as prescribed by the mechanical board. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-31. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  The mechanical board shall be responsible for making interpretations of the mechanical codes including the approval of equipment, material installation techniques, and granting special permission for the material and installations not covered herein. 
(b)  The mechanical board shall submit to the mayor, city council, and the building official, written suggestions and recommendations for the improvement of the City of Pasadena Mechanical Code. 
(c)  The mechanical board will review appeals requested on behalf of contractors, homeowners, and citizens of the City of Pasadena, and advise the permit department and/or the City of Pasadena Mayor and city council as to specific rulings and/or opinions. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-32. - Reports. 
The mechanical board shall prepare a written report to the mayor and/or building official indicating herein the official action of the board. Said report is to be submitted during January of each year or as may be requested in regards to specific appeals before the board. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-33. - Investigations. 
The chief mechanical inspector, or his representative, shall make such investigations regarding mechanical work as deemed necessary or as requested by the mayor, or building official, and prepare a written report, with correction requirements, to requestor and owner or occupant of property in question. 
Inspector shall have "right of entry" during reasonable hours for investigating the previous mentioned inspection or complaint as may be properly reported to the City of Pasadena. By adoption, this allows the City of Pasadena to recover an hourly amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) an hour for staff fees associated to any individual or company found at fault or responsible by determination of the mechanical board. This is separate and independent of fines that may result from the investigation. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-34. - Right to appeal. 
(a)  Any person, firm, corporation, or organization dissatisfied with an interpretation of a mechanical inspector shall have the right to appeal such decision. The appeal shall be in writing for review to the mechanical board within two (2) working days after such decision. If no appeal is made within the time allowed the inspector's decision will be final. There upon, the mechanical board within fifteen (15) working days shall hear and determine said appeal based on the current mechanical code(s) being used at the time of the original decision. The mechanical board shall have the right to affirm, modify, or reverse the action of the mechanical inspector, provided, that until such time as the inspector's decision is reversed or modified, such decision shall be in effect. The decision of the mechanical board shall be subject to review by the city council as provided for below. If no appeal is made within the time allowed below the board's decision will be final. 
(b)  Any person, firm, corporation, or organization that questions a decision of the mechanical board shall have the right to appeal. Such appeal shall be made in writing to the city secretary within ten (10) days after the decision of the mechanical board. After receipt of such appeal, the city council shall set the date for a hearing, and the city secretary shall notify the appellant and the chairman of the mechanical board. The mechanical board, as well as the appellant, shall have the right to be heard. The city council shall affirm, modify, or reverse the action and/or decision of the mechanical board. The action of the city council shall be final. If no appeal is requested within the time and manner herein provided, the ruling of the mechanical board shall be final. The action of the mechanical board shall in all things be effective until reversed or modified by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 16-35—16-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 16-41. - Definitions. 
No terms in this mechanical code are gender specific. 
Administrative "hold" prevents a contractor or owner from acquisition of mechanical or other permits. 
Air conditioning contractor: Any individual, partnership, firm, or corporation engaging in the business of installing, altering, replacing, or maintaining an air conditioning, heating, ventilating, refrigeration, boiler, or air treatment system or unit. Contractor shall be licensed by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation or have someone licensed by the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation on staff, and registered with the City of Pasadena. 
Air treatment: Any system which is capable of absorbing or neutralizing smoke, odors, dust, and other pathogens through ultra violet lights, filters, chemical, or electrically charged systems. 
Alteration: A change in air conditioning, heating, boiler, ventilation, air treatment, or refrigeration system that involves an extension, addition, relocation, or modification of the mechanical equipment or system. 
Amendments: More stringent code modifications made to ensure that life-safety and environmental concerns/improvements are satisfied for the citizens and this community. 
Authority having jurisdiction: The City of Pasadena Texas is hereby recognized as the authority having jurisdiction in every context and application of the adopted codes, regulations and amendments. 
Chief mechanical inspector: A person employed by the City of Pasadena Permit Department working under the authority and assignment for the duties of chief mechanical inspector as assigned by the City of Pasadena Building Official preferably certified by a nationally recognized certification agency in the mechanical inspections field. The chief mechanical inspector will enforce all regulations described in this and other adopted codes as pertaining to air conditioning, heating, ventilation, boilers, refrigeration and air treatment equipment. The chief mechanical inspector shall be accountable to the building official. 
French drain: A lined hole (18"×18"×18") dug in the ground, filled with gravel or rocks for the air condition condensate to drain into. 
Full time employee: An individual employed by an individual, partnership, or corporation on a full time basis of thirty-six (36) hours or more per week and reported on their federal and state tax records as an employee. These records shall be made available to the chief mechanical inspector, or his representative, during normal business hours. 
IECC inspector or designer: An individual certified, under a current nationally recognized model energy code, to design or perform energy inspections for IECC compliance. 
Inspector: Shall mean the inspector(s) as may be assigned by the City of Pasadena Building Official or his representative to enforce laws, regulations, codes and policies set forth by the City of Pasadena. 
Mechanical equipment: Air conditioners, heaters, heat pumps, air handlers, fans, boilers, air treatment, refrigeration, exhaust/ventilation and any other type of equipment used in these fields or similar industries. 
Mechanical work: Any work pertaining to mechanical equipment. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 16-42—16-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MECHANICAL PERMIT FEES 
 
Sec. 16-51. - Fees. 
All permit department fees, specific policies and procedures must comply with the provisions of the City of Pasadena Ordinance Number 2006-322 or if the fee was unmodified, it defaults to any previous established fee(s). 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 16-52—16-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - SPECIFIC POLICIES AND PROCEDURES 
 
Sec. 16-61. - Scheduled overtime or emergency inspections. 
All shall comply with the specific provisions in the City of Pasadena Ordinance Number 2006-322. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-62. - Gas connection approval. 
No connection from an energy or fuel source shall be made to any heating, air conditioning, or boiler equipment unless specifically approved by the chief mechanical inspector or his representative. An inspection shall be scheduled within forty-eight (48) hours of completion of installation or receive penalties. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-63. - Mechanical work by homeowner. 
Any homeowner may perform mechanical work, for which a permit is required, in and on his legal homestead, provided a permit is obtained first. The mechanical work shall not include equipment requiring EPA certification, gas heating furnaces, or work in other crafts requiring permits. All work must be in accordance with all applicable provisions of this ordinance and must pass inspection. The homeowner shall not employ, pay or compensate, in any manner, a mechanical contractor, or any other person to perform any part of the mechanical work. All mechanical work shall be performed by the homeowner, or immediate family, or permit will be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-64. - Electrical and plumbing work by mechanical contractors. 
No electrical or plumbing work is to be done by mechanical contractors or their employees. Work requiring permits must be performed by their respective contractor and scheduled for inspection at completion of job. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 16-65—16-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 16-71. - Enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to do any mechanical work in the City of Pasadena, unless a person has a valid mechanical license, issued by the State of Texas, and registered with the City of Pasadena, or works for a company, corporation, or an individual that has a valid mechanical license and is registered with the City of Pasadena Permit Department, and has a permit, if required, for the work. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a mechanical license holder to permit his license to be used in any manner contrary to any provisions adopted by this Code, or to obtain a permit required by this Code in their name, or to allow the use of their name or company name directly or indirectly by another person not legally employed by the license holder or the company he represents, for the purpose of obtaining a mechanical permit. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to use a mechanical contractor's license without his knowledge or permission to secure a mechanical permit. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to design, for IECC compliance, a Rescheck or Commcheck, or perform energy inspections without first being certified under a current nationally recognized energy code. 
(e)  A licensed contractor must be available to meet with the chief mechanical inspector or his representative within twenty-four (24) hours after being notified of this request. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 16-72—16-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - ADDITIONAL PASADENA AMENDMENTS 
 
Sec. 16-81. - Unlawful advertising by contractors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, or company to display a sign, advertise, including business cards, invoices, proposals, or other written material, when soliciting work in the City of Pasadena, indicating that such person or company is in the business of air conditioning or mechanical work unless authorized under the provisions of this Code or the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation and registered with the Permit Department of the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-82. - Ladders. 
The following apply to all new installations for projects permitted after the date of adoption: 
(a)  In all attic installed heating and/or air conditioning equipment shall have pull down attic stairways, that comply with OSHA Type 1 ratings for a minimum of three hundred fifty (350) pounds with an affixed listed approved label, and with a clear minimum opening of twenty-two (22) inches. 
(b)  Twenty-four-inch wide walkway from attic access to service platform. If a/c ducts must cross walkway, support a minimum of thirty-six (36) inches above walkway or build bridge over ducts. 
(c)  There shall be thirty-inch clear service platform on service side of heater, evaporator coil, emergency drain pan, and air treatment equipment, and any drains or refrigerant lines crossing platform shall be protected. 
(d)  Vertical difference in ceiling heights in attic walkway, over twenty-four (24) inches, shall have steps. 
(e)  Commercial roof top mechanical equipment installed on new buildings, or existing buildings, over fifteen (15) feet tall, shall have an approved ladder installed to service equipment. Safeguards must be in place to not allow access within eight (8) feet of grade by those not performing work or maintenance to the structure or equipment. 
(f)  No ladder shall be required on existing buildings if mechanical equipment has been installed on roof prior to present job. Ladders may be mounted on outside or inside of building, as per OSHA requirements. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-83. - Conditioned areas. 
All residential and commercial buildings used for any occupied use or business shall have conditioned air that meets winter and summer design conditions of sixty-eight (68) degrees in winter and seventy-six (76) degrees in summer. Maintained at a level of three (3) feet from the floor and two (2) feet from any corner or door opening. Storage, open bay service area, and unconditioned warehouses do not need to comply. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-84. - Return air. 
Return air shall be obtained from an approved interior location of the same building. Return air shall be taken from each level of a multi-story house. If an air conditioner or heater serves only one (1) specific area, return air shall be returned from that area to the unit serving it. 
A return air duct or chase shall have at least: 
Tonnage 	Duct Size 	Duct Size Square Inches 
1 	10" 	78.5 
1½ 	12" 	113.4 
2 	14" 	153.86 
2½ 	16" 	200.96 
3 	18" 	254.34 
3½ 	18" 	254.34 
4 	20" 	314.0 
5 	2-16" 	380 
 
Return air grills shall not be smaller than ten (10) square inches of net free area for every thousand BTU's of air conditioning. 
Return air shall not be obtained from the following locations: 
(a)  Where it will pick-up objectionable odors, fumes, or flammable vapors. 
(b)  A hazardous location. 
(c)  An unsanitary location. 
(d)  An area having a volume less than fifty (50) per cent of the entire volume served by the supply air system, unless there is a permanent communicating opening to areas having a volume equal to the required fifty (50) per cent. Appropriately sized transfer grills or door undercuts may be used to provide the required openings, as long as calculations are provided to the authority having jurisdiction. 
(e)  A mechanical room with gas fired equipment. 
(f)  A room or space containing fuel burning equipment. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  Fire places, decorative appliances. 
(2)  A listed vented wall furnace. 
(3)  The return air inlet shall not be within ten (10) feet of any appliance fire box, draft diverter, or gas burning appliance in the same room or space. 
(g)  A closet, bathroom, toilet room, or kitchen. 
(h)  Within four (4) feet of an air supply register. 
(i)  A corridor, exit passageway, or exit enclosure required by the building code to be of fire, or smoke resistive construction, unless sprinkled. 
(j)  A dwelling unit, guest room, or patient room other than the room in which the air originates. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-85. - Gas connections. 
A mechanical contractor shall be limited to the installation of the gas flex line serving the gas appliance. Gas flex lines are limited to a maximum of three (3) feet in length. A listed gas shut-off valve shall be installed on the service side of the furnace within three (3) feet of the furnace gas valve. A solid gas pipe nipple shall be added to the gas valve on the appliance for connection of the flex gas line outside the furnace cabinet, the nipple shall not extend more than four (4) inches outside the cabinet, including any ninety (90) elbow installed. 
Any addition, replacement, or relocation of the gas pipe must be done by a licensed plumbing contractor with a permit for that particular job. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-86. - Non-vented equipment. 
Non-vented fuel-burning room heaters and decorative appliances shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-87. - Adding or replacing equipment in attics. 
All heating or cooling equipment installed in attics shall be installed a maximum of twenty (20) feet from approved attic access, and shall have a minimum height of thirty-six (36) inches of attic space with sufficient openings communicating to the outside for required combustion air. A light shall be installed a maximum of six (6) feet in front of the service side of the unit being installed, and controlled by a switch at the attic access opening. All equipment shall have a separate means of disconnect, adjacent to and within sight of the equipment, for service or replacement. All 110v outlet shall be installed next to service side of equipment. All gas furnace flue pipe shall be installed as per Uniform Mechanical Code, with a maximum increase of one (1) size. All new flue pipe shall have matching new cap, collar, and flashing. Deteriorating roof jacks or flashings shall be replaced. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-88. - Condensate drains. 
Condensate drains shall not be less than three-quarters (¾) inch in diameter or reduced from original equipment size. Condensate drains may be of copper or PVC, or other material approved by the mechanical board. No black poly-vinyl tubing shall be used. All drain connections shall face the service side of the equipment that it is connected to, or have a twenty-four-inch walk way leading to the drain connections for service. Drains shall be connected to approved locations, such as, P-traps under lavatories, drains on bath tubs, or other locations designated by the plumbing code. Drains shall not be connected to sinks, hand wash stations, or food prep areas. Residential retrofit equipment drains shall run to French-drains, eighteen (18) by eighteen (18) by eighteen (18) inches filled with gravel or a five (5) gallon bucket with the bottom removed, placed into the ground with one (1) inch of the top of the bucket exposed, filled with rock; if not able to connect to approved location. Drains shall be supported every four (4) feet with a minimum of one-eighth-inch drop per foot, and insulated with one-half-inch insulation, through-out the entire horizontal run(s), and protected across walkways and service platforms. All main condensate drains shall be insulated, with a minimum of one-half-inch wall thickness insulation, in concealed walls and attics. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-89. - Evaporator coils: Requirements for installation. 
(a)  All evaporator cooling coils, or air conditioning units with cooling coils placed above a finished ceiling, closet, or any location that may cause damage, shall have a secondary drain run to a readily observable location. All secondary drain pans shall require a float switch. Package units shall require a float switch in the main drain pan. All float switches shall be listed by an approved testing laboratory. All new installations shall have emergency drains. 
(b)  Horizontal evaporator coils and plenums shall be supported on both sides with one (1) inch metal straps. Where straps are attached to over-head rafters or other wooden supports; nails or screws used shall be one (1) inch in length. No perforated straps shall be used. 
(c)  A minimum eight by eight (8×8) inch listed inspection door shall be installed in the transition for horizontal evaporator coils. 
(d)  When replacing evaporator coils, condensate drains will be brought up to current code standards. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-90. - Smoke detectors. 
All commercial air conditioning and heating units shall have a smoke detector installed in supply side, regardless of CFM's, unless pre-shipped from factory with smoke detector in return air side. If structure has a supervised fire alarm system, the smoke detector shall be connected to it. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-91. - Environmental air ducts; requirements for installation or replacement. 
(a)  Flex duct or duct board shall be a minimum of R-8. All duct insulation shall meet R-8 minimum requirement, unless required by the energy code to be more restrictive. 
(b)  All register boxes and bath fans shall be supported on a minimum of two (2) sides, and sealed. 
(c)  Residential bathrooms with open window area of at least three (3) square feet shall not require bath exhaust fans. If exhaust fans are required they shall be vented to outside. 
(d)  Domestic ranges shall have a hood with exhaust vented to outside and made of smooth sheet metal, connected by listed fittings, and with a back draft damper. 
(e)  Clothes dryer exhaust ducts shall be smooth sheet metal with no screws. Four-inch duct shall not run over twenty-five (25) feet in total length with two (2) elbows, additional elbows will deduct five (5) feet from total length for each elbow. A run may be extended to forty (40) feet by increasing the duct to five (5) inches with a listed increaser. The elbows will apply the same as for the four-inch exhaust duct. All dryer exhaust ducts, not vented thru the wall, shall have lint traps installed below the flex connector at the wall. Lint traps shall be made with a four-inch metal "T" and a four-inch metal ninety (90), with an end cap on the lint trap end. When vents for dryers or domestic ranges are vented thru a roof jack, a sheet metal escutcheon shall be installed to seal off the vent at the roof jack. No tape will be allowed to seal off vents in roof jack. 
Gas clothes dryers in enclosed rooms shall have a minimum of one (1) square inch per thousand BTU's of make-up air. An exhaust fan, vented to the outside of the house or building, is required unless the room has an operable window. 
(f)  Fresh air duct shall be smooth sheet metal duct extended to outside of building with one-fourth-inch bird screen at outside termination, and filtered. 
(g)  Combustion air may be taken from an attic area, if attic is communicable with outside air, otherwise it must be taken from outside of building. Combustion air duct shall be smooth sheet metal, and of sufficient dimensions to allow one (1) square inch per three thousand (3,000) BTU's, or in enclosed room providing fifty (50) cubic feet per thousand (1,000) BTU's of all gas fired equipment in the room. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-92. - Commercial kitchen hoods; requirements for installation or repairs. 
(a)  Commercial exhaust hoods Type 1 and Type 2 shall be of stainless steel material and thickness as noted in the current Uniform Mechanical Code. 
(b)  Listed zero (0) clearance insulating material may be used in lieu of a shaft or enclosure. Installation instructions must be on job site for inspection. No mineral wool batting shall be used. 
(c)  Make-up air shall be provided for all commercial exhaust hoods. Plans shall be submitted for approval before permit will be issued for class 1 commercial kitchen exhaust hoods. All details will be shown on plans, including size of hood, size of ducts, and CFM's and static pressure, of all fans. Exhaust ducts, and hoods, within eighteen (18) inches of combustible material or above ceilings, shall have zero (0) clearance duct wrap. 
(d)  Type 2 commercial hoods shall be installed over all commercial dishwashing equipment, and heat generating equipment. Hoods shall be constructed of stainless steel materials and shall be six (6) inches larger per each side than the dishwashing equipment, or heat generating equipment. 
(e)  All air intakes shall be a minimum distance of ten (10) feet horizontal or three (3) feet vertical from any vents or exhausts. 
(f)  Nail salons shall have six (6) air changes per hour with a separate exhaust and supply fan. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-93. - Fresh air requirements. 
CFM of fresh air per person: 
Dining room, offices, etc. 	10 
Auditoriums, theaters, churches 	5 
Cafeterias 	10 
Night clubs, taverns 	15 
All other occupancies 	5 
Hospitals 	15 
Operating rooms 	100% Outside Air 
 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Secs. 16-94—16-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - APPLICATION FOR MECHANICAL PERMIT 
 
Sec. 16-101. - Application. 
To obtain a mechanical permit, the licensed mechanical contractor, or their duly authorized representative, shall first file an application in writing on a form furnished for that purpose, by the Permit Department of the City of Pasadena. Each application shall: 
(a)  Identify and describe the scope of work to be covered by the permit, and list the sizes of each piece of equipment to be permitted. 
(b)  Describe the location, where the proposed work is to take place, by street address. 
(c)  Show the use or function of the building and/or project. 
(d)  Be accompanied by plans, heat load calculations, and specifications. 
(e)  Be signed by the licensed mechanical contractor, who may be required to submit evidence to indicate such authority. 
(f)  By requesting the issuance of a permit; the mechanical contractor is stating that they have read, and are familiar with this chapter, and will supervise, direct, and control all mechanical work performed under it. 
(g)  It shall be the responsibility of the mechanical contractor to final all permits, any permit not finaled will be submitted to the department of licensing and regulation for further action. 
(h)  Boiler installation or replacement shall be permitted by a mechanical contractor only. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-102. - Plans and specifications for commercial permits. 
(a)  With each commercial application that includes mechanical plans, the applicant must submit two (2) sets of plans, heat load calculations, and specifications. The chief mechanical inspector may require that such plans and specification bear the seal of a registered professional mechanical engineer licensed by the State of Texas. 
(b)  Plan submittal will require equipment and duct lay-out, size of equipment and air ducts; also CFM's of equipment, fans, supply ducts, exhaust ducts, and make-up air ducts. 
(c)  Plans and specifications for all commercial buildings, and commercial kitchen exhaust systems shall be submitted before permits are secured, except for minor alterations when specifically exempted by the chief mechanical inspector or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-103. - Approval of plans and specifications. 
(a)  The submitted applications, plans, heat loads, and specifications shall be reviewed by the chief mechanical inspector or his representative. Such plans may be reviewed by other departments of the City of Pasadena for compliance with laws and ordinances under their jurisdiction. If the chief mechanical inspector concurs with the other departments that the work described in the plans and specifications conform to the requirements for the City of Pasadena, he shall authorize a permit to be issued. 
(b)  When the chief mechanical inspector authorizes a permit, he shall stamp on both sets of plans and specifications "approved", and affix his signature thereto. 
(c)  All approved plans and specifications shall be on job site before any inspection will be made. 
(d)  No permit shall be transferred or assigned to any person by the applicant. 
(e)  Heat load calculations. Calculation of heating and cooling loads shall be determined in accordance with the procedures described in the ASHREA Fundamentals Handbook or by an approved equivalent computation procedure excepted by authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-104. - Validity. 
To issue or grant a permit with approval of plans, heat loads, and specifications shall not be construed to be a permit for/or approval of any violation of the provisions of this chapter. No permit shall give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this chapter, except to authorize the work or use as lawful. 
To issue a permit based on plans, heat loads, and specifications shall not prevent the chief mechanical inspector from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in the plans, heat loads, and specifications, or from preventing building operations from being carried out when in violation of any provision of this chapter or other ordinances of the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-105. - Display of permits. 
The permit on all mechanical work shall be displayed on the job site, in a readily observable location, prior to commencement of any mechanical work. The permit shall remain posted until final inspection of the mechanical work. The permit document shall be protected from the elements. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-106. - Expiration of permit. 
Each permit issued by the City of Pasadena Permit Department shall expire and become null and void if the project authorized has not started within sixty (60) days from the date of issue of such permit, or if the project is suspended or abandoned at any time, after the work has started. Before work can be resumed, a new permit shall be obtained. The fee shall be one-half (½) the amount of the original fee, if obtained within one hundred eighty (180) days of the original issue date, provided no changes have been made in the original plans and specifications. If changes have been made, a new permit shall be required. The permit shall be allowed to run concurrent with the building permit. 
All, stand alone, mechanical permits shall expire in one hundred eighty (180) days from issue date if inspections have not been completed. An inspection shall extend a mechanical permit and additional one hundred eighty (180) days from date of inspection. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Sec. 16-107. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  Mechanical contractors required to be registered as a business or entity under this Code shall keep in full force and effect, at all times, a policy or policies of insurance for the minimum limits of coverage as required by the State of Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation, and naming such contractor, with their license number, as an insured under the provisions of such policy or policies. The mechanical contractor shall make available to the air condition inspector or owner of project, on demand, a copy of the insurance. 
(b)  The insurance required by this code shall be written by an accredited company under the supervision of the Texas Department of Insurance Evidence of compliance with such insurance requirements shall be considered as having been met when a certificate of insurance (accord form) has been filed by the insurance agency, and is approved by the building official, or his representative, and lists the City of Pasadena as the certificate holder. 
(c)  Each policy of insurance required by this Code shall include an endorsement thereon that the City of Pasadena Permit Department shall be notified at least thirty (30) days in advance in the event the policy is cancelled or expires before the expiration date, and the name of the license holder and license number as it appears on the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation issued license. 
(d)  No mechanical contractor's license shall be valid in the City of Pasadena, unless the applicant has complied with this section. 
(Ord. No. 17-009, § 1(Exh. A), 1-17-17)  
Chapter 16½ - HOUSING[1]

Sec. 16½-1. - Adoption of a housing code. 
The 2006 edition of the International Property Maintenance Code, published by the International Code Council, Inc. is hereby adopted as the housing code of the City of Pasadena, State of Texas. This is for the protection of the public, health, safety, and welfare in all existing structures and properties regardless of occupancy or use. As herein provided; and each and all of the relations, provisions and conditions of the 2006 edition of the International Property Maintenance Code, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes if any, prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 96-234, 12-19-96; Ord. No. 02-98, § 1, 4-2-02; Ord. No. 07-170, 5-15-07)
