Charter reference— Municipal court, Art. VIII. 
Cross reference— Bonds for clerks of municipal court, § 2-5; duty of chief of police to attend municipal court and execute process issued therefrom, § 30-3; authority of chief of police to designate police officers to attend municipal court and to serve warrants issued by the judge thereof, § 30-5. 
State Law reference— Corporation court generally, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1194 et seq.; Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.01 et seq. Name of court changed to "Municipal Court," Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1194A. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 23-1. - Judges generally. 
(a)  The office of judge of the municipal court is hereby created. Such judge shall be appointed by the mayor, with the confirmation and approval of the city council, and he/she shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council. The judge of the municipal court shall be the chief judge and director of and presiding judge of the municipal court system. 
(b)  There are hereby created nine (9) part-time associate judges of the municipal court. One (1) associate judge shall be designated by the mayor as senior associate judge. The associate judges shall have duties and responsibilities as designated by the judge of the municipal court, and in the absence of the judge of the municipal court, act in his/her place. 
(c)  Such judges shall have all the powers and duties and jurisdiction and authority as is now or hereafter may be conferred upon municipal courts by the laws of this state and the charter and ordinances of the City of Pasadena. 
(d)  The judges of the municipal court referred to in subsections (a) and (b) shall serve for a term of office of two (2) years unless the council should provide for a longer term pursuant to Article XI, Section 11 of the Texas Constitution. A municipal court judge who is not reappointed by the 91 st day following the expiration of a term of office shall, absent action by the appointing authority, continue to serve for another term of office beginning on the date the previous term of office expired. 
(e)  Compensation for associate judges shall be determined as described on Exhibit "A" attached to Ord. No. 97-194, and as may be from time to time adjusted pursuant to Ordinance No. 96-2. 
(Code 1964, § 10-1; Ord. No. 97-194, § 1, 10-21-97; Ord. No. 11-006, §§ 1—3, 1-25-11) 
Charter reference— Judge of court, Art. VIII, § 2. 
State Law reference— Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Government Code, § 29.005.  
Sec. 23-2. - Monthly report of judge. 
The judge of the municipal court shall, upon request, provide to each member of the council a copy of the monthly report that is required by the State of Texas in such form as may be from time to time required by the State of Texas. 
(Code 1964, § 10-2; Ord. No. 11-006, § 5, 1-25-11)  
Sec. 23-3. - Seal. 
The municipal court shall be provided with a seal with star in the center and the words "MUNICIPAL COURT PASADENA, TEXAS" engraved around the star. The impression of the seal of the court must be attached to all papers issued out of the court except subpoenas and must be used to authenticate the official acts of the clerk and of the judge. The court seal may be created by electronic means, including optical imaging, optical disc, or other electronic reproduction technique that does not permit changes, additions or deletions to an original document created by the same type of system. A seal created by electronic means may be either black and white or with gold stars, lettering and borders on a black background. The official form of the court seal may be viewed in person in the office of the clerk or online at the municipal court's address on the City of Pasadena website. 
(Code 1964, § 10-3; Ord. No. 11-006, § 6, 1-25-11) 
State Law reference— Electronically created records, Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 45.012.  
Sec. 23-4. - Court days. 
The municipal court shall be open for the transaction of business at dates and times designated by the presiding judge, provided that any deviation from the schedule of normal business hours provided for conduct of city business generally shall first be approved by the mayor. 
(Code 1964, § 10-4; Ord. No. 11-006, § 7, 1-25-11) 
State Law reference— Court may sit at any time, Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 4.15.  
Sec. 23-5. - Disposition of fines and costs. 
All fines and costs imposed by the municipal court shall be paid over to the city controller and shall thereafter be allocated to the general fund and the several special funds of the municipal court as may exist at the time of imposition of the fines. All state traffic fines and costs as may be required by state law to be remitted to the controller shall be promptly paid to the state controller in the manner and in the amounts as may be required by state law. 
(Code 1964, § 10-6; Ord. No. 11-006, § 8, 1-25-11)  
Sec. 23-6. - Authority of judge to order return of property held for evidence. 
The municipal court judge shall have the authority to order that property in possession of the police department be returned to its rightful owner after final disposition of the case in which such property is being held for evidence or during the pendency of an action as specifically authorized and permitted by Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 47.01 et seq. and Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 38.34. 
(Ord. No. 68-38, § 1, 3-26-68; Ord. No. 11-006, § 9, 1-25-11) 
Cross reference— Disposition of unclaimed property in possession of police department, § 30-49 et seq.  
Sec. 23-7. - City to furnish supplies and forms. 
The city shall purchase and furnish to the judge of the municipal court all necessary supplies and forms required in the business to be transacted by the court and the officers thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 10-8)  
Sec. 23-8. - Special expense. 
(a)  A special expense of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is imposed for the issuance and service of a warrant of arrest for each offense under Section 38.10, Texas Penal Code (bail jumping and failure to appear), or each offense under Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Transportation Code, § 543.009, violation of written promise to appear. 
(b)  Special expenses of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the issuance and service of a warrant of arrest, and the additional expenses described in Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 17.04 and Art. 17.08, may be imposed by the municipal court, after due notice. 
(c)  A person on personal cash, or surety bond who does not appear as provided in the cash, or surety bond shall be notified of a hearing date for the court to consider the special expenses pursuant to subsection (b), payment to the court of the principal sum (amount) of the bond, plus all necessary and reasonable expenses incurred in any arrest for failure to appear. If the hearing on special expense and/or other necessary and reasonable expenses is conducted as a part of the bond forfeiture action, then the procedural rules that govern bond forfeitures generally shall apply. If the hearing is conducted not as a part of the bond forfeiture action, ten (10) days' notice of the hearing shall be given by the city marshal by personal or substituted service in substantial conformity with Rule 106, Texas Rules of Civil Procedure. Any of the expenses found to be due by the court may be collected by the city in accordance with the general laws of the state that govern collection of civil judgments generally. 
(d)  All special expenses provided for in this section shall be paid into the city treasury for the use and benefit of the city. 
(e)  This section applies only to the collection of special expenses after release following arrest for an offense committed on or after September 1, 1983. For the purposes of this section, an offense is committed before the effective date if any element of the offense occurs before the effective date. The collection of a special expense after release following arrest for an offense committed before the effective date of this section is covered by the law in effect when the offense was committed, and the former law is continued in effect for this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 83-347, § 1, 11-22-83; Ord. No. 11-006, §§ 10—12, 1-25-11)  
Sec. 23-9. - Work to discharge fines; work-release. 
(a)  (1)  The judge may require a defendant who fails to pay a previously assessed fine or costs, or who is determined by the court to have insufficient resources or income to pay a fine or costs, to discharge all or part of the fines or costs by performing community service. A defendant may discharge an obligation to perform community service under this article by paying at any time the fine and costs assessed. 
(2)  The judge's order requiring a defendant to participate in community service work under section (a)(1) must specify the number of hours the defendant is required to work. 
(3)  The judge may order the defendant to perform community service work under this article only for a governmental entity or a nonprofit organization that provides service to the general public that enhances social welfare and the general well-being of the community. A governmental entity or nonprofit organization that accepts a defendant under this article to perform community service must agree to supervise the defendant in the performance of the defendant's work and report on the defendant's work to the judge who ordered the community service. 
(4)  A judge may not order a defendant to perform more than sixteen (16) hours per week of community service under this section unless the judge determines that requiring the defendant to work additional hours does not work a hardship on the defendant or the defendant's dependents. 
(5)  A defendant is considered to have discharged one hundred dollars ($100.00) of fines and costs for each eight (8) hours of community service performed under this section. Credit for work release will hereafter be controlled by amendments to state law; provided, however, the city may from time to time provide for credit in an amount greater than that provided by state law, but not less than that provided by state law. 
(6)  Neither the municipal court judge nor any officer or employee of the City of Pasadena is liable for damages arising from an act or a failure to act in connection with manual labor performed by a defendant under this section if the act or failure to act was performed pursuant to court order and was not intentional, willfully or wantonly negligent or performed with conscious indifference or reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Ord. No. 85-227, § 1, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 85-263, § 1, 1-7-86; Ord. No. 02-158, § 1, 7-16-02; Ord. No. 11-006, § 13, 1-25-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 85-227, § 1, adopted Nov. 12, 1985, purported to amend § 23-30 of the Code. Inasmuch as the Code did not contain a § 23-30, said Ord. No. 85-227 was codified as a new § 23-9, at the editor's discretion.  
Sec. 23-10. - Code of Criminal Procedure adopted. 
The City Council hereby adopts the provisions of Texas Revised Civil Statutes Annotated, Code of Criminal Procedure, Chapter 45, as the same may hereafter be, from time to time, amended as the governing rules of procedure in the Municipal Court of City of Pasadena. Further, to the extent provided by Art. 45.002 thereof, the city council hereby adopts the provisions of the entire Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 02-158, § 2, 7-16-02)  
Sec. 23-11. - Additional rules for collection of fines. 
(a)  The city council hereby authorizes and approves collection of payment by execution against the property of the defendant. To that end, the city hereby adopts the provisions of Texas Revised Civil Procedures, Rules 621 to 656 as the same may be from time to time amended hereafter. 
(b)  The city council hereby specifically authorizes and approves the filing of an abstract of judgment to become a lien against the property of the defendant in the same manner and with the same priority as abstracts of other criminal judgments generally and as provided by Texas Revised Civil Statutes Annotated, Property Code, Chapter 52 as the same may be from time to time amended hereafter. 
(c)  The city council specifically authorizes imprisonment to a defendant as a method of enforcement of the collection of fines; provided however, that such imprisonment may only be effectuated in strict accordance with the substantive law of this state and the procedures provided for in this chapter. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision hereof, the city council hereby adopts the provisions of the common law of this state, as the same may now or hereafter exist for the collection and execution of its judgments. 
(Ord. No. 02-158, § 3, 7-16-02)  
Sec. 23-12. - Civil court costs. 
The clerk of the municipal court shall collect the following fees for services rendered to any person: 
(1)  Bond forfeiture proceedings: 
a.  Filing of original action ..... $30.00 
The fee for "filing of original action" is for all clerical duties in connection with an original bond forfeiture proceedings filed in the municipal court. 
(2)  Services rendered after judgment: 
a.  Abstract of judgment ..... 5.00 
b.  Execution or other writ or process, per page ..... 5.00 
(Ord. No. 03-153, § 2, 7-22-03)  
Sec. 23-13. - Juror reimbursement. 
Each person who reports for jury service in the Pasadena Municipal Court is entitled to reimbursement for expenses in the amount of six dollars ($6.00) for each day of jury service. 
(Ord. No. 11-006, § 14, 1-25-11) 
State Law reference— Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Government Code, § 61.001(c).  
Sec. 23-14. - Judges to perform marriages. 
(a)  A municipal court judge may receive, in addition to a salary, all fees or payments for performing marriages. 
(b)  A marriage performed by a municipal judge may be conducted during normal business hours either in chambers or in a courtroom of the municipal court, provided that such marriage does not interfere with the normal workings of the court. 
(c)  A judge may not require the assistance of municipal court personnel to schedule a wedding or to file any papers related thereto, including but not limited to the return of the marriage license. 
(Ord. No. 11-006, § 14, 1-25-11) 
State Law reference— Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Family Code, § 2.202(a)(4).  
Sec. 23-15. - Municipal court technology fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created and recreated a municipal court technology fund. 
(b)  A defendant convicted of a misdemeanor in the municipal court shall be required to pay a technology fee of four dollars ($4.00) as a cost of court. 
(c)  A person is considered convicted if: 
(1)  A sentence is imposed; 
(2)  The person is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication community supervision; 
(3)  The court defers final disposition of the person's case; 
(d)  A fund designated by this article may be used only to finance the purchase of or to maintain technological enhancements for the municipal court, including: 
(1)  Computer systems; 
(2)  Computer networks; 
(3)  Computer hardware; 
(4)  Computer software; 
(5)  Imaging systems; 
(6)  Electronic kiosks; 
(7)  Electronic ticket writers; and 
(8)  Electronic management systems. 
(Ord. No. 11-006, § 14, 1-25-11) 
State Law reference— Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 102.0172.  
Sec. 23-16. - Municipal court building security fund. 
(a)  A defendant convicted of a misdemeanor offense shall pay a three dollar ($3.00) security fee as a cost of court. 
(b)  A person is considered convicted if: 
(1)  A sentence is imposed on the person; 
(2)  The person receives community supervision, including deferred adjudication; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(c)  The clerk of the municipal court shall collect the fee provided for in subsection (a) hereof and pay it to the city controller. 
(d)  Money deposited in the municipal court security fund may be used only for security personnel, services and items related to the building that houses the operations of the municipal court. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, the term "security personnel, services and items" includes: 
(1)  The purchase or repair of X-ray machines and conveying systems; 
(2)  Handheld metal detectors; 
(3)  Walkthrough metal detectors; 
(4)  Identification cards and systems; 
(5)  Electronic locking and surveillance equipment; 
(6)  Bailiffs, deputy sheriffs, deputy constables, or contract security personnel during times when they are providing appropriate security services; 
(7)  Signage; 
(8)  Confiscated weapons inventory and tracking systems; 
(9)  Locks, chains, alarms, or similar security devices; 
(10)  The purchase of bullet-proof glass; and 
(11)  The continuing education on security issues for court personnel and security personnel. 
The municipal court security fund shall be administered by or under, the direction of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 11-006, § 14, 1-25-11) 
State Law reference— Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 102.017.  
Sec. 23-17. - Juvenile case manager fee. 
(a)  There is hereby created within the municipal court the position of juvenile case manager who shall be appointed by the judge of the municipal court, subject to the approval of the council. There shall be such assistant juvenile case managers as may be, from time to time, authorized by the council and appointed by the judge of the municipal court, subject to the approval of the council. The juvenile case manager and assistant juvenile case managers shall perform such duties as may be assigned them from time to time, consistent with the requirements of Article 45.056 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  There is hereby created a juvenile case manager fund that may be used only to finance the salary and benefits of any juvenile case manager employed under 45.056 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. This fund must be administered under the direction of the city council. 
(c)  A defendant convicted of a fine-only misdemeanor offense in the municipal court shall be required to pay a juvenile case manager fee of one dollar ($1.00) as a cost of court in addition to any other fine and costs relating to the case. 
(d)  The clerk of the municipal court shall collect the cost required hereby and pay it to the city controller for the uses described herein and none other. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, a defendant is considered convicted if a sentence is imposed on the defendant or if a defendant receives deferred disposition including deferred proceedings under Article 45.052 or 45.053 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(f)  The judge of the municipal court and each associate judge of the municipal court is authorized to waive the fee required herein in the event of financial hardship. (Ordinance 2005-309, 12-27-05) 
(Ord. No. 11-006, § 14, 1-25-11) 
State Law reference— Tex. Rev. Civ. Stat. Ann., Code Crim. Pro., Art. 102.0174; Art. 45.056.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY MARSHALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 82-205, §§ 2, 5, adopted Aug. 31, 1982, amended § 23-18 to read as herein set out and repealed § 23-19, respectively. Former § 23-18 referred to "warrant officers" rather than "city marshals," and derived from Ord. No. 67-1910, § 1, adopted Feb. 7, 1967; Ord. No. 72-9, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 25, 1972; and Ord. No. 75-191, § 1, adopted Nov. 11, 1975. Former § 23-19, pertaining to service and execution of process, and acknowledgment of noncivil service status, derived from Ord. No. 67-1910, §§ 2, 3, adopted Feb. 7, 1967; Ord. No. 72-9, §§ 1, 3, adopted Jan. 25, 1972; and Ord. No. 80-141, § 1, adopted July 22, 1980. 
Cross reference— Warrant service established in police department, § 30-9.1. 
 
Sec. 23-18. - General provisions. 
(a)  Supervision. The city marshals shall be under the direct supervision of the judge of the municipal court, who shall be in charge of the city marshal division and shall oversee and supervise the city marshals in the execution of their duties. 
(b)  Duties. Each city marshal shall serve and execute warrants of arrest, subpoenas and other legal process issuing out of any municipal court of the city. The city marshals shall also serve subpoenas or other legal process issuing out of the civil service commission, the council, any board, commission, or department requiring legal process for hearings, condemnation hearings, and none other. Each city marshal shall additionally perform such other and further duties as may be assigned by the judge of the municipal court. 
(c)  Qualification; certification. Each city marshal shall meet the qualifications for certification as a peace officer as established by the Texas Commission of Law Enforcement Officer Standards and Education pursuant to Article 4413(29aa), Texas Revised Civil Statutes Annotated, and shall seek and receive such peace officer certification within the time prescribed by Article 4413(29aa), Texas Revised Civil Statutes Annotated, as a necessary condition for continued employment as a city marshal. 
(d)  As peace officers. Each city marshal shall serve as a peace officer and shall have full police authority in the exercise of his assigned duties. 
(e)  Distinct from police department. No city marshal is a regular member of the police department of the city within the meaning of the state laws governing such department as to civil service, minimum wages, hours of employment or pension. Neither shall any city marshal be a paid law enforcement officer for the purposes of and within the meaning of Article 6228f of Texas Revised Civil Statutes Annotated. 
(f)  Regular police service of process. Nothing herein provided shall prevent or in anyway inhibit any regular police officer of the City of Pasadena from serving or executing any process issuing out of any municipal court which may be placed in his hands to be served or executed. 
(Ord. No. 82-205, § 2, 8-31-82; Ord. No. 89-153, § 1, 9-5-89)  
Sec. 23-19. - Reserved. 
Note— See the editor's note to Art. II.  
Chapter 23½ - OIL AND GAS WELLS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 72-157, adopted June 20, 1972, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion of §§ 1—5 herein as Ch. 23½, §§ 23½-1—23½-5, was at the discretion of the editors. Secs. 6 and 7 of said ordinance, validity and effective date provisions, were omitted from codification. 
Cross reference— Payment of taxes prerequisite for obtaining license or permit, § 26-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 23½-1. - Purpose of chapter. 
The city council finds that there has been and there is a likelihood of additional drilling and production operations for oil and gas within the corporate limits of the city requiring that operations for the drilling and production of oil and gas within such area be regulated because of the fire hazards created by such operations, as well as the menace of falling derricks, unsanitary conditions, contaminated water supply and all similar and like threats to the lives, property, health, safety and welfare of the public in general, for which the police power of the state delegated to this city is to be and is hereby invoked in aid of the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 72-157, § 1, 6-20-72)  
Sec. 23½-2. - Permit for drilling. 
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, acting either for himself or as an agent, employee, independent contractor, or servant of any other person, to commence to drill, or to operate any well for the production of oil, gas, or other hydrocarbons within the corporate limits of the City of Pasadena, or to work upon or assist in any way in the prosecution or operation of any such well, without a permit for the drilling and operation of such well having first been issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Each day during which a person violates any portion of this section shall constitute a separate offense, which said offense shall be punished by a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 72-157, § 2, 6-20-72)  
Sec. 23½-3. - Location of oil and gas wells near buildings prohibited. 
No well for the production of oil, gas, or other hydrocarbons shall be drilled and no permit shall be issued for any such well to be drilled in any location which is nearer than four hundred (400) feet from any residential or commercial building containing more than six hundred (600) square feet of floor space without the applicant's having first secured the written permission of the owner or owners thereof. 
(Ord. No. 72-157, § 3, 6-20-72)  
Sec. 23½-4. - Location of oil and gas wells on public property prohibited. 
No well for the production of oil, gas, or other hydrocarbons shall be drilled within any of the streets or alleys, parks, or other public property. 
(Ord. No. 72-157, § 4, 6-20-72)  
Sec. 23½-5. - Application for permit to drill an oil or gas well. 
(a)  Any person desiring to drill a well for the production of oil, gas, or other hydrocarbons within the corporate limits of the City of Pasadena shall present a written application for permit to drill, in duplicate, to the director of planning and traffic of the City of Pasadena. Such application shall include: 
(1)  A map or plat showing the well location with reference to a tract or tracts described by metes and bounds, or with reference to Lambert Coordinates, and all streets, alleys, parks, public property, and buildings, commercial or residential, having more than six hundred (600) square feet of floor space located within one thousand (1,000) square feet of the proposed well head; and 
(2)  A duly verified statement by the applicant that the proposed well location is not within a public street, alley, park or other property, and that either the proposed well head is not nearer than four hundred (400) feet from any residential or commercial building containing more than six hundred (600) square feet of floor space or that written permission has been obtained from the owner or owners of every such building within four hundred (400) feet of the proposed well location; and 
(3)  Copies of all written permissions obtained, if any; and 
(4)  A cashiers check in the amount of twenty-five and no/100 dollars ($25.00) made payable to the City of Pasadena, which shall be a filing fee, and shall cover the cost of investigating and verifying the statements contained in the application. 
(b)  The director of planning and traffic shall keep one copy of each application and the report of his investigation thereof as part of the permanent records of the city. A permit shall be issued upon a finding by the said director that all material statements in the application are true and correct and that the proposed well will violate no provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 72-157, § 5, 6-20-72)  
Chapter 24 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city to establish, maintain and regulate public parks, Art. I, § 4. 
Cross reference— Duties of planning and zoning commission relative to parks, § 28-41; littering parks, § 14-19; limitation on parking of mobile homes in parks, § 21-2; speed limit in parks, § 36-145; beautification commission, § 2-180; senior citizens' commission, § 2-191 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 24-1. - Department of parks and recreation created. 
There is hereby created and recreated within the municipal government a department of parks and recreation. There are hereby created in the department of parks and recreation the following divisions and subdivisions: 
(1)  Parks —#454 
(2)  Recreation —#490 
(Code 1964, § 19-1; Ord. No. 81-4, § 1, 1-13-81; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-1.1. - Position classifications, salary grades, numbers, career codes. 
There shall exist in the department of recreation and the divisions thereof such position classifications, salary grades, numbers and career codes as are set forth at Exhibit "A", attached hereto and incorporated herein for all purposes. [2] 
(Ord. No. 81-4, § 1, 1-13-81) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Exhibit "A" referred to in section 24-1.1 is not set out herein, but said exhibit and subsequent amendments thereto are on file and available for inspection in the office of the city secretary. 
 
Sec. 24-2. - Office of director of parks and recreation created; appointment of director. 
The office of director of parks and recreation is hereby created. The director shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation and approval by the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 1902; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84) 
Cross reference— Bond for director of parks and recreation, § 2-5.  
Sec. 24-3. - Director to be head of department; general powers and duties. 
(a)  Except as may otherwise be directed by action of the city council, the director of parks and recreation shall have general supervision of all public parks and shall further be charged with the duty of planning and supervising the recreational activities which may be sponsored and supervised by the city. The director shall have such further duties as may be prescribed by the council. 
(b)  The director shall be the head of the department of parks and recreation and all officers and employees assigned thereto whose duties shall be performed subject to the supervision of the director. In addition to the specific powers and duties prescribed by this article, the director shall engage in such other executive functions and perform such other duties as are assigned by the mayor and city council by ordinance to the department. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the director of parks and recreation to direct, control and manage all parks, parkways, recreational facilities [public golf courses], and improvements on park and recreation property belonging to or under the control of the city and such other grounds and facilities as may be placed under his control by the mayor and city council, and to direct the improvement and maintenance of all such properties. 
(d)  The director of parks and recreation shall have the power, subject to the approval of the mayor and city council, to prescribe rules and regulations for the orderly government and use of all parks and recreational parkways and improvements on park and recreation property, and assess deposits, user fees, registration fees, admission fees and rental fees; provided all existing rules and regulations heretofore established in accordance with the law shall be continued in force until changed in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(e)  Subject to the approval of the mayor and city council, the director may make such rules and regulations for the administration of the affairs of the department of parks and recreation he shall see proper, provided such rules are not in conflict with existing laws or ordinances. 
(Code 1964, § 19-3; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 78-212, § 4, adopted Dec. 26, 1978, repealed § 24-4, pertaining to the office of the park superintendent, derived from Code 1964, § 19-4.  
Sec. 24-5. - City parks closing times. 
(a)  The following city parks shall be closed except as provided in subsection (c) below to the public in the event at sundown and shall remain closed until 6:00 a.m. the following day: Asbury, Bliss Meadows, Bramley, Cascade, Community, Crane, Deepwater, El Jardin, Friendship Gardens, Gardens No. 1, Ghana Playlot, Golden Acres, Johnson, Light Co., Oaks Drive Playlot, Olson, Parkview, Parkgate North, Parklane Playlot, Pasadena Boulevard, Pasadena Highlands, Pine, Queens, Revelon, Rusk, Sherwood, South, Tatar, T.J. Cross, Vermillion, Yellowstone, and Bowling Green. 
(b)  The following city parks shall be closed to the public in the evening at 11:00 p.m. and shall remain closed except as provided in subsection (c) below until 6:00 a.m. the following day: Ben Briar, Burke/Crenshaw, Deepwater Optimist, East Southmore, Fairmont, Gardens No. 2, Hollybay Court, Memorial, Red Bluff, Satsuma, Strawberry, and Sunset. 
(c)  City parks that have gates to be unlocked for entry to the park shall remain closed until 6:30 a.m. rather than 6:00 a.m. as provided above. 
(Ord. No. 94-31, § 1, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 1, 3-24-98)  
Sec. 24-5.1. - Being in parks when closed prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be in a city park during the time the park is closed to the public. 
(Ord. No. 94-31, § 1, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 1, 3-24-98)  
Sec. 24-5.2. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates the provisions of section 24-5.1 above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 94-31, § 1, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 1, 3-24-98)  
Sec. 24-5.3. - Authority to install signs. 
The director of the department of parks and recreation shall have the authority to place, erect, and maintain signs specifying the times city parks are open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 94-31, § 1, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 98-49, § 1, 3-24-98)  
Sec. 24-6. - Riding or driving animals in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any horse, mule or livestock of any character, upon, over or across the grounds of any public park, playground or other recreational facility in the city. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit riders of horses or mules from riding or driving along roadways, driveways or streets through park grounds. 
(Code 1964, § 19-5; Ord. No. 71-139, § 1, 5-25-71) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 71-139, § 1, amended Code 1964, § 19-5, codified herein as § 24-6, by deleting provisions applicable to riding or driving vehicles in public parks. 
Cross reference— Animals generally, Ch. 6.  
Sec. 24-6.1. - Riding or driving motor vehicles upon public lands. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive a motor vehicle, as herein defined, upon, over or across the grounds of any public park, playground or other recreational facility; or upon any esplanade within the city limits of the City of Pasadena. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit riding or driving any vehicle licensed by the State of Texas along roadways, driveways or streets through park grounds. "Motor vehicles," as used herein, shall mean any vehicle which is, or can be, self-propelled. 
(Ord. No. 71-139, § 2, 5-25-71) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 71-139, § 2, amended Code 1964 by adding the provisions codified herein as §§ 24-6.1 and 24-6.2. 
Cross reference— Speed limit for vehicles in parks, § 36-145.  
Sec. 24-6.2. - Penalty for violation of sections 24-6 and 24-6.1. 
Any person who shall violate the provisions of sections 24-6 and 24-6.1, above, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 71-139, § 2, 5-25-71; Ord. No. 90-128, § 2, 7-24-90) 
Note— See the editor's note following § 24-6.1.  
Sec. 24-7. - Injuring, defacing, etc., park or recreation property. 
No person shall injure, deface, mar or destroy any park property, or property owned by or used by the recreation department. 
(Code 1964, § 19-6)  
Sec. 24-7.1. - Glass receptacles—Prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into or upon any park or playground, or into or upon any other public ground under the jurisdiction and control of the department of parks and recreation, or have in his or her possession or under his or her care, custody and control while therein or thereupon, any glass receptacle, including, but not limited to, glass bottles, glass jars, drinking glasses and glass containers of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 80-264, § 1, 11-12-80)  
Sec. 24-7.2. - Same—Penalty for violation of section 24-7.1. 
Any person who shall violate the provisions of section 24-7.1 above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 80-264, § 1, 11-12-80; Ord. No. 90-128, § 2, 7-24-90)  
Sec. 24-7.3. - Same—Authority to install warning signs. 
The director of the department of parks and recreation shall place, erect, and maintain signs prohibiting the conduct proscribed by Section 24-7.1 upon or at the entrance to the park or playground or part thereof affected as may be most appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 80-264, § 1, 11-12-80)  
Sec. 24-8. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited in certain public recreational facilities; penalty. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverages shall be permitted to be sold, possessed, carried onto or consumed on the premises of public parks and recreational facilities or public golf courses with the exception of the Pasadena Fairgrounds and the Pasadena Municipal Golf Course. It is the specific intent of this section that the term "premises" include any and all parking facilities adjacent to said recreational facilities that are owned, operated or controlled by the City of Pasadena. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision hereof shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction in a court of competent jurisdiction shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 76-65, §§ 1, 2, 4-13-76; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84; Ord. No. 90-128, § 2, 7-24-90)  
Secs. 24-9—24-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sections 24-9—24-11 were repealed by § 1 of Ord. No. 84-115, enacted June 19, 1984. Said former sections were derived from Ord. No. 78-212, § 1, enacted Dec. 26, 1978; and pertained to the creation of the parks department; creation of the office of the director, his appointment and term; and appointing the director to be the head of the parks department and describing his general powers and duties.  
Sec. 24-12. - Authority over trees, shrubs, plants. 
The department of parks and recreation and the director of parks and recreation shall be clothed with authority over all trees, shrubs and plants of any kind and character which are now or may hereafter be planted in or along the street medians or other public places of the city, the department and director being vested with full power, authority and jurisdiction over all planting of every kind and character lying outside of the property lines of privately owned property. It is hereby made the duty of such department and director to direct, regulate and encourage the planting, culture and preservation of shade and ornamental trees and plants on the street medians and public places of the city; to direct, regulate and encourage the pruning, spraying, cultivation and maintenance of such trees and plants, and to direct the time and method of pruning and trimming the same; to remove or cause to be removed any tree or plant, or other obstruction which, in their judgment, would interfere with the development of adjoining trees or plants or with the free use of the streets or sidewalks; to advise property owners with respect to the kind of trees to plant or shrubbery desired on the particular street and the method of planting the same; to take all such measures as may be deemed necessary or desirable to control all dangerous insects, pests and plant diseases which may affect trees or shrubbery on the street medians or other public places in the city; to devise plans for the planting of trees on and along the street medians within the city where trees may be desirable; to prescribe the character, kind, size, space and position of all trees so planted upon or along street medians or other public places; to prevent the planting of trees, shrubs or other plants not in their judgment desirable or proper; and to plant or cause to be planted such trees along such street medians or other public places as such department may deem proper. 
The land that may be selected, obtained or acquired by the city for use as parks or parkways shall be used exclusively for park purposes. 
(Ord. No. 78-212, § 1, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)

ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-54, §§ 1—13, adopted Oct. 16, 1979, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been codified as Art. I¾, §§ 24-15—24-15.12, at the editor's discretion. 
 
Sec. 24-15. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created and established, within and for the city, the City of Pasadena Parks and Recreation Commission, composed of eleven (11) members appointed by the mayor, whose offices are hereby created and established as an advisory commission to assist and advise the city council on the proper operation of Pasadena's parks and recreational facilities. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 1, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.1. - Qualifications of members. 
Each member of the commission shall be a resident citizen and a qualified voter of the city. Any member who ceases to hold all such qualifications shall, ipso facto upon each cessation, terminate his membership, subject only to written approval by the mayor filed with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 2, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.2. - Appointment and terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  All members of the parks and recreation commission shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. 
(b)  The chairman, vice-chairman and three (3) of the parks and recreation commissioners who are first so appointed shall be designated to serve for terms of two (2) years; and the remaining commissioners shall be designated to serve for a term of one year, respectively, from the date of their appointment, but thereafter, commissioners shall be appointed as aforesaid for a term of office of two (2) years, unless sooner terminated. 
(c)  All vacancies in membership of the commission for any reason shall be filled by the mayor for the unexpired terms as soon as practicable after the position becomes vacant (subject to confirmation by city council). 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 3, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.3. - Members to serve without compensation. 
The members of the parks and recreation commission, in the performance of their official duties, shall serve without compensation for office. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 4, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.4. - Officers designated. 
The officers of the commission shall consist of a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary. The mayor is directed to appoint appropriate ex officio members of the commission. The director of parks and recreation shall serve as the executive officer of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 5, 10-16-79; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-15.5. - Election and terms of officers. 
The chairman and the vice-chairman shall be appointed by the mayor, and the secretary of the commission shall be nominated by the members of the commission in such manner as the commission shall prescribe at its first meeting as a committee of the whole. The secretary shall be elected by a majority vote of the qualified and serving members of the commission. The terms of all offices shall be concurrent and limited within the terms of the officer's commission membership appointment. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 6, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.6. - Attendance at meetings. 
The commission may establish its own rules as to attendance of its members at meetings and, in furtherance of such, the commission may, by a majority vote, expel any member who, in the opinion of the commission, misses an unreasonable number of meetings. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 7, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.7. - Procedure. 
The commission is hereby empowered to establish its own parliamentary procedure, provided that such shall not be in conflict with the City Charter or other provisions of law, or the following: A quorum shall consist of a majority of the entire membership of the commission, and any issue to be voted on shall be resolved by those members present. The chairman shall be entitled to vote upon any issue, but shall have no veto power. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 8, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.8. - Authority to advise the mayor. 
Said parks and recreation commission is hereby authorized to work with the mayor and make recommendations to the mayor about any matter that it deems beneficial to the administration; provided, that such functions shall not contravene the City Charter or any other law and such shall be considered advisory only. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 9, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.9. - General powers and duties. 
In relation to the functions of the parks and recreational programs within the City of Pasadena, the commission shall be authorized to, for final approval to the mayor and city council: 
(a)  Advise and make recommendations for the use of said parks and recreational programs and facilities of the City of Pasadena to enhance the quality of the recreational environment of the city. 
(b)  Advise and recommend format of all lease agreements and other agreements between users of the recreational facilities and the City of Pasadena, including a survey of fees recommended for the use thereof. 
(c)  Recommend rules and regulations for the use and enjoyment of the recreational facilities of the city and to decide appeals from the decisions of the director of parks and recreation on rule violation or discipline. 
(d)  Make and, from time to time, amend and repeal bylaws, subject to approval of the city council. 
(e)  Advise and make recommendations regarding the need for additional parks and facilities. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 10, 10-16-79; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-15.10. - Obligation of city. 
The parks and recreation commission shall have no power to obligate the city in any manner whatsoever; its finances shall be administered in the same manner as any department of the city government. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 11, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.11. - Coordinator. 
An official of the city designated by the mayor shall serve as coordinator for the commission and shall prepare materials for distribution and conduct such other business of the commission as may be assigned. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 12, 10-16-79)  
Sec. 24-15.12. - Finances; rights of commission. 
The city council declares its purpose and intention (but does not in any way obligate itself or attempt to obligate any future city council) to, from time to time, appropriate and cause to be paid over to the commission (or upon commission's recommendation) such sums as the council may deem proper and appropriate to aid in defraying the expenses of operation, maintenance and development. 
By virtue of this article, there shall not be vested in the commission or in the members of the commission any right except it be subject to termination by the city by repeal or amendment of this article or other appropriate action of its governing body. 
(Ord. No. 79-54, § 13, 10-16-79)  
Secs. 24-16, 24-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PARK FIRE RINGS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 13. 
 
Sec. 24-18. - Established. 
The parks and recreation director is hereby authorized to establish fireburning facilities in city parks including barbecue pits and fire rings. 
(Ord. No. 1803, § 1, 4-26-66; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-19. - Use permit—Required. 
A permit from the parks and recreation director shall be required for the use of a park fire ring, and it shall be unlawful for any person to use such fire ring without a permit. Such permit must be obtained from the director at his office at Strawberry Park at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the use of such fire ring. 
(Ord. No. 67-1947, § 1, 5-23-67; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-20. - Same—Issuance or denial. 
The parks and recreation director shall determine whether an applicant for a permit for the use of the park fire ring is qualified to receive such permit, and the director shall not issue a permit if in his judgment an applicant is not so qualified. No such permit shall be issued unless it is first established that an employee of the parks and recreation department will be present at or in the vicinity of the fire ring during its proposed use, and able to supervise such use. 
(Ord. No. 67-1947, § 1, 5-23-67; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-21. - Same—Revocation. 
Any permit issued pursuant to section 24-20 may be revoked without notice, if the parks and recreation director, or his agents or employees, shall determine that a fire permitted by such permit is being flared in an unsafe manner, or if adverse weather conditions prevail at the time the fire is permitted, or if the permittee fails to follow accepted or prescribed safety precautions at the flaring of the fire. 
(Ord. No. 67-1947, § 1, 5-23-67)  
Sec. 24-22. - Use regulations. 
The fire marshal shall and is hereby directed to publish regulations regarding the building of fires in the park fire ring. Copies of such regulations shall be furnished to the parks and recreation director to be distributed to applicants for permits to use such fire ring. In establishing such regulations, the fire marshal shall include, but not be limited to, the following conditions for the use of the park fire ring: 
(1)  Only responsible persons shall be allowed in the fire ring at any time and the director, his agents or employees, at his or their discretion, may require the reduction of the number of persons in the fire ring at any time. 
(2)  At least one (1) five-gallon container of water must be inside the fire ring at all times. 
(3)  Any extra wood or fuel supply furnished by parties using the ring must be kept outside of the fire ring. 
(4)  Fire materials shall not exceed one (1) foot, eight (8) inches, in height or three (3) feet in diameter. 
(5)  No type of lighting fluid shall be sprayed on the fire before, during or after the fire has been built. 
(6)  A person approved by the director, his agent or employee, must guard a permitted fire at all times. 
(7)  No pressurized type of can or container shall be placed near or in the fire. 
(8)  No person shall wear dangling articles of clothing or other materials while working at the fire. 
(9)  The fire must be completely extinguished before the permittee leaves the site. Extinguishment with water and the spreading of coals is permissible. The director or his agent or employee shall, in all instances, be the final judge as to the proper extinguishment of any fire in the fire ring. 
(10)  The fire ring area must be cleared of litter and debris prior to the permittee's leaving. 
(11)  One (1) responsible adult shall be present for every eight (8) minors at all times during use of the fire ring. 
(12)  All fires must be extinguished by 9:00 p.m. and the same shall be checked by the director, his agents or employees, at that time. No fires may be lit in the park area before 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 67-1947, 5-23-67; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-23. - Suspension of use privileges. 
In addition to the general penalty provided by section 1-7 of this Code, the building of a fire in a park without a permit from the parks and recreation director, or in violation of safety rules promulgated by the fire marshal, may result in a suspension, for one year of the privilege of the group or individual involved to use the park fire ring, at the discretion of the fire marshal or the parks and recreation director. 
(Ord. No. 67-1947, § 3, 5-23-67; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Secs. 24-24—24-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MUNICIPAL FAIRGROUNDS AND CIVIC/CONVENTION CENTER COMPLEX[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), adopted March 15, 2011, amended article IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article IV, §§ 24-31—24-43, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 88-147, §§ 2, 3, 8-16-88; Ord. No. 94-1, § 7, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 94-7, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 94-164, §§ 2—4, 8-30-94; Ord. No. 98-52, §§ 1—5, 3-31-98; Ord. No. 00-22, § 1, 2-22-00; Ord. No. 00-24, § 1, 2-29-00; Ord. No. 04-187, §§ 2, 3, 8-31-04; Ord. No. 07-89, §§ 2—4, 4-3-07. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 24-31. - Name of the facility. 
That tract of land containing 105.817 acres of land, more or less, fronting on Red Bluff and Fairmont Parkway in the City of Pasadena, heretofore commonly known as the "Rodeo Grounds" is hereby officially designated "The Municipal Fairgrounds and Civic/Convention Center Complex", hereafter called the "facility". 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
Sec. 24-32. - Definitions and general authority of the director of the convention center and municipal fairgrounds relative to signing of agreement. 
Definitions: 
Additional time. Any time before or after scheduled event time; also defined in Section 2.02 of the Occupancy Agreement. 
Agreement means the Occupancy Agreement. 
Arena Complex. The Ross Kelley Rodeo Arena and south parking lot area that enters and exits from Red Bluff Road. 
Barbeque Pavilion or Cowboy Pavilion. Covered and fenced area at the south of the property with a concrete floor and lighting. 
City. City of Pasadena, Texas. 
Catering fee. The fee that is payable to the Pasadena Convention Center. 
Concert/festival. Event may include concert, various tents and stages with entertainment, food vendors, commercial booths, arts and crafts booths, carnival attractions, and/or cook-offs. 
Confetti. Natural flower petals, silk or synthetic flower petals, rice, birdseed, Silly String, small packaged items, small sparkly items, small paper cutouts, small mylar cutouts, any small cutout or torn up particles of any substance that is usually thrown or used for table decorations, or for festive occasions. 
Director. The Director of the Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds, General Manager, or any person designated by the Director. 
Excessive clean-up. Excessive clean-up is any service beyond normal, routine janitorial services. Examples include but are not limited to: Large amounts of trash and boxes left on floors (anything larger than what can be swept into a commercial dustpan); cleaning ground-in substances or food off tables or chairs; numerous spilled beverages; large amounts of trash left in bleachers; numerous instances of spilled substances that must be wiped or cleaned with cleaning solutions; large amounts of cans or bottles; pallets; crates; stains to any carpeting or other floor surfacing; tape residue left on any surface; balloons left floating on the ceiling; cleaning up confetti; any damage that requires extraordinary care; clean up and disposal of any grease, oil, chemicals, or bodily fluids; clean up of any graffiti or paint; clean up of mischievous acts; clean up of any coating or residue left in booth; and clean up of hazardous substances or bio-hazards. 
Event. A performance, meeting, exhibit, show, or any other occurrence sponsored or promoted by the occupant, which is described in Section 2.01 of the Occupancy Agreement. 
Event day. Consecutive twenty-four-hour period, 12:00 a.m.—11:59 p.m. 
FFA Pavilion. The covered pavilion and structure with a sand floor that is attached to the Pasadena Livestock Show and Rodeo Association's offices and is used for the Future Farmer's of America (aka FFA) livestock show area. 
Facility. The location identified as the Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds which encompasses all 100+ acres and any and all buildings, offices, barns, arenas, fences, structures, fixtures, pavilions, and equipment located on said premises. Addresses to include 7902 Fairmont Parkway, 7600 Red Bluff Road, 7601 Red Bluff Road, and 7603 Red Bluff Road, located in Pasadena, Texas 77507. 
Force majeure shall include but not be limited to: Acts of God, acts of the public enemy, war, blockades, insurrections, riots, epidemics, landslides, lightning, earthquakes, fires, storms, floods, washouts, tornadoes, hurricanes, arrests, and restraints of governments and people, explosions, power outages, and any other inability of either party, whether similar to those enumerated or otherwise that is not within the control of the party claiming such inability and which such party could not have avoided by the exercise of due diligence and care. 
Midway. the paved road that runs from the back of the Pasadena Convention Center to the Ross Kelley Rodeo Arena. 
Occupant. Approved applicant who has entered into an Occupancy Agreement with the Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds and has submitted required deposit(s) and rental fees; provided, however, the term shall not include any person whose Occupancy Agreement has been terminated or canceled. 
PCC. Abbreviation for the Pasadena Convention Center. 
PLS&R. Abbreviation for the Pasadena Livestock Show and Rodeo Association. 
Period of occupancy. That period of time specified in Section 2.02 of the Occupancy Agreement. 
Premises. The location identified as "premises" in Section 2.01 of the Occupancy Agreement as it pertains to the occupant or the entire premises known as the Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds. 
Rental fee. The fee paid by the occupant for the use of the facility as noted in Section 3.01 of the Occupancy Agreement. 
Reservation application. Form completed by the potential occupant to include, but not be limited to contact information, event details, and requesting specific dates. 
Reservation request. Event date requested by the potential occupant. 
Security deposit. A deposit to cover any miscellaneous fees (tables, chairs, etc.) and/or damages incurred due to the event. 
Special provisions. Any necessary additions regarding provisions which are peculiar to an event. 
Strawberry festival offices. Also known as the San Jacinto Day Foundation Offices. 
Authority of the director. The Director of the Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds or his designee is hereby authorized and empowered to pass upon applications for the rental of the facilities, including but not limited to, the convention center parking lot, the rodeo arena, the stockpens, the closed exhibit hall, the open exhibit hall, the cook-off area, the midway, the recreational vehicle areas, the barbecue pavilion and private park, and the general premises of the facility, and to determine the rate of rental to be charged to applicants in accordance with the schedule of rentals provided for in this article. In the event of any ambiguous definitions, terms, or conflicts within this article, the director is hereby authorized to interpret the ordinance in the best interest of the city. 
The director or his designee is hereby authorized to sign written agreements on behalf of the city with persons renting the facilities embraced in this article, in such form including such terms, conditions and stipulations as written and approved by the city legal department in accordance with this article. The director has the authority to adjust rental rates according to industry standards. The director may or may not refuse to rent portions of the facility if it could result in loss of revenue. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11; Ord. No. 15-168, § 1, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 24-32.1. - Occupancy Agreements; general provisions. 
The Occupancy Agreement shall be executed after occupant has received and filed with the director or his designee a reservation application. No oral agreement for the use of the facilities shall be valid. All set-up information, in and out times, actual event times, and electrical requirements shall be submitted at Occupancy Agreement execution. Due to staffing and scheduling requirements, these times are of the essence and must be strictly adhered to by the Occupant. Any changes after this time are subject to late fees or change order fees. All electrical changes made less than two weeks before the event are subject to increased rates for electrical services or equipment. 
Nonprofit groups as defined in section 24-35.1 of this article may pay fifty (50) per cent of the standard rental rates for the space rented. Exceptions are electrical rates which are to be charged as standard rates. Rental equipment and any other fees that may apply are to be charged at the fifty (50) per cent rate. 
The statement of policies shall agree with this ordinance and the Occupancy Agreement approved herein. If the policy conflicts with any of the terms of this article, then only that portion that conflicts ceases to be operable and the remainder of the policy is in full effect and enforceable. 
The City of Pasadena shall be entitled to all remedies available at law and in equity and maximum allowable interest with penalties for failure to comply with the requirements of this article as contained herein.

In the event of excessive janitorial services, the director or his designee reserves the right to deduct additional cleaning charges from the security deposit.

(6)  Holiday rates: Holiday rates will be in effect for events booked on city holidays. Holiday rentals are at the discretion of the director and availability of staff. There will be a fifty (50) per cent mark-up on the regular rental rate when an event is booked on a holiday. Holiday rates are applicable to both profit and nonprofit organizations. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
Sec. 24-33. - Refusal to rent or cancellation of agreement. 
The director reserves the right to refuse to rent any facilities embraced in this article, or to cancel any Occupancy Agreement so made and such refusal or cancellation will be not be considered default on the part of the city, whenever in its opinion the agreement is not in the best interest of the city. The director is authorized to make a determination regarding the refusal or cancellation in the case of a force majeure, anticipation of a force majeure, damages arising from a force majeure, or any other incident or emergency that may be of concern to public safety. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
Sec. 24-34. - Security deposit of occupant. 
A security deposit in any sum not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the exact amount to be fixed by the director or his designee in each instance of the rental of the facilities in this article shall be furnished by any and all persons leasing the facility, or a part thereof, conditioned upon the return of the facility, or part thereof, to the city in as good condition, reasonable wear and tear excepted, as the same was in when possession was delivered to the occupant; and provided further, the city shall be entitled to deduct from the occupant's deposit any amount necessary to cover damages to the city's buildings or facilities, the cost of necessary clean-up, and any other outstanding obligations. The occupant shall remain liable to the city for any balance not covered by said deposit. The security deposit must be paid no later than thirty (30) business days prior to the event. Events that schedule multiple events throughout the year may have the option of keeping a security deposit on file with the city. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11; Ord. No. 15-168, § 2, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 24-35. - Reservation of facility, booking procedure, payment, and fees. 
The complex, or any part thereof, subject to separate rental, may be reserved for any unscheduled date(s) upon the payment of a reservation deposit. Any applicant may reserve a tentative date no more than two (2) years in advance, for the use of the facility or any portion thereof subject to separate rental, provided that the applicant submits a deposit in the amount of twenty-five (25) per cent of the rental rate along with the application. One hundred twenty (120) days prior to the rental date, the Occupancy Agreement will be sent to the applicant. The signed Occupancy Agreement and twenty-five (25) per cent of the total rental rate shall be returned to the city within fifteen (15) business days of the Occupancy Agreement origination date or the date(s) will be canceled. The balance of the rental rate must be paid thirty (30) calendar days before the day of the move-in or the event day. The director or his designee may require special fees for the balance of other special rental charges in advance or may invoice the occupant after the final day of the event. In the event of cancellation by the occupant, all monies paid by the occupant as a deposit on a rental shall become the property of the City of Pasadena and shall not be refundable. Exceptions may be made on a case-by-case basis upon proof of extreme hardships or circumstances and at the discretion of the director. All rental fees shall be paid in lawful monies of the United States by cash, company check, personal check, cashier's check, credit card charge, or U.S. Money Order. All payment of federal, state, county or city taxes and licenses in connection with any attraction shall be the responsibility of the occupant. 
No refunds will be made to an occupant if it becomes necessary for a occupant to cancel the Occupancy Agreement for the date in question, or if the occupant fails to utilize all of the space rented. 
A second applicant may challenge such tentative date by depositing fifty (50) per cent of the rental rate and executing a tentative Occupancy Agreement if the first applicant does not have fifty (50) per cent of the rental rate on deposit and a signed Occupancy Agreement. The director or his designee shall give the first applicant two (2) days to verbally commit to using the date being challenged and fifteen (15) business days to return an executed Occupancy Agreement along with the balance of fifty (50) per cent of the rental rate. After such notice, and if the first applicant does not comply, the date shall be open for rental to the second applicant. 
The mayor, by written direction to the Director of the Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds, may, at his discretion, waive all or part of any fees regarding the usage of the facilities if the event is sponsored or co-sponsored by the city and it is in the best interest of the city. 
The director may make changes to fees based on industry standards, if it is in the best interest of the city, and if it is to accommodate and/or generate more business and revenues for the city. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
Sec. 24-35.1. - Nonprofit organization requirements and sponsorship policy. 
(a)  Any entity requesting consideration as a nonprofit organization shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Shall be an established nonprofit organization or corporation approved by and registered with the State of Texas or any other state within the United States of America; and 
(2)  Shall provide a needed service to the community and/or donate monies for scholarships to city programs and local schools; and 
(3)  Shall be required to follow all other policies and procedures related to the leasing of convention center and municipal fairgrounds facilities. 
(b)  Organizations that qualify as nonprofit, by meeting all of the above stated requirements, may apply for the following concessions when renting with the understanding that customers paying standard rates may be given priority for use of city facilities: 
(1)  Payment of fifty (50) per cent of the city standard rental fee. 
(2)  Table, chair, and stage setup and rental may be waived at the discretion of the director. 
(3)  Non-profit organizations shall pay standard electrical charges for booths. 
(4)  All catering charges shall be paid to the city's caterer. Catering charges must be negotiated with caterer under contract with the city. Outside caterers are prohibited unless approved by the director. 
(5)  Alcoholic beverages sales shall be provided by the city's contracted caterer. 
(6)  All contracted catering references apply to the convention center only. Catered meals and alcoholic beverages may be provided by outside caterers if events are held in facilities other than the convention center. Nonprofit organizations will pay fifty (50) per cent of all established fees relating to catered events in facilities other than the convention center. 
(c)  A function sponsored by the City of Pasadena may have all fees waived. 
(1)  Organizations seeking a sponsorship agreement for an event shall provide a letter of request clearly stating the event's purpose and any benefits the city and/or community may expect to receive as a result of the sponsorship. 
(2)  The mayor and/or his designee may make findings and if approved enter into written sponsorship agreements which fulfill a public purpose as determined by the city council; such purposes may include but not be limited to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Pasadena, economic development and education which directly benefit the city and/or community. 
(3)  The mayor and/or his designee shall confirm in writing that the promised benefit has been delivered to the city and/or community. 
(d)  The nonprofit organization shall also meet all security requirements. The City of Pasadena Police Department shall have first right of refusal for any and all security duties that may be required. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11; Ord. No. 15-168, § 3, 12-15-15)  
Sec. 24-35.2. - Temporary wiring and other technical requirements for events. 
(a)  Application of section. The provisions of this section shall apply to all use of electrical current for the purpose of illuminating, animating, activating or displaying in connection with temporary expositions, exhibits, shows, conventions, meetings or assemblies in the facilities embraced in this article. Temporary shall be deemed to indicate a use not to exceed ten (10) calendar days. The use of temporary wiring shall be limited to locations which are determined to be suitable and safe for the intended occupancy and use. 
(b)  Licensed electricians to do work. It shall be unlawful for any person other than a duly licensed master electrician, or a duly licensed journeyman electrician working under the direct supervision of the City of Pasadena Electrical Division, and subject to inspection and approval by the same division, to make any electrical installation of any appliance, fixtures, signs or equipment in any booth, temporary exhibits or the facilities' electrical systems. No installations or connections to any city-owned devices shall be made without prior consent of the City of Pasadena Electrical Division and/or City of Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds Department. 
(c)  Technical requirements. 
(1)  All exposed noncurrent-carrying metal parts of the electrical installation shall be effectively grounded. 
(2)  Flexible cord or cable shall be approved for extra hard usage. No individual conductor shall be permitted to be installed unless installed in an approved raceway. 
(3)  No conductor shall be fused or protected at a rating greater than its amp capacity. 
(4)  All branch circuits shall be protected by fuses or circuit breakers. 
(5)  All fuses or circuit breakers shall be installed in approved enclosure or cabinets. 
(6)  There shall be no exposed live metal parts. 
(7)  All electrical equipment or appliances connected to the building electrical system or extensions thereto in booths or displays shall comply with the National Electrical Standards adopted by the Building Code of the City of Pasadena. 
(8)  All cords, whether flexible or otherwise, shall be of a three-wire grounded-type cord of not less than No. 14 gauge wire. 
(9)  No extension cord shall extend more than one hundred (100) feet from its point of attachment to power supply. Any cord which must exceed this distance shall, upon approval by the city, not be less than a No. 12 gauge wire and also a three-wire grounded-type cord, s.o., s.j.o., or equivalent. 
(10)  No two-wire extension cords are permitted. Two-wire lamp cords or zip cord shall be permitted only if the cord is attached to a factory-wired light fixture, and said fixture carries an Underwriter's Laboratory seal of approval. 
(11)  Any moon walk, air inflatable type attractions similar to moon walks, water blow-up inflatable that children or the public will use must be plugged into a GFI receptacle that is supplied by the occupant, event organization or promoter of the event. 
(12)  Any event using water hoses must have back flow preventors supplied by occupant or event promoter attached to their hoses before they can be connected to the city's water faucets. 
(13)  For any cook-off type events and/or events using multiple electrical hook-ups on the grounds, occupant must hire and pay for a City of Pasadena electrician to oversee and service the event. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
DIVISION 2. - MUNICIPAL FAIRGROUNDS 
 
Sec. 24-36. - Concession rights. 
The City of Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds shall retain all concession and parking rights. Parking rates are to be determined by the director. 
Catering fees for any event in the fairgrounds are fifteen (15) per cent of the caterer's final bill, not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Concessions fees for any event in the fairgrounds are thirty (30) per cent of the concessionaire's total sales, not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
DIVISION 3. - CIVIC/CONVENTION CENTER 
 
Sec. 24-37. - Catering and concessions. 
The Director of the Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds has the authorization to supervise, control, and otherwise administer and obtain all necessary licenses pertaining to the leasing and use of the convention center and municipal fairgrounds regarding the sale, service, and delivery of catering and concessions including, but not limited to, food, refreshments, alcoholic beverages, novelties, souvenirs, reading materials, clothing, etc. The sale or dispensing of any item or bringing in food for personal consumption by a promoter or vendor or any other person attending events at the Convention Center, must first have the written approval of the director or his designee. A copy of the signed contract between caterer and client must be submitted to the director or his designee prior to catering an event in the Convention Center. The catering and concession company must meet the requirements of the facilities and sign a catering and concession agreement with the facilities. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
Sec. 24-38. - Rental. 
The basic rental rates of the facilities will include normal heat and/or cooling, normal lighting and water, normal janitorial cleaning services and the bleacher seating system. Changes made in the initial set-up may require payment of an additional charge. Changeovers (from one set-up to another) made within a single day will require payment of an additional set-up charge for any room. This includes set-up charges of tables, chairs, risers, stage, head tables, etc. (the rate will be determined by the director or his designee or the rate schedule for specific charges). 
Occupant must furnish drawings, location and dimensions of all exhibit booths and equipment indicating utility requirements (electrical) at the time of execution of the Occupancy Agreement and these requirements must be approved by the director or his designee and the City of Pasadena's Fire Marshal. Any changes made to the set-up after the initial plan is submitted may be subject to additional charges. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11)  
DIVISION 4. - GENERAL POLICIES 
 
Sec. 24-39. - Policies applicable to the facilities. 
(a)  Broadcast or telecast. Occupant or event coordinator has the responsibility to inform the director when a telecast or broadcast will be conducted at the complex at least four weeks prior to the event that will be broadcast. The director shall negotiate the cost for the right to broadcast these events. The director has the right to determine whether or not the telecast or broadcast will be conducted at the facility. 
(b)  Public address announcements. The Convention Center staff will not make public address calls for the general public attending events, but will make announcements in reference to the general welfare to the public attending events. 
(c)  Nonsmoking facility. The Pasadena Convention Center, Campbell hall, and the Ross Kelley Rodeo Arena are designated as nonsmoking facilities. 
(d)  Crowd control and security personnel. It shall be the responsibility of the director to determine the number of crowd control and/or security personnel for the occupant or event coordinator. It shall be the responsibility of the occupant or event coordinator to pay for crowd control and security personnel. Security shall be required at any event where alcoholic beverages are sold or served. 
(e)  Alterations of leased premises. If alterations of the facilities are required, said alterations must first be approved by the director or his designee. 
(f)  Abandoned equipment or articles. The facility shall not be held responsible for articles left on premises. The facility shall assume no responsibility for liability for any losses whatsoever or any losses associated with any articles left on the premises after the event. Said articles shall be considered abandoned and shall be disposed of immediately upon end of move-out. 
(g)  Copyright infringement. The occupant or event coordinator must accept all responsibility for and absolve the facility, its staff, and the City of Pasadena from any and all liability or expense arising out of any composition by members of the American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP), or any other copyright owner, which shall be played or sung in connection with any use of the facilities, whether amplified, televised, or otherwise not in the form of a mechanical recording, or a personal rendition, unless the sponsor of the program has first paid any fee required and the occupant or event coordinator shall provide satisfactory evidence of such payment to the director or his designee prior to such program. The occupant or event coordinator shall covenant and agree to indemnify and hold harmless the facility's staff and the City of Pasadena from all liability or cost whatsoever for infringements or other violations under the copyright laws. 
(h)  Solicitations. No collections or donations shall be allowed at the facility without the approval of the director or his designee. 
(i)  Reletting and subleasing. The City of Pasadena reserves the right to relet any portion of the facility which becomes vacant during the lease of any other contract. If the city relets because of occupant's or event coordinator's fraud, no refund will be due occupant or event coordinator. No occupant or event coordinator shall assign or sublet any part or portion of said lease. 
(j)  Authorized refunds of occupant or event coordinator's payments. Refund of advanced rental deposits may be authorized where: 
(1)  The scheduled performance or event is canceled under any terms of the regulations governing the management of the facilities. 
(2)  The performance or event is canceled at the request of the director or his designee. 
(k)  Permits and licenses. It is the responsibility of the occupant or event coordinator to obtain the necessary permits or licenses, prior to the occupant's or event coordinator's occupancy of the facilities. 
(l)  Holidays. Holidays will be defined as the official days that are recognized as holidays by the City of Pasadena and not necessarily the actual date of the holiday. Holiday rates shall apply if the facilities are leased during any holiday.
