Holiday rates will be left to the discretion of the director or his designee based on availability of staff, overtime pay, and other elements. 
(m)  Liability for occupant, event coordinator, or event organization; property. Neither the facility, the City of Pasadena nor its employees shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury on properties of any kind that are shipped or otherwise delivered to or stored on the premises. Properties shall not be received until occupant, event coordinator, or event organization has made prior arrangements for receiving, handling, and storage of such material with the director or his designee. Such request must be made in written form and received no later than two (2) weeks prior to the event. 
(n)  Box office rates and ticket procedures. Tickets may be sold by advance ticket agencies only by written permission from the director. The facility's staff shall not sell tickets unless they are directed to do so by the director or his designee as authorized by the mayor in writing. 
(o)  Advertising events. All advertising of said attractions must state total admission prices. The occupant shall not announce events scheduled at the facility until Occupancy Agreements have been prepared and executed by the facility's director or his designee. Advertising rates for the LED sign will be established by the director or his designee. 
(p)  Basic services. The facility's basic rental includes the established utilities which are electric light, heat and/or air conditioning and water necessary for the preparation of the attraction. However, failure to furnish any of the foregoing utilities resulting from circumstances beyond the control of the facility shall not be considered a breach of contract. A special rate shall be established for extraordinary utility usage. 
(q)  Compliance. Occupant or event coordinator shall comply with all city, state, county, and federal laws, with regulations pertaining to facilities. Violations by the occupant, event coordinator or its agents or employees may result in the cancellation of the Occupancy Agreement and/or discontinuation of the use of the facility. 
(r)  Objectionable conduct. Any person, performer, or person attending events at the facility whose conduct becomes objectionable, disorderly, or disruptive shall be subject to ejection from the premises. The occupant or event coordinator shall hold the City of Pasadena and its employees harmless from any claim for such action and will not be entitled to any refund for tickets of admission paid. 
(s)  Machinery, flammable liquids, and electricity. No person shall use any engine, motor, or other type of machinery within the facilities, or use any gas, flammable liquid, chemical, or gun powder without the approval of the director or his designee. No butane bottles of any size will be allowed or displayed with the buildings for any event for any purpose. No reloading equipment shall be used for any event for any purpose. Reloading equipment may be displayed but must be free of any and all gun powder residue. 
No gas or internal combustion vehicle shall be allowed inside the building unless the battery cables are disconnected and wrapped with black vinyl tape, gas tanks are at no more than one-quarter tank full and the tank caps are taped closed. All units must then be inspected by the director or his designee for compliance. 
No open-flamed candles or other type of open-flamed devices shall be permitted without the written approval of the director or his designee. 
The director may require the written approval of the City of Pasadena's Fire Marshal at any event. All of the items in this section are subject to the inspection and approval of the City of Pasadena's Fire Marshal. If the fire marshal refuses to approve it, it will not be allowed in the facility. 
(t)  Obstruction of doors, passageways, corridors, or lobbies. No portion of the sidewalks, entries, plaza (front), walkway, passageways, door aisles, vestibules, or other ways of access to the public utilities of the premises shall be permitted to be obstructed nor shall any window, ventilators, or lighting fixture be obstructed. 
(u)  Equipment usage. No person may use or transport any equipment, furniture, or other article which is the property of the facility without the approval of the director or his designee. As used in this section, the word "equipment" is to include all items of inventoried equipment which are movable or portable. 
(v)  Signs, posters, and literature. The hanging of pictures, banners, or other items from molding or elsewhere must have the approval of the director or his designee and must be installed by authorized personnel. The occupant or event coordinator shall not distribute or circulate or permit to be circulated any advertising matter or programs at the entrance to any part of the premises that does not pertain completely to the immediate attraction. Such material must have the approval of the director or his designee. At no time shall any such advertising matter be distributed or circulated on parking facilities or walkways adjacent to the facilities. 
No tape, no adhesives of any type, no adhesive labels, no staples, no tacks, no nails, or other items that could cause damage to surfaces shall be used on the facility's floors, tables, chairs, equipment, walls, brick, or limestone without express prior approval in writing of the director or his designee. 
In order to abide by the sign ordinance effect within the City of Pasadena, no sign of any type shall be placed on the facility's property outside the building without the written approval from the director or his designee. 
(w)  Nondiscrimination. No person, group, or association shall be excluded from the use of the facilities because of handicap, race, color, creed, or national origin and no rules or regulations may be promulgated by the occupant or event coordinator of the facilities which will discriminate against any person, group, or association or exclude them from use of the facilities or participation in the facility activities because of handicap, race, color, creed, or national origin. 
(x)  Animals. No animals or pets are allowed within the facilities except as a service animal or part of a regularly scheduled event, stage performance, act, rodeo, farm show, or circus. At no time will any animal other than a service animal be allowed in a designated food area. In order to promote the use of the facility for dog, cat, bird, horse, or other animal shows, kennel permits are not necessary to obtain for exhibitors, event coordinators, or promoters whose show lasts less than three (3) days unless animals are being sold during the show. 
(y)  Right of entry. The Pasadena Convention Center staff and other City of Pasadena personnel reserve the right to enter any facility at any given time including during an event. 
(z)  Parking. The City of Pasadena shall maintain and control parking on the facility's property. At all times parking for the facility's events shall have priority over parking for any other purpose. The Pasadena Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds retains all parking rights. Rates are to be determined by the director or his designee. 
(aa)  Force majeure. In the event that a force majeure renders the facility unsafe or unsuitable for occupancy for an event (as determined by the director or his designee), money deposited to secure the reservation and rental shall be returned to the occupant in full upon the determination of the director or his designee of the damages sustained and how long repairs will take to complete, however long that may take to assess or determine. The Convention Center shall be allowed a reasonable time to assess and determine the extent of the damages and to notice the occupant without any penalty to the Convention Center. It will not be considered a breach of contract to cancel any events to repair damages or in the event the force majeure, weather, or incident renders the facility unsafe for staff or for participants. Failure to furnish any of the foregoing facilities or utilities resulting from circumstances beyond the control of the facilities shall not be considered a breach of contract. A special rate, to be determined by the director or his designee, may be established for extraordinary circumstances under these conditions. 
(bb)  Protestors. Protestors are prohibited from protesting inside the gated grounds since the premises are leased for private events by individuals or other entities. The occupant leases the rights to peaceful enjoyment of the premises for the purposes intended by their Occupancy Agreement during the term of their lease. No political signs are to be posted on the grounds except in individual booths or within the confines of rented spaces by the political entity. 
(cc)  Lobby booths. No vendor or display booths will be allowed in the lobby area due to traffic congestion and public safety. This area should only be used for registration tables for the event. 
(dd)  Areas not included in the rental of the facilities. The concession stands in the Convention Center and the Ross Kelley Rodeo Arena are exclusively for the concessionaire's use and are not included as part of the Occupancy Agreement. The administrative office and the warehouse located in the Convention Center are exclusively for the Pasadena Convention Center staff's use and are not included as part of the Occupancy Agreement. The Pasadena Livestock Show and Rodeo office and the San Jacinto Day Foundation Office located at the Pasadena Municipal Fairgrounds are also not included as part of the Occupancy Agreement. 
(ee)  Mosquito spraying. If extra mosquito spraying is needed for any event whatsoever (including the Pasadena Livestock Show and Rodeo or the Strawberry Festival), the occupant or event coordinator must notify the Convention Center at least two (2) weeks in advance and pay two (2) weeks in advance for the spraying. The Convention Center has a normal spraying schedule four (4) times a year and anything beyond that will be considered extra spraying. Fogging of the drains will cost additionally as well. All spraying must be done by a licensed professional contracted by the City of Pasadena for public safety. Therefore, no entity utilizing the grounds may "do it themselves" or hire their own company. 
(ff)  Excessive clean-up. Excessive clean-up is any service beyond normal, routine janitorial services. Examples include but are not limited to: Large amounts of trash and boxes left on the floors (anything larger than what can be swept into a commercial dustpan; cleaning ground-in substances or food off tables or chairs; numerous spilled beverages; large amounts of trash left in the bleachers; numerous instances of spilled substances that must be wiped or cleaned with cleaning solutions; large amounts of cans or bottles; pallets; crates; stains to any carpeting or other floor surfacing; tape residue left on any surface; balloons left floating on the ceiling; cleaning up confetti; any damage that requires extraordinary care; clean-up and disposal of any grease, oil, chemicals, or bodily fluids; clean-up of any graffiti or paint; clean-up of mischievous acts; clean-up of any coating or residue left in booth; and clean-up of hazardous substances. 
(gg)  Confetti, sparklers, or bubbles. No confetti of any kind will be allowed in the buildings. The throwing or pitching of any substances such as natural flower petals, silk or synthetic flower petals, rice, birdseed, Silly String, or small packaged items is prohibited inside or outside the facility or elsewhere on the facility's property. The use of sparklers or bubbles is prohibited inside, outside, or anywhere on the facility's property. A reduction of the security deposit will be charged if occupant fails to comply with this policy. 
(hh)  Straw bedding or hay or straw used as filler. No straw bedding or hay or straw used as filler will be allowed in any stalls or on any of the premises anywhere including the fairgrounds and cook-off areas. A damages fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) will be assessed for any violation of this policy. For animal safety purposes, only new shavings will be allowed in any stall. 
(ii)  Occupancy Agreement changes. After the Occupancy Agreement has been created for the occupant, any changes requested by the occupant will result in a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) charge for changing the Occupancy Agreement. 
(jj)  Additional set-up fees. If the occupant requests changes to the agreed set-up less than two (2) weeks prior to the event, there will be an additional charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per table and one dollar ($1.00) per chair unless otherwise determined by the director or his designee. 
(kk)  Rental fees. Any rental fees not listed herein for equipment or signage or equipment that may be added at a future date may be set by the director or his designee based on the standard rental rates in the industry. 
(ll)  Metal wheels. Absolutely no metal wheels are allowed on the flooring of the Convention Center. 
(mm)  Tents, staging, lighting, or any other equipment. Tents, staging, lighting, or any other equipment on the grounds must be free-standing or set up with water barrels and must be approved by the director or his designee. 
(nn)  EMS requirements. For larger events such as concerts, festivals, rodeos, or events with livestock, the occupant or event coordinator is required to provide sufficient EMS and provide the Pasadena Convention Center staff with the company, contact name, and phone number of the EMS services provider no later than two (2) weeks prior to the event. 
(oo)  Lighting. For events held on the fairgrounds, additional lighting is required after dark. 
(pp)  Helicopters. Permission for helicopter landings on the fairgrounds must be requested in writing from the director of the facility at least six (6) weeks prior to the event. It is the responsibility of the occupant or event organization to comply with all laws, licensing, and safety associated with this activity. A safety plan, insurance, and contact information for the company, pilot, and the requesting organization must also be included with the request. 
(qq)  Political signage. Signage that is political in nature is prohibited from placement on the Convention Center grounds, the fairgrounds, or city property. Exceptions to this policy are placement inside individual booths or inside the rented space for a political fundraiser for that individual politician. 
(rr)  On-duty officers. All certified peace officers on duty shall be in uniform and shall remain on duty until the facility and parking lots are vacated. 
(ss)  Clean-up of outside areas. The occupant, event organizer, and/or event organization shall have full financial responsibility to canvass the building exterior and return to the condition in which it was originally presented. 
(tt)  Deliveries. Deliveries associated with the function are to be scheduled within the hours rented. Otherwise, unless a representative for the function is present to sign for deliveries, the Convention Center staff will not accept said deliveries and the packages will be returned to the shipping company's warehouse and delivery will have to be rescheduled by the recipient. 
(uu)  Ejection from the property. Any person at the Convention Center whose conduct is disorderly or disruptive in any of the following respects may be ejected from the premises by the city's designated representative or any certified peace officer: Intoxication; use of abusive, indecent, profane, or vulgar language; making offensive gestures or displays; abusing or threatening another person in an offensive manner; making unreasonably loud noises; fighting with another person; vandalism; and deliberate acts that damage the Convention Center and/or facility equipment. The occupant, event coordinator, or event organization for the function at which any such ejection occurs shall hold harmless, indemnify, and defend the city, its officers, agents, and employees against any claim related to such ejection. 
(vv)  Presence for the duration of the event. The individual who reserves the Convention Center and Municipal Fairgrounds and executes the Occupancy Agreement is required to be present at the scheduled function for the duration of that function including set-up, dismantle, and clean-up activities or appoint a duly authorized representative who is authorized to act on his/her behalf. 
(ww)  Meeting room space. Rooms 102, 103, and 107 are designated as meeting rooms and are not to be used for booth or exhibitor space unless authorized in writing by the director or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 11-042, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-11; Ord. No. 15-168, §§ 4, 5, 12-15-15)  
Secs. 24-40—24-44. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PASADENA HISTORICAL MUSEUM 
 
Sec. 24-45. - Pasadena Historical Museum Board—Jurisdiction and control of museum. 
The control and jurisdiction of the Pasadena Historical Museum and the buildings in Memorial Park and the responsibility and authority for the operation and maintenance thereof, are, subject to all of the terms of this article, vested in the Pasadena Historical Museum Board hereinafter created and established. 
(Ord. No. 73-288, § 1, 11-20-73; Ord. No. 84-115, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Sec. 24-46. - Same—Creation; members, number, terms of office, removal; quorum; rules of order. 
There is hereby created and established a Pasadena Historical Museum Board (hereinafter referred to simply as the "board") which shall consist of nine (9) members to be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. The members of the board shall not, by virtue of their membership, be employees of or officers or agents of the city, and shall receive no compensation from the city for their services on such board. Such board shall not, except to the limited extent hereinafter expressly stated, be an agent or instrumentality of the city or authorized to in any way obligate or bind the city. 
Each member of the board shall be a qualified voter and a resident of the City of Pasadena, Texas. Further, the members shall possess the following qualifications: 
(1)  Position 1 will be filled with a member of the City Council of the City of Pasadena, Texas. 
(2)  Position 2 will be filled with a member of the Pasadena Independent School District Board. 
(3)  Position 3 will be filled with a member of the Chamber of Commerce of the City of Pasadena, Texas. 
(4)  Positions 4 and 5 will be filled by two (2) members of the Pasadena Historical Society; said two (2) members to be elected by the membership of the said Pasadena Historical Society, and the names of those two elected submitted to the mayor with a request for appointment to said positions. 
(5)  Position 6 will be filled with a member of the Early Settlers who has been elected by the membership of the Early Settlers. After such person is so elected his name shall be submitted to the mayor with a request for appointment to said position. 
(6)  Position 7 will be filled with a member of the parks and recreation department of the City of Pasadena, Texas. 
(7)  Position 8 will be filled with a member of organized labor who is a member of a local union which has members who act as bargaining agent pursuant to a labor contract with the management of an area industry. 
(8)  Position 9 will be filled with a member of a minority group. A minority group shall be deemed to be any group or class of people who are not white Anglo-Saxons. 
Of the nine (9) members first appointed four (4) shall be appointed for a term to expire on December thirty-first of the second year and the other five (5) for a term to expire on December thirty-first of the third year. Before the expiration of one month after such expiration of the terms of office of members of such board, successors shall be so appointed, subject to such confirmation, to serve terms expiring two (2) years after the expiration of such previous term. Vacancies occurring from death, resignation or removal shall be similarly filled by appointment and confirmation for the remaining unexpired term of the member deceased, resigned or removed. The board shall elect its own chairman and such other officers as it desires and shall adopt its own rules of procedure and organization except that one-half of its members at any time shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 73-288, § 1, 11-20-73)  
Sec. 24-47. - Appropriations to maintain. 
The city council declares its purpose and intention (but does not in any way obligate itself or attempt to obligate any future city council) to from time to time appropriate and cause to be paid over to the board (or upon the board's recommendation, to the Pasadena Historical Society hereinafter referred to) such sums as the council may deem proper and appropriate to aid in defraying the expenses of operation, maintenance and development of such museum and the maintenance and improvement of the building in which it is housed. 
(Ord. No. 73-288, § 1, 11-20-73)  
Sec. 24-48. - Assuming control by nonprofit organization, terms and considerations; rules governing museum operation. 
Subject to the responsibility therefor to the city and its city council remaining always in such board, such board is hereby authorized upon an agreement which must be in writing and filed with and approved by the city council to agree with "Pasadena Historical Society", a private nonprofit organization of Harris County, Texas, for such society to take over the actual possession, control, maintenance and operation of such museum and of such building, upon such terms and considerations as such board deems proper, provided that the following terms shall be read into said contract: 
(1)  Open to public, rules to be adopted. Such building and museum shall always be and remain a public building and museum, open to the public generally, without discrimination between persons or groups affiliated or associated with such society and persons or groups not so affiliated or associated. Reasonable rules shall be adopted (subject to amendment of or addition thereto by the city council if it finds that the public interest and welfare require such amendment or addition) governing all matters incident to the operation of the museum, including the times when the museum shall be open to the public generally and the times when it, or such building or parts thereof, may be reserved for exclusive or semi-exclusive use by study groups or other groups interested in the matters which are within the scope of the activities of such museum; but no rule shall be established by which study groups or other interested groups not affiliated in any way with such society shall be at any greater expense, burden or inconvenience incident to their use of the museum or its facilities than the burden, expense or inconvenience directly borne by the society and its such affiliated groups incident to its or their like or similar use thereof; and 
(2)  Termination of operation agreement. Such contract or agreement shall be subject to termination as provided therein; whereupon all right of the society to any appropriation or contribution theretofore so made to it by the city but not yet paid over to it shall cease, as shall also all and every its rights of occupancy, control or management of the museum, except that it shall have a reasonable time after such termination within which to remove from the building such exhibits, specimens, furniture and furnishings, and other personal property, not the property of the city, as it may have placed therein; and 
(3)  Condition of premises, liability for injury. The society shall for itself, its employees and its invitees and guests accept the premises in the state and condition they were in on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, and agree that the city shall not be liable to it or to any of them, the aforesaid, for any injury whether to person or to property occurring in or upon such premises; and the society shall indemnify and agree to indemnity and save harmless the city from any liability, suit, claim or damage on account of any such injury; and 
(4)  Insuring by city. The city may carry upon the building and/or on the personal property therein which belongs to the city such insurance as the city from time to time sees fit; and 
(5)  Repairing, improving, right of entry therefor. The city may from time to time make such repairs of or additions and betterments of the building as it sees fit, but shall be the sole judge of whether to do so or not. The mayor and city council or all persons by any of them thereto designated, shall at all reasonable times have access to the museum not only to observe the manner in which it is being operated and maintained, but for the purpose of inspecting the building and of having done and constructed such repairs, additions, or betterments thereof and thereto as the city may from time to time deem proper. 
(6)  City not to be bound. The society shall not in the name of or on the credit of the city employ any person or purchase any materials, supplies or other thing whatsoever; and shall never obligate or bind or undertake to obligate or bind the city in any respect whatsoever; but the operation by the society of the museum shall be upon its sole credit and responsibility entirely. 
(Ord. No. 73-288, § 1, 11-20-73)  
Sec. 24-49. - Rights of board and society may be terminated. 
By virtue of this article there shall not be vested in the society or in the board or in the members of the board any right except it be subject to termination by the city by repeal or amendment of this article or other appropriate action of its governing body. 
(Ord. No. 73-288, § 1, 11-20-73)  
Chapter 25 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT VENDORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 89-91, § 1, adopted June 13, 1989, repealed Ch. 25 in its entirety. Said Ch. 25 pertained to peddlers, solicitors and itinerant vendors and derived from Code 1964, §§ 20-1—20-6, 20-15—20-23 and Ord. No. 83-50, § 2, adopted Feb. 8, 1983. Section 2 of said Ord. No. 89-91 enacted a new Ch. 25 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
Cross reference— Seafood dealers, § 15-111 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 25-1. - Definitions. 
[The following definitions shall apply to this chapter:] 
(1)  Itinerant vendor. The term "itinerant vendor" shall mean all persons, as well as their agents and employees, who engage in the temporary or transient business in the city of selling, or offering for sale, any goods or merchandise, or exhibiting the same for sale, or exhibiting the same for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business or conducting such exhibits thereof, display, exhibit, sell or offer for sale such goods or merchandise upon or from a truck or other vehicle, or who hire, rent, lease or occupy any room or space in any building, structure, other enclosure, vacant lot or any other property whatever in the city in, through or from which any goods or merchandise may be sold, offered for sale, exhibited for sale or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, or who shall sell or offer for sale any goods or merchandise while upon the property of another, without the express written consent of the owner or occupant thereof. The term "itinerant vendor" shall not include or be construed to include anyone upon whom the provisions of this chapter would impose a direct and unlawful burden on interstate commerce. 
(2)  Goods or merchandise. The phrase "goods or merchandise" shall mean any personal property of any nature whatsoever including but not limited to tickets for admission to athletic, sporting or entertainment events or shows. 
(3)  Public street or highway. The phrase "public street or highway" shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(4)  Temporary. The word "temporary" shall mean any such business transacted or conducted in the city for which definite arrangements have not been made for the hire, rental or lease of premises for at least one month in or upon which such business is to be operated or conducted. 
(5)  Transient. The word "transient" shall mean any such business as may be operated or conducted by persons who reside away from this city, or who have fixed places of business in places other than this city, or who have their headquarters in places other than this city, or who move stocks of goods, or merchandise or samples thereof into this city with the purpose or intention of removing them or the unsold portion thereof away from the city before the expiration of one month, or who sell and offer for sale such goods or merchandise while upon the property of another, without the prior written consent of the owner or occupant thereof, or conduct such business away from their fixed places of business, if any, or who have no such fixed places of business. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-2. - Exemptions. 
This chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Ordinary commercial travelers who sell or exhibit for sale goods or merchandise to parties engaged in the business of buying and selling and dealing in goods or merchandise. 
(2)  Sales of goods or merchandise donated by the owners thereof, the proceeds whereof are to be applied to any charitable or philanthropic purpose. 
(3)  Vendors of milk, pastries, bread, and newspapers who make such sales on existing routes or from fixed places. 
(4)  Persons who are exempt from the application of this chapter pursuant to federal or state law. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Secs. 25-3—25-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 25-11. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any itinerant vendor to sell, offer for sale, exhibit for sale, or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, any goods or merchandise in the city without first obtaining a license so to do in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-12. - Application. 
Every itinerant vendor shall make application to the building official for the license required by this article, which application shall be filed at least ten (10) days prior to the date of his contemplated sale or exhibit to be held in the city. Such application shall be in the form of an affidavit stating the full name and address of the itinerant vendor, the location of his principal office and place of business, the names and addresses of its officers, if it is a corporation, and the partnership name and the names and addresses of all partners, if such itinerant vendor is a firm. The application must be accompanied by: 
(1)  A statement showing the kind and character of the goods or merchandise to be sold, offered for sale or exhibited. 
(2)  A copy of the charter, if the itinerant vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of the state. 
(3)  A copy of its license to do business in Texas, if the itinerant vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of some state other than Texas. 
(4)  The local address, if any, of the applicant. 
(5)  The name and address of the person, firm or corporation, if any, that the applicant represents or for whom or through whom orders are to be solicited or cleared. 
(6)  Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand or receive or accept payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery. 
(7)  The period of time which the applicant wishes to solicit or sell in the city and a description of the proposed location of the business. 
(8)  If a motor vehicle is to be used in the vending business, a description of the vehicle together with the motor vehicle registration number and the license number. 
(9)  A sales tax permit issued by the state of Texas. 
(10)  Written permission from the property owner duly notarized by the property owner. Such forms shall be supplied by the building official. Written permission forms shall not be required for door-to-door sales. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 25-13. - Proof of identity. 
At the time of the application provided for in section 25-12, the applicant shall submit to the building official for inspection written proof of his identity, which may be in the form of an automobile operator's license or an identification letter or card issued to the applicant by the person for whom or through whom orders are to be solicited or cleared. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 25-14. - Bond required of applicant. 
(a)  The application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) signed by the applicant and signed, as surety, by some surety company authorized to do business in the state conditioned for the final delivery of goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs or magazines in accordance with the terms of any order obtained prior to delivery and also conditioned to indemnify any and all purchasers or customers for any and all defects in material or workmanship that may exist in the article sold, by the principal of such bond, at the time of delivery, and that may be discovered by such purchaser or customer within thirty (30) days after delivery, which bond shall be made payable to the mayor and his successors in office for the use and benefit of all persons that may make any purchase or give any order to the principal thereon, or to an agent or employee of the principal. 
(b)  In case the applicant is engaging in any activity mentioned in section 25-11, through one or more agents or employees, such applicant shall be required to enter into only one bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) as above required, which bond shall be made to cover the activities of all his agents or employees. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-15. - Fee. 
(a)  The fee for an itinerant vendor's license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). When any person engages in any activity mentioned in section 25-11 through one or more agents or employees, such person shall, in addition to such $50.00 fee, pay a license fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each agent or employee so engaged. The fees provided for herein shall be used for the purpose of defraying expenses incident to the issuing of such licenses. No such fee shall be prorated. 
(b)  None of the license fees provided for by this section shall be so applied as to occasion an undue burden upon interstate commerce. In any case where a license fee is believed by a licensee or applicant for license to place an undue burden upon such commerce, he may apply to the mayor for an adjustment of the fee so that it shall not be discriminatory, unreasonable, or unfair as to such commerce. Such application may be made before, at, or within six (6) months after payment of the prescribed license fee. The applicant shall, by affidavit and supporting testimony, show his method of business and the gross volume or estimated gross volume of business and such other information as the mayor may deem necessary in order to determine the extent, if any, of such undue burden on such commerce. The mayor shall then conduct an investigation, comparing applicant's business with other businesses of like nature and shall make findings of fact from which he shall determine where the fee fixed by this section is unfair, unreasonable or discriminatory as to the applicant's business and shall fix as the license fee for the applicant, an amount that is fair, reasonable and nondiscriminatory, or, if the fee has already been paid, shall order a refund of the amount over and above the fee so fixed. In fixing the fee to be charged, the mayor shall have the power to base the fee upon any method which will assure that the fee assessed shall be uniform with that assessed on businesses of like nature, so long as the fee amount assessed does not exceed the fees as prescribed by subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-16. - Licenses and identification cards. 
(a)  The building official shall issue to any itinerant vendor a license authorizing such itinerant vendor to sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, in the city, his goods or merchandise after such itinerant vendor has fully complied with all provisions of this article and paid the prescribed fee. Such license shall be carried with the itinerant vendor while he/she is engaged in the business of selling. 
(b)  A license issued under this article shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises where the sale or exhibit is being conducted and shall remain so displayed as long as any goods or merchandise are being so sold or exhibited. This subsection does not apply to door-to-door sales. 
(c)  In addition to the license the building official of the city shall issue an identification card to each itinerant vendor and employee or agent thereof. The identification card shall be carried with the itinerant vendor and each agent or employee of such vendor while he/she is engaged in the business of selling. If the identification card becomes damaged or obscured the itinerant vendor shall return it to the city and receive another card. 
(d)  Licenses and identification cards shall be used only by the person to whom they were issued and may not be transferred to any other person. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 25-17. - Term. 
Any license issued under this article shall be valid as long as the sale or exhibit is continuously held in the city, but in no event shall it be valid for more than ninety (90) days from the date of its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-18. - Selling, soliciting, etc., prohibited between certain hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any activity mentioned in section 25-11, whether he is licensed so to do or not, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-19. - Going upon posted residence without invitation. 
The practice of going in and upon private residences in the city, whereon a sign bearing the words "No Peddlers Allowed" is displayed, by an itinerant vendor and peddlers and persons selling or taking orders for goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, magazines or subscriptions to magazines, not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or occupant of such private residence, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, or merchandise, or disposing of, or peddling or hawking the same, is declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such nuisance as a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-20. - Not to issue to certain persons. 
Any person convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall not be eligible to receive a license under this article for a period of one (1) year from the date of such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-21. - To be carried on person. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any activity mentioned in section 25-11 unless he is carrying on his person, at all times while so engaged, a valid license and identification card issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-22. - Stationary business location restricted. 
No itinerant vendor shall conduct a stationary business within twenty-five (25) feet of a public street or highway. 
(Ord.No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-23. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  Any license issued under this article may be suspended or revoked for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud or misrepresentation in the application for the license; 
(2)  Fraud or misrepresentation in the course of conducting the business of vending; 
(3)  Conducting the business of vending contrary to the conditions of the license; or 
(4)  Conducting the business of vending in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute a danger to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  Upon suspension or revocation, the building official shall deliver written notice to the license holder stating the action taken and the reasons supporting such action. The written notice shall be delivered to the license holder's place of business or mailed to the license holder's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, §2, 6-13-89; Ord. No. 03-144, § 1, 7-8-03)  
Sec. 25-24. - Appeals. 
Persons who are denied licenses or whose licenses have been suspended or revoked may appeal by filing a written notice of appeal with the mayor. The appeal must be filed within fifteen (15) days after receipt of the notice of denial, suspension or revocation. The mayor shall hear and determine the appeal and the decision of the mayor shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-25. - Enforcement. 
This article shall be enforced by any police officer of the City of Pasadena in addition to being enforced by other applicable departments and employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-26. - Penalty. 
Any persons convicted of a violation of this article shall be fined in a sum not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 25-27. - Construction of chapter. 
This entire chapter is and shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the state and of the city for the public safety, comfort, convenience and protection of the city and its citizens, and all of the provisions hereof shall be construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 89-91, § 2, 6-13-89)  
Chapter 27 - PIPELINE TRANSPORTATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Permit for gas pipeline extensions in or parallel to streets, § 32-59 et seq.; street rental charge for gas mains, pipes, etc., § 32-75 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 27-1. - Definitions. 
All terms used in this chapter shall be taken in their ordinary signification except the following, which shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
Commodity. The term "commodity" shall mean any substance capable of being transmitted through a pipeline which is, or may become, flammable, toxic or otherwise hazardous to human, animal or plant health or life. 
Pipeline. The term "pipeline" shall mean a line of pipe with pumps, valves and control devices for conveying a commodity or commodities. 
Shut-off valve. A "shut-off valve" is any device installed in a pipeline and used to stop the conveyance of a commodity or commodities through a pipeline. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-2. - Registration of pipelines. 
(a)  The owner of every pipeline now located across or along and under the public streets, highways, sidewalks, parks, public squares or public places within the city, and the owner of any pipeline constructed or replaced under a franchise hereinafter granted under the terms of this chapter, shall prepare and file with the building official three (3) official, scaled, city street maps, as currently revised by the city engineer, upon which the owner shall fully delineate the area within the city's corporate limits traversed by the existing or proposed pipeline, with the route, distances and shut-off valve locations clearly and indelibly drawn thereon, together with the name and mailing address of the owner and the telephone number of at least one (1) office or person available on a twenty-four (24) hour basis who can furnish, or obtain immediately, information as to the pressure at the point or points of input nearest to the city and the common name of the commodity carried by the pipeline of such owner. Immediately upon receipt of such maps, the building official shall transmit one (1) copy to the director of public works and one (1) copy to the fire department, and shall retain one (1) copy in his files. The building official shall issue a receipt for each registration filed. Any change in the twenty-four (24) hour contact information must be promptly reported to the fire department. 
(b)  Since the Houston Natural Gas Corporation and Pennzoil United, Inc., successor to the United Gas Corporation, are franchised utilities of the city and have, at least since the year 1945, regularly applied to and advised the city of their extensions, changes and relocations of pipelines, such utilities shall not be required to file the maps and attachments referred to in subsection (a) above for any pipeline construction, extension, change or relocation since the year 1945 and prior to April 7, 1970; provided, however, such utilities shall file such maps and attachments for all gas trunk pipelines extant within the city's corporate limits prior to the year 1945 and still operated in the original routes. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-3. - Pipeline signs. 
Every pipeline, new or existing, within the corporate limits of the city shall bear, at all times, in plain, indelible lettering, signs denoting the ownership of the pipeline, permanently affixed in the pipeline right-of-way. No person, except the owner or his duly authorized agent, shall tamper with or remove any such sign. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70) 
Cross reference— Signs generally, Ch. 31.  
Sec. 27-4. - Unauthorized operation of or tampering with shut-off valves. 
No person shall turn off or on, or otherwise operate or tamper with any pipeline shut-off valve within the city's corporate limits, unless such person is an employee of the owner or operator of the pipeline or a duly authorized agent of such owner or operator. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-5. - Excavating over, changing grade of, etc., pipelines. 
No person, other than the owner of the pipeline or his duly authorized agent, shall excavate over or change the grade of, or operate on or construct anything on or across the right-of-way in any pipeline without first notifying the director of public works and the owner of the pipeline and giving them reasonable opportunity to have an observer present during such activity. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-6. - Exemptions from chapter. 
(a)  Except as provided in section 27-2(b), this chapter shall not apply to or affect any corporation now or hereafter providing natural gas service to the inhabitants of the city pursuant to a franchise granted to such corporation under the authority of the city's Charter as a gas distribution utility. 
(b)  Deleted. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70; Ord. No. 00-42, § 1, 3-28-00)  
Sec. 27-7. - Violations of chapter. 
Any violation of any section, subsection, or part of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor and each violation during all or any portion of any day shall be a separate offense and a misdemeanor. Upon final conviction, every person, firm, corporation, association, partnership or other entity guilty of such violation shall be fined an amount not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each violation during all or any portion of any day. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70; Ord. No. 99-104, § 1, 6-15-99; Ord. No. 00-42, § 2, 3-28-00)  
Secs. 27-8—27-17. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FRANCHISE FOR USE OF PUBLIC PLACES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Franchises, Art. XI. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 27-18. - Required. 
The right to control and use of the public streets, highways, sidewalks, parks, public squares and public places being invested in the city council by Article XI of the city's Charter, no person shall lay any pipeline, nor shall an existing pipeline be entirely replaced, across or along and under the public streets, highways, sidewalks, parks, public squares, or public places within the city, unless and until a franchise has been obtained for such pipeline under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-19. - To be granted by ordinance; ordinance enactment procedure. 
A franchise to lay or replace and operate a pipeline shall only be granted, renewed and extended by ordinance not in conflict with the city's Charter, which ordinance shall be read and passed at two (2) regular meetings of the council and shall not be finally acted upon until thirty (30) days after the first reading. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, Art. XI, § 3.  
Sec. 27-20. - Term. 
The ordinance granting a franchise under this article shall specify the term of the grant, provided that no franchise shall be granted for a term of more than twenty-five (25) years. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70; Ord. No. 81-128, § 1, 8-4-81) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, Art. XI, § 2.  
Sec. 27-21. - Classifications. 
Every franchise granted under the provisions of this article shall be classified as either a gathering line franchise or a trunk line franchise. A gathering line franchise shall be for the laying or replacement of a pipeline or pipelines as an incident to the development and operation of oil and/or gas fields, including what are commonly referred to as gathering lines, and discharge lines, together with salt water lines, fresh water lines and lines carrying oil, water or gas produced in such fields to locations in such fields for operational, gathering or drilling purposes. All other pipelines, regardless of the commodity or commodities carried, shall be covered by a franchise classified as a trunk line franchise. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-22. - Indemnification provisions. 
The ordinance granting any franchise under this article, whether for a trunk pipeline or for gathering lines, shall require the grantee to have the city harmless from liability for injury or damage to any person or persons or property caused by the construction, maintenance, operation, repair or removal of any part or all of such pipeline within the right-of-way of any street of the city, whether existing at the time such ordinance is passed or thereafter dedicated or otherwise coming into existence, and shall require the grantee to pay to the city all damages caused to the city or any of its agencies by the construction, maintenance, operation, repair or removal of such pipeline or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-23. - Duty of grantee to give notice of street excavations and to keep street open. 
The person to whom a franchise is granted under this article shall notify the director of public works before commencing any excavation in any portion of any street, and shall not wholly close any street, but shall at all times maintain a route of travel along and within the roadway area, which shall include any sidewalk area; provided, however, in the event of an emergency, it being evident that immediate action is necessary for protection of the public and to minimize property damage and loss of investment, such grantee may, at his own responsibility and risk, make necessary emergency repairs, notifying the director of public works and the mayor or the city council of this action as soon as practical. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70) 
Cross reference— Street openings generally, § 32-31.  
Sec. 27-24. - Grantee's obligation to refill excavations and repair streets. 
(a)  The ordinance granting any franchise under this article, whether for a trunk pipeline or for gathering lines, shall require the grantee to refill, including the repaving of any cut in any pavement, all excavations made by him within the right-of-way of any street, whether existing at the time such ordinance is passed or thereafter dedicated or otherwise coming into existence, in the construction, operating, maintaining or removing of such pipeline or any part thereof, and if, after once refilling such excavation, the earth within the excavated area settles so as to leave a depression, the grantee shall be required to make further necessary fills from time to time as ordered by the director of public works or by the city council. The grantee will be required, by such ordinance, to repair all portions of any street across or along and under which his line is laid and place the same in as good a state of repair and condition as they were in at the time the construction, repair or removal was commenced, such repairs to be to the satisfaction of the city council. Such ordinance shall further require that all such work of repairing or refilling shall be done under plans and specifications approved by the director of public works and subject to his approval of the completed work, and any excavation in or along and under any such street shall be replaced with materials of the same kind as those removed unless the director of public works shall have approved some other type of fill or material. 
(b)  The ordinance granting such franchise shall further provide that, in the event the grantee fails to commence or thereafter to diligently prosecute any repair, refilling or other work required to be done by him within a reasonable time after being notified to do so by the director of public works, the city may cause such work to be done at the expense of the grantee and may recover all such expense from the grantee, together with all costs and reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Secs. 27-25—27-29. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - GATHERING LINE FRANCHISE 
 
Sec. 27-30. - Scope generally. 
A single gathering line franchise will be granted under this article to a person desiring to lay or replace and maintain and operate pipelines as a facility incident to the development and operation of oil and gas fields wholly or partly within the city limits, or in close proximity to the city limits, including, but without limitation, lines for: 
(1)  The gathering of oil, gas and other minerals from wells, tanks or field pumping stations; 
(2)  The gathering and disposal of salt water; 
(3)  The transportation of water for drilling and other purposes; 
(4)  The transportation of gas within the fields for operational, gathering or drilling purposes; and 
(5)  The transportation of oil, gas and other minerals from a point in such fields to connection with a trunk pipeline. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-31. - Fee and license. 
The ordinance granting a gathering line franchise and license shall provide for the payment by the grantee to the City of Pasadena of an initial franchise fee and an initial license fee in the amount of three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00) and for the payment of subsequent fees thereafter in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per year per pipeline and all amounts as may subsequently be set by this chapter or otherwise set by the City of Pasadena. After payment of the initial fee, all subsequent fees shall be due and payable on December 31 of each subsequent year for the term of the license. Advance payment of the license fee for more than one (1) year shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-40; Ord. No. 81-128, § 2, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 94-102, § 1, 6-21-94; Ord. No. 99-104, § 2, 6-15-99; Ord. No. 08-125, § 1, 5-20-08; Ord. No. 08-307, § 1, 12-16-08)  
Sec. 27-31.1. - Transfer fee. 
A gathering line franchise that is transferred from a franchisee to another entity shall be subject to a franchise fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per pipeline payable by the transferee. After the payment of this transfer fee, the fees for subsequent years shall be payable by the transferee under the same conditions and terms as set forth in section 27-31. 
(Ord. No. 94-102, § 2, 6-21-94; Ord. No. 08-125, § 2, 5-20-08; Ord. No. 08-307, § 2, 12-16-08)  
Sec. 27-31.2. - Failure to pay fees. 
Failure to pay any fees required by this article shall result in the possible revocation of the franchise or license. All fees are payable within thirty (30) days. Thereafter, interest will accrue at the rate of ten (10) per cent per annum until paid. In addition thereto in such event company agrees to pay to city administrative fees of ten (10) per cent per month and costs of collection including reasonable attorney fees. This is inclusive of any other available remedy. 
(Ord. No. 99-104, § 3, 6-15-99; Ord. No. 08-125, § 3, 5-20-08)  
Sec. 27-32. - Grantee's right to run lines across, along and under streets. 
(a)  A gathering line franchise shall authorize the grantee to run any of the lines referred to in section 27-30 across or along and under any street, but only upon the approval of the director or public works as to the point or points at which the pipeline will cross or run along and under any such street, the depth of the line under the street and the means and manner of construction, and the issuance of a specific permit therefor by the director of public works, upon application made to him before any line is so laid. Before granting any such permit, the director of public works shall require the grantee to file with him maps and drawings of the area involved to constitute a permanent record in the office of the director of public works of the location of the line so permitted to be carried under city streets. 
(b)  Each gathering line franchise shall provide for the payment by the grantee of ten dollars ($10.00) upon the granting, by the director of public works, of the specific permit for the crossing of or running along and under one or more streets by each or any particular line, as provided for in subsection (a) of this section. Such permit fee shall be in addition to the fee prescribed by section 27-31. 
(Ord. No. 70-46, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-33. - Minimum depth of lines under streets. 
At every point or points where a pipeline is to cross or run along and under a street, as authorized by this division, the pipeline must be buried to a depth of at least six (6) feet, measured between the top of the line and the natural surface of the ground. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-34. - Provision for relocation or lowering of line for street improvements or water or sewer construction. 
A gathering line franchise granted under this article shall provide that any line crossing or laid within and along and under any street or street right-of-way in existence at the time the line is laid will, at any time thereafter, be relocated or lowered at such point of crossing, by the grantee at his cost, if found necessary by the director of public works incident to any future street improvement or water, sanitary sewer or storm sewer construction. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Secs. 27-35—27-39. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - TRUNK LINE FRANCHISE 
 
Sec. 27-40. - Application. 
Any person desiring to construct any trunk pipeline across or along and under any street within the limits of the city shall first submit to the director of public works and to the director of city planning a plan accurately showing the proposed location, course and alignment of the proposed pipeline. Such plan shall be accompanied by a written application for the passage of an ordinance granting the franchise, which application shall show (unless the same are sufficiently shown on the plan) the time, manner, means and methods of the proposed construction, the particular commodity proposed to be transported through such line and the maximum pressure and maximum temperature under which the same may be pumped or otherwise caused or permitted to flow through any and all of the particular portions of the line. Such plan, which shall consist not only of the plan but also of a suitable alignment map as drawn for the applicant for his own records, shall accurately show the location of all existing streets and all proposed streets designated on the master plan for the city or on the official map of the city, across or along and under which the pipeline is intended to be laid. Two (2) copies thereof and of the application shall be presented to the director of city planning and two (2) copies thereof and of the application shall be presented to the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-41. - Recommendation of directors of public works and planning as to granting or denying. 
The director of public works and the director of planning shall report to the city council upon their examination of an application and plans filed pursuant to this division (including such changes in the plans as the applicant may have made upon their suggestion) with their recommendations as to the granting or denying of the application. They shall, in their report and recommendation, state whether the depth or depths at which the pipeline is proposed to be laid through undeveloped or unplatted areas is, to the extent economically feasible, consistent with the probable future development of such areas and with the probable location of and opening of future streets and the probable laying of water, sanitary sewer and storm sewer lines incident to such probable future development. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-42. - Fee. 
Every ordinance granting a franchise or license for the carrying of trunk pipelines under any city streets shall provide that the grantee shall pay to the city an initial franchise or license fee in the amount of three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00) per pipeline and for the payment of subsequent fees thereafter in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per year per pipeline and all amounts as may subsequently be set by amendment to this section or otherwise set by the city. After payment of the initial fee, all subsequent fees shall be due and payable on December 31 of each subsequent year for the term of the franchise or license. Advance payment of the franchise or license fee for more than one (1) [year] shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70; Ord. No. 81-128, § 3, 8-4-81; Ord. No. 94-102, § 3, 6-21-94; Ord. No. 99-104, § 4, 6-15-99; Ord. No. 08-125, § 4, 5-20-08; Ord. No. 08-307, § 3, 12-16-08)  
Sec. 27-42.1. - Transfer fee. 
A trunk line franchise that is transferred from a franchisee to another entity shall be subject to a franchise fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per pipeline payable by the transferee. After the payment of this transfer fee, the fee for subsequent years shall by payable by the transferee under the same conditions and terms as set forth in section 27-42. 
(Ord. No. 94-102, § 4, 6-21-94; Ord. No. 08-125, § 5, 5-20-08; Ord. No. 08-307, § 4, 12-16-08)  
Sec. 27-42.2. - License fee. 
The ordinance granting a gathering line license shall provide for the payment by the grantee to the City of Pasadena of an initial license fee in the amount of three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00) per pipeline and for the payment of subsequent fees thereafter in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per year per pipeline and all amounts as may subsequently be set by this chapter or otherwise set by the City of Pasadena. After payment of the initial fee, all subsequent fees shall be due and payable on December 31st of each subsequent year for the term of the license. Advance payment of the license fee for more than one (1) year shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 99-104, § 5, 6-15-99; Ord. No. 08-125, § 6, 5-20-08; Ord. No. 08-307, § 5, 12-16-08)  
Sec. 27-43. - Designation of locations for line to cross or run along and under streets. 
The ordinance granting a trunk line franchise under this article shall state the streets across or along and under which the pipeline is to be laid and shall state, with particularity, the point or points at which the pipeline will cross or run along and under any such street. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Sec. 27-44. - Minimum depth of line. 
No trunk line franchise shall be granted under this article, unless so much of the entire pipeline as is proposed to be laid through or under any undeveloped or unplatted area within the limits of the city is to be buried and laid to a depth of at least four (4) feet, measured between the top of the line and the natural surface of the ground; provided that, at any point or points where such line is to cross or run along and under an existing street, or any proposed street which has been designated on the master plan for the city or the official city map, such line must be buried to a depth of at least six (6) feet, measured between the top of the line and the natural surface of the ground. If, at any particular point or points, the director or public works recommends that a greater or lesser depth be required, if known and reasonable facts presented show that the recommendation is prudent and reasonable, such franchise will not be granted except upon agreement by the grantee to comply with such required depth. 
(Ord. No. 70-59, § 1, 4-7-70)  
Chapter 28 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 9; mobile homes and mobile home parks, Ch. 21; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 32; basic subdivision ordinance, App. A; townhouse subdivisions, App. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 28-1. - Department created. 
There is hereby created the department of planning, an executive department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1707, § 1, 9-21-65)  
Secs. 28-2—28-16. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DIRECTOR OF PLANNING 
 
Sec. 28-17. - Position created; appointment and term. 
There is hereby established, in the office of city planning, the position of director of city planning. The director shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed and approved by the city council. The director may serve for a term of one (1) year or until his successor is appointed and qualified. Incumbency may be ended in less than one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 1707, § 2, 9-21-65)  
Sec. 28-18. - General powers and duties. 
The director of planning shall superintend the office of city planning and all employees assigned thereto. He shall coordinate the development of the plan or plans, map or maps, for all city planning over multiples of years. He shall also plan and recommend for the coordination of future municipal development with the planning and development of other governmental agencies, particularly as to vehicular traffic flow, street, highway and utility connections, and water procurement, storage and distribution. Studies and research for the maintenance and revision, as conditions indicate, of the city's plans and maps for multiple-years development shall be a continuing duty of the planning director and he shall have the right to submit all or any part of his studies and research, with or without recommendations, to the planning and zoning commission, in addition to work he may be directed to perform by such commission. 
(Ord. No. 1707, §§ 4-1, 4-2, 9-21-65) 
Cross reference— Duty of director of planning to assist building commission, § 9-33.  
Sec. 28-19. - To serve as executive officer of planning and zoning commission. 
The director of planning shall serve as the executive officer of the planning and zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 1707, § 4-2, 9-21-65)  
Secs. 28-20—28-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Planning and zoning commission action on mobile home park plats, § 21-80 et seq.; plats approved by planning and zoning commission to conform to driveway regulations, § 32-33. 
 
Sec. 28-30. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the term "commission" shall mean the City of Pasadena Planning and Zoning Commission created by section 28-31. The term "subcommission" shall mean the subdivision plat subcommission of the planning and zoning commission, as provided for in section 28-43.  
Sec. 28-31. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created and established, within and for the city the City of Pasadena Planning and Zoning Commission, composed of nine (9) members, whose offices are hereby created and established. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 1, 7-6-65; Ord. No. 68-54, § 1, 4-9-68)  
Sec. 28-32. - Qualifications of members. 
Each member of the commission shall be a resident citizen, a freeholder of land situated within the incorporated limits of the city, and a qualified voter of the city. Any member who ceases to hold all such qualifications shall, ipso facto upon such cessation, terminate his membership, subject only to written approval by the mayor filed with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 2, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-33. - Appointment and terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  All members of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. Each member shall serve for a term of one (1) year from the date of his appointment, unless sooner terminated. 
(b)  All vacancies in membership of the commission shall be filled as soon as practicable after the occurrence of such vacancies by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. The term of a member appointed and confirmed to fill a vacancy shall be one (1) year from the date of his appointment, unless sooner terminated. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 2, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-34. - Members to serve without compensation. 
The members of the commission, in the performance of their official duties, shall serve without compensation for office. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 2, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-35. - Officers designated. 
The officers of the commission shall consist of a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary. The director of planning shall serve as the executive officer of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 3, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-36. - Election and terms of officers. 
The chairman, the vice-chairman and the secretary of the commission shall be nominated by the members of the commission in such manner as the commission shall prescribe at its first meeting as a committee of the whole, and each officer shall be elected by a majority vote of the qualified and serving members of the commission. The terms of all elected officeships shall be concurrent and limited within the term of the officer's commission membership appointment. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 3, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-37. - General powers and duties of officers. 
The general powers and duties of the officers of the planning commission shall be as follows: 
(a)  Chairman: 
(1)  Preside at all meetings of the commission. 
(2)  Call special meetings of the commission in accordance with the bylaws and rules of procedure. 
(3)  Sign official documents of the commission. 
(4)  See that all actions of the commission are properly taken. 
(5)  Appoint other commissioners to committees or subcommittees. 
(6)  Be responsible for the general direction of the commission under the supervision of the mayor. 
(7)  May be a member of all committees and subcommittees. 
(b)  Vice-chairman: 
(1)  Exercise or perform all the duties and be subject to all the responsibilities of the chairman during the absence, disability or disqualification of the chairman. 
(c)  Secretary: 
(1)  Sign official documents of the commission. 
(2)  Exercise or perform all the duties and be subject to all the responsibilities of the chairman during the absence, disability or disqualification of the chairman and vice-chairman. 
(d)  Planning director and staff. The commission may delegate to the planning director and staff of the planning department the responsibilities as follows: 
(1)  Transcribe, edit and prepare in final format minutes of all meetings of the commission. 
(2)  Act as custodian of commission records and officially approved minutes of all meetings of the commission keeping same in an appropriate minute book. 
(3)  Give or serve all notices as required by law or by the bylaws. 
(4)  Prepare the agenda for all meetings of the commission. 
(5)  Prepare all correspondence and superintend all work ordered by the commission as related to official actions of the commission and respond to such correspondence, as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 3, 7-6-65; Ord. No. 84-61, § 1, 3-27-84)  
Sec. 28-38. - Monthly meetings required; termination of membership for failure to attend meetings. 
The commission shall hold regular monthly meetings. Any member having three (3) consecutive absences from regular monthly meetings without excuse approved by a majority of the commission qualified and serving, one of such majority to be the chairman, if then qualified and serving, after due notice, personally, by phone or mail, or by notice in the minutes of a prior regular meeting, shall have his membership ipso facto terminated, subject only to the mayor's approval. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 4, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-39. - Procedure. 
The procedure of the commission, except as prescribed in this article, shall be fixed by rules and regulations of the city council and by rules, regulations and bylaws of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 4, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-40. - Quorum. 
Fifty-one (51) per cent of the qualified and serving members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. A consensus vote by a minimum of five (5) members of the commission shall constitute an official act of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 3, 7-6-65; Ord. No. 83-379, § 1, 12-13-83)  
Sec. 28-41. - General powers and duties of commission. 
The commission shall have the power and it shall be its duty: 
(1)  To prepare maps and plans of the whole or any portion of the city and of any land outside the city which, in the opinion of the commission, bears a relation to the planning of the city, and to change, add to or extend such maps and plans as it deems advisable. Such maps and plans shall show and describe recommended land use sectors, the location and extent of streets, parkways, highways, concourse walks, elevated ways, subways, alleys, public ways, tunnels, bridges, viaducts, overpasses, underpasses, parks, playfields, playgrounds, and other public grounds, improvements, eleemosynary institutions, including public buildings and utilities and utility easements, public and private. The removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, shortening, extension, vacation, abandonment or change of use of any of the aforementioned structures, works, improvements, facilities or places shall likewise be shown and described. 
(2)  The commission may adopt the plan as a whole by a single resolution, or may by successive resolutions adopt successive parts of the plan, such parts corresponding to major geographical sectors of the city and to adjacent related lands or to functional divisions of the subject matter of the plan, and may adopt any amendment or extension thereof or addition thereto. Each resolution shall refer expressly to the maps and descriptive and other matter intended by the commission to form the whole or part of the plan and the adoption of the resolution shall be recorded on the map and the annexed descriptive and other matter by the signatures of the chairman and secretary of the commission. An attested copy of the plan or sufficiently identifying part thereof shall be certified by the city council for approval or disapproval. In the event there is one or more dissenting votes cast in the commission ballot for adoption of the plan, the member or members casting such dissenting votes shall be entitled to submit their objections or alternative plans directly to the city council prior to or at the time of the city council's consideration of the plan certified as adopted by the commission. Such objections and alternative plans, if any, may be submitted individually or jointly by the members dissenting. 
(3)  To accomplish research, studies and plans for city improvement and beautification over multiples of years. 
(4)  To act with and assist city officers and departments and other governmental agencies in formulating and executing proper plans of municipal development. 
(5)  To recommend all types of vehicular traffic flow planning and controls. 
(6)  To investigate, consider and report, with recommendations for action as hereinafter provided, to the city council upon the layout or platting of new subdivisions of the city or of property adjacent to or near the city, and upon changes, alterations and vacations of plats, and to perform all duties imposed upon city planning commissions by the statutes of the State of Texas. 
(7)  To act with and assist other city departments, the Pasadena Chamber of Commerce and the tourist and industrial attraction and promotion agencies of the County of Harris and the State of Texas in creating facilities and opportunities for the location of new business and industry and the improved accommodation of existing business and industry within the city. 
(8)  To submit to the mayor requests for funds, budgeted or unbudgeted, with approval of the city controller and the city council, for the working operations of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 4, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-42. - Public hearing prerequisite to adoption of plan. 
Before the adoption of the plan referred to in section 28-41, or any part thereof, or any amendment, extension or addition thereto, the commission shall hold a public hearing. The hearing shall be held within the city at a time and place to be designated in a notice published in the official newspaper of the city at least fifteen (15) days prior to the time stated in the notice. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 4, 7-6-65)  
Sec. 28-43. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 83-379, § 2, adopted Dec. 13, 1983, repealed § 28-43. Said section was relative to a subdivision plat committee and derived from Ord. No. 1686, § 5, adopted July 6, 1965.  
Sec. 28-44. - Rules, regulations and bylaws for government of commission and subcommission. 
(a)  The city council may prescribe rules and regulations for the government of the commission and the subcommission or may, by resolution, adopt rules and regulations promulgated by the commission or by the subcommission. The commission and subcommission may adopt bylaws for their respective government. 
(b)  All rules and regulations promulgated by the commission or the subcommission and bylaws adopted by the commission or subcommission shall become effective only after approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1686, § 6, 7-6-65)  
ARTICLE IV. - PLANNING DEVELOPMENT FEES 
 
Sec. 28-45. - General. 
(1)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish the fee amounts for administrative fees, which are designed to defray the costs incurred by the city for administering this chapter and/or plan and plat review. 
(2)  Amendment. The fees established herein may be revised from time to time. 
(3)  Procedure. No application for plan or plat review shall be accepted until the applicant has paid all fees as set forth herein. Fees paid shall be non-refundable. 
(Ord. No. 18-102, § 5, 8-21-18)
