DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, adopted Jan. 16, 1990, amended Art. III, Div. 1, to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. III, Div. 1, §§ 30-49—30-58, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 68-38, §§ 1, 5, 7—9, adopted March 26, 1968 and Ord. No. 83-65, § 1, adopted March 1, 1983. 
 
Sec. 30-49. - Delivery to director of purchases for sale; when. 
All unclaimed or abandoned personal property of every kind, except whiskey, wine, and beer, seized by Pasadena police which is not held as evidence to be used in any pending case and has not been ordered destroyed or returned to the person entitled to possession of the same by magistrate, which shall remain unclaimed for a period of thirty (30) days shall be delivered to the director of purchases of the City of Pasadena for disposition in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 94-96, § 1, 5-31-94)  
Sec. 30-50. - Notice to last known owner of intent to sell. 
The director or purchases of the City of Pasadena shall mail a notice to the last known address of the owner of such property by certified mail. Such notice shall describe the property being held, give the name and address of the officer holding such property, and shall state that if the owner does not claim such property within six (6) months from the date of the notice, such property will be sold and the proceeds of such sale, after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping such property and the cost of the sale, placed in the treasury of the City of Pasadena. 
If the owner of such property is unknown or if the address of the owner is unknown, then the director of purchases of the City of Pasadena shall cause to be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Pasadena a notice containing a description of the properties held, the name of the owner if known, the name and address of the director of purchases holding such property, and a statement that if the owner does not claim such property within six (6) months from the date of publication such property will be sold and the proceeds of such sale, after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping such property and the cost of the sale, placed in the treasury of the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90)  
Sec. 30-51. - Authorization to sell personal property. 
The city is hereby authorized to sell at a public auction, through the agency of its director of purchases, personal property which has been in the possession of the purchasing department for a period of at least six (6) months, which property has remained unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by its rightful owner. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90)  
Sec. 30-52. - Establishment of sale date. 
The director of purchases shall establish a proposed date for the sale at public auction of property under this article whenever, in the director's opinion, a sufficient amount of such property has accumulated to justify such sale. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90)  
Sec. 30-53. - Notice of sale to be published; insufficient bids. 
The sale of any property hereunder shall be preceded by notice published once at least three (3) weeks prior to the date of such sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Pasadena, stating the description of the property, the name of the owner if known, and the date and place that such sale will occur. If the director of purchases shall consider any bid as insufficient, the director need not sell such property but may decline such bid and reoffer such property for sale. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90)  
Sec. 30-54. - Right of real owner to file claims; allowance and denial by city council. 
The real owner of any property sold shall have the right to file a claim to the proceeds of such sale with the city council of the City of Pasadena. If the claim is allowed by the city council, the controller shall pay the owner such funds as were paid into the treasury of the City of Pasadena as proceeds of the sale. If the claim is denied by city council, or if city council fails to act upon the claim within ninety (90) days, the claimant may seek remedies as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90)  
Sec. 30-55. - Disposition of funds. 
All monies derived from any auction provided for in this article shall be applied first to the storage charge accrued against the property sold and secondly to the general revenues of the city; provided, however, that all such monies shall be deposited by the city controller in a special escrow account established for the purpose and held for a period of two (2) years prior to being transferred to the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90)  
Sec. 30-56. - Suitability of property to be sold; authority to determine disposition. 
For the purposes of this article, and except as otherwise specifically provided, the director of purchases is hereby authorized to decide upon the fitness or suitability of property to be sold at public auction or to be used by city departments, or to be destroyed, or to be donated to a charitable organization, such organization to be of the Salvation Army type. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 94-96, § 2, 5-31-94)  
Sec. 30-57. - Use of property by city departments. 
If the provisions of this article have been met and the property scheduled for sale, the property may be transferred by the director of purchasing to any city department for official use of that department. The department shall return the property to the director of purchases for sale when the department has completed its use of the property. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 94-96, § 3, 5-31-94)  
Sec. 30-58. - Liability of city. 
The City of Pasadena shall not in any instance be liable to any person for damages as compensation for any property retained for official use or sold at public auction under this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 1-16-90)  
Secs. 30-59—30-63. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DISPOSITION OF SPECIFIC PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 30-64. - Motor vehicles and auto accessories and tires. 
(a)  All motor vehicles and auto accessories and tires, which have been in the possession of the police department for a period of at least ninety (90) days, and remain unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owners, and which are not being held by the department as evidence for any trial or pending case filed of record, and which have not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession thereof by a court of competent jurisdiction, may be retained by the city for official use only or may be sold at public auction as set out in division 1 of this article. 
(b)  A list shall be prepared by the police department of all motor vehicles and auto accessories and tires that have been returned to their rightful owners and of those items retained by the city for official use only. 
(c)  A list shall be prepared by the police department of those motor vehicles not returned or sold, or being officially used, and a copy of such list shall be mailed to local junk dealers (or advertised) requesting bids for same and stating a three (3) day period to submit a bid for such vehicles. The highest bidder shall be notified to bring the amount of his bid, in cash or a cashier's check, to the police department, and the bidder shall remove such vehicles, at his expense, within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 68-38, § 2, 3-26-68)  
Sec. 30-65. - Firearms. 
(a)  All firearms which have been in the possession of the police department for a period of at least one (1) year and remaining unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owners, and which are not being held by the department as evidence for any trial or pending case filed of record, and which have not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession thereof by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be retained by the police department for its official use and placed in the police arsenal. If such firearms are nonusable, they shall be sold by public auction under the provisions of division 1 of this article or disposed of in accord with subsection (b) below. 
(b)  Those firearms not retained for official use or sold at public auction shall be transported to an established firm that melts steel and shall be destroyed by melting same. The chief of police shall supervise such destruction, or he may direct the superintendent of the identification and records division of the police department to do so. 
(c)  A list of all firearms that are retained by the police department shall be made by the chief of police, such list to consist of a physical description of the firearms, including the serial number, brand name, and the like. A copy of such list shall be sent to the mayor and to the superintendent of identification and records division of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 68-38, § 3, 3-26-68)  
Sec. 30-66. - Bicycles and tricycles. 
(a)  All bicycles and tricycles which have been in the possession of the police department for a period of at least ninety (90) days, and which have remained unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owners, and which are not being held by the department as evidence for a trial or pending case filed of record, and which have not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession thereof by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be sold at public auction as set out in division 1 of this article. 
(b)  Those bicycles and tricycles not sold at public auction nor returned to their rightful owners, and still in the possession of the police department on the first day of December of any year, may be donated to any organization, at the discretion of the chief of police, and such organization shall repair same and donate same to needy children. 
(c)  A list shall be prepared by the police department of bicycles and tricycles that are donated for charity, and a copy shall be delivered to the city secretary and the city council and a copy of same shall be retained by the police department in its record division. 
(Ord. No. 68-38, § 4, 3-26-68) 
Cross reference— Bicycles generally, Ch. 8.  
Sec. 30-67. - Alcoholic beverages. 
Alcoholic beverages in any type of containers, which have been in the possession of the police department for at least thirty (30) days, and which have remained unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owners, and which are not being held by the department as evidence for trial or trials and pending cases filed of record, and which have not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession thereof by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be destroyed under the supervision of the chief of police and he shall certify such destruction to the mayor within ten (10) days of such destruction. 
(Ord. No. 68-38, § 6, 3-26-68) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages generally, Ch. 3.  
Secs. 30-68—30-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 30-71. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm users and alarm companies to properly use and maintain the operational effectiveness of alarm systems in order to improve the reliability of alarm systems and reduce or eliminate false alarms. 
(b)  This article governs alarm systems intended to summon law enforcement response, and requires registration, establishes fees, provides for penalties for violations, establishes a system of administration, and sets conditions for suspension of police response or revocation of registration. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-72. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the content requires a different definition: 
Alarm protective service means any service whereby the person providing such service installs, services, repairs, maintains, sells, replaces, or responds to an alarm system or which causes any of the activities to take place. For the purposes of this chapter, alarm protective services shall not include any persons engaged solely in the sale of alarm systems designed to cause an audible and/or visual signal to be emitted only in or on the premises in which the system is installed. 
Alarm site means a single premises or location (one street address) served by an alarm system or systems that are under the control of one owner. 
Alarm system means any assembly of equipment, device or devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police are expected to respond. The term alarm system shall include the terms automatic holdup alarm system, burglar alarm system, holdup alarm system, and manual holdup alarm system as those terms are hereinafter defined. For the purpose of this chapter an alarm system shall not include: 
(1)  Fire alarm systems and other alarm systems that monitor temperature, humidity, or any other condition not directly related to the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or an attempted robbery at a premises. 
(2)  An alarm system installed on a motor vehicle. 
(3)  An alarm system designed to alert only the inhabitants of a premises that does not have a local alarm. 
Alarm system user means the owner, agent or person in control of the property on which an alarm system or systems is maintained within the corporate limits of the city. 
Automatic dialing device means an alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a pre-recorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
Automatic holdup alarm system means an alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the action of a robber. 
Burglar alarm system means an alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry into an area protected by the alarm system. 
Chief means the Chief of Police of the City of Pasadena, Texas or representative designated by such chief. 
Duress alarm means the deliberate activation of a silent alarm by entering at a keypad a code that is different from the normal arm/disarm code, or by a separate deliberate act at another device. 
False alarm means any activation of an alarm system through mechanical or electronic failure, malfunction, improper installation, negligence of the owner, agent or person in control of the property or any other such activation which is not a result of an emergency or threat of emergency for which the alarm system was designed to give notice and for which the responding police officer arrives within thirty (30) minutes after receipt of the alarm notification and finds no evidence of any criminal activity. For the purpose of this chapter a false alarm shall not include: Any activation of an alarm system to which the response by the police department is cancelled by the alarm protective service prior to arrival of responding police officer at the property on which the alarm system causing the response is located. 
Holdup alarm system means an alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted robbery. 
Manual holdup alarm system means an alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the direct action of the persons attacked or by an observer of the attack. 
Monitoring means the process by which an alarm company receives signals from an alarm system and relays an alarm notification to the city. 
Panic alarm means an audible or silent alarm generated by the deliberate activation of a panic device. 
Permit means a certificate of authorization issued by the police department to the owner, agent, or person in control of the property which authorizes the operation of an alarm system of systems at an alarm site. 
Permit holder means any individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization or other entity to whom an alarm system permit is issued. 
Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization or other entity. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-73. - Permit application; issuance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to be operated, or permit the operation of an alarm system or systems at an alarm site unless a valid permit has been issued by the police department for such system. This requirement shall not be applicable to an alarm protective service unless the alarm protective service is the owner, agent, or person in control of the property which the alarm system is designed to protect. An alarm system user shall be in violation of this chapter if he permits the operation of such system without a proper permit. 
(b)  An alarm system user or his agent shall obtain an annual permit for each alarm site. 
(c)  Application for a permit or renewal for the operation of an alarm system or systems at an alarm site shall be made with the police department by the owner, agent, or person having control over the property on which the alarm system is to be installed and operated. Application shall be made in writing on a form designated by the city. On such application form, the applicant shall set forth: 
(1)  The name, address, and two (2) telephone numbers of the owner, agent, or person in control of the property to be protected; 
(2)  The street address of the property on which the alarm system is to be installed and operated; 
(3)  A brief description of the type of property to be protected (i.e. commercial, residential, or industrial, etc.); 
(4)  Any business name or title used for the premises on which the alarm system is to be installed and operated; 
(5)  Name, address, and telephone number of the monitoring company and alarm installation company that will install and service the alarm system. 
(6)  Names and telephone numbers of one or more persons who are able to and have agreed to receive notification at any time from the police department in order to deactivate the alarm system if it becomes necessary; 
(7)  Any other pertinent information required by the police department which is necessary for the enforcement of the charter. 
(d)  The police department shall issue a permit to the individual, corporation or other legal entity in control of the property to be protected upon submission in person or by mail of a completed application and payment of the appropriate fee, unless any statement made in the application is incomplete or false. Incomplete or false application information will result in rejection of the application. 
(e)  The police department shall treat all information on the application as confidential. 
(f)  Any permit issued pursuant of this chapter shall be applicable only to the permit holder and is not transferable. 
(g)  Each permit issued to an alarm system user shall be valid for a one-year period unless one of the following occurs earlier: 
(1)  Control of protected property is transferred from the permit holder; 
(2)  Permit holder voluntarily discontinues services provided by a particular alarm protective service, and/or disconnects alarm system; 
(3)  Revocation of the permit by the police department pursuant to section 30-78. 
(h)  The annual fee for a permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be: 
(1)  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for a residential alarm site; 
(2)  Fifteen dollars ($15.00) for a residential unit of an apartment complex; and 
(3)  Thirty dollars ($30.00) for a commercial alarm site including an apartment complex. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-74. - Permit duration and renewal. 
(1)  A permit expires one year from the date of issuance and must be renewed annually by submitting an updated application and a permit renewal fee in accordance with section 30-73 of this chapter. Before terminating a permit for nonrenewal, the chief shall provide thirty (30) days prior written notice to the permit holder of the need to renew the permit and file an updated permit application. 
(2)  The chief may refuse to renew a permit for an alarm system that has had eight (8) or more false alarms during the calendar year (January 1 through December 31). 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 06-315, § 1, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 30-75. - Proper alarm system operation and maintenance. 
(a)  A permit holder or person in control of an alarm system shall: 
(1)  Maintain premises containing an alarm system in a manner that ensures proper operation of the alarm system; 
(2)  Maintain the alarm system in a manner that will minimize false alarm notifications; 
(3)  Respond or cause a representative to respond within a reasonable period of time when notified by the city to repair or inactivate a malfunctioning alarm system, to provide access to the premises, or to provide security for the premises; and 
(4)  Not intentionally activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report. 
(b)  A person in control of a local alarm shall adjust the mechanism or cause the mechanism to be adjusted so that an alarm signal, after being activated, will sound for no longer than: 
(1)  Thirty (30) minutes for an alarm system installed before October 1, 1995, except as otherwise provided in subsection (b)(2)b. of this section; and 
(2)  Ten (10) minutes for an alarm system: 
a.  Installed on or after October 1, 1995; or 
b.  Installed before October 1, 1995, but to which any improvement is made on or after October 1, 1995. 
(c)  The police department shall refuse police response to any alarm notification from an alarm site that does not have a valid permit, unless the alarm notification was a duress alarm, a hold up alarm, a panic alarm or reported to a 9-1-1 emergency telephone number or to the police department by a person other than an alarm company. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-76. - Monitoring procedures. 
Any alarm company engaged in the business of monitoring alarm systems in the city shall: 
(1)  Report alarm signals only by using telephone numbers designated by the chief; 
(2)  Before requesting police response to an alarm signal, attempt to verify every alarm signal, except a duress, hold up, or panic alarm activation; 
a.  For the purposes of this section verify means an attempt by the monitoring company, or its representatives to contact the alarm site and/or alarm user by telephone and/or other electronic means, whether or not actual contact with a person is made, to determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting law enforcement dispatch, in an attempt to avoid an unnecessary alarm dispatch request. For the purpose of this article, telephone verification shall require, as a minimum, that a second call be made to a different number if the first attempt fails to reach an alarm user who can properly identify themselves to determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting law enforcement dispatch. 
(3)  When reporting an alarm notification to the city, provide the alarm permit number and address of the alarm site from which the alarm notification originated; and 
(4)  Communicate alarm notifications to the city in a manner and form determined by the chief. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-77. - Penalty fee for city responses to excessive false alarms. 
(a)  For each false alarm the city will assess a penalty fee as follows: 
(1)  Fifty dollars ($50.00) if the location has had more than three (3) but fewer than six (6) other false alarms in the calendar year (January 1 through December 31); 
(2)  Seventy-five dollars ($75.00), if the location has had more than five (5) but fewer than eight (8) other false alarms in the calendar year (January 1 through December 31); or 
(3)  One hundred dollars ($100.00), if the location has had eight (8) or more other false alarms in the calendar year (January 1 through December 31). 
(b)  Upon new alarm installation the alarm company will not call the police department dispatch for response for the first seven (7) days after installation. The monitoring company shall not make an alarm dispatch request of a law enforcement agency in response to a burglar alarm signal, excluding panic, duress and holdup signals, during the first seven (7) days following an alarm system installation. The police chief may grant an alarm user's request for an exemption from this waiting period based upon a determination that special circumstances substantiate the need for the exemption. 
(c)  A permit holder will not be assessed a penalty fee for a response to notification of the activation of an alarm system if the permit holder shows to the police chief or his designated representative that the activation was not a false alarm and any response by the police department to such notification of an alarm system will not be included in determining the penalty fee set out above. For the purposes of determining the penalty fee set out above, the burden shall be on the permit holder to prove that the activation of the alarm system was not a false alarm. 
(d)  The police officer responding to a false alarm shall place a notice in a visible location on a window of the location for which the false alarm was reported advising of the responding officer's name and time and date of the response to the false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 06-315, § 1, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 30-78. - Revocation of permits. 
(a)  The chief of police may revoke an alarm system permit if he determines that: 
(1)  There is a false statement of a material matter on the application for a permit; 
(2)  The permit holder has violated this chapter or any of its provisions; or 
(3)  The permit holder has failed to make timely payment of a penalty fee assessed under section 30-77 within thirty (30) days of mailed notification to permit holder. 
(4)  The permit holder has had eight (8) or more false alarms during the calendar year (January 1 through December 31). 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an alarm system during the period in which his alarm permit is revoked. 
(c)  A permit holder or person in control of an alarm system shall attempt to resolve the revocation or denial of a permit with the chief or his designated representative before filing an appeal as described in section 30-79. 
(d)  The fee for reinstatement of any permit after revocation shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). This fee, however, shall not apply to any reinstatement made pursuant to an appeal under section 30-79. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 06-216, § 1, 9-12-06; Ord. No. 06-315, § 1, 12-19-06)  
Sec. 30-79. - Appeal from penalty fee; denial or revocation of a permit. 
(a)  Any permit holder aggrieved by the decision to assess a penalty fee by the chief of police or his designated representative as provided for in section 30-77, may appeal the decision to a Judge of the Pasadena Municipal Court by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal within ten (10) days after the chief of police or his designated representative renders the decision. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the city secretary stays an action of the chief of police in assessing a penalty fee until a judge makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the chief of police or his designated representative is final. 
(b)  If the chief of police refuses to issue or revokes a permit, he shall send to the applicant or permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action and a statement of the right to an appeal. The applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the chief of police to a Judge of the Pasadena Municipal Court by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal, within ten (10) days after receipt or the notice from the chief of police. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the board stays an action of the chief of police in revoking a permit until the board makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the chief of police is final. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 06-216, § 2, 9-12-06)  
Sec. 30-80. - Standards for alarm protective services and alarm system operation. 
(a)  The chief of police may set reasonable standards and procedures to be followed by any alarm protective service when giving notice to the police department or activation of an alarm system. Such standards and procedures shall be set out in writing and made available to any alarm system business requesting same. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to operate or cause to be operated any automatic dialing device which when activated uses a telephone device or attachment to automatically select a telephone line leading into the communication center of the police department and then transmits any prerecorded message or signal. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-81. - Violations; penalty; corporations, partnerships and associations. 
(a)  An alarm company, an alarm permit holder, or a person in control of an alarm system commits an offense if he violates any provision of this article by either commission of an act that is forbidden or omission of a duty or responsibility imposed upon him by this article. 
(b)  A person who violates a provision of this article is guilty of a separate offense for each day or portion of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense is punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not less than: 
(1)  Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the first conviction; and 
(2)  Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the second and each subsequent conviction. 
(c)  In addition to prohibiting or requiring certain conduct of individuals, it is the intent of this article to hold a corporation, partnership, or other association criminally responsible for acts or omissions performed by an agent acting in behalf of the corporation, partnership, or other association, and within the scope of employment. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-82. - Alarm system operating instructions. 
A person in control of an alarm system shall maintain at each alarm site a complete set of written operating instructions for each alarm system. Special codes, combination, or passwords must not be included in these instructions. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 30-83. - System performance reviews. 
If there is reason to believe that an alarm system is not being used or maintained in a manner that ensures proper operation to suppress false alarms, the chief may require a conference to review the circumstances of each false alarm with the alarm permit holder and the alarm company under contract with the alarm permit holder. A person may be issued a citation for failing to attend a system performance review after receiving notice of the conference from the chief. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Chapter 31 - STANDARD SIGN CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 95-229, § 1, adopted Jan. 7, 1995, repealed former Ch. 31, §§ 31-1—31-15, in its entirety. Former Ch. 31 provided for the standard sign code and derived from Ord. No. 88-9, § 2, adopted Jan. 26, 1988; Ord. No. 90-134, §§ 2, 3, adopted July 31, 1990; Ord. No. 91-25, §§ 1—6, adopted Feb. 19, 1991; and Ord. No. 93-57, § 1, adopted April 20, 1993. Section 2 of Ord. No. 95-229 enacted new provisions relative to similar subject matter set out herein as §§ 31-1—31-18. 
Subsequently, Ord. No. 00-51, § 1, adopted April 11, 2000, enacted a new § 31-19, pertaining to subdivision entrance and neighborhood signage, which was never published herein because Ord. No. 00-145, which amended the chapter in its entirety, was adopted before § 31-19 could be published. While Ord. No. 00-145 did not specifically amend § 31-19, it is assumed that § 31-19 is included in the complete amendment of the chapter.

No. 95-229, § 2, 1-7-95; Ord. No. 96-134, § 1, 8-27-96; Ord. No. 97-100, §§ 1—5, 7, 8—15, 6-3-97; Ord. No. 97-118, §§ 1—4, 7-8-97; Ord. No. 97-146, §§ 1—3, 8-12-97; Ord. No. 97-213, §§ 1—11, 11-25-97; Ord. No. 98-37, §§ 1, 2, 4—8, 9, 3-3-98; Ord. No. 98-91, §§ 1—4, 6-16-98; Ord. No. 98-149, §§ 1, 2, 9-8-98. 
Cross reference— Building and building regulations, Ch. 9; application of electrical code to signs, § 12-21; sign required on premises of drive-in restaurant, § 20-60; pipeline signs obstructing or encroaching upon streets and alleys, § 32-3; street banners, § 32-44 et seq. 
 
Sec. 31-1. - Purpose. 
It is the purpose and intent of this chapter to regulate signs and to authorize the use of signs that are compatible with their surroundings, that are legible under the circumstances in which they are seen, that are effective in indexing the environment, and that are conducive to promoting traffic safety and the convenience and enjoyment of public travel by preventing visual distractions, protecting pedestrians, attracting visitors to the city, preserving and enhancing property values, promoting first-class business and commercial districts, and eliminating fire hazards. 
It is also the intention and purpose of this chapter to promote short- and long-term civic beauty and order by establishing standards and regulations for sign design, location, size, type, compatibility, and aesthetics. By doing so it is hoped this chapter will help to create streetscapes that are functional and attractive to both residents and visitors of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-2. - Scope. 
The intent is to regulate within the corporate and extraterritorial jurisdiction of the City of Pasadena, Texas, the design and placement of all signs, commercial and governmental identification/communication devices, and structures that are built specifically to identify, inform, and direct patrons to a particular merchant, store, establishment, or service. It is not the intent of this chapter to regulate the content of public speech. 
The regulations of this chapter are intended to apply to both on-premises and off-premises signs, but do not apply to handheld placards and other similar devices traditionally used for public protest and the exercise of free speech. Any noncommercial message may be substituted for any commercial message permitted under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-2.1. - Superiority clause. 
If any subdivision or individual tract of land contains restrictions or covenants relating to signs or any person or persons enter into a legally binding agreement which provides for the regulating of signs in a particular development and for more restrictive than these regulations, the more restrictive requirements shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-2.2. - Enforcement. 
Any sign not expressly allowed by this chapter is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-3. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply to this chapter: 
(1)  Advertising shall mean to seek the attraction or direct the attention of the public to any goods, services, or merchandise whatsoever or a location that provides goods, services, or merchandise. 
(2)  Alterations or repair to an advertising display shall mean repairs or improvements to a display, sign, or sign structure not exceeding fifty (50) per cent replacement value. 
(3)  Banner shall mean any water-resistant fabric or material on which there appears a display, typically supported at both ends. 
(4)  Business shall mean the erection or use of any property, building, or structure, permanent or temporary, for the primary purpose of conducting in said building or structure or on said property a legitimate commercial enterprise in compliance with all ordinances and regulations of the City of Pasadena governing such activity; business purpose shall not include any property, building, or structure erected or used for the primary purpose of securing a permit or erecting a sign. 
(5)  City shall mean the City of Pasadena, Texas. 
(6)  Display shall mean the message of any sign whether it be in words, symbols, or objects. 
(7)  Embellishment shall mean structural or decorative elements of a sign incorporating representations of the significant architectural features of the associated building or development. Embellishment shall not include letters, numerals, figures, emblems, logos, or other features conveying a commercial advertising message. 
(8)  Face shall mean the total display area and border of a sign. 
(9)  Federal primary system shall mean the interstate and freeway primary system and the non-freeway primary system. 
(10)  Intersection shall mean the intersection of streets, driveways, alleys, or any two (2) surfaces intended for motor vehicles. 
(11)  Interstate and freeway primary system shall mean the portion of the national system of interstate and defense highways located within Texas which now or hereafter may be officially designated the "interstate system" by the Texas Highway and Public Transportation Commission and approved pursuant to Title 3, United States Code Section 131, as amended. 
(12)  Nameplate shall mean a nonelectrical sign identifying only the name and occupation or profession of the occupant or occupants of premises on which the sign is located and not exceeding six (6) inches by eighteen (18) inches. 
(13)  Non-freeway primary system shall mean that portion of the connective main highway located within Texas which now or hereafter may be officially designated the "primary system" by the Texas Highway and Public Transportation Commission and approved pursuant to Title 23, United States Code Section 131, as amended. 
(14)  Owner shall mean the person who owns or leases the on-premises sign, the owner of the off-premises sign, or the owner of the real property on which the sign, whether it be on-premises or off-premises, is located. 
(15)  Person shall mean an individual, company, corporation, partnership, association, or any other entity. 
(16)  Primarily residential area shall mean the right-of-way (and adjoining property area) between two (2) intersecting public streets in which a majority of the total front footage is used for residential purposes. 
(17)  Public street shall mean the entire width between property lines of any road, street, way, alley, bridge, or other similar thoroughfare not privately owned or controlled when any part thereof is open to the public for vehicular traffic, is the responsibility of the city or other similar public agency to maintain, and is over which the city has legislative jurisdiction under its police power. 
(18)  Relocate shall mean the removal of a sign and any supporting structure from one (1) location and placing it or its replacement at a new location, even if the relocation is to a place on the same lot or parcel of property. 
(19)  Residential purposes shall mean property devoted to use as a single-family or multifamily residence. Residential purposes shall include, but not be limited to, property used for houses, duplexes, condominiums, town houses, town homes, patio homes, and apartments. Property used for hotels, motels, and boarding houses shall not be considered as used for residential purposes. Property devoted to both residential and nonresidential use shall be considered as used for residential purposes. 
(20)  Right-of-way shall mean the property fronting or immediately adjacent to and on either side of a public street or a nonpublic street which the public authority has the authority to use for the road or street. 
(21)  Sight triangle shall mean the triangle formed at an intersection by intersecting curb lines and a non-curb line joining the curb lines. The triangle is formed by a motorist's view of oncoming traffic when exiting a private drive or at the intersection of two (2) (or more) public streets. The motorist's eye is assumed to be at a point fifteen (15) feet from the edge of the roadway. Traffic must be visible for a distance of ten (10) times the speed limit on either side of the vehicle parallel to the intersecting roadway. No sign shall be placed in or above the triangular area created by the motorist's view described by this subsection (see Illustrations 2-1 and 3-1). 
(22)  Sight distance is the minimum visibility distance parallel to the curb lines that must be preserved. This distance is ten (10) times the speed limit in miles per hour of the intersecting public roadway. 
(23)  Sign shall mean an outdoor structure, sign, display, light, device, figure, painting, drawing, message, plaque, poster, billboard, or other thing that is designed, intended, or used to advertise or inform. Each separate message shall be considered a sign. 
(24)  Sign administrator shall mean the sign administrator as defined herein and those representatives that he/she may designate. 
(25)  Sign appeals committee shall mean the committee as defined herein and appointed as established herein. 
(26)  Sign company shall mean the person who engages in the business of leasing, constructing, or maintaining signs or sign structures. 
(27)  Sign location shall mean the exact spot the sign is located which spot cannot vary even as little as one (1) inch; does not mean entire lot or parcel of land on which a sign has been placed. 
(28)  Sign structure shall mean any structure which supports or is capable of supporting any sign. A sign structure may be a single pole and may or may not be an integral part of a building. 
(29)  Time periods shall mean calendar days unless otherwise specified. Such periods shall start on the day following the event, starting the time period to run, and end at 5 p.m. local time on the last day of such period. Any period ending on a day city hall is closed for any reason shall be extended until the next actual working day at city hall of the City of Pasadena. 
(30)  Visible shall mean the message, copy area, or advertising display seen (legible or not) without visual aid by a person of normal visual acuity or, simply stated, can be seen. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-4. - Sign classifications. 
(a)  Site classification. For the purpose of this chapter signs shall be first classified as either an "on-premises sign" or an "off-premises sign." 
(1)  On-premises sign shall mean any sign identifying or advertising a business, person, or activity which is installed and maintained on the same premises as the business, person, or activity. 
(2)  Off-premises sign shall mean any sign displaying advertising copy that pertains to a business, person, organization, activity, event, place, service, or product which is not principally located or primarily manufactured or sold on the premises of which the sign is located. 
(b)  Type classification. All signs shall be classified further into one (1) of the following type signs and shall conform to the specifications and descriptions contained herein: 
(1)  Ground sign shall mean a sign which is supported by uprights or braces in or upon the ground including monument signs, two-pole monument signs, converted portable signs, and portable signs as described herein. 
(2)  Marquee sign shall mean a projecting sign attached to or hung from a canopy or covered structure, projecting from and supported by a frame or pipe support extending beyond a building. 
(3)  Monument sign shall mean a freestanding sign with a base at least one-half (½) the width of the sign face it supports. 
(4)  Projecting sign shall mean any sign which is affixed to any building, wall, or structure and extends beyond the building, wall, or structure more than twelve (12) inches. 
(5)  Roof sign shall mean any sign erected, constructed or maintained upon, and attached to and structurally supported by the roof of a building. 
(6)  Wall sign shall mean any sign affixed to or painted upon the wall of any building. 
(7)  Flag sign shall mean any sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, or material affixed to a building, wall, or structure or on a staff or pole set in a concrete foundation. 
(8)  Awning sign shall mean any sign made of cloth, metal, or plastic with a metal frame attached to a building and projecting over a sidewalk, thoroughfare, or parking area when the same is so erected as to permit its being raised to a position flat against the building when not in use. 
(9)  Canopy sign shall mean any sign, other than an awning attached to a building, projecting over a thoroughfare, sidewalk, or parking area and not erected so as to permit its being raised to a flat position against the building, does not permit use of marquee letters, and is commonly supported by poles or uprights set upon the underlying ground. 
(10)  Multiple business sign shall mean that type of sign that is a single structure but has a different display for each different business, such as may be found at a shopping center. 
(11)  Special function classification. Any on-premises or off-premises sign of any type may also be included within one (1) or more of the following additional classifications according to the special functions of that sign: 
a.  Electrical sign shall mean any sign containing electrical wiring or utilizing electric current, but not including signs illuminated by a light source exterior to the sign structure. 
b.  Portable sign shall mean any sign designed or constructed to be easily moved from one (1) location to another including signs mounted upon a motor vehicle or designed to be mounted upon a trailer, bench, wheeled carrier, or other nonmotorized mobile structure. A portable sign with the wheels removed shall still be considered a portable sign hereunder. For the purpose of this chapter trailer signs and signs on benches are "portable signs." 
c.  Spectacular sign shall mean any sign which has any automatically changing advertising equipped with glaring or rotating strobe or spotlights. 
d.  Temporary commercial banners shall mean banners used by commercial businesses to advertise the business or a product related to that business and shall conform to the following requirements: 
1.  Be limited to placement for no more than fifteen (15) days per calendar quarter. Provided, however, temporary commercial banners designed and intended to promote or advertise a grand opening, going out of business, new location or new management, shall be allowed a single period of thirty (30) consecutive days, which shall be in addition to the fifteen (15) days per calendar quarter otherwise allowed. Furthermore, temporary commercial banners designed and intended to promote or advertise a special service, product, or sale during the hereinafter stated holiday periods shall be allowed for only the period of time hereinafter so specified, which shall be in addition to the fifteen (15) days per calendar quarter otherwise allowed: 
Holiday Sign Periods 	
Valentine's Day - February 	5 days 
Presidents Day - February 	5 days 
Easter - March or April 	5 days 
Memorial Day - May 	5 days 
Fourth of July - July 	5 days 
Labor Day - September 	5 days 
Thanksgiving - November 	7 days 
Hanukkah, Christmas, New Year's (Dec. 15 through Jan. 2) 	19 days 
 
2.  Not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in size; 
3.  Be attached to a building so as not to project above the roof line of that building except for buildings with parapet walls; in which case, the sign shall not project above the parapet; 
4.  Be limited to one (1) side of the building which fronts upon a customer parking area; and 
5.  No permit shall be issued for a temporary commercial banner until a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is paid by the applicant to the city. Such permit shall expire one (1) year from the date of issue. 
6.  May be used to cover existing sign only while business is occupied by new tenant or owner during time new sign is being made but, in no event, shall the banner be used for more than thirty (30) days, which must be consecutive. 
e.  Temporary sign shall mean any sign not to exceed twelve (12) square feet in size. Further, a temporary sign is intended to be used for a specific period of time (not to exceed thirty (30) days) and then removed. A portable sign, temporary commercial banner, or flag sign shall not be considered a temporary sign. 
f.  Movable sign shall mean signs of six (6) square feet or less designed to be moved by hand and normally stored inside the building during the nighttime. 
g.  Emitting sign shall mean any sign or symbol that emits any noise, chemical substance, or odor. 
h.  Inflatable sign shall mean any sign that is erected or maintained by inflating with air, helium, or other gaseous substance. Such sign shall be permitted for no more than thirty (30) days per year. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 02-38, § 1, 1-29-02)  
Sec. 31-5. - Sign administration and enforcement. 
(a)  Sign administrator. The mayor shall appoint or shall designate a sign administrator to administer and enforce the terms and conditions of this chapter and all other provisions of the laws relating to signs. The sign administrator is empowered to delegate the duties and powers granted to and imposed upon him/her by this chapter to other persons serving under the sign administrator. The sign administrator and such other persons shall constitute the sign administration section. The sign administrator is directed to enforce and carry out all provisions of this chapter. Final policy, decision-making authority does not reside with the sign administrator. Policy-making authority of the City of Pasadena regarding signs resides with the Pasadena city council. 
(b)  Enforcement responsibility. The duties of the sign administrator shall include not only the approval of issuance of permits, as required by this chapter, but also the responsibility of ensuring that all signs comply with this chapter and all other applicable laws and that all signs for which a permit is required do, in fact, have a permit. The sign administrator shall make such inspections as may be necessary and initiate appropriate actions to bring about compliance with this chapter and other applicable laws if such inspection discloses any instance of noncompliance. The sign administrator shall investigate thoroughly any complaints of alleged violations of this chapter. 
(c)  Powers of the sign administrator. The sign administrator's power and authority is limited to administering and enforcing the provisions of this chapter and all other laws relating to signs. Included among such powers are the following specific powers: 
(1)  Inspection and approval. Every sign for which a permit is required shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the sign administrator. When deemed advisable by the sign administrator, a sign may be inspected at the point of manufacture if such point is within or adjacent to the city limits of the City of Pasadena. 
(2)  Stop order. When the sign administrator or his/her representative discovers that a sign is being constructed not in conformance with this chapter, he/she shall issue a "stop work order" to the person or persons known to be so engaged. Upon notice and issuance of a stop order from the sign administrator, work on any sign being conducted in a manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter or being conducted in a dangerous or unsafe manner shall be immediately stopped. Such notice and order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, his agent, or person doing the work and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. When an emergency exists and written notice is impractical or when work in progress on a sign is being done in violation of the law or city ordinance, written notice shall not be required to be given by the sign administrator. The stop order shall contain a notice of the right to appeal as provided herein. Work shall not resume until the condition causing the stoppage is corrected to the sign administrator's satisfaction or the appeal process results in a reversal of the sign administrator's stop order. A stop work order tag may be affixed to a sign pending the sign administrator's delivery of written notice. The stop work order tag shall constitute effective written notice pending formal notification. All work shall immediately stop and not resume once a stop work order tag is placed on a sign. 
(3)  a.  Permit and license revocation. The sign administrator shall have, and is hereby granted, the power and the authority to revoke any and all licenses or permits authorized by this chapter for violation of the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
b.  Appeal procedure. Upon revoking such license or permits, the sign administrator shall notify by certified mail return receipt requested to the address given by the permittee or licensee on the application for such permit or license, to advise the permittee or licensee of such revocation and notify the permittee or licensee that the revocation will become final if not appealed to the sign appeals committee within ten (10) days. 
(4)  Establish procedures. The sign administrator shall have the authority to adopt procedures and provide forms required to implement the provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Enforce state and federal regulations. Pursuant to and in accordance with any agreement between the City of Pasadena and the State of Texas, or the United States Government, the sign administrator is hereby authorized to enforce any applicable terms and provisions of the Texas Highway Beautification Act, Texas Civil Statutes Annotated, Article 6624v.1, the Agreement for Carrying Out National Policy Relative to Control of Outdoor Advertising, entered into between the United States of America and the State of Texas, by instrument dated May 2, 1972, and any supplements or amendments to that agreement, and any rules or regulations promulgated by the State of Texas and/or the Texas Highway Department, pursuant to the said act or agreements with regard to signs. 
(6)  Issue citations. The sign administrator or his/her designated representative shall have the authority to issue citations to any owner, agent of the owner, or person in charge of the premises for any violation of this code existing on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-6. - Sign appeals committee. 
(a)  Composition. There is hereby created by this chapter the sign appeals committee. This committee shall be composed of five (5) positions. Members and alternates shall be designated by position and by name. One (1) member and two (2) alternates for each position shall be designated. This number of choices or members and alternates allows the committee to meet with a quorum without delay. The positions are designated as follows: 
(1)  The city's chief building official or any of his designees. 
(2)  The city's director of traffic and transportation, a representative of the police department with ten (10) years' experience, or the safety coordinator. 
(3)  An employee of the city's electrical department, the electrical inspector, or a representative from the permit department designated by the building official. 
(4)  A person actively engaged in the sign industry; the alternates shall also be engaged in the sign industry. 
(5)  A resident of the city; the alternates shall also be residents of the city. 
All members of the committee shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. This committee shall be the body of first review for any appeal related to this chapter and shall conduct all hearings on the denial of licenses or permits, the revocation of any license or permit, the issuance of stop work orders, and orders of removal. Meetings shall be called by the sign administrator as needed. Decisions of this committee may be appealed to city council as provided for in this chapter. 
(b)  Scope of review. The committee's review of denial of licenses or permits, stop orders, and revocation of licenses or permits is limited to determining if the sign administrator followed the proper procedures and if, indeed, there was a violation of this chapter that permitted the action taken by the sign administrator. 
(c)  Appeal of a revocation or stop work order. Under this chapter in order to appeal a denial or revocation of a license or permit or the issuance of a stop work order or removal order, the person whose license or permit application is denied, whose license or permit is revoked, whose work has been ordered stopped by a stop work order, or whose sign has been ordered removed must within ten (10) days and not thereafter of notification of denial, revocation, or stop work order file a written notice of appeal to the sign appeals committee through the city secretary. At such hearing the person so notified shall be permitted to present relevant facts and legal argument regarding the denial, revocation, stop work order, or order of removal. Following such hearing the sign appeals committee shall consider the merits of the case and shall by a written opinion affirm or set aside such denial, revocation, stop work order, or order of removal. 
(d)  Quorum and majority. A quorum shall be three (3) members in a health or safety emergency; otherwise, because of the multiple members for each position the quorum shall be five (5). A simple majority will be sufficient for all matters except overturning the sign administrator's revocation or stop work action. 
(e)  Majority needed in appeals. The sign appeals committee may hear and decide appeals which allege error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the sign administrator or building official in the enforcement of this chapter. A 4/5 -vote of the members present is necessary to overrule a decision of the sign administrator or building official. 
(f)  Municipal board. 
(1)  If a municipality requires the relocation, reconstruction, or removal of a sign within its corporate limits or extraterritorial jurisdiction, the presiding officer of the governing body of the municipality shall appoint a municipal board on sign control. The board must be composed of the following: 
• Two (2) real estate appraisers, each of whom must be a member in good standing of a nationally recognized professional appraiser society or trade organization that has an established code of ethics, educational program, and professional certification program; 
• One (1) person engaged in the sign business in the municipality; 
• One (1) employee of the Texas Department of Transportation who is familiar with real estate values in eminent domain proceedings; and 
• One (1) architect or landscape architect licensed by this state. 
(2)  A member of the board is appointed for a term of two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 02-38, § 2, 1-29-02)  
Sec. 31-7. - Appeals to city council. 
Any person wishing to appeal a decision of the sign appeals committee on the grounds that the decision misconstrues or wrongly interprets this chapter may within ten (10) days after receiving an adverse ruling of the committee, either by personal service or by certified mail return receipt requested, appeal the same to the city council, provided that the appealing party shall personally deliver to the city secretary or deposit that notice in the United States Mail addressed to the city secretary of the City of Pasadena within the said ten-day period. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the sign administrator may, subject to approval by the mayor, seek council review of matters brought before the sign appeals committee. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-8. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  (1)  General. Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction by court of competent jurisdiction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. Each day in which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the city attorney is hereby authorized to take all actions, both legal and equitable, necessary to assure compliance with this chapter. 
(2)  Real property owner. Any person who is the owner of the real property upon which an on-premises or off-premises sign is located and who shall permit a violation upon such real property of any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. Each day on which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the city attorney is hereby authorized to take all actions, both legal and equitable, necessary to assure compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  Subterfuge. Any permit secured before or after the effective date of this chapter which in the opinion of the sign administrator has been secured through subterfuge and not in full compliance with the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the sign administrator. 
(c)  Denial of entry for inspection. Whenever the sign administrator or his/her representative is denied admission to any premises for inspection or enforcement, the sign administrator may revoke all sign permits. 
(d)  Work done without a permit. Any person, firm, or organization installing, erecting, or reconstructing a sign or changing the location of a sign without a proper permit will be assessed an amount twice the applicable permit fees, in addition to any penalties, civil or criminal, which may be assessed as a result of a violation of the terms of this chapter. 
(e)  Illegal political campaign signs. No political campaign signs of any description shall be allowed on publicly owned property or the property of a public utility. All political campaign signs posted on private property shall be posted only with the consent of the owner or lessee of such property. 
(f)  Signs not currently permitted. Any sign not permitted under the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to all of the penalties and provisions of this chapter including removal, pursuant to the requirements of section 31-11 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-9. - Sign applications, permits, and fees.[2] 
(a)  Application procedure. Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be made upon forms provided by the sign administrator and shall contain, or have attached thereto, the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant. This shall be kept current at all times. 
(2)  Location of the building, structure, or lot to which or upon which the sign is to be attached or erected including lot, block, section number, and subdivision name or a metes-and-bounds description. 
(3)  Position of the sign in relation to nearby buildings or structures and all street curb lines and sidewalks bounding any part of the lot on which such sign is to be placed. 
(4)  Two (2) blueprints or ink drawings on a scale not smaller than one (1) inch to fifteen (15) feet of the plans and specifications showing the method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground. 
(5)  Applications for new ground signs when erected or constructed to heights exceeding twelve (12) feet above ground level shall be accompanied by a drawing of the entire sign structure prepared and certified by a professional engineer registered in the State of Texas. 
(6)  The sign administrator at his/her option may also require similar certification by a registered professional engineer where any unusual structural provisions of a proposed sign indicate such certification is necessary in the interest of public safety. 
(7)  A copy of stress sheets and calculations showing how the structure is designed for dead load and wind pressure on every point in the display surface. 
(8)  The name, street/business addresses, home/business telephone numbers, and driver's license number of the foreman, supervisor, or other person in charge of the construction, destruction, placement, or relocation of the sign and related structures. 
(9)  Notarized written consent of the owner, lessee, or duly authorized agent of the building, structure, or land to which or on which the sign is to be erected. 
(10)  Any electrical permit required and issued for the sign. 
(11)  Evidence of the insurance policy and bonds required by this chapter. 
(12)  Such other information as the sign administrator shall require to show full compliance with this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the city. 
(13)  Permission for the sign administrator or his/her representative to enter the property at any time the sign administrator or his/her representative deems it necessary for inspection and enforcement. 
(14)  The location of the sign. 
(15)  Detailed diagrams or drawings of the landscaping plan for the sign as well as a written description of the barrier wall around the landscaping and the materials which will be used to form the landscaping. The sign shall not extend beyond the landscaped area. Curbing, railroad ties or landscaping stones, rocks, bricks or other types of approved vehicular barriers at least one and one-half (1½) feet in height shall be placed around the landscaped area if necessary for the protection of the sign and pole cover from vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(b)  Permit required. No person shall hereafter erect, takedown, construct, destroy, reconstruct, relocate, remove, alter, or use a sign without first having secured a written permit as herein provided from the City of Pasadena. All signs illuminated by direct or indirect lighting shall, in addition, be subject to the electrical code and the permit requirements thereof. Permits are not transferable and will be used only by the person to whom it was issued. A copy of the permit will be posted at each erection site. No sign permit issued is effective unless it has been approved in writing by the sign administrator. By applying for and/or maintaining a sign permit, the owner or person in control of the premises upon which the sign is located acknowledges that the sign administrator or his/her representative may enter the premises whenever the sign administrator or his/her representative deems it necessary for inspection or enforcement. The City of Pasadena does not waive any of the permit application and inspection requirements set forth in this chapter. Further, any administrative or clerical errors committed in issuing a permit do not constitute waiver of any such requirements. Any person or company issued a permit under this section shall satisfy all the requirements of section 31-10(h) of this Code regarding cash completion bonds. 
(c)  Permit duration. Any permit to erect, takedown, construct, destroy, reconstruct, relocate, remove, or alter a sign shall become null and void unless erection, takedown, construction, destruction, reconstruction, relocation, removal, or alteration of the sign is completed within ninety (90) days, or the permit is renewed for an additional ninety (90) days, in which case an additional fee shall be payable equal to one-half (½) the original fee paid and the proposed sign shall meet all of the requirements of this chapter on the date of renewal. 
(d)  Reports required. 
(1)  Change in condition. Any person holding a permit shall report any change in condition that makes the sign nonconforming within ten (10) days of when that condition becomes known to the permit holder. 
(2)  Damage to the structure. Any person holding a permit shall report any damage to the structure that makes the sign structure nonconforming within ten (10) days of when that condition becomes known to the permit holder. 
(3)  Consent of landowner for portable off-premises signs. Upon renewing the portable off-premises sign permit each year, the person shall provide a new notarized consent form evidencing the consent of the owner or agent thereof. 
(4)  Off-premises sign location. At the time of the renewal of the operating permit, the person obtaining the permit will list the location of all signs owned or operated by that person in the City of Pasadena and shall submit non-Polaroid photographs of all such signs showing the entire sign and its location. 
(5)  Change of address. Any change of address of the permittee must be provided to the sign administrator within ten (10) days of such change. 
(e)  Relocation permits. Relocation permits are required before any sign may be removed for relocation. 
(f)  Definition of permits, applications, and fees. The following is a list of the various required applications and permits and for which a fee is charged: 
(1)  Application. There shall be an application made for all permits or renewal of permits. 
(2)  Transfer of ownership application. If a sign owner or maintainer wishes to transfer its interest in the sign to another, the purchaser must make an application for transfer within twenty (20) days after the sale. Upon the payment of the transfer application fee and the prorated portion of the operating fee, a new operating permit will be issued. If application is not made within the twenty (20) days, the application will be considered an application for a new sign and subject to all provisions hereof. 
a.  Transfer application. Application for transfer of ownership or maintenance responsibility will be made for each sign transferred. The application will be the same as an application for a new sign, except structural information will not be required. The purchaser will acknowledge that the signs have been inspected and meet all code provisions, are structurally sound, and are not now a hazard to the public. 
b.  Construction/destruction/reconstruction permit. The permit required to construct, destroy, or reconstruct a sign or sign structure. 
(3)  Operating permit. Permit required to display and operate any sign other than a portable sign and exempt signs. These permits shall be valid for two (2) years and shall expire on December 31. Each face requires a separate operating permit. 
(4)  Inspection. No sign shall be legal and no advertising displayed thereon until all three (3) of the below inspections have been made and approval of the sign administrator obtained. Inspection, except for portable and exempt signs, will consist of these three (3) phases: 
a.  Site inspection required before a sign may be located; 
b.  Construction inspection to determine if the design requirements are met; and 
c.  Hole inspection required for all ground signs. 
(5)  Inspection of portable signs. Inspection of portable signs will consist of one (1) inspection after installation to determine if all requirements of this chapter are met. 
(6)  Portable sign operating permit. 
a.  Permit required for right to operate portable sign during permit term. All portable sign permits shall expire on December 31 of each year. 
b.  Before a portable on- or off-premises contractor sign operating permit may be issued by the sign administrator, an application containing the following information will be submitted to and approved in writing by the sign administrator: 
1.  The total number of portable sign permits requested; 
2.  Separate listing and identification of which signs are "on-premises" and which are "off-premises"; 
3.  Exact location of each portable sign with street designation and measured distance (in feet) to nearest intersecting street, as well as all compass directions necessary to locating such sign (Due to the exact measurement required by this subsection, no two (2) signs can occupy the same location.); 
4.  A separate affidavit for each sign from the owner or lessee of the real property on which the sign is located consenting to the placement of the sign on that owner's or lessee's property regardless of the number of signs on the real property of any one (1) owner or lessee. (For example, if one (1) owner consents to the placement of five (5) signs on property he/she owns, there must be five (5) separate affidavits from that owner.) Such affidavit must be acknowledged by a notary public in the presence of the owner or lessee and with all the attendant requirements of notary public law; 
5.  A notarized affidavit for each sign signed by the applicant that all signs are properly anchored with at least one (1) three-foot-long, screw-type anchor with steel cable attached; 
6.  Proof of liability insurance by a certificate of insurance and letter from the insurance company for each sign stating that the requisite insurance covers the exact on-premises portable sign for which an operating permit is sought; 
7.  All of the documents in original form (copies are not acceptable) shall be presented at the same time. Submission of less than all of the documents at one (1) time shall be grounds for rejection of the application; and 
8.  All documents submitted to the sign administrator in the application for an operating permit shall be original documents bearing original signatures. Copies of documents or signatures are not acceptable and shall be grounds for rejection of an application under this section. 
(7)  Reinspection. When the initial inspection reveals nonconforming items, inspection must continue until there are no nonconforming items. A fee for each reinspection will be charged. 
(8)  Renewal of operating permits. Before the expiration of each operating permit, the owner shall apply for a new operating permit. 
(9)  All documents submitted to the sign administrator in the application for an operating permit shall be original documents bearing original signatures. Copies of documents or signatures are not acceptable and shall be grounds for rejection of an application under this section. 
(g)  Fees. The applicant for a permit or holder of a permit shall not be entitled to a refund of any fee paid in the event the permit is revoked. 
(1)  Removal fund except licensed sign companies. Each applicant shall pay an additional ten dollars ($10.00) per application of an operating permit to the sign removal fund. 
(2)  Removal fund licensed sign companies. Each company shall pay fifty dollars ($50.00) annually into the removal fund, in addition to other fees. 
(3)  Fees for permits and other administrative procedures, unless specified differently elsewhere in this sign code, shall be as follows:
