c Proration of operating fees will be 1/11 th per month of the annual fee for all months or fractional parts thereof remaining in the year. 
 
(h)  Electrical signs. Any electrical sign shall conform fully to the requirements of the prevailing City of Pasadena electrical code and shall additionally receive a permit under the provisions of that code. 
(i)  Political campaign signs. Must be placed in conformance and accordance with State of Texas law and cannot cause a hazard, found to be a hazard for traffic/pedestrians or found to be a traffic sight triangle problem that poses a hazard. This type signage is not subject to fees. State law does not apply to signs that do not conform with any of the following: 
(1)  An effective area of more than thirty-six (36) square feet. 
(2)  Is more than eight (8) feet in height. 
(3)  Is illuminated. 
(4)  Has any moving elements. 
Allowed installations must be on private real property with permission of the legal owner or tenant with specific conveyed rights. Political sign installations shall not be placed on public property, rights-of-way, easements or private real property without the expressed permission of the owner. Signs placed in violation of this chapter must be relocated to a lawful location or are subject to removal. 
(j)  Obligations upon sale of a sign. The seller must remove his name from the sign within ten (10) days after the sale and notify the city that the sign has been sold. It is the obligation of the buyer to comply with the provisions hereof. 
(k)  Permits not transferable. Permits are issued to the applicant only and no permits are transferable. 
(l)  Exemptions. No permit shall be required under this chapter for the following on-premises signs unless any such sign is a spectacular sign or a portable sign. Any sign listed hereunder shall be erected and maintained in conformity with the provisions otherwise of this chapter: 
(1)  Signs painted on glass surface of windows or doors not to exceed twenty-five (25) per cent of the window or door area; 
(2)  Directional and regulatory signs erected by the city, State of Texas (inducing its political subdivisions such as counties and school districts), or the federal government and the lessees of such governmental entities; 
(3)  Railroad signs; 
(4)  Legal notices and house numbers: "no trespassing," "no parking," and other similar warning signs not exceeding two (2) in number; 
(5)  Temporary signs smaller than six (6) square feet, provided that the number of such signs on any one (1) address does not exceed one (1) in number; 
(6)  Signs required by federal, state, or local law; 
(7)  Signs displayed, designed, or used for or upon motor vehicles as long as such vehicles are used by the business for delivery or identification. (This is not to be construed to exempt signs built or placed upon a motor vehicle solely for the purpose of advertisement.); 
(8)  Signs which are painted on the face of a building not exceeding five (5) per cent of the wall surface area and no higher than the roof line and state only the street number and name of the proprietor, provided that the number of such signs shall be one (1) per address for such premises; 
(9)  Signs within a stadium, open-air theater, arena, or public or recreational area which are designed primarily to be viewed by patrons within such stadium, open-air theater, or arena; 
(10)  On-premises real estate signs five (5) square feet or less; 
(11)  Christmas displays and similar temporary displays erected without advertising; however, such displays shall be subject to the fire and electrical code and fire safety rules promulgated by the fire marshal; 
(12)  A sign not over forty (40) square feet in area setting forth information concerning a building or other structure under repair or construction or advertising the sale or rental of the premises; 
(13)  Subdivision identification signs: one (1) per subdivision, forty (40) square feet or under; 
(14)  For each business premises: one (1) flag of the United States, one (1) flag of the State of Texas, one (1) flag of the City of Pasadena, and/or one (1) corporate flag of the business occupying the business premises. The United States Flag Code, Title 36, United States Code, Chapter 10, as amended by P.L. 344, 94 th Congress, shall be used as a guideline for the display of the United States flag; 
(15)  Businesses and other establishments may have on-premises signs displaying no advertising copy setting forth only the location of or directions to parking entrances and exits, buildings located on the premises, or regulating the flow of on-premises traffic; provided, such signs contain no electrical wiring, in and out directional signs with the company name and/or logo if such signs do not exceed one and one-half (1½) square feet of sign face per side, two (2) sides maximum, and are not over forty (40) inches in height, in addition to the five (5) on-premises signs allowed by this subsection; 
(16)  Any on-premises sign viewed only from within the premises and not visible from any public road; 
(17)  Any nameplate sign placed on the entrance door or within six (6) inches of the entrance opening; 
(18)  Any on-premises sign located atop service station or convenience store gasoline pumps which has less than six (6) square feet of sign face area on any one (1) side of such sign. 
(19)  Signs exempt from operating permit only: 
a.  Any on-premises sign used for the purpose of perpetuating the doctrines and teachings of any generally recognized church or religious organization holding a valid "nonprofit" charter which has been filed in the office of Secretary of the State of Texas and for which a current tax exemption certificate has been issued by the Internal Revenue Service; 
b.  Signs which are mounted on the face of a building no higher than the roof line and state only the street number and name of the proprietor, provided that the number of such signs shall be one (1) per address for such premises; or 
c.  Any on-premises sign operated by and used to further the interests of other recognized charitable organizations holding valid "nonprofit" charters which have been filed in the office of Secretary of the State of Texas and for which current certificates have been issued by the Internal Revenue Service. 
It shall be the duty of any person, company, organization, or entity claiming exemption status under this section to provide any documentation or other items of proof to the sign administrator. An organization claiming exemption status as a tax-exempt organization shall submit a photocopy of its charter and state and federal tax exemption certificate to the sign administrator. 
(m)  Normal maintenance, changing of message or electric light bulbs. A sign permit is not required for normal maintenance of a sign previously permitted. Any change in advertising display shall require a permit unless the sign is a marquee, reader board, or portable sign. This provision shall not release a person from complying with all other applicable permitting requirements of the City of Pasadena, including those of the BOCA Basic Building Code. 
(n)  Misrepresentations. Any misstatement, misrepresentation, or incorrect information supplied in order to obtain any type of sign permit, whether or not intentionally done, shall be grounds for the revocation of such sign permit. Such sign shall be removed within twenty-four (24) hours after permit revocation. If the sign is not removed within twenty-four (24) hours after permit revocation, the city may remove the sign at the owner's expense and place a lien against the property of the owner for the cost of removal. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 02-38, § 3, 1-29-02; Ord. No. 02-100, § 1, 3-26-02; Ord. No. 06-291, § 1, 11-21-06)

Editor's note— Any previously adopted specific reference within this section to the BOCA Building Code, the BOCA National Building Code or the BOCA Basic Building Code is changed to read as per the relative section of the NFPA 5000 Building Construction and Safety Code. See § 9-60. 
 
Sec. 31-10. - Sign companies. 
(a)  License required. Any person or company wishing to engage in the business of selling, leasing, repairing, constructing, or erecting signs shall first obtain a license from the City of Pasadena. A notarized form, approved by the sign administrator, shall be completed by the person or company, submitted to the sign administrator and placed on file with the City of Pasadena. This license requirement shall apply to any business, firm, or individual selling, erecting, repairing, constructing, or leasing on or off-premises signs. 
(b)  License fee. Any person required to obtain a license under the terms of this section shall pay an annual license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00). Further, the sign company shall upon application, and thereafter annually by December 31, pay the fee to the removal fund as set out herein. 
(c)  Address and agent for service of process. Any person who is required to obtain a license under the terms of this section shall provide a current address and keep such address current at all times, at which services of process may be had, or provide the current name and address of its registered agent, such agent's name and address to be kept current. Any person failing to comply with this provision is subject to having his/her license revoked. 
(d)  Insurance. Each person licensed under the terms of this section shall submit copies of policies of insurance certified by the agent issuing them, together with written proof that the premiums have been paid, showing that the performance of work in connection with each sign will be covered by approved public liability and property damage insurance in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any person injured, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage. Such policies of insurance shall be in a form selected or approved by the city and shall name the city as an additional insured. In addition, such policies of insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue such policies of insurance in the State of Texas and maintaining an office or represented by an authorized agent in the State of Texas, shall expressly state that it may not be canceled unless ten (10) days' written notice is given to the sign administrator before cancellation of the policy, and must contain an endorsement to the effect that the issuer waives any claim or right in the nature of subrogation to recover against the city, its officers, agents, or employees. Whenever any policy of insurance is canceled the sign administrator shall require that all work, to which such policy applies, be stopped immediately. No permits shall be issued until such time that the person or company complies with these insurance requirements. 
(e)  Number to be displayed on vehicles. Vehicles owned or operated by a duly licensed sign installer shall have displayed thereon at all times the license number shown on such installer's license prefixed by the initials "P.S.I." 
(f)  Electrical sign contractors. Each person licensed under the terms of this section whose operations include signs that in any manner include the use of electrical power shall adhere to the requirement provisions of the electrical code of the City of Pasadena as that code now exists or may hereinafter be amended. 
(g)  Violations of chapter. Violations of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be grounds for the revocation of the license or denial of the license application of any person who has committed such violation. 
(h)  Contractor's bond. No person or company shall be issued a license under this section to engage in the business of selling, leasing, repairing, constructing, or erecting signs unless such person or company has deposited a contractor's completion cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to be used to complete signs, including landscaping, which the licensee fails to do. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 02-38, § 4, 1-29-02)  
Sec. 31-11. - Sign maintenance and removal. 
(a)  Maintenance. 
(1)  The area around any sign location must be maintained and kept clean by the owner. Grass will be cut a minimum of six (6) feet from said billboard on all sides and entirely to the street curb on the side nearest the street and debris, etc., will be removed at least weekly. 
(2)  All signs shall be thoroughly painted as often as necessary, unless of galvanized or noncorroding metal or treated with appropriate wood preservative, and shall be kept in good repair consistent with good maintenance. All braces, bolts, clips, supporting frame, and fastenings shall be free from deterioration, termite infestation, rot, or loosening. All signs shall be able to withstand safely, at all times, the wind pressures specified elsewhere in this chapter. In case any sign is not so maintained the sign administrator shall give written notice to the owner or lessee thereof to so maintain the signs or to remove the sign. Nonmaintenance shall be considered a misdemeanor and penalty shall be assessed accordingly. 
(b)  Unsafe signs. Should any sign in the opinion of the sign administrator become insecure or in danger of falling or otherwise unsafe, the sign administrator shall give written notice of the condition of the sign to the person owning, leasing, or responsible for the sign. Said person so notified shall correct the unsafe condition of the sign in a manner to be approved by the sign administrator in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Unlawful signs. In case any sign shall be installed, erected, constructed, or maintained in violation of any of the terms of this chapter, in addition to any other rights and remedies provided herein, the sign administrator shall give written notice to the owner, lessee, or person responsible for said sign ordering said owner, lessee, or person to alter the sign such that it complies with this chapter or to remove the sign. 
(d)  Removal fund. There is hereby established a removal fund which shall only be used to remove illegal signs. Each person or company that is issued a new on-premises sign permit for a sign not previously permitted shall be required to pay a ten-dollar ($10.00) sign removal fee as part of the application fee. However, licensed sign companies shall contribute only fifty dollars ($50.00) annually in lieu of a removal bond and, further, each request for a variance shall be accompanied by a twenty-five dollars ($25.00) payment to the removal fund. The fund shall be maintained by the city as a separate trust account invested at interest. 
(e)  Removal of signs. 
(1)  Signs with current permits. Any sign with a current operating permit that is in violation of the provisions herein shall be subject to removal. The sign administrator shall notify the person responsible for the sign by certified mail return receipt requested, or by personal notice, to repair or remove within seven (7) days. Upon written request to the sign administrator for good cause, this period may be extended up to no more than thirty (30) days. If the sign is not repaired or removed, the city may remove the sign at the owner's expense and a lien may be placed against the property of the owner for such expense. 
(2)  Signs without current permits. Any sign without a current operating permit that is in violation of the provisions herein shall be subject to removal. The sign administrator shall notify the person responsible for the sign by certified mail return receipt requested, or by personal notice, to remove the sign within seven (7) days. Upon written request to the sign administrator for good cause, this period may be extended up to no more than thirty (30) days. If the sign is not repaired or removed, the city may remove the sign at the owner's expense and a lien may be placed against the property of the owner for such expense. 
(3)  Discontinued signs. Any abandoned sign or sign structure shall be treated as a sign without a current permit. An on-premises sign for a business location that is vacant or unused for more than sixty (60) days, or an on-premises sign itself that is unused as advertising for the business location on which it is located for more than sixty (60) days, shall be considered a discontinued sign and, as such, shall be considered a sign without a current permit, said permit having been made void by the vacancy or nonuse. Such discontinued sign shall be removed or made to conform to the size restrictions presently found in this chapter. If such discontinued sign is not removed or made to conform within ten (10) days after it is considered a discontinued sign under this section, the city may remove the sign at the owner's expense and place a lien against the property of the owner for the cost of removal. 
(4)  Removal of unlawful signs by the city. The following procedures will be followed by the city in removal of unlawful signs by the city: 
a.  Signs found on public property. All signs found on public property or public utility property or easement may be removed and discarded by the city without notice to the owner. This removal does not relieve the owner of any penalties. 
b.  Portable signs found on public property. The owners of portable signs that have the proper identification on them found on public property or public utility property or easement may be removed by the city and stored for ten (10) days after the notice or removal is received by the owner for the owner to reclaim. If not reclaimed within ten (10) days, the sign may be sold at auction or disposed of by the city. The cost to reclaim shall be the sum of the following: 
• Two hundred dollars ($200.00) civil penalty; 
• Actual cost of removal and hauling, minimum fifty dollars ($50.00); 
• Storage fee of five dollars ($5.00) per day per one hundred sixty (160) square feet of storage surface; and 
• One hundred dollars ($100.00) for employee's time to administer such confiscation. 
c.  All other signs removed by the city under any provision of this chapter shall be stored for ten (10) days after the notice of removal is issued to the last known address of the owner of the sign or the owner is personally notified. If such sign is not reclaimed by the owner within ten (10) days of such notice, the sign may be sold at auction or disposed of by the city. The cost to reclaim shall be the sum of the following: 
• Two hundred dollars ($200.00) civil penalty; 
• Actual cost of removal and hauling, minimum fifty dollars ($50.00); 
• Storage fee of five dollars ($5.00) per day per one hundred sixty (160) square feet of storage surface; and 
• One hundred dollars ($100.00) for employee's time to administer such confiscation. 
(f)  Replacement or repair of sign. 
(1)  When any sign, or a substantial part of it, is blown down or otherwise destroyed or taken down or removed for any purpose other than for routine maintenance operations, it may not be replaced, re-erected, reconstructed, or rebuilt except in full conformance with the provisions and requirements of this chapter including, but not limited to, the requirement of obtaining a permit. Changing any design, color, or symbol of any sign shall require a permit and full conformance with all of the other provisions of this chapter and shall not constitute routine maintenance. 
(2)  For the purpose of subsection (1) of this section, a sign or substantial part of it is considered to have been destroyed if the cost of repairing the sign is more than fifty (50) per cent of the cost of replacing the sign, exclusive of the pole or poles supporting the sign. 
(3)  The engineering specifications must receive final inspection and approval by the City of Pasadena sign administrator or his/her designee prior to setting. 
(4)  It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter to continue any work after having been verbally advised to stop work or given a stop work order by the City of Pasadena sign administrator or his/her designee. 
(5)  It is unlawful and a violation of this chapter to remove a stop work order issued by the sign administrator or his/her designee. 
(6)  In addition to all other requirements of this chapter, a new sign permit is required whenever the cost of repairing the sign, exclusive of the pole, is more than fifty (50) per cent of the cost of erecting a replacement sign of the same type at the same location. 
(7)  Whenever there is a change in ownership or use of the business premises upon which an on-premises sign is located, any and all on-premises signs on such premises shall be made to conform to all applicable requirements of this chapter. 
(8)  Provided, however, that the wooden support structure of an off-premise sign, otherwise lawfully in place on January 1, 2003, may be replaced with metal or steel superstructure and monopole. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 03-27, § 1, 2-11-03)  
Sec. 31-12. - Prohibited use of signs. 
(a)  Signs not to be posted on or to public property. It shall be unlawful for any sign other than official signs erected by the city, county, independent school district, State of Texas, or railway company to be placed or caused to be placed, painted, printed, posted, or affixed in any manner, any picture, bill, sign, or other advertising matter whatsoever on any curb, sidewalk, pavement, telephone pole, electric pole, traffic signal standard or pole, or other public improvement in any public street or grounds; or upon any bridge, overpass, underpass or parts of the same, median, esplanade, road right-of-way, public utility easement, traffic island, or public building, structure, or erection of any type belonging to the city. 
(b)  No sign shall resemble an official sign. No sign shall be constructed which resembles any official marker erected by the city, state, or any governmental agency which by reason of position, shape, or color would conflict with the proper functioning of any traffic sign or signal or which by its shape or color would conflict with or be confused with emergency vehicle lights, especially blinking lights. Use of words such as stop, look, danger, or any other word, phrase, symbol, or character in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead, or confuse traffic is prohibited. (See section 36-99 of this Code.) 
(c)  Signs not to interfere with official signs. Signs may not be located or illuminated in such a manner as to obscure or otherwise interfere with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign, signal, or device or so as to obstruct or interfere with the view of a driver or approaching, emerging, or intersection traffic. All such signs shall comply with the provisions of section 36-22.1 and section 36-99 of this Code. 
(d)  Proper shielding of lighted signals; interference with drivers of motor vehicles. Signs containing lights which are not effectively shielded as to prevent beams or rays of light from being directed at any portion of the traveled way from which the sign is primarily viewed and which are of such intensity or brilliance as to cause glare or to impair the vision of the driver of any motor vehicle, or which otherwise interfere with any driver's operation of a motor vehicle, are prohibited. 
(e)  Spectacular signs. The following types of spectacular signs shall be deemed prohibited: 
(1)  Signs with strobe, rotating strobe, or blinking strobe lights. 
(2)  Signs with flashing spotlights, rotating spotlights, or blinking spotlights shall not operate in a capacity which will interfere with traffic. 
(3)  Automatically changeable advertising signs with more than one (1) message which changes every four (4) seconds. 
(4)  Flashing lights with bulbs of greater than fifteen (15) watts. 
(f)  Signs not to obstruct egress. 
(1)  No sign shall be erected, constructed, or maintained so as to obstruct any means of egress or any opening necessary for required light, ventilation, or firefighting or for escape from the premises or so as to prevent free passage from one (1) part of a roof to any other part thereof. 
(2)  No sign shall be attached to any exterior stairway, fire escape, fire tower balcony, or balcony serving as a horizontal exit. 
(3)  No sign shall be erected, constructed, or maintained so as to interfere with the operation of a counterbalanced section of a fire escape, and no projecting sign shall be erected, constructed, or maintained without a minimum of seven (7) feet of clearance over any such counterbalanced section. 
(4)  No sign shall obstruct the free use of any window above the first story. 
(g)  Emitting signs prohibited. No emitting sign shall be permitted and are strictly prohibited at any location within the city. 
(h)  Signs employing motion picture machines. No sign shall employ a stereopticon or motion picture machine. 
(i)  Signs not to create easements. No permit for a sign extending beyond private property onto a public street, public sidewalks, or public alley shall constitute a permanent easement, and every such permit shall be revocable at any time by action of the city council. The city shall not be liable for any damages to the owner by reason of such revocation. The only time such a permit shall be issued shall be in the case of a projecting sign extending over a public sidewalk, when such sidewalk abuts the front of the building to which the projecting sign is attached. 
(j)  Location on vacant buildings. No sign or sign structure shall be permitted to remain for more than thirty (30) days on any vacant building or premises, except a conforming sign pertaining to the lease or sale of the building or premises, or a sign which is maintained in a manner conforming to the requirements of this chapter. After thirty (30) days of vacancy, the message must be blanked out. 
(k)  Vision restrictions prohibited. Any sign that restricts vision necessary for safety is prohibited. If such a sign is erected and it does restrict vision so as to be a safety hazard, it will be removed or modified to correct such restriction and eliminate the hazard. It is the responsibility of the person owning and erecting the sign to ensure that the sign does not create such a hazard. The following are guidelines for construction to prevent such restrictions of vision: 
(1)  Any sign over pedestrian traffic shall be no lower than eight (8) feet above the pedestrian surface. 
(2)  Any sign over passenger vehicle traffic shall be no lower than ten (10) feet above the vehicular traffic surface. 
(3)  Any sign over general vehicular traffic shall be no lower than fourteen (14) feet six (6) inches above the traffic surface. 
(4)  Any sign which obstructs vision within the sight triangle as defined in section 31-3(u) of this chapter. 
(l)  Obscene signs prohibited. No obscene sign shall be permitted. 
(m)  Fence signs. Fence signs shall not be permitted except when structurally and permanently incorporated into a masonry or architecturally and aesthetically coordinated fence. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 02-38, § 5, 1-29-02)  
Sec. 31-13. - On-premises and off-premises sign regulations. 
(a)  General requirements. 
(1)  No new off-premises permits. In accordance with the fact, issuance of new off-premises sign permits has not been allowed since October 18, 1983, and as such, no new permits shall be issued for off-premises signs including temporary signs affixed to any post, stake, or other device off the property of the business being advertised within the city limits of the City of Pasadena. Only off-premises signs continuously and lawfully permitted prior to October 18, 1983, may receive permits. 
(2)  No sign in right-of-way. No sign shall be placed in or extend into a public street, sidewalk, easement or street right-of-way. 
(3)  Shall not obstruct view. No sign shall be installed in such a way to obstruct a motorist's view of oncoming traffic when exiting a private drive or at the intersection of two (2) (or more) public streets. The motorist's eye is assumed to be at a point fifteen (15) feet from the edge of the roadway. Traffic must be visible for a distance of ten (10) times the speed limit on either side of the vehicle parallel to the intersecting roadway. This shall be applied to all public and private approaches affected. 
(4)  Poles shall be covered. On-premises sign pole and poles shall be covered with pole cover(s) made of 6061T6 etched aluminum for painting or twenty-two-gauge paint grip sheet metal to make the sign resemble a monument sign. Such pole cover shall be a width of at least one-half (½) the width of the sign to which it is attached. Pole covers shall be painted. Unpainted metal pole covers shall not be permitted. 
(5)  Landscaping. All signs which are required to be permitted under section 31-9(b) shall be landscaped. The landscape area shall be comprised of a continuous space at least equal to the square footage of the sign face (one (1) side) from the base and at an equal distance from each side of the sign and extending along the entire length and width of the sign base and shall consist predominantly of living plant material. Provided, however, decorative stone or rock may be used when the area to be landscaped as described above is paved by existing asphalt, brick, or concrete. Use of living plant material is preferred. Installation of pavement to avoid the preference of landscaping with living plant material is prohibited. All living plant material landscaping shall be maintained in a healthy, growing condition at all times. All decorative stone or rock landscaping shall be kept free of weeds and maintained in a neat and orderly appearance at all times. 
(b)  Street addresses. On-premises signs shall display the street addresses of the business location it advertises in numbers at least five (5) inches high on each pole cover in legible form within forty (40) feet of the nearest public roadway. Such numbers shall increase one (1) inch in height for each additional forty (40) feet, or fractional part thereof, the sign is located from such roadway. 
(c)  Face restrictions. 
(1)  No business may have more than five (5) faces per on-premises location except for wall signs. For signs on a double-faced, back-to-back, four-sided or V-type nature, each face is considered a separate sign in computing the face area. A curved surface sign shall be considered as three (3) faces and a circular sign shall be considered as four (4) faces. Those five (5) sign faces may not exceed in total face area the total of three hundred (300) square feet. 
(2)  In addition to five (5) sign faces per business location or premises, each business shall be allowed wall signs not to exceed one (1) per cent of the total usable square feet of the business building, plus one (1) square foot for each linear foot of street frontage of such location or premises, not to exceed twenty (20) per cent of the area of the wall or building below the roof line. 
(3)  No off-premises billboard shall exceed six hundred seventy-two (672) square feet plus cutouts as herein provided. 
(d)  Size and quantity of types restrictions. Total number of on-premises signs allowed at any one (1) business shall not exceed five (5). The maximum of the individual types of categories of signs are as follows: 
• One (1) portable sign for not more than sixty (60) days a year. 
• One (1) monument sign. 
• Two (2) monument signs if business has frontage on two (2) roads with a total street frontage of three hundred (300) feet or more. Such monument signs shall be at least two hundred (200) feet from each other. 
• One (1) marquee sign. 
• Two (2) canopy signs. 
• One (1) ground sign per separate street frontage. 
(e)  Monument signs. 
(1)  All on-premises ground signs shall be of the monument style. An on-premises monument sign shall not be erected that exceeds the dimensions allowed by the point system stated in the schedule provided by this subsection. Except, an on-premises sign that abuts State Highway 225 and Beltway 8, as measured by a straight line drawn perpendicular from the roadway to the on-premises sign, may have a maximum height of twelve (12) feet above the elevated portion of such roadway. Such sign may also have a maximum sign face of one hundred twenty (120) square feet plus thirty (30) square feet of architectural embellishment for each sign face. As with signs not abutting State Highway 225 and Beltway 8 (see Illustration 1-1), any architectural embellishment shall be included in the maximum allowable sign square footage. 
(2)  The points for each sign permitted under this subsection shall be equal to the number arrived at by adding together the following: (a) one (1) per cent of the total usable square feet of building floor space of the business building advertised by the sign and (b) the number of linear feet of street frontage of such business building. Provided, however, any on-premises sign located at a point more than fifty (50) feet from the roadway right-of-way nearest to it may be increased in size one (1) square foot for every linear foot such sign is from such point on a perpendicular line drawn from the roadway. Such sign shall not, however, exceed one hundred and twenty (120) square feet in size or one hundred and sixty (160) square feet with a reader board, regardless of its distance from the roadway. 
Maximum allowable height 	Maximum total sq. ft. allowed each sign face 	Points 
12 feet 	60 sq. ft. or 50 sq. ft. with 30 sq. ft. of reader board 	less than 1,100 
14 feet 	100 sq. ft. 	1,100 or more 
 
(f)  Cutout areas permitted. Exclusions or appendages (cutouts) shall not exceed twenty (20) per cent of the total sign face area and shall not exceed an additional five (5) feet in height or an additional three (3) feet in width. 
(g)  Roof signs. Roof signs must have one (1) foot of open space between the roof line and the bottom of the sign, three (3) feet of open space shall be required between the sign structure and the edge of the roof and between the sign structures. A roof sign may not at any point exceed six (6) feet above the roof line facia of the building upon which it is constructed and shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet of sign face. 
(h)  Spacing. No off-premises sign will be placed within fifteen hundred (1500) feet of another sign subject to the provisions hereof. No on-premises pole sign shall be erected within five hundred (500) feet of a pole sign for the same business on the same street, except each business within the limit of five (5) signs shall be permitted one (1) sign for each street frontage. 
(i)  Multiple business signs. Multiple business signs (MBS) advertising multiple business centers, in addition to all other regulations herein contained, shall observe the following rules that apply to the installation and operation of multiple business signs: 
(1)  A multiple business sign shall not be erected, constructed, or maintained within two hundred (200) feet of any other sign except for signs on the buildings of the businesses advertised on the multiple business sign and directional signs. 
(2)  There may be more than one (1) multiple business sign on each street frontage. The minimum distance between each such multiple business sign shall depend upon the maximum size of the multiple business sign allowed by section 31-13(i)(4) and shall be controlled by the following formula: 
Maximum Allowable 
Height 	Minimum Distance 
Between MBS 
16 feet 	300 feet 
19 feet 	400 feet 
25 feet 	500 feet 
 
A multiple business center (MBC) with less than three hundred (300) feet of street frontage shall be permitted no more than one (1) multiple business sign. 
(3)  A multiple business center with street frontage on more than one (1) street shall be allowed signage for each such additional street frontage in accordance with the rules set forth in section 31-13(i)(2) and section 31-13(i)(4). 
(4)  A multiple business sign shall not be erected that exceeds the dimensions allowed by the point system stated in the schedule that follows. The points for each sign permitted under this section shall be equal to the number arrived at by adding together the following two (2) items: (a) one (1) per cent of the total usable square feet of building floor space of the multibusiness center advertised by the multibusiness sign and (b) the number of linear feet of street frontage of such multibusiness center. If the multibusiness center is on two (2) or more separate streets, the calculations called for by the formula stated above shall be based upon each street separately. Linear feet of street frontage of separate streets shall not be combined. 
Maximum Allowable Height 	Maximum Total Sq. Ft. Allowed Each Side 	Points 
16 feet 	120 	less than 500 
19 feet 	200 	500 to 1099 
25 feet 	300 	over 1100 
 
Notwithstanding the foregoing or any other provision of this chapter, the maximum allowable size of a sign for any single business in a multibusiness center sign shall be fifty (50) square feet, regardless of the number of businesses. 
(5)  A multibusiness sign only shall be utilized in situations in which two (2) or more business entities or operations occupy the same location or building. Each business, however, must have a separate different address in order for such businesses to be entitled to use a multibusiness sign. Multiple single business signs shall not be allowed at locations where more than one (1) business is located or housed. 
(j)  Movable signs. Movable signs, in addition to all other regulations herein contained, shall observe the following rules applicable to the installation and operation of movable signs: 
(1)  The number of movable signs allowed for the first street of frontage is one (1) movable sign. 
(2)  One (1) additional movable sign will be allowed for each additional street that adjoins the business. 
(3)  Movable signs must be removed during the hours the business is closed. 
(k)  Subdivision signs. Only one (1) off-premises sign with the name of the subdivision and directions thereto will be permitted, in addition to the one (1) exempt sign for a residential subdivision situated within the city limits of the City of Pasadena that has been approved by the city and duly platted and recorded in the records of Harris County, Texas. The size of such sign inclusive of all sides shall not exceed a total of seventy (70) square feet. Such sign is allowed for a maximum period of two (2) years and shall be promptly removed at the end of the two-year period. If the subdivision is less than ninety-five (95) per cent sold, the sign may be repermitted for two (2) years. 
(l)  Location. No off-premises sign shall be located in a primarily residential area. 
(m)  Relocation, removal, and reconstruction. 
(1)  Relocation of off-premises signs will be permitted only in the case of a governmental taking of the land used for the sign location and no compensation paid to the sign owner. 
(2)  The owner of the billboard or portable sign must obtain a site for relocation of the billboard or portable sign within one (1) month of removal, and construction or placement must be completed within ninety (90) days thereafter. 
(3)  The city will only permit reconstruction if the sign proposed to be constructed will be in compliance with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  Removal of any sign may be required if in the opinion of the sign administrator the sign unnecessarily distracts motorists, hinders the view of the natural landscape, or although grand fathered is still in too close proximity to other signs. 
(5)  Any off-premises sign relocated as required by this chapter shall not change its dimensions, shall be aesthetically pleasing, and shall have no exposed wood. Any sign taller than forty-two-and-a-half (42½) feet prior to relocation shall be constructed to a height not taller than forty-two-and-a-half (42½) feet upon relocation. 
(n)  Off-premises signs on private property. No person shall place an off-premises sign on private property without the consent of the owner or agent for the owner of said private property. Further, no person shall place an off-premises portable sign on private property without the authorized written, notarized consent of the owner or agent for the owner of said private property. 
(o)  Accumulation of rainwater prohibited. All signs shall be designed, constructed and maintained to prevent the accumulation of rainwater in or on the sign. 
(p)  Garage sale signs. The person obtaining the permit for the sale is entitled to post two (2) on-premises and three (3) off-premises temporary signs on private property only not to exceed one and one-half (1½) square feet in size. All signs must be removed after the sale or the holder of the sale is subject to penalties. 
(q)  Political campaign banners. Installations shall not exceed thirty-six (36) square feet in area and must be securely attached to a structure by acceptable means that will not allow the banner to become windborne. Political campaign banners are not subject to fees. Allowed installations must be on private real property with permission of the legal owner or tenant with specific conveyed rights. Political banner installations shall not be placed on public property, rights-of-way, or easements. Banners placed in violation of this chapter must be relocated to a lawful location or are subject to removal. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 02-38, §§ 6—8, 1-29-02; Ord. No. 06-156, § 1, 5-7-06; Ord. No. 06-291, § 1, 11-21-06)  
Sec. 31-14. - Structural requirements; generally and for specific signs.[3] 
(a)  Design. 
(1)  General. All sites and sign structures shall be designed and constructed to resist wind forces as specified in this section. All bracing systems shall be designed and constructed to transfer lateral forces to the foundations. For signs on buildings, the dead and lateral loads shall be transmitted through the structural frame of the building to the ground in such a manner as not to overstress any of the elements thereof. 
(2)  Wind loads. All signs and sign structures shall be designed to resist wind loads as follows: 
Wind Load Pressures in Pounds Per Square Foot For All Signs 
Height Above Ground*, Feet 	Pressure, Pounds/Ft. 2 
0—50 	30 
51—99 	35 
*Measured above the average level of the ground adjacent to the structure. 
 
(3)  Vertical design loads. Vertical design loads, except roof live loads, shall be assumed to be acting simultaneously with the wind loads. 
(4)  Working stresses. All signs shall be designed to conform with the requirements of the BOCA Basic Building Code regarding allowable working stresses. The working strength of chains, cables, guys, or steel rods shall not exceed one-fifth ( 1/5 ) of the ultimate strength of such chains, cables, guys, or steel rods. 
(5)  Registered engineer's seal. All commercially erected signs over twelve (12) feet and all roof signs shall be approved by a professional engineer registered in the State of Texas, and all plans shall contain the registered engineer's seal. 
(b)  Construction. 
(1)  General. The supports for all signs or sign structures shall be placed in or upon private property and shall be securely built, constructed, and erected in conformance with the requirements of the BOCA Basic Building Code. All sign footings and foundations shall be buried beneath ground level. 
(2)  Materials. 
a.  Materials for construction of all signs and sign structures shall be of the quality and grade as specified for buildings in the BOCA Basic Building Code. Notwithstanding any of those provisions to the contrary, signs shall not be constructed of plywood. Examples of approved sign face materials are lexan, acrylic, MDO, duraply, and lustre. 
b.  Any sign which utilizes neon lighting shall be constructed so that any neon lighting below eight (8) feet above ground level shall be completely encased in clear plexiglass. 
(3)  Nonstructural trim. Nonstructural trim and portable display surface may be of wood, metal, approved plastics, or any combination thereof consistent with the BOCA Basic Building Code. 
(4)  Anchorage. All ground signs shall be anchored to resist the wind load specified in section 31-14(a)(2) herein acting in any direction. Anchors and supports shall be designed for safe-bearing loads on the soil and for an effective resistance to pull out. 
(c)  Electrical requirements. All electrical fixtures, equipment, and appurtenances installed in conjunction with a sign shall be designed and installed in accordance with the City of Pasadena electrical code as it now exists or may hereinafter be amended. 
(d)  Clearances. 
(1)  Clearance from high voltage power lines. Signs shall be located a minimum distance of twelve (12) feet measured horizontally and twelve (12) feet measured vertically from overhead electrical conductors commonly called distribution lines and a minimum distance of five (5) feet measured horizontally and five (5) feet measured vertically from what are commonly called service drop lines. The term electrical conductors as used in this subsection means any electrical conductor, either bare or insulated, installed above the ground. 
(2)  Clearance from poles. No sign shall be erected nearer than five (5) feet horizontally or eight (8) feet vertically from any telephone pole or cable pole or cross member of that pole. 
(e)  Exempt signs not exempt from this section. No sign which is otherwise exempt is exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00) 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Any previously adopted specific reference within this section to the BOCA Building Code, the BOCA National Building Code or the BOCA Basic Building Code is changed to read as per the relative section of the NFPA 5000 Building Construction and Safety Code. See § 9-60. 
 
Sec. 31-15. - Portable signs. 
(a)  Hitch. Every portable sign shall be equipped with a trailer hitch and locking device approved by the sign administrator to hold the trailer in a securely locked position during transport. All such hitching equipment shall also comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws regulating same. 
(b)  Anchoring. Every portable sign not in transit shall be securely anchored to the ground by cables, ground supports, or such other methods in order to comply with the wind load requirements set out herein or so anchored so that the sign will fall to its side without moving beyond the limits of that fall. All anchoring systems intended to be used by the sign company or sign owner shall be approved by the sign administrator, and the application for a portable sign, whether it be original, repermit, or relocation, shall designate the anchoring system to be used on that particular sign. 
(c)  Standards. Portable signs for the purpose of this chapter shall be subject to all provisions of this chapter, including the structural requirements, spacing requirements, permitting and fee requirements, insurance and bonding requirements, and all other provisions of this chapter applicable to ground signs unless a provision specifically includes or excludes a portable sign. 
(d)  Maintenance. The area where any portable sign is located must be maintained and kept clean by the owner. Grass will be cut a minimum of six (6) feet from said sign on all sides and entirely to the street curb of the side nearest the street and debris, etc., will be removed at least every seven (7) days. 
(e)  Number on premises. Each business will be allowed one (1) on-premises improved portable sign or one (1) portable on-premises sign displayed for no more than sixty (60) days per calendar year and meets all requirements of this chapter. 
(f)  Electrical. No portable sign may contain electrical components unless it fully meets the city electrical code. Extension cords may not be laid across any sidewalk, driveway, or any other line of traffic. 
(g)  Changeable face protection. Portable signs with changeable face display shall be secured by a locked cover so that the message cannot be tampered with and the changeable items will not be blown away by any wind. 
(h)  Size. No portable sign shall exceed in outside dimension six and one-half (6½) feet vertical or twelve and one-half (12½) feet horizontal. The advertising space on each side shall not exceed seventy-two (72) square feet or a dimension of six (6) feet by twelve (12) feet. 
(i)  Prohibited signs. 
(1)  New portable signs are prohibited. No permits shall be issued for new portable signs. 
(2)  The owner or occupant of the premises shall not display portable on-premises signs more than sixty (60) days per calendar year. No portable on-premises sign shall be displayed for more than thirty (30) consecutive days. Furthermore, there shall be a fifteen-day waiting period between displays so that no portable sign shall be displayed with less than fifteen (15) days between displays. Each time the sign is intended to be displayed a permit must be obtained. The permit fee is one dollar ($1.00) per day of exhibition. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-16. - Off-premises sign locations continuously permitted since October 18, 1983. 
All off-premises sign locations permitted prior to October 18, 1983, will continue to be permitted locations notwithstanding the provisions hereof, provided that they have been continuously permitted and maintained as provided herein or as may have been required by previous ordinances then in existence. 
All off-premises sign locations permitted between October 18, 1983, and the date of passage of this chapter will continue to be permitted locations notwithstanding the provisions hereof, provided that they have been continuously permitted and maintained as provided herein or as may have been required by previous ordinances then in existence. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-17. - Variance procedure and committee. 
(a)  Definition of the committee. The sign appeals committee created herein may, for a particular site, authorize the following special variances and exceptions with respect to the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Functions. The sign appeals committee shall recommend to the city council legislation for amendments to this code in keeping with technological progress with respect to public health, safety, and welfare. 
(c)  Granting variances. The committee may, in specific cases and subject to appropriate conditions, recommend to the city council for final approval only the following special variances and exceptions to the regulations established in this chapter when the committee has made a finding from the evidence presented that strict compliance with the requirement of this chapter will result in a hardship or inequity to the applicant in accomplishing the objectives of this article, provided that economic or self-created hardship alone shall not be a sufficient basis for the granting of a variance or exception. 
(1)  Grant up to a forty (40) per cent variance in the following: 
• Total square footage of sign area 
• Height 
• Setback 
(2)  Authorize the relocation on site of a legal sign which meets the general requirements of this chapter or variable items in this section. 
(3)  Allow the erection of one (1) additional on-premises, freestanding sign per site, provided that the additional sign shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of any other freestanding sign. 
(d)  Nonconforming signs. The committee may require a nonconforming sign to be brought into immediate conformity with all current standards of all ordinances of the city or to be removed when, from the evidence presented, the commission finds the sign to be hazardous to the public or to have been abandoned by its owners. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-18. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Adverse possession. No sign or its location will gain any future rights to that location or rights to a sign no matter how long it has been displayed. 
(b)  Presumptions of ownership. There is a rebuttable presumption of ownership under the following circumstances: 
• Printed name of the owner on the sign. 
• Holder of the permit number on the sign. 
• The beneficiary of the display on the sign. 
• The property on which the sign is located. 
(c)  Current address required. Any person, company, firm, partnership, or corporation who is required to obtain any permit under this chapter will maintain his current address with the sign administrator. The last address furnished by the entity holding the permit shall be presumed to be the correct address and any notice sent to that address shall be effective delivery of notice. 
(d)  Presumption of notice. Each notice required hereunder shall be sent to the listed owner of any sign by certified mail return receipt requested and at the same time by regular mail. If the registered mail is not picked up, refused, or undeliverable but the regular mail is not returned, it will be presumed that the notice sent by regular mail was delivered on the 5th day after posting or the date that first notice of registered/certified mail was given to the addressee. 
(e)  Notice to presumed owner. Notice of a violation will be sent to the person presumed to be the owner in the order above set out, and if the presumed owner refused to acknowledge that he/she is responsible for the sign, the city may without further notice remove the sign. 
(f)  City permit is not an endorsement. Any approval of a sign or its structure by the city is not a verification or endorsement of the worthiness of the sign, and any failure of the sign or its structure is strictly the responsibility of the owner, operator, designer, or person erecting the sign and its structure. 
(g)  The sanitation division is designated to assist in removals. The sanitation division of the public works department is designated as the division of the city government to assist and aid the sign administrator in the removal of signs. The sign administrator shall make a request in writing on forms provided and prepared by him/her to the sanitation division indicating the sign and its location and the location to which it is to be removed. 
(h)  City-sponsored and community events. 
(1)  Except for banners, signs advertising city-sponsored or community events will be permitted for not more than forty-five (45) days prior to the event, provided that the signs meet all other requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  Banners advertising city-sponsored or community events shall conform to the following requirements of this subsection: 
a.  Approval. No banner advertising a city-sponsored or community event may be displayed until approved in writing by the sign administrator. 
b.  Terms and conditions. In order to receive approval to display a banner, the following requirements must be met: 
1.  The banner shall be used only to inform the community of an upcoming event. 
2.  Banners may be displayed during and up to thirty (30) days prior to a community event and must be removed within two (2) days after event has ended. 
3.  A banner shall not be displayed unless approved by the traffic director who shall consider traffic safety and flow in the decision to approve the display. 
4.  Approval of the display of a banner at a particular location shall be on a first-come, first-serve basis. However, preference may be given for recurring annual events, historically or traditionally tied to a specific date or holiday season. Additionally, a request to advertise the reoccurrence of the same event, or same type of event within any one (1) calendar year, may be honored if no request for the banner site of a recurring annual event is received. 
5.  All banners over public property shall be placed by city personnel. 
6.  Maximum banner size shall not exceed four (4) feet by thirty (30) feet, and minimum size shall not be less than three and one-half (3½) feet by twenty-four (24) feet. 
7.  Day-glo or fluorescent colors shall not be allowed. 
8.  Banners shall be constructed of suitable water-resistant fabric. 
9.  Banners must be slit to reduce wind resistance. 
10.  Banners must be reinforced with rope within the casing of the edge of the banner. 
11.  The owner of a banner shall agree to assume full liability and indemnify the city for any damage to persons or property arising from the display of the banner by the city. 
12.  The city is not responsible for any damage that may occur to the banner for any cause. 
13.  Prices or fees charged for the event shall not be displayed. 
(i)  Official state historical signs and markers are exempt from the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-145, § 1, 9-26-00)  
Sec. 31-19. - Electronic off-premises signs. 
(a)  Authorization. An existing off-premises ground sign structure may be modified to support an electronic face subject to the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Electronic sign standards. An off-premises electronic sign face shall conform to all specifications herein: 
(1)  Dwell time. Each message on an off-premises electronic sign face shall remain static for at least eight (8) seconds and a change of message shall be accomplished within two (2) seconds. 
(2)  Change of message. A change of message on an off-premises electronic sign face must occur simultaneously on the entire sign face. 
(3)  Brightness. The brightness level is limited to 0.3 footcandles over ambient light conditions at a distance of two hundred fifty (250) feet from the sign. 
(4)  Malfunction. An off-premises electronic sign face shall contain a default mechanism, that will freeze the sign in one (1) position if a malfunction occurs. 
(5)  Driver impairment. An off-premises electronic sign face shall not face light of such intensity or brilliance to cause glare or otherwise impair the vision of the driver, or results in a nuisance to the driver. 
(6)  Automatic dimmer. An off-premises electronic sign face shall be equipped with both a dimmer control and a photocell which automatically adjusts the face's intensity according to natural ambient light conditions. 
(7)  Official signage. An off-premises electronic sign face must not resemble or simulate any lights or official signage used to control traffic in accordance with the 2003 Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, with Revision No. 1 published by the Federal Highway Administration (FHVVA). 
(c)  Static face removal. An existing static face off-premises sign may only be modified to support an electronic face if the owner presents the sign administrator with pictorial proof and a sworn affidavit evidencing the removal of at least three (3) square feet of static face from within the city for every one (1) square foot of electronic face to be erected. (Example: for a six hundred seventy-two (672) square feet electronic face, an owner would have to remove at least two thousand sixteen (2,016) square feet of existing face area.) The removal of the face which the electronic face will replace shall not count toward the removal total. 
(1)  Completed signs. Sign faces used for this purpose must be from physically completed sign structures with complete sign faces. No partially erected/completed signs may be used. 
(2)  Size. No electronic sign face may exceed six hundred seventy-two (672) square feet. 
(d)  Structure modification. The owner of an existing off-premises sign may replace any structural components necessary to support an electronic face. A sign structure that is modified: 
(1)  Shall not increase the number of poles used to support the sign's superstructure. 
(2)  Shall not increase the sign support's height or the number of faces on the structure. 
(3)  Shall obtain all necessary permits, including electrical and sign permits for the electronic face, from the city. 
(e)  Emergency messages. The owner of an off-premises electronic sign face shall coordinate with local authorities to display, when appropriate, emergency information important to the traveling public such as Amber Alerts, alerts concerning terrorist attacks, natural disasters or as authorized by the office of emergency management. Emergency information messages shall remain in the advertising rotation according to the protocols of the agency that issues the information. 
(f)  Except as provided by this section (31-19), electronic off-premises signs shall otherwise conform to the requirements of this chapter 31. 
(Ord. No. 10-283, § 1(Exh. A), 12-21-10; Ord. No. 11-033, § 1, 3-1-11)
