Chapter 32 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city relative to streets, sidewalks and other public ways, Art. I, §§ 4, 5. 
Cross reference— Ambulances, Ch. 4; auto wreckers, Ch. 7; riding bicycles on sidewalks, § 8-5; setback requirements for buildings, § 9-76 et seq.; moving of buildings on streets, § 9-111 et seq.; littering streets and alleys generally, § 14-19; littering streets by patrons of drive-in restaurants, § 20-59; discharging firearms, air guns, etc., in or across streets, § 20-3; loitering on streets, § 20-4; pipeline transportation, Ch. 27; franchises for use of streets, sidewalks, etc., for pipeline transportation, § 27-18 et seq.; planning, Ch. 28; duties of planning and zoning commission relative to streets, § 28-41; traffic, Ch. 36; streets and sidewalks in townhouse subdivisions, App. A; streets and sidewalks in townhouse subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference— General authority of city relative to streets and sidewalks, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175 (16—18). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Certain ordinances relating to streets not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed as repealing or otherwise affecting the validity of any ordinance: 
(1)  Dedicating, accepting, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, improving, widening or vacating any street or other public way in the city; 
(2)  Relating to municipal street maintenance agreements with the state; or 
(3)  Establishing or prescribing grades for streets in the city; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.  
Sec. 32-2. - Street numbers for buildings. 
(a)  All houses erected within the city limits shall have affixed thereto permanent, or semipermanent, house numbers prior to inspection by the city inspectors. Such numbers shall be made of aluminum, iron, plastic, or a similar material. Before such numbers are attached to such houses, the owner or the builder shall request the assignment of a proper street number from the building official. 
(b)  No official of the city shall authorize the connection of utilities to any building in the city unless a proper street number has been attached to such building. 
(c)  All buildings shall display the street address of the business location it advertises in numbers at least four (4) inches in height, in a legible form and within forty (40) feet of the nearest public roadway. Such numbers shall increase one (1) inch in height for each additional forty (40) feet or fractional part thereof from the center of the nearest public roadway. 
(Code 1964, § 24-7; Ord. No. 00-201, § 1, 12-12-00) 
Cross reference— Buildings generally, Ch. 9.  
Sec. 32-3. - Obstructions or encroachments on streets or alleys. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, place, build, construct or maintain any fence, gate, pole, post, sign, building or other obstruction or encroachment upon any public street or alley or any portion of a public street or alley within the city or to cause any of such things to be done. The enumeration of certain types of obstructions and encroachments shall not limit the scope and effect of this section, but the same shall be construed to prohibit and forbid every type and kind of obstruction or encroachment upon any public street or alley of whatever nature or character. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall authorize the prosecution of any person for obstructing or encroaching upon any street or alley within the city, where such obstruction or encroachment is permitted by some other provision of the ordinances of the city or the laws of the state; provided that, it shall not be necessary, in any complaint, action or proceeding under this section, to negate this exception, but the same shall be proved by the defendant by way of defense. 
(Ord. No. 67-1915, § 1, 2-28-67) 
Charter reference— Authority of city to remove street encroachments, Art. I, § 4. 
Cross reference— Signs generally, Ch. 31; signs projecting over streets and sidewalks, § 31-8; location of signs near streetlight standards, § 31-10; minimum height of signs over sidewalks, § 31-65 et seq.  
Sec. 32-4. - Use of sidewalks for display of goods, wares, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any merchant, owner, manager or person in charge of any mercantile or other business located in the city to display or permit to be displayed upon the sidewalk in front of or adjacent to his place of business any goods, wares or merchandise kept for sale, or to leave or permit to be left on the sidewalk, in front of his place of business or adjacent thereto any boxes, barrels, crates, packages or containers, whether empty or containing merchandise, waste materials or trash. It shall not be deemed a violation of this section for goods, wares and merchandise, whether in containers or not, to be unloaded upon the sidewalk for immediate removal into the place of business, or for same to be placed upon the sidewalk for the purpose of being immediately loaded upon trucks or other vehicles for shipment or for delivery to a purchaser, or for removal to some other location, provided such goods, wares and merchandise or boxes, barrels, crates, packages or containers, whether empty or not, shall in no case be permitted to remain on such sidewalk for more than ten (10) minutes after being placed thereon. 
(Code 1964, § 24-8)  
Sec. 32-5. - Inspection and repair of utility fixtures in streets and alleys. 
The city fire marshal, building official, electrical inspector, police officers, and such other persons as may be designated by the city shall have power and it shall be their duty to examine and inspect, from time to time, all gas pipelines, and other fixtures in the streets, alleys and other public places within the city for the purpose of seeing that all of same are in a safe and suitable condition, and whenever any such item is found unsafe or unsuitable for the purpose for which it is used, the person using, possessing or maintaining same shall be notified and required to place same in a safe and suitable condition. 
(Code 1964, § 24-9) 
Cross reference— Pipeline transportation, Ch. 27.  
Sec. 32-6. - Liability of city for damages caused by defective streets and sidewalks. 
The city shall not be liable to any person for damages caused from streets, ways, crossings, bridges, culverts or sidewalks being out of repair from negligence of the city, unless the same shall have remained so for ten (10) days after special notice in writing given to the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 24-10)  
Sec. 32-7. - Change in names of certain streets lying north and south of Shaw Street and east and west of Shaver Street. 
(a)  All of the streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, lanes or plazas lying north of Shaw Street and West Shaw Street, presently having like corresponding numbers south of Shaw Street and West Shaw Street shall be designated with the prefix of "North" to each street, avenue, boulevard, road, lane or plaza; example, to wit; that portion of Shaver Street lying north of Shaw Street shall be designated as North Shaver Street and that portion lying south of Shaw Street shall be designated as Shaver Street only. 
(b)  All of the streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, lanes or plazas lying south of Shaw Street and West Shaw Street, presently having like corresponding numbers north of Shaw Street and West Shaw Street shall be designated by only the name of such street so as to eliminate the prefix "South"; example, to wit; that portion of Shaver Street lying south of Shaw Street shall be designated as Shaver Street. 
(c)  All of the streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, lanes or plazas lying west of Shaver Street and west of North Shaver Street presently having like corresponding numbers east of Shaver Street and North Shaver Street shall be designated by the prefix "West" to each street; example, to wit; that portion of Shaw Street lying west of Shaver Street shall be West Shaw Street and that portion of Shaw Street lying east of Shaver Street shall be designated as Shaw Street only. 
(d)  All of the streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, lanes or plazas lying east of Shaver Street and east of North Shaver Street presently having like corresponding numbers west of Shaver Street and North Shaver Street shall be designated by the name of such street only so as to eliminate the prefix "East"; example, to wit; that portion of Shaw Street lying east of Shaver Street shall be designated as Shaw Street. 
(Ord. No. 72-23, §§ 1—4, 2-1-72) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 72-23 did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion of §§ 1—4 herein as § 32-7 was at the discretion of the editors.  
Sec. 32-8. - Obstruction of street crossing by railroad train. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any railway train to obstruct a street crossing in the city for a longer period of time than five (5) minutes at one time. After a crossing has been illegally obstructed for the initial period of five (5) minutes, each succeeding period of five (5) minutes of illegal obstruction shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  By the term "obstruct a street crossing" is meant the blocking of the flow of traffic on such street by stopping a railway train on the railroad tracks across such street, or by occupying the tracks across the street with a moving railway train, or by a combination of both, it being the intent and purpose of this section to prevent the person in charge of the railway train from obstructing traffic flowing upon the street by either a moving railway train or a stopped railway train or a combination of both. 
(Ord. No. 74-186, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-74) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 74-186, not expressly amendatory of this Code, has been codified as § 32-8 by the editors.  
Secs. 32-9—32-16. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - IMPROVEMENTS ON RIGHT-OF-WAY PROPERTY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Installation of electrical conduits, wires, etc., on, over or under streets, § 12-18. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 32-17. - Purpose of article. 
The purpose of this article is to set out the standards, specifications, minimum requirements, fees, permits, and any other standards that this article shall require of any person for work to be done in this city on any public, private or city right-of-way property. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, § A, 11-25-69)  
Sec. 32-18. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply, unless clearly indicated to the contrary: 
Builder. Any person, partnership, company or corporation, or a representative of any of them, shall be referred to as "builder" or "person," and such terms shall be synonymous with each other. 
Director. The term "director" shall mean the director of planning for the city. 
Exhibits. Reference to various "exhibits" refer to the exhibits attached to the original of Ordinance No. 69-254 and made a part of this article by section 32-19. 
Inspector. The term "inspector" shall mean the building official of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
Opening. An "opening" is any breaking in or on any public street, curb or sidewalk for the purpose of placing pipelines, sewer lines or other utilities. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, § B, 11-25-69)  
Sec. 32-19. - Minimum standards. 
(a)  No person shall construct, alter, improve or install any curb, gutter, tile drain, sidewalk, street or driveway, or make any other installation upon the streets or upon any other city-owned property or right-of-way, unless the same meets the minimum standards and specifications as set out in this article, chapter 9 of this Code and Exhibits "A" through "G", as attached to the original of Ordinance No. 69-254 on file in the city secretary's office, which exhibits are hereby made a part of this article to the same extent as if set out at length herein; however, where public sidewalks are required in a residential subdivision, the wire mesh as shown on the City of Pasadena "Standard Paving Detail" may be eliminated. 
(b)  If there is any variance between any portion of this article, chapter 9 of this Code, or the exhibits referred to in subsection (a), then such exhibits shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, §§ D2, F1, 11-25-69; Ord. No. 74-151, § 1, 7-23-74)  
Sec. 32-20. - Work permit generally. 
(a)  A permit from the building inspection department shall be required before any work is started on any type of construction project for improvements, altering, landscaping, or construction governed by this article. A permit will be required for each street, sidewalk, curb, culvert, opening, or alteration of same that a builder intends to construct or make, even though the job site includes more than one of same in his contract, except in residential subdivisions, the permit for a new house shall also authorize construction of sidewalks and driveways according to the approved plans and the City Code, however, in no event shall the five dollar ($5.00) permit fee provided for in section 32-20(d) be waived. 
(b)  All sidewalks that are constructed in this city shall have a minimum width of four (4) feet and shall comply with the minimum specifications set out in Exhibits "C" and "E" referred to in section 32-19, except in residential subdivisions, the wire mesh may be eliminated. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued for the paving of any portion of the public right-of-way without the express written approval of the director. 
(d)  A fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be charged for each permit issued by the building inspection department under this article. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, §§ E1—E3, E4, E6, 11-25-69; Ord. No. 70-120, § 3, 6-16-70; Ord. No. 74-151, §§ 2, 3, 7-23-74) 
Cross reference— Provisions of building code relative to fee for construction or alteration of sidewalk, culvert or driveway, § 9-63(118.4).  
Sec. 32-21. - Plans and specifications for work. 
Plans and specifications shall be required and must be submitted to the building inspection department for any type of improvements, altering, landscaping or construction of any building, structure, sidewalk, gutter, curb, culvert, opening, drainpipe, or the like that is within the scope of this article. Such plans and specifications must meet the minimum standards as set out in this article and must be approved in writing by the director of planning. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, § D1, 11-25-69)  
Sec. 32-22. - Inspection of work. 
(a)  For the purpose of inspecting the forms and materials used on the site for work authorized by a permit issued under this article, the builder shall notify the building inspection department at least twenty-four (24) hours before pouring any concrete. 
(b)  When the inspector is called on a job site for inspection approval and, upon his inspection, he determines that the work does not meet the required minimum standards, then the builder shall be required to pay a reinspection fee of five dollars ($5.00) before the inspector can be called to reinspect the work. Such fee shall be required to reinspect each and every job that has failed to pass the first inspection by the inspector. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, §§ C2, C3, E7, 11-25-69)  
Sec. 32-23. - Correction of defects. 
(a)  When the inspector makes an inspection of the job site covered by a permit issued under this article and finds that defective workmanship or defective materials are being used, and therefore do not meet the minimum standards provided for in this article, he shall order all further work to be stopped until the defective condition is remedied. If the work is not stopped or the defective condition is not remedied, then the inspector shall void the permit and instruct the builder, in writing, to replace the street, alley, easement or sidewalk in an approved manner. 
(b)  If, within fifteen (15) days after written notice by the inspector, the builder fails to replace the street, alley, easement or sidewalk opening in an approved manner, the director may order the work done by the city employees or by city contract and shall bill and collect from the builder the cost of restoring the street, alley, easement or sidewalk opening to its original condition. If the replacement work is done by city employees or by city contract, the cost thereof shall be deducted from the deposit made by the builder under this article or a claim on the builder's bond shall be filed. If the deposit is insufficient to restore the street, alley, easement or sidewalk to its original condition, the builder shall reimburse the city for such replacement by paying such difference to the city. 
(c)  If the director orders uncompleted work to be completed by city employees or by city contract, then all permits issued to that builder shall be cancelled and no permit shall be issued under this article to that builder for a period of twelve (12) months from the date of the director's order. In the event that the city is unable to collect from the builder for the costs incurred by the city for the completion of the work, then that builder shall not be issued any permit until such costs are paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, §§ C, C1, 11-25-69)  
Secs. 32-24—32-28. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - REQUIREMENTS FOR SPECIFIC IMPROVEMENTS AND WORK 
 
Sec. 32-29. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Where a building is to be constructed and it faces one or more streets, it shall be required by the city that sidewalks shall be constructed and installed on all sides of the building fronting or siding a street, except that, where more than fifty (50) per cent of the block fronting on the street where a proposed residential building is to be constructed has been developed without sidewalks, such residential construction shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(b)  All sidewalks that are constructed in this city shall have a minimum width of four (4) feet and shall comply with the minimum specifications set out in Exhibits "C" and "E" referred to in section 32-19. 
(c)  There shall be a minimum space of six (6) feet between the curb of the adjacent street and the edge of the sidewalk nearest the curbline, unless a lesser distance is approved by the director in writing. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, §§ G1, G2, 11-25-69; Ord. No. 70-120, § 1, 6-16-70)  
Sec. 32-30. - Culverts. 
(a)  Concrete culverts shall be installed in all open ditches adjacent to all public streets which are adjacent to the construction site where a building or driveway permit is obtained for the purpose of constructing a building or driveway, unless otherwise approved by the director in writing. 
(b)  The size and type of culvert to be installed shall be as specified by the director of public works and in accordance with city specifications. 
(c)  The flow line of the culvert shall be determined by the director of public works or by a registered professional engineer and approved by the director of public works. 
(d)  Inspection of the culvert installation shall be made by the city inspector, and no building or driveway permit shall be finally approved until such time as the culvert installation is approved and accepted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, § G3, 11-25-69)  
Sec. 32-31. - Openings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any opening in any street, alley, easement or sidewalk in the city for any purpose, including the making of any connection with a city sewer, without first having obtained written permission for such openings from the director and obtaining a permit from the building inspection department. The permit shall specify the number of and type of openings to be made. Such openings shall comply with all requirements of this article, and construction must be completed within thirty (30) days. 
(b)  No permit required by this section shall be issued unless the builder first files with the building inspection department a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) cash bond for each opening. In lieu of the cash deposit, the builder may submit a written bond or an insurance policy in the amount required for each opening or for each instance where the deposit is required. The company that issues the insurance policy or bond shall be a reputable company doing business in, and under the laws of, the State of Texas. Such insurance policy or surety bond shall be valid from the date of the issuance of the permit and shall expire not less than five (5) years from the date of final completion of the construction project. 
(c)  Any person having a franchise to do business in the city may, under circumstances creating an emergency or upon request of a city official, open a street, alley, easement or sidewalk for the purpose of making emergency repairs or the installation of facilities, without complying with the provisions of this section. In any event, utility companies holding franchises to do business in the city shall be exempt from payment of fees for such openings. 
(d)  The builder shall be required to place barricades around or near any opening or construction project, and such barricades shall be properly located, lighted and maintained in order to maintain minimum safety to the public, either as pedestrians or in vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 69-254, §§ E5, H, 11-25-69) 
Cross reference— Boring streets for purpose of making sewer taps, § 37-6; street excavations by persons holding pipeline franchises, § 27-23 et seq.  
Sec. 32-32. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 95-218, adopted Nov. 7, 1995, repealed § 32-32 in its entirety. Former § 32-32 provided for construction of off-street parking areas and derived from Ord. No. 69-254, § I, adopted Nov. 25, 1969; Ord. No. 70-120, § 3, adopted June 16, 1970; and Ord. No. 73-295, § 1, adopted Nov. 27, 1973. See § 9-7.1 of this Code for similar provisions.  
Sec. 32-33. - Driveways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or permit to be constructed, as a means of ingress and egress to and from the public streets, ways, alleys and easements within the city, any driveway, other than such as are necessary for ingress and egress to and from the property to be served and as shall be deemed as not interfering with or creating unsafe conditions for traffic on the public streets, ways, alleys and easements. The director of public works and the traffic director shall jointly determine, upon application to be made to the director of public works for a permit to construct a driveway as such means of ingress and egress, whether the construction of the driveway proposed in the application is necessary and safe as provided herein for such ingress and egress. The directors of public works and traffic shall arrive at their determinations pursuant to the requirements and standards prescribed in this article, and in accord with applicable, generally accepted principles and techniques of civil engineering and of public traffic control. No permit shall be issued in contravention of the express requirements or restrictions of this section and without the written approval of both the director of public works and the traffic director. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by the decision under this section of the directors of public works and traffic shall have the right of appeal to the city council within fourteen (14) days after the refusal of the permit application. The city council, upon such appeal, shall determine whether or not the proposed driveway is necessary for ingress and egress to and from the property to be served, at a hearing, either in regular or special meeting of the council, as it shall determine from case to case, of which the applicant shall have notice by certified return receipt mail. Within seven (7) days after such hearing, the city council shall enter and file with the city secretary an order either affirming or reversing the appealed action. 
(c)  All plats approved by the planning and zoning commission shall conform with the requirements and standards of this section, except where different, applicable requirements and standards are provided by another effective ordinance or ordinances. 
(d)  The herein prescribed dimensions shall be observed in the issuance of permits for and the construction of driveways: 
(1)  Minimum width of driveway opening: Ten (10) feet. 
(2)  Maximum widths of driveways: 
a.  On thirty (30) foot to fifty (50) foot lot or parcel frontage: Twenty (20) feet net clearance. 
b.  On fifty (50) foot and more lot or parcel frontage: Thirty-five (35) feet net clearance. 
(e)  A minimum of twenty (20) feet shall separate the outer edges of the entrances of any two (2) driveways opening onto any public street, way, alley or easement. 
(f)  No driveway in the city shall be permitted to open into or within thirty-five (35) feet of the extended curbline's intersection of the nearest public street, way or alley intersection, or if there is no intersection of two (2) or more curblines thereat, within thirty-five (35) feet of the nearest point of intersection of the traveled portions of such public streets, ways or alleys. 
(g)  Every driveway shall, as nearly as practicable, be of the same materials and standards as the public street, way, alley or easement abutting thereon, or of approved equals and as fixed by current Driveway Construction Materials and Methods Specifications, prepared by the director of public works and filed with the city secretary. 
(h)  For the purpose of processing any driveway permit application, the personnel of the department of building inspection are hereby designated as the duly authorized representatives of the director of public works, subject to his direction in all matters appertaining thereto. It shall be the responsibility of such personnel to handle all such applications with the traffic director. 
(i)  Every driveway permit application shall be accompanied by a complete, scaled plat of the existing premises, a scaled plan of the proposed driveway, a description and quantity list of materials to be used, and such other plans and specifications as the director of public works may require to ascertain the exact construction proposed. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1, 6-14-66; Ord. No. 67-1995, § 1, 8-8-67) 
Cross reference— General requirements for driveways for multifamily residential developments, § 9-2(4); driveway required for mobile home located outside mobile home park, § 21-50; limitation on driveways in mobile home parks, § 21-65.

(Ord. No. 1818, § 1, 6-14-66)  
Sec. 32-34. - Median openings. 
(a)  Where an opening is to be constructed in the median of a divided street, such median opening shall be located a minimum distance of four hundred (400) feet from the nearest point of an adjacent median opening or street intersection. 
(b)  Standards for design of approved median openings are shown in Table 1. 
(c)  All median openings hereafter constructed shall have a length equal to the width of any intersecting street, if any, plus sixteen (16) feet, or as shown in Table 1, whichever is greater. 
(d)  Every median opening shall, as nearly as practicable, be of the same materials and standards as the public street upon which it is constructed, or of approved equals and as fixed by current construction materials and methods specifications, prepared by the director of public works and filed with the city secretary. 
(e)  Requests for construction of median openings on existing streets shall be submitted in writing to the director of traffic and transportation stating the desired location(s). 
(f)  Variances to the minimum distance of four hundred (400) feet as specified in subsection (a) may be approved by the city council. Such variance shall be placed on the city council agenda under Item 22, "Other Business," for consideration by city council. 
(Ord. No. 81-147, § 1, 8-25-81; Ord. No. 84-120, § 1, 6-19-84)  
Secs. 32-35—32-43. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STREET BANNERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Signs, Ch. 31. 
 
Sec. 32-44. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article, a "banner" shall be any sign erected or maintained for any type of advertising or public display on or across a public street, whether it be of a commercial or noncommercial nature. 
(Ord. No. 68-69, § 1, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 32-45. - Permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct or maintain, or cause or permit to be erected, constructed or maintained, any banner in the city, without first having obtained a permit from the director of public works. Any person desiring such a permit must submit a request to the director of public works, in writing, stating the type and nature of the banner, its size, materials, and the proposed location of the same. The request must be approved by the director before a permit will be issued. A permit shall be required for each location where a banner will be placed along or across a public street. 
(b)  A fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be charged for each permit issued under this section and each permit shall state the location of the banner to be erected. 
(Ord. No. 68-69, §§ 3, 4, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 32-46. - Material and erection requirements. 
Banners placed on or across any public street shall be constructed of cloth or similar material. The banner itself shall be no higher than forty (40) inches and it must be at least thirteen (13) feet above the roadway. Such banner shall not be constructed or erected in any manner so as to constitute a traffic obstruction or hazard. 
(Ord. No. 68-69, § 2, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 32-47. - Maximum time permitted. 
No banner shall be erected or maintained along or across a public street for a period of more than fifteen (15) days. 
(Ord. No. 68-69, § 5, 5-21-68)  
Sec. 32-48. - City not liable for damages caused by banner. 
The city shall not be liable for any damages to any person or persons caused by any manner. 
(Ord. No. 68-69, § 6, 5-21-68)  
Secs. 32-49—32-58. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PERMIT FOR MAIN GAS PIPELINE EXTENSIONS IN OR PARALLEL TO STREETS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Pipeline transportation, Ch. 27. 
 
Sec. 32-59. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article, a "main gas pipeline extension" is defined as any gas pipeline extension which runs in or parallel to any street, avenue, parkway, easement or other public property within the corporate limits of the city. This definition shall not be construed to include lines one and one-fourth (1¼) inches in diameter, or less, by which gas is transported from a main line to the consumer, such a line being commonly known as a "service line", and it shall not be necessary to obtain the special permit required by this article in order to lay such a service line. 
(Code 1964, § 24-18)  
Sec. 32-60. - Required. 
No person using or maintaining any gas pipeline, pipes, and other fixtures for the distribution of gas in any of the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks or other public places within the corporate limits of the city shall build, make, construct or install any main gas pipeline extension within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a permit therefor from the director of public works. 
(Code 1964, § 24-19)  
Sec. 32-61. - Application. 
Application for a permit required by this article shall be made to the director of public works upon a form to be prescribed by him, such form to include a plat or map showing the location of the proposed extension. Such application shall give complete information as to the location, kind and character of the proposed extension, the depth to be installed, the pressure to be carried, and if more than one hundred fifty (150) pounds pressure and less than thirty (30) inches in depth, the reason that it cannot be installed at that depth. 
(Code 1964, § 24-20)  
Sec. 32-62. - Fee. 
There shall be a fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) for each permit issued by the director of public works for a main gas pipeline extension. 
(Code 1964, § 24-21)  
Sec. 32-63. - Issuance or refusal. 
(a)  If the application for a permit under this article is for an extension for a distance of six hundred (600) feet or less, upon the filing of the application and examination of same by the director of public works, he shall, unless such extension is to carry more than one hundred fifty (150) pounds pressure and is not to be buried at least thirty (30) inches below the surface, or in his opinion the extension would, in other respects, seriously interfere with the public welfare and convenience of the inhabitants of the city, promptly issue a permit. If any application is refused by the director, he shall, within two (2) days, certify same with his recommendation thereon to the city council for its consideration by filing the same with the city secretary. If the application is not approved by the city council, it shall notify the director within seven (7) days after receipt of same of such disapproval and the permit shall not be granted; provided, however, that whenever the city council refuses such permit, the applicant may make written application to the city council, within ten (10) days, for a reconsideration and a personal hearing thereon, and the decision of the city council thereon at such hearing shall be final. 
(b)  If such application is for a distance of more than six hundred (600) feet, the director of public works shall not grant the same without prior approval of the city council. If such permit is denied, the applicant may, within seven (7) days, make written application for reconsideration and a personal hearing thereon, and the decision of the city council at such hearing shall be final. 
(Code 1964, § 24-22)  
Sec. 32-64. - Condition. 
Every permit issued under this article shall be issued on condition that the permittee agrees to lower such line at his own expense, within thirty (30) days of the mailing of written notice by the director of public works to the permittee at the address shown in the application, in the event future street construction or other city improvement projects should require that such line be lowered, in the opinion of the director of public works. 
(Code 1964, § 24-23)  
Secs. 32-65—32-74. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - STREET RENTAL CHARGE FOR GAS MAINS, PIPES, ETC.[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Pipeline transportation, Ch. 27. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to fix compensation to be paid for use of streets and alleys by utility companies, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175 (12). 
 
Sec. 32-75. - Imposed; amount; when payable. 
Upon the first day of February of each year, every person occupying or using the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks, or other public places in the city with gas mains, pipes and other fixtures for the distribution of gas shall, as a condition to such further occupancy, pay to the city annually for such privilege, a rental equal to two per cent (2%) of the gross receipts received by such person from gas sold and delivered to residential and commercial consumers at residential and commercial rates within the corporate limits of the city for the preceding calendar year. 
(Code 1964, § 24-31) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to make reasonable charge, not exceeding 2% of gross receipts, for use of streets, alleys, etc., by public utilities, V.A.T.S. Tax.—Gen. art. 11.03.  
Sec. 32-76. - Report of gross receipts of payor. 
All persons using or maintaining any gas pipelines, pipes and other fixtures in any of the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks or other places within the corporate limits of the city shall, on the first day of February of each year, file with the city controller a sworn report showing the gross receipts from gas sold and delivered to residential and commercial consumers at residential and commercial rates by such persons within the corporate limits of the city for the preceding year ending December thirty-first. 
(Code 1964, § 24-32)  
Sec. 32-77. - Examinations of books and records of payor. 
The city council may, when it may see fit, have the books and records of any person rendering the statement required in section 32-76 examined by a representative of the city to ascertain whether such statement is accurate, but nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the city from ascertaining the facts by any other method. 
(Code 1964, § 24-33)  
Sec. 32-78. - Receipt for payment. 
Upon receipt of the rental charge imposed by this article by the city, the city controller shall deliver to the person paying the same a receipt therefor, which receipt shall authorize such person to use and occupy the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks and other public ways of the city in carrying on his business for twelve (12) months from January first of such year. 
(Code 1964, § 24-34)  
Sec. 32-79. - Charge is not a tax, but is additional to taxes. 
The rental charge imposed by this article is not charged as a tax but is made for the privilege now enjoyed by the persons upon whom it is imposed of using the streets, easements, alleys, and other public ways of the city in the conduct of their business, and such charge is additional to all ad valorem and franchise taxes and to all taxes of every nature whatsoever against such persons. 
(Code 1964, § 24-35) 
Cross reference— Taxation, Ch. 34.  
Sec. 32-80. - Article grants no relief from other laws and ordinances. 
Nothing in this article is intended to relieve any person of any condition, restriction or requirement imposed by any law or ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 24-36)  
Sec. 32-81. - Article does not grant franchise; cancellation of privileges and refund of rental. 
This article does not grant a franchise to any utility or person to use the streets, easements, alleys, and other public ways and shall never be so construed by the courts or otherwise, and the city reserves the right to cancel the privileges granted hereunder and refund the unearned rentals paid to the city. 
(Code 1964, § 24-37)  
Sec. 32-82. - Right of city to adopt restrictions, regulations, etc. 
The city hereby reserves the right to put into effect at any time other restrictions and regulations as to the erection and maintenance of gas mains, pipes, and other appurtenances in the streets, easements, alleys and other public ways of the city and from time to time to require such gas mains, pipes and other property, equipment and fixtures as it may deem proper to be removed on such terms as the city may deem proper. 
(Code 1964, § 24-38)  
Secs. 32-83—32-88. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SALE OF GOODS ON STREETS OR SIDEWALKS 
 
Sec. 32-89. - Sale of goods on streets or sidewalks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to expose for sale or to sell any foodstuffs of any nature, any liquids, or any other goods, wares, or merchandise, either exposed or enclosed in boxes, crates, barrels, baskets or any other container or any animals, on any sidewalk, street, parkway, esplanade or any other public property or any property dedicated to public use. It shall be unlawful to erect, construct, build, maintain or occupy any booth, stand or other structure, either permanent or temporary, or occupy any vehicle upon any sidewalk, street, parkway, esplanade or other public property or any property dedicated to public use for the purpose of carrying on or furthering any private business, enterprise, calling, vocation or profession. 
(Ord. No. 89-92, § 1, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 32-90. - Exemptions. 
This article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Persons selling or dispensing frozen dessert products that are fully wrapped, enclosed and contained in individual wrappers or containers from sanitary and such other refrigerated vehicles approved and licensed by the director of public health pursuant to this Code, provided that such vehicles shall be operated in full compliance with the health, food, drug and sanitary provisions of this Code and the applicable statutes of the state; 
(2)  Persons selling and/or installing any nonelectrical apparatuses for the sale of newspapers on sidewalks, or other public property or property dedicated to public use, provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to install any apparatus for the sale of newspapers where such apparatus will impede or interfere with the free passage of persons on sidewalks or other public property. The permission granted by this subsection shall apply to the extent of the city's right, title, and interest only; 
(3)  Persons acting in compliance with a franchise granted by the city; 
(4)  Religious, charitable and non-profit organizations that have obtained approval from city council to sell merchandise or products on public property; or 
(5)  Transactions in public buildings or on public property in which transaction the city is a party. 
(Ord. No. 89-92, § 1, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 32-91. - Enforcement. 
This article shall be enforced by any police officer of the City of Pasadena in addition to being enforced by other applicable departments and employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-92, § 1, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 32-92. - Penalty. 
Any person convicted for a violation of this article shall be fined in a sum not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 89-92, § 1, 6-13-89)  
ARTICLE VII. - RIGHTS-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 32-93. - Findings and purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to: 
(a)  Assist in the management of facilities placed in, on or over the public rights-of-way in order to minimize the congestion, inconvenience, deterioration, visual impact and other adverse effects, and the costs to the citizens resulting from the placement of facilities within the public rights-of-way; 
(b)  Govern the use and occupancy of the public rights-of-way; 
(c)  Assist the city in its efforts to protect the public health, safety and welfare; 
(d)  Conserve the limited physical capacity of the public rights-of-way held in public trust by the city; 
(e)  Preserve the physical integrity of the city's streets, utilities and highways; 
(f)  Control the orderly flow of vehicles and pedestrians; 
(g)  Keep track of the different entities using the public rights-of-way to prevent interference between them and the city's utilities; 
(h)  Assist in scheduling common trenching borings and street cuts and other general construction impacting city infrastructure; and 
(i)  Protect the safety, security, appearance, and condition of the public rights-of-way. 
This article may be referred to as the "city public rights-of-way management ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 09-062, § 1, 3-17-09; Ord. No. 17-116, § 1(Exh. A), 8-15-17)  
Sec. 32-94. - Authority; scope. 
This article applies to all persons that place facilities in, on or over public rights-of-way. Compensation for use of the public rights-of-way shall be paid in accordance with all applicable law, including, but not limited to, cable and video service providers, in accordance with the Federal Cable Act, 47 USC § 541, et seq. and Chapter 66 of the Texas Utilities Code; for certificated telecommunication providers providing services within the scope of Chapter 283 and not installing the facilities described in Chapter 284 of the Texas Local Government Code, Chapter 283 of the Texas Local Government Code; for network providers, Chapter 284 of the Texas Local Government Code; for distributors of natural gas or as otherwise applicable. Texas Tax Code § 182.025; and/or in accordance with Tex. Civil Statute, Art. 1175(1), all as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 09-062, § 2, 3-17-09; Ord. No. 17-116, § 1(Exh. A), 8-15-17)  
Sec. 32-95. - Definitions. 
In this chapter the following words, terms and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
Abandonment shall mean the permanent cessation of all uses of a facility; provided that this term shall not include cessation of all use of a facility within a physical structure where the physical structure continues to be used. By way of example, and not limitation, cessation of all use of a cable within a conduit, where the conduit continues to be used, shall not be "abandonment" of a facility in public rights-of-way. 
Applicant means an applicant for a permit under this chapter. 
Bond means a cash deposit with the city, or a bond executed by the permittee, as principal, and a corporate surety authorized to transact business, as such, in Texas on condition that the permittee will promptly and fully comply with all provisions of this chapter and will reimburse the city or any utility company for all costs associated with the removal of the facility and the restoration of the facility site if removed by the city or a utility company pursuant to this chapter. A surety bond must be in a form approved by the director and be accompanied by a power of attorney or other convincing evidence of the issuing agent's authority to act for the surety company. A surety bond issued by a company that is not listed on the then current listing of accepted sureties on federal bonds as published by the United States Treasury Department must also be accompanied by a certificate of qualification as a surety from the Texas Board of Insurance Commissioners. 
Cable or video service provider (or CVSP) means the same as defined in Texas Utilities Code, § 66.002 (3) and (11) [any entity that has been issued a certificate of franchise authority by the Public Utility Commission of Texas to offer cable or video service]. 
Certificated telecommunications provider (or CTP) means the same as defined in Tex. Loc. Gov't § 283.002(2) [any entity that has been issued a certificate of convenience and necessity, certificate of operating authority, or service provider certificate of operating authority by the Texas Public Utility Commission to offer local exchange telephone service]. 
City means The City of Pasadena, Texas. As used throughout, the term city also includes the designated agent of the city. 
City property means all city buildings, infrastructure, bridges, parks, golf courses, parking lots and other real property that is not dedicated for utility or street transportation purposes. 
Direction of the city means all ordinances, laws, rules, resolutions, and regulations of the city that are not inconsistent with this article and that are now in force or may hereafter be passed and adopted. 
Director means the director of public works department or such director's designee. 
Excavation means an activity that cuts, penetrates, or bores under any portion of the public way that has been improved with a paved surface for street, sidewalk, surface drainage, or related public transportation infrastructure purposes. The term includes but is not limited to cutting, tunneling, jacking and boring in the public rights-of-way. The term does not include a transportation improvement; however, it does include excavations that are undertaken for the improvement or maintenance of publicly owned utility systems, such as water and wastewater lines and facilities. The term also does not include utility maintenance or other activities that are performed within already existing structures, vaults, conduits, or cableways that are located underneath street improvements, provided that any access required for the work is obtained through existing manholes, or other previously constructed entrances that may be utilized without cutting or penetrating any pavement or other street improvement. 
Facilities means any and all of the wires, cables, fibers, duct spaces, manholes, poles, conduits, underground and overhead passageways, other equipment, structures, plant and appurtenances, monitoring well and its associated apparatus designed and constructed to measure or monitor the quality or movement of foreign substances, elements, chemicals, fluids, or pollutants below the surface of the ground; or any mechanical device, method, or apparatus designed and constructed to obtain a sample soil core boring from a depth of greater than one (1) foot below the surface of the ground, for the purpose of removing soil for environmental quality or geotechnical testing and all associated physical equipment placed in, on or under the public rights-of-way. 
Hazardous substance shall mean any hazardous, toxic, or dangerous substance, material, waste, pollutant, or contaminant. The term shall specifically include natural gas, petroleum and petroleum products and their bi-products, residue, and remainder in whatever form or state. The term shall also be interpreted to include any substance which, after release into the environment, will or may reasonably be anticipated to cause death, disease, injury, sickness, illness, behavior abnormalities or, genetic abnormalities. 
Maintenance means non-emergency repairs of a facility located in the right-of-way without causing any damage to the surface of pavement and no more than one (1) foot of excavation of unpaved areas and no more than three (3) hours during any non-peak traffic period. 
Network provider means the same as defined in Tex. Loc. Gov't Code § 284.002(13) [either (A) a wireless service provider; or (B) a person that does not provide wireless services and that is not an electric utility but builds or installs on behalf of a wireless service provider: (i) network nodes; or (ii) node support poles or any other structure that supports or is capable of supporting a network node]. 
Peak traffic periods means 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. on weekdays. 
Permit means a current and valid authorization issued under Section 4 of this article and as defined in Tex. Loc. Gov't Code § 284.002(15) [a written authorization for the use of the public right-of-way or collocation on a service pole required from a municipality before a network provider may perform an action or initiate, continue, or complete a project over which the municipality has police power authority]. 
Permittee means a person who holds a permit: the singular term includes the plural if two (2) or more persons jointly hold the permit, where applicable. 
Person means a natural Person (an individual), corporation, company, association, partnership, firm, limited liability company, joint venture, joint stock company or association, and other such entity. 
Public rights-of-way means the same as defined in Tex. Loc. Gov't Code §§ 283.002(6) and 284.002(18) and Texas Utilities Code, § 66.002 (8) [the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, public sidewalk, alley, waterway, or utility easement in which the municipality has an interest.] The term does not include the airwaves above a public right-of-way with regard to wireless telecommunications. The term does not include city property or a private easement. 
Public street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way which is held by the city in fee or by easement or dedication when any part thereof has been accepted by the city, or has been opened to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel; the term "public street" shall include any designated state or federal highway or road or any designated county road which is under the administrative control of the City for maintenance, repair, or vehicular traffic control purposes. 
Roadway means that portion of a public street which is improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the curb, berm, or shoulder. In the event that a public street includes two (2) or more separate roadways, "roadway" means each such roadway separately. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a public street which is between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines and is improved and designed for, or is ordinarily used for, pedestrian travel. 
Transportation improvement means the portion of work within the finished paved surface of a public right-of-way undertaken by or pursuant to contract for the state or a political subdivision of the state for the purpose of improving or maintaining public right-of-way transportation and related storm drainage and street lighting infrastructure, but does not include any activity, such as connection to other facilities, that cuts, penetrates, or bores under a public right-of-way after installation of new paving. 
Utility means the city or any other person, whether franchised as a public utility or not, who is lawfully authorized to construct, install, or maintain any pipes for transportation of gas, liquids, or other materials, or any electrical distribution system, or any telephone or intelligence distribution systems, or any cable television transmission system, in, on, under or over a public street. 
(Ord. No. 09-062, § 3, 3-17-09; Ord. No. 17-116, § 1(Exh. A), 8-15-17)  
Sec. 32-96. - Municipal authorization required. 
(a)  (1)  Any person seeking to place facilities on, in or over the public rights-of-way, shall pay a five hundred dollars ($500.00) construction permit application fee (except CTPs and CVSPs and their contractors to the extent exempted by Tex. Loc. Gov't Code, Chapter 283, and Texas Utilities Code, Chapter 66, respectively, or network providers to the extent limited by Tex. Loc. Gov't Code Chapter 284) and shall file an application for such construction permit with the director and shall abide by the terms and provisions of this article pertaining to use of the public rights-of-way and with an applicable design manual adopted by the city. If there are additional direct costs to the city in processing the applications, the city may recover those from the applicant prior to the issuance of the construction permit. Persons exempt from obtaining a permit are not exempt from providing evidence of compliance with applicable city ordinances and regulations and providing timely, advance reasonable notice to the city of construction activities in the public rights-of-way in a form as reasonably determined by the city, provided that such reasonable notice to the city shall require substantially similar information as would be provided by applicants for construction permits in the public rights-of-way. 
(2)  With such application, applicants shall submit to director of the department of public works written applications for such permits identifying the applicant and all of the applicant's affiliates that may have physical control of facilities within the public rights-of-way, with a map of the proposed installations, general description of the services to be provided, a construction schedule, and a general description of the effect on public rights-of-way as detailed in subsection (h) below. 
(b)  Any person, except a CTP, CVSP, or network provider prior to placing, reconstructing, or altering facilities in, on or over the public rights-of-way, must obtain separate municipal authorization from the city, such as a license agreement or franchise, as may be applicable. 
(c)  Any person with an unexpired franchise agreement or other unexpired person specific authorization from the city ("grant") to use the public rights-of-way for fixed and certain specific time that is still in effect at the time this article is adopted shall continue to operate under and comply with that grant (except to the extent the police power regulations in such grant are inconsistent with this article, in which event, this article will control, as determined until the grant expires or until it is terminated in accordance with its terms or by mutual agreement of the city and the person, or is terminated as otherwise provided for in law). 
(d)  Prerequisites to issuance of construction permit - each person must register with the city. In order for the city to have a record of the persons owning and having control over the facilities and excavation and boring activities in the public rights-of-way within the city, each such person must register with the city. Registration form can be obtained from the public works department or the city's web site. 
(e)  Provisions of this subsection (e) do not apply to any person with a franchise agreement, CTPs and CVSPs, or network providers. The requirement to obtain a permit or permits applicable to a network provider is as prescribed in Tex. Loc. Gov't Code §§ 284.152 and 284.156. A separate permit is required for each facility. Upon registration of existing facilities as required by this Chapter, permits for the facilities will be issued to the owners at no cost (first time only) with expiration date of one year from the effective date of this chapter of the ordinance. An annual fee will be charged for renewal of permits. Any person seeking to place facilities on, in or over the public rights-of-way after the effective date of this chapter, shall pay construction permit fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and upon completion of construction a permit (renewable annually) will be issued at no charge for the first time. A permit renewal fee will be charged annually, thereafter. Annual permit renewal fee shall be calculated based upon the following fee structure: 
Facilities with a minimum of four (4) feet horizontal and two (2) feet vertical distance from city's utilities and up to seven (7) feet deep shall be charged five hundred dollars ($500.00) for up to one hundred (100) feet of length and $0.10/foot for each additional foot of length. 
Facilities with less than minimum distance from city's utilities as given above or more than seven (7) feet deep shall be charged $700.00 for up to 100 feet of length and $0.15/foot for each additional foot of length. 
In addition to assessment of penalties per section 32-98 of this chapter, failure to renew a registration may result in the (city) restricting the issuance of additional permits until the facility owner has complied with the registration requirements of this article. 
(f)  Except CTPs and CVSPs, no transfers, sales or assignments can be made without written consent of the city. If a person is granted permission to transfer, sell or assigns its assets, in part or all, located in public rights-of-way incident to a transfer, sale or assignment of the person's assets, the transferee, buyer or assignee shall be obligated to comply with the terms of this article. 
(g)  A permit for any excavation shall be obtained by the owner of the facility. If the owner of a facility will not be making the excavation with its own personnel, then the contractor retained to perform the work shall join with the owner as an applicant in obtaining the permit. Where two or more related excavations are being performed as part of the same project, the application and permit may cover the related work, consistent with the requirements of this chapter. 
(h)  Applications for permits and registration of facilities located within rights-of-ways shall be signed before a Texas Notary Public, notarized and submitted to the Director. The application shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, assumed name, or business name, business type (corporation, partnership, individual/sole proprietor or other) of each applicant; 
(2)  Each applicant's mailing address (and street address if different), telephone number, facsimile number, and e-mail address; 
(3)  The location, depth, length, and width of each excavation to be made in each block and/or intersection, which may alternatively be set forth on the provided drawings and specifications; 
(4)  The purpose of the excavation, including a description of the facilities to be installed, maintained and/or repaired; 
(5)  The method of excavation; 
(6)  The proposed excavation start date and duration; 
(7)  A statement that each person executing the application is fully authorized to act on the behalf of and bind his principal in executing and filing the application; 
(8)  A statement that each applicant accepts and obligates itself to the following indemnification provisions: 
INDEMNIFICATION 
PERMITTEE AGREES TO INDEMNIFY THE CITY PER THIS ORDINANCE SECTION 14 WHICH PROVIDES: 
(A)  EXCEPT AS TO CTPS, CVSPS, AND NETWORK PROVIDERS, EACH PERSON PLACING FACILITIES IN THE PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY SHALL INDEMNIFY AND HOLD THE CITY AND ITS OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES HARMLESS AGAINST ANY AND ALL CLAIMS, LAWSUITS, JUDGMENTS, COSTS, LIENS, LOSSES, EXPENSES, FEES (INCLUDING REASONABLE ATTORNEY'S FEES AND COSTS OF DEFENSE, WHICH EXPENSES SHALL INCLUDE THE REASONABLE VALUE OF ANY SERVICES RENDERED BY ANY EMPLOYEES OF the CITY), PROCEEDINGS, ACTIONS, DEMANDS, CAUSES OF ACTION, LIABILITY, AND SUITS OF ANY KIND AND NATURE, INCLUDING PERSONAL OR BODILY INJURY (INCLUDING DEATH), PROPERTY DAMAGE, OR OTHER HARM FOR WHICH RECOVERY OF DAMAGES IS SOUGHT THAT IS FOUND BY A COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDICTION TO BE CAUSED SOLELY BY THE NEGLIGENT ACT, ERROR, OR OMISSION OF THE PERSON, ANY AGENT, OFFICER, DIRECTOR, REPRESENTATIVE, EMPLOYEE, AFFILIATE, OR SUBCONTRACTOR OF THE PERSON, OR THEIR RESPECTIVE OFFICERS, AGENTS, EMPLOYEES, DIRECTORS, OR REPRESENTATIVES, WHILE INSTALLING, REPAIRING, OR MAINTAINING FACILITIES IN THE PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY. 
(B)  THE INDEMNITY PROVIDED BY THIS SECTION DOES NOT APPLY TO ANY LIABILITY RESULTING FROM THE NEGLIGENCE OF THE CITY, ITS OFFICERS, EMPLOYEES, CONTRACTORS, OR SUBCONTRACTORS. IF A PERSON AND THE CITY ARE FOUND JOINTLY LIABLE BY A COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDICTION, LIABILITY SHALL BE APPORTIONED COMPARATIVELY IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE LAWS OF THIS STATE WITHOUT, HOWEVER, WAIVING ANY GOVERNMENTAL IMMUNITY AVAILABLE TO THE CITY UNDER STATE LAW OR THE CITY CHARTER AND WITHOUT WAIVING ANY DEFENSES OF THE PARTIES UNDER STATE LAW OR THE CITY CHARTER. 
(C)  A PERSON OR CITY SHALL PROMPTLY ADVISE THE OTHER IN WRITING OF ANY KNOWN CLAIM OR DEMAND AGAINST THE PERSON OR THE CITY RELATED TO OR ARISING OUT OF THE PERSON'S ACTIVITIES IN THE PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY. THE PERSON SHALL PROMPTLY PROVIDE A DEFENSE TO ANY SUCH CLAIM, DEMAND, SUIT OR SUITS, INCLUDING ANY APPELLATE PROCEEDINGS BROUGHT IN CONNECTION THEREWITH. 
(D)  THE PROVISIONS OF THIS INDEMNITY SECTION ARE SOLELY FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE CITY AND ARE NOT INTENDED TO CREATE OR GRANT ANY RIGHTS, CONTRACTUAL OR OTHERWISE, TO ANY OTHER PERSON OR ENTITY. 
(E)  UPON FAILURE OF THE PERSON TO COMPLY WITH THE PROVISIONS OF THIS ORDINANCE, AFTER REASONABLE NOTICE BY THE CITY, THE CITY SHALL HAVE THE RIGHT TO DEFEND THE SAME AND IN ADDITION TO BEING REIMBURSED FOR ANY SUCH JUDGMENT THAT MAY BE RENDERED AGAINST THE CITY, TOGETHER WITH ALL COURT COSTS INCURRED THEREIN, THE PERSON SHALL PROMPTLY REIMBURSE THE CITY FOR ATTORNEY'S FEES, INCLUDING THOSE EMPLOYED BY THE CITY IN SUCH CASE OR CASES, AS WELL AS ALL EXPENSES INCURRED BY THE CITY BY REASON OF UNDERTAKING THE DEFENSE OF SUCH SUIT OR SUITS, WHETHER SUCH SUIT OR SUITS ARE SUCCESSFULLY DEFENDED, SETTLED, COMPROMISED, OR FULLY ADJUDICATED AGAINST THE CITY. 
(F)  IN THE EVENT THE CITY IS COMPELLED TO UNDERTAKE THE DEFENSE OF ANY SUCH SUIT BY REASON OF A PERSON'S FAILURE TO PERFORM AS HEREINABOVE PROVIDED, THE CITY SHALL HAVE FULL RIGHT AND AUTHORITY TO MAKE OR ENTER INTO ANY SETTLEMENT OR COMPROMISE OF SUCH ADJUDICATION AS THE CITY COUNCIL SHALL DEEM IN THE BEST INTEREST OF THE CITY, THIS WITHOUT THE PRIOR APPROVAL OR CONSENT OF THE PERSON WITH RESPECT TO THE TERMS OF SUCH COMPROMISE OR SETTLEMENT. 
WHERE APPLICABLE, THE PROVISIONS OF SECTIONS 283.057 AND 284.302 OF THE TEXAS LOCAL GOVERNMENT CODE OR SECTION 66.012 OF THE TEXAS UTILITIES CODE SHALL CONTROL IN LIEU OF THE FOREGOING; ADDITIONALLY, TO THE EXTENT THAT THE APPLICANT HOLDS A CURRENT AND VALID UTILITY FRANCHISE FROM THE CITY, THE INDEMNIFICATION PROVISIONS OF THE FRANCHISE SHALL CONTROL IN LIEU OF THE FOREGOING." 
a.  The name of the owner of the facility; 
b.  The twenty-four-hour telephone number at which each applicant's representative who will respond to emergencies may be contacted; 
c.  The name, mailing address, telephone number, facsimile number, and e-mail address of a person who is authorized to receive all notices authorized to be given by the city under this chapter to each applicant; 
d.  Confirmation that all materials necessary for construction will be on hand and ready for use so as not to delay the excavation; 
d.  A transmittal number issued by the Texas Underground Facility Notification Corporation evidencing that the applicant has complied with the Texas Underground Facility Damage Prevention and Safety Act or an assurance that the transmittal number will be provided to the director before the excavation commences; 
f.  Evidence of insurance as required in section 32-104 of this chapter; 
g.  Drawings and specifications, as provided in subsection 32-99(d) of this chapter; and 
h.  The work warranty as required by the subsection 32-99(g) of this chapter; 
i.  An application for a permit for an excavation performed pursuant to subsection 32-99(k) of this chapter shall, in addition to the items required above, also include a written statement: 
1.  Explaining the basis for the emergency actions; 
2.  Describing the excavation being performed; 
3.  Describing any work remaining to be performed in the public right-of-way; and 
4.  Stating the time and date when the emergency occurred. 
(i)  It is unlawful to place a steel plate at an excavation without a permit. The director may authorize as a condition of a permit the use of a steel plate as a temporary surface for an excavation. Any such permit shall specify the length of the time the steel plate is allowed to remain in the public right-of-way. It shall be unlawful for any permittee or former permittee to maintain or cause to be maintained a steel plate in the public right-of-way after the time specified in the permit for the excavation at which the steel plate is located. Each steel plate shall be clearly marked with the name of the owner of the steel plate, and a permittee's failure to use a steel plate so marked shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(j)  It is unlawful to close a lane(s) of a public street without a permit issued by the director. Any such permit shall specify the date(s) and length of the time of the lane closure. Failure to comply with this provision shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 09-062, § 4, 3-17-09; Ord. No. 17-116, § 1(Exh. A), 8-15-17)  
Sec. 32-97. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  The director, police, fire and other appropriate agencies shall administer and enforce compliance with this article. Failure to comply with the provisions of this ordinance will result in enforcement action per section 32-98 of this chapter. 
(b)  A person shall report information related to the use of the public rights-of-way that the director requires in the form and manner reasonably prescribed by the director. 
(c)  The director shall report to the city council upon the determination that a person has failed to comply with this chapter. 
(d)  In addition to other persons, the provisions of this chapter are applicable to excavations made by or on behalf of other governmental entities and subdivisions, to the extent of the city's police power jurisdiction. The provisions of this chapter are not applicable to the city and its contractors. 
(e)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to give any person or permittee any property right in or to the use of the public rights-of-way. All permits issued and held under this chapter shall be subject to the superior right of the public to control the use of the public rights-of-way and ensure the safe and orderly movement of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 09-062, § 5, 3-17-09; Ord. No. 17-116, § 1(Exh. A), 8-15-17)  
Sec. 32-98. - Penalties. 
Any person convicted for a violation of any provision, restriction, requirement or prohibition of chapter 32, for which no specific penalty is provided, shall be fined in a sum of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). A separate offence shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 09-062, § 6, 3-17-09; Ord. No. 17-116, § 1(Exh. A), 8-15-17)  
Sec. 32-99. - Construction obligations. 
A person is subject to reasonable police power regulation of the city to manage its public rights-of-way in connection with the excavation, construction, installation, expansion, reconstruction, relocation, alteration, removal, maintenance or repair of facilities in the public rights-of-way, pursuant to the city's rights as a custodian of public property based upon the city's historic rights under state and federal laws. Such regulations include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(a)  At the city's request, a person shall furnish the city accurate and complete information relating to the excavation, construction, installation, expansion, reconstruction, relocation, alteration, removal, maintenance or repair of facilities performed by the person in the public rights-of-way. 
(b)  A person may be required to place certain facilities within the public rights-of-way underground according to applicable city requirements, in accordance with the city's design manual, and consistent with the requirements applicable to a designated historic district or design district, unless the person makes a compelling demonstration that, in any specific instance, this requirement is not reasonable, feasible or equally applicable to other similar users of the public rights-of-way. 
(1)  The undergrounding of facilities is encouraged. In any event, facilities shall be installed underground where existing utilities are already underground. A minimum of four (4) feet of horizontal and (2) feet of vertical distance shall be maintained between the City of Pasadena utilities and facilities and if this distance cannot be maintained, a request for variance can be submitted to the director. A variance will be considered if it will not adversely effect public safety or cause the city to incur excessive maintenance costs. The utility owning the underground facilities shall make a reasonable determination as to whether space is available to accommodate the new facilities. A negative determination shall not relieve the person of the responsibility to underground its facilities in underground utility areas. To the degree reasonably feasible previously installed aerial facilities shall be placed underground in concert, and on a cost-sharing basis, with other utilities when such other utilities convert from aerial to underground construction. 
(2)  Underground conduits and ducts shall be installed in the public rights-of-way between the adjacent property line and the curb line unless otherwise directed by the city. 
(3)  Conduits and ducts shall be installed parallel with the curb line and cross the public rights-of-way perpendicular to the public rights-of-way centerline unless otherwise directed by the city. 
(4)  Ducts and conduits shall be installed by trenchless excavation or directional boring when placing these facilities under paved public rights-of-way or a driveway crossing to avoid motor vehicle interruptions, unless otherwise directed by the city. 
(c)  A person shall perform excavations and other construction in the public rights-of-way in accordance with all applicable city requirements, including the obligation to use trenchless technology whenever commercially economical and practical and consistent with obligations on other similar users of the public right-of-way. The city shall waive the requirement of trenchless technology if it determines that, based upon information provided to the city by the person, the particular field conditions such as known or unknown or unknown underground conditions that may necessitate open cut warrant a waiver. All excavations and other construction in the public rights-of-way shall be conducted so as to minimize interference with the use of public and private property. Any plant or facility placed within the public rights-of-way which is suspended in any manner above ground shall either be placed on existing poles or equipment or be suspended at a height not less than twenty-two (22) feet above ground level, unless otherwise approved by the director, but in no event less than fifteen (15) feet, except to the extent state law controls. A person shall follow all reasonable construction directions given by the city in order to minimize any such interference. 
(d)  (1)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (d)(3) below, a person must obtain a permit, as reasonably required by applicable city codes, including section 39-93 (requiring a permit from the traffic and transportation department), seventy-two (72) hours prior to any excavation, construction, installation, expansion, reconstruction, relocation, alteration, removal, maintenance or repair of the person's facilities, which seventy-two (72) hours may be waived or altered by the city for good cause shown by the applicant. All permit applications shall be accompanied by the certification of a professional engineer licensed in Texas that the drawings, plans and specifications submitted with the application comply with applicable technical codes, rules and regulations when required by state law. A Person shall submit a traffic control plan signed and sealed by a professional engineer licensed in the state of Texas at the director's discretion based upon traffic density, duration for street closure and public safety. 
(2)  Bonding will be required as in subsection 32-99(m) below, and insurance as in section 32-104. 
(3)  A construction permit is not required for routine maintenance that does not require excavation of the public rights-of-way or which does not block traffic lanes or sidewalks during peak traffic periods between 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. on weekdays, or for more than three hours during any non-peak traffic period. The failure of the person to request and obtain a permit from the city prior to performing any of the above listed activities in, on or over any public right-of-way, except in an emergency as provided for in subsection 32-99(j) below, will subject the person to a stop-work order from the city and enforcement action pursuant to the city's Code of Ordinances. If the person fails to act upon any permit within one hundred twenty (120) calendar days of issuance, the permit shall become invalid unless extended by the city upon a showing of good cause. Upon expiration of a permit, a person shall be required to obtain another permit pursuant to the requirements of this article. 
(4)  A person shall furnish the director with construction plans, specifications and maps using the standard format adopted by the department of public works including the location and proposed routing of new construction or reconstruction at least three (3) business days before beginning construction or reconstruction that involves an alteration to the surface or subsurface of the public rights-of-way, unless otherwise approved by the director. A person may not begin construction until the location of new facilities and proposed routing of the new construction or reconstruction and all required plans and specifications have been approved in writing by the city, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld, taking due consideration of the surrounding area and alternative locations for the facilities and routing. 
(5)  These construction plans shall show all features within the public rights-of-way that would affect the placement of the proposed facilities such as, but not limited to, existing underground and aerial wires or conduits, ducts, poles, wires, pipes, sewer, water lines, and cables as well as their ownership; traffic signal and street light poles; fire hydrants; driveways; curbs, inlets and drains; sidewalks, wheelchair ramps; and trees and large shrubs. Drawings shall be drawn to an appropriate scale of no larger than one (1) inch equals fifty (50) feet using the standard format adopted by the public works department. State plan coordinates shall be shown for benchmarks, curb lines, and structures. Drawings shall show horizontal dimensions from the curb line and elevations. If typicals are used, they shall reference the station numbers for which they are to be applied. Traffic control plans shall be in conformance with the latest revision of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(6)  A person shall use its best efforts to coordinate joint trenching with any other persons and/or public utilities which may be constructed in and along the same public-rights-of-way in a time frame reasonably similar to the persons construction time table. The department of public works may mandate such coordination to the fullest extent allowed by law. 
(7)  To the extent known, plans for ongoing repair, maintenance, and improvements which involve cutting into paved city roads or streets shall be submitted to the department of public works on an annual basis, no later than April 1 of each year, and updated based upon any changes. This does not require any proprietary information, such as equipment or customer specific information. Such information may be designated confidential, and to the extent allowed by law, will be kept confidential by the city. Alternatively, a person may meet with the appropriate representative of public works each calendar quarter to provide such plans to the extent known. 
(8)  Once all required permits are issued, the departments of public works and the department of traffic and transportation shall be notified in writing or via e-mail or facsimile at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance that construction in the public rights-of-way is ready to proceed by a person or its representative. Information signs (at least 3 ft. × 3 ft. in size) stating the identity of the person doing the work, their telephone number, shall be placed at the location where construction is to occur forty-eight (48) hours prior to the beginning of work in the public rights-of-way and shall continue to be posted at the location during the entire time the work is occurring and/or until permanent repairs are completed. 
(9)  Person owning a gas line, high pressure hazardous material, petroleum pipeline or facilities shall provide the area residents and businesses located within one-half (½) mile area at least ten (10) calendar days written notice prior to start of any construction and/or maintenance, or other substantial activity. A Pasadena Police Officer is required to be present during the time of construction and/or maintenance. This requirement does not apply to emergencies, routine inspections and maintenance, by the person, its agents, employees or contractors on person's pipeline(s), gas lines or facilities. 
(10)  Erosion control measures and advance warning signs, markers, cones, and barricades must be in place before work begins. A person may be required to show proof of engineered plans relating to stormwater and erosion when applicable or a letter stating a person is not required to provide such plans. A person shall be responsible for storm water management erosion control that complies with city, state and federal guidelines, as applicable. 
(11)  Lane closures on major thoroughfares will be limited to between 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. unless the traffic and transportation department grants prior approval. All lane closures shall comply with the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways. Arrow boards will be required on lane closures with all barricades, advance warning signs, and thirty-six (36) inches reflector cones placed according to the specifications of the city.
