State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate traffic by means of traffic-control devices and signals, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, §§ 27(a)(2), 31. 
 
Sec. 36-87. - Conformity with manual and specifications of state highway department; uniformity. 
All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved and adopted by the state highway department. 
All signs and signals required under this chapter for a particular purpose shall, so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic-control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic-control devices. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-66, 28-67), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 31.  
Sec. 36-88. - General powers and duties of traffic and transportation director relative to devices. 
(a)  The traffic and transportation director shall place and maintain traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of such chapter and ordinances, and he may place and maintain such additional traffic-control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic thereunder or under state law or to guide or warn traffic. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the traffic and transportation director to determine the proper timing of traffic-control devices, and he may test traffic-control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-15, 28-16, 28-65), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 80-79, § 3, 4-22-80) 
Cross reference— General authority of director of traffic and transportation, § 2-136.  
Sec. 36-89. - Marking of traffic lanes. 
The traffic and transportation director is hereby authorized to mark or make traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-78), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 80-79, § 3, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 36-90. - Warrant of permanency for devices initially installed on temporary or emergency basis. 
In the event the traffic and transportation director has, in the first instance, instituted a temporary or experimental traffic-control device, sign, signal, mark, marking or marker, or combination thereof, as authorized by section 2-137, and within ninety (90) days thereafter determines that such should be permanent, he shall file a writing captioned "WARRANT OF PERMANENCY" as to the same prior to the expiration of such ninety (90) day period, reciting that the same is made permanent and stating the effective date for the commencement of such permanency. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-17), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 80-79, § 3, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 36-91. - Presumptions as to devices. 
(a)  Whenever official traffic-control devices are placed in position substantially conforming to the requirements of this chapter, such devices shall be presumed to have been so placed by the official act or direction of lawful authority, unless the contrary shall be established by competent evidence. 
(b)  Any official traffic-control device placed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and purporting to conform to the lawful requirements pertaining to such devices shall be presumed to comply with the requirements of this chapter, unless the contrary shall be established by competent evidence. 
(c)  As to any given traffic-control device, signal, sign, marker or marking, it shall be initially presumed that such device, signal, sign, marker or marking independently erected by the traffic and transportation director has been installed pursuant to his observations and studies, based on generally used, accepted traffic-control principles and techniques. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-19, 28-70), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 80-79, § 3, 4-22-80)  
Sec. 36-92. - Obedience to devices. 
The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-69), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 32.  
Sec. 36-93. - Permit required to work within city right-of-way. 
Anytime a contractor performs any work within the street right-of-way of the City of Pasadena, the contractor shall be required to obtain written permission from the traffic director. This permit is in addition to any other permit required by the city. All routine submissions for permits shall be received a minimum of forty-eight (48) hours in advance of beginning of the work. At no time shall the contractor begin work without obtaining the required permit. The permit shall be kept on site and shall be presented on demand at all times for review by the police, fire, public works, permit, and traffic departments' personnel. 
In the event of an emergency, the contractor may take immediate action to correct the situation but shall also immediately and personally contact the office of the traffic and transportation department to make application for a permit. If the emergency occurs after normal working hours and the traffic and transportation department is closed, the contractor shall immediately contact the emergency dispatcher and make application for a permit in the morning of the next normal working day. 
When applying for the permit, the contractor or contractors' designated representative shall be required to submit all pertinent information including but not limited to the number of days required to complete the work, the times of day, area of work (including street names, block numbers, direction of travel affected), and reason for working in the city right-of-way. 
Depending of the complexity of the work, the traffic director or his designated representative may require plans to be submitted by a licensed traffic engineer and bear the appropriate seal, signature, and date of preparation. In all cases, the contractor, as a minimum, shall be required to install any and all signs and pavement markings required by the latest revision of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. Flagmen or other means of traffic control may be required upon the determination of the traffic director. 
In the interest of increasing public safety and reducing delay and inconvenience, no lane closures shall be allowed during the morning and evening peak periods of traffic from 7 to 9 a.m. and from 4 to 6 p.m., Monday through Friday. The traffic director may grant exceptions upon specific request. 
Upon issuance of the permit, the traffic director shall notify the police and fire dispatch, police operations, and public works department of the nature and terms of the permit. 
Failure to comply with any of the provisions of this section may result in immediate termination of work within the right-of-way and revocation of any other city permit. Any police officer or representative of the traffic and transportation department, permit department, or public works department may order immediate termination of work within the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-76), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 01-53, § 1, 3-20-01)  
Sec. 36-94. - Traffic-control signal legend generally. 
Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals exhibiting the words "Go," "Caution" or "Stop," or exhibiting different colored lights successively one at a time, or with arrows, the following colors only shall be used and such terms and lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(a)  Green alone or "Go": 
(1)  Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. But vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited; 
(2)  Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(b)  Yellow alone or "Caution" when following the green or "Go" signal: 
(1)  Vehicular traffic facing the signal is thereby warned that the red or "Stop" signal will be exhibited immediately thereafter and such vehicular traffic shall not enter or be crossing the intersection when the red or "Stop" signal is exhibited; 
(2)  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway until the green or "Go" signal is shown (unless authorized to do so by a pedestrian "Walk" signal). 
(c)  Red alone or "Stop": 
(1)  Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection and shall remain standing until green or "Go" is shown alone. 
(2)  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway until the green or "Go" is shown alone (unless authorized so to do by a pedestrian "Walk" signal). 
(d)  Red with green arrow: 
(1)  Vehicular traffic facing such signal may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow but shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
(2)  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway until the green or "Go" is shown alone (unless authorized so to do by a pedestrian "Walk" signal). 
In the event an official traffic-control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of this section shall be applicable except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of any such sign or marking the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-71), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 33.  
Sec. 36-95. - Flashing signals. 
Whenever flashing red or yellow signals are used they shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red (stop signal). When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at a limit line when marked, or if none, then before entering the intersection, and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-73), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 35.  
Sec. 36-96. - Pedestrian walk and wait signals. 
Whenever special pedestrian-control signals exhibiting words or symbols indicating that it is permissible to walk or that pedestrians should wait are in place, such signals shall indicate as follows: 
(1)  Signals indicating walking is permissible. Pedestrians facing such signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles. 
(2)  Signals indicating it is necessary to wait. No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the walk signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the wait signal is showing. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-72), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 34.  
Sec. 36-97. - Lane-direction-control signals. 
When lane-direction-control signals are placed over the individual lanes of a street or highway, vehicular traffic may travel in any lane over which a green signal is shown, but shall not enter or travel in any lane over which a red signal is shown. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-74), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-98. - Ratification of existing devices. 
All traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings heretofore placed or erected by any officer or employee of the city and now in use for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic are hereby affirmed, ratified and declared to be official traffic-control devices, provided such traffic-control devices are not inconsistent with the provisions of street law or this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-68), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-99. - Unauthorized signs, signals, etc. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic-control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic or which attempts to control parking or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal, and no person shall place or maintain nor shall any officer of the city permit upon any highway or street any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection, upon private property adjacent to streets or highways, of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
(b)  Every such prohibited sign or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and either the chief of police or the traffic director is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-75), 3-15-66) 
Cross reference— Removal of unlawful signs generally, § 31-18. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 36.  
Secs. 36-100—36-109. - Reserved.

Sec. 36-110. - Streets designated. 
The following streets or portions thereof are hereby designated as one-way streets: 
Cruse Drive, east, the 1000 block exclusive;

(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-99), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 75-113, § 1, 7-1-75; Ord. No. 88-194, § 1, 10-4-88) 
State Law reference— Authority to designate one-way streets, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 27.  
Sec. 36-111. - Signs. 
Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of this city designates any one-way street or alley, the traffic director shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-98), 3-15-66)

Sec. 36-112. - Vehicles to move only in indicated direction. 
Upon those streets and parts of streets and in those alleys designated for one-way traffic, the driver of a vehicle shall drive only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-34, 28-99), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-113. - Restriction of direction of movement during certain periods. 
(a)  The traffic director is hereby authorized to determine and designate streets, parts of streets or specific lanes thereon upon which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one direction during one period and the opposite direction during another period of the day and shall place and maintain appropriate markings, signs, barriers or other devices to give notice thereof. The traffic director may erect signs temporarily designating lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction, regardless of the center line of the roadway. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle in violation of such markings, signs, barriers or other devices so placed in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-100), 3-15-66)  
Secs. 36-114—36-123. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - TRUCK ROUTES[4]

V pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 67-2005, § 1, 8-22-67; Ord. No. 77-144, § 1, 8-2-77; Ord. No. 80-121, § 1, 7-8-80; Ord. No. 83-119, § 1, 5-10-83; Ord. Sec. 36-124. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. 
Deviating heavy truck. A "deviating heavy truck" is a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling inside the city. 
Heavy truck. The phrase "heavy truck" means any motor vehicle or towed vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR), registered gross vehicle weight rating (RGVW), or an actual weight, whichever is greater, of twenty-six thousand one (26,001) pounds or more; or any combination of vehicles where the gross combined weight rating (GCWR), total registered gross vehicle weight (RGVW), or the actual weight of the combination is twenty-six thousand one (26,001) pounds or more. 
Shall. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
Truck route. The term "truck route" means a way over certain streets, as designated in this article, over and along which all heavy trucks coming into and going out of the city must operate. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05; Ord. No. 08-156, § 2, 7-15-08)

(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating a heavy truck as defined herein to travel on any street except as designated as established truck routes. The following are hereby established as truck routes within the City of Pasadena:

(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05; Ord. No. 09-129, § 2, 6-16-09)  
Sec. 36-126. - Required use generally; exceptions. 
(a)  All heavy trucks within the city shall be operated only over and along established truck routes, except as otherwise specifically provided. The operator of such truck shall keep a log book, delivery slip or other evidence of his destination and point of origin. 
(b)  This article shall not prohibit: 
(1)  The operation of heavy trucks upon any street where necessary to the conduct of a commercial enterprise ("in commerce") at a destination point, provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. 
(2)  The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city. 
(3)  The operation of heavy trucks owned or operated by the city, public utilities, any contractor or materialman while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements, or street utilities within the city. 
(4)  The operation of heavy trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 36-127. - Use by trucks originating outside city. 
(a)  All heavy trucks entering the city with a destination point within the city shall use a route that minimizes use of city and/or county roadways by entering via state maintained roadways, SH 225, BW 8 and/or SH 146, and not departing from these roadways until the state maintained roadway intersects the designated truck route providing the closest access to the destination; proceeding on the designated truck route, deviating only at major thoroughfare intersections in closest proximity to the destination point. Departing from the destination point, all heavy trucks shall return to the state maintained roadway by the shortest route via the designated truck route to the state maintained highway. 
(b)  All heavy trucks traveling through the city shall only use state maintained roadways, i.e. Pasadena Freeway, East Sam Houston South Parkway, and State Highway 146. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05; Ord. No. 08-156, § 3, 7-15-08; Ord. No. 09-129, § 3, 6-16-09)  
Sec. 36-128. - Use by trucks originating inside city. 
(a)  All heavy trucks with a destination point outside the city shall proceed from their point of origin to a major thoroughfare by the shortest route to a designated truck route proceeding to the state maintained roadway. 
(b)  All intra-city heavy trucks shall proceed from their point of origin to a major thoroughfare by the shortest route and then proceed to an established truck route by the shortest route and only depart at the intersection of a major thoroughfare and not leave the major thoroughfare system until the intersection nearest to the destination point. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05; Ord. No. 08-156, § 4, 7-15-08; Ord. No. 09-129, § 4, 6-16-09)  
Sec. 36-129. - Maps to be kept. 
The traffic director shall keep and maintain maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which heavy truck traffic is permitted. Copies of the maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city secretary and shall be available to the public. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 36-130. - Signs required. 
The traffic director shall cause all truck routes to be signposted to give notice that this article is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 36-131. - Deed restrictions. 
Nothing contained in this Code of Ordinances generally or this chapter specifically shall be construed to allow the violation of any residential deed restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 36-132. - Weight limits on specific streets. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall operate any vehicle with a gross weight in excess of the amounts specified on such signs at any time upon any of the streets or parts of streets so signed. Under this section, as vehicle weight is indicated by the number of axles supporting such vehicles, signs limiting the number of axles on through vehicles shall be official. 
(Ord. No. 05-170, § 2, 7-5-05)  
Secs. 36-133—36-135. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V½. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS ROUTES 
 
Sec. 36-136. - Definitions. 
The following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section when used in this article: 
Hazardous material. "Hazardous material" includes any type of material designated as hazardous under Title 49, U.S.C. Sections 1802(2) and 1803 and under Art. 6701d, Section 139, V.T.C.S., and any of the following types of materials: 
(1)  Compressed gas: Any material with a gauge pressure exceeding forty (40) pounds per square inch at seventy (70) degrees Fahrenheit, or any flammable material having a Reid vapor pressure exceeding forty (40) pounds per square inch absolute at one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(2)  Corrosive material: Any material which may cause severe damage to living tissue or to freight by chemical action when in contact therewith, or which may cause fire when in contact with organic matter or certain chemicals. 
(3)  Explosive material: Any material, the primary or common purpose of which is to function by explosion. 
(4)  Flammable material: Any material which is subject to ignition through friction, sparks, absorption of moisture, spontaneous chemical changes, or retained heat from the manufacturing, processing, or transporting the material. 
(5)  Oxidizing material: Any material that yields oxygen readily to stimulate the combustion of organic matter. 
(6)  Poisonous material: Any material that may cause irritation or damage to living tissue through mixture with air, external contact, contamination of food, water, or feeds, or emission of radiation. 
Hazardous material route. The term "hazardous material route" shall mean those routes designated by this Article. 
Shall. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
Truck. For the purposes of this Article every motor vehicle designed, used, or maintained primarily for the transportation of property and every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-137. - Intent and scope. 
It is the intent and purpose of this article to safeguard life, health and property from the hazards of fire, explosion or other emergencies and dangers arising from the transportation of hazardous materials in and through the city. 
This article shall apply to all hazardous materials which are transported into, through and out of the city and shall be in addition to all other provisions of this Code regarding hazardous substances or materials or the rules or regulations of any city department, board or commission pertaining thereto. For the purpose of this article, a point of origin or destination, including loading docks or terminals where hazardous cargos are handled, within the area bounded by the corporate limits of the city shall be considered to be a point of origin or destination within the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-138. - Authorized traffic routes. 
The movement of hazardous materials within the city shall occur only on the following designated routes, as shown below, and shall not deviate therefrom except as provided by this article. 
Street 	From 	To 
Beltway 8 	North city limits 	South city limits 
State Highway 225 	East city limits 	West side of Shaver Street 
West State Highway 225 	West side of Shaver Street 	West city limits 
 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-138.1. - Departure from routes; access to restricted areas. 
The operator of any truck restricted to hazardous materials routes set forth under this article may depart from such routes only under the following conditions: 
(1)  Such departure is necessary to reach a terminal or to load or unload materials at a location situated off of the applicable route; 
(2)  Such departure follows the shortest practical route consistent with the reasonable operation of the vehicle; and, 
(3)  The operator of such truck keeps in his possession a log book, delivery slip or other evidence of his destination and point of origin. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-138.2. - Truck route signs. 
Appropriate signs and markings shall be erected and maintained by the city traffic and transportation department advising the operators of vehicles of designated hazardous materials routes within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-139. - Alternate hazardous materials routes. 
When a street designated as a hazardous material route is under repair or otherwise temporarily out of use, the city traffic engineer is authorized to designate alternate hazardous materials routes. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-140. - Penalty. 
Unless otherwise permitted by this article, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to transport hazardous materials within or through the city on any road or highway not designated as a hazardous materials route in this article. An offense under this section is a Class "C" misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-141. - Conflicts. 
All city ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith, are hereby repealed. 
If any portion of this ordinance is held unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions hereof shall nevertheless be valid, the same as if the portion or portions held unconstitutional had not been adopted. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-141.1. - Publication. 
The city secretary shall publish the caption or a descriptive title of this ordinance one time within twenty (20) days after final passage of the ordinance in the official city newspaper of the City of Pasadena in accordance with Article II, Section 15 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
Sec. 36-141.2. - Effective date. 
The provisions of this ordinance shall become effective ten (10) days after publication. 
(Ord. No. 90-69, § 1, 4-10-90)  
ARTICLE VI. - SPEED REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 36-142. - Maximum limits generally. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a motor vehicle within the city at a rate of speed greater than thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no person shall drive a motor vehicle on any street or highway in the city at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing, having regard to the actual and potential hazards when approaching or crossing an intersection or a railway grade crossing, when approaching or going around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon a narrow or winding street or highway, or when a special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or street conditions. In every event, speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street or highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-80), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Speed of vehicles in cities and towns and authority of local authorities to alter prima facie speed limits established by state law, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, §§ 166, 169.  
Sec. 36-143. - Finding with regard to maximum limits prescribed by article. 
The city council finds, upon traffic and engineering studies and having regard to all other elements and factors required by law, including, but not limited to, the widths and conditions of pavements and other circumstances, as well as the usual traffic thereon, that the maximum rates of speed as prescribed in this article are the maximum, reasonable and prudent, safe prima facie speeds for motor vehicles operating as described herein. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1, (28-80—28-82, 28-84—28-88), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 1822, §§ 1, 2, 6-21-66; Ord. No. 1841, § 1, 8-2-66; Ord. No. 1850, § 1, 8-23-66; Ord. No. 6-1938, § 1, 5-7-67; Ord. No. 67-2019, § 1, 9-5-67)  
Sec. 36-144. - Maximum limits in school zones. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour in any of the school zones designated in Table 1. The speed limit established in this section shall be in effect between 6:45 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and between 2:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m., each and every school day, Monday through Friday, of each and every week from the first day of the school term, through the last day of the school term of each and every school year, when the school zone to which such limit applies is properly signed or posted as a school zone. Timed flashing lights, as well as fixed signs, may be used to sign or post a school zone.

Sec. 36-145. - Maximum limits in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle on any street or road within a city park at a rate of speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-81), 3-15-66) 
Cross reference— General provisions relative to operation of vehicles in parks, § 24-6 et seq.  
Sec. 36-145.1. - Twenty-five m.p.h. zones. 
The following streets or portions thereof shall constitute special speed zones, and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour in any such zone. 
(1)  On Shirleen Drive from its intersection with NASA Road 1 to its intersection with Lakeview. 
(2)  On Lakeview from its intersection with NASA Road 1 to its intersection with Shirleen Drive. 
(3)  On Denton Street from its intersection with NASA Road 1 to its intersection with Shirleen Drive. 
(4)  On Wildwood Drive from its intersection with Denton Street to its intersection with Shirleen Drive. 
(Ord. No. 96-86, § 1, 6-18-96; Ord. No. 97-188, § 1, 10-7-97; Ord. No. 98-69, § 1, 4-22-98)

Sec. 36-153. - Speed limit signs. 
The traffic director is hereby authorized and directed to post signs at both ends of special speed zones created in this article, which signs shall reflect the speed limits of the respective zones. 
(Ord. No. 72-87, § 1, 4-4-72; Ord. No. 75-111, § 1, 7-1-75)

ARTICLE VII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Stopping or parking vehicles used for transportation of flammable liquids, gas or chemicals, § 13-3; leaving motor vehicle on premises of drive-in restaurant, § 20-57; parking of mobile homes, § 21-2. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate standing and parking of vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(7). 
 
Sec. 36-163. - Unattended vehicles. 
No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine and effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-112), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 97.  
Sec. 36-164. - Prohibited in specified places. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or a traffic-control device or marking, at any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within thirty (30) feet of any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway, unless otherwise designated. 
(7)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection, unless otherwise designated. 
(8)  Between a safety zone or safety island and the adjacent curb, or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless otherwise designated. 
(9)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing, unless otherwise designated. 
(10)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within seventy-five (75) feet of such entrance (when properly sign-posted). 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street, to the end that "double parking" be hereby prohibited. 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a roadway, or within a roadway tunnel. 
(14)  In front of the entrance or exit of any theatre, hotel, inn or depot for a space of thirty (30) feet immediately in front of such theatre, hotel, inn or depot and ten (10) feet immediately in front of all other exits thereof. 
(15)  At any place where official signs or curb markings prohibit stopping, standing or parking. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-112), 3-15-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 95.  
Sec. 36-164.1. - Stopping, standing, or parking outside of business or residence districts. 
A person may not stop, park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon the main-traveled part of a highway outside of a business or residence district unless: 
(a)  It is not practicable to stop, park or so leave such vehicle off such part of said highway; 
(b)  An unobstructed width of the highway opposite a standing vehicle is left for the free passage of other vehicles; and 
(c)  A clear view of such stopped vehicle is available from a distance of two hundred (200) feet in each direction upon such highway. 
(Ord. No. 84-59, § 1, 3-27-84) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 84-59, § 1, adopted March 27, 1984, amended Ch. 36 by adding a new § 36-164½. The editor, in his discretion, and in order to preserve the numbering format of the Code, has renumbered the new § 36-164½ as § 36-164.1.  
Sec. 36-165. - Prohibited for certain purposes. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle upon any street or highway (including esplanades, medians, shoulders, etc., between the boundary lines) for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying it for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing, repairing or dismantling such vehicle, except for making such repairs necessitated by the physical impossibility of removing such vehicle until such repairs have been made. 
(3)  Advertising. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-130), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 92-124, § 1, 6-30-92)  
Sec. 36-166. - Method of parking. 
Every vehicle parked on any street in the city shall be parked parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curb-side wheels of the vehicle within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except where streets are appropriately marked for perpendicular or for angle parking, in which case the vehicle shall be parked entirely within the lines designating the parking space, with the front of the vehicle headed in the direction of the curb. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-129), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-167. - Parking in prohibited areas; overtime parking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, let, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name or owned or operated by him or in his possession or under his control to be or remain in any no parking area designated according to the provisions of this chapter, or in a time limit parking area for a longer period of time than that designated by the markings on the street or by signs clearly visible. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-128), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-168. - Parking in alleys. 
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-113), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-169. - Authority of traffic director to prohibit parking on narrow streets. 
(a)  The traffic director is hereby authorized to erect signs or pavement markings indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty (20) feet, or upon one side of a street as indicated by such signs or markings when the width of the roadway does not exceed thirty (30) feet. 
(b)  When official signs or markings prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign or marking. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-114), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-170. - Parking for the sale of merchandise or other products near schools. 
To the extent that the sale of merchandise or other products is authorized pursuant to this Code, it shall nonetheless be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle in any school zone or any street adjacent to any school for the purpose of selling merchandise or other products between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 4:15 p.m. on school days. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-131), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 89-93, § 1, 6-13-89)  
Sec. 36-171. - Parking for more than twenty-four hours prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing in any public street, alley or other public place any vehicle for a longer continuous period of time than twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-132), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-172. - Parking of trucks, trailers, tractors, etc., between sunset and sunrise. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any heavy truck, dump truck, truck trailer, farm trailer, road tractor, trailer, semi-trailer, pole-trailer or mobile home on any roadway in the city at any time from sunset to sunrise. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or haul any heavy truck, bus, semi-trailer, or pole-trailer on any street not established as a truck route as enumerated in section 36-125 of this chapter in order to park same on any residential property within subdivisions with deed restrictions recorded with Harris County that restrict land development to single family residential use. The fact a heavy truck is parked on residential property shall be prima facie evidence that such heavy truck was operated on the street immediately adjacent to such residential property in violation of this subsection, if not a truck route as designated and established by this chapter. For the purposes of this section, residential property shall mean property at which a person or persons reside. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any person operating any vehicle of the fire department, police department, public or private ambulance in the performance of his duty, or to any person parking or standing such a vehicle in obedience to a traffic-control device or a police officer, or to any person loading or unloading such a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-133), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 05-170, § 3, 7-5-05) 
Cross reference— Four-hour limit on parking of mobile homes, § 21-2.  
Sec. 36-173. - Parking of trailer for more than two hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, stand or park a trailer, either attached or unattached to a motor vehicle, on the public streets of the city for a period of time in excess of two (2) hours. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1 (28-134), 3-15-66) 
Cross reference— Four-hour limit on parking of mobile homes, § 21-2.  
Secs. 36-174, 36-175. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-170, § 4, adopted July 5, 2005, repealed §§ 36-174 and 36-175, which pertained to delivery vehicles blocking traffic and backing to curb for loading or unloading and derived from Ord. No. 1780, §§ 1(28-123, 28-124, 28-135), 3-15-66.  
Sec. 36-176. - Parking spaces for disabled persons—Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall, for the purposes of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. All other words used in this chapter shall have their ordinary and commonly accepted meanings as set forth in dictionaries of recognized standing: 
Disabled parking placard means a placard issued under Sec. 681.002 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
Disabled person means a person who is permanently or temporarily disabled within the meaning of Sec. 681.001(2) of the Texas Transportation Code and who has applied for and received a registration insignia or identification card from the state. 
Identification card means the identification card issued by the state to a temporarily disabled person for purposes of Sec. 681.003 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
Registration insignia means the specially designed symbol, tab, or other device to be attached to the license plate of a vehicle, issued by the state to a temporarily or permanently disabled person for purposes of Sec. 681.006 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(Ord. No. 82-141, § 1, 6-29-82; Ord. No. 95-159, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 02-297, § 1, 1-7-03)  
Sec. 36-176.1. - Same—Signs available from city. 
(a)  A person who owns or controls property used for parking may designate one (1) or more parking spaces or a parking area for the exclusive use of vehicles transporting disabled persons in accordance with Sec. 681.009 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(b)  The owner or operator of a parking facility may obtain from the city a sign for designating a parking space for vehicles transporting disabled persons at a charge equal to the city's cost in preparing the sign. 
(c)  A disabled person may obtain disabled parking identification from the county tax assessor-collector as provided in Sec. 681.003 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(Ord. No. 82-141, § 1, 6-29-82; Ord. No. 95-159, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 02-297, § 1, 1-7-03)  
Sec. 36-176.2. - Same—Sign requirements. 
Each such sign provided or installed shall conform to the requirements of Section 5(i), Article 9102, Revised Statutes, as adopted by the Texas Commission of Licensing and Regulation (Exhibit A).  
Exhibit A 
(Ord. No. 82-141, § 1, 6-29-82; Ord. No. 95-159, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 02-297, § 1, 1-7-03)  
Sec. 36-176.3. - Same—Offenses. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person: 
(1)  Is neither a disabled person nor transporting a disabled person and stops, stands, or parks a vehicle displaying a registration insignia or identification card in a parking space or area designated specifically for the disabled; or 
(2)  Stops, stands, or parks a vehicle displaying neither a registration insignia nor an identification card in a parking space or area designated specifically for the disabled; or 
(3)  Stops, stands or parks a vehicle in such a manner that the vehicle blocks an access or curb ramp or any other architectural improvement designed to aid the disabled. 
(b)  Except as provided by subsections (c)—(f) of this section, an offense under subsection (a) is punishable by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  If it is shown on the trial of an offense under this section that the person has been previously convicted one (1) time of an offense under this section, the offense is punishable by a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or more than six hundred dollars ($600.00). 
(d)  If it is shown on the trial of an offense under this section that the person has been previously convicted two (2) times of an offense under this section, the offense is punishable by a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or more than six hundred dollars ($600.00), and not less than ten (10) or more than twenty (20) hours of community service. 
(e)  If it is shown on the trial of an offense under this section that the person has been previously convicted three (3) times of an offense under this section, the offense is punishable by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and not less than twenty (20) hours or more than fifty (50) hours of community service. 
(f)  If it is shown on the trial of an offense under this section that the person has been previously convicted four (4) times of an offense under this section, the offense is punishable by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and fifty (50) hours of community service. 
(Ord. No. 95-159, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 02-297, § 1, 1-7-03)  
Sec. 36-176.4. - Appointment of person with authority to file charges. 
The mayor may appoint a disabled person or a nondisabled person to have the authority to file charges against a person who commits an offense under this chapter. A person appointed under this subsection must be a United States citizen of good moral character who has not been convicted of a felony. The person must take and subscribe to an oath of office that the city prescribes and must complete a training program developed by the city. The person is not a peace officer, has no authority other than the authority applicable to a citizen to enforce a law other than this chapter, and may not carry a weapon while performing duties under this subsection. The person is not entitled to compensation for performing duties under this subsection or to indemnification from the city or the State of Texas for injury or property damage the person sustains or liability the person incurs in performing duties under this subsection. The city and the state are not liable for any damages arising from an act or omission of the person in performing duties under this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 95-159, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 02-297, § 1, 1-7-03)  
Sec. 36-177. - Loading zones generally. 
(a)  The traffic director is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs or markings indicating the same. These zones shall be operative from 7:00 a.m. to 6:30 p.m., on each day, except Sundays and legal holidays. 
(b)  A curb loading zone shall be designated by upright signs or painted curb markings of a distinctive color imprinted with the wording "Loading Zone." However, if the zone lies within a section of curb at which parking is normally prohibited, such zone shall be designated by red curb markings imprinted with the wording "Delivery Only." 
(c)  Every person desiring or requiring a loading zone shall make application on appropriate forms to the traffic director. No loading zone shall be granted where the flow of traffic would be impeded or traffic hazards created by such zone. 
(d)  For the purpose of regulating and supervising curb loading zones and to provide a fund to cover all costs involved in installing adequate signs or curb markings designating loading zones and to pay the cost of periodic maintenance thereof, there is hereby imposed against the applicant for a loading zone and against any person who desires the maintenance of a loading zone abutting their property, a charge of one dollar per lineal foot per year for such space reserved. The traffic director shall not establish any such zone until the tax assessor and collector has certified that the applicant has paid such annual charge. The tax assessor and collector shall collect the renewal fee on the same basis for subsequent years, and in the event the same is not promptly paid, he shall advise the traffic director who will remove the signs or curb markings designating such loading zones. 
(e)  All loading zones shall be available to anyone who may have loading or unloading to do in the immediate vicinity. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-115—28-119), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-178. - Unlawful use of loading zones. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period of not to exceed two (2) minutes. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pick-up and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed fifteen (15) minutes, except on written permission from the traffic director, which shall be a designated time, for a period necessary to complete only the one undertaking. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting the use of passenger type vehicles for the purpose of loading or unloading freight in a freight curb loading zone, but no person shall use a passenger type vehicle to load or unload freight in a freight curb loading zone unless he places an appropriate legible, printed, English language sign at least six (6) inches by eleven (11) inches on his windshield advising that he is parked for loading or unloading freight. Absence of an appropriate sign on the windshield of a passenger type vehicle in a freight curb loading zone shall be prima facie evidence that the vehicle is illegally parked. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-120—28-122), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-179. - Bus stops and taxicab stands; parking of buses or taxicabs outside such stands. 
(a)  The traffic director is hereby authorized and required to establish bus stops and taxicab stands on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop or taxicab stand shall be designated by appropriate signs or curb markings. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers, when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(c)  The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not park upon any street in any business district or urban district at any place other than at a bus stop or a taxicab stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-125—28-127), 3-15-66) 
Cross reference— Taxicabs, Ch. 35.  
Sec. 36-180. - Owner not to permit parking or standing violations. 
No person shall knowingly allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or be parked in any street in this city in violation of any provision of this article or other ordinances regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-136), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-181. - Presumption that owner of vehicle illegally parked same. 
In any prosecution charging a violation of any regulation governing the parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of such regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. The owner shall have the right to introduce evidence to show that such vehicle was not parked or placed by him as charged in the complaint. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-137), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-182. - Removal or impoundment of parked or standing vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle standing upon a street in violation of this chapter, such officer is hereby authorized to move such vehicle, or require the driver or other person in charge of the vehicle to move the same, to a position off the paved or main-traveled part of such street. 
(b)  Any police officer is hereby authorized to provide for the removal of a vehicle from a street to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the city council, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, or causeway, or in any tube or tunnel where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2)  When any vehicle is illegally parked so as to block the entrance to any private driveway and it is impracticable to move such vehicle from in front of the driveway to another point on the highway. 
(3)  When any vehicle is found upon a street and report has previously been made that such vehicle has been stolen or complaint has been filed and a warrant thereon issued charging that such vehicle has been embezzled. 
(4)  When any such officer has reasonable grounds to believe that any vehicle has been abandoned. 
(5)  When a vehicle upon a street is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical and the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are incapacitated by reason of physical injury or other reason to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its removal or custody, or are not in the immediate vicinity of the disabled vehicle. 
(6)  When an officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and such officer is, by law, required to take the person arrested immediately before the municipal court judge. 
(7)  When any vehicle is illegally parked in violation of any ordinance of the city or law of the state not provided for in this section. 
(c)  Any police officer is hereby authorized to provide for the removal of any vehicle parked or standing in or on any portion of a highway when, in the opinion of such officer, the vehicle constitutes a hazard, or interferes with a normal function of a governmental agency, or by reason of any catastrophe, emergency or unusual circumstances the safety of the vehicle is imperiled. 
(d)  No vehicle impounded in an authorized garage as herein provided shall be released therefrom until the charges for towing such vehicle into the garage and storage charges have been paid. The charge for towing or removal of any such vehicle and storage charges shall be fixed by the city council, such charges to be based upon a computation of all actual expenses entering into the current cost of such services. Such charge or charges shall be maintained for public inspection in the office of the city secretary and in each authorized garage. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-27), 3-15-66) 
Cross reference— Authorized garages designated for purpose of impoundment and storage under above section, and charges prescribed for such storage, § 7-13(b)(5); general provisions relative to removal and impounding of inoperable vehicle or vehicles constituting a safety hazard, § 20-12.  
Secs. 36-183—36-192. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDESTRIANS 
 
Sec. 36-193. - Picketing residential dwelling prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Picketing means the posting of a person or group for a demonstration or protest. 
Targeted picketing means activity that is targeted at a particular residential dwelling and proceeds on a definite course or route in front of or around that particular residential dwelling. 
Residential dwelling means any permanent building being used by its occupants solely for nontransient residential uses. 
This section does not and shall not be interpreted to preclude picketing in a residential area that is not targeted at a particular residential dwelling. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to engage in targeted picketing before or about the residential dwelling of any individual in the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-361, § 2, 12-18-07)  
Secs. 36-194, 36-195. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-69, § 1, adopted March 15, 2005, repealed §§ 36-193—36-195, which pertained to application of article; designation of crosswalks and safety zones for protection of pedestrians; right-of-way in crosswalks and derived from Ord. No. 1780, §§ 1(28-157, 28-158), 3-15-66.  
Sec. 36-196. - Prohibited crossings generally. 
Pedestrians are prohibited from crossing, under certain conditions, those streets designated by the traffic director, as evidenced by the erection of appropriate signs or pavement markings. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-160), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-197. - When use of crosswalk required. 
(a)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business district or in any portion of a roadway within six hundred (600) feet of the property line of any school or building being used for school purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-160), 3-15-66; Ord. No. 05-69, § 2, 3-15-05) 
State Law reference— Provisions similar to subsection (a) above, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 78(c); authority of city to enact subsection (b), Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 76(b).  
Secs. 36-198—36-201. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-69, § 1, adopted March 15, 2005, repealed §§ 36-198—36-201, which pertained to duty to yield right-of-way to vehicles; crossing at right angles or by shortest route; walking on roadways; soliciting by pedestrians and derived from Ord. No. 1780, §§ 1(28-159, 28-161, 28-162, 28-165), 3-15-66.  
Sec. 36-202. - Receiving and discharging of passengers. 
The driver or operator of any motor vehicle shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway of any street in the city, but shall drive to the right-hand sidewalk as nearly as possible, or in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side of the road, and there receive or discharge passengers, except upon one-way streets where passengers may be discharged or received at either right-hand or left-hand sidewalk or roadway in the absence of a sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-164), 3-15-66)  
Sec. 36-203. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-69, § 1, adopted March 15, 2005, repealed § 36-203, which pertained to duty to duty of drivers with regard to pedestrians and derived from Ord. No. 1780, § 1(28-163), 3-15-66.  
Secs. 36-204, 36-205. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - TRAFFIC AND TRANSPORTATION COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; department of traffic and transportation, § 2-133 et seq. 
 
Sec. 36-206. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the term "commission" shall mean the City of Pasadena Traffic and Transportation Commission created by section 36-207. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-207. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created, re-created and established, within and for the city, the City of Pasadena Traffic and Transportation Commission composed of thirteen (13) members, whose positions are hereby created and established. This membership shall consist of a member of city council, the chief of police, the deputy chief of police in charge of the patrol bureau, the city engineer, an assistant city attorney, a municipal court judge, the traffic and transportation director and six (6) citizens. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-208. - Qualifications of members. 
Each member of the commission who is not a city employee shall be a resident citizen and qualified voter of the city. Any member who ceases to hold such qualifications shall, ipso facto, upon such cessation, terminate his membership, subject only to written approval by the mayor filed with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-209. - Appointment and terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  All members of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. Each member shall serve for a term of one year or until September 30, whichever first occurs, unless sooner terminated. 
(b)  All vacancies in membership of the commission shall be filled as soon as practicable after the occurrence of such vacancies by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. The term of a member appointed and confirmed to fill a vacancy shall be for the balance of the original term. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-210. - Members to serve without compensation. 
The members of the commission, in the performance of their official duties, shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-211. - Officers designated. 
The officers of the commission shall consist of a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary. The director of traffic and transportation shall serve as the secretary of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-212. - Election and term of vice-chairman. 
The vice-chairman of the commission shall be a noncity employee nominated by the members of the commission in such a manner as the commission shall prescribe at its first meeting as a committee of the whole, and he shall be elected by a majority vote of the qualified and serving members of the commission. The term of the vice-chairman shall be limited within the term of his commission membership appointment. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-213. - General powers and duties of officers. 
(a)  The chairman shall serve as presiding officer of the commission and appoint such other commission officers and committees as he deems fit, subject to such rules, regulations and bylaws as may be enacted by the commission under the supervision of the mayor. 
(b)  The vice-chairman of the commission shall serve in the performance of the duties and exercise of the powers of the chairman in the event of his absence or disability. In all cases, the mayor shall have the sole power of determining and declaring the disability of the chairman. 
(c)  The secretary of the commission shall write and have custody of the minutes of all meetings of the commission and shall have charge of all records of the commission. Commission correspondence shall be handled under the supervision of the secretary. 
(d)  The traffic and transportation director shall advise and consult with the commission in all its research projects, studies, tests and experiments and shall prepare recommendations and proposals, cost estimates and reports as to such projects, studies, tests and experiments. Unless otherwise provided by the commission, the traffic and transportation director will superintend the work ordered by the commission in the discharge of its duties. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-214. - Monthly meetings required; termination of membership for failure to attend meetings. 
The commission shall hold regular monthly meetings. Any member having three (3) consecutive absences from regular monthly meetings, without good cause shown, shall have his membership terminated, subject only to the mayor's approval. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-215. - Procedure. 
The procedure of the commission, except as prescribed in this article, shall be fixed by rules and regulations of the city council and by rules, regulations and bylaws of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-216. - Quorum. 
Fifty-one (51) per cent of the qualified and serving members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. The majority vote of a quorum of the commission shall be the act of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-217. - General powers and duties of commission. 
The commission shall have the power and it shall be its duty to: 
(1)  Coordinate traffic activities, carry on educational activities in traffic matters, supervise the preparation and publication of traffic reports, receive complaints having to do with traffic matters, and recommend to the city council and to the traffic and transportation director, the chief of police and other city officials ways and means for improving traffic conditions and the administration and enforcement of traffic regulations. 
(2)  Conduct hearings in response to appeals filed under the provisions of section 36-22.1 of this Code regarding obstructions of view of traffic at intersections. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Sec. 36-218. - Rules, regulations and bylaws for government of commission. 
(a)  The city council may prescribe rules and regulations for the government of the commission or may, by resolution, adopt rules and regulations promulgated by the commission. The commission may adopt bylaws for its respective government. 
(b)  All rules and regulations promulgated by the commission and bylaws adopted by the commission shall become effective only after approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 83-32, § 2, 1-25-83)  
Chapter 36½ - TREES AND SHRUBS[1]
