ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 36½-1—36½-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PISTILLATE COTTONWOOD TREES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 71-178, adopted June 22, 1971, did not expressly amend this Code, hence inclusion of §§ 1—9 herein as Art. II, §§ 36½-11—36½-19, was at the discretion of the editors. Catchlines were added by the editors to facilitate indexing, reference and use; and § 10, validity provisions, was omitted from codification. 
 
Sec. 36½-11. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
Person includes one or more persons of either sex, natural persons, corporations, partnerships, associations, joint stock companies, societies, organizations and all other entities of any kind capable of being sued. 
Property owner shall mean and include every person who owns, occupies or exerts control over any real property within the city limits of the City of Pasadena. 
Public property shall mean and include that portion of the street right-of-way situated between the street curb and property line along all public streets and highways within the City of Pasadena. 
Pistillate cottonwood tree is defined as any female tree of the genus populus including all poplar and cottonwood bearing tatones in which cottonwood cotton is formed. 
Tatones are defined as the pods which grow on pistillate cottonwood trees and which produce a cottonwood cotton. 
Cottonwood cotton is defined as a fleecy white material closely resembling true cotton which, when released from the tatone, carries cottonwood tree seeds through the air. 
Prune shall mean the removal of cotton and cotton producing parts of trees as herein required. 
When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the singular number include the plural number. 
The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(Ord. No. 71-178, § 1, 6-22-71)  
Secs. 36½-12—36½-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 85-175, § 1, adopted Sept. 3, 1985, repealed in their entirety §§ 36½-12—36½-17, pertaining to pruning and removal of pistillate cottonwood trees, derived from Ord. No. 71-178, §§ 2—7, adopted June 22, 1971.  
Sec. 36½-18. - Sale, etc., of pistillate cottonwood trees prohibited. 
No person, firm, corporation or association shall sell, display for sale, distribute, exchange, barter or trade, within the city limits of the City of Pasadena, a pistillate cottonwood tree as contemplated by this article; provided, however, this section shall not be construed to prevent the transportation of pistillate cottonwood trees through the City of Pasadena for distribution or use at some location other than within the corporate limits of the City of Pasadena. 
(Ord. No. 71-178, § 8, 6-22-71)  
Sec. 36½-19. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 71-178, § 9, 6-22-71)  
Chapter 37 - WATER, SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Bond for clerks employed in water division of department of public works, § 2-5; buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 9; heating, air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration code, Ch. 16; water and sewer connections for mobile homes located outside mobile home park, § 21-48; water lines and sewer connections in mobile home parks, § 21-68; payment of taxes prerequisite to obtaining license or permit, § 26-1 et seq.; duty of planning director to make recommendations as to water procurement, storage and distribution, § 28-18; plumbing, Ch. 29; street openings for water and sewer connections, § 32-31; swimming pools, Ch. 33; subdivisions, App. A, App. B. 
State Law reference— General authority of city relative to water and sewer systems, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(11), (13). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 37-1. - Water control and improvement districts. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance abolishing any water control and improvement district and assigning the property, facilities, functions and services of such district to the city, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Sec. 37-2. - Water taps and meters generally; application for water service. 
(a)  All water taps shall be made by the city, after application is made for a meter and the same is fully paid for by the applicant. Whether the applicant is the property owner or the property owner's agent, the meter shall remain the property of the city but the owner shall be responsible for its protection. The city shall, in all cases, decide on the size of the meter which can be set and the location of same. 
(b)  In case any person shall move into any premises such person shall file an application for water service before using any water from the service connections for such premises. 
(c)  Where an application is accepted for water service, it shall be deemed that the place of service and the name of the applicant shown upon such application is the bona fide place of service and name of the applicant, and should water services be discontinued for nonpayment of bills or for other infractions of this chapter, no new application will be accepted from the owner, agent or any other person to continue service in such place under any other name, so long as such place is occupied by the original applicant as the bona fide place of service, whether as a business or a residence, until after all bills, penalties, damage costs to city water equipment and other service charges have been paid in full or a payment, settlement or release agreement reached. Should water services be furnished by anyone to a tenant, it shall be considered additional service to the applicant and the provisions of this subsection shall apply in the same manner. 
(d)  Where a contractor applies for the use of water for construction purposes, the meter shall remain the property of the city, but the contractor shall be responsible for its protection during the tenure of its use. When the contractor or contractor's representative agent makes an application, a deposit shall be made as provided in section 37-37 or shall be an amount equal to twice the price of the estimated monthly usage as payment guarantee for water to be supplied and protection of the meter. The deposit will not be refunded until all water and any damage bills are paid in full. If water usage estimates prove to be seriously out of line, an adjustment of the amount shall be made up or down as the case may be. 
(e)  Water meters shall not be set unless the correct street name and correct number are given by the applicant. When the application is made, it will also be necessary to give the correct name of the owner, or if the application is for a tenant, the tenant's correct name, street and house number. 
(f)  If any person shall give any false statement in any application for water service such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(g)  An application for temporary services shall be submitted to the water billing office. A fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) shall be paid in advance for temporary water service for activities such as cleaning, plumbing checks, remodeling and so forth. The following temporary water rates are hereby established and shall be collected for water services furnished by the city: 
(1)  The thirty-five dollar ($35.00) fee is for fifteen (15) days and two thousand (2,000) gallons of water; 
(2)  Two dollars seventy-five cents ($2.75) per one thousand (1,000) gallons thereafter; 
(3)  Service will be terminated after fifteen (15) days and if additional service time is required, customer must pay an additional twenty dollars ($20.00) for another 15 days of service and two thousand (2,000) gallons of water except that all usage thereafter will be charged as indicated in subsection (2) above; and 
(4)  Customer can request additional days by paying twenty dollars ($20.00) for another fifteen (15) days of service and two thousand (2,000) gallons of water except that all usage thereafter will be charged as indicated in subsection (2) above provided however that after sixty (60) days, it will be considered a regular account and assessed the deposit requirement as indicated in section 37-37. 
(h)  Water customers in good standing shall be allowed a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days when transferring from one residence to another. Before the expiration of that fifteen-day period, either a new deposit or a cosigner must be in place, or the original water service will be disconnected. A transfer fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be paid when a customer moves water service from one (1) location in the city to another location within the city. 
(i)  In accordance with TAC 30 Chapter 290 of the TCEQ Rules each private residence with a single water meter must have a water distribution system within the home that meets the following standards: 
(1)  No direct connection between the public drinking water supply and a potential source of contamination. Potential sources of contamination may be isolated from the public water system by an air gap or an appropriate backflow prevention assembly in accordance with state plumbing regulations. Additionally, all pressure relief valves and thermal expansion devices may be in compliance with state plumbing codes. 
(2)  No cross-connection between the public drinking water supply and a private water system. Where an actual air gap is not maintained between the public water supply and a private water supply, an approved reduced pressure-zone backflow prevention assembly must be properly installed and in place. A service agreement for annual inspection and testing by a certified backflow prevention device tester is required. 
(3)  No connection which would allow the return of water used for condensing, cooling or industrial processes back to the public water supply. 
(4)  No pipe or pipe fitting installed on or after July 1, 1998 which contains more than 8.0 per cent lead. 
(5)  No private plumbing facilities installed on or after July 1, 1998 which contain solder or flux with more than 0.2 per cent lead. 
(6)  No installed plumbing fixture which is not in compliance with state approved plumbing code. 
(j)  To ensure compliance with TCEQ standards each residential unit must be inspected by a plumber, approved by the city, or plumbing inspector and each must be licensed by the State Board of Plumbing Examiners. Such inspection may also be performed by a water supply protection specialist licensed by the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners or certain others who are approved by the TCEQ. 
(k)  A certificate of inspection, as described herein, completed by a registered inspector, must be on file with the water department before water service will be provided to any single-family dwelling with a single water meter. This requirement applies to both initial connections and re-connects. 
(l)  A service agreement, as described herein, must be executed by each new applicant for water service. This requirement applies to new construction and re-connects. 
(m)  Commercial establishments and multifamily dwellings served by one (1) meter must meet the same criteria as set out above but the inspection must be done by those listed above. 
(n)  Copies of the service agreement and inspection form are prescribed by 30 TAC chapter 290 and may be obtained from the water department. 
(Code 1964, § 29-3; Ord. No. 1805, §§ 1, 4, 12, 5-3-66; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 78-5, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 86-98, § 1, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 00-36, § 1, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 10-074, §§ 1—6, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-3. - Water meters required. 
All water supplied by the city shall be metered by a self-contained encoder water meter which registers the water supplied in gallons and registers the current odometer reading through a remote radio frequency into the city billing system. All meters shall need approval by the Director of Public Works and be installed with removable strainers. 
(Code 1964, § 29-33; Ord. No. 1805, § 6, 5-3-66; Ord. No. 99-193, § 1, 10-12-99)  
Sec. 37-4. - Installation for water meter and taps; boring/tunneling. 
There shall be collected by the city the following fees for water meters and their installation within the city.

The contractor shall bear all costs incurred for any road tunneling and boring necessary for sewer lines and water taps.

All meters shall be installed by the property line or at a location specified by the city engineer or his duly authorized representative.

Extra pipe $1.00 per foot beyond forty (40) feet. 
Thirty-five (35) sacks of ready mix concrete, $90.00. 
The meter fee for the exchange of a one (1) inch or larger meter for a standard five-eighths ( 5/8 ) meter is waived. 
(Code 1964, § 29-5; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 78-5, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 83-336, § 1, 11-15-83; Ord. No. 92-21, § 1, 2-11-92; Ord. No. 93-135, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 99-193, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 7-1-08; Ord. No. 08-223, § 1, 9-23-08)  
Sec. 37-5. - Fee for sewer taps, permit and inspection. 
(a)  All taps into a city sewer trunk or tap to connect to any city sewer shall be made by employee of the city of Pasadena (taps made by other than city personnel shall result in a double fee); provided, however, a sewer tap permit will be issued to a master plumber licensed by the State of Texas, who is bonded with the city, upon application to the building official. Such master plumber shall make application to the building official for a permit to tap a city sewer trunk or tap or connect to any city sewer. 
(b)  No person shall replace, repair or otherwise renew a service line without first making application for and obtaining a permit from the building official. 
(c)  Whenever a service line is replaced or renewed, such replacement work shall extend to and connect to the sewer main with a tapping saddle, and shall be inspected by the building official or his authorized representative prior to cover-up. If such cover-up occurs prior to inspection, the contractor shall be required to uncover at his expense the tapping saddle for inspection. 
(d)  The building official shall exercise care in giving the location land depth of city sewer mains belonging to the city, but the city shall not, in any case, guarantee such location and depth. All streets under which sewer lines shall be placed in making the sewer tap shall be bored. No open cuts in the street shall be permitted. Provided, however, upon application to the director of public works upon good cause shown and the written consent of the mayor, an open cut may be made. 
(e)  There shall be collected by the city the following fees for sewer tap, permit and inspection within the city: 
(1)  For one-family residential dwellings: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and or each additional sewer tap a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) each. 
(2)  For commercial users: One thousand three hundred dollars ($1,300.00) each and for each additional sewer tap five hundred fifty dollars ($550.00). 
(3)  For the permit and inspection fee for replacement of existing service sewer lines: Twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(4)  No permit shall be issued to replace or renew a service line unless such replacement provides for the renewal of such service line so as to extend and connect into the existing sewer main line with a tapping saddle and until the fee therefor is fully paid. 
(5)  The minimum street boring charge shall be one thousand six hundred dollars ($1,600.00), standard fifty-foot road bore length, each additional foot to be charged for at the rate of twenty dollars ($20.00) per foot. 
(f)  There shall be collected by the city the following fees for commercial site work, permit and inspection within the city:

Sec. 37-6. - Reserved. 
This section reserved at the request of the City.  
Sec. 37-7. - Testing water meters. 
Any consumer may at any time request that his water meter be tested for accuracy. The procedure shall be as follows: an application for a test shall be accompanied by a special deposit of fifty dollars ($50.00). A test will be scheduled. The customer shall be notified by the city of the time and place of the test. Whether the customer appears or not, the test shall be performed and witnessed. If the test shows the meter to be more than two (2) per cent fast, the meter shall be replaced with an accurate one and the fifty dollar ($50.00) deposit returned to the customer, together with a written statement of the test findings. If the test shows the meter to be any less than two (2) per cent fast, the fifty dollar ($50.00) deposit shall be forfeited to the city. A brief written statement of the test findings will be mailed to the customer. Field testing of one-inch meters, when requested by the owner and made by the city, shall cost seventy-five dollars ($75.00); testing of one and one-half-inch meters shall cost one hundred dollars ($100.00); testing of two-inch and three-inch meters shall cost one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); testing of four-inch meters shall cost two hundred dollars ($200.00); and testing of six-inch, eight-inch, and ten-inch meters shall cost three hundred dollars ($300.00), respectively. 
(Ord. No. 01-183, § 1, 10-30-01)  
Sec. 37-8. - Material and size of house piping for water. 
All house piping for water shall be galvanized wrought iron, galvanized steel or copper, and no lead shall be permitted. The pipe shall be of a size as best suits the owner, except that the connection for the water meter shall be of such size as will take the size of meter connections which are to be used. 
(Code 1964, § 29-8)  
Sec. 37-9. - Cross connections with water supply prohibited. 
No cross connections of other water supplies shall exist or ever be made to or with the water system of the city, either within or without the city. 
(Code 1964, § 29-9)  
Sec. 37-10. - Water customers to give notice of change of address. 
In case any person subscribing to city water services shall change his place of business or residence he shall, within forty-eight (48) hours after such change, give notice thereof to the water division of the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 1805, § 12, 5-3-66)  
Sec. 37-11. - Prohibited deposits in sewers generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to blow, sweep, throw or deposit into any sewer manhole, catch basin, or into any private drain connecting with a city sewer or city street, any straw, hay, grass, grass clippings, trees, limbs, trimmings, weeds, branches, leaf litter, dirt and other fill material, construction/demolition material, garbage, debris or any other substance which would be liable to cause stoppage in the sewers or be injurious to the disposal plant. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or with criminal negligence violate any provision of this section and any person convicted of violating any provision, restriction, requirement, or prohibition of this section for which no specific penalty is provided shall be fined in a sum of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1964, § 29-10; Ord. No. 99-146, § 1, 8-31-99)  
Sec. 37-12. - Discharge of industrial waste into storm sewers. 
(a)  The discharge of industrial waste into any of the city's storm sewers or storm water drainage system is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, "industrial wastes" are hereby defined as being the liquid or other character of waste resulting from any commercial manufacturing or industrial operations or processes, other than sanitary sewage. "Sanitary sewage" is hereby defined as the waste from water closets, urinals, lavatories, sinks, bathtubs, showers, household laundries, cellar floor drains, garage floor drains, storerooms, drinking fountains, soda fountains, refrigerator drips and stable floor drains. 
(Code 1964, §§ 29-1, 29-11)  
Sec. 37-13. - Sanitary sewers not be used for roof, storm or surface drainage or commercial waste. 
It shall be unlawful for any person renting, owning, leasing or controlling, in whole or in part, any premises within the city to use the sanitary sewer line for roof drainage, storm drainage, surface drainage or commercial waste. 
(Code 1964, § 29-12; Ord. No. 1671, § 1, 2-16-65)  
Sec. 37-14. - Connection of sanitary drain lines to storm sewers, creeks, rivers or lakes. 
No sanitary drain lines shall ever be connected to any storm sewer, creek, river or lake, unless the drainage is first purified to such extent that the approval of the state health department and the city health officer can be and is first obtained in writing. 
(Code 1964, § 29-13)  
Sec. 37-15. - Unauthorized opening of sewer manhole covers, lampholes or cleanouts. 
No person, except an authorized employee of the city, shall open any manhole cover, lamphole or cleanout of the city sewer system. 
(Code 1964, § 29-14)  
Sec. 37-16. - Unauthorized turning on of water service. 
No person who is not specifically authorized by the city shall turn water on for any premises, and where the water has been turned off for vacancy, nonpayment of water and sewer service charges, or for any other reason, any unauthorized person turning on such water shall be held guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 29-15)  
Sec. 37-17. - Damaging meters, service lines, mains, laterals, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or otherwise injure any water meter, water tap, service line, water or sewer main, lateral trunk line, fire hydrant, valve or other property used in connection with the city's water and sewer system. In addition to any penalty imposed upon conviction for a violation of this section, the person responsible for any such damage shall fully reimburse the city for any expenses incurred in repairing the damage, and general contractors will be held fully accountable for any damages by their subcontractors or their agents during any service being performed for the contact, any of his subcontractors or their agents. 
(b)  If a customer service line is so deteriorated or in such a state of disrepair that city personnel cannot service or replace the water meter attached thereto, the city shall notify customer of such condition. Customer shall have seven (7) days to correct the problem and notify the city of said correction. If customer fails to make necessary corrections, then city may either discontinue water service until such corrections are made or make the necessary corrections and charge customer for same. 
(Code 1964, § 29-18; Ord. No. 99-220, § 1, 12-7-99)  
Sec. 37-18. - Right of entry for meter readers and inspectors; meter accessibility. 
(a)  City water meter readers or inspectors shall have access to all premises where water or sewer service exists at all reasonable business hours, which are normally from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on all days, except Sundays. Consent to enter private property shall be obtained. 
(b)  The owner of the property must keep the meter exposed and accessible for repair at all times. Should the meter be inaccessible or covered with concrete, black topping, dirt, rocks, lumber, or other materials, the owner shall immediately uncover it. Should he fail to do so, the city shall uncover the meter and charge the owner two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for such service. 
(Code 1964, § 29-19; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 86-98, § 3, 5-20-86)  
Sec. 37-19. - Vicious dogs and other animals not to interfere with meter readers and inspectors. 
Vicious dogs or other animals of vicious nature shall not be allowed to be where they can or may be a menace or danger to any authorized water meter reader or inspector. Any violation of this section shall be cause for discontinuance of the water service, and whenever it is necessary to so handle a case, the water service shall not be restored until a proper assurance is furnished the city that the danger and menace has been permanently removed, and a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is paid to the city to repay the city's expense of restoring the service. 
(Code 1964, § 29-20; Ord. No. 86-98, § 4, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 01-183, § 2, 10-30-01) 
Cross reference— Animals generally, Ch. 6.  
Sec. 37-20. - Shutting off water for repairs, etc. 
The department of public works may, at any time, order the water cut off from any premises connected with the city mains for repairs, extensions or other necessary purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1805, § 2, 5-3-66)  
Sec. 37-21. - City not liable for damages caused by change in water pressure or shutting off water. 
The city shall not be liable for any damage which may occur due to any change in pressure in its water mains or in any connections or laterals or to water meters or on account of water being cut off for any purpose or on account of the bursting of any pipe or fixture by pressure of the water from city mains or appurtenances thereto. 
(Code 1964, § 29-17; Ord. No. 1805, § 3, 5-3-66)  
Sec. 37-22. - Chapter not to interfere or conflict with plumbing ordinances. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed or understood to interfere or conflict in any way with any part of the plumbing ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 29-21) 
Cross reference— Plumbing, Ch. 29.  
Secs. 37-23—37-33. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER SERVICE CHARGES[2]

Sec. 37-34. - Water rates prescribed. 
(a)  The following words and terms shall have the following meanings when used in this section: 
City's water, distribution systems. All water distribution systems and extensions or enlargements thereof owned or operated by the City of Pasadena, or in which the city has an equity of ownership, and there is specifically included the systems that have been constructed by the city and those systems constructed by persons, as that term is defined herein, and which have heretofore or may hereafter be acquired by the city, and those systems constructed by or acquired by reclamation and conservation districts organized under Article XVI, Section 59, of the Texas Constitution, and which have heretofore or may hereafter be acquired by the city by operation of, or as authorized by, law. 
Designated unit. An area established for either (1) human habitation including single-family type residences, duplexes, townhouses, condominiums, multifamily projects and mobile home park spaces or (2) any commercial establishment containing fixture units. For the purposes of this section a designated unit shall not include a hospital room, a continuing care nursing home room, a hotel/motel room, or a recreational vehicle park space for rent on a daily basis.

The city shall be under no obligation to extend its lines or service outside the city, or to continue the service once begun, and may terminate the service at any time for any reason upon one hundred twenty (120) days' written notice. For failure to pay charges, or for violation of its rules and regulations of service; the city may disconnect or turn off either or both services as specified in section 37-41. 
(8)  Fire line minimum charge, 2,000 gallons or less ..... $55.25 
Next 8,000 gallons of water, per 1,000 gallons ..... 2.75

Sec. 37-36. - Against whom levied. 
(a)  The charges for water, garbage and sewer service rendered by the city shall be levied and assessed against the person in whose name the water meter is listed in the city water department record, or as otherwise provided by this chapter, whether or not such meter is owned by the user or the city water department. In the event any person is connected to or is using the sanitary sewer system or garbage service of the city and is not connected to the city's water system, the charges for said services shall be levied and assessed in the name of the person connected with and using the sewer system or garbage service. 
(b)  Residential and commercial users of the city sewer system who have a private source of water supply or who receive water from a source other than the city's water system shall be billed as follows, for premises served within the city limits: 
(1)  Single-family residential, per month ..... $11.00 
(2)  Duplex residence, per month ..... 22.00 
(3)  Multiple dwelling units or, at option of owner, from metered water supply, per unit ..... 9.50 
(4)  Commercial, per month ..... 12.00 
(c)  For sewer service to property located outside the limits of the city, where there is no existing contract with the city precluding the application of the charges established by this article during the term thereof, the charges to be made by the city for such service shall be twice the amount of the minimum charge and one and one-half (1½) times the amount of all charges above the minimum charge for like service within the city limits. 
(d)  All persons owning, renting, leasing or having management or control of property or premises that produce waste that is discharged into the sanitary sewers of the city, including domestic waste, and subject to the provisions of this article, shall be charged the rates established in this section, and no reduced rates or free sanitary sewer service shall be furnished to any such person, property or premises. 
(e)  In those instances where water meters are provided on the sources of water providing water to the facilities discharging into the sanitary sewer system of the city, water usage will be determined from the water meter readings, for the purpose of determining the sewer service charge. As to such water sources that are not metered, estimates of water usage will be made by the city and sewer service charges based upon such estimates will be in addition to those determined from water meter readings. 
(f)  Any person discharging waste from any property or premises into the sanitary sewers of the city who has a private source of water supply or who receives his water supply from a source other than the city may choose to install a water meter of the type and standard approved by the department of public works for the purpose of measuring the amount of water taken into such facilities. Such meter shall be installed in a location approved by the department of public works and accessible to the water meter readers of the city at all times during the hours from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday of each week of each year. The water consumption indicated by such meter shall be the basis of determining the sewer charge provided for in this article. 
(Code 1964, § 29-34; Ord. No. 1805, § 7, 5-3-66; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 75-159, § 1, 9-23-75; Ord. No. 86-98, § 7, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 93-168, § 2, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 16-040, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-16)  
Sec. 37-37. - Deposit for water, sewer and garbage services—Generally; residential, multi-family dwellings and commercial. 
(a)  Service to user. Whenever application is made for water, garbage, and/or sewer service by a person, such application shall be accompanied by a deposit payable to the city to guarantee payment of all such service charges. The amount of such deposit shall be determined as specifically listed below or, if not specifically listed, then by estimating monthly usage and doubling that amount. The water department may classify and list businesses according to the hereinbefore stated formula and require payment of the deposit listed. The deposit shall be held by the city during the entire occupation of the premises by each customer and until all bills due for such services thereto are paid. Except that: 
(1)  No person of the age of sixty-five (65) years or older shall be required to make or maintain a deposit for water, sewer, and/or garbage services to his residence if he submits to the water department satisfactory proof of age. A customer shall lose his exemption by reason of terminating for nonpayment and again be required to make a deposit as herein provided as a condition of restoration of service. 
(2)  Any account requiring a minimum deposit in excess of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) may, in lieu of other deposit and with approval of the water department, provide a corporate surety bond in a form acceptable to the city attorney, in the amount of the required deposit. 
(b)  Deposit/connect fee. Deposits for service are as follows: 
(1)  Residential: 
a.  Owner of single-family dwelling ..... $125.00 
b.  Renter (non-owner) of single-family dwelling ..... 150.00 
(2)  Commercial deposits shall be determined by the water billing office. This deposit is to be generally comparable to two (2) months' service of a commercial business similar to the applicant. 
(3)  Deposits for apartment houses, mobile parks or other multi-family dwelling shall be determined as follows: 
a.  Small apartment, mobile home park, or townhouse complex (3—5 units) per unit ..... 75.00; 
b.  Medium apartment, mobile home park, or townhouse complex (6—15 units) per unit ..... 75.00 
c.  Large apartment, mobile home park, or townhouse complex (over fifteen (15) units) per meter shall be twice the monthly rate. This will be calculated by averaging the last twelve (12) months' billing for this property. If water usage estimates prove to be seriously out of line, an adjustment of the amount shall be made up or down as the case may be. 
(c)  Sprinkler (irrigation) meters ..... 25.00 to 500.00 
(based on size of meter) 
(d)  Swimming pool deposits: 
Single-family dwellings and duplexes ..... 50.00 
All others, per pool ..... 75.00 
(e)  Sewer or garbage deposits. Should any resident not be serviced by city water but by sewer and/or garbage service only the following deposits shall apply: 
Single-family dwelling for garbage only ..... 35.00 
Single-family dwelling for sewer only ..... 16.00 
Duplex for garbage only ..... 70.00 
Duplex for sewer only ..... 35.00 
(f)  In addition to the deposit, a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be charged for the connection of new water service. A transfer fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be paid when a customer moves water service from one (1) location in the city to another location within the city. 
(Code 1964, § 29-35; Ord. No. 1770, § 1, 2-15-66; Ord. No. 1835, § 1, 7-5-66; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 78-5, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 80-299, § 1, 1-6-81; Ord. No. 86-98, §§ 8—10, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 86-214, § 1, 9-16-87; Ord. No. 01-183, § 4, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 10-074, §§ 8, 9, 4-20-10; Ord. No. 12-135, § 3, 9-25-12)  
Sec. 37-38. - Same—By contractors. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, "contractor" shall mean any person, natural or artificial, engaging in the construction, erection, installation of buildings or structures for hire, according to plans and specifications approved for a city building permit. 
(b)  Deposits for water service at construction sites shall be as follows: 
Single-family dwelling (one (1) house) ..... $100.00 
Single-family dwellings (for each five (5) houses) ..... 400.00 
Commercial buildings (small) ..... 100.00 
Apartment or townhouse complexes, per meter ..... 500.00 
Commercial buildings (large), per meter ..... 500.00 
Fire hydrant meter, affixed to hydrant, per meter ..... 400.00 
Fire hydrant meter, movable, per meter ..... 1,000.00 
For fire hydrant meters, water readings must be provided in writing to the city water billing office on a monthly basis or a two hundred fifty dollar ($250.00) penalty may result. Failure to comply with the monthly reading schedule shall entitle the city to take back the meter and discontinue the person's use of the meter. Additionally, the city may apply all or part of the utility deposit to the payment of a delinquent utility bill. In such cases, the amount shall be determined by the preceding month's usage. 
(1)  The deposits required by this section shall be required only during construction. Construction shall be conclusively deemed completed as of the approval of the city permit department upon final inspection thereof. The deposit shall be refundable only after all city service charges assessable to any water meter connected in the name of such building contractor, whether corporate, assumed, or true, have been fully paid. 
(2)  A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be charged to move a fire hydrant meter from one location to another for the same customer. Any outstanding bill on the current amount must be paid prior to transfer even if it is not yet past due. In addition, a two hundred dollar ($200.00) fee will be assessed the builders, contractors, and subcontractors who intentionally move meters from one location to another to avoid the cost of setting up service at each location where they are working. Water service will not be restored until this fee has been paid. 
(c)  Lost or stolen meter. There will be a charge of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to replace any meter that is lost or stolen. Water service will not be restored until this fee has been paid. 
(d)  Interest and transferability. Interest shall not be allowed on said deposits and they shall be nontransferable. 
(e)  Exemptions. Churches, public schools, religious or charitable organizations, and governmental bodies are hereby exempted from the payment of deposits. 
(Code 1964, § 29-35; Ord. No. 1770, § 1, 12-14-66; Ord. No. 1835, § 1, 7-5-66; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 78-5, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 86-98, § 11, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 01-183, § 5, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 10-074, §§ 10—13, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-39. - Meter reading; billing procedures. 
All water meters, as nearly as possible, shall be read once a month and bills shall be rendered therefor to each customer not less than once during an equivalent of one (1) calendar month. Billings shall be arranged to issue on approximately the same date or dates of each month. All bills shall be considered rendered when sent to the customer by the city. If the meter reader is unable to procure a reading of the meter because ingress thereto is obstructed in any manner, or entrance to premises is made hazardous by a vicious dog or otherwise, a charge shall be made based on an estimate of the amount of water consumed since the last reading. 
(Code 1964, § 29-36; Ord. No. 1805, § 8, 5-3-66) 
Cross reference— Garbage and trash collection charges to be billed with water and sewer charges, § 14-11.  
Sec. 37-40. - Collection agents. 
The director of the department of public works shall have authority to designate such person, partnership, association or corporation as he may deem to be qualified for the conduct of the business of the City of Pasadena, as agents of the City of Pasadena for the sole purpose of collecting such sums as may be due to the City of Pasadena for water, sewer and garbage charges subject to the following conditions: 
(a)  No fee or salary shall be paid to any such person or corporation for the services performed as such agent. 
(b)  Each such agent shall keep records of collections on forms provided by the City of Pasadena and approved by the city controller. 
(c)  Each such agent shall make a daily accounting of collections to the City of Pasadena and pay over each day's collection to the City of Pasadena. 
(d)  Each such agent shall deposit with the city secretary a surety bond in the amount of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) in such form as may be acceptable to the city attorney. 
(e)  No agent herein provided for shall be authorized to accept any payment except that it be made by an individual presenting a City of Pasadena water bill and payment be in the exact amount of said bill. 
(f)  No agent herein provided for shall be authorized to collect any delinquent bill. 
(Ord. No. 1805, § 10, 5-3-66; Ord. No. 79-166, § 1, 12-4-79)  
Sec. 37-41. - Due date; delinquencies; disputed charges. 
(a)  All bills for water, garbage, and sewer charges rendered by the city are due and payable within eighteen (18) days from the date of the bill, and if not paid within such period, the amount of the bill shall be increased by ten (10) per cent. Provided, however, that the water department shall waive the late penalty for governmental bodies. 
(b)  All customers with delinquent amounts will be notified in writing on their monthly statement of the date services will be terminated if said delinquent amounts are not paid in full. A customer with questions concerning a delinquent account may request a date for hearing with the City of Pasadena Water Billing Manager or designated representative. Nonpayment of all water, garbage, and sewer bills which remain due and owing after the due date shall be cause for the water to be cut off for delinquency as the city water department finds necessary, according to the purposes and terms of this chapter. In order to avoid service disconnection for a delinquent account, the customer must contact the water billing office prior to the service being disconnected and make arrangements to pay the charges. Water service which has been scheduled for disconnection or cut off for delinquency shall not be restored until all past due water, garbage, and sewer service bills, charges, fees, and penalties, if any, are paid in full by cash, money order, or credit card and until an additional or new deposit is paid bringing the deposit up to the present schedule, except that a water customer who has not had a delinquent bill during the preceding twelve (12) months shall not be required to place a new deposit. A fee of forty dollars ($40.00) shall be collected by the city if a customer's account is listed on the final disconnect for non-payment listing. This fee will be assessed even if the customer's services are not physically interrupted. No service shall be furnished to any person who is delinquent in the payment of any bill for water furnished on the premises to which water service is requested or to any other premises in the city. 
(c)  Disputed charges. A customer may advise the water billing office that a bill is in dispute by written notice or in person during normal business hours. A dispute must be registered with the city and a payment equal to the customer's average monthly usage at current rates must be received by the water billing office prior to the date of proposed discontinuance for a customer to avoid discontinuance of service. 
(Code 1964, § 29-37; Ord. No. 1805, § 9, 5-3-66; Ord. No. 1814, § 1, 5-31-66; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 81-208, § 2, 11-10-81; Ord. No. 83-222, § 1, 8-16-83; Ord. No. 84-222, § 2, 9-11-84; Ord. No. 86-98, § 12, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 93-138, § 1, 9-7-93; Ord. No. 00-36, § 2, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 01-183, § 6, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 05-85, § 1, 3-29-05; Ord. No. 07-269, § 2, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 10-074, §§ 14—17, 4-20-10; Ord. No. 12-135, § 4, 9-25-12; Ord. No. 16-041, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-16)  
Sec. 37-42. - Payment extensions; deferred payments. 
(a)  Partial payments/extensions of service. An extension of service for up to thirty (30) days will be granted if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The request is made in writing, on a form provided by the city; 
(2)  The written request is made prior to disconnection; 
(3)  The account has not been disconnected for nonpayment more than three times in the previous twelve (12) months; 
(4)  The customer pays twenty-five (25) per cent of the bill at the time of the extension request; 
(5)  In order to process such installment basis there shall be a fee of five dollars ($5.00) per extension of payment request, and such fee shall be payable as part of the extension payments; 
(6)  In addition, the city may waive the penalty amount on a delinquent bill if the customer meets the terms of the extension. 
The city may refuse to accept the payment for a part of such service unless the entire amount is paid in full or an extension agreement as described above is executed. 
(b)  Deferred payment plan. A deferred payment plan is any arrangement or agreement between the city and a customer in which an outstanding bill will be paid in installments. The water billing office may offer a deferred payment plan to any current customer with a previous balance owed the city for water, sewer and/or garbage service, except for a back billing resulting from diversion of service, unlawful use of service, or customer damage to city equipment. Under other circumstances in which the city determines are reasonable, the city may, but is not required to, enter into a deferred payment agreement with a customer. The following is required for a deferred payment plan: 
(1)  The agreement must be in writing and signed by the applicant and an authorized representative of the water billing office. 
(2)  The agreement shall require payment of the current bill plus twenty (20) per cent of the delinquent bill each month until the delinquent bill is paid. 
(3)  If a customer fails to meet the terms of a deferred payment agreement, the city may terminate service and is not required to offer another deferred payment agreement prior to termination. 
(4)  An administrative arrangement fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be added to an account whenever a payment arrangement agreement, providing for extension of payment amounts due on the account, is made. No account may obtain more than one (1) payment arrangement agreement per quarter and a payment arrangement agreement must be paid in full prior to requesting a new payment arrangement agreement. An account that is currently in a payment arrangement agreement status that becomes delinquent and is disconnected may not be reconnected until the account is paid in full. 
(5)  In addition, the city may waive the penalty amount on a deferred payment plan if customer meets the terms of the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 10-074, § 18, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-43. - Over billing/under billing. 
(a)  If the city determines an account is over billed, the city will refund or credit the account up to a maximum of eighteen (18) months. 
(b)  If any account is found to be on the wrong rate, the account will be adjusted back to the date when the account was set up with the wrong rate, up to a maximum of eighteen (18) months. 
(c)  If the city determines any account is undercharged, the city will back bill the customer for the amount that was undercharged. The back billing will not exceed eighteen (18) months, unless the undercharge is the result of meter tampering, bypassing, or an unmetered connection, or diversion by the customer. 
(d)  If the amount of the back billing is $50.00 or more, the city will offer the customer a deferred payment plan for the same length of time as that of the under billing. If the back billing is a result of utility service diversion, unlawful use of service, or damage to city equipment, the city may, but is not required to, offer the customer a deferred payment agreement. 
(e)  Wastewater charges will be adjusted in the same manner and for the same time period as water. 
(f)  All reimbursements or collections will be made at the rates in effect at the time of each over billing or under billing. No refund is required from the city except to the customer last served by the meter. 
(Ord. No. 10-074, § 19, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-44. - Failure to receive bill does not excuse nonpayment. 
The failure of any customer to receive a bill for water, garbage and sewer services shall not relieve him from the obligation to pay the amount due the city for such services nor waive penalty for failure to pay when due. 
(Code 1964, § 29-38; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 86-98, § 13, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 10-074, § 18, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-45. - Necessity of notice to discontinue levy. 
All rates and charges for water and sewer service to a customer's premises shall accrue and be levied against such customer until such time as written notice, given by the customer or by his duly authorized agent, to discontinue all service to the customer's premises is filed with the water division of the department of public works. Where service is supplied through more than one meter to a customer at the same premises, the customer may, upon written notice to the water division, permanently discontinue the service through one of the meters and thereafter be billed on the basis of the remaining services and meters. Upon receipt of written notice of such permanent discontinuance, the water division will disconnect the meter and service. Any service thus discontinued will be restored only at the total expense of the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 1805, § 11, 5-3-66; Ord. No. 10-074, § 19, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-46. - Miscellaneous water service charges. 
(a)  The following miscellaneous service charges shall be assessed and collected by the city water department for such services as are herein below described: 
(1)  The city will charge a returned payment fee, plus any direct charges assessed against the city by any financial institution, for each returned check, returned ACH draft, credit card or other form of payment that is dishonored or returned to the city ..... $30.00 
Payment of such water service shall then be made by cash, credit card, money order or cashier's check. 
(2)  Replacement of broken meter lock by the city ..... 25.00 
(3)  Repair by city of damage to meter locking device ..... 25.00 
(4)  Replacement by city of damage to meter cut-off ..... 35.00 
(5)  Reset by city of pulled meter: 
Not over 1 inch ..... 35.00 
1½ to 2 inches ..... 75.00 
All over 2 inches ..... 200.00 
(6)  Connection/transfer of new water service ..... 30.00 
Connection of service is done by the end of the following day. 
(7)  Same day service fee ..... 25.00 
If requested by the customer and upon payment in advance of a twenty-five dollars ($25.00) special service fee, service will be connected, transferred and/or closed by the end of the same working day. 
(8)  Collection/tagging fee ..... $20.00 
(9)  Delinquent service charge fee. If a customer's account is scheduled for disconnection for nonpayment, a charge of forty dollars ($40.00) shall be assessed if a customer's account is listed on the final disconnect for non-payment listing. This fee will be assessed even if the customer's services are not physically interrupted. 
(10)  After hour fee. If city personnel are called out within twenty (20) minutes of closing from the water billing's normal business hours or after normal business hours, to set a water meter or turn water on, a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) after-hour fee will be charged to the customer's account. The timing used will be a clock at the city's billing office as opposed to customer's watch. 
(11)  Multiple tenant notification for possible service discontinuance. When it is necessary to notify tenants of possible service discontinuance due to the delinquent payment(s) of a customer having a master meter serving four or more units, the customer will be assessed a charge of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per unit for posting the cutoff alerts. 
(12)  Processing of request by customer to keep information confidential or to rescind confidentiality ..... 2.00 
(13)  Re-read. The city will reread any customer's water meter at the customer's request. The first recheck will be at no charge to the customer. If another re-read is requested within a twelve-month period, a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee will be assessed if the meter was correctly read and there was no error on the part of the city. 
(14)  Damaged meters. If a meter is damaged as a result of vandalism, foul play or inadvertence, customer shall immediately notify the city of same so that repairs may be made. If the same customer experiences repeated manifestations of the preceding, then said customer may be subject to charges for meter repair. In the alternative, water service may be discontinued. 
(15)  Credit/debit card payment processing fees. Payments by credit card or electronic means (payment by "electronic means" means payment by telephone or computer but does not include payment in person or by mail - from § 132.001 of the Local Government Code), can be assessed a fee for processing the payment. At no time will such fee be more than five (5) per cent of the amount of the charge being paid. This processing fee will apply to recurring payments as well. 
(16)  Customer service inspection certification fee, required by TCEQ ..... 25.00 
a.  Any multi-unit premises will require the $25.00 fee plus an additional $20.00 per unit; and 
(17)  Re-inspection fee per failed unit ..... 20.00 
If the property does not pass the initial customer service inspection or for any non-unit related violations. 
(18)  If the designated representative does not keep the scheduled appointment or cancels the appointment before the inspector leaves for the appointment, a twenty dollar ($20.00) service charge shall apply. 
(b)  Any or all of the foregoing charges and fees may be included in a regular or special billing of the city water department and shall be in addition to all other charges, fees or penalties provided by this chapter. 
(c)  Provided, however, this section shall not apply to industrial district customers utilizing a one (1) inch or smaller water meter. Such industrial district customers shall meet all city requirements including the requirements of city commercial customers and shall be charged for water at the same rate as commercial customers within the city limits or at such rate as may be determined by the city. Furthermore, such customers shall not sell or transfer potable water received from the city to any other persons or entities and shall, within sixty (60) days of being offered a contract by the city, execute such water supply contract with the city. 
(d)  Water supplied to industrial users under the provisions of this section, whether or not provided by contract, may be terminated at the sole discretion of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1805, § 13, 5-3-66; Ord. No. 1814, § 2, 5-31-66; Ord. No. 72-110, § 1, 5-16-72; Ord. No. 78-5, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 83-336, § 2, 11-15-83; Ord. No. 86-98, § 14, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 94-1, § 10, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 93-138, § 2, 9-7-93; Ord. No. 00-36, § 3, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 01-183, § 7, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 04-156, § 2, 7-27-04; Ord. No. 10-074, §§ 20—25, 4-20-10; Ord. No. 12-135, § 5, 9-25-12; Ord. No. 16-041, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-16)  
Sec. 37-47. - Sale of water to industrial users. 
(a)  Sales of potable water for industrial uses for a monthly quantity for periods of time of at least five (5) years shall be made by special contracts authorized by city council. The sale of such potable water by special contracts shall be made in consideration of payment for a minimum monthly quantity of water during each month (called "minimum monthly quantity") and payment for water taken in excess of such minimum monthly quantity at the prices set forth in the block schedule below. The block schedule prescribes a minimum monthly quantity of water for which a customer must take and pay for during each month at the prices set forth in the block schedule. "MGM" is an abbreviation for "million gallons of water per month" and refers to a quantity of water during a calendar month. The unit of measure and sales unit for water shall be one thousand (1,000) gallons, U.S. Standard Liquid Measure. 
(b)  Base rates. The base rates for potable water delivered or contracted for in section 37-45 are as follows:

(c)  Provided, however, this section shall not apply to industrial district customers utilizing a one (1) inch or smaller water meter. Such industrial district customers shall meet all city requirements including the requirements of city commercial customers and shall be charged for water at the same rate as commercial customers within the city limits or at such rate as may be determined by the city. Furthermore, such customers shall not sell or transfer potable water received from the city to any other persons or entities and shall, within sixty (60) days of being offered a contract by the city, execute such water supply contract with the City of Pasadena. 
(d)  Water supplied to industrial users under the provisions of this section, whether or not provided by contract, may be terminated at the sole discretion of the city. 
(Ord. No. 76-119, § 1, 7-13-76; Ord. No. 83-346, § 1, 11-22-83; Ord. No. 84-159, § 2, 7-24-84; Ord. No. 86-98, § 15, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 98-211, § 1, 12-15-98; Ord. No. 01-94, 5-29-01; Ord. No. 02-81, § 1 3-12-02; Ord. No. 05-233, § 1, 9-20-05; Ord. No. 06-252, § 1, 10-17-06; Ord. No. 10-074, § 26, 4-20-10; Ord. No. 16-205, § 1(Exh. A), 1-3-17)  
Sec. 37-48. - Confidentiality of certain information of a customer. 
Upon written request of a customer, the address, telephone number or social security number of a customer will be kept confidential. This provision does not prohibit disclosing the personal information in a customer's account records to: 
(1)  An official or employee of the state or a political subdivision of the state, or the federal government acting in an official capacity; 
(2)  An employee of a utility acting in connection with the employee's duties; 
(3)  A consumer reporting agency; 
(4)  A contractor or subcontractor approved by and providing services to the utility or to the state, a political subdivision of the state, the federal government, or an agency of the state or federal government; 
(5)  A person for whom the customer has contractually waived confidentiality for personal information; or 
(6)  Another entity that provides water, wastewater, sewer, gas, garbage, electricity, or drainage service for compensation. 
(Ord. No. 93-99, § 1, 6-8-93; Ord. No. 93-138, § 3, 9-7-93; Ord. No. 10-074, § 27, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-49. - Annual adjustment of water and sewer rates. 
The rates to which this section applies shall be adjusted according to this provision and automatically increased each year on October 1 using the U.S. Consumer Price Index (CPI) for all Urban Consumers for the Houston-Galveston-Brazoria Texas Metropolitan Area published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The year over year percent change in the April index will be used as the basis for this charge. If there is a decrease in the CPI, or if there is no increase in the period measured, the rates then existing shall remain unchanged. 
(Ord. No. 16-040, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-16) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-040, § 1(Exh. A), adopted March 15, 2016, repealed the former § 37-49, and enacted a new § 37-49 as set out herein. The former § 37-49 pertained to sanitary sewer rehabilitation charge. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 37-50. - Liens on delinquent accounts. 
All delinquent accounts for water, garbage, and sewer services, as defined in section 37-41 of this Code, create a lien in favor of the city in the amount of the delinquency and all penalties and fees. The city may file, in the real property records of the county clerk's office, notice of lien on the property receiving the utility services, except in the case of a homestead protected by the Texas Constitution. A lien shall not apply to bills for service connected in a tenant's name after notice by the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 95-95, § 1, 3-28-95; Ord. No. 10-074, § 28, 4-20-10)  
Sec. 37-51. - Establishment and funding of a water/sewer reserve; permitted withdrawals. 
(a)  A reserve is hereby established, to be maintained by the city controller's office and to be designated as the water/sewer reserve (the reserve). 
(1)  The water/sewer reserve shall be accounted for in the water and sewer fund (system fund); 
(2)  Reserve should be maintained at ninety (90) days' worth of the prior fiscal year's expenditures; 
(3)  Contributions may vary from year to year when the water and sewer fund has produced a surplus after payment of all operation and maintenance expenses and debt service. 
(b)  Expenditures/withdrawals from the reserve: 
(1)  Withdrawals from the fund should be restricted to: 
a.  Make up for a severe shortfall in funds where projected revenues are not met, typically because of unusually wet weather or other unexpected negative influence on revenue stream; 
b.  Pay for catastrophic repair events of such magnitude that the cost of such would initiate an unplanned rate increase or a greater than planned rate increase (i.e. increases that would not have been needed if such event had not occurred); 
c.  Lessen a sharp rate increase necessitated by sudden increase in an uncontrollable, ongoing expense; or 
d.  To pay for capital improvement projects as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 16-041, § 1(Exh. A), 3-15-16)  
Secs. 37-52—37-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WATER AND SEWER MAIN EXTENSIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Permit not to issue for erection of sign on land on which water and sewer pro rata charges are past due, § 31-33. 
 
Sec. 37-56. - Definitions. 
Whenever the words, terms or phrases defined herein or pronouns used in their place occur in this article, the intent and meaning shall be interpreted as follows: 
Applicant: The owner of a lot or tract of land, or his agent, requesting water or sanitary sewer service. 
Consumer: The actual user of water or sanitary sewer service from a city connection. 
Developer: The owner or agent of the owner subdividing lots or tracts for sale or lease as homes, apartments, commercial shopping centers or industrial sites. 
Engineer: The director of public works, or his duly authorized assistants, agents, engineers or superintendents, acting within the scope of the particular duties entrusted to them. 
Evaluated cost: The cost of a water or sewer main as established by unit values for the size of main and appurtenances as established in this article. 
Individual owner: A person requesting extension of water or sewer service to a property which will be used as his own residence or business, or an individual commercial or industrial concern requesting extension of water or sewer service to property to be used for its own operation, which property or portion thereof will not be sold, leased or rented in connection with its intended function. 
Off-site main: Water or sewer mains totally outside of a tract of land to be subdivided and developed for resale. 
On-site main: Water or sanitary sewer mains which lie within a subdivision or along one or more sides of a subdivision and serve that subdivision exclusively. 
Over-size cost: The difference between the evaluated cost of the main as built and the evaluated cost of the size of main determined to be the minimum size required to serve the subdivision. The minimum size main upon which over-size cost shall be determined shall not be less than the standard main defined herein. 
Programmed extension: A water or sanitary sewer extension included in a master plan of the system design for which funds have been specifically provided in a properly authorized program of capital fund expenditures. 
Property owner: The record title holder of premises served or to be served with a connection to a city water or sanitary sewer main. 
Pro rata connection charge: A portion of the cost of water or sanitary sewer main extensions to serve the owner's property based upon the front footage to be served. The amount of these charges per front foot are stated in this article. 
Side main: Water or sanitary sewer mains which lie along one or more sides of a subdivision and serve adjacent property other than that for which the extension was made. 
Standard size sewer main: A sanitary sewer main eight (8) inches or larger in diameter. 
Standard size water main: A water main six (6) inches or larger in diameter, adequately supported by eight (8) inch or larger water mains to provide standard fire protection as recognized by the American Insurance Association, successor to the National Board of Fire Underwriters. 
Water division: The water division of the department of public works of the city. 
(Ord. No. 68-202, § 1-19, 11-19-68)  
Sec. 37-57. - Purpose of article; variation of method of determining charges. 
The intent and purpose of this article is to provide an equitable charge for water and sanitary sewer connections in the city on a front foot basis as a proportionable distribution of the cost of water and sanitary sewer main extensions to serve property not previously served with standard mains. In case property or a tract of land is so situated or shaped that the front foot rule creates an inequitable basis, as between it and other tracts of land in the city, then in that event the director of public works shall determine the proper charges in accord with the intent and purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 68-202, § 1-18, 11-19-68)  
Sec. 37-58. - Article does not grant vested rights. 
No person shall acquire any vested rights under the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 68-202, § 1-18, 11-19-68)  
Sec. 37-59. - Authority to make extensions. 
The department of public works may extend water and sanitary sewer mains in the streets, alleys and easements, within the city limits, in order to permit connection by persons desiring and seeking water service and sanitary sewer service. 
(Ord. No. 68-202, § 2-1, 11-19-68)  
Sec. 37-60. - Pro rata charge established. 
(a)  A charge, which shall be known as the "pro rata", shall be made against each lot or tract of land and the owner thereof, whose water or sewer line is connected with any water main or sanitary sewer main in the city, and the charge shall be at the following rates, which rates are a portion of the total cost of such water and sanitary sewer mains: 
(1)  One dollar and seventy-five cents ($1.75) per front foot of the lot or tract of land to which water connections may be made. 
(2)  Two dollars ($2.00) per front foot of the lot or tract of land to which sanitary sewer connections may be made. 
The above front foot rates shall apply to property fronting on streets in areas platted into the usual rectangular lots or tracts of land, with a depth not to exceed one hundred fifty (150) feet. (See Table 1) 
(b)  Where lots or tracts have greater depth than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the front street line, and are occupied or are to be occupied exclusively as single residential or duplex dwelling places, then additional depth shall not be assessed. If the property in question or adjacent property is later subdivided, requiring an extension of mains to serve the same and application is made for additional service to the property, then the terms of this article shall govern and apply to such property frontage as is created. (See Table 2) 
(c)  On lots or tracts of land which extend through from one street to another, with frontage on both streets, and where the distance between street lines is two hundred sixty (260) feet or more, then the pro rata charges herein provided for shall be paid on both frontages when a connection is secured to the lot or tract. (See Table 3) 
(d)  Where lots or tracts are irregular in size or shape, the pro rata charges shall be based upon equivalent rectangular lots or tracts, using one (1) front foot for each one hundred fifty (150) square feet of area, or the pro rata charges provided herein on the average frontage of such tracts, whichever is least. (See Table 4) 
(e)  Where lots or tracts are intended to be used for other than single residential or duplex purposes and have a depth greater than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the front street lines, then the pro rata herein provided shall be paid on the frontage on all streets which the property may abut, minus one hundred fifty (150) feet frontage for each corner of the property abutting a street intersection. Should such property be resubdivided whereby main extensions are required to serve same, the terms of this article shall apply. 
(f)  Where unsubdivided tracts of land are to be developed as a unit for shopping centers, apartment sites, industrial sites or other similar uses, the applicant will pay pro rata charges on street frontages as outlined for business properties. Any mains extended through or into such tracts for service to individual buildings or leased spaces will be built at the applicant's expense in accordance with section 37-62. In the case of standard mains being built in city streets or utility easements at the request of the city, refunds on such mains will be made to the applicant as outlined in sections 37-62 and 37-64. (See Table 5) 
(Ord. No. 68-202, § 2-1, 11-19-68)

Sec. 37-61. - Extensions for individual owners. 
(a)  Upon request of an applicant, and receipt of payment of the charges due, the department of public works shall extend, lay or construct all necessary sanitary sewer and water mains, including valves and hydrants, a distance of one hundred (100) feet, excluding streets, alleys, and the like, plus the distance across the frontage necessary to provide the service for which application has been made. The owners of all intervening property served by the given main extension will be required to pay the charges provided for in this article at such time as their property is connected to the mains thus laid. Where an applicant for service secures an extension and service under this particular option for main extension, he will pay the pro rata charges on all property owned by him and which is served by the extension requested. In applying the one hundred (100) foot rule, the required extension of the main shall be figured in such manner as to leave out of the calculations that portion of any main adjacent to property already having other than a temporary water service, and for which the pro rata charges thereon have been paid or credited under the terms of this article. (See Tables 6 and 7) 
(b)  An exception to the above one hundred (100) foot rule shall be made where two (2) or more individual applicants desire water or sanitary sewer service and the nearest applicant is more than one hundred (100) feet from existing mains. In such case, the city shall extend their mains upon receipt of payment of the charges due under this article, provided there is one (1) customer for every one hundred (100) feet of such extension, excluding street intersections and that portion of the extension adjacent to property already having other than temporary water or sanitary sewer service. (See Table 8) 
(c)  At the option of the city, the following method for extending water and sanitary sewer mains may be used where the applicant's property is more than one hundred (100) feet from an existing water or sanitary sewer main. This method shall be available only for use by an individual owner, personal or corporate, to secure water and sanitary sewer service for the individual's residence or business. Where eligible for this option, the applicant may advance and pay to the city the entire pro rata costs as set forth in this article on all property served by the desired main extension, less the one hundred (100) feet allowable, and the city, when such money has been actually deposited with the director of public works, will construct the desired water or sanitary sewer main along a street, alley or easement. When any property for which such person has advanced the pro rata costs is connected to such main extension, then, in that event, the pro rata advanced on both sides of the street for the frontage of the connecting property shall be refunded by the city to the applicant making the original deposit. At such time as sufficient frontage is connected so that the original applicant who advanced total pro rata should be eligible for extension under the provisions of this article, such applicant will be refunded the remainder advanced except for the charges due on the property for which the extension was originally made. (See Table 9) 
(d)  Where an extension is requested by an industry or commercial concern using large quantities of water and which cannot meet the requirements of one (1) customer per one hundred (100) feet, the extension may be made at the discretion of the city, provided forty (40) per cent of the estimated annual revenue from such customer will support interest and principal payments on the total cost of the extension required to serve. 
(e)  Should property be rental or leased property, the city is authorized to refuse service on the property or to discontinue service to any or all properties owned by, or places served in the name of, the owner until the property owner makes satisfactory arrangements with the city under the terms of this article to pay the applicable pro rata. 
(Ord. No. 68-202, §§ 2-2, 3-2, 11-19-68)
