Hydrocarbon means any chemical substance consisting in whole or in part of a combination of hydrogen chemically bonded to carbon and particularly those hydrocarbons, but not exclusively, produced from mining, drilling, distillation, or refining and generally known as fuels, oils, and lubricants used to propel and lubricate vehicles and commonly known as gas, oil, and grease, excluding, however, those hydrocarbon substances in use as paving material and painting. 
Health director means the director of health of the City of Pasadena, Texas or a person designated by the health director. 
Illicit connection means any man-made conveyance connecting an illicit discharge directly to a municipal separate storm sewer. 
Illicit discharge is defined at 40 CPR 122.25 (b) (2). 
MS4 is an acronym for "municipal separate storm sewer system" and is used to refer to either a large or medium municipal separate storm sewer system. 
Mayor means the mayor of the City of Pasadena, Texas or a person designated by the mayor. 
Municipal separate storm system (MS4) means a system of conveyance (including storm drains, gutters, ditches, man-made channels, impoundments, roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, storm sewer manholes, pumping or treatment facilities, private drains and any other drainage devises) designed or used for collecting and conveying storm water and surface water drainage to the bays and natural tributaries, which is not part of a publicly-owned treatment works (POTW), as defined at 40 CFR 122.2, that is owned or operated by the City of Pasadena or a utility organized by the city. The MS4 includes any other publicly or privately owned structures or improvements that drain into or connect with the system owned or operated by the city that is located within the incorporated limits of the City of Pasadena or within five thousand (5,000) feet of the city limits, unless it is under the jurisdiction and control of any state agency that regulates water quality or water pollution. 
Permittee refers to any "person", as defined at 40 CFR 122.2, authorized by this NPDES permit to discharge to waters of the United States. 
Point source means any discernible, confined, and discrete conveyance, including but not limited to, any pipe, ditch, channel, tunnel, conduit, wall, discrete fissure, container, rolling stock, concentrated animal feeding operation, landfill leachate collection system, vessel or other floating craft from which pollutants are or may be discharged. This term does not include return flows from irrigated agriculture or agricultural storm water runoff. 
SWMP is an acronym for "storm water management program". 
Storm sewer, unless otherwise indicated, refers to a municipal separate storm sewer. 
Storm water means any flow occurring during, following or resulting from any form of natural precipitation, including snowbelt. 
Storm water discharge associated with industrial activity is defined at 40 CFR 122.26 (b) (14). 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99; Ord. No. 12-156, § 5, 10-16-12)  
Sec. 37-217. - Prohibited discharges into the MS4. 
It is unlawful and no person may intentionally knowingly, recklessly, or with criminal negligence to commit or allow an of the following acts: 
(a)  Blow, sweep, throw or deposit or store in a manner which would allow to wash or flow into the municipal storm sewer system any straw, hay, grass, grass clippings, trees, limbs, trimmings, weeds, branches, leaf litter, dirt and other fill material, construction material, demolition material, garbage, debris or any other substance. It shall be defense to prosecution that these wastes occurred naturally or from normal landscape maintenance (e.g., leaves falling from trees, grass clippings left on lawns); 
(b)  An illicit discharge (e.g. a discharge of other than storm water), including artesian well water, cooling water (including contact and non-contact cooling water and treated and untreated cooling water), ground water, subsurface drainage, industrial wastewater, water from a well; 
(c)  An illegal discharge (e.g., a discharge of any substance that is prohibited from being discharged into the water of the United States or the State of Texas, or a tributary to those waters, by any federal or state law); 
(d)  A direct discharge of a pesticide or fertilizer; 
(e)  A pollutant or wastewater, other than storm water or a discharge that is not classified as an illicit discharge in subsections (b) and (c) (1) of this section, that is prohibited from being discharged into the publicly owned treatment works (POTW) by section 37-11 through 37-15 (a) of this chapter; 
(f)  To dispose of hydrocarbons or absorbent material by washing or otherwise allowing them to enter the public streets, bayous, drainage channels, or storm sewers of the City of Pasadena. 
(g)  To prevent entry into the public streets, bayous, drainage channels, and storm sewers of the city all hydrocarbon spills or accumulation shall be removed with absorbent materials. The absorbent material and the absorbed hydrocarbon shall be disposed of properly in trash containers or dumpsters in accordance with the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pasadena, Texas or other proper method of disposal as provided by any regulatory authority having jurisdiction thereof. 
(h)  Solid wastes, including animal wastes (including an animal carcass, animal parts or scrap, excrement, grease of animal origin, offal, paunch manure and urine), ashes or clinkers, construction/demolition materials, dirt or other fill materials, debris, asphalt, floatables, garbage, heavy brush, heavy trash, automobiles, packing materials, crates, shopping carts, car parts, household appliances, household hazardous waste from chemicals or other substances utilized for residential or housekeeping purposes, including, but not limited to, bleaches, drain cleaners, paint, paint thinners, and solvents), industrial or commercial wastes, medical wastes refuse sewage, used motor vehicle fluids, (including motor oils, anti-freeze, brake fluids, transmission fluids, and other lubricants that have been drained from or any excess materials remaining after servicing a vehicle or piece of equipment including any absorbent material), yard waste (including grass clippings, weeds, leaves, mulch, trees, and shrub limbs, trimmings, or other plant material); 
(i)  Over spray and amounts of runoff from irrigation of vegetation that pools in a gutter or on a road surface, or flows in a steady stream into any manhole or catch basin, is considered an illicit discharge into the municipal separate storm sewage system; 
(j)  It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution for a violation of this section that the discharge was: 
(1)  Swimming pool water shall not be prohibited discharge, provided that the discharge has been tested using a method approved by the director to assure that it will not contain a harmful level of chlorine or other pollutants when it reaches streams, lakes or bays. 
(2)  The following discharges may be put into the municipal separate storm sewer system a discharge under a valid national pollution discharge elimination system (NPDES) permit when properly implemented, a discharge resulting from fire fighting activities, a discharge resulting from washing an automobile at a residence or at a charitable car wash maximum of two (2) per year per location each day counting as a separate occurrence, a discharge of potable water, a discharge of any surface waters (including water from diverted stream flows, uncontaminated rising ground water, water from foundation drains, crawl space pumps and footing drains, water from springs, and flows from riparian habitats and wetlands), a discharge resulting from flushing a water supply line when approved by the director, a discharge of street wash water, a nonpoint source discharge from agricultural activities (including return flows from irrigated agriculture); or condensate from cooling systems. 
(3)  An illicit discharge is considered uncontaminated if in the opinion of the director the quality of the water is equal to or better than the quality of the first natural body of water into which a portion of the municipal separate storm sewage system flows (receiving waters), including the Armand Bayou, Vince Bayou, Little Vince Bayou, Boggy Bayou, Horsepen Bayou, Lake Pasadena, Clear Lake, Cotton Patch Bayou, Houston Ship Channel and Galveston Bay. The results of the last water quality test of the receiving waters published by the director of public works with the city secretary will constitute prima facie evidence of the quality of the receiving waters. 
(4)  Nothing in this article prevents the placement of solid wastes scheduled for pickup at a location designated by the sanitation superintendent. 
(5)  Runoff from any effort to remove graffiti from buildings or other structures is not considered an illicit discharge into the municipal separate storm sewer system. 
(6)  Nothing in this section prohibits any activities relating to the construction, maintenance, or operation of the municipal separate storm sewage system. 
(7)  Notwithstanding subsection (c) of this section, a person may discharge any substance or material specified, if at the time of discharge, the discharge of the substance or material was authorized by a valid permit from the Texas Natural Resource Commission or United States Environmental Protection Agency and the discharge was in compliance with all requirements contained in the permit. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-218. - Removal of improper discharge from and repair of damage to MS4. 
(a)  Any person who discharges any substance or article into the MS4 in violation of section 37-217 of this article shall promptly remove the substance or article from the MS4, take all measures necessary to reduce or eliminate any harmful effects for any substance or article that cannot be removed, repair any damage caused to the MS4 by the substance or article, and compensate the city for any additional expenses it was caused to incur as a result of the illegal or illicit discharge. 
(b)  If any person who discharged the substance or article into the MS4 fails to remove the substance or article within ten (10) days after receiving notice as provided in Section 342.006 (b) of the Texas Health and Safety Code, the mayor may have the substance or article removed from the MS4 and any damages to the MS4 repaired at the expense of the person who discharged the substance or article. 
(c)  The mayor may remove any substance or article from the MS4 without notice to the person who discharged the substance or article into the MS4, when directed to do so by the federal or state on-scene coordinator, under the Act; the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, as amended; the Oil Spill Prevention and Response Act; or Texas Oil Land Hazardous Substances Sill Prevention and Control Act. The person who discharged the substance or article is liable for all costs incurred by the city as a result of the discharge. 
(d)  A person is presumed to have discharged a substance or thing into the MS4 if the substance or article contains any writing or other marking indicating that the person is the owner of the thing or has had possession of the thing. However, a person who manufactured or offered the item for sale to the public, which is marked with a trade name, is not presumed to have discharged the item if found in the MS4. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the director may temporarily disconnect any connection with the MS4, in order to prevent the continuing discharge of oil, a hazardous substance, sewage, or any other substance that poses an imminent health or safety threat to the community into the MS4. The person who discharged the substance is liable for all costs incurred by the city under this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-219. - Prohibited connections with MS4. 
(a)  It is unlawful and no person may construct, maintain, or use, or cause or allow to be constructed, maintained or used, any drain from private property into a public street or any drain that connects with the MS4, unless the person has applied for a building or plumbing permit for the connection and obtained a permit from the building official with approval from the director. 
(b)  Any person in apparent control of any property in the city, who is maintaining any connection, or causing or allowing any connection to be maintained that does not conform with the provisions of this section or any other applicable provision of the city's Code of Ordinances shall be deemed to be maintaining a prohibited connection and such shall be deemed a prima facie violation of this chapter and, upon notice in writing from the Director, must remove the drain or obtain the required permits and make any modifications necessary for the drain to conform to the requirements of this section and any other applicable provisions of the city's Code of Ordinances. 
(c)  Upon receipt of written notice, the person in apparent control of any property in the city has five (5) working days to request a timely meeting with the director. The purpose of the meeting will be to establish a schedule, setting out when the drain will be removed or made to conform with the provisions of this section. In no event may the schedule allow for a time period greater than six (6) months to remove the drain or bring the drain into conformance with this section. 
(d)  The director is authorized to execute schedules in writing. 
(e)  A violation of the schedule constitutes a violation of this article, and each day beyond the scheduled time of removal or repair constitutes an separate violation of this article. 
(f)  For purposes of this article, any person in whose name a water meter connection is registered for servicing the private property, is presumed to be the person in apparent control of the property. Proof that the property in question has a water meter connection registered in the name of the defendant named in a criminal complaint filed under this article constitutes prima facie evidence to support the presumption that the person in whose name such water connection is registered is the person who permitted or allowed a prohibited connection under this section. 
(g)  In the event a person in apparent control of any property in the city, upon receipt of the notice requirement set out in section 37-216(b), fails to remove the drain or make the drain conform in every respect to the requirements of this section and any other applicable provisions of the city's Code of Ordinances, and in addition to any other remedies set out in this article, the city may disconnect the prohibited connection from the MS4 and charge the costs of the disconnection to the person in apparent control of the property from which the prohibited connection originates. 
(h)  In the event the prohibited connection is deemed a health problem by the Texas Health Director, under section 432.007 of the Health and Safety Code, the city may attach a lien on the property from which the prohibited connection originates. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-220. - Annual report, NPDES compliance monitoring, inspection, and sampling. 
(a)  The holder of a NPDES permit shall annually report its federal compliance status to the director of public works on forms provided by the city. 
(1)  it shall be the duty of every holder of a NPDES permit to notify the city of the existence of such permit by providing the director of public works a copy of the permit upon receipt by the permittee. 
(2)  Holders of either federal NPDES permits or state NPDES permits, and persons who facilities connect to the MS4 under written authority of the city, shall report to the director of public works any spill, release, or event for which the holder was required to notify the National Response Center (NRC), TNRCC, or Texas General Land Office (TGLO) within reasonable time of the report to the NRC, TNRCC, or TGLO. 
(3)  The director of public works has the authority to demand to see any NPDES permits held by the owner or operator of a business facility. The director of public works may enter a business facility to investigate and make determination whether such business facility is subject to NPDES permitting requirements. 
(4)  It is unlawful and a violation of this article if a business facility required to have a NPDES permit operates without a NPDES permit. 
(b)  The director of public works or persons designated by the mayor may enter any business facility during hours in which the business facility is open for business or is operating or is discharging into the MS4 to ascertain whether there is a violation of this article. The owner or operator of a business facility must allow the director of public works or persons designated by the mayor ready access to all parts of the business facility for the purpose of inspection, sampling, records examination and copying and the performance of any additional duties. 
(1)  Where a business facility has security measures in force that require proper identification and clearance before entry into the business facility, the owner or operator shall make necessary arrangements with its security guards so that, upon presentation of suitable identification, personnel from the city, state and federal agencies are permitted to enter without delay, for the purposes of performing their specific responsibilities. 
(2)  City, state and federal agencies have the right to set on the business facility any device necessary to sample and/or meter any discharge or to detect any illegal or illicit discharge into the MS4. 
(3)  The director of public works may require the owner or operator of a business facility to install monitoring equipment, as necessary. The business facility's sampling and monitoring equipment must be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the owner or operator of the business facility at the owner's or operator's expense. 
(4)  Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to a business facility to be inspected and/or sampled must be promptly removed by the owner or operator at the written or verbal request of the mayor and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be born by the owner or occupant. 
(5)  Unreasonable delays in allowing city personnel access to residence or business facility is a violation of this article. 
(6)  Hours of operation of the business facility and times during which the facility is discharging into the MS4 are deemed reasonable hours for entry of city, state or federal inspectors for the purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-221. - Other enforcement actions authorized. 
(a)  Upon the written certification by the mayor or the director of a violation of any section of this article, the city attorney is authorized to petition any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction to enjoin the continued violations. This remedy is cumulative of all other enforcement powers granted to the city by the terms of its charter, any ordinance or by the laws of the state. 
(b)  In the event the responsibility and maintenance of the MS4 is transferred from the City of Pasadena to another public utility, such utility, upon approval of its board, is also authorized to petition any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction to enjoin the violation of this article upon the written certification of the violation of a provision by an authorized representative of the governing body of such utility. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-222. - Collection of expenses; liens, suit. 
The mayor shall file statements of expenses incurred under sections 37-210, 37-211, 37-216 and 37-217, giving the amount of such expenses, the date on which such work was done and a description of the property upon which such work was done or improvements made with the county clerk of the county. The city has a privileged lien on such lot or real estates upon which such work was done or improvements made to secure the expenditures so made, under section 342.007 of the Texas Health and Safety Code, which lien is second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements, and such amount bears ten (10) per cent interest from the date the statement was filed. For any such expenditures and interest, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure of such lien may be had in the name of the city, and the statement of expenses so made, or a certified copy of the statement, is prima facie proof of the amount expended for such work or improvements. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-223. - Special warrants. 
Under Article 18.05, Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, if the director has been refused access to a building facility or residence, or any part thereof, and if such official can demonstrate (1) probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this ordinance and (2) that there is a need to inspect as part of a routine inspection program of the city designed to verify compliance with this ordinance, or any permit or order issued under this ordinance, to protect the overall public health, safety and welfare of the community, then upon application by the city attorney, through an enforcement official, the municipal court judge of the city shall issue a search and/or seizure warrant describing therein the specific location subject to the warrant. The warrant shall specify what, if anything, may be searched and/or seized on the property described. Such warrant shall be served at reasonable hours by the code enforcement official in the company of a uniformed police officer of the city. Hours during business operation or during permittee's discharge to the MS4, if there be a permit, shall be presumed reasonable hours of access. In the case of a suspected unpermitted discharge, or discharge from a domestic source, the municipal court judge shall make determination of reasonable hours for entry. In the event of any emergency affecting public health and safety, inspections shall be made without the issuance of a warrant. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-224. - Conflicts with other laws. 
Nothing in this article is intended nor shall any part or portion hereof be construed so as to conflict with any applicable provisions of the Texas Health and Safety Code, or Texas Water Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 37-225. - Penalties. 
(a)  A violation of any provision of this chapter is a class C misdemeanor. A conviction is punishable by a fine as provided in section 37-205 of this Code. Each day a violation continues constitutes a separate offense. Each violation of a separate provision in this article constitutes a separate offense. A culpable mental state is not required to prove an offense under this ordinance. 
(b)  If the person violating any of the provisions of this article is a corporation, the president, vice-president, secretary or treasurer of the corporation or any manager, agent or employee of the corporation responsible for the management of the property where the violation occurred is severally liable for any penalty. 
(c)  Failure to appear in response to a citation issued for violation of this chapter is a separate violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 99-204, § 2, 11-2-99)  
Secs. 37-226—37-240. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - LIQUID WASTE GENERATORS AND TRANSPORTERS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 37-241. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Company shall mean anyone owning or operating one (1) or more liquid waste transporter vehicles. 
Disposal site shall mean a permitted site or part of a site at which grease interceptor waste, grit interceptor waste is processed, treated and/or intentionally placed into or on any land in a manner compliant with all applicable federal, state and local regulations, and at which site said waste will remain after closure. 
Disposer shall mean a person who receives, stores, retains, processes or disposes of liquid waste. 
Fats, oils, and grease (FOG) shall mean the organic polar compounds derived from animal and/or plant sources that contain multiple carbon chain triglyceride molecules. These substances are detectable and measurable using analytical test procedures established in 40 CRF 136, as may be amended from time to time. All are sometimes referred to herein as "grease" or greases." 
Generator shall mean any person who owns or operates a grease trap or grease interceptor, or whose act or process produces a grease trap waste. The generator is responsible for assuring that the produced waste is disposed of in accordance with federal, state and local disposal regulations. 
Grease trap shall mean a device designed to use differences in gravities to separate and retain light density liquids, waterborne fats, oils and greases prior to the wastewater entering the sanitary sewer collection system. These devices also serve to collect settleable solids, generated by and from food preparation activities, prior to the water exiting the trap and entering the sanitary sewer collection system. 
Grease trap waste shall mean material collected in and from a grease trap in the sanitary sewer service line of a commercial, institutional or industrial food service or processing establishment, including the solids resulting from de-watering processes. 
Incompatible wastes shall mean wastes which have different processing, storage or disposal requirements. 
Liquid waste transporter shall mean a person who is registered with and authorized by the TCEQ to transport grit trap waste and grease trap waste. 
Manifest/trip ticket shall mean the written, multi-part documentation required to be in the possession of the transporter enabling disposal of hauled grit trap waste or grease trap waste at a permitted or registered disposal site. 
Permit shall mean a valid Liquid Waste Transporter Permit issued by the City of Pasadena Health Department. 
POTW or publicly owned treatment works shall mean a treatment works which is owned by a state or municipality as defined by section 502 (4) of the Clean Water Act. This definition includes a devices and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature. It also includes all sewers, pipes and other conveyances that convey wastewater to a POTW Treatment Plant. The term also means the municipality as defined in section 502 (4) of the Act, which has jurisdiction over the indirect discharges to and the discharges from such a treatment works. For purposes of this ordinance, the terms "sanitary sewer system" and "POTW" may be used interchangeably. 
Regulatory authority shall mean the director of the City of Pasadena Health Department or their duly authorized representative. 
TCEQ shall mean the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
DIVISION 2. - TRANSPORTERS 
 
Sec. 37-242. - Accumulation of liquid waste prohibited. 
A person commits an offense if he allows liquid waste to accumulate upon property under his control that emits noxious or offensive odors, is unsanitary, injurious to the public health or is deleterious to the environment. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-243. - Restricted disposal of liquid waste. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if they unload or offer for sale or exchange liquid waste, except at a place approved by the city and permitted by the state or federal government. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if they deposit or discharge liquid waste onto a street or into a storm or sanitary sewer or an area that drains into a storm system. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-244. - Tampering with monitoring device. 
No person may falsify, tamper with or knowingly render inaccurate any monitoring device or method required to be maintained under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-245. - Permit required; application. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if they operate or cause to be operated a vehicle for the purpose of transporting liquid waste without an applicable permit. A permit shall be issued for transportation of liquid waste. A separate vehicle permit number shall be issued for each vehicle operated. Excluded from this division are vehicles which operate within the city solely for the purpose of transporting liquid waste through the city and where no liquid waste is received, unloaded, stored or parked within the city and vehicles owned or operated by the city or vehicles operated for the city with the permission of the regulatory authority. 
(b)  A person who desires to obtain a permit must make application by legibly completing a form provided by the regulatory authority. 
(c)  Each driver shall submit to the regulatory authority at the time of application a photocopy of his or her driver's license. 
(d)  The regulatory authority shall not issue a permit unless the applicant submits for an inspection by the regulatory authority the vehicle the applicant proposes to use to transport liquid waste and the vehicle is found by the regulatory authority to be constructed and equipped in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(e)  The regulatory authority shall not issue a permit unless the applicant submits proof of current registration with TCEQ. 
(f)  Each applicant must specify in writing with application of the disposal site to be used for the authorized disposal of liquid waste. The approving authority shall be immediately notified of additional disposal sites used during the permit period. 
(g)  A permit issued by the city excludes the hauling of incompatible waste, hazardous waste material and prohibits the commingling of hazardous waste and non-hazardous waste. 
(h)  Waste materials to be recycled for other commercial uses such as but not limited to waste motor oil and waste cooking oil, are not required to be manifested or permitted under this chapter, but shall be stored collected and transported in and through the city in conditions that are sanitary, free from odors and which will not adversely affect the environment. 
(i)  Prior to the issuance of a permit, the applicant must provide to the City of Pasadena Health Department, evidence of a policy of automobile liability insurance and thereafter keep same in full force and effect with an insurance company authorized to do business in the state. The policy shall insure the public against any loss or damage that may result to any person property from the operation of a defective vehicle or negligence of the owner or any person of such policy shall provide a minimum amount of coverage in the policy as to each and every transporter vehicle to be not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death of any one person, for bodily injury or death in any one accident, for the damage to, or destruction of, property in any one accident. Coverage is to include the pollution liability endorsement with limits not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). Such coverage shall be endorsed to cover the upset, overturn, and remediation of the load in transport. The certificate of insurance required by this subsection shall contain a provision requiring that the City of Pasadena Health Department be provided with thirty (30) days advance notice, in writing, of cancellation or material change in the policy. In the event of cancellation or material change in the transporter's policy, the permit shall be suspended until such time as the transporter can again secure appropriate coverage. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-246. - Fee; display of permit. 
(a)  A permit shall not be issued until the appropriate established fee is paid. The fee for a permit required by this division shall be a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per company and one-hundred dollars ($100.00) per transport vehicle. Such fee shall be paid prior to issuance of the initial permit and upon renewal of such license each year thereafter. A transporter operating in the city without a valid permit shall be required to pay the full annual fee. The permit shall expire on the fifteenth day of July and must be renewed annually. 
(b)  Renewal applications received after the expiration date shall be charged an additional twenty-five dollar ($25.00) late fee. Permits are not transferable and the permit fee is not refundable. 
(c)  Each permit holder shall cause to be displayed in the lower right corner of the front windshield a current permit sticker. 
(d)  Each permit holder shall have the following information on both sides of the vehicle in a color contrasting with the background, in three inch high letters or larger: company name, TCEQ (Texas Commission on Environmental Quality) registration number, telephone number and tank capacity in gallons. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-247. - Liquid waste transporter vehicle; inspection and maintenance. 
(a)  A liquid waste transporter vehicle shall be inspected by the regulatory authority prior to the issuance of a vehicle permit with qualifications as follows: 
(1)  Tank shall be at fifty (50) per cent capacity upon inspection and have a functional volume measuring or an indicating device accessible during inspection of vehicle; 
(2)  Use a vehicle with a single tank capacity of not less than five hundred (500) gallons. The tank shall be an integral portion of the liquid waste transport vehicle; portable tanks or other containers temporarily installed in vehicles are prohibited; 
(3)  Piping, valves and connectors shall be permanently attached to the tank and/or vehicle; 
(4)  Tank shall be liquid tight; 
(5)  Tank shall be constructed so that every interior and exterior portion can be easily cleaned; 
(6)  Piping, valves and connectors shall be accessible and easy to clean; 
(7)  Inlet or opening of tank shall be constructed so that collected waste will not spill during filling, transfer or transport; 
(8)  Outlet connections shall be constructed so that no liquid waste will leak, run or spill out from the vehicle; 
(9)  Outlets shall be of a design and type suitable for the liquid waste handled and capable of controlling flow or discharge without spillage or undue spray on or flooding of immediate surroundings while in use; 
(10)  Pumps, valves, cylinders, diaphragms and other appurtenances shall be of a design and type suitable for the type of waste handled, capable of operation without spillage, spray or leakage and capable of being easily disassembled for cleaning. 
(b)  A liquid waste transporter shall: 
(1)  Maintain hoses, tanks, valves, pumps, cylinders, diaphragms, pipes, connections and other appurtenances on a vehicle in good repair and free from leaks; 
(2)  Provide a safety plug or cap for each valve of a tank; and 
(3)  Cause a vehicle exterior to be clean and odor free at the beginning of each work day. 
(c)  The regulatory authority may cause to be impounded a vehicle which is being operated in violation of this chapter, and to authorize the holding of the vehicle until the violation(s) is corrected. The regulatory authority may also revoke the permit for an improperly operated vehicle. If a vehicle is impounded or a permit is revoked, an appeal may be filed by the transporter pursuant to the appeals section of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-248. - Responsibilities of liquid waste transporters. 
(a)  Before accepting a load of liquid waste for transportation, a liquid waste transporter shall determine the nature of the material to be transported and that his equipment is sufficient to properly handle the job without spillage, leaks of release of toxic or harmful gases, fumes, liquids or other substances. Upon delivery of the waste to the disposer, the transporter shall inform the disposer of the nature of the waste. 
(b)  Hazardous waste or hazardous waste in conjunction with non-hazardous waste shall not be transported in any vehicle permitted by this chapter. 
(c)  A transporter holding a city permit must use a disposal site permitted by the state or federal government for disposal of non-hazardous liquid waste. 
(d)  At no time shall a transporter commingle incompatible wastes in any transport vehicle. 
(e)  A manifest system, consisting of a five part trip ticket is used to document the generation, transportation and disposal of all applicable liquid waste generated in the city and shall be used as follows: 
(1)  City of Pasadena trip ticket books will be used exclusively for individual vehicles. One trip ticket book shall be issued annually to each permitted vehicle upon inspection and approval by the regulatory authority. In the event additional trip ticket books are needed during a current permit year, books shall be purchased from the City of Pasadena Health Department. 
(2)  A transporter will legibly complete one trip ticket for each location serviced. 
(3)  The original top copy of a trip ticket shall be legibly signed by the transporter and the generator at the time of waste collection and the second copy maintained by the generator. 
(4)  The original top copy of a trip ticket shall be legibly signed by the disposer at the time of disposal and the third copy maintained by the disposer. 
(5)  The fourth copy of a trip ticket shall be maintained by the transporter. 
(6)  The fifth copy of the completed trip ticket shall be delivered to the generator. 
(7)  The original top copy of the trip ticket shall be delivered, at least monthly, by the transporter to the regulatory authority. 
(8)  All voided trip tickets must be returned within one month of voiding to the City of Pasadena Health Department and missing tickets shall be explained in writing. 
(9)  A legible copy of all trip tickets shall be maintained for a period of three (3) years and shall be made available to the regulatory authority or their representative for inspections during normal business hours. 
(f)  A transporter or any person servicing a grease trap shall remove the entire contents of the collection device. Skimming the surface layer of waste material, partial cleaning of the trap or use of any method which does not remove the entire contents of the trap is prohibited. 
(g)  A transporter shall: 
(1)  Maintain sanitary conditions in area where picking up liquid waste and assure that area is free of litter and odor free; 
(2)  Report spills of liquid waste to the regulatory authority immediately; and 
(3)  Clean up all spills and abate unsanitary conditions immediately, and have all materials used to mitigate the spill disposed of by approved means. 
(h)  For compliance and tracking purposes, a transporter shall, upon submission, provide to the regulatory authority: 
(1)  Past or current routes or schedules of a vehicle's full daily operation; 
(2)  Notice, prior to operation in the city, of the time and location of the vehicle's operation; and 
(3)  A grab sample of transported waste. The sample shall be analyzed at an accredited lab and required sampling shall be at the expense of the operator. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-249. - Denial, suspension and revocation of permit. 
(a)  The regulatory authority may deny a permit if it is determined that an applicant for a liquid waste transporter's permit is not qualified under any section of this chapter and may suspend or revoke a permit if it is determined that a permitee: 
(1)  Is not qualified under any section of this chapter; 
(2)  Has violated or failed to comply with a provision of this chapter; or 
(3)  Has failed to maintain a vehicle in safe working order as evidenced by conviction or statutory violations. 
(b)  The regulatory authority may revoke for a period of one year or less all permits held by a liquid waste transporter, if the transporter or an employee of the transporter violates any provisions of this chapter, any rule or regulation promulgated by the regulatory authority, or applicable provisions of the City Code or state law. 
(c)  A permitee whose permit is suspended or revoked shall not collect, transport or dispose of any waste material within the city limits of the City of Pasadena. 
(d)  After suspension under this section, a permitee may file a request for reinstatement of the permit. When the regulatory authority determines that the permitee is again qualified, all violations have been corrected, precautions have been taken to prevent future violations, and all required fees have been paid, the permit may be reinstated. 
(e)  After denial of a permit application, suspension or revocation of a permit, the applicant or permit holder shall not be entitled to any refund of fees. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-250. - Penalties. 
Any violation of the article is a class "C" misdemeanor and will result in a fine, upon conviction, of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2000.00). Each day a violation under this chapter exists will be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-251. - Appeal. 
If the regulatory authority denies the issuance of or revokes a permit, the department shall send to the applicant, or permit holder, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his/her action and the right to an appeal. The applicant, or permit holder, may appeal the decision of the regulatory authority to the city council. Any appeal must be filed with the regulatory authority, in writing, within ten days of notice of the action taken. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
DIVISION 3. - GENERATORS 
 
Sec. 37-252. - Operations. 
(a)  Facilities generating fats, oils, or greases as a result of food manufacturing, processing, preparation, or food service shall install, use, and maintain appropriate grease traps or interceptors as required in section 37-253 of this chapter. These facilities include but are not limited to restaurants, food manufacturers, food processors, hospitals, hotels and motels, nursing homes, and any other facility preparing, serving, or otherwise making any foodstuff available for consumption. 
(b)  No user may intentionally or unintentionally allow the direct or indirect discharge of any petroleum oil, non-biodegradable cutting oil, mineral oil, or any fats, oils, or greases of animal or vegetable origin into the POTW system in such amounts as to cause interference with the collection and treatment system, or as to cause pollutants to pass through the treatment works into the environment. 
(c)  All operations, maintenance and installations must comply with City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances, Chapter 29, Plumbing Code. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-253. - Responsibilities of liquid waste generators. 
(a)  Grease traps shall be constructed to prevent fats, oils or greases from entering the sanitary sewer. The standards for allowable legal limits shall be as they now exist or as they may from time to time be altered, in the City of Pasadena Code of Ordinances Chapter 37, Article V. Grease traps shall be located so that they are easily accessible for cleaning, maintenance, and inspection. The size and installation of grease traps shall comply with the requirements of the City of Pasadena Plumbing Code. 
(b)  A generator shall install a sample port on the discharge side of the grease trap to allow for sampling of the grease trap effluent. 
(c)  The sampling port and grease trap shall be accessible to the regulatory authority by the owner/operator. Each generator is subject to random sampling and grease trap inspection. Generators will be subject to fines and penalties if samples and/or inspections exceed allowable limits. 
(d)  A generator may be required to provide samples of the grease trap at random intervals as determined by the regulatory authority. Samples shall be analyzed at an accredited lab and all samples required will be at the expense of the facility being sampled. Records shall be made available to the regulatory authority for inspections during normal business hours. 
(e)  A generator will have grease trap cleaned and serviced as frequently as necessary to prevent bypass or overflow and to insure proper operation of the trap. Such generators, at a minimum, shall have the grease trap serviced once every ninety (90) days. 
(f)  No generator shall allow a transporter to remove waste from a site under the person's control unless the transporter's vehicle displays current and valid registration decals. 
(g)  A generator shall supervise the servicing of their grease or grit traps and shall ensure they are completely emptied by the transporter during such servicing. The transporter shall not return any material to the grease or grit trap once the trap has been cleaned. 
(h)  A generator shall cleanup or cause to be cleaned up all spills of liquid or solid waste and shall have the waste properly disposed of by the transporter. 
(i)  A manifest shall be generated every time the grease or grit trap is pumped or cleaned. The generator shall sign a copy of the manifest as well as the liquid waste transporter. It shall be the responsibility of the generator to insure they receive a copy of the manifest from the liquid waste transporter after the grease or grit trap has been cleaned and that they receive a final copy of the manifest after the waste has been disposed of at the final disposal site and the disposal facility has signed the manifest. The generator shall post the most recent manifest/trip ticket next to the food establishment permit. 
(j)  It shall be unlawful for any establishment to install and/or operate a grease trap within the city limits of the City of Pasadena without first obtaining a permit for installation from the approving authority. 
(k)  Grease trap self-cleaning generators must receive approval from the regulatory authority annually prior to removing grease from their own grease trap(s) located inside a building, provided: 
(1)  The grease trap is no more than fifty (50) gallons in liquid/operating capacity. 
(2)  Proper on-site material disposal methods are implemented (e.g. absorb liquids into solid form and dispose into trash). 
(3)  The local solid waste authority allows such practices. 
(4)  Grease trap waste is placed in a leak proof, sealable container(s) located on the premises and in an area for the transporter to pump-out. 
(5)  Detailed records on these activities are maintained. 
(l)  Grease trap self-cleaning operators must submit a completed self-cleaning request to the regulatory authority for approval. The written request shall include the following information: 
(1)  Business name and street address. 
(2)  Grease trap/interceptor operator name, title, and phone number. 
(3)  Description of maintenance frequency, method of disposal, method of cleaning and size (in gallons) of the grease trap/interceptor. 
(4)  Signed statement that the operator will maintain records of waste disposal and produce them for compliance inspections. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Sec. 37-254. - Penalties. 
Any violation of the chapter is a class "C" misdemeanor and will result in a fine, upon conviction, of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day a violation under this chapter exists will be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 2-27-07)  
Chapter 38 - WATERWAYS AND WATERCRAFTS 
 
Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
Definitions used in establishing water safety rules and regulations shall be in accordance with the accepted meaning as used in context with the pertinent subject or as further defined in other ordinances passed by city council. For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
Boat means any vessel or watercraft, other than a seaplane on water, used or capable of being used for recreation or transportation on water. 
Motorboat means any boat propelled or designed to be propelled by a motor, the same being defined as a self-contained internal combustion propulsion system, excluding fuel supply whether or not permanently or temporarily affixed. 
Operate means to navigate or otherwise use a motorboat or a boat on water. 
Owner means the person who rightfully claims lawful possession of a boat by virtue of legal title or an equitable interest. 
Person means individual, partnership, firm, corporation, association, or other entity. 
Personal watercraft means a specific category of motorboat, less than ten (10) feet in length, designed to be operated by a person or persons kneeling, sitting, standing on or straddling the boat or vessel rather than in the conventional manner of sitting or standing inside the vessel. 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91)  
Sec. 38-2. - Applicability. 
These rules and regulations shall be applicable to, and enforceable on, all public waters within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91)  
Sec. 38-3. - Restrictions on boating operations on public waters. 
(a)  Armand Bayou (also previously known as Middle Bayou) from its confluence with Lake Pasadena (also previously known as Mud Lake and/or Forest Lake), and its tributaries within the city, including but not limited to Horsepen Bayou, Big Island Slough, and Spring Gully: 
(1)  These water courses shall be designated as no-wake and safety zones. 
(2)  The use and operation of any category of motorboat, including any personal watercraft on these waterways, shall be expressly prohibited. 
(3)  Only boats being propelled by an electrical trawling motor or such category of boats or vessels as canoes, kayaks, and rowboats shall be permitted on these water courses. 
(4)  However, all governmental agencies and Armand Bayou Nature Center staff that are directly involved in the maintenance, rehabilitation of habitat, preservation of wildlife and the law enforcement of the aforementioned environmental tasks will be allowed to use motorboats (propelled by internal combustion engines), but shall do so with the utmost care and responsibility using well-maintained and monitored motors. Every effort shall be made to minimize any introduction of petrochemicals or other harmful substances into the waterway. 
(5)  Swimming and paddle boards are prohibited at any location designated by signage. 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 97-220, § 1, 12-2-97; Ord. No. 15-163, § 1, 12-1-15)  
Sec. 38-4. - Speed. 
(a)  No person may operate any boat or motorboat on the public waters of the city at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the conditions and hazards, actual and potential, then existing, including weather and density of traffic, or greater than will permit him, in the exercise of reasonable care, to bring the boat to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motorboat on the public waters of the city at a speed greater than five (5) miles per hour. City waters are designated a "Slow, No Wake Zone." 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91; Ord. No. 15-163, § 2, 12-1-15)  
Sec. 38-5. - Alcoholic beverages and controlled substances. 
No person shall sell, possess or consume any alcoholic beverage or any controlled substances on public waters within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91)  
Sec. 38-6. - Rules concerning special events. 
The city council may authorize the holding of regattas, boat races, tournaments and exhibitions. Whenever a regatta, boat race, tournament or exhibition is proposed to be held, the person in charge shall, at least thirty (30) days prior to such event, file a written application with the city secretary for permission to hold such a regatta, boat race, tournament or exhibition. The application shall set forth the date, time, and location where it proposes to hold the regatta, boat race, tournament or exhibition, and it shall not be conducted without the explicit authorization of the city council. The city may recover actual expenses incurred in connection with special events, such as administrative fees, personnel costs, and services rendered. A deposit may be required with the application or the city may invoice the applicant for expenses incurred by city. Nothing in these rules and regulations shall be construed to apply to the operator of a boat or vessel, motorboat, or any type of personal watercraft when competing in a race, regatta, tournament or exhibition duly authorized by city council. Compliance with this section does not exempt persons from operating in compliance with United States Coast Guard Rules and Regulations. 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91)  
Sec. 38-7. - Rules of the road. 
The United States Coast Guard Inland Rules apply to all public water of the corporate limits of the city to the extent they are applicable. 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91)  
Sec. 38-8. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who violates the rules and regulations created and established herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 91-205, § 1, 10-29-91)  
APPENDIX A - BASIC SUBDIVISION ORDINANCE[1] 
ORDINANCE NO. 67-1966 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE PROVISIONS OF CHAPTER 231, ACTS OF THE 40TH LEGISLATURE REGULAR SESSION, 1927 AS HERETOFORE OR HEREAFTER AMENDED (COMPILED AS ARTICLE 974a V.T.C.S.) AND THE PROVISIONS OF SECTION 4 OF THE MUNICIPAL ANNEXATION ACT AS HERETOFORE OR HEREINAFTER AMENDED (COMPILED AS ARTICLE 970a V.T.C.S.) DECLARING THE POLICY AND THE RULES AND REGULATIONS GOVERNING THE PLATTING AND SUBDIVISION OF LAND IN AND ADJACENT TO THE CITY OF PASADENA, TEXAS. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF PASADENA, TEXAS: 
Footnotes:

Editor's note— Ordinance No. 67-1966 is set out herein as adopted on July 5, 1967. The original arrangement, including article and section numbers and headings, has been retained. Amendments have been worked into their proper places and are indicated by history notes appearing at the end of the amended section or subsection. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is derived, unamended, from Ordinance No. 67-1966.
